file: RIO - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 5August2010 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Aug-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Third quarter iron ore prices from the 1st of July are based upon the average index price from  March to May of 2010. Pilbara production was steady, running close to its nameplate capacity of  220 million tons per year throughout the year. Mesa A produced its first ore for the first quarter and  is now ramping up to a full capacity of 25 million tons per year. In July we commenced production  of the Brockman 4 and at the Western Turner Syncline extensions of Tom Price.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Our incremental capacity increases of five million tons per year by the first quarter 2011 and an  additional five million tons by the second quarter of 2012 remains on track. And I want to  emphasize the quality of our tier one iron ore assets, such as continued growth options we have in  the Pilbara.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: We are moving forward with expansion of the Pilbara to annual capacity of 280 million tons by early  2014, and then 330 million tons we’d expect by about the first half of 2016. We have recently  approved one billion in total for dredging, marine works and some long lead-time items, and this  should allow us to start the construction of the 1.8-kilometer jetty that will work as part of the early  works on the expansion of the Cape Lambert facility, with the full project approval expected during  the course of our second half. We’ve restarted the expansion of the program at IOC, with the  approval of $401 million to increase annual concentrate capacity to 22 million tons per year, and  this is the first of three stages that could see annual concentrate capacity increasing to 26 million  tons.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Rio Tinto and Chalco are determined to advance the project rapidly and are working with all  stakeholders to expedite this process, which will be done in consultation with the Guinean  government. This current plan anticipates an annual capacity of 95 million tons per year using a  trans-Guinean dedicated rail line, and we would expect mining operations to begin within five years.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Turning now to aluminium. We saw a healthy improvement in pricing during the first half following a  robust recovery in demand and the continued rollover of inventory financing positions. Quoted  prices have dropped back recently, once again testing the profitability of smelters on the higher end  of the cost curve in a context of rising input prices.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: With curtailments already announced at key production bases such as Henan Province in China,  we would expect output levels to stabilize or maybe even fall slightly over the remainder of 2010.  During 2009 Jacynthe and her team led a transformation of the aluminium business that resulted in       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: For the first half of 2010 we saw the benefit of technological and transformational changes aided by  the improvement in aluminium prices, with more than a $1 billion increase in underlying earnings  half on half.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Our EBITDA breakeven level in the first half was $1,530 per ton. This was a sight increase on last  year’s number, mainly reflecting the higher Canadian and Australian currencies. At constant  exchange rates the breakeven level has been relatively consistent over the past 18 months, and  this has allowed us to capture virtually all the benefit from increases in aluminium prices, despite  some pressures that we have on aluminium-linked costs.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Our aluminium business continues to improve, but we do have some short-term challenges,  particularly in the second half of this year. Abnormally low snow and rain levels in the Saguenay  during the first half have led to a reduction in power generation, resulting in the need for purchase  of additional power from the state utility company. And the impact on EBITDA in the second half of  2010 is expected to be approximately $100 million as a consequence of these abnormally low rain  and snow falls.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: In July, the Laterriere smelter in Quebec suffered a significant power outage after two transformers  failed. The smelter’s currently running at half of its capacity of 235,000 tons, and we expect to be  back at full production in the fourth quarter of 2010.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: The second wave of transformation is now underway and further improvement in the performance  of the aluminium group is part of a longer-term program to increase the long-term EBITDA margin  to a level comparable with our other product groups. As part of our transformation of the smelter  portfolio, approval of Phase 1 of the AP50 pilot project and the upgrade of the Kitimat smelter in  British Columbia would be scheduled for 2011, and we’ll advance the preparation of the Kitimat  upgrade project by primarily closing two lines of production in the second half of this year. And this  closure represents about 67,000 tons of annualized capacity and is a progressive step in the  modernization that should transform Kitimat into a tier one, low-cost, large-scale and low-carbon  asset.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: At the ISAL smelter in Iceland we expect to move forward with an additional 44,000-ton-per-year  expansion and upgrade the second half of this year following implementation of a new long-term  power contract with the state-owned utility company in Iceland. And we are progressing with  improvement of our alumina portfolio via the optimization of Gove and the completion of the Yarwun  2 refinery.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: This Yarwun 2 expansion is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2012, and it will  significantly reduce the cost of alumina and bring down operating costs for the entire facility. I was  at Yarwun just a few weeks back, and some of you and I were here and were encouraged to see  the progress there with the commissioning of the cogeneration plant which is now underway. This  should result in the alumina portfolio moving down the cost curve from the third quartile to the  second quartile, and will be a key part of improving Rio Tinto Alcan’s EBITDA margins to levels  competitive with our other product groups.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Now let’s look to copper. Prices were stronger year on year but softened comparably compared to  the highs experienced at the end of 2009. We saw reduction in underlying earnings from lower  mine copper production as a result of lower grades at Grasberg and Kennecott Utah Copper.  Refined copper production was also impacted by the 19-day planned maintenance shutdown at the  KUC smelter. And higher production of refined gold and moly helped partly to offset this copper  shortfall.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: 5 Declining grades at maturing mines in addition to the difficulty of finding and bringing new copper  supply in the market is symptomatic of the continued supply challenges facing the industry.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: We have approved two growth projects in 2010: the moly autoclave project at Kennecott Utah  Copper, and the Eagle nickel mine in Michigan. Moly autoclave should improve moly recovery  rates, should enable the processing of lower grade and provide entry to the chemical-grade moly  markets, and is an important part of the ongoing plans to extend the mine life of Bingham Canyon.  Eagle is a small but high-quality asset which will provide an excellent reentry into the nickel project  market. It will be the only primary nickel mine in the U.S. and the first new nickel operation to be  built in Michigan after several decades. These have been under some of the most stringent  environmental permitting rules in the U.S. Eagle is small but very prospective. It’s in the middle of a  very prospective exploration region, and we’ve got a very significant land and mineral rights holding  in the surrounding district.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: During 2010 we’ve continued to increase our interest in Ivanhoe, bringing the current interest to  29.6%. We are committed to developing Oyu Tolgoi in a way that delivers sustainable economic  development to Mongolia and its people. Construction work has now commenced, and we expect  to see first production in 2013. Oyu Tolgoi is another example of tier one development assets and  part of our next generation of producing assets. As an iron ore and aluminium technology it will play  an important role in future copper developments. We are a key leader in this area. With our  partners we’re investigating new tunneling concepts that are more productive and more cost  efficient. We’re also developing new shaft boring machinery with the potential to dramatically  reduce the development time for underground mines, particularly underground future block cave  operations.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Moving onto energy, demand for seaborne thermal coal in the first half of 2010 was quite strong.  We do continue to see strong demand growth in China and India, and we’ve seen our traditional  Asian markets continue their recovery. Contracts for 2010 fiscal year were settled in the high 90s  per ton, an increase of 38% on the previous fiscal year. The majority of coking coal contracts for the  2010 fiscal year were settled for the first time on shorter-term pricing periods, and prices for the first  six months have varied by quarter and were settled in U.S. 187 to $225 per ton range, depending  on the quality of particular coal fractions.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Earnings in the energy group declined overall 15% due to, on average, a lower price effect, a  stronger Australian dollar and the inclement weather impacting thermal coal production in New  South Wales and uranium at ERA. The sale of two undeveloped coal properties partly mitigated  these factors.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Hard coking coal production was 30% higher in the first half of 2010 as a result of commissioning  new heavy mobile equipment at Hail Creek and good plant reliability and higher processing rates at  Kestrel. Australian coal thermal production was lower in the first half of 2010. Thermal coal was  impacted by periods, as I’ve said, of wet weather in New South Wales and some increased strip  ratios at our Hunter Valley operations and at Mount Thorley Warkworth.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: In Queensland, thermal coal was lower due to Blair Athol beginning to wind down, offset by the  ramp-up in Clermont, which commenced production in May. These lower volumes were offset by  improvement in sales mix of Rio Tinto Coal Australia, with sales of semi-soft coal increasing by  87%.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Infrastructure constraints are slowly easing in East Australia. Expansion by the Port Waratah Coal  Services to 133 million tons is expected to be complete by the end of 2011. However, the coal  chain will remain constrained, as rail capacity is expanding at a slower rate.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: 6 The implementation of a long-term framework for port access is continuing, and this framework will  give certainty to coal producers and service providers and is expected to align commercial  contracts with those service providers across the entire Hunter Valley coal chain.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Moving to TiO2, market conditions for titanium dioxide feedstocks did improve in the first half, with  increased global demand evident in line with the global economic recovery. And this was reflected  in higher production, which included the increased QMM ore from the Madagascar mine, which we  processed in Quebec.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Prices have strengthened, then deteriorated significantly, and then strengthened again. Higher non- traded commodity prices increased earnings by $1.9 billion. Prices for iron ore were settled at a  significant premium to the levels of 2009. Prices for thermal and coking coal were on average lower  than the first six months of 2009. However, the second quarter of 2010 prices reflected a significant       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: 7 step-up in coal prices from the first quarter of 2010. Following the evolution in the marketplace, the  majority of our iron ore and coking coal is now sold on shorter-term pricing periods. Higher traded  metal prices also increased earnings by $1.9 billion. The aluminium price was on average 50%  higher than the first half of 2009. This added $1.1 billion to our underlying earnings. Stronger  copper prices, net of the adverse effect from provisional pricing, added just over $600 million.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: In iron ore, market demand was strong following the lows experienced in the first half of 2009. The  Pilbara system continued to operate close to its nameplate capacity following the completion and  ramp-up of the 220-million-ton-per-annum expansion project. With the recent approval of $1 billion  of early funding for expansion of capacity to 330 million tons, we’re well positioned to take  advantage of the next phase of growth in the demand for iron ore.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Gold volumes were also higher, adding 75 million to underlying earnings. This was due to the  processing of high-grade raw material produced in late 2009 at Utah copper. The benefit from gold  volumes was partly offset by lower copper volumes of $48 million due to a lower share of copper  under the metal strip arrangement at Grasberg, as well as safety interventions and weather  interruptions at Escondida and lower copper grades at Utah Copper.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: A favorable sales mix occurred in the aluminium group as demand for value-added products  recovered. In the energy group, a greater proportion of higher-value semi-soft and hard coking coal  contributed to higher margins.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Turning now to costs, the combined effect of general price inflation and energy-linked costs  reduced underlying earnings by $238 million. The effect on earnings of cash costs has been  broadly flat year on year, following the significant reduction that we achieved last year.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Copper group costs increased following the planned shutdown of the Utah Copper smelter, which  led to higher contractor costs and the need to purchase some cathode. Lower grades led to unit  cost inefficiencies at Grasberg. In the aluminium group, lower costs added $110 million to  underlying earnings. Lower costs in coke and pitch prices, together with improved efficiency at the  alumina refineries, contributed to this improvement.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: We will not be complacent in ensuring that our costs remain well controlled. Spend on exploration  and evaluation projects was broadly flat year on year. We expect the rate of spend to increase  during the second half of the year as we progress our greenfield exploration program and ramp up  spend on our important evaluation projects, including resolution.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: We approved the expansion of iron ore production at IOC. The moly autoclave project in Utah. The  construction of the new Eagle nickel mine in Michigan. The announcement of the minerals resource  rent tax in early July largely removed the great uncertainty that existed in Australia for much of the  first half. This will allow us to get many of our Australian projects moving again.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: We have a strong pipeline of projects currently in the study phase and where we expect to make  decisions in the coming months. These include the full commitment to the expansion of the Pilbara  iron ore network to 330 million tons, the resumption of the Argyle project, the modernization of the  Kitimat aluminium smelter in British Columbia and the construction of the AP50 pilot plant.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: In aluminium we have a range of greenfield and brownfield growth options which are significant.  And many of these are expansions of our current operations and our current infrastructure. Our  greenfield smelter options are primarily positioned close to sources of power, clean power, a  competitive advantage in the future world of carbon pricing. We have one of the best portfolios of  undeveloped copper prospects and projects in the world, with an ownership interest in four of the  ten largest greenfield projects.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: We have growth options in India, in Australia, in Serbia, in Madagascar and in Namibia across the  diamonds, minerals and energy groups at various stages of evaluation. Our exploration programs  are active in seeking to identify future options for growth. Right now we have exploration teams on  the ground in over 25 different countries. I’m proud of our sustainable development practices that  we’ve been consistently applying as a key focus area through every stage of a project’s life.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: And our focus on sustainable development provides the framework for which we operate, ensuring  ongoing access to projects, people, capital and ultimately mineral resources. So far this year we’ve  approved over three billion of investment in growth projects. As Guy had mentioned, we expect this  rate of spend will increase over the coming months and predict capital expenditure of up to 13  billion over the next 18 months. Projects approved so far this year include the moly autoclave in  Utah, the expansion of the iron ore production capacity in IOC, and the construction of an Eagle  nickel mine in Michigan, and our iron ore business in the Pilbara, where we approved one billion of  expenditures in preparation for the expansion of 330 million tons capacity. And I would expect  again this project to come before the board later this year for full approval.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Following the signing of our joint venture with Chalco last week we announced 170 million of further  investment in Simandou. Simandou will be the largest iron ore mine, integrated iron ore mine  infrastructure project ever developed in Africa.

texts.speaker: Jan du Plessis, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everyone, and good evening to those of you joining us from Australia, and also
texts.text: Rio Tinto’s experience and expertise in developing large-scale iron ore projects, together with  Chalco’s knowledge of the infrastructure development, will enable us to bring this complex project  on-stream.

file: RIO - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 4August2011 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Rio Tinto has produced another set of impressive results, reflecting favorable market conditions and strong  demand for our products, in particular from Asia. Our operations have performed well in the face of unusually  adverse weather conditions, and I must say that I continue to be impressed with the way that our people respond  to challenges such as these, leading to excellent operating results at all of our managed operations.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Turning now to our first half results. In 2011, we achieved record earnings, record EBITDA, and record operating  cash flow for the first half period. This was despite the exceptional adverse weather conditions that we  experienced. We are recovering well through these, although there are still some residual effects at some of our  operations, in particular in Queensland and the Northern Territory. We are making great progress in our industry- leading portfolio of growth leading projects and during the first half of the year, we increased the pace of spend at  these projects to expand iron ore production from the Pilbara to 283 million tonnes per year by the end of 2013.  We also announced the acceleration of our plans to expand this business further, to 333 million tonnes, and our  target has actually been brought forward by six months, to the first half of 2015. This is in stark contrast to  broader iron ore industry trends, which have seen many projects subject to significant delay.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Now, let's turn to the product groups, starting with iron ore. We benefited from relatively stable prices through the  first half, driven by robust demand from China, for this has more than offset the weak demand from Japan that we  saw after the devastating tsunami. On the supply side, weaker than expected seaborne supply was the result of  adverse weather in the Pilbara, lower than expected Brazilian exports, and Indian supply still constrained by  export bans. As I've said, our Pilbara operations were affect – heavily affected by the significant rains; we did  suffer widespread flooding, a related train derailment, and loss of about nine shipping days. All in all, these events  lead to a 5% decline in shipments during the first half compared to 2010.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Production did recover strongly in the second quarter, and was in fact the second highest quarter on record. And  this was a great result considering the adverse weather conditions. We successfully expanded our Pilbara capacity  to 225 million tonnes per year on time and on budget, and we remain on track for global production of 240 million  tonnes this year from our Australian and Canadian operations. Critical to the optimization of our supply chain and  the maximization delivery of iron ore to the seaborne market is the flexibility and efficiency derived from our  integrated systems.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Our Canadian expansions are also progressing to plan. At IOC, we expect annual capacity to be lifted by 4 million  tonnes early next year to 22 million tonnes, and we have a clear pathway to 26 million tonnes with the potential to  almost double this to 50 million tonnes.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In addition, we've had to contend with other external and abnormal factors, such as heavy rains in Australia,  which impacted our alumina refineries in Queensland in particular. Hydrology conditions in the Saguenay did,  though, return to normal in 2011, following the low snow and rain levels experienced in 2010. Operationally there  have been some improvements, notably at the Gove alumina refinery, where output was stable and we set a new  quarterly production record in the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The expansion of the Yarwun alumina refinery remains on track. Bauxite processing will start in the first half of  2012, leading to the first alumina production in mid-2012. This expansion will move our average position further  down the cost curve. However, like in iron ore, the U.S. dollar cost has impacted by the strengthening Australian  dollar. Our transformation of the aluminum business continues, with plans firmly in place to achieve an EBITDA  margin of 40% by 2014.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Strategic reviews are underway for Lynemouth smelter and power plant in the UK and at European specialty  alumina refineries. And more work is being undertaken across the Aluminum portfolio. At Kitimat, if the decision  is made to invest in the full modernization project at the end of this year, we would expect to have this project  completed by the end of 2014. And this is a key element to realizing our 40% margin objective.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Moving into copper. Stronger prices continue for copper and all the byproducts, driven by a steady increase in  demand coupled with a very small increase in world refined production. Market tightness has meant that any  news of labor disputes or weather disruptions reverberate through the stock price. And of course, one example is  guidance on our future copper production, and, as anticipated, we did see a dip in grades at the Kennecott Utah  Copper, Escondida and Grasberg operations.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: During the first half of this year and following the agreement reached with Ivanhoe in December 2010, Rio Tinto  put in place a management team to lead the development and operations at Oyu Tolgoi. I have been pleased with  the progress on the ground, with construction nearly a third complete as of 30th of June 2011. While development  continues to be on schedule, Oyu Tolgoi does require an agreed power solution to deliver first commercial  production in 2013.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Our other copper projects are making steady progress. At a recent Resolution project in Arizona, we recently  approved just over $100 million to deepen shaft number 9 to full depth and for engineering commitments on two  further shafts. Exploration of the resource continues, with encouraging drill results over the first half.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: At La Granja in Peru, we completed 50% of our 30 kilometer drilling program, with some promising high-grade  intersections identified. And at Kennecott Utah Copper, we recently approved $238 million to fund the feasibility  study and long lead time items for the extension of the Bingham Canyon Mine from 2020 to 2028. Approval has  been given for pre-feasibility funding to evaluate the additional potential for a small underground mine near the  Bingham Canyon, [ph] Colbinworth rid and Skarn. (16:28) This would operate in parallel with the open pit and  could be operating in about five years' time.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In Northparkes, we're evaluating a step change expansion which would increase production threefold. In addition,  next year we will try our new tunneling technology at Northparkes, which has the potential to more than double  the rate of conventional tunneling methods. Moving on to energy. Demand for both coking and thermo coal was  healthy in the first half of 2011, with growth from China and India offsetting reduced consumption by Japan  following the tsunami. Supply disruptions are playing their part in boosting prices, and our operations were no  exception. Our four Queensland coal mines experienced major production challenges during the first quarter,  leading to a declaration of force majeure at all sites. This has now been lifted and all operations are recovering  well, although production rates have not yet reached their full capacity.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: At Hunter Valley, mines were impacted to a lesser extent, but were also affected by rains in June. Expansions are  progressing, with additional port capacity now secured for the 8.5 million tonne per year Mount Pleasant thermal  coal project. And we would expect this to come up for full board approval toward the end of this year, with first  production in 2014.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Energy projects have also been affected by the strength of the Australian dollar and other inflationary effects,  Kestrel in particular. We have not yet approved any additional capital for Kestrel, but we are reviewing the budget  and schedule at this underground expansion following the extensive flooding in the first quarter and currency  movements.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Turning to uranium, ERA experienced some of the worst weather conditions in living memory, causing it to shut  down the processing plant from January to June. We intend to raise support of ERA's strategy and plans as  engaged a financial advisor, and is well developed to developing a long-term funding plan. Subject to the usual  internal approvals, Rio Tinto's committed to playing its role as part of that funding.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: An important highlight of this half was the transformation of our Energy group's growth portfolio through the  acquisition of Riversdale, giving us access to a number of Tier one coking coal projects in Mozambique. On  Monday, we completed the compulsory acquisition process and now own 100% of Riversdale. This was an  uncontested bid where there were two existing strategic shareholders, and many observers doubted our ability to  reach full ownership. This was a major achievement by the Rio team.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Eric Finlayson, who took over from me as Global Head of Exploration, has been appointed managing director of  Riversdale and is now based in Mozambique. He is well-placed to bring his expertise in resource optimization  development to our newly acquired coking coal resources, assuring that they deliver value to shareholders for  years to come. Eric and his team are reviewing the engineering and strategic planning options for this world-class  asset. Their near-term focus is to get the first phase of Benga project up and running.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: And at this stage, we'd expect first production at the end of the year, ramping up to full production for the phase  one of 1.6 million tonnes of coke per year – coking coal – and 800,000 tonnes per year of thermal coal by the end  of 2012. There are some further exciting growth options underway, including further expansion of Benga and the  development of a substantial Zambezi Resource from the Tete East project, both of these 100% owned by Rio  Tinto.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Now, let's take a look at our Diamonds and Minerals product groups. Demand for borates and titanium dioxide  feedstocks continued to strengthen in line with improving global economic conditions. Market conditions for  rough diamonds strengthened during first half of 2011, as demand from India and China continued to grow, with a  moderate recovery from the U.S. TiO2 prices have been receiving a lot of focus this year. For the time being, our  exposure to spot prices will be relatively limited. As our multi-year contracts mature over the next few years,  they'll be replaced by contracts with alternate pricing mechanisms which will provide increased exposure to the  current market pricing. At Argyle, production was impacted by significant rainfall that occurred in March and  April, which restricted access to the ore body due to flooding. Access has now been restored and the underground  development project is progressing.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Lower sales volumes reduced earnings by $444 million, following the extraordinary weather disruptions in the  first half. Iron ore operations were disrupted by several cyclones, widespread flooding and a subsequent train  derailment. Despite these challenges, we completed the expansion of our Pilbara system to a capacity of 225  million tonnes per year, and are looking forward to a strong second half.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: However, we did see some pressures on our operating costs, which I'd like to explain more thoroughly. As I just  mentioned, cash costs reduced underlying earnings by $1.2 billion in the first half. This increase was significantly  influenced by uncontrollable factors in the first half of 2011, including adverse weather and lower grades, higher  input prices for raw materials, and general inflation.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Bad weather in the first half, particularly at our Australian operations, impacted earnings by $245 million. This  was a consequence of higher unit operating costs from lower volumes and remediation costs to return operations  to normal operating levels. As Tom previously highlighted, our operations have largely recovered from these  severe weather conditions.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Markets for key raw materials to the mining and minerals industry have continued to tighten, as output and  investment has increased across the industry. Raw material prices have continued their upward trend. Some  products with structural supply side constraints, such as caustic, coke, pitch and explosives, have continued to  experience high prices during the first half of the year.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Tightening raw materials prices, increased labor costs, localized inflation in mining hot spots and commodity  price-related expenditure, including an increase in royalty rates; all these decreased earnings by $384 million.  Then, there were unit cost increases associated with non-weather related production declines, most notably from  previously foreshadowed lower grades in the Copper group. These decreased earnings by a further $67 million.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Wherever we operate, sustainable development underpins our approach to developing and operating our  businesses. The mining and natural resources sector occupies an increasingly strategic and exposed position in the  thinking of host governments. While these factors can lead to tensions, with effective management and proactive  leadership, we can develop this into a competitive advantage. In volatile markets, some companies may find it  difficult to finance projects. Considering the strength of our balance sheet, this environment may present  opportunities for us to gain access to new resources.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: This is well-demonstrated by the fact that China's Central and Western provinces continue to experience far lower  GDP per capita and metals intensity rates than their Eastern neighbors. I was recently in Chengdu, the capital of  Sichuan province, and witnessed the growth of the Western cities for myself. The activity in the ground and the  development plans demonstrate quite clearly the intent of the inner regions to grow rapidly. As urbanization rates  rise, we're also seeing increasingly metals-intensive construction in China, as buildings become higher and  regulations for construction more stringent.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Notwithstanding the short-term uncertainty and volatility in the markets, we continue to expect that, over the  next 15 to 20 years, consumption trends will lead to a doubling in demand for iron ore, for copper, for aluminum  and certainly for other commodities. On the supply side, volatility of the capital markets could reduce availability  of finance for some projects. New ore bodies are harder to find, are getting deeper and are more technically  challenged. Many are located in higher risk regions and often subject to longer stakeholder engagement processes.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: This is just one reason why the group's strategic commitment to sustainable development is a crucial factor  maintaining and extending our ability to do business. The combination of strong demand growth and industry  supply challenges gives us confidence that real long-term prices and margins for almost all the minerals and  metals will continue at elevated levels, albeit, of course, with heightened price volatility.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Looking further ahead, we have a world-class portfolio of high-quality tier one projects in advanced study. We  have tens of billions of dollars of this type, including the underground development at Oyu Tolgoi, the world's best  undeveloped greenfield copper deposit, and the largest high-grade undeveloped iron ore deposit at Simandou.  These projects have not yet been approved for full development, but most are expected to come before the board  over the next 12 months. Each of these projects is a natural fit with our strategy, and they are truly tier one assets.

file: RIO - Q2 2011 Earnings Call US 4August2011 1100 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Flipping onto slide number four, we produced a great result today, another record breaking set of numbers. These  were record earnings, record EBITDA, and we built more than $2 billion of cash flow amongst record cash flows.  Strong prices, of course, were the main driver, but our operations also performed well particularly in the face of  exceptional weather conditions that we saw all around the world, but particularly in Queensland and WA. We did  – we've continued to buy back shares over – since out original amounts in February that we would put that in  cash flows, our strong balance sheet, the continuation of growth program, it's allowed us to maintain the pace,  increase the program of the overall buyback program from $5 billion to $7 billion, an increase of $2 billion and we  expect to complete this by the end of the first quarter 2012. Of course, with the usual caveats of market conditions.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Our Pilbara operations were affected – heavily impacted particularly in the first quarter by significant rains. While  production did recover strongly in the second quarter and in fact was the second highest quarter on record. I think  this was a great result considering those adverse weather conditions. We did successfully expand our production  in Pilbara capacity to 225 million tons per year by March – end of March 2011, which is exactly when we said we  would have that done and we accelerated the planned expansion, the 332 million tons a year by six months in the  first half of 2015.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Moving to Canada, at IOC we are expecting capacity to be lifted by 4 million tons early next year to 23 million tons  and we have a clear pathway to 26 million tons and potentially almost double this to 50 million tons. Those of you  in Canada know that we had some challenging weather conditions particularly in the first part of the year and that  did impact production of IOC in the first quarter and again we saw that picking up by the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: And then finally for iron ore in Simandou activities on the ground continue to gear up following the signing of a  settlement agreement with government of Guinea earlier this year. We are now spending about $20 million a  month on the ground and this is going to be increasing nearly fivefold in the coming months. We are currently in  the process of ramping up quite a bit of activities on the ground.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Moving on to copper on slide number seven, underlying earnings increased and that reflects the higher price  driven by a steady increase in copper demand and that's all you know continued tightness in the supply side of  last year and those in particular the mature pits in [ph] mostly (0:06:27) coppers, these are pretty predictable in  cycle, up and downs, this was a cycle down for 2011 and we do expect a recovery in 2012 as those grades do pick  up again.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: And looking further ahead, we'll deliver new production, which will be timely into the tight markets from Oyu  Tolgoi project in Mongolia from about 2013. Construction is going well at OT with nearly a third complete as of  the June 30, 2011. And while development in OT continues to be on schedule, OT will require an agreed power  solution sale schedule to deliver first commercial production in 2013. We've approved further funds at resolution  United States. We completed the 50% of the 30 kilometer drilling program at La Granja in Peru. We are also  progressing brownfield options at KUC and Northparkes.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Turning to the energy group on slide eight, earnings were impacted by severe bad weather particularly at our  Queensland coal mines during the first quarter. Operations are recovering well although we are not yet at full  production rates. Hunter Valley mines were affected to a lesser extent although we did see some additional rain in  the second quarter particularly in June. Expansions are progressing with additional port capacity now secured for  the 8.5 million ton per year proposed Mount Pleasant thermal coal project.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Moving onto slide number nine, I would like to say a few things about Riversdale. An important highlight of this  half, was the transformation of our energy group growth portfolio through the acquisition of Riversdale given the  fact that the number of Tier I company coal development projects in Mozambique. On Monday we completed the  compulsory acquisition process and we now own 100% of Riversdale.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: As we move to the slide number 10, demand for borates and titanium dioxide feedstock continued to strengthen in  the line with improved global market conditions. Market conditions for rough diamonds also strengthened in the  first half of 2011, as demand from India and China continued to grow with a moderate recovery from the U.S.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: There's been quite a bit of focus on TiO2 prices over the course of this year, and of course you have seen quite a bit  of strength and I think recognition that there are some structural issues with TiO2 supply which will benefit the  producer. For the time being though our exposure to swap prices is really relatively limited as our multi-year  contracts mature over the course of the next couple of years, they are being replaced by contracts with alternative  pricing mechanism, which will provide increased exposure to current market pricing.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: I would like to now talk about prices and cost structures and move to slide number 11. It should come as no  surprise the primary driver of our performance has been price, partially offset by the impact of the currency  movements, notably the stronger Australian dollar. As previously highlighted, volumes were impacted by  extraordinary weather disruptions in the first half and lower copper and gold grades in the first half. The effect of  higher exploration and evaluation costs reflect the greater levels of investment in the forward look of the business  and what we would consider to be a good cost. The increase in cost was significantly influenced by uncontrollable  factors in the first half 2011 including adverse weather and lower grades, higher input prices and also the raw  materials and general inflation.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: And this is well demonstrated by the fact that China's Central and Western provinces continue to experience far  lower GDP per capita and metals intensity rates than their Eastern neighbors. I was in Central China just last  month and judging by the construction crane count, we were talking with mayors and senior – senior leaders,  certainly the expectation will be that, that cities like Chengdu and provinces like Sichuan will be growing at even  the higher levels of rate than you'd see overall within China and this will certainly have a positive effect on the  overall demand for our products.

file: RIO - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 8August2012 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Many of our high-quality projects are getting close to completion and will start to generate returns over the next  12 to 18 months. By the end of 2013 we'll have 50 million tonnes of new capacity at Pilbara, taking us to 283  million tonnes. The second phase taking us to 353 million tonnes by mid-2015 is also underway. Commercial  production for Oyu Tolgoi will start in the first half of 2013.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: These integrative and innovative technologies are delivering returns now and they'll allow us to transition to a  much higher capacity of business in the near future. Our underlying iron ore earnings were the second highest for  a first-half period. And this was achieved despite lower prices, as the market came off historic highs. Of course  even in these challenging markets, we realize an average price for a Pilbara Blend fines product of US$133 per  tonne. Our results were boosted by first half production, leading to increased sales volumes as we increased  annual capacity by 5 million tonnes to 230 million tonnes.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We are setting the stage for the whole of the sector with our focus on productivity improvement and cost  management to our Mine of the Future program. This is delivering real performance improvements on the ground  as we speak. But it's also setting us up for our planned growth in annual capacity of 353 million tonnes in 2015  and for further major debottlenecking gains beyond that level. So once again we've delivered an outstanding result  in iron ore. It is a good place to be.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: As expected our copper production was lower in the first six months of 2012. At Kennecott Utah Copper the  relocation of the in-pit conveyor at the mine and the 26-day smelter shut down were scheduled to coincide with  the period of lower grades. Both were successfully completed in the first half.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: At Escondida, copper grades began to improve with mine copper production 29% higher half-on-half. During the  period we approved projects that are Tier 1 brownfield assets to maintain production into the future. At Kennecott  Utah Copper we're extending the life of the mine by another 10 years to 2029. And at Escondida a new mill will  replace Los Colorados and allow access to higher grade ores.  In addition to brownfield volume growth we will see first commercial production coming from Oyu Tolgoi in the  first half of next year. After acquiring our majority stake in Turquoise Hill, we agreed to support the  comprehensive financing plan and nominate a new team of Rio Tinto management, led by Kay Priestly. After over  two years of construction I'm looking forward to seeing Oyu Tolgoi coming on-stream in the very near future.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Moving on to aluminum, our aluminum business is better positioned compared to its industry peers, but we have  experienced increasingly challenging market and operational conditions. I am confident that we are pursuing the  right course with our focus on EBITDA improvement, concentrating the portfolio on Tier 1 assets and completing  strategic investments in modernization projects. But we do need to do more and particularly to aggressively  achieve further cost reduction and EBITDA improvements. This will require us to take some tough decisions  across the global aluminum portfolio with these businesses that continue to lose cash in the current environment.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Global economic concerns continue to weigh on the LME price, with aluminum now trading about $1,820 per  tonne. At these prices, combined with continued elevated raw materials costs, approximately 25% of the smelting  capacity outside of China is in a loss-making position. Some smelter closures have been announced, but we've also  seen local governments, both in and outside of China, providing incentives to ensure loss-making smelters  continue to produce. This is preventing the rationalization of high-cost capacity that's required to balance the  industry. Given these circumstances we will continue our proved projects, including at Kitimat, AP 60 Phase 1 and  ISAL, but we'll be deferring further allocation of capital to aluminum smelting and refining projects for the  foreseeable future.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The net result of higher prices, higher raw material costs – or lower prices, higher raw material costs and  favorable currency movements was to reduce EBITDA by about $600 million compared to the first half of 2011.  EBITDA was further reduced by approximately $100 million as a result of the lockout at Alma. This was resolved  in July when employees ratified a new collective labor agreement. The new agreement will provide RTA with the  flexibility required to implement cost and productivity improvements into the future. The adverse impacts were  partly offset by further progress on business improvement initiatives and the recovery from abnormal flooding  that we saw in Queensland back in 2011.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Delivering on the business improvement initiatives outlined last year remains a top priority and we've now  achieved a run rate of $250 million of annual EBITDA improvement. However, in the current environment, we  are prioritizing our efforts and delivering further cost reductions. To the late, we have delivered improvements  from better terms on bulk site sales, reductions in corporate costs and capacity creep at the Canadian smelters. In  the second half, further cost savings will be delivered from reducing site and support costs, in addition to  productivity gains from the ramp up at Alma.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Another driver in the transformation of our aluminum business is delivering on strategic investments in the  highest-quality assets. During the first half, the expansion of Yarwun, the first of these projects was completed.  The expansion more than doubles capacity to 3.4 million tonnes of alumina per year and is expected to ramp up to  full capacity by the third quarter of 2013 and will deliver unit cost improvements, moving our alumina production  firmly into the second quartile of the cost curve.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Our Energy group has also seen a tough environment recently. Excess seaborne thermal coal supply has been  driven by growth from all the major producing regions as well as an increase in seaborne supply from the U.S. due  to low domestic gas prices. Thermal coal prices have now fallen to levels that are putting pressure on producers at  the top end of the cost curve. The current environment of excess supply, coupled with rising Australian costs, is  likely to be with us for some time. Despite these global changes in the Energy sector, we continue to see continued  growth in demand for seaborne thermal coal over the long term. As recent blackout events in India have

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The coking coal market has been affected by increased supply from Australian and other regions at a time of  weaker demand from the steel industry. We are under no illusion about the scale of these challenges and we'll take  strong action to return to acceptable levels of profitability. All of our Australian coal operations are actively  looking for ways to reduce costs through ongoing business improvement and asset management programs.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In Mozambique we achieved a key milestone with the first delivery of coking coal to an Indian customer. We do  expect Benga Mine to produce and rail more than 400,000 tonnes of coking coal this year. Meanwhile we're  continuing exploration activity with promising results. Early indications are that the exploration potential is far  higher than anticipated just a year ago and beyond that of coking coal. Significant additional tonnes may be  delivered, however, it is likely that it will take longer to develop this infrastructure than previously planned due to  the timing approvals and internal constraints on our capital. Discussions continue with the Mozambique  government on a range of future infrastructure solutions.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Turning now to diamonds and minerals, we'll see a portfolio shift to this product group over the coming years. In  particular our late-cycle TiO2 feedstock business is just starting to see the benefits of growth in demand from  China and other emerging markets. Earnings did more than double over the period as the group benefited from  higher prices across the minerals portfolio. In particular, we saw significant momentum for the prices achieved in  titanium dioxide feedstock, as long-term contracts continued to unwind.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Markets for both TiO2 and zircon did soften in the first half compared to late last year. And this is in line with the  current economic cycle, following inventory build by consumers and weaker demand growth this year. However,  we do remain positive on the mean-in-term outlook for TiO2 feedstocks and demand will strengthen in line  urbanization in the emerging markets.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We also enjoyed a healthy increase in TiO2 product with record half-year production at RTFT and year-on-year  growth at QMM in Madagascar, following successful implementation of dry mining and other improvement  initiatives. RTIT is the world's leading producer of TiO2 feedstock and has many options to enhance shareholder  value through expansion and investment.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We are excited to be doubling our stake in Richards Bay Minerals, which is expected to be complete in the second  half of this year. This is a significant Tier 1 asset and will give us increased exposure to the growing market, where  China now represents 30% of global TiO2 feedstock demand.  The outlook of the diamonds industry is attractive and strong demand growth in the world's emerging economics,  coupled with lack of new supply, means that it has some good prospects. However, given the relative scale of our  Diamond business within the broader Rio Tinto group and the capital intensive nature of the industry, we may be  able to create more value through a different ownership structure.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Lower sales volumes reduced earnings by $584 million, largely due to temporarily lower copper and gold grades at  Kennecott, as expected, and no metal share from Grasberg. This was partly mitigated by record iron ore and  higher coal volumes in line with recently completed thermal coal expansions and less severe weather conditions.  These boosted earnings by $366 million compared with the first half of 2011.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Industry-wide cost pressures continued in 2012, notably in some of the mining hot spots in which we operate. The  impacts of inflation and higher energy costs lowered our first half earnings by just over $170 million. Higher cash  costs reduced earnings by a further $388 million, of which the majority related to an increase in operational  readiness and site transition costs connected with the Pilbara expansions. I'll return to this in a moment, but  overall I would say that we've had a good cost performance during the first half.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In 2012, we've seen quite a significant increase in exploration and evaluation costs, notably at some of our more  advanced projects, including Simandou, Resolution, La Granja and Mozambique coal. Given progress made,  Simandou evaluation costs are now being capitalized from the 1 of April this year. These higher exploration and  evaluation costs are shown net of the gains on disposal of various exploration properties, notably our interest in  Kalahari Minerals and Extract Resources. Their total impact, together with other movements, including interest  and non-cash, was to lower earnings by just over $100 million. This brings us to our underlying earnings of $5.2  billion.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Now let me touch briefly on net earnings. The Australian government introduced the Minerals Resource Rent Tax  or MRRT on the 1 of July this year. We've recognized a deferred tax asset of just over $1 billion within net earnings  in relation to this. This is a non-cash accounting item. It reflects the deductibility for MRRT purposes of the  market value at the 1 of May, 2010, of our considerable past investment in our Australian iron ore and coal assets  to the extent recovery is considered probable. This is clearly a highly technical accounting area, but it has no  bearing on our underlying business performance, and so it's excluded from underlying earnings. So overall, net  earnings came in at $5.9 billion.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: While we would expect these costs to continue as we prepare for commissioning, they will be offset by higher sales  volumes and unit cost efficiencies through improved productivity in the future. We've also highlighted an increase  in stripping rates at Rio Tinto Coal Australia, which is a phenomenon that we would expect to reverse over the  shorter term. And we incurred some additional one-off costs, in particular the impact of the Alma lockout, which  we've shaded in this chart. Last year we suffered significantly higher costs from exceptional weather events. These  have had a lesser impact in the first half of 2012, creating a positive variance.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: For some time we've been taking a phased approach to many of our project approvals, such as our decision in  2009 to expand the Pilbara in two distinct stages. This phased approach allows us to commit capital in a risk- measured way, balancing our CapEx commitments with the market environment and other potential uses of cash.  In the Pilbara it has not only reduced risk, but has created embedded options. We've also enhanced the overall  value of the project by increasing its scope from 100 million tonnes to 133 million tonnes of annual capacity by  identifying and eliminating bottlenecks.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Our approach to investment will shortly be rewarded, as we bring these new projects on stream. Over the next 18  months we will see first production from Yarwun 2, Oyu Tolgoi and the first phase of the Pilbara expansion. And  any new project approvals will only get the green light should market conditions be favorable.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Alongside investment to create – to generate superior returns, we're also continually reviewing the portfolio to  ensure that it remains aligned with our strategy. We're, of course, aware that iron ore has come to dominate our  earnings in recent times. This reflects the superb quality and performance of that business.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Looking specifically at steel demand, the urban population will typically reside and work in high-rise buildings,  own at least one car, have a myriad of home appliances, including computers, et cetera, and depend on supporting  infrastructure such as metro, rail, elevated roads, bridges, power and water to sustain an urban lifestyle.  Construction will continue to drive steel demand in this decade before consumer demand begins to take over  beyond 2020.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Our top-down and bottoms-up analysis indicates that Chinese annual crude steel production will peak at around 1  billion tonnes toward 2030. And you can see from this chart that our projections are modest compared to some of  the most other reputable industry analyses.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In addition, and as we've been saying for some time, resource nationalism is elevating risk and reducing available  capital, leading to reduced supply. A range of emerging stakeholder issues is also leading to greater pressure on  permit approval processes. The cumulative effect of all these factors will continue to lead to less supply coming to  market than envisioned just several years ago. And this is not just a feature of the iron ore industry. It's also  affecting copper, coking coal and a number of other key commodities.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Our track record of delivering iron ore expansion projects in Western Australia on time and on budget is  unrivaled, as demonstrated by this third party study. Our Pilbara expansion project will be amongst the first to  market, taking advantage of conditions created by other project delays. I am confident that this is the best iron ore  project in the sector today and will generate high returns for shareholders under any probable macroeconomic  condition.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We are making great progress with the expansion of our Pilbara annual capacity to 283 million tonnes, due to  come on stream the second half of next year. And in June we approved the next stage of phased growth from our  global iron ore business. Approval has included the port and rail elements of the 353 million tonne per year  capacity project and funding for other detailed studies, early works and long lead items, for a continued  development of the Simandou project in Guinea with our partners, the IOC, Chalco and the government of  Guinea.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Not only are we delivering projects on time and on budget, but we can hold our product quality for the longest  single traded iron ore product, our Pilbara Blend fines for the next 30 years. And this is an unrivaled position in  the sector.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Our product portfolio will also be enhanced with high grade and high quality Simandou iron ore in 2015, as  construction in that project continues. While we have options for further expansion of the Pilbara beyond 353  million tonnes, as I've said before, it's unlikely – it's likely at that time we will pause for breath. And our intention  is that we will redirect our engineers toward debottlenecking, with a plan to have a larger stated capacity than the  current name plate objective of 353 million tonnes at that time. These efforts will be focused on a combination of  normal business improvement plans and taking full advantage of the integration on automation of the Pilbara,  through our Mine of the Future program. We'll cover this in more detail later in the year.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: These next few slides show pictures of the progress we're making with our Pilbara growth programs. At the port  we've now completed, ahead of schedule, dredging for not only the 283 million tonne expansion project, but also  that required for the ramp up of production, 353 million tonnes. We're also on schedule with the sinking of pylons  for the phase A wharf and jetty, which is now almost 85% complete. And you'll see in the quarterly production, it's  progressively ramping up new mine capacity at some of our existing mines in anticipation of this infrastructure  expansion.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Moving to the rail system, we are in the process of fitting out all ore cars, Electrically Controlled Pneumatic  brakes. This will improve braking efficiencies and reduce the risk of breakaways and derailment, and work  progresses on fitting out the same technology on our locomotives to further increase speed at which our trains can  safely travel. Overall, the 283 million tonne expansion program is now about 55% complete and on schedule for  the ramp up to commence at the second half of next year.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: As you know, we are ahead of the industry in developing and using innovative technologies. As I've said, we're  already seeing the benefits of the Mine of the Future program in the Pilbara. Integrating these technologies at the  Pilbara iron ore operations is helping us hold the line on costs. Automation in the operations center are bringing  greater efficiencies and in the near term, there will be more benefits from further debottlenecking in the Pilbara  supply chain.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The Mine of the Future is much more than just automation. It's things like faster underground tunneling, better  mineral recovery and an airborne gravity gradiometer that will help us find future Tier 1 ore bodies, all of which  we're starting to trial.

file: RIO - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 8August2013 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In aluminium, we've been focused on improvements for quite some time, as you know. We have simplified and  improved the portfolio by divesting or curtailing of 15 assets; 15 over the past five years. It's now clear we can't sell  Pacific Aluminium for value in the current market, so therefore we're bringing these assets back into our  aluminium product group.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We do have a way to go to improving the performance in the aluminium business and its returns. Let me be clear,  there is no straightforward easy solution here, but we are making progress in aluminium, including continuing  success in reducing our cost base where we've achieved a cost improvement of around $200 million so far this  year.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: And finally, we're delivering results by completing our major projects and divesting of non-core assets. So far this  year, we started the commissioning of four major projects, including the open pit mine and concentrator at Oyu  Tolgoi. And we're about to commission a major expansion of our Pilbara iron ore business to 290 million tonnes a  year of annual capacity. These are significant milestones.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Turning to prices, so far this year, the iron ore spot price has ranged between $110 and $160 per tonne delivered  to China. On average, our achieved prices were $137  a tonne in the first half, $5 lower than the same period last  year.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Coking coal prices have weakened substantially due to strong supply growth from major seaborne producers and  ongoing weakness in import demand. And the copper market has been in modest surplus resulting in a 7 % price  decline. Overall, lower average prices led to a $1.3 billion drop in underlying earnings compared with 2012.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Let me make just a few comments of that some of the good efforts starting with our aluminium division. A major  cost driver for this business is raw materials where we've achieved cost reductions well-ahead of market prices by  renegotiating pricing mechanisms, securing new sources of supply, and standardizing our product qualities. This  has led the cost savings of $37  million across our raw material spend in the first half compared to last year.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Another example comes from our energy group, where we're targeting a reduction of over 60% in the number of  contract to companies we engage, in addition to negotiating reduced rates in order to drive the material reduction  in contract to spend levels. This is forecast to deliver over $100 million of cost savings for the full year of 2013.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We've also seen a number of adverse influences on our costs. The major flood in the Gladstone area in  Queensland, Australia has severely disrupted operations at QAL and Y arwun, and we continue to incur additional  operation readiness and ramp up costs in the Pilbara as part of our growth plans. Despite these headwinds, we  have delivered solid operating cost reductions of $97 7  million.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Over the past decade, our geologists have discovered nine Tier 1 resources, which is an excellent achievement. Our  investment in exploration will ensure that we continue to have an industry -leading pipeline of Tier 1 growth  options that we may choose to develop over the years to come.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The slide was a defining moment in 110-year history of the Bingham Canyon mine and the employees of Kennecott  have rallied as part of the recovery efforts. We're delivering approximately 100,000 tonnes of ore per day to the  concentrator from the pit. And this is being supplemented by ore from a lower grade stockpiles. Concentrator  throughput has recently been close to full capacity which is a solid achievement after such a significant event.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Cleanup of the slide has begun. A major piece of work here is to reestablish a heavy equipment access road which  we expect to have completed by the first quarter of 2014. This will enable additional ore production along with the  remediation and waste removal. There does remain a significant amount of slide material to move which we  expect to continue until the end of 2015.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Replacement equipment importantly is already operating and four of the 13 damaged ore trucks have been  recovered and they're back in service. As you'd expect, our operating cost will also be affected in the second half of  2013 driven by recovery costs, the purchase of concentrate to meet customer commitments.
