texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: However, the team continues to pull cost out of the business and align to the changed environment including the  removal of a number of wells. The business interruption and equipment loss insurance process is also underway.  Near and medium term production is being limited by being able to physically access the ore. In 2013, we expect  to produce around 150,000 tonnes of copper with further improvements as per the slide in 2014 and 2015.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: At Oyu Tolgoi, we've reached a major milestone in July making the first delivery o f concentrate to our customers.  Their completion of this $6 billion greenfield project, the largest ever private investment in Mongolia, is a truly  remarkable feat. And thousands of people who've contributed to our success here should all be proud of what's  been achieved.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Now, back to Australia and our Pilbara iron ore expansion program. We're making great progress towards the  commissioning of the next stage of growth, which will see us add 53 million tonnes to reach 290 million tonnes a  year of annual capacity. We remain on track to deliver first ore from the expansion in September, in line with the  accelerated schedule that we announced in February.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In April, we achieved a key milestone with the delivery of the shiploader, which is now installed at Cape Lambert.  All of the coastal infrastructure for 290 is now in place, and the first train was unloaded by the new Car Dumper  on the 20th of July. Also between July and October of this year, four new trains will be delivered which will help  us to steadily ramp up shipments over the next 12 months. This highly valuable project will deliver excellent  returns for years to come.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The Phase 2 expansion of the port, rail and power infrastructure to 360 million tonnes a year as you know was  approved in June last year. And as I previously mentioned, there are multiple pathways for bringing on new mine  capacity. We could choose to develop new mines to ramp up quickly and deliver tonnes or we could fill some  capacity with incremental tonnes from existing mines at lower capital intensity before we bring the new mi nes on.  But I can assure you that we'll always be focused on getting the most out of our existing and newly expanded  business. And we've already demonstrated our ability to grow our production through low cost incremental  productivity improvements.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Our Pilbara expansion project, as you know, has grown from 320 million to 360 million tonnes a year as we've  progressively found debottlenecking opportunities. So we have options to grow from 290 million to 360 million  tonnes with flexibility around the timescale and capital intensity. The decision on which path we'll actually choose  will be made, as we've previously said, at the end of the year.

file: RIO - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 7August2014 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Shannon
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: So, if I could just start off by asking you all, as always, to turn off your mobile phones, please, or turn them to  silent. There is no planned trial of the fire alarm today. So if you do hear a fire alarm, it is a real event. In those  circumstances, you should go out of the same doors that you came in through. Immediately after that, there is an  entrance to a fireproof stairwell.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: So, let me turn to some of the highlights in our half year performance. Our underlying earnings were $5.1 billion,  up 21% over the same period last year. We have achieved $3.2 billion of sustainable cost reductions, exceeding the  $3 billion target that we had set and achieving this six months ahead of schedule.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Copper earnings were up by over 70%. A strong operational performance saw mine copper production increase by  23%, following the recovery in grades at Kennecott Utah Copper and the continuing ramp up of shipments at Oyu  Tolgoi.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In Energy, thermal coal prices declined at the lowest level since October 2009 during the first half. However, the  exceptional work of the team to reduce costs and increase productivity at our thermal coal operations has helped  to mitigate this impact. In Diamonds & Minerals, underlying earnings were down, reflecting lower prices for  zircon, titanium dioxide, feedstocks, borates and metallics. We continue to reshape these businesses to ensure that  they're matching production to demand. We're minimizing cost and are well-positioned to take advantage of  future price increases.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: One of the key headwinds we've faced this year is lower iron ore prices with a spot price averaging 20% less than  in 2013. But the quality of our business, together with our marketing leadership is ensuring that we continue to  deliver significant value. Demand for iron ore remains strong, but steel production in China are expected to grow  by 3% to 4% year-on-year in 2014. Most of this increase has been driven by domestic consumption. We're seeing  growth in steel consuming sectors like infrastructure, machinery and transport, offsetting weaker activity in  residential construction.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: As anticipated, this has been a period of growth in seaborne supply of iron ore and a commensurate exit of high  cost supply with around 125 million tonnes of capacity expected to leave the market this year in response to lower  prices.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We've already seen significant curtailments of iron ore supply from the Chinese domestic sector, as well as  reductions from non-traditional suppliers such as Indonesia and Iran. We are better placed to thrive in this  environment than any other iron ore producer, given our industry-leading cost of production, the quality of our  Pilbara Blend products and our strong marketing capabilities.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Pilbara Blend products, introduced by Rio Tinto in 2007, are the base feed and largest consumed product by  Chinese steel mills. Pilbara Blend sets the industry standards, so to speak. While much of the industry growth in  seaborne supply over the past six months has been lower quality material, leading to increased discounting by  some producers, the focus of our expansions has been on our Pilbara Blend products. These now represent  approximately 70% of our current Pilbara portfolio. We continue to experience high levels of demand for these  products across varying market conditions.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: As an example, you can see from the chart that Pilbara Blend fines spot sales achieve on average a premium above  the Platt's 62% iron ore index. Over the whole of our Pilbara sales portfolio, we achieved an average realized FOB  price of $99 per wet metric tonne in the first half. Furthermore, the relative value of our non-Pilbara Blend  products has remained consistent in the first half of 2014 compared to prior years.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Turning from revenue to cost, we've beaten our cost reduction targets, with $3.2 billion of sustainable operating  cash cost improvements. This is a great result, six months early and reflecting the determined efforts of our  employees across the business. And based on our planning for the rest of this year and next year, we're expecting a  further $1 billion of sustainable cash cost improvement by the end of 2015.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: What's truly impressive about our cost reductions is that our assets already had well-positioned cost structures.  Almost half of our revenue is generated by businesses with EBITDA margins in excess of 60%. And those assets  that are not currently generating such high margins are, in general, low cost producers in their respective industry  sectors, poised to benefit from price recoveries. For example, our Aluminium business realized on average an  EBITDA margin of around 20% in the first half. But these assets are low cost and any price improvement will flow  through to the bottom line. In fact, a 10% change in the LME price for aluminium leads to a $444 million earnings  impact. We're now starting to see some improvement in the aluminium prices as a modest supply deficit opens up  outside of China.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We're confident that these levels of CapEx will provide future options for long-term sustainable growth, whilst at  the same time maintaining the strength of our balance sheet and the conservative price assumptions. We expect to  achieve significant volume growth of more than 8% a year on a copper equivalent basis from 2012 to 2015.  Increased volumes are coming on-stream in iron ore, copper, coking coal and diamonds.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Further ahead, we have a strong suite of potential future projects across the groups, including in bauxite with  South of Embley; in copper, with Oyu Tolgoi Stage 2; and in thermal coal with the Mount Pleasant Project.  However, these projects will compete with other uses for cash, and only the highest quality projects will attract  capital.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: And in the first half of this year, we reached our run rate capacity of 290 million tonnes a year, two months ahead  of schedule. And we're making great progress with a next-stage expansion of our infrastructure capacity, to 360  million tonnes a year. We've already completed the necessary rail duplication and track work, and we're on  schedule to complete the automation of our Pilbara rail operations. This technology will be in full operation in  2015 and will unlock further productivity gains.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The Copper group is focused on its 4 + 2 strategy with the immediate objective of improving the quality of its  earnings and its cash flows. And during the first half, the team continued to prioritize three key areas. Firstly,  enhancing productivity at all Copper operations; secondly, reducing costs; and thirdly, optimizing the portfolio  around four Tier 1 assets while building a pipeline of attractive growth projects.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Strong progress is being made in simplifying the Copper portfolio this year with the divestment of three non-core  assets announced. The Copper group is delivering strong operational and financial performance in the first half  with underlying earnings growing by over 70%, and this was achieved despite lower prices and was driven by  another exceptionally strong operating performance at Kennecott Utah Copper. At Kennecott, the team are  continuing to oversee the recovery of the mine from the pit wall slide last year and in doing so importantly they  have realized record productivity improvements and sustainable cost reductions.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We're continuing to focus the business on the highest quality assets. We're recording strong results in our cost  reduction program with over $800 million of savings from the Aluminium group. And overall we've increased  EBITDA from Aluminium by 26% to $1.1 billion in the first half.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: At Gove in the Northern Territory, we're well-advanced in the transition to our bauxite export business. This is  already operating and the export capacity is six million tonnes a year and will grow to around eight million tonnes  a year by the end of 2015. The expansion of Weipa through development of the South of Embley project is a truly  Tier 1 growth opportunity and is expected to deliver a very attractive return on investment. And the team is now  completing the study work with a focus of leading – or producing the lead time to bring this world project into  first production.

file: RIO - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 6August2015 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Chris will go through, in a moment, the results in detail, but let me first point out a few of the highlights. Today,  we're reporting underlying earnings of $2.9 billion. Our cost saving initiatives, along with positive currency  movements and lower energy costs, have offset almost 40% of the $3.6 billion of price decline.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Non-Executive Director
texts.text: There's a modest benefit from higher volumes, which we expect to continue in the second half of the year as we  ramp up our completed infrastructure project in the Pilbara, and increased output from the modernized and  expanded Kitimat smelter.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Non-Executive Director
texts.text: Underlying earnings were $2.9 billion for the first half. Net earnings were $806 million, $2.1 billion below  underlying due to impairments and non-cash exchange movements. This compare with $4.4 billion of net  earnings in the same period last year. Impairments of $421 million booked in the period related mainly to the  carrying value of Energy Resources of Australia. This was flagged on the 11th of June following a decision made by  the ERA board not to proceed with the final feasibility study of the Ranger 3 Deeps project.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Non-Executive Director
texts.text: Adverse prices impacted the underlying earnings of the Copper & Coal businesses, which you'll recall were  combined earlier this year. This combination has created additional opportunities to improve cost and  productivity, and the product group achieved total savings of $150 million in the first half. Underlying earnings  decreased to $393 million during this half. However, operating EBITDA margins rose to 36 %, which is an  impressive achievement in a declining price environment. Our Australian coal mines are amongst the lowest cost  in the industry and continue to generate positive cash flows.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Non-Executive Director
texts.text: We started this year with a cost saving target of $750 million. In the first half, we've achieved $641 million, $551  million of operating cash cost reductions and about $90 million from reduced exploration and evaluation, which  brings us to 85% of the full year target. We're now increasing our full year 2015 target to $1 billion. Our cost  reductions have been achieved across the business with Copper & Coal delivering about $1.9 billion and Iron Ore  and Aluminium each delivering around $1 billion since the program began in 2013.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Thanks, Chris. Over the course of the first half, we improved our safety as measured by all injury frequency rate.  However, tragically, we've had three fatalities. One at our operation at QMM in Madagascar, one at our Canadian  titanium dioxide business, and one at our coal operations in South Africa. My thoughts and prayers are with their  family and their friends.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: This half, our Iron Ore assets and the team running them have again demonstrated their exception al capability.  During the half, we've increased production in the Pilbara compared to the same time last year, despite late  cyclones which saw us lose 7 million tonnes in shipments. The operations benefited from the weaker Australian  dollar and lower energy costs, but also management delivered a significant cost savings of $244 million for the  half, taking their cumulative cost savings to almost $1 billion since the beginning of 2013.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: This business continues to deliver an FOB EBITDA margin in excess of 60% in the first half. It's a remarkable  outcome considering there's been a near 50% decline in the average index price. Even with the impediment of  weather that I've just talked about, our Pilbara assets still remain the lowest cost producer delivered into China  with C1 cash costs of $16.20 per tonne. However, at today's currency and energy prices, this is $15.20 a tonne. It's  a stunning achievement from Andrew Harding and his team, and there's more to come.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Operating and commercial excellence is a core skill for Rio Tinto and critical for success in this environment. So,  let's look at a few examples of this from across the group. Achieving maximum efficiency from our equipment and  infrastructure allows us to simplify our processes and lower unit costs, and this can be seen in reducing iron ore  rehandling in the Pilbara or redesigning our railcar unloading system at Kennecott to handle tolling.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As well as efficiency saving, we also look for ways to increase production through incremental improvements in  the way that we use our assets. And this allows us to get additional throughput without additional equipment. For  example, increasing the conveyor speed at Gove, our bauxite operation in Northern Territory, and fitting dovetails  to the trucks at Oyu Tolgoi in Mongolia, these have both contributed to improvements in utilization and  throughput.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Having achieved production at this cost, our aim is then to sell the product at the best price. Our Iron Ore sales  continue to achieve a price premium over the index, demonstrating the deep capability in our marketing team. In  Aluminium, our focus on value-added products has reduced the need for some of our customers to remelt  material. And this has delivered additional average product premiums of $259 a tonne.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In every area of our business, we look for continual improvement, greater efficiency, lower cost and higher prices.  I personally believe that there are always opportunities to improve a business. The group has a pipeline of  exceptional near-term projects. The 360 Mt/a infrastructure project in the Pilbara is largely complete, which will  enable us to deliver global sales in line with the guidance of 340 million tonnes of iron ore in the full year. We  optimized the value of our 360 Mt/a infrastructure. Our future Pilbara investment will be focused on maintaining  the quality of the Pilbara product.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In bauxite, we have the high-quality and large-scale resource at South of the Embley, where we anticipate  completing the feasibility study by the end of 2015.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our Aluminium product group, it is a truly world-class business. In May, we announced the signing of the  Underground Plan of Oyu Tolgoi. And we're now carrying out a refresh of the feasibility study, we're  finalizing the  project financing, as well as obtaining the necessary permits. Along with our increase in our share of copper metal  from Grasberg, we'll see a significant increase in future volumes of our Copper product group in the years to come.

file: RIO - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 3August2016 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: John Smelt
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Morning, everyone. My name is John Smelt, Head of Investor Relations at Rio Tinto. Thank you all very much and  welcome to our 2016 Interim Results. Couple of bits of housekeeping. First of all, in terms of fire alarms, there's  no practice alarm set for this morning. So if it does go off, it is a genuine alarm. It's voice activated. The fire exits  are either through that door and to the right or out through the back and to the left, very clearly marked, and there  will be wardens here. If you could at least turn your mobile phones on to mute. Off would be great. But if you can't  cope with that, mute would be good.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive-Copper Business
texts.text: The Energy & Mineral group under Alan Davies include some solid and well-established businesses, such as [ph]  borate (8:10) and some potential rising star. There are also challenged businesses in this portfolio, but Alan and  his team are focused on cash generation via cost and productivity improvement. The group has managed to  increase operating EBITDA margin to 23% against the backdrop of lower prices.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In February, we announced a cost reduction target of $2 billion for 2016 and 2017 combined. During the first half,  we've delivered more than half of this year's target, and costs have reduced by $580 million. This takes our total  cost reductions since we've launched this program, I guess, 2012 cost base, to almost $6.8 billion. And has  assisted us in delivering an EBITDA margin of 33%.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As always, it's important to note that this excludes the impact of exchange rates, in particular in Australia and  Canada, and changes in oil and energy costs. We've continued to make good progress due to the cost culture  that's now embedded throughout the organization. All of the product groups and central functions have  contributed to this success.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Late last year, the Aluminum group set out their target of $300 million for 2016. And during the first half, they've  actually reduced their cost by $223 million. Iron ore have delivered pre-tax operating cost savings of $138 million,  further reducing their operating unit cash cost to $14.30 a tonne. This is actually an increase, though, on the  second half of 2015, due largely to seasonally lower volumes and a stronger Australian dollar. The Energy &  Minerals group have contributed $152 million of operating cost reductions during the half, taking that group's total  to $1.2 billion since 2012.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As operating cost reductions are measured on a unit cash cost of production basis, the impact of lower volumes  from Escondida means that the contribution from the Copper & Diamonds group is minimal this half. We'll  continue to find opportunities and capture greater value in all of our businesses.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning to CapEx, we're maintaining our CapEx guidance through to 2018. We continue to find ways of achieving  the same outcome at lower cost. But spending is also reduced with the completion in 2015 of the iron ore  infrastructure expansion and the Kitimat project.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We expect our overall spend to be second-half weighted, with CapEx of just $1.3 billion this half. During the  period, we have progressed the Amrun bauxite project, which was approved in December of 2015, and so far  spent about $100 million on initial construction of accommodation, roads, and river terminals, yeah. It should be  noted that approximately 70% of the $1.9 billion approved for this project is expected to be spent in 2017 and  2018. In May, we approved the $5.3 billion underground project at Oyu Tolgoi in Mongolia. Activities have started,  with the EPCM contract awarded, and mobilization is in progress.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive-Copper Business
texts.text: Let me give you some examples. Our Pilbara assets are not just low cost, they deliver a product of exceptional  quality. In Aluminum, our position in bauxite mining and aluminum smelter is sector-leading. Our smelters keep  improving their cost position, and their low carbon footprint makes our aluminum attractive to customers.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive-Copper Business
texts.text: In Copper, we have interest in three of the largest and highest quality copper deposits globally, Escondida,  Grasberg and Oyu Tolgoi. The Energy & Minerals group has a world-class thermal coal asset and a significant  TiO2 business. This group can act as an incubator for smaller businesses and new commodities.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive-Copper Business
texts.text: The third P is really about building distinctive capabilities to enable a step-up in our delivery. And at the core of it  are people. Excellent commercial capability is key to quality returns. Let me give you some examples. In iron ore,  we have a strong track record of achieving a premium on our Pilbara blend spot sales. During the first half of this  year, this translated into a $0.80 per tonne premium over the average Platts price for the period. In Aluminum,  more than 50% of our products are value-added, allowing us to charge an additional premium. In Copper, we  have taken advantage of the underutilization of the Kennecott smelter and processed over 600,000 tonnes of  third-party concentrate since 2014, generating a margin on every tonne.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive-Copper Business
texts.text: In thermal coal, we have increased the premia achievable to benchmark following the development of the  [indiscernible] (25:23). Clearly, there are real benefits derived from spreading marketing and commercial best  practices for the group, and our people are key to delivering both commercial and operational excellence.

file: RIO - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 2August2017 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We delivered our $2 billion cash cost saving program six months early, and momentum is building on our  productivity drive. We already had the strongest balance sheet in the sector. At the end of June, our net debt was  $7.6 billion. We continue to strengthen our portfolio of assets. As you know, we announced the sale of our thermal  coal business in Australia for $2.7 billion which is expected to complete this quarter.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We realized a strong first half iron ore price of $67.80 a tonne, 40% higher than the same period last year  reflecting the well-placed product portfolio. Copper prices increased 23% compared to the first half of last year  reflecting strong demand from China and some supply disruptions during the period. However, this was partially  offset by continued supply additions from Peru and increased scrap volumes.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Aluminum prices improved compared to the first half of 2016 with an increase of 22% reflecting strong demand.  We believe this also has been driven by news flow around China's supply-side reforms that they've announced  earlier in the year, yet to take effect because their winter – their actually wintertime measures.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The coking coal price spiked as a result of weather disruptions in Australia and has now dropped back to prices  seen in the first quarter. This chart shows the striking recovery in prices from the first half of last year. As you can  see, inflation, energy cost and exchange rates have remained relatively stable. Volumes were generally lower  compared to the first half of 2016.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In the Pilbara, shipments were impacted by wet weather in the first quarter and accelerated rail upgrade in the  second. Hard coking coal also suffered from adverse weather in the first half following Cyclone Debbie in late  March, which impacted both rail and pit access at Hail Creek.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: These lower volumes were partly offset by record production in bauxite and increased production of TiO2. The  14.9 million tonnes of third party sales of bauxite were a first half record. On cost, we also delivered a further $300  million of cash cost savings, or $0.5 billion pre-tax.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In February 2016, we set a $2 billion cash cost reduction target for 2016 and 2017 combined. As I mentioned, we  have achieved $500 million in the first half, which together with last year's $1.6 billion means we've now achieved  our target some six months ahead of schedule.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: This takes our total reductions against the 2012 cost base to $8.2 billion. This excludes the impact of exchange  rates, inflation and changes in oil price and energy costs on the way through that. This is an ongoing journey and  we don't intend to stop.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In June, shareholders approved the disposal of our Australian thermal coal business to Yancoal for consideration  of $2.7 billion. This is a much improved offer compared to the one made in January including $500 million more  cash on completion. The transaction is expected to close this quarter.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Including Coal & Allied, we've now announced divestments of almost $8 billion in the last four years, but we still  retained flexibility in our portfolio. Some of our assets are smaller, but they're valuable and highly cash generative.  We'll continue to exit any assets or projects that don't fit our requirements and where we can realize attracted  value to shareholders.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Separately to AutoHaul, we've brought forward upgrades to the Pilbara railway network. This had another solid  impact on iron ore shipments in the second quarter. The CapEx for this work is already included within our CapEx  guidance. The upgrade work will continue during the year and ultimately along with AutoHaul create a far more  flexible system.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: So now, let me focus on the steel industry in China. It is today both healthy and profitable. Order books are full.  As a result, demand for high-grade iron ore has been strong and due to productivity should continue in the  foreseeable future. This creates opportunities for us, Rio Tinto. So, the outlook is stable but price volatility will  remain a feature of the market.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We have more than 800 trucks which we can use more effectively. We have around 50 processing plants, which  today are not fully loaded. We are investing to upgrade our railway infrastructure in the Pilbara. This will give us  greater flexibility to extract value from our iron ore asset base in WA, Western Australia. We will be generating an  additional $5 billion of free cash flow over the next five years and the run rate of $1.5 billion of free cash flow per  year by 2021.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Two weeks ago, Chris and I were at our $1.9 billion Amrun bauxite project in Queensland. Key construction  activities and fabrication of the process plant have started. And we are on schedule for first production in the first  half of 2019.

file: RIO - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 1August2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Turning to capital allocation. As I mentioned today, we announced a record interim dividend and a top-up to our  existing buyback programs. We also continue to improve our world-class portfolio, announcing divestments for a  total of $5 billion in the first half of this year. Overnight, we closed the sale of our remaining Queensland coal  assets for around $4 billion. The post-tax proceeds from our divestments will be returned to our shareholders. Our  strong balance sheet with a net debt of $5 billion positions us well for the future

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Thanks, J-S. These are another strong set of results. But let's have a look at the numbers in more detail, starting  with the commodities. In iron ore, benchmark 62% prices declined by 9% versus last year. This was driven by  slightly lower demand, stronger-than-usual first half seaborne supply, and some destocking of inventory at the  ports, mostly in the second quarter. However, lower iron ore prices were offset by higher prices across the rest of  the group.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Copper prices in the first half of 2018 were 20% higher than the first half of 2017, primarily as a result of strong  demand from both China and the rest of the world. China's environmental policies also curtailed the importation of  scrap, which created increased demand for concentrate and cathode. Copper prices sold off in the last month or  so as markets became concerned by the noise around potential trade wars.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: As I've just discussed, pricing has been broadly positive across the commodities with higher pricing in most of our  products, more than offsetting slightly lower iron ore prices. Overall, there was an improvement of $600 million  compared to the first half of last year.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Price improvements during the period could have been about $200 million higher for the group, but for the impact  of legacy alumina contracts. These contracts are for the supply of just over 2 million tonnes of alumina per year  and are linked to the primary metal LME price have ended into first half in 2003. We're likely to see the same  impact in the second half should prices stay high. The impact of unfavorable exchange rates, energy costs and  measured inflation, have had a combined negative $400 million impact in this period. This brings us to flexed  underlying EBITDA of $9.2 billion.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: During the period, we've seen input costs in both our Aluminum and TiO2 businesses, negatively impacted by  about $300 million. Other cash costs have had a negative impact of $200 million. This includes additional  exploration and evaluation activity, as well as spend in Information Systems & Technology, and further investment  to support the group's mine-to-market productivity program. These were partially offset by improvement in the iron  ore cost base, further enhancing our productivity gains.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We started to see cost increases in 2017, initially in the Aluminum group. As you can see here, the indexed price  of caustic, coke and pitch remain well above the first half of 2017. And as a bell-wether for input costs, average oil  prices rose approximately 28% to $68 a barrel during the first half. We'll continue to fight against rising inflation  across the business. And I'll now discuss how our productivity program has assisted in offsetting some of these  increases, and allowed us to keep our EBITDA margin broadly in line with the first half of 2017.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: For 2020, we're raising our guidance to around $6.5 billion. This $0.5 billion increase partly reflects the timing of  spending and additional capital required for some of the replacement production in the Pilbara and increased  CapEx expected in that year on the Oyu Tolgoi power station. In each of those years, the expectation is that  sustaining capital will be between $2 billion and $2.5 billion. In 2018 and 2019, we'll continue to spend CapEx at  Amrun. At OT, we're spending around $1 billion in each year to develop the underground mine, and from 2019,  we'll also start spending CapEx on the power station.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In the iron ore business, we'll need to spend around $3 billion on sustaining CapEx over the next three years.  We'll also spend about $2.7 billion on replacement mines over the same period. And starting in 2019, we expect  to see spend coming through for the Koodaideri Mine. The increase that we're seeing in the Pilbara replacement  mine spend is due to a combination of increased capital costs from revised scopes for some of the projects and  the fact we're bringing forward some of our 2021 spend into 2020. The feasibility study for Koodaideri is ongoing.  And yesterday, the board approved $150 million of early-works funding for this project. One of the advantages of  a strong balance sheet is the ability to invest in the business through the cycle and to drive future returns.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: During the first half, we've announced $5 billion of divestments from our coking coal assets in European  Aluminum smelters. We've now received $4.1 billion pre-tax proceeds from the disposal of our coking coal assets,  Hail Creek and Valeria, Kestrel and Winchester South. The bulk of this was actually received overnight, pretty  close timing.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In addition, China's policy changes have had a significant and enduring impact on several industries, including the  mining sector. Supply side reforms and pollution controls have resulted in capacity reductions, which are  unprecedented. This is particularly the case in steel making, the outcome of which is higher capacity utilization  and improved profitability.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The change in industry structure has also led to a shift in iron ore demand, which in turn has given rise to a  significant premium for higher quality product. And that is absolutely good news for Rio Tinto.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Resource nationalism is not the new feature of the mining industry. But there is no doubt that many stakeholders  want a greater share of the wealth created by minerals development. There is also an increasing emphasis on  how we operate and our impact on the world around us. This is why we believe our license to operate is a make  or break for the industry.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Yesterday, the board approved around $150 million, $146 million exactly, Chris, for early works and studies at the  Koodaideri mine. This will be our first fully-autonomous mine. We also have an extensive pipeline of additional  replacement and growth options in the Pilbara. Oyu Tolgoi and Resolution are two of the largest Copper projects  in the industry, long life, low cost and close to our customers in China and in the USA.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Our Canadian Aluminum smelters are in the first quartile. Long term, as demand grows, we will strengthen these  assets through continued productivity gains and potentially, brownfield expansions. These smelters are already  the greenest in the industry. And the new technology joint venture between Rio Tinto, Alcoa and Apple to create  carbon free smelting will mean an even more attractive product for consumers and the further reduction in  operating costs.

file: RIO - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 11February2010 1100 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Tom Albanese, Chief Executive  Thank you, operator, and good morning to everyone on the conference even though they are  probably sitting in snow or maybe at home waiting for the snow to melt. You should all have a slide  pack titled North American conference call available from our website.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Production has exceeded the employed capacity with Pilbara since the second quarter and we’re  now set  full year production and sales records despite severe weather and poor market conditions  at the start of the year. The Operations Centre in Perth continued to enhance performance as it  neared the final stages of construction and ramp up. We remain active across a range of sales  mechanisms with our Asian customers and in late 2009 we made the first delivery of iron ore to  India.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our iron ore business in the Pilbara is currently expanding beyond its 220 million tonne per year  capacity. This will be achieved by first injecting a new incremental capacity of 10 million tonnes per  year and then looking at further stage development to take us to 330 million tonnes per year by the  end of 2015.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Moving on to slide number nine. Earnings at the energy group were study with higher volumes  compensating for weaker prices. Demand for the Clermont thermal coal, particularly from China  increased in the second half and China also emerged as a significant met coal important in 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: U.S. coal earnings reflected higher prices in contracts and the impacts of divestments. At our  uranium businesses, ERA production was strong and continued to benefit from higher realized  prices as legacy contracts continued to expire. At Rossing, lower market prices resulted in lower  revenues.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: I would like to add, well on uranium, that my view uranium is an increasingly important part of our  energy portfolio as we move progressively toward a carbon-constrained world.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Lower energy cash costs from reduced spending on evaluation and exploration improved the  earnings further. At 6.3 billion, 2009 full year underlying earnings were 2.4 billion higher than 2.8  once adjusted for the effect of movements in traded and non-traded prices and exchange rates.  Our total cash costs declined by 5.6 billion between 2008 and 2009 as shown in slide 14. Setting  the under controllable costs aside and excluding the impact on costs of changes in production level  between the two years, we reduced our pre-tax cash operating costs by 2.6 billion. This exceeds  the target we set for ourselves one year early.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Energy will complete the Clermont and Grasberg projects, with first call from Clermont expected to  be shipped on time and on budget in the fist quarter of this year and at full capacity by 2013. And  we have had one of the best portfolios of undeveloped copper projects in the world highlighted by  our Oyu Tolgoi Investment. Construction planning is underway for the target of first production in  2013.

file: RIO - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 10February2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: While I’m on this slide, let me add a few words on the effects of recent severe weather conditions.  About 80 of our employees in Queensland saw their homes flooded and several of our office  locations in Brisbane were closed for a period of time. We’ve reacted rapidly. We established a  formal volunteer programme for employees to opt to help with their local communities. And we  continue to support the community and other efforts to recover from the damages caused by these  devastating floods.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: We’re seeing continued, very tough weather throughout Australia and we’re keeping a very close  eye on these weather patterns. And we’ll take the necessary actions and protect our employees,  their families and our assets.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: Our priority remains disciplined investment in value adding growth. And since the start of 2010,  we’ve announced another over $12 billion of major capital project approvals. Of this amount, $8  billion is being invested in our Pilbara iron ore businesses. Our project to increase iron ore volume  by over 50% by the end of 2015 is the lowest-risk, highest-return major iron ore project in Australia  today.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: And certainly we have a range of other value adding options for growth across the diverse portfolio,  including the modernization and expansion of our aluminum smelters in Canada. In December, we  reached a new agreement with Ivanhoe under which we now manage the Oyu Tolgoi project in  Mongolia and have an agreed pathway to increase our stake in Ivanhoe to 49%.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: At the end of last year, we also announced a recommended A$16 per share cash offer for  Riversdale Mining. And if successful, this acquisition would provide Rio Tinto with a coking coal  development pipeline in the emerging Moatize Basin in Mosambique, in line with our established  strategy.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: Demand from developing countries, particularly China, have exceeded expectations. Moving over  to the OECD countries, low interest rates and sovereign debt concerns have encouraged  investment in emerging nations and commodities. Moving to the supply side, weather disruptions  have caused some shortages and expectations for the supply side response in a number of  commodities have been downgraded as others’ expansion projects have proven to be more  difficult.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: At our Operations Centre in Perth, we’re using next-generation technologies to drive even greater  efficiencies across our network of 14 mines, 1,400 kilometers of track and three ports. We already  started to see the benefits from what I believe is a significant competitive advantage. Guy will cover  some of the costs off in more detail. But I was very pleased that we’re able to hold cost at close to  normal inflation in the Pilbara, which as most of you know is no mean feat in today’s heated  operating climate.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: In December, Rio Tinto and Sinosteel announced the extension of the historic Channar mining joint  venture in the Pilbara and this will lead to a further 50 million tonnes of iron ore being produced  from this operation.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: We have considerable reserves and resource position in Canada with possible expansions to  expand the capacity at IOC to 50 million tonnes per year. And it does make an interesting  comparison with recent Canadian transactions in the iron ore space, which should demonstrate the  significant value of our Canadian iron ore businesses.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: Of course, our largest and most valuable growth project is in the Pilbara, where we have plans to  increase capacity by over 50%. During 2010, we’ve approved $5.6 billion of capital expenditures  toward expanding our operations and infrastructure in the Pilbara to 283 million tonnes per year by  2013. We are advanced stages of feasibility study for the phase two expansion to 333 million  tonnes per year by 2015.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: 4 that’s new to Rio Tinto. We believe this is the lowest-risk, highest-return, major iron ore project in  Australia.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: Our aluminum business returned to profit in 2010 with a year-on-year improvement of over $1.3  billion. This was primarily driven by an improvement in pricing but and also noticeably higher value- added product sales. Cost pressures are returning to the industry, including the effect of strong  currencies and higher coke and caustic prices. We’ve had to contend with other external and  abnormal factors during the year, such as low rainfall in the Saguenay and heavy rains in Australia.  These have had the effect of pushing up our cost base during 2010, but our EBITDA breakeven  was still a credible $1,570 per tonne.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: The Yarwun alumina refinery is progressing well and the expected completion date has now been  accelerated to August 2012, three months ahead of the previous schedule. The co-generation plant  was commissioned in September and the shiploader in November of 2010. This project is a key  component of our drive to move our alumina refining capacity into the second quartile of the cost  curve.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: In the last half of 2010, we announced three major smelter modernization projects: firstly, $487  million to increase capacity of the ISAL smelter in Iceland by 40,000 tonnes and building a new  leading-edge casting facility, second, $758 million for the first phase of AP60 in Quebec, and finally,  a further $300 million toward the modernization of the Kitimat smelter in British Columbia. Final  approval for this $2.5 billion project is expected later this year.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: I firmly believe that our portfolio of mining, refining and smelting capacity will continue to move  down their respective cost curves and in time deliver returns that are commensurate with the  investments that we’ve put on the balance sheet.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: Moving into copper, prices have continued to be high as demand across the OECD and developing  markets increase. The sector has struggled to maintain supply, challenged by declining grades,  delays to expansion programmes and disruptions from strikes or other events. We ourselves have  not been immune to the industry-wide phenomena of a lower grade. In 2010, we moved forward  with our capital projects with the approval of the Eagle nickel and copper project in Michigan and  the Moly Autoclave project at Kennecott Utah Copper. These are relatively small in the context of  Rio Tinto but they offer very high returns, a quick payback and create future options for growth.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: Our copper evaluation projects are also progressing well and we’ve increased their budgets for the  next few years. At Kennecott Utah Copper, the cornerstone project’s expected to extend the life of  Bingham Canyon to 2028, while maintaining further options beyond that point. This plan calls for  pushing back the south wall of the mine to access about 650 million tonnes of additional mineral  resources. As outlined in our November seminar, we’ve also had options for the expansion at       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: At our greenfield projects, we continue with the shaft sinking at the Resolution project in Arizona.  And we are currently evaluating a higher-grade target at the La Granja project in Peru. During  2010, we progressively increased our interest in Ivanhoe mines and actively supported the  development of Oyu Tolgoi. In December, Rio Tinto signed the agreement with Ivanhoe, under  which we assumed management of the development and operations of Oyu Tolgoi.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: Moving on to energy, 2010 saw ongoing strength in the seaborne market for Australian coal.  Demand for thermal and coking coal remains strong from key Asian markets and underlying  earnings were a similar level to 2009. Higher prices and volumes and a gain on disposal of two  undeveloped coal properties were matched by the adverse impact of stronger Australian dollar and  higher cash costs. Hard coking coal production increased by 20%, benefiting form the recent  investment in Hail Creek and strong operational performance at the Kestrel underground mine.  During the year, our Clermont thermal coal mine commenced production and is steadily ramping up  to its 12 million tonne capacity by 2013.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: The current very severe wet season at Queensland, which has already caused major flooding, had  a slight impact on 2010 production levels and will continue to impact production rates in 2011.  Force majeure continues to remain in place at our four Queensland coal mines due to the impact of  mining operations as well as road and rail access. January coal production from our Queensland  operations was about 25% lower than normalized rates. And let’s not forget we’re still in the middle  of the wet season.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: At our New South Wales coal operations we’ve invested in overburden removal, which is critical to  realizing future growth plans. Our operations are running well and now selling into strong markets.  The Northern Territory in Australia has not been immune from this bad weather. Just a few weeks  ago, ERA announced a temporary suspension of its processing plant for 12 weeks to assist in  water management through the wet season.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: So now let’s take a look at our diamonds and minerals product group. Sustained demand from  emerging markets was reflected in higher prices and increased sales volumes, leading to a  significant turnabout in the operational profitability of the business. Rough diamond prices in  particular demonstrated a robust recovery through 2010 as demand from India and China  accelerated. And markets for titanium dioxide feedstocks, talc, and borates all continued to recover,  in line with improving global economic conditions.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: As Tom mentioned earlier, the aluminum group achieved further controllable cost savings in 2010  of at least $300 million in addition to the $1 billion realized in 2009. This demonstrates the  transformation which is underway in our aluminum business. These cost improvements have been  achieved through the cumulative effect of many different initiatives. Our continued focus on  procurement has supported further caustic soda and coke cost savings. We continue to focus on  identifying further sustainable and significant operating cost improvements in the business.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: Elsewhere, we did see some upward pressure on costs. Adverse weather, higher strip ratios and  lower yields led to higher costs at our Australian coal operations. In New South Wales, part of this  increase in waste removal is in order to prepare for a ramp up of production over the next two years  to utilize latent capacity. It’s likely that strip ratios will increase slightly in 2011 before falling  modestly in 2012.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: As I’ve said before, a stable investment climate is critical to allow commitments of this size. We’ve  worked in consultation with the Australian government’s Policy Transition Group on the proposed  mineral resources rent tax. We acknowledge that the PTG’s recommendations are an important  step towards ensuring that the design and principles of the heads of agreement entered into with  the government are carried through to the final MRRT legislation.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: Rio Tinto has announced the investment of almost $9 billion in Australia since the MRRT was  proposed. This includes our iron ore expansion plans in the Pilbara, which is the largest mining  project ever undertaken in Australia. This investment underlines our confidence that the MRRT deal  will be honored. We will work constructively with the government and the proposed implementation  group in 2011.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: There’s two primary projects in differing phase of evaluation and development and the key features  of these properties based upon Riversdale reports are set out in the table below. Both projects will  produce about 60% hard coking coal and 40% thermal coal. If successful, this acquisition would  provide Rio Tinto with a substantial development pipeline in the emerging Moatize Basin in  Mozambique, in line with our established strategy.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: I’m a great supporter of investment in new innovative technologies through our Mine of the Future  programme. We now advance programmes in a number of areas. Our focus ranges from  exploration to rapid underground mine development, advanced mineral sorting and autonomous  equipment. We are now moving these technologies from proof of concept to pilot to implementation  across our product groups.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: In iron ore, as I’ve said, the Operations Centre has been a resounding success. We’ve also been  trialing automated equipment in the Pilbara at West Angelas. We’re also seeing greater efficiency  and lower production costs as well as improved health, safety, and environmental performance.

texts.speaker: Jan P. du Plessis, Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Well, let’s start then. Good morning, everyone, here in London and good evening to those of you
texts.text: In copper, we’re actively responding to the challenges of deeper and lower-grade ore bodies.  Technologies for rapid underground mine construction will allow us to develop future mines more  quickly, more safely and at lower costs. Advanced mineral recovery techniques will enable us to  turn low-grade deposits into future tier one assets. And as competition for tier one resources  increase, competitive advantage in exploration and technology will continue to deliver great value.

file: RIO - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 9February2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: So let's now turn to 2011 results. We achieved record underlying earnings, record EBITDA and record operating  cash flows. This was despite the severe weather conditions in the first half and the fall in commodity prices we saw  through the second half. Our Pilbara iron ore business broke annual production and sales records and shipped  record volumes in the fourth quarter, not – of course, as Jan said, not all our divisions are enjoying those same  tailwinds. At our November seminar, we outlined our refocused aluminum strategy in response to the uncertain  and evolving macroeconomic conditions.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We're advancing our industry leading portfolio of growth projects, and it's worth highlighting that Pilbara has the  highest quality iron ore expansion in the global sector. Pilbara at 283Mt/a is now fully approved and on track to  months, raised them to 20 million tonnes to 353 million tonnes per year. Subject to board approval, we will reach  this capacity in the first half of 2015.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: This is in stark contrast to the broader iron ore industry trend, which has seen some projects subject to significant  delay and increased capital intensity. We've successfully completed a number of acquisitions through the year,  which complement our organic pipeline and give us further growth options.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We now have significant Tier 1 resources in coking and thermal coal in Mozambique, and uranium in Canada. And  earlier this year, we moved to majority stake in Ivanhoe Mines, further demonstrating our commitment to a safe  and successful development of the Oyu Tolgoi copper-gold mine.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: On the supply side, we estimate that about 45 million tonnes of iron ore was removed from the market in 2011 due  to adverse weather in the Pilbara, lower than expected Brazilian exports and rising export tariffs in India.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We exceeded our production targets for 2011 and increased our annual capacity in the Pilbara to 225 million  tonnes, completing our first debottlenecking project on time and on budget in the first quarter last year. This  incremental capacity together with the continued productivity improvement from our industry leading operations  center helped us achieve these records.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: It is important, of course, to – remember, we're currently in the middle of the cyclone season in Western  Australia, and already this year, we've seen some disruption and we'll a keep careful eye on all of the weather  forecast.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: At Cape Lambert, all the dredging for the expansion of 283 million tonnes is complete and engineering is at 82%.  We've just approved the construction at Amaldi Mines, and so this 283 million tonne expansion is now fully  authorized. And, of course, studies are progressing well and are accelerated and enhanced expansion to 353  million tonnes. We've already ordered the long-lead items, and just this week we approved $1.2 billion for further  early works. Cape Lambert, as shown in the picture here, continues to be the best expansion opportunity in the

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We continue to drill out the resource base in our Tier 1 Pilbara ore bodies and over the next five years, we plan to  drill another 600,000 meters per year to add to our 2.9 billion tonnes of iron ore reserve in line with our multi- decade mine planning. And our global growth options are not limited to the Pilbara. At our Canadian operations,  the first stage of concentrate expansion project is currently being commissioned. And at Simandou in Guinea,  solid progress has been made, early works construction is ramping up, including the construction of roadworks  and the development of early trucking options.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In China, aluminum prices have historically traded at a premium to the LME and have been less volatile. Despite  experiencing a rising cost of electricity, higher margin cost smelters in the coastal and central provinces are able to  take advantage of this higher Shanghai price premium. This has also led to a further expansion of smelting  capacity at the remote but coal-rich provinces in the West, particularly in the Xinjiang province.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Outside of China, we estimate roughly 2.5 million tonnes of smelting capacity is at a loss-making position at the  current prices and input costs. Further capacity reductions are necessary to move the aluminum market to a more  balanced state.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Looking further ahead, we continue to believe in our long-run outlook for aluminum demand growth. But Chinese  output of primary aluminum is still tracking internal demand. Production has shifted more towards the  Northwest, where stranded coal is being used to generate cheaper electricity.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Programs are underway to deliver $1 billion of incremental EBITDA from business improvements. And we are  focusing investment on the high return creep and modernization projects. We'll be longer in bauxite and alumina,  taking full advantage of our exceptional Tier 1 bauxite resources, and with have a portfolio of modern hydro-based  smelters supported by leading industry technology.  This is absolutely the right strategy, but it has required us to relook at the value ascribed to aluminum assets. As a  result, we have recorded an impairment charge this year, which Guy will speak to in more detail.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In 2011, the copper market was in deficit with the shortfall of supply met by drawing down supplies mainly in  China. We expect the market to continue to be finally balanced in 2012. New global copper mine supply is  expected to come online in 2012. However, experience has shown that project delivery and ramp-up timelines  have taken longer, globally, than expected.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Just a few weeks ago, just shortly after the expiry of the standstill agreement with Ivanhoe, we – our shareholding  Ivanhoe increased to a majority 51% interest. The project itself has made good progress. But as you know,  discussions continue on security of power source for the project, we still needed to remain on schedule. I have a  feasibility study to Phase II to develop the underground block cave mine continues to make progress.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We're also, of course, moving forward on other Tier 1 copper projects. La Granja received prefeasibility funding to  evaluate a three-staged phase development using conventional milling and leaching. The feasibility study at  Kennecott Utah Copper to extend the mine life to 2028 is expected to be complete in the first half of this year. And  again at Escondida, project approval for OGP1 is targeted for the first half of 2012.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: So again, now let's turn to our Energy group. In 2011 coal markets were volatile with both global supply and  demand disruptions occurring at different times throughout the year after cheering near-record prices in January  2011, following Indonesian and Australian supply side disruptions, global thermal coal markets experienced broad  price declines through the remainder of 2011.  This decline reflected weaker global economic activity and strong supply growth, however, prices remain well  supported. While the uranium market is likely to be subdued over the next few – five years, uranium will continue  to form an important part in the overall energy mix, with long-term demand expected to be driven by strong  growth in China.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Our Energy operations in Australia recovered well from the effects of significant wet weather that occurred  extensively in Queensland, New South Wales and the Northern territory in the first quarter of 2011. Disruptions to  the supply of explosives in Eastern Australia has impacted overburden removal for some of our New South Wales  operations as it has in the rest of the East Australian mining sector, with the consequential effect to the level of in- pit inventories.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Though there was no overall significant impact to the Australian coal production in 2011, there will be some  impact in the first half of 2012. As part of our continuous program to improve our portfolio, we just completed  joint acquisition of the minority interest in Coal & Allied in December in partnership with Mitsubishi. And this has  resulted in a simpler ownership structure with greater flexibility and access to funds for growth.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: At ERA, extreme wet weather caused the prolonged suspension of operations in the first half, but the operations  did recover well in the second half. AUD 500 million rights issue was completed in December, which will allow  ERA to fund its strategic water management plan, closure obligations and the Ranger 3 Deeps exploration decline.  At Rössing, grade will progressively improve over the next two years as we access lower benches in the mine.  Meanwhile, work continues on excavation drilling to extend mine life beyond 2023.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Our Energy group is now entering a new phase with many prospects for value-adding growth in the near term and  beyond. At Australia, our target has increased annual coal capacity to 73 million tonnes per year by 2015. This  growth will be underpinned by the development of new mine at Mount Pleasant in the Hunter Valley, which is  currently in feasibility study.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In the short term, we're increasing capacity at existing operations, such as the Clermont Mine and the brownfield  expansions into Hunter Valley, Mount Thorley Warkworth and at Bengalla. These will lead to an increase of about  15% to 20% in total Australian coal production in 2012. The Kestrel Mine extension is well advanced and is  scheduled to start production in 2013 with incremental annual production of around 1 million tonnes.  Infrastructure will be a critical factor in the delivery of this growth, and our position for the future continues to  strengthen.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In New South Wales and Queensland, investment has been made in the coal supply chain to meet this increasing  demand. During the first half of the year, we completed the acquisition of Riversdale, which has now been  renamed Rio Tinto Coal Mozambique. There's a good photo of it in the upper side of the plant and under  construction at present. This does provides a substantial Tier 1 coking coal development pipeline in the emerging  Moatize basin. Initial production from the Benga project is scheduled for the first half of this year.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Following the Riversdale transaction, we completed the acquisition of Hathor in Canada, and these encouraging  uranium exploration development opportunities are one of the highest grade uranium basins in the world. With  the forecast demand for energy and steel production over the coming decades, I have real confidence the high  quality growth projects being pulled together by the Energy team, will deliver excellent results over the long term.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Turning now to diamonds and minerals.
