Demand for borates and titanium dioxide feedstocks held up well despite  ongoing market volatility. 2011 saw a continued tightness in TiO2 feedstock supply, which is expected to continue  over the medium term. Diamond prices were strong in the first half of 2011, but the second half did see lower  new diamonds and further potential for diamond growth in China and India. Diamond production did decline  15%, overall, due to heavy rains we saw due to flooding at Argyle early in the year and maintenance shutdowns  that we saw at Argyle in the fourth quarter in the processing plant.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The impact of the record wet season in Argyle, coupled with the continued strength of the Australian dollars, did  result in a further $500 million of capital be improved – being approved to complete the Argyle underground  project. And we would expect to experience lower grades until the underground mine is at full production by 2014.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Earnings for Iron & Titanium business did double in 2011 as we continue to replace these multi-year sales  contracts with alternative pricing mechanism, increasing the business' exposure to market prices for TiO2  feedstocks.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: At QMM and Madagascar, production steadily increased due to successful dry mining operations. Full capacity is  expected to be reached over the next two to three years. As you know, we sold our talc business in August and have  created new opportunities in potash through a joint venture agreement in Saskatchewan, home to nearly half the  world's potash reserves.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: And finally, just last week, we announced we'll be doubling our stake in Richards Bay Minerals on Tier 1 asset that  we've been managing for many years, actually, many decades.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Let me start by taking a look at how our record underlying earnings were achieved. It will come as no surprise that  the primary driver has been price, increasing earnings by $6.7 billion. By far, the largest benefit came from iron  ore prices, although, copper and hard coking coal increases were also significant. These benefits were partially  offset by the impact of currency movements, notably, the stronger Australian dollar. These collectively reduced  our underlying earnings by nearly $1 billion compared with 2010.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: As previously flagged, lower copper and gold grades at Kennecott Utah Copper, Escondida and Grasberg have led  to lower sales volumes, which reduced our earnings by just over $0.5 billion. This was partially offset by record  volumes from iron ore as increased port capacity was brought online.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Continued cost pressure is evident throughout the industry and we are not immune. The impacts of inflation and  higher energy costs reduced our 2011 earnings by over $600 million. And more importantly, higher cash costs  reduced earnings by a further $2.1 billion, which I'll return to in detail in a moment.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The exceptional weather experienced in the first half of the year also impacted our volume and, as a consequence,  increased our unit cash costs. And we've also incurred additional cost due to our investment in operational  readiness as we prepare to bring online a number of major growth projects, in particular in the Pilbara.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Purchases from China include coke, caustic soda, rail cars and other supply. And we will also continue to mitigate  some of these cost increases through our industry leading investments in technology. This will lead to increased  automation and improve productivity across many of our operations in years to come.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The industry, as Guy says, does continue to face challenges with the supply side, from rising raw material and  labor costs as well as industrial action and weather events. And projects, as you've heard, will becoming  increasingly difficult to finance for some, and the capital intensity for both projects is continuing rise. Resource  nationalism and long processes for permitting, stakeholder engagement improvals also have the effect of reducing  supply growth. Of course, geologically, the deposits are becoming more difficult to find and, technically, more  difficult to develop. And all these factors will continue to put pressure on the supply side within the environment  of this increasing demand. This development, of course, will go through periods of volatility such as what we're  currently facing right now.

texts.speaker: Tom Albanese
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Over in the Exploration group, work has led to the finding and developing of the next generation of ore bodies,  from bauxite in Brazil through the potash in Saskatchewan, new projects across the globe are delivering promising  results.

file: RIO - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 14February2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: These write-downs are deeply disappointing. In particular, the substantial impairment of our Mozambique coal  business is unacceptable. There clearly is a need for greater discipline, in particular in the way we allocate and  manage capital at Rio Tinto. I believe Sam is ideally placed across a fisheye over how we address the challenges  and opportunities in the business. He's a highly experienced and capable executive who has already made a  significant contribution to Rio Tinto, not only as an executive, but as a director of the company.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Putting it very, very simply, this means individuals will have clear targets and will be accountable for their  performance. It also means we'll strengthen our management and approval systems, bringing greater rigor to  internal debate and having more effective checks and balances and clearer lines of sight to critical business issues.  We will deliver on our cost-saving targets. We will see an annual run rate improvement of $3 billion a year by the  end of 2014. And Guy will talk us through this shortly.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Sam. We've reported underlying earnings of $9.3 billion and cash flows from our operations of $16.5  billion. Whilst lower than last year, principally due to lower commodity prices, these results demonstrate the good  performance and healthy position of our underlying business. As we flagged in January, we've recognized an  impairment charge of $14.4 billion, mainly related to our aluminium and Mozambique coal assets.  The aluminium market deteriorated further in 2012, while the Australian and Canadian dollars remained strong.  These factors, coupled with high energy and raw material costs, reduced market valuations substantially.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In Mozambique, we had planned to barge coal along the Zambezi River. This has not received formal approvals,  but we remain actively engaged with the government of Mozambique on all transport options.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We've revised down our estimates of our recoverable coking coal, which necessitated a reassessment of the overall  scale and ramp-up schedule, resulting in the impairment. The impairment charge has been partly reduced by a  deferred tax asset of $1.1 billion, following the introduction of the MRRT in Australia last year. We recognized net  gains on the consolidation of Richards Bay Minerals and Turquoise Hill of around $800 million. So, overall, we  recorded a net loss of $3 billion.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: It was a tale of two halves for iron ore prices in 2012. The first half of the year was relatively stable. The second  half was highly volatile, with prices falling to as low as $89 per ton before recovering to the mid-$150s in early  2013.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In aluminium, we continue to face challenging market conditions. The 16% decline in the LME price lowered  earnings by just over $940 million. It was also a difficult year for coking coal, driven by a combination of a  recovery in supply from Australia and a weak macroeconomic environment.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In 2012, copper markets moved from a net deficit to a slight surplus. The 10% decline in the copper price lowered  our earnings by just over $300 million. On a more positive note, the unwinding of legacy contracts for titanium  dioxide feedstocks resulted in $270 million of additional earnings. This sector will become an even more  important driver of our earnings momentum, as repricing of legacy contracts continues.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Turning now to volumes, volume increases enhanced earnings by $634 million. Just over half of this came from  rising iron ore sales following the debottlenecking projects in the Pilbara. Other significant gains included higher  copper volumes at Escondida and at Northparkes, in line with a recovery in grades.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Raw material cost inflation continued, particularly in our aluminium business, where higher coke, pitch and  caustic soda prices persisted. Offsetting these cost increases was less weather disruption than we experienced a  year earlier.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: So, by the end of 2014, we will have achieved sustainable reductions of $3 billion in our operating cash costs  compared with our 2012 cost base. For context, in 2012, our net operating cash costs were $35 billion, around $6  billion higher than just three years ago. This is not a sustainable trend, so we're taking decisive actions to reverse  it.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Let me explain the rules we will apply in measuring performance against this target. We're assuming constant  including inflation, currency movements, the impact of input prices linked to quoted metal prices and major one- offs, such as a significant weather event.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Performance against this target will be measured by pre-tax unit cash cost improvements, shown in our earnings  variance analysis. Productivity gains that reduce unit cash costs will be reflected in our performance against the  target. Equally, any increases in unit costs as a consequence of operating conditions, such as greater haul  distances, will need to be more than offset. All earlier cost reductions that we've talked about are included in our  new target. This includes the cost savings from our aluminium transformation program and from our service and  support cost review.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: However, our planned reductions in exploration and evaluation spend of $750 million and further reductions in  sustaining capital are in addition to this target. Nearly two-thirds of the $5 billion cumulative savings will come  from our aluminium and energy businesses. These have experienced the highest cost increases over recent years.  Central service and support costs also make up a substantial part of the reduction.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: What sorts of initiatives are we taking to get there? Well, a few examples may help explain. In our energy business,  we've implemented a salary freeze, which will result in a real terms cost saving. We're also improving labor  sourcing strategies. We've recently completed the first round of our service and support cost review, which  included significant head count reductions and the downsizing of a number of high-cost city offices. And we're  now reviewing our central office locations and are aiming for substantial savings through further relocations,  outsourcing and offshoring.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Beyond our cost reduction programs, we're also taking action at some of our higher-cost operations. For example,  at Gove, we're working closely with the Northern Territory government to finalize agreements for gas supply and  are advancing plans to convert the refinery from high-cost fuel oil to gas.

texts.speaker: Guy R. Elliott
texts.profession: CFO & Senior Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We will be looking at existing projects with a fresh pair of eyes and considering alternatives. These include  continuing with the current plan, slowing down, introducing partners or canceling projects altogether. For  example, we have slowed down the development of Kitimat over the winter period, given the aluminium market  conditions. And we've deferred work at the Argyle underground project not required to bring first production  onstream. And we're looking at options for reducing the capital we've invested in shipping, including novating two  existing new ship orders to a third-party provider of freight services.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Rio Tinto is a company that's always focused on the longer term. Here, our view is unchanged. But over the course  of the next two decades, billions of people will move from rural to urban areas, driving up consumption of the  metals and minerals that we produce.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The aluminium industry is likely to face challenging market conditions for some years to come. A structural shift  has occurred, driven by the decoupling of the supply chain for bauxite, alumina and aluminium, and continuing  growth in the Chinese smelting industry. We have seen some smelter closures and they've been announced, but  we've also seen local governments across the globe providing incentives to ensure that loss-making smelters  continue to operate. These actions are preventing the rationalization of the high-cost capacity that's required to

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Secondly, our energy group also gave disappointing performance in 2012. And under Harry Kenyon-Slaney's new  leadership, I expect significant new steps to be taken, costs to be cut, and underperforming operations to be closed  or divested. Harry's already taking tough decisions to turn that business around. So, as I said, there's a lot to be  done.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Now, turning to our investment program, we have a number of projects at varying stages of completion. We're  focusing on delivering our major capital projects on time and on budget. In Queensland, Yarwun 2 was completed  in mid-2012 and we've ramped up at an unusually fast rate to 90% of capacity. New tons are also being delivered  from our Australian thermal coal operations following the completion of brownfield expansions in 2012. And in  British Columbia, the Kitimat modernization is expected to deliver first metal by the end of 2014.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Looking further ahead, we continue to make good progress at Simandou. In 2012, we formed the joint venture  with Chalco, received a $1.3 billion earn-in, and we also focused on the social and environmental impact study.  We anticipate further progress once project financing has been put in place and approval is granted by the  government of Guinea for work on the ground.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In Western Australia, our Pilbara expansion project will see us grow annual iron ore production from 237 million  our annual capacity from 230 million tons to 237 million tons, with minimal capital investment. And today, Guy  mentioned that we've brought forward the completion of the 290-million-ton-a-year project from the fourth  quarter of this year to the third quarter of 2013, delivering value faster. As a result, our global iron ore production  will grow to around 265 million tons in 2013 on a 100% basis.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: And in 2014, we'll have a full year of operating at this higher capacity, delivering further year-on-year growth. This  will be quickly followed by an additional 50 million tons of annual capacity by the end of 2014 and a further 20  million tons by the end of the first half of 2015 to reach an annual capacity of 360 million tons per annum.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We've also saved $1 billion of capital by removing the wet plant at Brockman 4 from the expansion project. So,  this means we'll be able to maintain a capital intensity in the Pilbara of mid-$150 per annual ton, despite facing  some of the highest inflation rates in the industry and major headwind from the strong Australian dollar.  Importantly, this is an achievement unmatched by any other developer of a major iron ore project. We run a  highly efficient, fully integrated mine, rail and port network in the Pilbara. And I welcome last week's decision by  the Australian Competition Tribunal regarding third-party access to our rail. This protects the value of the system  that we've created over decades of investment.

file: RIO - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 13February2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We have achieved record production in bauxite, thermal coal and iron ore despite operational and weather-related  challenges we've a more accountable and disciplined business. And we've strengthened our systems and our  processes. Importantly, we've delivered strong underlying earnings and improved cash flows against a  backdrop  of weaker commodity prices.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: As I mentioned, our financial results demonstrate the very real and significant progress that we've made. With  sharp focus on every dollar we spend, we've improved cash operating costs by $2.3 billion. By focus ing on our  exploration and evaluation spend, we've reduced these costs by $1 billion – a further $1 billion. And at the same  time we set new production records in bauxite, thermal coal and iron ore. Across our total group production grew  by 9% in 2013 on a copper equivalent basis.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We've also delivered on our major growth projects. Of note, expansion at our Pilbara iron ore assets to 290 million  tonnes a year was commissioned $400 million under budget and four months ahead of schedule. We completed  the first phase of the Oyu Tolgoi copper/gold mine in Mongolia, and shipped first concentrate in July.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Underlying earnings were also impacted by the effects of commodity prices during the year. Overall, lower  commodity prices reduced earnings by $1.3 billion. In particular, lower coal prices reduced earnings by $530  million as supply increased and onerous take-or-pay freight contracts in Australia incentivized uneconomic  supply  to remain in the market.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In aluminum financial deals continue to lock up substantial amounts of metal in the LME system. Although we  saw strong growth in demand for aluminum in 2013, and therefore increases in regional premia for physical  delivery, this was not enough to offset an overall 9% decline in the LME. And in the copper market supply  increases resulted in a fall in prices of 8%.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Within this generally weaker price environment iron ore prices stood out with average spot prices higher in 201 3  than in 2012.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: I'll return to our cost reduction program in more detail shortly. But adding together our cash cost improvements  and lower exploration and evaluation spend, you can see this has boosted earnings by over $3.3 billion pre -tax or  $2.1 billion for the year on a post-tax basis.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Overall our group average unit cash cost has been reduced by 10% before the further impacted exchange  movements. These improvements can most clearly be seen in the unit cost reductions at each individual business.  By way of example Kennecott Utah Copper has reduced gross cash costs by $1,500 per tonne. Primary aluminum  in North America has reduced its cash costs by $300 per tonne, and Rio Tinto Coal Australia has achieved a $30  per tonne unit cost reduction.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: While the bulk of the operating cost savings have been realized in aluminum, energy and copper, all of the product  groups have contributed and will continue to do so. Each of the product group CEOs gave examples of the work  underway in their businesses at our December investor seminars.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: However let me walk you through a couple of initiatives being implemented in 2014. In September of last year our  Hail Creek Mine in Queensland ran a two-day trial, producing saleable thermal coal from reject product. It was so  successful that this process will continue throughout 2014, leading to an additional 7 50,000 tonnes of annual  production, largely using existing equipment and available capacity.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Fuel usage at our coal operations in Australia is another area which will be targeted this year. Through engine  calibration, reduced revolutions during idling, and component upgrades for older trucks, we estimate that we can  save over 4 million liters of fuel without affecting production. And in iron ore our competency-based approach to   training will free up 200,000 man hours, the equivalent of more than 90 full-time staff.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: As you can see with thousands of cost saving projects underway across the group, the focus on cash and running  the business for value continues. And we're confident that we'll achieve our 2014 targets.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We're comfortable that this is a level which will allow us to continue to develop a robust pipeline of future options.  Right now we're progressing 30 projects across 10 different commodities, with a particular focus on the La Granja  and Resolution copper projects, together with our ongoing central exploration program.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The iron ore team has recently shown a clear example of this with a breakthrough pathway for expanding the  Pilbara operations, which was announced in November. This new pathway to 360 million tonnes per annum is  planned at a substantially reduced capital intensity of between $120 to $130 per tonne, and $3 billion less than  the previous forecasts. This shows that CapEx can be reduced whilst delivering exciting value -adding growth. And  we're adopting the same mindset to our sustaining CapEx, which reduced by around $2 billion i n 2013.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: 2013 was another landmark year for our iron ore business. In the Pilbara we completed and began operating the  new facilities at Cape Lambert. Ramp up of mine capacity to 290 million tonnes a year is underway. And as  mentioned we've completed expansion four months ahead of schedule and $400 million under budget.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We've achieved record production in shipments at our Pilbara operations in 2013, up 5% compared to 2012.  Importantly we took advantage of delivering these additional tonnes into the strong iro n ore market. The  infrastructure expansion project is on track to increase annual capacity to 360 million tonnes a year in the first  half of 2015.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The breakthrough development pathway announced last year will maximize the value of our resources. Additiona l  tonnes from low-cost brownfield mine growth and productivity gains will feed the expanded infrastructure as it  comes online. We'll be extending the lives of some of our existing mines, as well as adding additional resources  into the system.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In copper we focused the business around a 4+2 strategy. This is a clear roadmap to position the copper group as a  first quartile, low-cost producer and leader in its sector. The 4 of the strategy are our Kennecott Utah Copper, Oyu  Tolgoi, Escondida, and Grasberg.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: At Kennecott the recovery from the slide which occurred in April is well underway. The heavy haul road was  completed ahead of schedule, which allowed further waste movement to provide access to all. Work on the  Cornerstone Project, which extends the life of the mine also, continues. The recovery from the Manefay slide is a  remarkable achievement after such a major event. And I would like to congratulate the Kennecott team on the way  they've responded to this challenge.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The 2 of the 4+2 strategy represents two world-class greenfield projects. These are Resolution in the United States  and La Granja in Peru. Both are exciting and prospecting copper growth options, which will develop in a stage  manner in the years ahead.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: During the year we continue to rationalize our aluminum portfolio. We sold Saint-Jean, we closed the Shawinigan  smelter, and announced the suspension of the Gove alumina refinery.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: At the same time we're seeking ways to maximize value from the Kitimat asset. We recently sold assets to acqui re  or lease a parcel of land near our Kitimat operations to a Shell-led joint venture. And whilst the financial terms are  confidential, this agreement has the potential to generate meaningful value for Rio Tinto.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: And in energy we've made real in-roads into addressing the challenges of the economic outlook facing the energy  sector. The team has pulled significant costs out, and we have driven an aggressive transformation agenda. I'm  confident that we'll achieve the targeted 2014 cost reduction in our energy business of $1 billion compared to  2012.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: So to sum up, 2013 was a year of delivering on our commitments. We achieved underlying earnings of $10.2  billion, up 10%. We exceeded our cost reduction targets, whilst we set production records. And we significantly  increased our operating cash flows, whilst reducing our net debt. At the same time, we have reduced capital and  completed projects, such as Oyu Tolgoi Phase I and the Pilbara 290 [million tonnes] expansion.

file: RIO - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 12February2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: There are no scheduled fire alarms for today. So if you do hear any announcements, then please make your way to  the nearest exits. Nearest exits are out the two doors to your front and turn left or right and follow the green  running man signs. Once you're out of the building, we've conveniently placed a fire assembly point via easily  recognizable landmarks. So if you head towards St. Paul's and as you get there, there'll be some members of the  staff sporting the latest fashion in high visibility jackets; and if you'll just muster there, and you'll be given further  instructions.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: There were impairments relating to overruns of the Kitimat modernization project, which were recognized at the  half year, and the write-down of the Moly Autoclave project at Kennecott. These were partially offset by the  reversal of a previous impairment taken on the PacAl assets. This reversal reflects improved pricing in the  industry, but more importantly is driven by our successful work to improve the efficiency and cost  competitiveness of the PacAl assets.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Losses on disposal mainly relate to the divestment of our interests in Rio Tinto Coal Mozambique in October. And  following the repeal of the Minerals Resource Rent Tax, or MRRT, in Australia in the second half of last year, we  wrote off the deferred tax asset to the tune of $362 million.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Iron Ore prices declined significantly in 2014. On average, the price of 62% iron declined by 30% from the prior  year. Notwithstanding this, our Iron Ore business' underlying earnings were $8.1 billion, a reduction of only 18%.  We increased our sales with 90% of our expansion tonnes going into our premium Pilbara Blend product. And in  addition, continued cost reduction efforts and the favorable effect of the weaker Australian dollar partially offset  the price decline.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: This year, as promised, you will have seen that we've split out the revenues, EBITDA, and earnings of our  bauxite  and alumina businesses. This enhanced disclosure reveals that our bauxite business is generating strong margins,  but also that more work needs to be done in the alumina refineries. We've set some tough targets for 2015, so we  expect that alumina's profile will steadily improve.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our Copper product group delivered an 11% increase in underlying earnings. This was despite a 7 % reduction in  average copper prices and reflects the efforts of our team there in reducing costs and boosting productivity.  Improved volumes from OT and reduction in cash unit costs and exploration and evaluation were the main  reasons for the improvement.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our Energy business faced a very tough year and generated a loss of $210 million at underlying earnings. This is  down from a $33 million profit in 2013. Lower prices across the coal sector reduced earnings by $433 million, but  not all of this could be offset by cost reductions of $170 million. Rio Tinto Coal Australia was profitable at $21  million, but ERA incurred a loss of $119 million; and Rio Tinto Coal Mozambique, a loss of $93 million before it  was divested in October of 2014.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Compared with the 2012 base, we've now reduced our operating cash costs and evaluation and exploration  expenditure by $4.8 billion, but we're not stopping there. When we announced at the half year that we had  achieved $3.2 billion cash unit cost reductions, beating the $3 billion target six months ahead of schedule, we  were keen to ensure that the momentum in the business was maintained and the focus on reducing these costs  continued. We, therefore, set an additional target of a further $1 billion of sustainable cost improvements by the  end of 2015.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Since the end of 2012, we've now delivered over $3.6 billion of operating cash unit cost savings, beating our  original $3 billion target by about 20% by then end of 2014. As you can see from the chart, we've achieved  significant cost reductions across our portfolio with around $900 million coming out of our Copper group, $800  million from each of Aluminum and Energy, and $700 million from Iron Ore. The remaining $300 million came  largely out of Diamonds and Minerals, other operations and the head office cost reductions. Additionally, we've  saved $1.2 billion over the past two years by reducing our exploration and evaluation activities, focusing only the  highest-value projects.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We continue to deliver greater operating and commercial efficiency in our unrivalled Pilbara assets. In 2014, our  cash unit cost was $19.50 per tonne. But if you take current oil currency rates, our estimate for Q4 unit cash cost  would be equivalent to about $17 a tonne.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our average realized price for our Pilbara Blend products was $84.30 per wet metric tonne for the full year of  2014, equivalent to about $91.60 per dry metric tonne; and our spot sales continue to be consistently above the  Platts 62% Fe benchmark. The combination of low cost and sound marketing has led to consistent and attractive  margins.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And we'll further expand our bauxite business at Gove and the South of the Embley project where we recently  approved capital to complete the feasibility study this year with first production expected in 2018. And we have  further growth options also in the Cape Y ork Peninsula, which we'll seek to develop in line with market demand as  we continue to develop our product as the seaborne bauxite of choice.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Aluminum has grown into a significant contributor to group earnings and cash flows. Jean-Sébastien and his team  in Copper have delivered some impressive cost improvements and they've also restructured the Copper division,  preserving EBITDA margins of 42% year-on-year. And there's a continued focus on our Copper portfolio. We  exited Pebble in 2014, and we're in the process of exiting South Gobi. Ramp-up of Oyu Tolgoi continues; and  Kennecott will have a year of preparation as we work towards higher output in 2016.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In Energy, and a pretty difficult industry environment, Harry and his team have worked hard to maximize  efficiencies and reduce costs. Our Australian coal operations continue to generate positive earnings and positive  cash flows.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: A key focus for 2015 will be progressing the Hunter Blend project. This is a plan to operate our  Hunter Valley  assets as a fully integrated network of mines, rail and port; and the strategy will be underpinned by the Integrated  Operations Center, which is expected to open in Singleton early this year, and the Process Excellence Center which  is already operating in Brisbane.

file: RIO - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 11February2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: John Smelt
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Good morning and welcome to Rio Tinto's 2015 Full Y ear Results. My name is John Smelt. I'm the Head of  Investor Relations at Rio Tinto. First of all, on safety, there are no scheduled fire alarm test today, so if the alarms  do go off, please listen to the announcements and follow the instructions. In the event of an evacuation, the  assembly point is over by St. Paul's Cathedral and the Stock Exchange team will be on hand to assist. The nearest  fire exits are these two doors to either side of me. If you go out of here, you can go either left or right and the exits  are in the same direction. So, behind where we are standing and they're indicated by the standard green signs.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Further outcome of our actions has been margin stability. Tier 1 assets with tight operational control assure that  we continue to generate strong cash flows and to protect margins and profitability. The success in the Pilbara has  been remarkable. The second half of 2015, we reduced our C1 cost to $13.80 per tonne, which, of course, includes  the benefit of weaker Australian dollar and lower oil prices but a lot of action by the team on the ground.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: If we use spot prices at the end of January, this $13.80 would be equivalent to $13.20 per tonne. And I should  highlight that C1 cost is an all-in measure, which includes SG&A. EBITDA margins at our aluminium business  increased year-on-year to 31%. I believe the statistics show it that we have the best aluminium business in the  world. Their performance was assisted by further portfolio optimization and cost reduction.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: First, our price volatility continued to be the dominant theme, and it's taken – the impact of declining prices on  our earnings continued in the second half and led to a significant reduction of $7.7 billion for the year. There was  some offset from currency but the impact of energy costs and inflation was relatively modest. This brought us to  the flexed 2014 earnings of $3.8 billion. There was a benefit from higher volumes, mainly from the Pilbara and  increased bauxite exports from Weipa and Gove, but this was partly offset by lower volumes at Kennecott and in  titanium.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Further impairments of $684 million relate mainly to the carrying value of Energy Resources of Australia,  following a decision by the ERA board to not proceed with the final feasibility study on the Ranger 3 Deeps  project. We also impaired the Roughrider uranium project in Canada following completion of an order of  magnitude study.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Over the past three years, we've delivered $6.2 billion in cost savings. Obviously, it's getting harder. But we  continue to find opportunities to reduce costs and have been able to maintain strong momentum. All product  groups have contributed to this impressive achievement, with Copper & Coal delivering $1.9 billion and Iron Ore  and Aluminium each delivering about $1.1 billion of cumulative savings.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Signs of recovery in industrial demand are yet to emerge, and a prolonged downturn brings increased risk.  Housing sales in China stabilized during the second half of 2015, but we're yet to see a turnaround in China's  construction activity. The transition to a less commodity-intensive and slower growth path, often referred as the  new normal, is further compounded by these soft industrial trends. The recent decline in oil prices has wide  repercussions. Even though we benefit from it, a lower oil price clearly has a negative impact on many  governments and their economies. The volatility in global financial markets reflects concern over the strength of  global manufacturing and global trade, and we can see this impact on emerging equity markets.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The iron ore market dipped below $40 per tonne towards the end of last year, representing an 80% fall since its  peak in 2011. Domestic steel consumption in China fell by between 4% and 5% in 2015 due to its exposure to  property and investment. China's iron ore demand, however, was more stable due to a combination of higher steel  exports and lower scrap use.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: For some time, we've been highlighting the iron ore exits. At the start of 2015, we anticipated cuts for the year of  around 85 million tonnes. We actually saw 130 million tonnes cut from high cost production, and this was on top  of the 125 million tonnes of exits that occurred in 2014. So high-cost supply is leaving the market.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In 2016, we estimate that around 75 million tonnes of new supply will come on to the market from seaborne  producers. This will be more than matched by exits. But it's not just iron ore prices that have been impacted by  recent market turmoil. Prices for aluminium, thermal and met coal are at levels preceding the China boom or only  briefly seen during the depth of the Global Financial Crisis.

texts.speaker: Samuel Maurice Cossart Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In each of these cases, strong Chinese supply and slow curtailments have exacerbated global market imbalances.  As a result, prices are cutting deep into cost curve, despite significant reductions in cost, weaker currency and  lower energy prices. We've also seen a gradual erosion of the copper price with rising expectations of continued  supply growth, coupled with weaker demand.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We continue to look to ensure that our balance sheet is robust and that returns are based more on profitability.  Our 2015 underlying earnings were $4.5 billion. Now while this is simplistic, if we adjusted that number with the  current consensus iron ore price alone, today's earnings would've been around $2.7 billion. And as before taking  into account any other commodity prices or premia that we're seeing in the markets today.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In the Pilbara, we've essentially finished the infrastructure build and are now looking at a much smaller spend on  the Silvergrass project. And this primarily provides product quality for the Pilbara Blend. It's now expected to  come in below $500 million.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The Amrun project team are working hard to find alternate ways to finance key infrastructure components as well  as re-phasing expenditure. And at OT, the feasibility study continues and we expect that to be completed in the  first half of this year.

file: RIO - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 8February2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: I've been very pleased with our cost reduction program. We delivered $1 billion in the second half. This comes in  addition to the $580 million in the first half. So, we are well on track to deliver on our promise of $2 billion in cost  savings across 2016 and 2017.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In 2016, we further strengthened our portfolio as we said we would, again, not just talking, but delivering. We  announced disposal of more than $1.3 billion in the year, closing the sale of Lochaber in the UK in December.  And last month, we announced the divestment of our thermal coal business in Australia worth $2.45 billion which,  subject to approval, should complete later this year.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The Copper & Diamonds product group had operating EBITDA margins of 35% and continued to develop our  world-class resources including Oyu Tolgoi. And Energy & Minerals match production with market demands,  generating significant free cash flow in 2016 due to improved prices in some commodities including coal. I am  delighted with the strong performance across the group and with the hard work and commitment of all our  employees around the world.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Thanks, J-S. These are another strong set of results. Let's have a look at the numbers in more detail starting with  the commodities. Prices were depressed at the start of 2016. However, we saw an improvement during the year  in most of our main commodities. Iron Ore started the year at around $40 a tonne, ended the year around $75 a  tonne. The average price was $53.60, which was 6% higher than 2015. Copper prices were, on average, 11%  lower than 2015, notwithstanding a 25% increase during the year. Aluminium ended the year 20% higher. But the  average was 3% below 2015, but market premia also fell. For example, the Mid-West premium declined by 40%  to $162 per tonne in 2016.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Higher sales across most of our commodities were offset by lower copper and byproduct sales and there was a  lower attributable share of coal arising from the restructure of the coal in Allied Group and the sale of Bengalla.  We delivered a further $1.6 billion of unit cash cost savings in 2016, which equates to $1.2 billion post tax, but we  maintain our target of $2 billion of cost savings over 2016 and 2017 combined.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: As always, it's important to note that this excludes the impact of exchange rates and changes in oil and energy  costs. This takes our total reductions against the 2012 cost base to $7.8 billion. A strong culture of cost cont rol is  required to assist in further cost reductions, especially where many of the easier wins have already been taken.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: I'm sure that each of our businesses will apply the same tenacity to our new target of increasing free cash flow  through productivity improvements by $5 billion over the next five years. J-S has already mentioned the  outstanding work that we've seen in the Aluminium group this year where cost reduction targets have again been  beaten, delivering a further reduction of $481 million. Aluminium found a total now of $1.6 billion of cost  reductions since 2012 and a program of more than 1,250 initiatives is still being worked on.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The Energy & Minerals group also reduced costs further, taking out an additional $342 million in 2016 and  bringing its cumulative total to $1.4 billion. And Copper & Diamonds took out $278 million in 2016 despite lower  volumes.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The growth projects are progressing well under the oversight of our Growth and Innovation group. The Silvergrass  project in the Pilbara will deliver high-grade low phosphorus ore for the Pilbara Blend and give us operating  benefits.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Our work and expenditure on this project is ramping up now and we're on track for production in the second half  of 2017. At the $1.9 billion Amrun bauxite project in Queensland, the access road is now complete and we'll have  the river terminal operational this quarter. As previously guided, most of the project spend will be over the next  two years, with first production in the first half of 2019.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We continue to refine our portfolio to ensure that we make the most efficient use of our capital. In 2016, we  announced $1.3 billion of divestments. We closed the sales on our Bengalla mine and the Mount Pleasant  thermal coal project. We announced the sale of the Lochaber's aluminium smelter for which we received slightly  more than half the proceeds in 2016 with the remainder to be received later this month.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Two weeks ago, we announced that we'd agreed the sale of Coal & Allied for up to $2.45 billion plus potential  royalties. This sale is subject to a number of conditions, but the transaction should close in the second half of this  year.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Including Coal & Allied, we have announced divestments of more than $7.7 billion in the last four years, but we  retained flexibility in our portfolio. Some of our assets are smaller, but they're valuable and highly cash generative.  We'll continue to exit any assets or projects that don't fit our portfolio and where we can realize attractive values.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Let's look at the iron ore market. Recently, the market has been much stronger than expected by many observers.  There are four key drivers that will continue to impact the iron ore supply/demand balance in 2017. The first is the  health of the Chinese economy, which I've just covered. Next, the Chinese domestic steel market is looking to  drive out high-polluting production. This is a clear opportunity for us as we will see demand switch from low-grade  ore to high-grade product we offer. The third, the additional supply from seaborne iron ore producers, we expect  about 40 million tonnes of new capacity in 2017. And last but not least, the domestic iron ore production in China  is a key source of uncertainty and could keep the balance.

file: RIO - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 7February2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In 2017, we also further strengthened our portfolio, generating $2.7 billion of proceeds from our divestments,  including Coal & Allied. We will continue to exit any assets or projects that do not fit our strategy. Let me give you  an example. Last month, we received a binding offer of $500 million for the sale of our Aluminium Dunkerque  smelter in France. So, in summary, we are in good shape, we have the very strong set of results, and we are well  positioned for the future. But let me be clear, I can assure you we are not becoming complacent at all.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Now, I will cover some of our operational and product group highlights, starting with safety. Safety comes first at  Rio Tinto. Our ambitions remain the same: all of our employees and contractors must return home safely at the  end of each and every day. Sadly, you will remember we lost a colleague in a tragic incident at our Kennecott  operation in October. Albert Lozano died following injuries he suffered after SO2 exposure. I was on site at the  time and I can tell you that Albert's loss was deeply felt by his family, friends and all over Rio Tinto. We are  working very hard to try and ensure this never happens again.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Let's take a look at our product group performance. Every part of the business is focused on maximizing cash  through driving productivity from mine-to-market. In Iron Ore, we delivered free cash flow of $7.3 billion and  EBITDA margin of 68% as customers demanded our higher-quality product, driven by the need to improve  environmental performance.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Copper prices increased 27% compared to last year, reflecting strong demand from China and supply disruptions  during the period. Tighter Chinese environmental policies curtailed the importation of scrap which has created  increased demand for concentrate and cathode.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Realized hard coking coal prices were 42% higher on average compared with 2016. Impacts from Cyclone  Debbie in Queensland saw prices spike in the first half. And whilst these have come off from those levels, strong  demand from China and a tight supply chain have meant prices have remained strong compared with 2016.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: With the aluminium business, we have the hydro-powered Canadian smelters, which are in the first quartile and  even first decile of the cost curve. And we have the exceptional bauxite assets in North Queensland. Having high  quality Tier 1 assets with attractive commodity offerings is key to delivering higher margins through the cycle.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Underlying earnings are up 69% on last year. This chart shows clearly the recovery in prices in 2017 across our  commodities, with prices increasing earnings by $4.1 billion versus 2016. As you can see, energy costs and  exchange rates, whilst increasing, have only had a modest negative impact.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In the first half of the year, Pilbara shipments and hard coking coal production was impacted by significant  cyclonic weather. And our copper division saw disruptions from labor negotiations at Escondida. The strong  second half, particularly in the Pilbara and the Australian bauxite operations, meant that we were able to recover  volumes for the year, and production finished pretty much in line with 2016.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We've achieved cost savings which more than offset raw material cost increases of around $200 million,  particularly for input prices in aluminium which we mentioned in December. There was a one-off impact to  underlying earnings of $176 million as a result of the strike at Escondida. The completion of the Coal & Allied  disposal on the 1st of September reduced thermal and semi-soft coal volumes in 2017. So, overall, delivered  underlying earnings of $6.8 billion (sic) [$8.6 billion] (00:12:49).

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: As before, the cash cost variance excludes the effects of inflation, energy costs and exchange rates. All other  costs are being taken on the chin. For example, the current headwinds on input prices for coke, pitch and caustic  have not been forgiven. We have adjusted for tax. On a post-tax basis, the total productivity improvements,  including what was achieved in the first half of this year, amount to $0.5 billion.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Capital spend for the year was $4.5 billion, of which $2 billion was sustaining our current operations and $2.5  billion on the compelling growth projects. During the year, we completed the $338 million Silvergrass project with  commissioning occurring in the fourth quarter. The mine will continue to ramp up. It's currently delivering around  10 million tonnes of low-cost additional capacity, supporting our highly valued Pilbara blend product.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The Amrun bauxite project in North Queensland is on track to deliver first ore in the first half of 2019. During the  year, we installed both the wharf and the plant beneficiation modules. At Oyu Tolgoi, we saw a ramp up in spend  in 2017 as we continue to mobilize contractors. We've recently completed this sinking of Shaft 2 and lateral  development is on track. An annual project review was completed during the year and we remain on track to  deliver first drawbell production in 2020.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In 2018 and 2019, we'll continue to spend CapEx at Amrun; and at Oyu Tolgoi, we're spending around $1 billion  in each of these years, including plant funding for a power station from 2019. Both of these projects are highly  value accretive.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In the Iron Ore business, we'll need to spend around $3 billion on sustaining CapEx over the next three years  including spend on rail. We'll spend about $2.2 billion on replacement mines over the same period, and starting in  2009, we expect to see spending coming through for the Koodaideri mine.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: One of the advantages of a strong balance sheet is the ability to drive future returns. When we make capital  allocation decisions we ensure that we only fund the best projects. During 2017, we reduced our net debt to $3.8  billion, a 60% reduction from the end of the previous year. Two things we want to point out here that are factored  into our thinking. The first is $1.9 billion on market Rio Tinto plc-share buyback program announced in September  2017 following the Coal & Allied divestment. This portion of that buyback will be completed by the end of this year.  There's $1.9 billion to spend there.

texts.speaker: Christopher J. Lynch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: And then we did the off-market buyback in Rio Tinto Limited of $0.6 billion related to the Coal & Allied proceeds.  That was also completed in November of 2017. The $2.5 billion supplementary buyback was split between Rio  Tinto Limited and plc on the weighting of the DLC as you'll see on the next slide. $1.9 billion of that remains to be  completed this year.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The Party Congress restated its focus on environmental performance starting with the steel industry. This has  resulted in high premiums for our product such has our Pilbara blend. Longer term, the Belt Road initiative will  create further opportunities in the infrastructure and construction space.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Let's take a look at steel fundamentals in more detail. This chart shows that we can expect to see around a 5%  reduction in steel capacity in China due to supply side reforms in 2017 and 2018. In addition, further reductions in  capacity will occur over the winter period as a result of environmental policy impacts. This is good news for Rio  Tinto's Pilbara blend, which meets the high-quality requirements of our Chinese customers.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Let's turn to Aluminum. We remain very positive about demand. We see annual growth of around 4%, and we  expect this trend to continue over the next 15 years. This is underpinned by growth in the transport sector with the  uptake in electric vehicles.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: More significantly, over the medium-to-longer term, we expect China to be broadly balanced in aluminium, which  creates significant implication for supply from the rest of the world. This could be a turning point for the aluminium  industry, for which we are uniquely positioned with our 2.3 million tonnes hydro-powered Canadian smelters. And,  of course, we remain optimistic about copper because of constrained supply and rising demand from  electrifications.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Our position in both sides provides attractive growth options which we can trigger when there is market demand.  Our first-quartile smelters in Canada are the most profitable and energy-efficient in the industry, with attractive  brownfield options. In Copper, we have large high-quality expandable resources at Oyu Tolgoi and potentially  resolution. Copper is the primary area of focus for exploration teams. And the high-quality energy and minerals  portfolio has already shown its capability to increase supply into a growing market.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: OT is one of the few copper growth projects in the world. The Underground Project is 18 months into a five-year  program and is well on track. I saw it for myself last month and the progress is pretty impressive. I spent time with  the Prime Minister and we're working with the government of Mongolia to strengthen the relationship.

file: RIO - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 27February2019 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In summary, we generated $18.1 billion of EBITDA with a strong merging of 42%, and we delivered cash of $11.8  billion from our operations. We achieved $8.6 billion in assets sales, the divestment of coal and Grasberg adding  to our sustainability credentials.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Today, we are the only large mining company with no coal or oil and gas in our portfolio. And we also invested  $5.4 billion in a world-class portfolio. We generated a return on capital employed of 19%. AutoHaul is now  running. We have progressed Oyu Tolgoi and Amrun, and we found a promising new mineralization – copper  mineralization that we knew in Australia. More on that later on.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Now, let me turn to safety and sustainability. But before I talk about Rio, I would like to acknowledge the sad loss  of life at Minas Gerais in Brazil. This is an absolute tragedy and also a dark moment for the entire industry. It's the  responsibility of everyone in this industry to do better. At Rio Tinto, across 32 operations, we have 100 tailing  facilities and 36 that are no longer active. We take management of all of them very, very seriously. Since 2015,  we have had a global tailings standard, which is regularly reviewed. This standard applies to every Rio Tinto site  worldwide.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The second level of protection to the Rio Tinto standard is through business conformances audit and technical  reviews supported by our Surface Mining Centre of Excellence. And then the third level includes an external audit  program. If you like more details, they are available on our website including our standards and our guidance  notes.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Sustainability is absolutely vital in the 21st century where we must be part of the solution. In 2018, we progress  our sustainability agenda. For example, today, we published our first climate change report, which outline the  risks and opportunities to our business in the transition to a low carbon future. The materials we produce are  essential to this transition from the aluminum in your phone, cars and in airplanes to the iron ore in the buildings  we see every day.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: We continue to take steps to reduce emission from our oil footprint as we innovate with customers to develop  greener products like what we are doing with our new technology partnership for aluminum with Alcoa and  supported by Apple. And we have a portfolio free of coal and oil and gas. We are well-positioned to thrive in the  world that values sustainability more and more.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The iron ore price was supported by robust demand from both inside and outside of China. China steel production  reached a record level of 930 million tonnes last year, and we saw a particularly strong demand in China for  higher quality iron ore such as ours, driven by environmental policy and steel sector reforms.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Global seaborne supply was essentially flat year-on-year as producers experienced higher levels of disruptions  that we haven't seen for a number of years, in total, around 40 million tonnes. And so we saw stable iron ore  pricing, 4% lower than in 2017.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In copper, we experienced good price conditions in the first half of the year, but a weakening price environment in  the second half as supply outgrew demand. This was mainly because the major copper producing assets  generated a better output than what we have seen for many years. Unlike iron ore, there barely were any  significant supply disruptions, 3% against the historical average supply percent. Despite that second half, on  average, copper prices were 6% higher in 2018 than in 2017. So in summary, a quite benign pricing environment  in 2018.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The volumes and product mix added $0.9 billion. Energy prices went up significantly last year and raw materials  prices went up even higher, particularly for aluminum. But because of our growth, we could absorb these cost  headwinds to deliver strong and consistent earnings.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Excluding our coal assets, we generated EBITDA of $17.2 billion at a margin of 41%. Strong EBITDA turns into  strong underlying earnings of $8.8 billion after primarily deducting depreciation and tax. Our IFRS net earnings  was $13.6 billion, equivalent to 30% return on capital employed. That, of course, also includes profits from our  divestments. Our effective tax rate of our underlying result was 29%, in line with our earlier guidance of 30%.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Also, for our world-class assets to continue to deliver at their full potential, we must invest in them. This means  investing both in sustaining CapEx and replacement projects, such as the recently approved $2.6 billion  Koodaideri project, which will add 43 million tonnes capacity in phase 1 and open up a whole new prosperous  area in the Pilbara.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Now to Aluminium. Despite higher prices and stable operations, the performance our Aluminium business was  squeezed by inflation in raw materials and energy cost of $0.5 billion. And we also had the impact from our legacy  contracts of another $0.45 billion.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: External events such as China's environmental policy changes and restructuring of the aluminum industry  resulted in a reduction in supply. Also, the potential for trade tariffs and proposed sanctions created considerable  uncertainty and unusual price movements.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Despite all of this, we have some of the best aluminum assets in the industry and the most integrated ones with  bauxite mines, refineries and smelters. This is reflected in our industry-leading EBITDA margin.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: In 2018, we actually strengthened our aluminum portfolio. We made great progress at Amrun project six weeks  ahead of schedule and below budget. We also divested Dunkerque and land at Kitimat at attractive prices. Our  focus in 2019 will be on delivering additional free cash flow from improved productivity.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: The outlook for 2019 is production of 550,000 tonnes to 600,000 tonnes of mined copper. The top of the range is  similar to 2018 when you exclude the divested Grasberg asset. The reason for the lower guidance is because we  do expect to see a lower grade at the open pit at Oyu Tolgoi and at Kennecott.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: During 2018, we made good progress on our underground project at Oyu Tolgoi. And we closed 2018 by meeting  our commitment to agree a power solution for the mine, which we are now focusing.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: As we learn more about the rock mass around and under the orebody, we continue to encounter geotech  challenges. This is a complex project. And we have indicated a further delay to the main production shaft. And we  will continue to assess the mine plan and design.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Our E&M group went through significant changes in 2018. We divested our remaining Australian coal assets for  over $4 billion. And let me just repeat what JS said, for the first time in 60 years, we have not taken coal out of the  ground. We are the only major miner no longer involved in extracting fossil fuels. We also agreed to sell our share  of our Uranium business in Namibia. With these divestments, we will now have a more simplified business with  really high-quality assets.

texts.speaker: Jakob Stausholm
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Due to strong cash flow and the $8.6 billion of cash received from divestments, primarily coal assets and  Grasberg, our balance sheet moved to a net cash or $0.3 billion at the end of 2018. However, we should  acknowledge that some cash has already been allocated. And from the beginning of January 2019, we recognize  an additional $1.2 billion of net debt related to operating leases with the changes to IFRS 16. Hence, the pro  forma net debt is around $8 billion. This is still a low level. And that has been recognized only three weeks ago  when Moody's upgraded us to A2 that complements our A rating from Standard & Poor's.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Turning to our value-over-volume strategy, it's about portfolio, performance, people, partners. Portfolio is about  world-class assets. Here, we will focus on delivering on average of 2% growth per annum over the next five years.  Performance is about operating and commercial excellence. We will focus first and foremost on safety. We will  drive greater productivity and exit 2019 with $1 billion run rate from our productivity program. This is an additional  $600 million of free cash flow. And we will make sure the benefits of our commercial [ph] excision (00:30:26) are  fully realized. People, it's about developing industry-leading capabilities. We will focus on building our technical  skills and engaging with our workforce. And partners is about long-term relationships. It's about sustainability with  a strong focus on engaging host governments, communities and employees will all hear the agenda including  climate change.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Before I close, let me cover one of our priorities in more details, growth. As you've heard, we have been investing  in our existing business and we have exciting growth projects already underway in iron ore, in copper and in  bauxite. We are progressing other options. For example, on Resolution, our copper project in Arizona, we are  spending $368 million in infrastructure as we progress the permitting process. We are on track to complete the  EIS in 2020. In exploration, which is the upstream part of our pipeline, we have over 50 projects underway. We  have activity in over 8 communities and 16 countries. We plan to spend around $250 million in exploration this  year only.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Copper remains the bulk of our exploration spend, and we have a number of exciting opportunities. One of them  is Winu that I mentioned earlier. It is early days, and we have more work to do. But the initial results from the first  phase of drilling are pretty encouraging. We just disclosed the results of the first 24 drill holes that you can see on  this slide. As you can see, there is copper, there is gold, there is silver. And I'm really looking forward to the  second phase, and we will keep you updated.

texts.speaker: Jean-Sébastien Jacques
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rio Tinto Plc
texts.text: Our recent track record speaks for itself, with $29 billion return – being returned to our shareholders over three  years, including $13.5 billion declared for 2018 only. We have a world-class portfolio, well-positioned for a low  carbon future. We have the strongest balance sheets in the sector, and we are progressing exciting growth  options. We will continue to deliver on our promises day in and day out.

texts.speaker: Bart Becht, Chief Executive Officer

texts.speaker: Bart Becht, Chief Executive Officer
