How do we actually get fantastic  results without the hassle that sometimes it has, the complication it has.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So what we've actually done is launched what is called Spawax. You get the result that you get in a spa, a  professional salon because the container that you've seen from the view can actually heats the wax to the exact  right level so it's designed to heat it at the right level. And then we give people wax discs so that they can put the  wax, the heating at the right level and gives you the right conditions with a spatula to use it and get professional  wax results at home. So I think it's very interesting technology in how we actually achieved that and would be a  good initiative for Veet in 2015.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And when you actually interrogate our cost, I see the equation somewhat like this. Our COGS clearly have been  coming down over a number of years, and that's good. So that's why it's [indiscernible] (1:12:45). Our BEI has  been going up and that's good, even though you might call it as a cost. But our non-BEI cost, everything else is  actually going up. It is going up total of non-BEI. That includes other marketing by the way, non-BEI marketing.  What we pay for POS material and how we buy it and how many times we buy it, and whether it's actually fully  gets used or not get used. All of this stuff when you actually look at it altogether, it's gone up. And therein lies the  opportunity. Therein lies the opportunity.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Okay. So before I get to my final messages for the day, let me start talking about the KPIs. And this is something to  be taken into with the new organization in mind, you might remember when we started our 2011 journey, we had  67% of our business in Health and Hygiene. I don't know some of you might remember, 66% – two-thirds. And we  are already three-fourths, and we hope to be eight-tenths or four-fifths of our business being Health and Hygiene.  So we still believe that we are going to progressively become a Health and Hygiene company over 2020.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So we basically used 1% per year mathematics to actually think about our KPI. So that's how we feel, high growth  from Health and Hygiene because it is also virtuous because some of the gross margin expansion you've seen over  the last three years comes also from mix, not just from squeeze or fuel or cost-saving initiatives. And that's an  important part of our model.

file: RKTL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 15February2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Of course, there is a real stakeholder in terms of how we look after the environment we operate in and whether we  can be responsible to the environment that we live in today, so that we can keep our future generations also  prosperous and free from all the challenges of a world that has environmental challenges. And finally, of course,  I'm reminded everyday that we need to deliver better financials. We need to deliver better financials.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: There's a couple of other programs we do, some on more ad hoc basis like the one I'm going to describe on Zika,  but also on some more far-reaching programs that we've championed with Dettol in India. As you know, Prime  Minister Modi came and said that he wants to see a cleaner India, probably much more – both physically and  probably in modern ways too. But we have in Dettol, taken that very seriously and been a massive force in this  whole program, which I will also describe to you.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Better environment, another thing that we haven't really talked about. But let's take a look at the kind of programs  we have in the company. How do we deal with a better environment? The first thing we're doing is I think you've  heard about the Carbon20 program, which means that we look at the end-to-end impact of our carbon and this is  a commitment to reduce our carbon impact by one-third by 2020.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: But beyond that carbon impact, we're talking about water reduction, we're talking about how do we actually make  sure that our – there's a program called Race to Zero, which means zero hazardous and non-hazardous waste to  landfill by 2016. End of 2016, all our factories will have zero hazardous and non-hazardous waste to the landfill.  That's a fantastic program.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Another program which makes sure that with every innovation, we find that we are making it more sustainable.  But beyond that, you do all these programs and say, well, are we doing something which is interesting. And I'm  very, very, very pleased to say that actually RB is one of the – probably the most – one of the most decorated  companies, if I may say so, in terms of external recognition. We've been recognized by leading indices, clearly,  FTSE4Good, Carbon Disclosure Project, Dow Jones Sustainability Index. But more recently, we've actually been  awarded one of the top 10 companies in the world and the top company in the UK in terms of sustainability.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, the green sustainability awards from both Newsweek, which is a respectable benchmark, and also another  such benchmark which gave us basically one of the most sustainable companies. And that tells us that we are  making a difference, we're doing something which is really good. So, better society, better environment. They're all  very important. But you are not here, I'm quite sure, to talk about society, environment. You're here to talk about  financials.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Okay. So, that's how the financials are. Is the model working? Is the model virtuous? It is absolutely very virtuous.  Gross margin increased by 140 basis points, a combination of things driving that. There is some tailwinds in terms  of commodity, but also our own programs in driving fuel, our flat programs to make sure that our mix is working,  and of course, the whole strategy is driving better mix so I think that should not be a matter of surprise. And then  you've got efficiency programs. The efficiency program that I have described and I'm going to come back to from  Supercharged, 50 basis points off in our – excluding BEI line of all the rest of the SG&A.

texts.speaker: Adrian N. Hennah
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Does this mean we think that there is margin improvement to be found in BEI? That the substantial efficiency  improvements that we're achieving in the way we spend our BEI can drop to the bottom line?

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, the first example is already something I alluded to. This is an example of a program for a cleaner India  championed by the Prime Minister, and here he is on the podium in front of Dettol. No other brand can achieve  that. Okay?

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, that's fantastic, what we've been able to do with Scholl. And, therefore, my second example, of course, is what  this product is. Now, people tell us that our previous launch did not work and it did not work in wet conditions.  So, some women, actually, or men, prefer to remove their [ph] hard skin (41:35) when they're wet, with wet feet.  Wet their feet and then do it. And the previous product doesn't work.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: This one works also in wet condition. But beyond that, it also comes with a charger button, so it's not with battery - operated. It comes with charger button, works on wet and dry feet. It's a fantastic product. It's going to market  and it's going into your goodie bag. So hopefully, you like it.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Moving from Dettol to Lysol. And in my opinion, this is one of the more material innovations we've done in the  disinfectant spray although it's a very different [ph] world innovator (45:22). Which is we do know that people use  disinfectant sprays on large surfaces, but not just large surfaces, some soft surfaces too, like mattresses and like  your pillow covers and stuff like that. And you need to have the right product which can be right for these soft  surfaces, but also you need a product that works really rapidly to cover those surfaces, but sometimes also the  nooks and crannies that you can't normally spray.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, this is a wide max cover mist which in three seconds you can actually have a king-size mattress disinfected.  Three seconds. That's the power of this spray, and we're very excited about this one too.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Anyway, moving on from Barry Scott to Powerball, and the challenge here is very simple, which is that we are  moving to phosphate-free products in Europe. Finish is going to be phosphate-free in Europe. And when you have  phosphate-free products, we all know that the cleaning performance is compromised and it's not very easy to get  the same high level of cleaning with phosphate-free products. And that's what Supercharged Powerball is all  about; supercharging the performance of the product and yet having it phosphate-free.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, this is what is going into Europe but also a number of markets across the world, and we are very happy [ph]  And it's also doing a massive (49:36) redesign and a new campaign behind it. So, Finish is going to have a big – at  least a technical upgrade, but also an environmental upgrade in 2016.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In my personal opinion, this could be the best innovation in aerosols in 10 years.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, moving to another one in Air Wick, and we know this category for a long time and we know that people love air  fresheners, particularly these electrical products, [ph] so there by (51:11) the large homes or small homes. Some  like it more strong and sometimes like it weak. And we were tempted in the past to give some kind of a control,  where you can control the fragrance level. But actually, believe it, no control products actually work. They don't  really actually control the amount of fragrance. It's tough to actually get there.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, in line with maybe all the things that we want to do in life, get healthier, what these people did was to [ph]  interrogate (52:47) all formulas – all the formulas in our business in 2015 and took out all artificial flavors,  preservatives, fillers, colors, made them gluten-free and to redesign them and put them with the promise of real  ingredients, nothing artificial, great tastes. And beyond that, there's a program to actually help 11 million meals –  serve 11 million meals for free. To help communities and so on and so forth.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, it's a fantastic relaunch of the entire, I would say, French's line behind the green promise – or not green  promise, I would say, healthy promise – healthy-eating promise. And they have a wonderful plan to take this  forward.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And actually, if you just take a look at the market-leading products in ketchup – let's just take ketchup as an  example – take the market-leading products, you'll find some tomatoes of course, but you'll also find high fructose  sugar, corn syrup and so on and so forth. Okay? We've taken high-fructose corn syrup out and still have fantastic  tasting products.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So really, there's a huge commitment to having healthy eating and to have greener products and better products  for you with the promise of the French's brand, and I think this is going to be also appreciated. I already see some  good signs that people love to see French's being the leader of this very significant position in the market.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, that's how I feel about one part. The other part was, of course, to supercharge the earnings model from a waste  and cost reduction point of view, because we've always said that there is that juice in the lemon. Don't forget this  visual. And you can give me the squeezed, most squeezed lemon, and I'm going to take out some juice from it, too.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: But we did say at that time, our ambition is not to become the very best in the world when it comes to cost. Our  ambition is to right size it for RB and to find that treasure hunt. The waste is there, where we can take waste out of  the company.

file: RKTL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call Acquisition of Mead Johnson 10February2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: I refer to our earnings model, and I've always said actually to you all that our earnings model in this company  starts with gross margin. So, this is the normal earnings model slide I present to you every year. And if you start  with gross margin expansion in 2016, our gross margin increased by 180 basis point, which is an excellent result.  Clearly, all the drivers of our gross margin were fully ignited. Input costs were favorable. We took advantage of  our usual Project Fuel programs, the mix improvement, the pricing, all of them came to bear to give us 180 basis  points of gross margin expansion.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: So, the first one, let me just take straight away, is Korea. And when it comes to Korea, I cannot begin to tell you  anything without, once again, reiterating my apology for what has happened for the harm and damage that our  Humidifier Sanitizer, our Oxy's Humidifier Sanitizer, caused to families and individuals in Korea. And you know  that we've taken a huge number of steps over the last 12 months and I just wanted to recap some of them.

texts.speaker: Adrian N. Hennah
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: Events have made it somewhat more abrupt, so be it. We are pleased that we are developing the footcare  segment with energy and prefer to accept the slightly higher volatility that comes with this approach rather than  take a more conservative, if also smoother, approach.

texts.speaker: Adrian N. Hennah
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: With regard to Round 4 applicants, the Korean Ministry of Environment in its press release dated the 13th of  January noted that 4,059 applicants had registered – had applied, that is. The Ministry of Environment has said  that it also expects all Round 4 applicants to be categorized by the end of 2017.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: So, marine minerals is something which is associated with the exfoliating, and we're adding marine mineral rollers  to make sure that the hard skin removal that you have is not just removing the functional part of hard skin but also  offers you the exfoliating benefits, a fantastic product. And, of course, taking from the learning, this does not come  with a price increase, you will be happy to note. So, innovation without price increase, you can't better than that.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: By the way, now you have our first-ever actually self-care kit, comes with two things, one is the aerosol, which  relieves your pain and creates basically a hygienic nail, and then you use a clip, actually a clip which removes the  nail from the skin. So, actually, you get immediate relief from your pain and suffering on ingrown toenails.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: And when they have fever, you don't even know what time the fever actually peaks up or shoots up, and how do  you actually know when to provide, what type of medication, when to go to an [FCP], and actually our work tells  us that a large percentage of people – I saw some data which says more than 80% of the people actually don't  manage to monitor their temperature, particularly when it spikes up and find out when to actually do something  about it.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: So, the first thing we do here is to launch this very, very – how should I say – integrated end-to-end device, which  allows people to put a very safe hypoallergenic patch on the child's body. It's wirelessly connected to your mobile  phone. And it monitors real-time the temperature of your child. It tells you even in the middle of the night with a  beep when the fever goes beyond a certain point, at which point in time you want to be alerted. And then, also  tells you what kind of choices you have to medicate your child.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: So, this is, I think, a very exciting example of how, and I can go on and paint the story of how you can connect it  really into a in-store solution, how you can connect it to healthcare professionals in terms of the connection, how  you can make sure that you have temperature charts to tell you how the fever moves and progresses over the  number of days so that actually people can see patterns and so and so forth. So, this is actually a very, very  exciting innovation and an example where you move beyond just the product into area of innovative solutions,  which is how we also describe the vision and purpose of the company. And it's the first-ever example of a  connected innovation that we're launching and this is why I find it particularly interesting. And we are looking at all  these kinds of areas to expand the way RB can innovate beyond chemistry and beyond products using the power  of digital and technology in the future. And I do hope in time, we will have many examples like this in our  innovation pipeline.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: So, moving on from here to Hygiene and I thought I should talk about something which I have personally actually  witnessed. I was in India in November, just after this fantastic festival of lights which we call Diwali, and there's  huge amount of crackers. I think now you also have crackers here. It's mostly on Guy Fawkes Day. But Diwali  also is a big event, actually, mostly in Northern India but also many parts of India. And when you go – I mean, I  was there two days after Diwali, and there was smoke inside the hotel I was living in.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: And for the very first time I saw people wearing masks in India, I never saw them before. Now, believe it or not,  you'll think that air pollution, air quality is an issue which happens in Beijing or even New Delhi now. I saw an  article which says London has air pollution, air quality issues, air pollution and air quality issue in western  countries. Yet in China, where it's such a big problem, only 5% of the people use masks.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: And the reason is very simple, try wearing a mask and you can't breathe. You can't breathe. So, you can wear a  mask but then you can't breathe properly. So, the wonderful thing about this mask actually is not only in terms of  technology and in terms of purity reductions, et cetera, it's the top end of the mask that also comes with a  ventilator and a fan, which means all the carbon monoxide and other issues that can affect your breathability can  be taken care of.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: So, we've launched this now in China to start with, but also on digital channels in a number of other markets to  make sure that we can bring the solution across the wide number of people, which is a very, very wide issue, and  I do believe air quality, air pollution is an issue which we will see much more of in times to come.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: Moving on from Dettol masks to much more mainstream Dettol products. This is a very exciting innovation with a  very simple benefit, 100% better skin protection. It again comes with, let's call it exfoliating beads, the kind of  things that I've talked about in Scholl, with scrubbing beads, which actually work deep within your skin pores to  get rid of dirt, pollutants, and germs that cause skin irritation. So, this is a significantly better product in terms of  skin benefits launching into developing markets.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: First of all, parents want to protect their children out of home, not only in home. So they want something children  can use which is skin-safe. And the active ingredient we are using here, picaridin, is a safer alternative to the  most popular active ingredient called DEET. And the second thing this active ingredient does is the protection is  twice as long versus DEET. So it's a significantly better product in terms of long-lasting protection, but also a safer  product to use on skin for children. So, we are very excited about this launch going into Brazil and into 2017.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: Moving on from Hygiene to Home, I'm going to take you to just two of these innovations that are in the pipeline.  The first one is on Air Wick. Now a couple of years ago, I talked to you about the launch of Air Wick Pure  aerosols. In fact, I showed you the advertising, 100% fragrance, no water. And that actually – launched in  aerosols. That launch has done very well.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: So, this Pure aerosol segment has actually become a very interesting and important segment for Air Wick  aerosols across the geographies we've launched it in. So, actually, Air Wick Freshmatic Pure is nothing but taking  that benefit of Pure fragrance into our very important and large segment of the market, which is the Freshmatic  segment, but it also comes with the launch of a new gadget which is a better designed gadget and also has more  control and many more features than the previous one.

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: Now, this is all I have to say about targets for the time being and maybe we can come back to this in Q&A, but let  me just actually now do a very quick summary of our strategy for the last five years, because I did say that five  years ago, we launched a new strategy or strategy based on healthier lives, happier homes; a strategy based on  focusing on Powerbrands in Health and Hygiene.

file: RKTL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 19February2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Executive Director & President, RB Health Business Unit, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: And just to remind you what those inorganic parts have looked like, you know brands like Nurofen, which – we put  this beautiful air freshener that I'm going to talk about so close to me. No. It's okay. It's nice. The fragrance is  great, but -.

texts.speaker: Adrian N. Hennah
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: Increases in BEI in 2016 under MJN leadership were described at the time of acquisition, a necessary recovery  from a period of underinvestment, and this continued in half one of this year. The 100 basis points reduction in  BEI in half two does not, of course, reflect any reduction focus on BEI. It reflects annualizing a heavy period of  spend in MJN and it reflects an increased focus on efficiency, which we are together bringing.

texts.speaker: Adrian N. Hennah
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: Specifically, we are at present seeing some commodity cost headwinds. We do not expect these to improve  materially in aggregate in the short term, notwithstanding the comment specifically on dairy cost a couple of  moments ago. And we are also in a phase of tougher price pressure with our established retail customers facing  substantial structural change. We absolutely do not see this as a long-term pressure, but we also do not see it  going away in the very short term. We do not expect our internal efficiency programs to be able to offset fully  these commodity cost and price pressures in 2018.

file: RKTL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 18February2019 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Rakesh Kapoor
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: The last bit I wanted to talk to you about was the unleashing of Hygiene Home, because of course when I grew  up, in RB, we had Hygiene Home and we had Vanish and Air Wick and Finish and Mortein. And clearly, we were  not doing as well as we wanted to. And it's not something that we realized at the end of 2017 and this is like, well,  let's wake up and do something about it. It was just not possible to create RB 2.0 without Mead Johnson. We  needed that infrastructure, the catalyst, the footprints to be able to do that and create sustainable business units.

texts.speaker: Aditya Sehgal
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Health, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: Moving onto another iconic power brand, Dettol is a much-loved iconic brand across a large part of the world. It's  the number one family protection disinfection hygiene brand in the world. It's a massive, massive brand which we  all love. We are re-launching this brand for the first time in over 10 years with new branding. We are also re- launching our portfolio of personal wash products starting with Southeast Asia with more natural ingredients  derived from nature while retaining the same germ kill and efficacy and protection that Dettol is known for. But it's  not just that, we've also been working very hard on products that are great for consumers and also great for the  environment, and we are just about to launch a new wipe – a new Dettol multi-surface wipe which is made from  100% biodegradable plant fibers, and these wipes will kill 99.9% of bacteria and they are plastic-free.

texts.speaker: Aditya Sehgal
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Health, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: And we have all kinds of channels and models, things that you have not heard about. So I am going to – forgive  me, I am going to lapse into some jargon here, but I am going to tell you a list of channels and models that we are  working in China. So we are doing B2C, C2C, marketplace, cross-border, D2C, O2O, P2P, B2B2C, OMO,  S2B2C. These are all – each of these, trust me, is different, needs expertise, and RB either has a business or it  has a test going on in each of these.

texts.speaker: Aditya Sehgal
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Health, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: So I talked about sustainable growth, and I talked about how RB 2.0 has set us up so that we can deliver and  drive sustainable growth. But for a great company, and I'm sure you will agree with this, it is not enough to have  sustainable growth. We need to have sustainable margins as well. And there's been a lot of talk and discussions  about our margins and the sustainability of those margins. And today I'm going to explain to you exactly why our  margins are sustainable.

texts.speaker: Aditya Sehgal
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Health, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: So, Gaviscon is the one on the left here and you've got an ordinary antacid on the right. The way the ordinary  antacid works is by neutralizing the pH of your stomach acid, and that works quite well. The way Gaviscon Double  Action works is by doing the same. And then on top, what Gaviscon does is it creates this raft, this white raft that  you see on top. This raft comes from a very special ingredient known as alginate. Alginate comes from algae,  which is like seaweed, seaweed kind of floats on the top of water. This is highly concentrated, very well-sourced  product with great secret sauce in how we make it, which actually floats on the top of your stomach acid. This  means that you've neutralized the acid, but it also stops any chance of it coming back into esophagus. So,  Gaviscon has two actions. It lasts for twice as long as the ordinary antacid, so 2x mode of action, 2x duration, only  1.5x price. Therefore, great value, yet premium.

texts.speaker: Robert de Groot
texts.profession: President-Hygiene Home, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: In the UK, one out of two consumers does not have a dishwasher. Now, project yourself 50 years ahead from  now. Do you still think that people are going to do the dishes by hand while there are dish solutions which are so  much superior than doing the dishes by hand, not only from a cleaning perspective, but also from a sustainability  perspective. But you don't only have to compare hand dish and machine dish. You can also go within a category.  Take a category like air care. Air care, the aerosol that everybody will have in a bathroom, has a high penetration,  yet captive systems, like Freshmatic, or like oils, Electrical Oils, have a much lower penetration. So it's not only a  category play, it's also within the category which segments you decide to play is very relevant here.

texts.speaker: Robert de Groot
texts.profession: President-Hygiene Home, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: When you start doing laundry, you don't have a lot of disposable income, you probably have a soap bar and you  do the laundry that way. Then you move up to laundry powder. At a certain point of time, you realize that stains  don't go out, so you use another product that you have in a household on top, which is bleach. But then you  realize that there's actually a better solution as well, which is not only bleaching, but is also safe to use for your  clothes and you trade up to fabric treatments.

texts.speaker: Robert de Groot
texts.profession: President-Hygiene Home, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: So also here you see that the premium segment is growing much faster than value. And the overrepresentation  that we have in the premium segment on Hygiene Home is even more than what we saw in the healthcare part.  And how that comes to life, for example, in air care is that each time that consumer benefits are increasing, there  are better solutions being brought to consumers at higher price points. So from an aerosol to an automatic  aerosol to actually the Essential Mist, which is not only automatic, but is also filled with essential oils and they  actually create moods. So they actually work on your neuro systems, and they therefore can determine if your  mood is going to be on the relaxing side or on the uplifting side, depending on the fragrance that you're using.

texts.speaker: Robert de Groot
texts.profession: President-Hygiene Home, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: These innovations and these decisions of what segments you play, they also have an impact on the margin. So  the margin difference between Vanish fabric treatment and a laundry detergent powder is more than 2,000 basis  points. The difference between Finish monodose and our hand wash is more than 2,000 basis points. And also  within segments, if I take the product that I was just talking about, the Essential Mist, and our competitors with  base aerosol, the margin difference is more than 2,000 basis points.

texts.speaker: Robert de Groot
texts.profession: President-Hygiene Home, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: And therefore, we started working on a vision, a vision that supports that purpose, that company purpose. And  this is the vision, is create a cleaner world. Now, here you think that also create a cleaner world is kind of a nice  marketing sentence, and you're right. You're actually right. It comes only to life once you really understand the  three missions that are underneath on this page. And I want to take you a little bit through, because I'm really  passionate about it and so is my business unit.

texts.speaker: Robert de Groot
texts.profession: President-Hygiene Home, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: So it's eliminating dirt, pests, germs, odors that impact your health and your happiness. But then if you have this  beautiful product portfolio, what else can you do with that? And that brings me to the second mission, which is to  accelerate the hygiene foundations across the world. Our brands can mean so much more. I give you an  example, Harpic. Harpic is our toilet cleaning brand and is the leading toilet cleaning brand in India. And what we  have created there is something that goes far beyond just cleaning toilets.

texts.speaker: Robert de Groot
texts.profession: President-Hygiene Home, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: The third mission is about delivering sustainable outperformance and outperformance is something that I think it  will not be a surprise. Sustainable is, obviously, a beautiful English word that has a double meaning that says that  – and you have to do it every time, but at the same time you also have to do it in a way that takes care of this  world and makes it a more sustainable place.

texts.speaker: Robert de Groot
texts.profession: President-Hygiene Home, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: Another example that we're super excited about, to really stop diseases that are borne by mosquitoes, and this is  a Brazil example. So you can see this purpose coming to life, on multiple brands, Lysol, Harpic, SBP, across the  world and taking a meaning social cause. And what this does, it also engages very much the organization, the  HyHo organization. We asked people like, are you excited to be part of Hygiene Home? Are you confident that we  can create a cleaner world? Are we actually faster and more entrepreneurial? And are we at the frontline?

texts.speaker: Robert de Groot
texts.profession: President-Hygiene Home, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: But also our big brands have bigger innovation in 2019 and some of them are displayed here, so you can have a  look later. These are our large brands and I want to pick out one, which is Vanish. The Vanish gel with Oxi Action  is quite an evolution in today's world. I'm not sure you've realized, but your laundry detergent has removed all of  the bleachable actives out of the ingredients. So what we're doing now as consumers is we're washing at lower  temperatures, which is very good, and we're not using a laundry detergent that has any bleach power. And here  Finish kicks in and now in your favorite form, which is the liquid, you also have the Oxi Action power to add to  your laundry detergent. So all your bleachable stains like coffee, tea, wine comes out.

texts.speaker: Robert de Groot
texts.profession: President-Hygiene Home, Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc
texts.text: But we're also serving new needs; new needs like consumers want to have absence of harshness, absence of  harsh ingredients. So both the brands Vanish and Finish are launching a lineup of 0% unnecessary ingredients  while they have 100% performance. And last, definitely not least, we're continuing our journey on the purpose.  We're continuing the journey to transform more communities on SBP in Brazil, to place more toilets into India, and  actually maybe in the next speech we talk about more activities that we do in India about building a whole toilet  economy.

We want to  make beautiful objects in beautiful workshops. And our CapEx on our workshops are fairly large because there's a  lot that goes into the architectural project on top of all of the efforts that we make with Olivier Fournier for  sustainable development. file: RNO - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 28July2011 215 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Dominique Thormann
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: Good morning, everyone. As you all have already seen from the headlines, the group's financial results for the first  half of 2011 show that the first six months of our mid-term plan are in line with its objectives considering the  harsher environment that we operated in.

texts.speaker: Dominique Thormann
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: The cost of raw materials caused a negative impact of €313 million. This impact is worse than our initial guidance  in February, which is something that I pointed out to you as a risk when I presented Q1 revenues. This on-cost  relates to the steel contracts signed in July 1, 2010, which took a further increase on January 1 of this year, as well  as higher impacts from indexed raw materials and oil-based products.

texts.speaker: Dominique Thormann
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: For the next part of the walk down, we have grouped four items which together form the major part of our  Monozukuri cost reduction efforts announced during the strategic plan presentation Renault '16 – Drive The  Change.

texts.speaker: Dominique Thormann
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: As our sales mix outside of Europe expands, this is increasing the level of natural stock due to the longer supply  chain. However, this does not completely explain the difference above and beyond the one-time impact, such as  our new distribution scheme in China, inventory management was negatively impacted by the tsunami.

texts.speaker: Carlos Tavares
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: Of course, on the downside, the quake that hit Japan in March has had a disastrous impact on the car industry  and has aggravated pre-existing supply constraints impacting our company. These constraints have in return  impacted negatively our European commercial performance where we have not been able to produce enough cars  to meet the demand. It has also forced us to adjust the mix of models produced, namely gasoline versus diesel and  increased incentives in order to align demand levels to what we could supply.

texts.speaker: Carlos Tavares
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: We estimate that the lost opportunity totaled 50,000 units, and in order to maintain the production levels, we  choose to distort our mix by producing cars where the supply of components were not limited. I would like to take  the example of the 1.5 diesel engine, which normally accounts for 84% of Clio sales in France.

texts.speaker: Carlos Tavares
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: The tsunami also increased our upstream logistic costs in order to find quick replacement alternatives to provide  our plans with the missing parts. For the full year, we estimate that the tsunami and impact – will impact our  profits by €200 million. That tsunami was also impacted working capital due to a rise of inventories. As the  shutdown period for many industrial sites have been brought forward in July, we have had to build stock to cover  the vacation period.

texts.speaker: Carlos Tavares
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: Stock of petrol versions is also higher, as when factories restart, the mix will heavily shift back to diesel. In  addition, there was also an overstocking of 20,000 vehicles due to the teams concentrating on parts availability  rather than strict stock control.

texts.speaker: Carlos Tavares
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: In 2012, capacity investments should reach €150 million enabling a 3.2 million unit capacity per year. Three- quarters of this investments will help increase the powertrain capacity with the remaining quarter of our – for our  vehicle production capacity.

texts.speaker: Carlos Tavares
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: Let me give you a concrete example. In order to improve our response to the strong 1.5 dCi powertrain demand,  we have increased our production by 100,000 units per year in the last three years, from 900,000 units in 2008 to  an expected 1,200,000 engines in 2011. In 2012, we expect our output to increase by another 70,000 units.

texts.speaker: Carlos Tavares
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: The €279 million savings in the first half are the result of thousands of improvements of part processes, product  content across our line-up. Each single action helps reduce our TDC by a few cents of euros per vehicle. For  instance, on Scénic, the Douai plant decided to integrate the anti-corrosion treatment of several [indiscernible]  parts. It leads to a cost increase of €0.65 per vehicle for the plant. But it also allows a €5 per car purchase cost  reduction since the suppliers no longer need to process these parts through anti-corrosion. For the full year, the

texts.speaker: Carlos Tavares
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: We are expecting a similarly high success as the one we enjoy in Europe. By the end of next year, we will also have  localized production in Russia, India and Colombia. The second half of 2011 will mark a real breakthrough in the  automotive industry with the first ever electric vehicle sold at the same price as the diesel equivalent. Kangoo ZE  will start sales in October, Fluence ZE in November and Twizy in December. EV is not a bet, it's an insurance for  the future, insurance to be the best in CO2 emission, insurance to have a proper answer to further certain oil price  increases, insurance to stand years ahead of competition in terms of mastering the technology and its costs.

texts.speaker: Carlos Tavares
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: A few hundred electric vehicles are already in customers' hands in Europe for testing, and the feedback we have  from old users is very supportive. Great driving pleasure, little range anxiety, practicality of the home or office  recharging, feeling of doing the right thing for the planet, and this without paying more than a traditional internal  combustion engine.

texts.speaker: Carlos Tavares
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: Raw material prices should remain above the level initially expected in February, taking the full year impact to  €600 million. Additional risks could emerge from further Forex deterioration and the concern on the euro zone  situation.

texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Renault’s 2009 Financial Results. For those of you joining us
texts.text: Also Nissan still has a quarter to go. I can announce to you today that the €1.5 billion target had  already been achieved by the end of December. The implementation of the dedicated Alliance team  within our NBV that I announced in May last year has brought faster, deeper and more sustainable  results than initially foreseen.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Renault’s 2009 Financial Results. For those of you joining us
texts.text: Let me remind you what we consider is synergy. First we have what we call fuel cost saving  synergies. These allow both companies to reduce their cost or capital expenditures compared to  previous year. These synergies can be read directly in both companies’ free cash flow statements.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Renault’s 2009 Financial Results. For those of you joining us
texts.text: The second kind of synergy is cost avoidance. These defined synergies had allowed Alliance to  reduce its costs or capital expenditures compared to a reference scenario, our reference scenario,  not compared to previous year expenses. They can not be read in the free cash flow statements,  but they allow each company to do more with less. For instance, instead of developing its own 1.6  liter diesel engine that existed in the plan of Nissan, Nissan will benefit from Renault’s  development. So the D&D cost plans in Nissan’s budget are avoided.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Renault’s 2009 Financial Results. For those of you joining us
texts.text: Cost avoidance on this project account for €50 million in 2009 for Nissan, while Renault’s entry  ticket is now shared with Nissan and therefore reduced by €20 million. Those are integrated within  the fuel cost saving synergies.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Renault’s 2009 Financial Results. For those of you joining us
texts.text: 9 obviously the mass marketed zero-emission vehicle for which neither Renault or Nissan could have  supported the required expenditures alone.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Renault’s 2009 Financial Results. For those of you joining us
texts.text: Looking at our international projects, the line up renewal, our powertrain improvements or our zero- emission investments all have been carried out on a linear budget. This improvement is now  structurally part of our process. We have learned how to better cross develop project with Nissan.  This experience will bring benefits long after the crisis has past.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director, Investor Relations

texts.text: A key indicator is CapEx and R&D as a percentage of revenues. In 2009, Renault was below 9%.
