If we exclude our commitments to the electric vehicle projects, CapEx and R&D will see a further  decrease. Including the EV development cost, which amount will be €400 million, the level will be  stable versus 2009, without sacrificing our ability to develop new products and the technology that  is crucial for growth and brand enhancement.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Renault’s 2009 Financial Results. For those of you joining us
texts.text: Manufacturers are forced to work together, find innovative solutions in order to stay fully cost  competitive and meet the increasing demand for new products and new technologies. Of particular  concern is the need to respond to regulatory and consumer pressure in the reduction of CO2 and  other tailpipe emissions, and do it in a way which is affordable. In all these fields, product  development, new market expansion, environmental concerns, the lines will once again prove to be  a significant competitive advantage for both partners.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Renault’s 2009 Financial Results. For those of you joining us
texts.text: As for Renault, our priorities are clear. We will pioneer on mass marketed electric cars and continue  to offer low CO2 affordable cars. We will aggressively pursue our sales development in emerging  markets, especially by building on our existing positions such as Russia, Brazil or India. We will  reinforce our leadership on low cost cars with the Logan platform, and our development on the ultra  low cost segment will be part of our international development.

file: RNO - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 10February2011 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: Purchasing savings equaled €528 million in line with the target fixed for the year. The higher cost of  raw materials impacted our accounts by €148 million driven by a negative impact of €260 million in  the second half. Higher steel prices resulting from the renewal of 12 month contracts on July 1st will  continue to have a negative impact into the first half of 2011.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: Carlos Ghosn, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer  Thank you, Mr. Thormann. Good morning ladies and gentlemen. Renault 2010 results were  obtained in a challenging business climate for the industry in Europe. Now we can say clearly that  the crisis is behind us and 2010 proved to be a solid base on which we can now deploy our mid- term plan.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: Our engineering spending has also been optimized. For example the entry ticket of Mégane 3 was  30% lower than the one on Mégane 2. In September 2009, we unveiled Renault’s ambition to make  sustainable mobility affordable for all. This was summed up in our brand baseline ‘Drive the  Change’, which guided us in the building of the strategic plan, I will present to you today. Continuity  is underlined by the name we have chosen for our plan, which is ‘Renault 2016 Drive the Change’.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: Our priority is to ensure that Renault’s core business generates consistent free cash flow. As you  can see on the screen, it is something that Renault has hardly managed to sustain in the past.  Various levers will help us achieve these results. We have indentified seven, which are developing  innovation to face current energy and environmental challenges, renewing and reinforcing our  product offer, strengthening our brand image, enhancing sales power in terms of enhancing  customer experience, optimizing our R&D and investment expenditures, reducing our costs and  maintaining our positions in Europe, while accelerating our international growth. We will be working  on these levers through the next six years.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: I will now consider each one of them in detail with a more in depth analysis of their impact on the  period from 2011 to 2013. Let’s start with innovation, which is a crucial factor in preparing our  future. It’s only by innovating that we can meet the energy and environmental challenges that the  planet is facing. Innovation will enable the car to become a symbol of modernity once again in the  mature markets. In the face of rising oil prices and the need to contain CO2 emissions the solution  is twofold. We must improve the efficiency of internal combustion engines and bring to the market  zero emission vehicles that are accessible to the greatest number of people.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: With regard to internal combustion engine, Renault is already well positioned with the European  range emitting an average of 137 gram of CO2 per kilometer. With 130 horsepower our new energy  1.6 dCi engine will be the most powerful engine on the market in its cubic capacity bracket. And it  will enable our models to reduce their fuel consumption and CO2 emissions by 20%. In May 2011,  Scénic and Grand Scénic will be the first MPVs of this level of performance, to score under 120  gram of CO2 per kilometer with a fuel consumption of 4.5 liters per 100 kilometer, a reduction of 1  liter compared to current comparable versions.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: Furthermore, in 2012 our energy level will be expanded to a new family of petrol engines ranging  from 900 cubic centimeter to 1200 cubic centimeter and developing up to 115 horsepower.  Available in direct injection and fitted with stop and start on the B and C segments, these engines  will enable a 30% reduction of CO2 emissions. Mégane will emit 115 gram of CO2 per kilometer  and should become the first petrol engine hatch in the C segment to fall below the 120 gram mark.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: Our electric vehicle range is our second answer to our planet’s current environmental challenges.  This year marks a decisive chapter in Renault’s history with the launch of the three first electric cars  in our zero emission line-up.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: With Nissan, we are prudent to be present across the entire electric vehicle value chain developing  not just their technical architecture but also motors, batteries, chargers. This comprehensive  approach allows us to better manage our vehicle performance from quality to cost and time to  market. The alliance is the only group currently able to offer electric vehicle at the same price at  their diesel equivalent in Europe.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: Improving our internal combustion engine should enable us to reduce our CO2 emissions by 12%  by 2013; thus, going from an average of 137 gram per kilometer to less than 120 gram per  kilometer in Europe. With the growth of our electric vehicle sales, we ought to be under the 100  gram of CO2 per kilometer in 2016. This effort is part of the wider company drive to reduce our  worldwide carbon footprint, which should fall by 20% per car sold by 2016.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: Our electric vehicle offensive is central to the strengthening of our product offer. Between now and  2016, the Renault-Nissan alliance plans to sell a cumulative 1.5 million electric vehicles, and we will  have an installed capacity of 500,000 cars per year by 2015.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: The electric vehicle is more than an image builder. With our complete line-up, we expect significant  sales volume. And once we have entered the mass production phase, our electric vehicles could  well be among the most profitable models in our range. In addition to the four electric vehicles  already announced, other vehicles will be added to complete our zero emission offer between 2014  and 2016.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: Let’s start with innovation. Renault’s mission is to make cars with useful and affordable  technologies that meet our customers’ needs. Our electric vehicle strategy sticks with this mission,  making progress accessible to the greatest number of people and playing a major role in  strengthening our image. This approach is already found in many of our offers.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: Our design renewal was presented during the last Paris Motor Show. We aim to design warmer,  more sensual, more passionate cars. We’ll be incorporating these elements into our upcoming  models. And today, you may have a preview of the concept car that will be presented at the  Geneva Motor Show. Captur is a sports crossover vehicle that prefigures a model to be added to  our range. Our new design identity will take concrete form on our new production models and will  be rolled out across our entire range. Our models will retain their specificity but will gradually benefit  from the brand’s new design codes and choices.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: The sixth lever of our Renault 2016 plan relates to cost reduction. The overall cost of our vehicles  should fall by at least 4% annually, product enrichment included, meaning a 12% decline by 2013,  with a goal of 15%. This overall cost-reduction calculation excludes raw material price fluctuation.  Such a performance requires working across the entire vehicle value chain, from product definition,  through engineering, manufacturing, working with the suppliers, including logistics. This is what our  Monozukuri project is about. All our plants will roll out this project this year. The results we obtain in  2010 on four pilot sites have confirmed that our goal for a 12% to 15% cost reduction over three  years is realistic.

texts.speaker: Duncan Minto, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning everybody. Welcome to Renault Square to the Presentation of Renault 2010
texts.text: So a more competitive Renault that meets all stakeholder expectation, a stronger Renault with a  powerful brand image and a high level of quality of products and services that will make our  employees proud, a Renault rooted in its French base, and at ease everywhere on the planet,  making mobility affordable for all, a sustainable Renault in tune with the energy and the  environmental priorities of the 21st century. That’s exactly what Renault 2016 is about.

file: RNO - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 16February2012 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: Second, we launched the electric car. Renault brought to market two electric vehicles on time, at costs, at the right

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: The switch from fast to slow four times in one year, obviously, weighed on our ability to obtain the maximum  gains from manufacturing efficiencies and we incurred higher logistic costs for air freight emergency deliveries.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: The second area where we did not fully perform was the pricing of vehicle content and specifications on to our  customers, in particular in Europe. The supply disruptions caused by the tsunami prevented us from  manufacturing the required mix of engines, particularly diesel, resulting in the negative impact of €50 million on  the second half of 2011. We were selling cars to customers that we were able to produce. In 2012, we will be able to  sell cars to customers with the mix, hopefully, totally in line with the demand.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: A revival plan has been rolled out in January to address these issues. It targets 80% local sourcing, better sales  facelifts and optimized power trains to be launched during the year. The plan targets a return to breakeven at the  latest in 2013.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: These three models alone are expected to contribute to Renault's growth by an additional 30,000 vehicles during  the year 2012. Growth in 2012 will also be supported by our new plant in Tangier, Renault's first greenfield site  since 1999. Initial full year capacity will be 170,000 vehicles, which will be doubled by mid-2014.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: The Renault range will benefit from the launch of four new Alliance powertrains in 2012. On the diesel side, for  instance, the model here of Mégane will start at a best-in-class consumption level and only 90 gram of CO2 per  kilometer. This level is 1 gram away from competitor's hybrids, but the Mégane does not have the dual technology  in its cost base.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: A more leaner production plan during 2012 should help our group accelerate Monozukuri cost reductions. More  importantly, we expect this activity to produce a gain, net of the impact of raw materials, of at least €300 million.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: Within this cap, we're expanding capacity in Morocco, in Brazil, and in Russia. We are pioneers in the launch of  electric vehicle, while presenting a benchmark range of both gasoline and diesel engines in Europe.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: Thanks to this collaboration, the entry ticket for the CMF-1 platform will see a 40% reduction compared to the  previous cycle investments for the C and D segment vehicles in the Renault range.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: Variable costs, the reduction will also be significant as the commonality between Renault and Nissan vehicles will  significantly surpass our existing levels and achieve in access of 50%. At the same time, we are working on the  next steps for the second phase of our plan beyond 2013.

file: RNO - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 14February2013 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Dominique Thormann
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Renault SA
texts.text: For the next part of the walk-down, we have grouped four items which together form the major part of our  Monozukuri cost reduction efforts announced when we launched our strategic plan, Renault 2016 – Drive the  Change.

texts.speaker: Dominique Thormann
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Renault SA
texts.text: G&A costs decreased €72 million, proof of the strong effort deployed by the company to limit fixed costs,  particularly in the decline in European environment. Other items yielded a negative €31 million. And as I already  pointed out, RCI Banque remained flat compared to 2011.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Nissan Motor Co., Ltd.
texts.text: Even though we did not reach our sales objective for the reasons I just outlined, we managed to achieve our main  target, which was to deliver a positive Automotive operational free cash flow for the full year, which shows free  cash flow as the main key performance indicator for two reasons: first, to demonstrate that Renault is able to  create value in a sustainable manner and, in so doing, create a basis for a fair value of its – for its core business;  and second, free cash flow is necessary to secure the integrity of our strategy. We will continue to invest for  international expansion, for renewal and extension of our lineup offer as well as develop state-of-the-art  technologies such as clean diesels, low-emission gasoline engines and electric vehicles.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Nissan Motor Co., Ltd.
texts.text: Regarding technical innovation, beyond the development of a full range of electric vehicles, we have been  pursuing our effort without interruption to develop and offer best-in-class gasoline and diesel engines. Last year,  we introduced the Energy dCi 90 engine on the Clio IV that makes it a benchmark of its segment with 83 grams of  CO2, which is almost on par with the more expensive hybrid technology. This year, we will introduce the Energy  TCe 120 engine on Captur, which will enrich our gasoline offer and will contribute further to reducing our CO2  footprint.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Nissan Motor Co., Ltd.
texts.text: We aim now at regaining market share with the launch of our new products. We have received positive feedback  so far for the facelifts of the SM3 and SM5 launched at the end of 2012; and before the end of 2013, will also  introduce Captur as an import unit and SM3 Zero Emission. The next milestone for RSM, Renault Samsung, will  start in 2014 with the production of 80,000 Nissan Rogues for export.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Nissan Motor Co., Ltd.
texts.text: We are facing tough times in the European market, notably in Southern Europe. However, we see an opportunity  to recover in 2013 based, not exclusively, but mainly on our product offensive. First, we will benefit fully from the  impact of the vehicles launched at the end of 2012, which are now gaining sales momentum for the Renault brand.  Clio IV has already proven its popularity with more than 95,000 orders. ZOE will come next as the first mass- produced electric-only vehicle, completing our zero emission lineup offer.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Nissan Motor Co., Ltd.
texts.text: In India, we have gained significant savings by sharing products and manufacturing capacity with Nissan. In  Russia, our partnership with AVTOVAZ will give us access to additional capacities without carrying the very high  costs of building Greenfield capacity.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Nissan Motor Co., Ltd.
texts.text: Renault is working today to improve its segment coverage, its product quality, its cost efficiency and is investing to  accelerate its regional expansion. We know that it is not enough to be among the long-term winners in this  industry. So we're doing more. We have developed a unique and performing alliance, several win-win  partnerships; a global, and successful and profitable entry range concept that would be expanded with the sub- entry platform. Last, but not least, Renault is the only OEM offering a comprehensive zero emission lineup.

file: RNO - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 13February2014 145 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & President, Nissan Motor Co., Ltd.
texts.text: In Europe our sales are supported by product offensive with cars that so far have well attracted customers. These  cars, three cars particularly, symbolize this renewal. The first one to embody our new design strategy and open the  way for the full transformation of the lineup is Clio. It is connected vehicle via R-Link, recognized today as being  among the best multimedia systems in the world. Clio is also best-in-class in CO2.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & President, Nissan Motor Co., Ltd.
texts.text: We intend to maintain our leadership in environmental responsibility. On the one hand, we'll continue the  development of the competitive offer of electric vehicles. On the other hand, for internal combustion engines,  Renault will stay among the leaders in CO2 performance. At the end of the day what matters in terms of product  competitiveness is what customers say about our vehicles. Customer satisfaction and overall opinion are the  drivers of share and profitability.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & President, Nissan Motor Co., Ltd.
texts.text: We are a 2.6 million car company starting to benefit from an 8.3 million scale. Our objective for the second half of  our plans are ambitious yet realistic. They're ambitious because they require a high level of discipline and focus on  execution, with a strong commitment from every corner of the company to deliver a level of sustainable  performance that was never done in our past. But they are realistic because we have already made most of the  necessary decisions and investments.

file: RNO - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 12February2015 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Regarding the global mobility, we are also working on the car of the future, which, as you know, must be safer,  more connected and more environmentally responsible. In this endeavor, we presented two prototype. The first  one called Next Two foreshadows the autonomous car that could be on the road by 2020 in mature markets.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The second one, Eolab, addresses the CO2 emissions challenge featuring fuel record efficiency with 1 liter of fuel  per 100 kilometers. These are the important topics for the industry for which we are actively working on solutions.

file: RNO - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 12February2016 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The success of all these activities allow us to meet one of our Drive the Change midterm objectives sooner than  forecasted, namely delivering an operating margin in excess of 5 %. Our challenge is now to transform 2015  achievement into a recurring one, and of course, to reach our second target, which is to generate more than €50  billion in revenues measured in 2017.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Before moving to 2016, I would like to say a few words about the alliance stability covenant that was signed with  the French government and Nissan in December, and the recent controversy surrounding emission levels from  diesel-powered vehicles. The alliance stability covenant is good for Renault and good for the alliance. There is a  shared understanding amongst all party that the alliance need to continue to prosper and generate growing  synergies. For the last 17 years, the alliance has enabled both Renault and Nissan to grow profitably in a  sustainable way.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As regards emissions, at the risk of stating the obvious, there is no fraud or cheating at Renault. This has been  independently verified by government appointed commission in France that concluded that our vehicles are not  equipped with any fraudulent software. A ll our vehicles are compliant with existing regulation in all markets  where the group operates.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: That being said, we are working to further improve our performance in emissions. We already made an  announcement in December stating that the specific engineering taskforce had been put in place and that we  would roll out enhancements for better emissions performance.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We are confident in our own strengths, yet we are also aware of the challenges surrounding the industry. Let me  illustrate a few. Given commodities and energy price trends, we are not expecting that demand will improve in  some key emerging markets anytime soon. This is especially the case for Russia and Brazil, where we expect  further declines this year by 12% for Russia and 6% for Brazil. We remain convinced then these markets will  recover at some point and will be ready when this happens. However, for the time being, we have to continue the  hard work or keeping our businesses healthy in these markets.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Emissions regulations are nothing new. But following what happened last year to one of our competitors and the  confusions surrounding this issue, we will address this topic in a more demanding, clear, and stringent manner.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: 2016 will also be a year during which we will be framing the controls of our next business plan. Much of the  upstream work has already started and will lead to specific targets to be achieved in the future. The  transformations underway in the industry will allow us to capitalize our know-how in some segments, where we  are playing a leadership role such as electric cars.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The electrification of powertrains and the place of zero emission vehicles will gain an importance in the coming  years. Simultaneously, as we have already announced, the alliance is moving forward in the field of autonomous  driving and connected cars with plan to bring vehicles to market at different stage between 2016 and 2020. All of  these and more will be contained in our future mid-term plan that we will announce next year.

file: RNO - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 10February2017 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Clotilde Delbos
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Executive Officer - RCI Banque, Renault SA
texts.text: Let's see this in more detail. Slide 9 shows the main variance that explains this increase. I will start the walk down  reading left to right. Cost reduction activities contributed positively for €72 million. As we told you when we  published our Q3 results, our Monozukuri activities impacting positively €184 million for the full year have been  penalized by costs related to overheated demand and launch costs. In addition, we have decided to increase our  R&D spending both in terms of new technologies and additional products.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: Beyond 2017, I would like to share a few brief thoughts. Our industry, as you know, is going to witness a lot of  disruptions, both in terms of products and services, and consequently, also in term of organization and  management. By 2030, a lot are expecting electric vehicle to account for 25% of new cars sold in urban areas.  And virtually, all vehicles will be connected to the Internet. It's no surprise for you if I say that the car of the future  will be electric, autonomous, and connected.

file: RNO - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 16February2018 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: In 2017, we strengthened our leadership in the electric vehicle market. Our worldwide sales were up 38% versus  2016. Our best seller, the ZOE, is the number one electric vehicle sold in Europe, offering the best autonomy at  the best level of price for the fifth year running. Despite growing competition, more than 90,000 ZOE have been  sold so far. Last year, Renault-Nissan and Dongfeng formed eGT New Energy Automotive, a joint venture  designed to manufacture competitive and affordable electric vehicles for the Chinese market.

texts.speaker: Carlos Ghosn
texts.profession: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer, Renault SA
texts.text: From the risk side, the first one is obviously raw materials. We expect pricing headwinds throughout the year. The  second is uncertainty around ForEx exchange rate, particularly due to a surging euro. And, finally, the volatility in  mature markets due to stock market instability, rising interest rates, changing environmental and safety regulation,  consumer behavior will be particularly difficult to predict.

file: RNO - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 14February2019 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Clotilde Delbos
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer-Groupe Renault & Chairman of the Board-RCI Banque, Renault SA
texts.text: Let's have a closer look at slide 9 at operating profit variances. To the left of this step chart, we see Groupe  Renault's cost reduction activities contributing €362 million, of which Monozukuri contributed positively €421  million.

texts.speaker: Clotilde Delbos
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer-Groupe Renault & Chairman of the Board-RCI Banque, Renault SA
texts.text: Groupe Renault's pricing efforts explain the positive mix/net price enrichment effect of €261 million, despite the  negative impact of lower demand for diesel powertrain. This stems from price increases in more major – in major  emerging markets which partially offset weaker currencies, but also from some increases in Europe to cover  regulatory costs.

texts.speaker: Thierry Bolloré
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman, Renault S.A.S, Renault SA
texts.text: We anticipated an evolution of the energy mix. It was faster than expected. We were able to adapt with a slight  delay, but to the slowing down of diesel and strong demand for petrol engines, we answered.

texts.speaker: Thierry Bolloré
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman, Renault S.A.S, Renault SA
texts.text: In the electric vehicle segment, Renault confirmed its European leadership with a 22.2% market share. Groupe  Renault worldwide EV sales increased by 37% over the year. Growth was driven, of course, by our best-sellers,  ZOE and Kangoo Z.E., which sales increased respectively by 27% and 106%. EV is now representing more than  3% of Renault Group's revenue. The profitability of our EV segment improved significantly, thanks to the volume  growth scale, of course, and also our efforts to reduce costs. EV will continue to be a growth driver in the  upcoming years. And in 2018, we made significant investment, as you know, to expand our production capacities  and develop the third generation of electric vehicles.

texts.speaker: Thierry Bolloré
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman, Renault S.A.S, Renault SA
texts.text: We also see major opportunities for 2018. Our strong product plan with launches accelerated particularly in the  second half of 2019 will help a lot. We are expecting the new Clio and Arkana to contribute significantly to our  growth. In India, we will launch a new vehicle to resume our growth and EV will also be a growth pillar, particularly  in China with the launch of our new electric vehicle K-ZE this year and we're also stepping up our EV offensive by  investing, as you know, in GMEV, the fifth largest electric vehicle manufacturer in China.

texts.speaker: Thorkild Diness Jensen

Of course, very much  carried by our acquisitions and also by favorable weather conditions. So, the acquisitions actually contributed with  8% and we also had a negative currency effect of 4%.

texts.speaker: Thorkild Diness Jensen
texts.profession: Head of Investor Relations, Group Marketing, Communication & Public Affairs, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: In North America, the growth was, to some extent, hampered by the harsh winter weather in that continent and  also the fact that we are sold out on the existing factory.

texts.speaker: Thorkild Diness Jensen
texts.profession: Head of Investor Relations, Group Marketing, Communication & Public Affairs, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Next slide, please, which is the final one, our full year expectations. On the full year, we expect to increase sales  by 12%. This is including the acquisitions. And if we look at it organically, we expect 5% growth and all based on  comparable currency rates. So, that should bring us to a net profit, which is still expected to  end around €127 million. CapEx expectation, excluding acquisition, is also expected to remain around the early  announced €188 million.

file: ROCK.B - Q1 2015 Earnings Call First Call 21May2015 415 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-May-15.pdf
ROCK.B - Q1 2015 Earnings Call Second Call 22May2015 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jens Birgersson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Germany and France, if you look into those, the – in Germany last year, we had a quarter that was exceptionally  strong due to weather and other factors. So, compared to that, we are down. Also, France, slightly down. And  when I look at those two, I will say, France, with the new regulations, government incentives as of December 2014,  I would maybe carefully say that we started to see some signs of that, it's improving in France. In Germany, we  haven't seen any of that yet, and they are watching that. So, Germany is still very challenged.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Senior Vice President Finance, Procurement, Public affairs and IT
texts.text: A bit more further down, Germany, it's a very difficult situation for us to judge where we are in Germany. In the  sense that last year, we had a very good first quarter. This year, it's not bad. Weather condition are a little bit more  difficult than it was last year, sorry, they were a bit more difficult last year than it is this year. But still, we don't see  in Germany a kind of a trend where we can rely on.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Senior Vice President Finance, Procurement, Public affairs and IT
texts.text: What we also have here is GRODAN is not only about delivering stone wool-based product, which is a substrate  for the roots of the plant, but we also deliver a lot of services around. And one of the service, which we have been  good at developing is what we call water management. So, inside the plant, we manage all the water level which is  required by the plant to have an optimum growth. And that type of system is a bit sophisticated, and we are  definitely – we're also leader in this, enlarging the offer, we have to our customers in that segment.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Senior Vice President Finance, Procurement, Public affairs and IT
texts.text: I won't go through that one. You get all the figures on exchange rate. Maybe two words about how do we do in  terms of input price, and also on [ph] this energy situation (21:37). Here we – what we do here, we always follow  the spot price of the main energy type. And we are using foundry coke which is here on the red curve. And you'll  see that this has fluctuated. That's from 2005, you might not see it, so we took 10 years of review. And you might  see that depending on the period, this energy has been either underpriced or overpriced.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Senior Vice President Finance, Procurement, Public affairs and IT
texts.text: If you recall, in that period, we have been quite concerned because it has been overpriced for quite some time. A nd  of course, that was giving us a disadvantage in our competitive position. This is where we have worked hard to  move on different technology in order to be less dependent of that energy. So, the reason behind why we have  moved is that independence to one energy type.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Senior Vice President Finance, Procurement, Public affairs and IT
texts.text: What is also interesting is to see that those days first, the energy gap between resources is very limited. And also,  as you can see, foundry coke has gone down quite well. We don't expect – and maybe that's important comment –  we don't expect the price to go down much further. Maybe, for your information, out of the four, five key  producers of foundry coke in Europe, two of them are in financial difficulties. So, we have reached a price now  where margin for them is rather low, so we could not really expect a significant decrease of that.

ROCK.B - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 18May2017 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jens Birgersson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Move on to slide 5, Western Germany, we had, I won't say, it was a hiccup, but we had a slightly surprising end of  the year in Germany last year, where the market was actually up, but they closed building sites early due to the  form issues with the hazardous waste. So, we should have had the growth quarter last year in Q4 [ph] I felt  (04:49) in Germany, because the fundamentals are right. Now in Q1, we saw it. It's increased building starts, the  backlog of building permits, it's there and it speaks for pretty good year in Germany.

texts.speaker: Jens Birgersson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Let's move on to slide 14. We launched the Sustainability Report today, the second time we're doing it. It's not a  long report; I hope some of you can read it. I just want to emphasize that this is not the [indiscernible] (12:41)  sustainability ambition we have in there, and obviously, it's easy for us to do. We already have our raw material; I  think we have the highest percentage of non-virgin material. On the incoming side more than 30% already, and  we have ran some plants up to 80%. So, we have the technology and the way to do that. We will build on that,  and then obviously, all the downstream mass effect: the durability, the fire, the water aspects of our products, but  also the circularity of 50 years, 60 years time that we can re-melt the product. And as far as I know, there is no  other virgin material that can do that.

file: ROCK.B - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 18May2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jens Kr. Krogsgaard
texts.profession: Vice President-Group Finance & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: First, Jens Birgersson will as always go through our presentation. Today, also talk about our new Sustainability  Report and give you a quick update. And then afterwards, we will be ready to answer all your good questions. But  before I hand over the word to Jens Birgersson, I must ask you to note the slide number 2, our forward-looking  statement. So, please, as always, be aware that this presentation contains uncertainties.

texts.speaker: Jens Birgersson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Good morning, everyone. Since we did a pre-announcement already on the 30th of April and we did a call in  conjunction with that. I'm starting with the news, which is the Sustainability Report so that I make sure that you  stay on that for little bit. And I think for us this is quite an important work we are doing and there is an increasing  interest in sustainability and we have this feeling that with our positioning on sustainability what's good for the  business is good for the world.

texts.speaker: Jens Birgersson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: And you have a couple of drivers in here, one is this whole aspect of sustainable cities and non-combustibility we  have seen the Grenfell development, and a voluntary preference for that. And the other is the whole climate  change, and at the end of that reaching the end of the efficiency goals. And if you look at that slide 4, not all of  this is governmental initiatives. Sub-national players and in particular the C40, to the 100 top cities of the world,  that's where we are driving and trying to go with the move that we see there.

texts.speaker: Jens Birgersson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: And if you take one the C40 cities, in city more than 50% of the greenhouse gas derives from the buildings. So we  fit in there together with the non-combustibility for high rises and other sensitive buildings like hospitals. So  therefore, we put a little bit of extra work in this.

texts.speaker: Jens Birgersson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: If we go over to slide 5, you see little bit what we have done is, on the one hand, the message on the outside, the  other is the internal work. We have managed, thanks to the improved productivity, to get CO2 emission, to grey  CO2 from our production, down by 4%. During 2017, we also reduced the landfill, didn't have any fatalities. So  that's on the key percentile work towards our own goals to stay fit to derive to see some of the payback of the  grey CO2 and the grey energies, so to say, during this whole life.

texts.speaker: Jens Birgersson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Finally, and maybe the piece that you are more interested in for the share, we have received quite a bit of  recognition externally for the work we are doing on the sustainability side. And I would say, so on slide 6, you see  some of the ratings we have. And I think this one to the right, SDG Invest, where they screened 65,000  companies and picked 100 and we are in there, it's quite pleasing to see that with this communication and the  work we do, we get picked up sometimes without having actively done anything other than doing the  Sustainability Report and setting some goals.

texts.speaker: Jens Birgersson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Regional developments. Move on to slide 10, Western Europe, Central Eastern Europe, North America, I would  say it's all quite strong. Western Europe very pleasing with the growth in the UK that is really high now France,  Germany and also some of the incentive initiatives the government have issued for energy efficiency France have  announced, sometimes they call it €12 billion, sometimes €20 billion, but we used to number €12 billion, we  haven't started to see that, but there is a true focus on energy efficiency.

texts.speaker: Jens Birgersson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Germany has also pledged money and Poland has come out with money for energy efficiency and this  awareness, if it start to come that you need to do energy efficiency to meet climate goals. Again, I'm not sure to  see much in the numbers yet. The general market perception is good and I think that some of the growth we see  now it's on the one hand sound building market, but some of it is actually some of the other insulation materials  shifting into stone wool, just a fraction on the plastic foam side coming off to stone wool will give good growth to  us.

file: ROCK.B - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 16May2019 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Jens Birgersson, I will now hand over the words to you.  Jens Birgersson  President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S  Thank you, Thomas and good morning everyone. I apologize for my voice today. I have a little bit of a cold.  Before we get into the financials, I would like to use the fact that I have your attention and talk a little bit about the  sustainability report that we issued at the time of the AGM. Normally we focus a lot on the external world and what  the product does for the environment and the climate et cetera. But today I'll also talk a little bit what we do  internally.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: So, first, let's look at the positive impacts, the key drivers slide, the next slide, four, slide four. And what you see  there is this fortunate situation that Rockwool has, that the product does a lot of work. It has a very positive impact  on the environment around us. And there are basically three fundamental driver. The one is, it's used to combat  climate change, a very relevant topic. The second is that it's circular. There aren't – a third of the waste on the  planet comes from the building and construction industry, and stone wools is one of the few construction materials  that can be recycled still down the line.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: There are many products around that talk about that they have recycled material in. We have that too, a third of  what we use today. We have [indiscernible] (00:03:19) material. But the fact is at the end of the day we can take it  back and we can do things with it, and we can use it for new product.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: And the third driver here is to safeguard people's well-being. And here what we increasingly discovered over the  last couple of years is that with the urbanization, our safe fire-resilient products, with its durability, fits extremely  well into the dense urban environment.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: On top of this, if you read this slide, fire safety is always there. On top of this, under I will say climate change,  comes a new emerging trend that natural material like stone wool is also a perfect substitution and a viable  substitution that is ready today to reduce the amount of plastics in the world and that's a very key theme.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: We ourselves, for example, we haven't found a way to replace plastics in the wrapping. There are very good  applications for plastics, but as a building material, stone wool can replace a lot of plastics in construction and  that's a trend we see coming.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Turning to slide 5, sustainability goals, these are the goals we have set ourselves. These are fitness goals that we  have set for our organization. The first one off to the left is the CO2 emission. Today, well, the benchmark year is  2015 and we have a target for 2022 and 2030. There are people that say we should have even longer targets, but  we tend to prefer to see what we can achieve in the next five years and then re-adjust the targets and maybe  accelerate it as we move along.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: But on the CO2 emissions, today since you need a lot of amenity when you melt the materials to make the fire- safe stone wool product, we are using around 696 – we emit 696 kilos of CO2 per ton of stone wool we produce,  and we have improved that as we go, but we want to reduce that factor as we move forward.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: And the second one in the upper row is to reclaim waste. The infrastructure to take back the product, we can take  back the product and we can repurpose it. We can use it in our production and add it in the production. The value  chain is not there yet in the construction industry, but we are increasing the number of countries and we have  targets for that, where we offer to take the product back. We just recently launched it in Sweden, and we could  see an immediate impact on our top line from that. So this is something we are driving and it will take a while to  change the construction industry, but it will happen.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Then, water consumption, and reduce a fair amount of water in producing stone wool and also here we said we  need to reduce [indiscernible] (00:06:49); I'll come back on all of these factors, what actions are we taking.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Then on energy efficiency, we put ourself a goal to renovate our own offices around in the world and cut the  kilowatt hour per square meter by 75%. So that is basically, apply our own product in our offices and to achieve a  substantial improvement.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: And then on landfill waste, we have also set the target to reduce that by 85%. We are producing millions of tons of  stone wool and we are sending something like 3%, 3.5% in terms of tonnage to landfill waste today, and we want  to drop by – to 5%.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: If we flip to the slide 6, you'll see a little bit on the progress what we have done. Example, on the CO2, I'll start  again in the top-left upper corner, the CO2 emissions so far, we have reduced by 4%. And fundamentally the way  to drive this is efficiency of the output to not waste material and the melting technology. For example, if you melt  with the electrical melt that is using renewable energy, that will have a lower CO2 impact. On the other hand,  melting with gas smelter instead of buying directly electricity from far away would also be better. So, we have a  strategy for how to improve this by at least 10% by 2022. But it's a lot about melting technology, and we are I think  the only supplier that can melt with gas, coke, coal and electricity. We are good at all of those basic things.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Then we have the reclaimed waste to increase the number of countries where we offer that. I think that trend will  accelerate as the years go. And it's a matter of doing it, I think through the logistics and also think through the  incoming side of a plant, how you deal with the material when it comes in and how you collect it in a market. In  some markets, there are small startups that are making a business how to take this from a building site. And in  other markets, we have to do it more ourselves. We already do it with several daycare car companies that we  deliver new flat roof or the new materials for it, and we take back the old material. Volkswagen, for example, is a  good example of that.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: And then we get to the water consumption. This is a tricky target to get to, because water in the geographies we  are is cheap. So, we have noticed that if we apply our own investment criteria and these investments to save  water and use less water in our processes, they don't get done. So, what we have done here is to lower the  investment thresholds for water saving so that we get some work done. And what are the actions in this area? It's  basic water management: stop leaks, put in meters, know where it's going, not wasting, not leaving the tap on.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: And then it's a lot of water recycling in many of our plants. We just take in tap water, we clean it, use it as  processed water and then it evaporates a little bit in the process. But we can recycle water all the time, and that's  in place in most places already. And then we also do rainwater harvesting. We have big areas on the plants. And  by just collecting rainwater that would otherwise pass through our plant and have that through the system, we  consume less freshwater from the grid.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Then on the energy efficiency of the buildings it is just to renovate. And this is also a good way for us to showcase  how you use a Rockpanel, Rockfon, our normal insulation in building project and how you renovate effectively and  quickly. We have, for example, doing a project now on Gladbeck. It's a really old 70-ish building that is not pretty,  but we are now uplifting with the renovation and making it top in terms of energy efficiency, very interesting to  take that project on. And we use it a little bit also to train our own managers in understanding how you do  renovate. It's good as a manager for an OPCO to have – operational company to have a renovation project and  have to live with your product renovating your own office.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Then on the landfill waste, that looks like we have gone back, and that's true. We've gone from 94,000 tonnes to  95,000 tonnes of landfill waste. It's still a small percentage of the total production, but that is the function of that  we grew so much last year. The investment plans are approved here, and the trick to not send things to landfill is  to have a way to feed the waste, the product that doesn't pass the final quality test, back into the process. And we  do that, but that fragment that we don't manage today, but we have a couple of ways of doing that.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Depending on the melting technology, you need a special process to be able to get the last bits and pieces, some  of the bulk pieces into it. And we have approved a number of briquetting plants in some places. So, I'm very  confident to meet that goal, bringing that down to less than 1% of the total production going into landfill and  including other materials too. So that's an overview of those.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Then if we look a bit at the external [ph] brands (00:14:11). We have many, many rating agencies around. And  there're ESG money around and a little bit depending on the emphasis of the rating authorities, what they focus  on. You have environment, you have social and governance, depending a bit where they slant it, we will score  differently well. For example, we don't have a female board member today. If that is a high rating, we simply can't  score well today. But if I were to emphasize a few of the heavy ones, the MSCI and then the Trucost and SDG  Invest, I'll take those two.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: We start with the New York-based Morgan Stanley Capital International, MSCI. This is the biggest one in the  world as far as I know, and we are top rated on that one. We are very proud of that. Let me take Trucost. This is  the Standard & Poor's, Dow Jones. This is London-based. They acquired a controlling stake in this. And we are  the only company in their rating. So, they address to 3,000 biggest companies that's in the scope. They're not  through with all companies, but that's their goal. We are the only company of the companies they have now  evaluated that every product has a score of 100% positive impact on the environment. So, they are very much  focused on the environmental aspect of things. Proud of that record.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: And then the Danish SDG Invest, they analyze 65,000 companies, and they picked 100 to say that these are  environmentally sound doing things in the right direction. And we are one of the 100. Again, very proud of that.  So, we have a lot of work left. We never score perfect in all of these, but we're working and we are very well  positioned, okay.

texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director, Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: With that, move on to the numbers, Slide 8. Okay, so slide 8, to just summarize the quarter. The quarter is what  we expected it to be. The top line had a few starts and stops, some places we have had a heavy winter, and we  saw some market grow tremendously. We saw others not grow at all. And this is what we predicted. The top line  is price and mix driven primarily. Then we look at the CapEx. We have invested what we expected to invest. And  it should also be said on the top line, that is the biggest sales we ever achieved in the history of the company in  Q1. So, we're happy about that. I think that's another sign that this fundamental demand for the product, I'm  talking fire-safe materials, natural materials and not made of plastics. It confirms that again the interest in stone  wool is high, and it keeps selling. And then if you look at the numbers, you can read them yourself.

file: ROCK.B - Q2 2014 Earnings Call Investor Meeting 22August2014 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Eelco Lucas Dudok van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On a positive note, the EU Commission is working and deciding upon a next set of targets. This time, it's about  2030 and what is it we want to accomplish on the energy saving and CO2 reduction front FY 2030. This is, of  course, as always, exciting stuff for us because we are major contributors to reducing CO2 emissions and to saving  energy as 40% of the energy consumed in, for example, Europe is used in buildings.

texts.speaker: Eelco Lucas Dudok van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The current driver before we get into the 2030 story is the 2020 story where the target is 20% reduction compared  to the level of 2010. There's two elements to this. The first one is new build, to-be-built buildings. There we see  that the target is probably or the [ph] part (07:32) target is probably going to be reached. This is a question about  building according to passive house standard by 2020 and we see building codes in different countries gradually  being changed towards that goal.

texts.speaker: Eelco Lucas Dudok van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So we think that doing that works well. However, as usual, I would say, in the refurbishment sector, which is much  more complicated, there is a commitment for 1.5% saving for – annual saving through various initiatives. And  here, we could definitely see that things are not running the way they should and we are behind target.

texts.speaker: Eelco Lucas Dudok van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, the 30% savings in 2030 is good news to us. However, we are pragmatic. We do know that the 2020 targets are  questionable if they are going to be reached, which then means what's going to happen to 2030. However, we are  doing all we can to support the commission and to support [ph] the member states (08:41) in executing these  targets and even trying to influence them to tighten them.

texts.speaker: Eelco Lucas Dudok van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The acquisition of CMC which is a grid producer, it's the steel-bearing systems in which you place the ROCKFON  tiles was – had very different effects. When you look regionally on the business, in Europe, ROCKFON is very  strong. ROCKFON is a very strong number two in suspended ceilings and sometimes we even think we might be  very close to be number one. There, the CMC business, the grid business was kind of added to a successful  ROCKFON business. [ph] Induration dam (16:27), it works and it's already clear that the fact that we can now  offer systems instead of separate products is going to work.

texts.speaker: Eelco Lucas Dudok van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: ROCKPANEL, the cladding facade business is doing well. We opened up our new plant in the Netherlands not so  long ago and it runs nicely. So also there, big smiles, Lapinus Fibres, the engineered fiber business for the break  lining industry, the gasket industry, the plastics industry runs well, especially on the back of Asian success.  GRODAN, our substrate – horticultural substrate business runs well. So it's all nice stories for the businesses  within systems.

texts.speaker: Eelco Lucas Dudok van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Then we have informed you on Wednesday, was it? Yes, it was Wednesday – what we expect for this year. We  maintain our assumption that we will grow by 12% and 5% on a like-for-like basis. We continue to see good  effects, positive effects on our bottom line of the developments in energy prices and raw materials. We anticipate 1  percentage point less tax than last year – or the budget, sorry, and we maintained a net profit – [ph] audience  (19:26), did I say something wrong?

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: CFO, Senior VP & Head-Corporate Affairs
texts.text: So when we said we are happy with our solid position and development in Russia, you can also, behind that figure,  see Russia being the biggest business in that region, see how good it was – it has been. We are also quite happy, as  Eelco mentioned, on our North American phase. Like-for-like was 13%, and that's also could be seen in the  perspective of the first quarter, which was not so good in U.S. because of climate condition, and of course, also  with capacity availability in North America which was rather limited. From now on, we could push more.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: CFO, Senior VP & Head-Corporate Affairs
texts.text: On the inventory part, if you look at the profile, you can see that the main growth come from our finished goods  and from the acquisition effects. This year, as we were planning quite a nuclear recovery, and especially in Europe,  we decided to take a bit of a safer approach compared to last year in terms of seasonality of our inventories.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: CFO, Senior VP & Head-Corporate Affairs
texts.text: A few words about energy. Eelco has mentioned we were happy with the development of raw material and energy.  But you might have noticed that in our stock release, we speak about input costs which are slightly negative. And  the difference between these two is that the logistics costs are not decreasing and are compensating for the benefit  we get on energy price [ph] and raw materials (32:11).

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: CFO, Senior VP & Head-Corporate Affairs
texts.text: Having said that, we are extremely happy with the energy price development. The reason behind that, if you follow  this red curve that we have been showing you many times, you can see that the foundry coke is, in our opinion,  back to a reasonable level. So, all the big disturbance we have seen over the last years is gone, meaning that we are  back to a good competitiveness level in terms of energy.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: CFO, Senior VP & Head-Corporate Affairs
texts.text: You can also see that when you look at the electricity and the gas price, which are also getting closer to the level of  the coke. So, for us, this is a good situation because it puts the competition back to a similar level of energy, where  we have seen a period where we were definitively not favored by the market. So that's the good news. We hope this  will continue for some time. I don't see, for the moment, any tension on the coke price market, which could  change this level in the coming – in the near future.
