The other side is a red line, which was the coke has been for a period  extremely high and very much higher than the other energy if we just consider the cost of 1 kilowatt hour or  whatever energy unit you want to use.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Group Finance & Corporate Affairs, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: The interesting situation we face now is that this gap is decreasing. On the one hand, gas and electricity are  increasing, which we will also pay in our books. But what is interesting is that the coke situation seems to have  normalized a bit for what reason we have quite some difficulties to understand this market, it's very much  demand-driven. China has most likely a strong influence in it, but we have so far a position on the coking coal,  which is the main method you're using in the production of coke, which is giving us some, I would say,  advantages compared to what we have seen on the year before. So, we [indiscernible] (13:13) that this gap will  close because it will also help us to recover part of this margin I was mentioning before.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Group Finance & Corporate Affairs, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Profit after minority, we have guided by the figure which is more than DKK 600 million and you should understand  this figure as a similar result as what we have seen in 2012. The reason why we would like to guide that way is  because there is still lots of uncertainties on the different cost elements that we are facing in 2012. One of the  uncertainties is inflation. I've mentioned the positive elements regarding our coke price development, but we have  seen also for many other materials a quite steep increase early in 2012 and I could mention for that, as an  example, plastic foil materials, benzene which is one of the main chemical component for the different binders or  other chemicals we use, or wood pellets are also on the rise and I would not speak about logistic costs which are  also very much linked to the oil price.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Group Finance & Corporate Affairs, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: So, we have a significant part of our cost structure which will be impacted by what we see in early 2012. What I've  said another one will be positively affected, which is some of the energy part. So, this is a high uncertainty. We  cannot conclude yet, but we want to be a bit safe on how this can develop because I still believe that the world  demand will still continue to ask for more material, meaning an inflation because of the supply/demand situation.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: On the picture what you see at the moment, this is an airport. And airports is actually big business. Maybe not so  much in Europe, but especially in the growth and emerging markets, but also in Europe a lot of building  construction is going on in airports. Berlin is building its new airport, which will open in June. Terminal 2 in  Heathrow is completely redone. And the reason I mention this is that it becomes more and more obvious that  airports are very important and nice market for us. Airports and acoustics fit together and our stone wool product  is very suited for acoustical purpose. On top of that the fire behavior and the fire performance of our product really  helps to make our products specified in airports. So, just an interesting development.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: So, our business is more and more driven by the refurbishment segment, driven by energy efficiency  improvement actions in various markets, legislation that follows that as well as incentive programs from  governments that also support this development. For us, as a stone wool producer, this mix of refurbishment  increasing compare to new build is good news because we are typically stronger in the refurbishment market than  we are in the new build market.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Germany is really spearheading the whole energy performance of buildings movement. We can also see our  performance in Germany is quite good. There are good and long-term incentive programs in place and we  actually expect that this will be expanded upon.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Russia, 11% of our sales. You can see the Russian part of our business relative to the rest is really growing.  Energy refurbishment is high on the agenda. It is supported by the government, but also fire safety. In Russia, we  have seen some very, very disastrous fires with a lot of dead people, which has meant that fire safety is very high  on the agenda of the legislator.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Asia, 5% of sales, something – and we have told you about this before, but I would like to confirm that what  happened in China in March last year when the government basically put a ban to combustible insulation  materials on the outside of buildings due to fires that this has meant that the market is really booming in China  and our four factories in the Southeast Asian region are completely sold out. We have started to import goods  from Europe and India into the Chinese market. Of course, this is an expensive exercise, but we need to fulfill the  demand in this booming market.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: China is actually a stone-wool market. China is actually used to insulating buildings. You can sometimes ask the  question what the quality of that work is, but they are used to insulate, especially on the outside of buildings. And  we have made a study telling us that the Chinese production capacity of stone wool is 1 million tonnes or probably  much more. However, the quality of this product produced locally is really inferior. So, we think that we can  basically follow our Russian strategy from the start where we found initially the same situation to go in with good  quality products at relatively high prices and convert the market to our way of thinking.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: A few words about one of the Systems division activities, the Rockfon, suspended ceiling activity, now  representing 10% of our business, which is significant, growing very fast and being a very strong number two in  the suspended ceiling market in Europe and getting stronger. Our confectioning capacity making the Rockfon  product itself based on wool produced on the insulation lines is getting to be a limiting factor, which is the reason  why we have established a rather high capacity confectioning outfit in Vyborg in Russia at our plant close to St.  Petersburg and we will open this officially in a few weeks.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Like to spend a few words on ETICS. ETICS stands for and here I have to read. I can never remember it. External  thermal insulation composite systems, which is what we used to call external wall insulation. So, a system that is  put on the outside of the wall is rendered and in the eyes of many people depending on where you live a very  aesthetic and nice system. It's a total system solution. It's not just the combination of products. So, it's a rather  complicated market.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: EPS is the dominant material used in this segment around the world. And we have decided that this should  change because we feel that a stone wool ETIC system compared to an EPS system has many advantages,  might be somewhat more expensive to install, but the issues of fire safety, the issues of stability of the product will  make stone wool in the end the preferred material. This was the reason for us acquiring the Polish company,  FAST, last year. And FAST is a company that produces all the other stuff that is needed to install an ETIC  system. They produce the dry renders, they produce the topcoats, the paints on the outside and they are very  knowledgeable about the Polish market how to serve this, how to do this. So, we have put a total strategy  together between the company FAST and our Polish Rockwool colleagues and have now implemented this  strategy in Poland. And we have started in a few other countries in Europe as well. We're very positive about this  acquisition and the possibilities that this will give us.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: A few last words about one of the main topics in our company. It has been the main topic for the last 50 years and  it will be the main topic for the next 50 years. And I'd just like to repeat to the world that in our view, the usage of  combustible materials – of combustible insulation materials in sensitive segments like roof, sandwich panels and  facades is irresponsible in light of the danger to human life and also facades.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: The second message that we have is if insufficiently protected combustible insulation exposed to fire may add  speed and power to the spread of fire in a building. So, this stuff is dangerous, especially because we are  focusing on the ETIC segment at the moment, especially facades are attracting focus from the public, the press  and the legislator, actually especially in emerging markets like in China, but now also again in Western Europe.

file: ROCK.B - Q4 2011 Earnings Call QA 1March2012 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-12.pdf
ROCK.B - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 1March2013 1215 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Thorkild Diness Jensen
texts.profession: Vice President, Investor Relations & Corporate Communications, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Next slide, please. So the first slide that we have here is showing the net sales development, as you have seen  we had compared to the general economic climate a rather decent development in 2012 with a 7% increase in our  sales over the year. There was a good positive currency effect. So if we correct for that, we will see that the  increase is around 5%. Quite big differences between the regions. We saw a 2% increase in Western Europe, a  12% increase in Central and Eastern Europe, including Russia and a 19% increase in rest of the world, which in  our case is basically North America and Asia.

texts.speaker: Thorkild Diness Jensen
texts.profession: Vice President, Investor Relations & Corporate Communications, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: So next slide, please. A good result was also reflected in a nice development in our EBIT results, we saw a 26%  increase compared to 2011 with some nice positive effects from price and also from mix. We had also helped  from energy prices, which over the year went down. Somewhat counteracted by inflation on other raw materials.  Also impacting this picture was, of course, the startup of our new Russian factory, which had a very good start  over the year.

file: ROCK.B - Q4 2012 Earnings Call Investor Meeting 4March2013 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, Group Finance, Corporate Affairs & Director, ROCKWOOL International A/S
texts.text: Cash flow. Positive improvement from the cash flow also linked to the balance with cash generated and with, as  I've mentioned, a rather low level of investments. I want to be back with this graph, which I have been using some  time, which is a price development for the different kind of energy. It's also to show you that the coking coal or the  foundry coke, which is the material we use, the price has decreased quite a lot over the year 2012. And I think it is  interesting to notice that we are back on track in terms of cost between the different nature of energy. If you look  to this graph, you can see that in the period 2010-2011, this energy, our main energy was priced at higher level  compared to the other type of energy. This is not the case anymore. We expect this situation to stay also during  2013 and to have a price of the foundry coke, which would be competitive to the other type of energy use by the  industry.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Nice to notice that there is finally spring in the air and one of the advantages of always being so late with our  investor meetings is that at least we can celebrate spring. A few years ago I did that by showing up in my summer  clothes. I haven't done that this time but it was actually a very good thing to step out of the door and see the sun  and feel the good vibrations in the air.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Fortunately, the industry, the mineral wool industry and the total industry and insulation industry in Europe has  professionalized very much over the last couple of years. It was something that I hoped for and predicted five to  seven years ago that this industry will be able to protect their margins in good times as well as bad times.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Materials on a global level you can see plastic foams have more than 50% and there is kind of a balance between  glass wool and stone wool. The fact that plastic foams on a global level take more than 50% is very much related  to the situation in Asia. So Asia is really a plastic foam market and of course it's our long term goal to go out and  change that.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: When we look at Western Europe we have strong indications that stone wool gained market share in Western  Europe last year. This is also very logical as new built is definitely not to the market to be and the insulation  activities in Western Europe are focused on refurbishment and in the refurbishment sector stone wool is more  than natural choice than anything else as refurbishment is very close to the end user, to the decision maker and  the decision maker typically is after the combination of all the good characteristics of our product.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: What's been happening in Western Europe last year? We did increase by 2% compared to 2011. However, as  already indicated, the volumes declined over the year quarter-by-quarter. However, margins remained very  positive. So despite the fact that I guess everybody lost volume over the year the margins were kept at a  reasonable level. Market is continuing to be pushed by Germany and France where we continue to have very  long-term and very constructive incentive programs, which, which really puts – put a bottom under the energy  renovation in these countries and which make the insulation markets sustainable also when we look at the total of  Europe.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: We are focusing at the moment very much on the segment which is called ETICS and ETICS stands for External  Thermal Insulation Composite Systems. It's also called outside insulation facade insulation. It's a system whereby  the insulation, the mesh, the render and the top coat are put into one solution. And it's definitely at the moment in  Europe but also in places like Asia and Russia the segment in the market which we see growing fast.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: However, we have a firm belief that the North American roof – flat roof market should be ours at a certain stage.  We've been working on this very hard. The plastic foam solutions that are tradition in North America in our view  are not good enough and they should be replaced by a stone wool solution which really gives what you pay for.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Sales developed double-digit pace, very good. The reason we decided in December to go in the air with a very  big Greenfield in Tianjin close to Beijing in the North of China is the fact that the Chinese government is going in  one way or the other to make legislation about the need for non-combustible insulation in the outside of buildings  of dwellings.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: We have developed for complete different purposes another way of treating our fibers. To tell you the truth, the  other purposes did not really work out so well. So then we thought what else can we use this, this special  technology for. And one of the ideas that came out of this exercise is the fact that we think we can produce a very  specific stone wool product, which can help the window producers to live up to standards which they will have to  live up to six to seven years from now.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: We're using the two of the many specific properties of the stone wool, but in this case durability which is equal to  maintenance free and the good old thermal performance. We have thought about how can we combine this  thinking with some of the challenges that colleagues in the wider building industry are struggling with. We ended  up with the window producers. But in 2020 we'll have to live up to thermal performance requirements, which day- to-day cannot really live up to using the technology that is the tradition.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: So, we have produced a – [indiscernible] (00:43:12 part for their window production, which is maintenance free  and which adds thermal performance to the window, which does make it possible for them to get through their  2020 requirements.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: It's combining insulation and the maintenance free surface in one product. We've launched this at the big industry  fair at above and mentioned in 2013 and we could anticipate that with this small example of innovative thinking  and a new way of looking at the market that we can open up a huge potential for our business as well as ensure  that somebody else, other parties in the building industry can get on with product development in their concepts.

file: ROCK.B - Q4 2013 Earnings Call Investor Meeting 24February2014 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: North America, Russia, Asia, with the exception of China give us good market circumstances and therefore, a  very good performance in 2013. Energy efficiency is still very high on the agenda in Europe. I have a few remarks  about that also later. It might get a little bit technical, but I don't think we can prevent that because there are a few  developments ongoing which are very important for us to follow and to adhere to. And I think it would be wise that  you and us, we both understood a little bit of what's going on there.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: We have things happening in the EU on the climate front, on the CO2 emission front, and hopefully also soon new  initiatives in energy efficiency, also in buildings. And I'll try to lead you through a little bit what we see happening  there. As you probably know, the commission has put targets for CO2 reduction by 2030 of 40%, which is an  increase of the old target which was in the beginning of the 30s. And we also know that the European parliament  is pushing for more. So, the target for CO2 emission reduction in the future has been severely tightened.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: We have something called the emissions trading system which is very much linked to the CO2 quota system. Not  going into details, what's happening here is that industry in the past, basically has been overburdened by financial  costs due to this system. And, we now see that also other segments like agriculture transport et cetera, et cetera,  are getting their share of the burden which means some kind of a relief, relatively speaking for industry.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Maybe the most important part of this whole story is that the EU and the Commission have announced that they  will, under this 40% CO2 reduction target, they will come with targets for energy efficiency improvements. And of  course, in our industry, this is what we are waiting for and we hope to have clarification about this by – in summer  – beginning of the fall this year.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: We also see that within the emission trading system that the CO2 quota, story has not really worked for the EU.  The target price for one ton of CO2 within the EU theoretically is €30, the market has shown prices all the way  down to [ph] $5, $6 (08:27) and maybe you'll recall that many months ago, the EU took a kind of measure to take  out CO2 quota from the market in order to increase the price.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: We expect CO2 quota prices to increase gradually it has a negative and a positive for us; the negative of course  is that we do emit CO2 ourselves as a producer, so we'll have to pay more for a ton of CO2, on the other hand it  will gradually but surely increase the focus on energy efficiency and the payback of these measures.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Another little technical thing is that the EU within the ETS has a system which is called carbon leakage which is  meant for Industry to be compensated, in case, producers from outside of Europe who do not have to pay all  these levies, import into the union and therefore make it very difficult to compete for us.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: So far, we have been as a mineral wool industry, part of this carbon leakage program and we also expect this to  continue at least until 2019. We still have lots of initiatives from the past. We have directives that have been  implemented and we should not forget that these initiatives continue to give effects in 2013 for example, we saw  tightening of building quotes in the Czech Republic and Spain.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: We have – I am back to my original story after the EU climate and energy efficiency policies, we have a strong  focus within the group on the facade segment which we split up in two primary parts, the ventilated facade and  what we call the ETICS, the outside facade insulation. I will give you a few words also related to our acquisition of  BASF Wall Systems and on top of that, we now see a very serious discussion in the German press about the  combustibility of some of the foam products in the market, in this segment and the effects of that on safety of  buildings and people.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Integration merge of this company which is owned by our Deutsche Rockwool. This is ongoing including IT  systems because the curious part of this acquisition was that the seller said at the day and the hour of closing,  we'll pull the plug on our IT systems, so we were pretty busy getting our own systems in place and that worked  well. The main purpose, of course, of going into this type of acquisitions and becoming a system holder in this  segment is that we wish to convert the insulation part of these systems from plastic foams into stone wool. The  first signs that this will be successful.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Poland has been a difficult market for quite a while. We see some good improvements there. And we now finally  also can see that the Polish government is getting more serious about energy efficiency in buildings, also from a  legislation point of view. Things in the Czech Republic and the Baltics are improving quite fast. Southeastern  Europe is still a challenge.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: The third focus area in North America is technical insulation. There is a huge demand for stone wool in the  petrochemical and energy sector, the Mexican Gulf, the Alberta Oil Sands, and other places. And the last remark  about chemical industry is maybe an interesting one because due to the shale gas and shale oil story in North  America, gas prices are so low that we see the US of A attracting a lot of chemical industry within its boundaries.  So, industry is going to come back to the U.S. and this is, of course, for our business, very positive.

texts.speaker: Eelco van Heel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Our highest priority, and this is going very well, is to ensure that this new activity becomes and has one market  profile. Of course, we're integrating all the things that need to be integrated with priority and focus on the sales   and marketing activities. And if we then split up a little bit what we're doing regionally, in Europe, ROCKFON is  taking the lead. They are and were the biggest. The grid business is very fast integrated into the ROCKFON  business, meaning that the specifier already today is able to specify complete suspended ceiling system and not  two individual products. This work goes very well, so we have no worries on this front.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Senior Vice President Group Finance, Corporate Affairs and Procurement, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Overall, as also Eelco mentioned, we have seen some inflation. We were quite happy on the raw material side  where we have seen some decrease. We see energy, especially on foundry coke but on the other type of  materials, especially the chemicals, we are still seeing some inflation during the year.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Senior Vice President Group Finance, Corporate Affairs and Procurement, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: In the DKK 734 million we spent for capacity increase, the major part of that and the most important single  investment is a new factory in North America. Eelco has mentioned that it will start soon in May and we will, of  course, still see in 2014 some cost for this new greenfield factory.

file: ROCK.B - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 19February2015 1115 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-15.pdf
ROCK.B - Q4 2014 Earnings Call Investor Meeting 20February2015 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: CFO, Senior VP & Head-Corporate Affairs
texts.text: Having said that, the German government has also taken measures to support the energy renovation of buildings.  And one of this measure is a tax incentive program, which is now being debated, and we hope that this will be  concluded in the coming weeks.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: CFO, Senior VP & Head-Corporate Affairs
texts.text: Of course, this one might last a bit longer, because we have this oil price situation, but we are still very happy to be  present in Russia despite the turbulences on our results and the volatility on the currency.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: CFO, Senior VP & Head-Corporate Affairs
texts.text: We also have started, through our reengineering project in Poland, a big renovation of one line, the same project  as we are doing in Denmark. This one is going also okay, but the delay will be – we have delayed a bit to start-up,  to have a start in Q1 in 2016. So the year 2015 will be dedicated to the construction of the project.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: CFO, Senior VP & Head-Corporate Affairs
texts.text: Let's move a bit on North America. I would first convey a message that, on the sales side in North America, we are  extremely happy. The strategy which has been to create a differentiation in insulation material in North America  by showing how good stone wool can be in construction with the many different properties is working.

texts.speaker: Gilles Pierre Maria
texts.profession: CFO, Senior VP & Head-Corporate Affairs
texts.text: On the Asian front, we have in 2014 decided to discontinue our project for a new factory in China. And that  decision was made on the – ground of this lack of regulation for non-combustible insulation in China. You recall  that the government has anticipated the churn in this regulation. We have not seen that coming in 2014. We will  see in 2015, some progress, but not at the level which we have anticipated three years ago. So some progress  outgoing, I would say, gradual improvement is being seen in China.

file: ROCK.B - Q4 2015 Earnings Call First 26February2016 315 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Feb-16.pdf
ROCK.B - Q4 2015 Earnings Call Second 29February2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Kim Junge Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Then the [indiscernible] (00:04:40) business have had again a very, very good year. This whole concept of  growing vegetables and what have, using less water and less fertilizer seems to be taking off in some new  market, especially in the US and that's very nice to see because it's underlying profitable business, good margins  and also this type of business is quite sticky. It's a whole system around us so if you buy into our way of doing it,  you get used to it and I don't think you shift around all of it all the time. So that's good.

texts.speaker: Kim Junge Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: But we have a couple of these markets that are not improving. The oil price is not improving. So, to get the overall  number, I'm not expecting or I don't want to say that Germany is turning around quickly. Even though I did see a  slight improvement in Q4, so we haven't factored that into our forecast.

texts.speaker: Kim Junge Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: In the two businesses, insulation and systems, 17% growth in systems that's fine. And on the Insulation business,  we moved the margin from 3.9% to 5.5%, so 47% up. So, this ambition to move the insulation business up in  terms of profitability, that continues, I think we made a first step here.

texts.speaker: Kim Junge Andersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: There's a difference between having every factory on a core technology and designed differently as supposed to  go for a bit more standardized. But again, it's housekeeping. We need to do it. We can do it now with a stronger  central organization for it, hasn't been done and it's a bit like we talked about the new melters, the coal-fired  melters that it doesn't happen overnight, you need to work that, it'd take you 10, 15 years to bring in new  principles in the installed base.

texts.text: A smaller market around the factory in the sweet spot you can build the smaller one. And he set himself some goals for he wanted to achieve and he has achieved that now. So after eight years, he  has decided to step down. And he has done a great job in that role. texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: In terms of the – in the annual report, I don't know if you have had time to read, the Management Letter, that CEO  Letter and some of the other market outlook. On the other hand, we also see energy efficiency [indiscernible] (00:16:36)  pledged €12 billion for renovation and energy efficiency. Out of that, maybe €5 billion will flow into things related  to what we do, the housing renovation. Germany, the not-yet-government, the coalition has said that if they form  the coalition, they will have €1 billion tax deductions coming for energy efficiency. We saw that last time, but did it  really work? It's not decided. We still need the coalition to form a government. But fundamentally, I see an  inflection point in the market.

texts.speaker: Jens Birgersson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: And then, on the other side, you have many people talking about [indiscernible] (00:17:19) coming. And this  means that we are – every month, looking through the capacity plant. But we might be stepping in or we are stepping into a period with higher CapEx. That doesn't mean  that we want to do bad investments to drive down return on invested capital below 15%. That's not at all our  objective. texts.text: The energy efficiency and the renovation of the [indiscernible] (00:18:14) to meet the climate goals, you know  everything about 40% of the energy and 40% of the CO2 is from buildings in Europe and going after the building  stock and renovating it. texts.profession: Director,  Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Many of us do this that we take a paper bag in the shop instead of a plastic bag and we wonder how can we get  rid of plastic. texts.speaker: Thomas Harder
texts.profession: Director,  Group Treasury & Investor Relations, Rockwool International A/S
texts.text: Glass wool, stone wool another insulation materials can do that easy. texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We are, however, disappointed about the recent setback in our pipeline. We are disappointed about  the delay of taspoglutide, and we are very disappointed about the ODAC’s recommendation few  days ago.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The other element, if you use the term Forex loss, it always turns tough, and somebody -- like  somebody mixed – makes something up, I can really also comfort you there. We had to really  assess our operations in Venezuela. And for those a little bit familiar with this country, it has now, I  think, 3 official exchange rates. And it’s quite a jungle to find it – the way through these official  exchange rates. And it gave a one-time hit which we had in the first half of this year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: On the other hand, you also have to respect – and this will absolutely not surprise you – that  government have become extremely aggressive at all fronts, not only on pricing product, but also  on what they can grant in – at the tax field. And I have to admit that there were never so many open  ends at the tax side that suddenly governments have changed their attitude. And let’s say they  move into negotiations, which you always have, because in many countries, especially in Europe,  you don’t pay annual taxes. But you have this kind of tax review period which sometimes are quite  in the past, and then it’s quite a challenging process to come to a conclusion. And here we have  just realized that the environment has changed. And you know what? In the one or the other case,  we also then reassess how we saw the situation 6 months ago and how we see it now. And we -- I  would say if you take the summary of tax provisions 6 months ago and now, we have increased  them slightly, because the environment has become more difficult. So I would really confirm here  that you don’t have to worry around the tax rate.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: So as Jonathan has already explained, each of the divisions has had a positive first half with revenues in all cases
texts.text: higher than the same period last year. The Instruments division is performing well and in line with our  expectations. In terms of the end markets, we have seen a change in the mix profile of our business with oil and  gas growing the strongest. Water growing, I'm pleased about, and power declining.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: So as Jonathan has already explained, each of the divisions has had a positive first half with revenues in all cases
texts.text: The reason we have still seen growth is due to stronger oil and gas business and an improvement in the water  market. The fastest growing regions in the period are North America and Eastern Europe. North America has  benefited by some of the acquisitions being North American-focused. But we have also seen positive trends in  areas such as liquid pipelines and oil and gas in general. Eastern Europe is generally driven at this time by oil and  gas activity.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: So as Jonathan has already explained, each of the divisions has had a positive first half with revenues in all cases
texts.text: In general, the division has performed well but we saw especially strong performances from the Americas, Russia  and Australia. Each benefited from a good spread of business across the main markets that we serve, but also  increased oil and gas infrastructure investment. As in the other divisions, the acquisitions that we completed last  year are being integrated into the business, where appropriate. And this will lead to further opportunities in the  future.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: So as Jonathan has already explained, each of the divisions has had a positive first half with revenues in all cases
texts.text: As most of you are aware, the Controls division will benefit from areas of the oil and gas industry that are  classified as midstream and downstream markets. And as we are expecting the oil and gas market to remain  positive, this will provide further potential as we look forward.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: So as Jonathan has already explained, each of the divisions has had a positive first half with revenues in all cases
texts.text: There have been a lot of discussions in the press regarding the slowdown in the Chinese and Indian economies.  However, for Rotork, both countries still provide significant opportunities for growth. We still have the ability to  take market share in our existing market and we can also focus on markets that historically have not been strong  for us in these countries. This will include a greater focus on the water market as well as the industrial market.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: So as Jonathan has already explained, each of the divisions has had a positive first half with revenues in all cases
texts.text: Fluid Systems is mainly focused on oil and gas and as such continues to benefit from the increased investment  being seen in this area. This is especially being seen in midstream or transmission pipelines and in an active LNG  markets. The investment in new products will provide further opportunities to grow our addressable market and  the acquisitions of companies such as K-Tork provide opportunities in new end markets of Fluid Systems, such as  power and water.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: So as Jonathan has already explained, each of the divisions has had a positive first half with revenues in all cases
texts.text: Energy demand, electricity capacity and water infrastructure spend remain good indicators of future investment  over the long term, which can be seen on this graph. Our own internal project tracking system provides us with a  more medium term view of the market, based on projects being announced or active. This provides us with a level  of comfort regarding project activity. The latest report shows an increase in projects across the board by industry  and geography.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: So as Jonathan has already explained, each of the divisions has had a positive first half with revenues in all cases
texts.text: So based on the information we have, the overall outlook is positive. We will see further opportunities to grow the  business as we continue to focus on expanding our product offering by product development and through  acquisitions. We will continue to look for acquisitions in each of the divisions, but we anticipate that the  Instruments division will be driven mainly by acquisitions. The markets that we serve remain positive, especially  the oil and gas market and we anticipate power to come back. Our investment in the sales channel will provide  further opportunity to benefit from our broad product portfolio.

file: RORL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 6August2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Fluid systems, however, continues to be the fastest growing division due to market share gains and an active  marketplace. You can see on the end user market graph here that the oil and gas market has once again shown the  strongest growth with power slightly down reflecting the continued weakness of the Indian power mar ket, as well  as a general slowdown around the world in other areas. Our industrial and mining business continues to grow as  we develop our product offering and find new markets.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Although fluid systems had seen a strong performance from our European subsidiaries, the market for controls  has been subdued. The large coal seam gas orders for Australia have started to be delivered benefiting controls  and RFS and the deliveries will continue in the second half and into 2014.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Rotork fluid systems saw a margin progression in the first half and achieved 15.9% return on sales. This was due  to positive operational gearing, driven by strong performance of a number of offices in each of the regions that we  serve, demonstrating a very broad geographic sales mix not focused on one particular area where we should  highlight very strong performances from Mexico and Australia. Mexico continues to benefit from the inv estment  in the midstream sector, with Australia benefiting from the investment in coal seam gas.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: I will provide more detail on the acquisition of GTA on a later slide, but the continued expansion of our product  portfolio does provide opportunities to enter new markets and also take advantage of investment in traditional  markets. We continued to see investment in the gas sector with unconventional gas production accounting for a  significant proportion of the increase with the U.S.A. and Australia leading th e way, but expected further  investment from China. We continued to invest in product development and this will benefit us as we expand our  product portfolio.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Flowco is a small company that is focused on providing actuator service to the water utilities in  the southwest of  England. This acquisition will be managed by the controls division and it will form part of the controls division,  and falls under our Rotork U.K. operations. The owner-managers will remain in the business.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Our internal project tracking system provides a medium- to long-term view of the market. And at the end of June,  we see a similar level of projects within the oil and gas and water sectors and power is basically flat. We are seeing  an increasing trend in the mining and industrial sector as we continue to develop our end market exposure and  broaden our product portfolio.

file: RORL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 5August2014 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Thanks. Good morning. I'll start with financial highlights. Currency features in many of my slides with organic  constant currency or OCC figures given wherever helpful. After this slide, I'll only comment on both reported and  OCC numbers where the difference varies from the general impact that currency has had.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The group order book is £202.6 million, 12.1% higher on an OCC basis. At June 2013, the order book was £208.2  million, but the currency difference is greater compared with this point in time and the current order book is  actually 4.1% higher on an OCC basis.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Work to reduce component costs continue to deliver benefits in Gears, but despite this, gross margins declined by  80 basis points. A reduction in the level of Subsea gearbox sales and growth in manual gearbox sales meant  product mix had a negative impact on gross margins. Overheads actually reduced slightly on an OCC basis, so this  led to a 50 basis point increase in OCC-adjusted operating margins.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Oil and gas revenue were slightly down on the prior year, recognizing the phasing of orders for the coal -bed  methane project in Australia and a slower market in China. Although order intake did improve in the second  quarter and this has not yet being reflected in the revenue. The water market was impacted by a slow start in the  municipal business in the U.S.A. due to bad weather in the first quarter. And again, we have seen this improving  in the second quarter in terms of order intake.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The industrial and mining market continues to grow as we develop sales channels and products for this sector.  Against the full year 2013 revenue split, we see that oil and gas has reduced as a total contribution to 56% with  midstream showing the most significant change from 22% to 18%. In general, I am pleased to report that the  markets that we serve do remain active.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Asia Pacific saw a decline against a challenging comparative period with the large coal-bed methane project, as I  explained in the last slide, being delivered last year. Eastern Europe saw a slowdown in some of the pipeline  projects, however the Middle East and Africa benefited from a number of significant orders in the period. And  whilst Europe remained subdued, we did have a few pockets of good performance with Turkey and Spain doing  well in the period.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Rotork Controls saw good performances from Latin America and Asia with a slight decline in oil and gas being  offset by an improving power market in China and an improving situation in India. Latin America saw an increase  in the oil and gas market in the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Towards the end of the year, we are looking forward to the introduction of the Centork electric actuator design for  the water and power market. This is likely to benefit us in 2015 rather than in 2014. However, in 2014, we ar e  introducing new variant of the CMA process control actuator that will provide improved specification to compete  against the incumbent products.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Fluid Systems saw a marginal improvement due to the management of cost and favorable product mix. Latin  America continues to provide fantastic opportunities for growth with a couple of significant orders booked in the  quarter; one for a power station in Mexico and the other for a second phase of the gas and liquid pipeline  automation project in Mexico. The pipeline order represents the largest single order that Rotork has received at  £11 million. Deliveries will start this year, but the majority of the order will ship in 2015 and 2016.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The external market indicators remain positive, with activity levels remaining high in North America, with the  focus on unconventional oil and gas exploration resulting also in an increase in midstream activity. Australia will  see some more investment in coal-bed methane and there is significant investment reported in the downstream  sector, especially in developing and emerging economies.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Power is showing signs of improvement with India following the election-making positive noises about  investment. China has a strong pipeline in new power generation, capacity requirements with come private  investors also now becoming active. It is also reported that there are encouraging energy requirements from a  variety of regions, including the Middle East, Asia, Latin America and the Americas.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: We are expecting to see growth in industrial water treatment, produce water, process water reuse and  desalination. The Middle East is increasing infrastructure spend as urbanization puts additional pressure on fresh  water resources. The water market remains stable, although the investment is lagging the economic upturn in the  developed countries.

file: RORL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 4August2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance
texts.text: Rotork has always been a cost-conscious and lean company. Our outsource manufacturing model means that  material costs are always our largest expense item. Sourcing initiatives to reduce the cost of materials are our  constant activity, and we've increased our strategic sourcing expertise during the period to accelerate this activity.  Across the group, the current materials initiatives drive anticipated annual savings of £4 million.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance
texts.text: Personnel costs are our next largest expense. Following the slowdown in the oil and gas market, we implemented a  recruitment freeze early in the year, and to reduce overtime and temporary workers. As a result, the head count  has fallen 36 since the start of the year, but is still 152 higher than it was in June 2014, although, 115 of these  people joined with acquisitions. The recruitment freeze not only affects new positions, but also the replacement of  levers. All recruitment requires approval and the reorganization of duties, vacated roles – with the reorganization  of duties, vacated roles are now being permanently eliminated where possible.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance
texts.text: Order intake for Gears was 2% higher than the comparative period, or 4.7% ahead when currency is removed.  Revenue has grown slightly ahead of the rate of order intake growth at 3.7% or 6% on an OCC basis. The impact of  currency on Gears is clearly visible here. Whilst reported gross margin has declined 120 basis points on an OCC  basis, it has increased 140 basis points.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance
texts.text: In the first half of 2014, YTC contributed three month's results, whilst Midland wasn't purchased until early in the  second half. The reported growth figures therefore reflect double the contribution from YTC and the full benefit  from Midland. Order intake is 1.1% higher on an OCC basis, despite the impact of a softer oil and gas market.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: I will try and provide a little color on each of the divisional slides to help with the movement in each market. But  what is clear is that oil and gas has reduced as a percentage of the total revenue and now account for 52% down  from 57% reported in the full year of 2014. In terms of other end markets, the water market was down slightly,  mainly as a result of AMP6 program in the UK taking time to benefit the market. The power market was up by  2.5%, despite the slowdown in China, which is our largest market for power. And one area of strong growth was in  the industrial market reflecting our continued strategy of broadening our end market exposure.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of geography, we saw a strong growth in North America and Europe. North America continue to see  upstream oil and gas expenditure, but we also saw good levels of activity across all markets. In Europe, all of the  divisions performed well except Controls, who saw a decline in business activity. And with the exception of  Instruments, all divisions experienced a challenging trading environment in Asia Pacific and the Middle East.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The Controls division saw good levels of activity in North America predominantly in the oil and gas sector. And  across the division as a whole, we also experience growth in water and the industrial market.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Fluid Systems is the division most reliant on the oil and gas industry. And so it is not surprising that they have  been the most impacted by the challenging oil and gas market. We have been expanding our presence in other end  markets and all of these areas showed growth in the period. But unfortunately, the growth was not enough to  replace the oil and gas revenue.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of region, North America, Latin America, Europe and the UK, all delivered some growth, and we saw  positive order intake in the second quarter as we benefited from a number of project placement, including a  number of North American LNG projects.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So in terms of market dynamics, we expect capital expenditure in the oil and gas sector to remain subdued due to  the low oil price. And this will see contract delays as customers review the long-term viability of projects. This will  mean uncertainty is likely to remain in the market and this may lead to increase pricing pressure, as we move into  a more competitive landscape. And then, although, we are a premium brand, we will not be immune to this.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: However, there are and will continue to be pockets of investment activity such as North American LNG. And we  anticipate that this will continue driven by commercial and non-commercial rationale, including national interest.  Some industries will see increased spend due to lower raw material costs and changes in legislation. We also  expect to see continued investment in our old infrastructure.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, let me summarize the key messages of the morning. We have had a challenging first half with several  headwinds to contend with, including a downturn in the oil and gas market, geopolitical uncertainty in a number  of key markets, and currency volatility. To reflect the market, we have accelerated a number of cost management  programs; however, we continue to drive our sales teams because we believe that the market still poses  opportunities if we invest and focus on the markets and regions that are still active.

file: RORL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 2August2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director
texts.text: The absolute value of overheads is broadly flat with the first half of 2015 with overhead savings offset by  inflationary pressures and targeted investments. Europe and the Middle East grew supported by a positive oil and  gas market, but this was insufficient to offset declines in oil and gas in all other regions.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director
texts.text: The Americas and Far East saw a reduction in sales across most end markets. Improved project activity in China  compared with the first half of 2015 did not translate into sales in the period and this led to lower power sales for  the division as a whole. In water, U.S.A. was the bright spot with strong growth in revenue.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director
texts.text: The market for Fluid Systems remain challenging and the very low volumes have resulted in a disappointing profit  margin in the period. Order intake was 17.3% lower than the strong first half of 2015 as we continue to see a  subdued oil and gas market. However, order intake was higher than second half of 2015 and the second quarter  of this year grew compared with the first.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director
texts.text: Weak project activity in oil and gas saw the proportion of revenue from this end market declined to 65% of the  division's sales in the period. LNG was particularly strong in the second quarter of 2015 and further orders on the  same projects meant it was also a positive within the oil and gas market in the second quarter of 2016. Latin  America and Asia Pacific were the regions, which showed the largest percentage reduction, whilst the Middle  East and Africa saw growth as a result of a stronger oil and gas market.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director
texts.text: In Gears, the water market grew organically by 18% with North America and Asia Pacific, the two most active  regions. In the Middle East, the growth came from oil and gas, whereas most other regions saw a decline in this  end market. The inclusion of Roto Hammer and Mastergear – with the inclusion of Roto Hammer and Mastergear,  oil and gas sales grew and are now 51% of the division's sales.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director
texts.text: Instruments' results are heavily influenced by the acquisition of Bifold and M&M, both of which took place in the  second half of 2015. Whilst reported order intake is 55.8% higher; on an OCC basis, it declined 8.3%, as s ome of  the slowdown experienced by Fluid Systems impacted Instruments' customers. The revenue comparison is similar  with a reported 56.3% increase reversing on an OCC basis to a 9.1% reduction. The reduction in OCC revenue  and a tougher tire market for Fairchild contributed to 130 basis points reduction in gross margin on an OCC basis,  despite a 330 basis points reduction in material costs.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director
texts.text: Oil and gas was 52% of Instruments sales in the period. Industrial Process is Instruments' next largest end market  and this was affected by a slowdown in the tire market in China, but additional sales from M&M meant that the  end market grew overall. Water, which is the smallest end market, was the fastest growing, whilst rail, which is  within the other end market remains a lumpy project business with lower order intake in this period than the first  half of 2015.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Thank you, Jonathan. So, to summarize the first half, the oil and gas market remained weak and now accounts for  51% of group revenue; excluding Bifold, the percentage would have been 50% of group revenue. To remind you,  Bifold is heavily oil and gas-focused and particularly upstream-focused and this is why we have seen an increase  in the percentage related to the upstream sector as can be seen on this graph.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Midstream and downstream both reduced as a proportion of group revenue, reflecting the general downturn in the  market. Sales to the water market have grown with activity in both the developed and developing economies,  largely benefiting Controls and Gears divisions. Our Industrial market is continuing to grow and now represents  15% of revenue with our HVAC business performing well and companies like M&M taking us into new industrial  markets.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So I'd like to share with you a little more color on the markets in the second half. In the oil and gas sector,  upstream continues to see financial constraints and this is impacting subsea and deepwater production the most.  In the U.S.A. and Middle East, we are starting to see signs of an improving market, although it is too early to say if  this is sustainable.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We are also benefiting from recent acquisitions and product developments, giving us new opportunities within our  existing markets and customer base. In midstream, we expect the oil market to remain subdued, however, gas  pipelines are expected to be more active. The downstream market will continue to be supported by LNG activity,  although this is slowing. However, the geographic mismatch between the available capacity and growing demand  should drive opportunities.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In water and sewage, recent reports suggest that the market is forecast to grow at 5% per annum until 2020, with  China, U.S.A. and Japan the most active. Power, we're seeing a rapidly evolving landscape with renewables  growing particularly fast. We are still seeing investment in clean coal but increasingly in gas and nuclear,  especially in China. The heating, ventilating and air conditioning or HVAC market continues to see good levels of  growth across most regions.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As can be seen by our internal project activity graph, all our markets are still very active. All industries are  showing an increase over June 2015. And in terms of end destination, only Europe is showing a decline, mainly  driven by lower oil and gas expenditure and a slowdown in the power market. The general indication is that  projects are smaller in nature with few mega projects being worked on.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: This slide aims to show the direction of travel of our innovation strategy. Our focus is to recognize the drive to  reduce the environmental impact of our products and the activities of our customers by reducing the energy  consumption of our product, provide customers with lower cost of ownership and provide a complete solution to  the customer from a broad product portfolio, whilst giving more information to our customers to manage their plant  with more data. This is driving a number of initiatives across all of our divisions.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In Controls, we are seeing more quotation activity, but fewer units per quote as we see a trend for smaller  projects, as mentioned earlier. The water market remains active although it is not currently growing as fast as the  potential we see in this area would suggest. We are seeing more project activity in the Middle East and China,  offset by weaker markets at the start of the year in the USA and India, but there are signs of this improving  recently.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Process control remains a good growth area for Controls, as customers demand more information from their  plants. And given the potential in the water market, the new Centork electric actuator launched last year is an  important product and is gaining acceptance in the market although it will take time to establish it as an industry  standard.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Fluid Systems remains the division with the most exposure to oil and gas, and has, therefore, been the most  impacted by the slowdown in the sector. As with Controls, we are seeing more quotations, but less units per  quote. Although unlike Controls, some of the units are for engineered solutions at higher value per unit as the  market looks for increased reliability. Fluid Systems, non-oil and gas markets of water, power and Industrial  Process are growing as a percentage of sales as we develop our product offering and look to broaden our end  market exposure.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As I've just said, the non-oil and gas opportunities are important for this division and we are seeing positive results  for the K-TORK product in water, Industrial Process and vehicle applications. This division interacts with all of the  other divisions and developing technology superior solutions is key to the success of the business. Going forward,  the engineering collaboration is important across all of our divisions.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of active market, the water and Industrial Process markets remain active and are expected to drive  demand with activity strong in the Americas and Middle East. This division benefits from having a diverse  customer base and a fragmented market with many small competitors. It is very difficult for them to provide the  level of sales and service support that the Rotork subsidiaries can in the 38 countries where we are active. These  subsidiary offices will also benefit from the expanded product portfolio provided by the acquisition of Roto  Hammer and Mastergear.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The automation market continues to develop with a focus on lower energy demands and the impact of plants on  the environment. Technology that helps customers reduce their energy consumption and improve their impact on  the environment are in demand, and although it is a focus for each division, it is clearly driving activity in the  instrumentation market.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: However, we anticipate that margins for the full year will be lower than in 2015 due to a combination of increased  overheads, product mix and pricing pressure. We anticipate that activity in the oil and gas markets will remain  subdued and the timing of order placement will be difficult to forecast. However, based on our current order book,  project visibility and market-focused opportunities, the board believes the group remains well-placed for the  current year and beyond.

file: RORL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 8August2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Rotork Plc
texts.text: I'm pleased to report a continuation of the slightly more favorable market trends we observed – sit down please,  Andy, that's great – towards the end of last year within the oil and gas sector, which still represents around half of  our business. The oil price seems to have stabilized in the $40 to $50 price range, and the industry is showing  signs of coming to terms with this new norm. Evidence is beginning to emerge of a slow, but gradual return to  more consistent project activity after some of the sharp slowdowns and project cancellations over the last two  years.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Unquestionably, cost pressures persist, and we have to work hard on a project-by-project basis to justify our  premium solutions, but project activity levels continue to show gradual improvement. Increased activity is  particularly evident in the North American shale market, for example, whereas areas like deep sea will clearly take  longer to recover.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Outside of the oil and gas sector, the water, HVAC and industrial process markets continue to exhibit steady  progress, whilst power markets remain subdued albeit benefiting from increased investments in renewables.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Inventory reduction initiatives are ongoing, however due to the increased level of activity mid-year, inventory is £6  million higher than at the start of the period and now represents 15.4% of sales compared with 14.5% at the year  end.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Now turning to the operational review. This slide summarizes the group's key markets and geographies. These  slides are on an as-reported basis. Revenue grew in each division and all end markets were up 2% on the prior  period. Oil and gas was a lower percentage of group revenue due to the faster growth in our other end markets as  our strategy of diversifying our end markets continues to make progress. Oil and gas revenue increased in each  division except Instruments. Our other end markets: water, power and industrial were up across each division.  Controls performed particularly well in the industrial sector.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: In terms of geography, revenue grew in all regions except Latin America. North America saw positive activity in  upstream and downstream oil and gas, as well as water and industrial. All markets were up across Asia. In  Europe, industrial performed especially well. As part of our strategy, we have continued to strengthen our  presence in the Middle East and this is having a positive impact with all end markets up in the region, with notable  increases in upstream oil and gas and power. Latin America is predominantly an oil and gas market for us and  continues to be challenging.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Turning now to the divisions. Controls performed well in the period. Order intake was up 18.7% or 6.3% on an  OCC basis. Improvements in the water, power and industrial markets and upstream oil and gas drove a 14.1%  increase in revenue or 2.2% OCC. Underlying gross margins have improved 60 basis points, reflecting material  cost savings initiatives. At an adjusted operating profit level, OCC margins were 30 basis points lower as the  inflationary increases in staff costs offset the gross margin improvement.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Asia grew due to investment in downstream in China and growth in the power market. North America and the  Middle East were positive due to upstream oil and gas. Europe was more mixed, with strength in industrial offset  by lower oil and gas sales, and Latin America remained challenging.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: There is growing interest in our CK product range for the power and water markets, which will support our focus  on this growing area. We also see good opportunities for Controls products in the growing HVAC and industrial  markets

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Fluid Systems is the division with the highest proportion of oil and gas sales and has seen order intake up 17.8%  or 5.3% on an OCC basis, as activity has increased primarily in upstream oil and gas in the Middle East, Africa  and Eastern Europe. Reported revenue increased 10.2%, but on an OCC basis decreased by 1.8% as the  improvement in order intake takes time to flow through to revenue.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The power and industrial markets made modest progress with the biggest growth in water. The Americas and  Europe both grew with Asia and Latin America up as well. We continue to leverage the Mastergear additions t o  our portfolio both through strengthening existing relationships with customers and developing relationships with  new valve makers. Our global brand with local support is becoming increasingly important to customers as our  innovative solutions such monitoring fugitive emissions and gathering information on how the valve is operating.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: We saw a double-digit growth across the water, power and industrial markets. Asia and North America was strong  and accounted for just under 50% of Instruments sales in the period. Each of the Instruments businesses  continue to expand their product ranges and new products – with new products and variants of existing products  across the wide range of end markets that Instruments sells in to.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Rotork Plc
texts.text: We're seeing several common trends across the divisions. The North American and Middle East regions are  active across each division, particularly in upstream oil and gas where positive sentiment in the U.S. and activity  in the Middle East has provided some support for new onshore drilling activity.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Rotork Plc
texts.text: We're starting to see stabilization across the oil and gas market. Midstream oil and gas is still expected to exhibit  modest growth in the medium term, mostly arising from incremental investments in new gas pipelines and  territories such as Eastern Europe and Asia.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Downstream activity will be driven by emerging markets, low raw material costs, and new environmental  legislation such as the demand for lower sulfur content. The need to cut the cost of production is driving a  requirement for increased reliability and plant efficiency. The ability to understand how equipment in the plant is  performing is critical to this. Asset management and data analysis provide the customer with insights to the  performance of the plant and can help to reduce unplanned shutdowns. There is a trend to extend the life of  plants wherever possible and an improved understanding of plant performance facilitates this.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The board has ambition to return in time to the mid- to high-single digit growth enjoyed prior to the oil and gas  downturn, and to the higher margins associated with that. And it seeks to deliver that growth without an ex pressed  reliance on a material upturn in capital spend in the oil and gas market.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Now, this ambition requires a fresh perspective on our approach to our business. And such an approach is likely  to include a material increase in the investments in our new product development activity. And a significant  expansion of our service activity. Both represent fertile territory for Rotork with oil and gas customers, for  example, demanding much greater innovation from their supply chain as they seek to regroup around the new  $50 a barrel norm.

file: RORL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 7August2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Kevin G. Hostetler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Let's take a look at our first half results. Once again, we have delivered a very encouraging set of results. Our  orders for the first half were strong, increasing by over 13% on an organic constant currency basis. Input was  supported by increasing activity within our oil and gas markets, particularly evident in small- to midsized projects,  as we see a continuing return to more normal investment patterns around maintenance and operational upgrades.

texts.speaker: Kevin G. Hostetler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rotork Plc
