texts.text: Larger project investments in oil and gas are also returning yet still remain lower than historic levels and still  somewhat patchy. Quotation levels for these larger programs remain high, driven by the stabilization of oil prices  above $60 per barrel, coupled with major oil companies' multi-year efforts to reduce the costs of their large  programs.

texts.speaker: Kevin G. Hostetler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: A general increase in automation across our other end markets continues to benefit all of our divisions providing  good growth opportunities in water, our growing HVAC market and our industrial and processing market  segments.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Now turning to the operational review. This slide summarizes the group's key markets and geographies. These  slides are on as reported basis. Revenue grew in each division but the pattern by geography and end market was  mixed. Oil and gas was the fastest growing end market which increased 21%. In total, oil and gas was 53% of  revenue, with downstream, the largest and fastest growing area now 27% of group revenue.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Upstream grew nearly in line with group revenue, holding at around 17% whilst midstream declined. Industrial  continued to perform well, up 16%, but water and power both declined, down 7% and 11%, respectively.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: In terms of geography, growth was strongest in the Far East, but declined in the Middle East. The Far East  benefited from increased spend in downstream oil and gas, with the other end markets consistent overall with the  comparative period. The Middle East showed a decline in power, and upstream oil and gas spend, both of which  had been positive in the comparative period. Western Europe was the region with the strongest growth in  industrial, offsetting a decline in midstream in this area.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Controls oil and gas exposure is greatest in downstream. The growth in that market has therefore benefited the  division and boosted its sales particularly in the Far East and to a lesser extent North America. Upstream and  midstream, we're broadly flat. But within this, upstream was positive in Eastern Europe but declined in the Middle  East, and midstream was positive in the Far East. Power declined due to lower activity in the Middle East and Far  East, with North America reporting the largest reduction in water. Industrial process, including HVAC, grew as a  result of a positive performance in Europe.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Fluid Systems is still a division with the highest proportion of oil and gas sales, and has seen a rebound in sales in  the period. Order intake increased more in Fluid Systems than any other division, up 14.7% on an OCC basis.  Revenue increased by 20.6%, as the improvement in order intake at the end of last year and in the first quarter of  this year particularly converted to revenue. This pickup in volume and a reduction in the material cost percentage  of 80 basis points has driven an improvement in underlying gross margin of 410 basis points. This has more than  covered a rise in overheads, and adjusted operating profit increased by 590 basis points against a very poor  result in the first half of last year.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Fluid Systems has a more balanced spread across the three elements of oil and gas. Improvements in upstream  and downstream were offset by a decline in midstream. Upstream was supported by Eastern Europe,  downstream by North America, and the Far East.

texts.speaker: Kevin G. Hostetler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Within our stated workstreams, individual initiatives have been divided into sand, pebbles and boulders,  classifications depicting the dimensions of both complexity and impact for each initiative. We've identified many  pebble and sand initiatives enough to keep our operating team busy for the next 12 to 18 months. We'll come  back and talk to you more about the boulders after we've executed upon our near-term improvement  opportunities. These smaller and midsized initiatives will yield strong results in terms of both growth and margin  improvement. Further, they represent lower-risk projects that don't require a wholesale shift in the company in  order to be successful.

texts.speaker: Kevin G. Hostetler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: These sand and pebble initiatives will be driven in parallel to our overall IT systems implementations and our  continued focus on improvement of core business processes. It is this combination of core business process  improvements and systems implementations that will enable a second phase of operational integrations and back  office leverage in the future.

texts.speaker: Kevin G. Hostetler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Within the year, we've added three additional key account managers, bringing our total to eight team members.  The team now focuses on 15 of our largest oil and gas end users and the most active international engineering  contractors. This key account team has been able to adapt to the end user's business requirements and to  improve relationships with key influencers and decision-makers within the procurement, operations and project  departments.

texts.speaker: Kevin G. Hostetler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: In relation to our footprint optimization, you can think of this in two waves. The first wave is comprised of the no- brainers. These are the small locations with high infrastructure costs that will always be highly dilutive to our  margin ambitions. Each of these are being evaluated, and we will act upon these more quickly.

texts.speaker: Kevin G. Hostetler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Lastly, these pillars are supported by our strategy, portfolio and product line assessment activities. The initial  assessment of our portfolio yielded three determinations of businesses we should exit at once: the nuclear island  actuation business, the valve adaptation business, and a small regional engineering center. These businesses  account for around 1% of group revenue and with overheads of circa £5 million are highly dilutive to group  margins. The payback on these exits will be less than one year.

file: RORL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 28February2012 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & MD-Rotork Controls, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Jonathan. All three of the established divisions made good progress in the year and in the next few  slides I'll just be focusing on the three existing divisions that we had for the data. With RFS reporting the strongest  revenue growth, 24.1% ahead of last year. RFS and controls especially benefited from the growth in the oil and gas  market which grew 17.9% on last year and accounted for just over 53% of the company's revenue. This is difficult  to breakdown further as projects are often complex and multifaceted. However, our estimates are that 7% of our  total revenue in the year can be attributed to upstream activity, 18% midstream and 28% downstream.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & MD-Rotork Controls, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The water market remains stubbornly flat year-on-year and now accounts for just over 12% of revenue. However,  as we have stated on several occasions, we still believe that this is a market with high potential. The power market  has once again grown with the Asia Pacific region leading the way. And as we continue to strengthen our product  portfolio, we will also see opportunities to broaden our end market exposure with the industrial sector and other  smaller markets providing further opportunities for growth.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & MD-Rotork Controls, Rotork Plc
texts.text: We have improved our test facilities in Leeds to support the development of our electro-hydraulic product range,  and in Lucca we are finally to release the latest range of gas-over-oil actuators. Our Gears division, also has a  strong pipeline of product introductions planned for 2012 and all three divisions have been working on the  nuclear development project that is not expected to benefit the group until 2013 at the earliest.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & MD-Rotork Controls, Rotork Plc
texts.text: So the focus at present is on technology and products that sit within the flow control and pressure control area of  this slide. We are also interested in flow and pressure measurement. These products will either control or measure  flow and/or provide diagnostic capabilities back to the control room. So this slide indicates the product grouping  and the areas of interest to the company.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & MD-Rotork Controls, Rotork Plc
texts.text: To support our growth plans, we have increased the Rotork management board with the addition of Mark  Williams as Global HR Director and Pamela Bingham as Group Business Development Director.  In terms of market drivers, the largest market for Rotork is the oil and gas market and we continue to see positive  market trends with countries demonstrating economic growth such as China and India driving demand. The  activity of the oil majors also supports the view that further investment is expected in the future with new  technologies and industries such as the development of the unconventional oil and gas field, we will see further  growth opportunities.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & MD-Rotork Controls, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Changes in technology also drives the market and we see an increase in the demand for low sulphur fuels and the  subsequent changes to existing refineries as positive for us, as is the need for a strategic storage facility worldwide.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & MD-Rotork Controls, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Power generation is the second largest market for Rotork and while we see the addition of new capacity as the  main driver in recent years, we have also seen an increasing aging plant being replaced as a positive development.  The major demand is still from emerging markets and especially China and India. Emissions reduction will also  generate further opportunities and in this I include the nuclear program. China alone has 160 plants planned and  335 proposed, most are programmed to be operational over the next 15 years.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & MD-Rotork Controls, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Water sources are becoming depleted especially in urban areas and with populations growing in developing  counties, there is a requirement for water and wastewater management and investment. Water is one of the  heaviest regulated industries and this will drive demand for further investment in order to meet the regulations  that are set. Similar to the power market, the aging assets are going to need to be replaced.

file: RORL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 5March2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: We introduced a number of new products during the year, including the IQ3 electric actuator that will benefit us  in 2013 and beyond. We have seen expenditure on our infrastructure increase recently, and this trend continued  in 2012 with new facilities, expansion of existing facilities, and new openings all being undertaken.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The oil and gas market remains our largest market and the share of business in this sector actually grew and now  accounts for 54% of the Group revenue. All three sectors of the market saw strong growth over 2011 with upstream  up 31%, midstream up 16% and downstream, the largest market, up 14%.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: As a result of the mining activity, we have tried to identify mining in this presentation for the first time. In terms  of end destination, activity in North America was strong. And this was benefited from the increase in oil and gas  expenditure on the back of shale gas.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Asia Pacific remains our largest end market, even taking into account the slowdown we have experienced in the  power sector, and this is due to the increased spend in other areas, such as oil and gas and water. Europe was the  only market to go backwards, reflecting the difficult trading environment in Europe, although I still see this as a  very positive result for Europe.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The initial reaction to the product from customers has been very positive. The CMA extends our process control  family of products and we will provide – and will provide our customers with a complete solution in the process  market where electric actuators are preferred.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: In 2011, we acquired Rotork Norway and Centork, a Spanish electric actuator manufacturer, and the integration of  both are proceeding to plan. The coal seam gas market has been very active for us, and I will expand on this on a  later slide, but our success has led us to consider opening new offices in Australia to provide increased service  support to our customers. Our investment in new offices and acquisitions, such as Schischek, with the new  product introductions, provide opportunity for continued growth.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: We continue to introduce new products in this division, and this year saw the important introduction of the  second generation of Gas-over-Oil product range. This is used generally in gas pipelines. This is significant as it  supports our ability to compete in this very important market.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Schischek is an electric actuator company that was established in 1975 in Langenzenn, near Nuremberg in  Germany. The business has focused on the niche area of explosion-proof electric actuators used in the heating,  ventilating and air-conditioning or HVAC market. The company will join the Controls division and the existing  GM and management team will stay with the business.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: One important market for us this year relates to coal seam gas. We received orders for over 5,000 actuators on  three projects in Australia. The consortiums behind QCLNG, GLNG and APLNG are developing coal seam gas  reserve in Queensland's Surat and Bowen basins. Pipelines will link the natural gas production wells with a world- class LNG production plant on Curtis Island that will initially produce more than 27 million tonnes of LNG for  export each year.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: We will supply a full range of products, including electric, electro-hydraulic, pneumatic, Gas-over-Oil and over  4,000 CVA actuators for process valve control. The value of orders received to date for the three projects exceed  £26 million and will be delivered in 2013 and into 2014.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The long-term market drivers remain positive with growth anticipated in the oil and gas sector driven by global  demand. To satisfy this demand we are seeing new exploration opportunities and increasingly these are in deep  water or challenging environments. The traditional markets have also been supplemented by unconventional oil  and gas developments, increasing activity in the LNG market and this looks set to continue.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: With the growth in the oil and gas sector, the demand for storage is also expected to grow and this is often due to  governments assessing their need for strategic reserves. We also believe that there will be a reallocation of refining  capacity over the next few years for a variety of reasons, including national security and the changing industrial  landscape. Water and sewage, again, grew in the year for Rotork, but it still remains the market with the highest  potential.  Population growth, water scarcity, urbanization with an increase of water re-use and desalination taking with the  ageing plants already in operation are all reasons to remain positive about this market.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Power; although 2012 was not a great year for power, the growing population and general industrialization of  developing countries suggest that more generating capacity is required. And if you then add the environmental  story with the need for reducing the impact of generating power on the environment and improving the  efficiencies of the existing plants, you can see why this market will remain positive for some time to come.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Of course, renewable energy is also a growing area of this market. We expect positive developments in the power  market, as we recognize the lack of power generating capacity in certain countries around the world and the  ageing plants in others.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: We have always supplied actuators into the mining sector. It's not a new sector from that point of view. But  recently we have seen an increase in this area. Whilst in the past, we have generally included the mining projects  in the oil and gas chart, we have now shown them as a separate bar. Although we have a reduction in the terms of  number of projects being tracked in the oil and gas area and less projects destined for Asia, the overall activity in  both cases remain at very high levels.

file: RORL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 4March2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Rotork Controls order intake grew 2.9% and revenue by 9.7 %, but these both reduced on an organic constant  currency basis, with input 3.4% lower than 2012. This is partly a feature of the large Australian coal bed methane  projects which were won in 2012 and resulted in revenue spread through 2013 and into 2014.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: So 2013 was another year of progress, with all four divisions achieving revenue growth. Power continued to be  challenging, however, oil and gas saw good growth levels, with our upstream, midstream, and downstream sales  all higher than the previous year.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The fastest growing areas were seen in the upstream and midstream sectors. This reflects the success we have  enjoyed in North American shale and especially Australian coal bed methane projects along with general activity  levels being good. This has resulted in 59% of revenue now coming from the various oil and gas sectors, up from  54% last year.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Our North American offices performed well overall and this was due to a number of factors including the  continued expansion of tight oil and gas exploration and production in the U.S., targeted growth from municipal  water infrastructure and a strong export market from the U.S. valve makers.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: China continued to deliver growth and despite the downturn in power projects globally, there was still significant  China power projects. We also saw growth in the water and marine industries. Following the investment in our  facilities in China, we continue to focus on expanding our domestic business alongside our international one.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: We are planning on expanding or opening nine new offices as we continue to develop our sales channel and  improve our facilities. We also have a number of product releases due in 2014 with one major product  introduction focused on the water, power and industrial market that we anticipate will start to have a positive  impact on our results in 2015. Our focus on HVAC will also see further opportunities.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Fluid Systems, oil and gas remains the largest end market. We saw strong growth within the oil and gas sector  with revenue increasing 21%. 77% of the revenue for RFS is now oil and gas related, but it is spread across many  aspects of the oil and gas market ranging from the upstream coal seam gas demand in Australia to safety systems  and tank storage applications in downstream.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: We've also seen good increases in our sales destined for the water, industrial and mining markets with sales into  power declining, reflecting the challenging market conditions in power seen across the business. In August, we  acquired GTA and I will refer back to this on a later slide.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: We have a number of product launches planned for 2014 and 2015, following a number of years of increased R&D.  The most anticipated launch this year is the SI-3 product that takes the IQ3 technology and combines it with a  range of electro-hydraulic products. We continue to look for locations to expand our CoEs. As mentioned, we  opened a number in 2013 and we will look to open a number more in 2014. The development of our product  portfolio provides us with products for markets other than our traditional oil and gas market. Products such as  GTA and K-TORK are focused on water, industrial petrochemical and power applications.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Sales into the various oil and gas markets remain constant at 52% of Gears revenue this year with good levels of  sales of our subsea range of gear boxes. Like other divisions, Gears saw a reduction in sales into power market, but  this was offset by growth in the water market.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: North Asia performed well with project success in the tire sector, one of the highlights. Our European sales was  supported by customers there winning export projects around the world. The Instruments division has the most  diversified end market exposure of all Rotork's divisions. Just over 30% of sales are now into the oil and gas  market. This increased during the year with the addition of Soldo which has a greater focus on oil and gas than the  Fairchild product line.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: In July 2013, we acquired Flowco, an actuator service company based near our headquarters in Bath. And the  company has been successfully integrated into our Rotork UK sales subsidiary. Flowco has a small team of  dedicated service engineers focused on the water industry.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: There has been some comment in the last few months on the health of the oil and gas market. We see that there is  still a significant amount of investment around the world in places such as the USA, where we have seen activity  last year, supporting our view that Rotork will continue to benefit from that investment for a number of years to  come.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: A recent publication suggested that worldwide upstream oil and gas investment is expected to have risen by  around 6% to $7 10 billion in 2013 relative to 2012, a new record high for the fourth consecutive year. Declining  output from existing fields is a major driver of upstream investment, and the new unconventional oil and gas  fields provide countries without their own natural resources access to energy resource for the first time in some  cases. This will also trigger further investment in LNG, as gas is transported around the world and we are seeing  good levels of LNG projects being planned. The spend in upstream is also continuing, with over $216 billion  planned to be spent over the next five years on over 270,000 kilometers of pipeline, with Russia and USA leading  the way.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The main drivers for the water market remain population growth, water scarcity, although that may be a  worldwide issue rather than a UK problem, and urbanization. We will also see continued investment in water  reuse and desalination. We are seeing increased spend in aging assets, as the developed economies look to keep  their plants operational and look to develop them to cater for the increased population and tighter environmental  regulations that continue to support further investment in technology to help manage our infrastructure.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Power has been challenging for us in the last couple of years. However, the drivers are still positive. Population  growth and the lack of available power coupled with the continued industrialization of developing economie s with  the need to reduce harmful emissions as well as increase the efficiency of the plant will require increased  investment over the next few years in traditional as well as nuclear and renewable power generation.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The sector that we classify as industrial, mining, and other will largely follow the world economies' demands. The  need for minerals or consumer products will be driven by the improving living standards around the world, but  this will also lead to the need to reduce our impact on the environment and look for energy efficiency in plants,  increasing the need for process control and automation.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Our own project tracking system shows project activity remaining positive, with oil and gas seeing a good increase  on last year. Water remained flat and power is slightly down. However, we have seen a significant increase in  mining and other general industry with our focus in these areas and the addition of our recent acquisitions. It is  good to see the trend is across the globe, with Australasia, Europe and the Americas all reflecting more projects  than this time last year.

file: RORL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 3March2015 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Rotork Fluid Systems actually saw a slight decline reflecting the challenging oil and gas market. I recognized that  there will be a lot of interest in what we are seeing now with regard the oil and gas market, and I will try and deal  with this on a later slide. But for now, looking at 2014, we can see that the oil and gas market as a whole was lower  than the prior year.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We did see a strong performance in the upstream sector with revenue benefiting from projects received in 2013 as  well as order intake of 2014 from North American shale. With the current market, we would expect our upstream  business to return to normal levels going forward. Oil and gas contribution as a percentage of total revenue  declined in the period to 57% down from 59%. However, the reduction was in midstream, with upstream and  downstream both growing in real terms and as a percentage of revenue.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As I've already said, North America saw the benefit of continued upstream investment in shale, especially in the  first half of the year, although we did see this decline in the second half as the oil price weakened. The Middle East  is more exposed to the timing of large, lumpy oil and gas project orders, and we saw a reduction versus a high  comparative period in 2013.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: During the year, we launched a new actuator for the water and power markets and expanded our geographic reach  with the opening of new offices in Poland and Chile. We also invested in our current offices with improved  facilities in the UK, Spain, and Singapore.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The water and power markets are important markets for us. And the introduction of the Centork actuator, we  anticipate that we will see positive results in the second half of the year as production volumes of Centork  increase, supporting the division as a whole. We have identified Eastern Europe and Latin America as growth  markets for the group and the increased product portfolio will support our sales initiatives in these areas.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Whilst there is concern about the impact of the lower oil price on upstream investment, there is a potential upside  in the midstream and downstream market as lower cost may increase demand increasing the need to transport,  refine and store product. The speed of the oil price fall means that it would take time for this investment to come  through in the other areas of the oil and gas market. But in other downturns such as 2008 and 2009, we managed  to report revenue growth as investment moved from one segment of the oil and gas market to another. We  anticipate that this will also have a positive impact on Rotork Site Services as customers look to improve the  efficiency and uptime of their plant and request more data from the field.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Fluid Systems had a difficult year with Russian sanctions and the lower oil price both impacting order intake in  the second half of the year. Despite the slowdown, upstream was the largest market for Fluid Systems in 2014. As  I've already mentioned, the reason for this is that we benefited from a number of upstream projects being  delivered out of the 2013 order book, especially in North America. However, it is worth noting that the yearend  order book at the end of 2014 is at the same level as December 2013. This is partly due to the growth in other  markets such as power and water that both saw an improving market in the period. Oil and gas of Fluid Syste ms  reduced as a percentage of revenue to 72% from last year's 77%.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Asia has been a target market for Gears in recent years and it was good to see progress being made with strong  growth reported in the region. In terms of end market, Gears benefited from the oil and gas activity as well as the  increases in the power, industrial and mining sectors. Margin was slightly impacted in the year due to the  investment in the new manufacturing plant in Leeds. The increased cost associated with the plant was offset to  some extent by the focus on reducing material costs, by developing the global supply chain. And there is further  work to be done in this area.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: This is a small company with a good product that Rotork will be able to support and grow as an international  supplier to the industry over time. While this has increased our addressable market in 2015, we anticipate limited  contribution from the business in 2015 and 2016. The other small acquisition announced today relates to the  Rotork sales and service operations of our agent in Turkey that we acquired last week. This is a small asset  purchase that provides us with direct access to a strategic market. We anticipate growth in the water, power and  shipbuilding markets and to benefit from the investment in oil and gas infrastructure.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So once the addressable market has increased in 2014, what is going to happen in 2015? I think it's fair to say that  taking to account the dramatic decline in the oil price, the current climate has clearly become more challenging  especially in relation to oil and gas upstream investment. Some of this is due, I think, to the investment cycle of  markets such as U.S. shale being shorter. It is far easier to turn on and turn off a project related to oil and gas  production in shale than traditional oil and gas mega projects, and they'r e difficult to cancel once you have started  them.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So whilst this may create some short-term unpredictability, there is still analyst forecasts that show oil demand  growth. The IEA, for instance, still forecast oil demand to rise by an average 0.9% per year until 2020. We may see  a reduction in new exploration in some areas, however, we could see an increase in investment to extract more  from marginal or mature fields by some to maximize profit. We also believe that the low oil price can be positive in  driving demand. This would result in a positive impact in midstream as planned pipeline infrastructure is brought  online.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In certain regions, this is driven by national security reasons, as well as economic drivers. The latest forecast I  have seen states that over 100,000 miles of pipelines are planned for 2015. We also understand that Asia will  overtake North America as the largest market for onshore pipeline, as the region looks to increase imports of oil  and gas from neighboring regions.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Asia is also an important market for downstream activity, with plans to increase refining capacity by 2.7 million  barrels per day by 2040. And by 2040, it is anticipated that two out of every three barrels of crude oil will be  destined for Asia, reflecting the reallocation of refining capacity from mature markets to emerging markets. This  geographical rebalancing will also see consolidation of facilities in developed markets and new petrochemical  complexes in emerging markets.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: World electricity demand is forecast to grow on average by 2.1% per year to 2040, driving investment in  developing economies, in new plant and replacement of aging and obsolete plants elsewhere. Tighter emission  regulations will continue to trend from coal to gas. For instance, in the U.S., a 40% incre ase in the use of gas for  power is forecast up to 2040.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In the Middle East, strong economic and population growth will drive 2.7% growth in demand for electricity.  China and India have both been important markets for us in power and still provide considerable opportunity for  coal, gas and nuclear newbuilds.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: A main driver for an increase in the water market is population growth. However, there are many areas of the  water market, each have their own drivers, but water scarcity and poor infrastructure are the main ones, leading  to an increase in planned capital spend over the next few years. Increasingly, businesses are expected to increase  their investment in water and waste water treatment technology, and this will especially impact the mining  industry where tighter environmental regulations will put pressure on mining companies to invest in water  infrastructure.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Mining, as already mentioned, is a growing market for Rotork, and is expected to see an increase in CapEx spend  from 2016, and a stable year in 2015. We are likely to see continued benefit from increased environmental  regulation in relation to water management, in countries focused on mining such as Chile.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Marine is a market that we have limited exposure to over the years. However, we are expecting the ma rket to  increase over the next three years and the low oil price could be beneficial as it stimulates economic growth. More  general trade results in more sea trade requiring ships, and oil speculators may take a view on the oil price and  look for floating storage vessels. With the acquisition of Masso, we are looking to build a suitable product platform  to benefit from this growth.

file: RORL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 1March2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Despite continued difficult trading conditions in the oil and gas market in the second half, the results we are  delivering today are in line with the revised guidance we provided in September. We acted swiftly to mitigate the  challenging environment with an accelerated cost management program, we announced this at the half year  results in August, and it has delivered greater than anticipated annualized savings. Continued cost management  will remain a key focus in 2016 and we are taking further actions as regards material, overhead, and  manufacturing cost, which I'll come on to later in my section.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance
texts.text: Thank you, Peter. As you can see from the slide, all key measures were impacted by deteriorating oil and gas  market conditions. Order intake of £526 million was 11.7% lower than the prior year. On an organic constant  currency basis or OCC, order intake was 15.2% lower, with the second half 17.7% lower than the second half of  2014. Order intake in the fourth quarter was 3.2% higher than the third quarter on an OCC basis.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance
texts.text: Order intake for Gears was marginally higher than the comparative period, 0.4% up on an OCC basis. H2 was 2%  higher than H1, but on an OCC basis H2 was 2.6% lower. Revenue was also lower in the second half compared  with the first half, 3.3% down as reported or 7.8% lower on an OCC basis. For the year as a whole, revenue grew  just over 1% with the currency headwind, a very similar value to the contribution from Roto Hammer.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance
texts.text: Instruments results are heavily influenced by acquisitions with the full year contribution from YTC and Midland  for the first time in 2015, as well as the M&M, Bifold and Eltav acquisitions during the year. Whilst reported order  intake is 43% higher, on an OCC basis, it declined 9.1% as some of the slowdown experienced by Fluid Systems  impacted Instruments customers. The revenue comparison is similar with the reported 46.5% increase reversing  on an OCC basis to a 5.8% reduction. The reduction in revenue resulted in a 50 basis point reduction in gross  margin on an OCC basis, with the reduction increasing to 250 basis points with the addition of the acquisitions.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: During 2015, the oil and gas market continued to be impacted by the weakness in the oil price with all sectors;  upstream, midstream and downstream being affected. Oil and gas contribution as a percentage of t otal revenue  declined in the period to 53%, down from 57%, with midstream and downstream declining as a percentage of  revenue, and upstream remaining at 15% of revenue despite the absolute reduction in the oil and gas sector.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Total revenue in the power market was also down. Our strategy, as we've said many times, is to have a diverse  product portfolio and end market focus. And this provided resilience as we saw a positive progress in the global  industrial and mining and water end user market.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Looking in more detail at the divisions, Controls had a difficult year, with sales to the oil and gas markets being  the most heavily impacted with reduced revenue across upstream, midstream and downstream applications. The   division's market exposure to oil and gas reduced to 48%.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Despite the challenging market conditions, North America continued to grow across most end user markets,  including oil and gas. The Middle East also saw growth in the oil and gas sector and also p ower. The gains in these  markets were not sufficient to offset the reduction in revenue in Asia, which remains the largest market for the  Controls division, and where all end user markets, apart from water, showed a decline.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Centork is the new actuator for the water, power and industrial markets. The final variants of this product range  are being launched in the first half of 2016, which will enable Controls to better leverage direct valve maker  business.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Fluid Systems is the Rotork division with the largest exposure to oil and gas. However, the division's exposure to  this end market reduced once again in 2015 with revenue down from 72% to 68% with all segments experiencing a  reduction. Oil and gas did, though, continue to provide opportunity for the division in some areas. For example,  North America saw a modest growth. Within other end markets, results were mixed. Industrial market grew the  fastest and became the second largest market for Fluid Systems, and most of this increase came from Western  Europe.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The nuclear, marine, power, LNG and HVAC end markets are all potential sources of market expansion and  growth in 2016. Products like the SI3 take time to gain traction in the market, but we expect to see positive  momentum in the second half of the year. There is a significant opportunity for Fluid Systems to collaborate with  the Instruments division to deliver solutions for our customers. And Fluid Systems will start to see the benefit of  our new world-class manufacturing facility in Lucca as production ramps up and as the offices are completed in  the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, turning to Gears. Western Europe was the division's best-performing region and remains its largest end  destination market representing 31% of sales, up from 28% in the previous year. In terms of end markets, Gears  saw growth in power, industrial and water markets. Oil and gas remained the division's largest end market, but  reduced from 57% to 50% of sales. The Roto Hammer acquisition in September adds a new product line to the  Gears product range and increases its presence in the important U.S. market.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In August, we completed the acquisition of Bifold for up to £125 million. This is the largest acquisition completed  by Rotork to-date. Bifold was established more than 100 years ago and has operations in Manchester and Taunton  in the UK. It manufactures pneumatic and hydraulic instrument valves for the oil and gas industry and  wider  industrial markets with expertise in a number of niche sectors such as subsea and wellhead control systems.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The difficult short-term conditions in the oil and gas market are likely to remain for some time. However, we  believe the longer-term trends remain intact in all our markets. The IEA, for instance, still forecasts oil demand to  grow at an annual average growth rate of 1.2% from 2015 to 2020. This is only 0.5 percentage point below the  previous comparable time period from 2009 to 2015. Global gas demand is also projected to grow 2% per year on  average from 2014 to 2020, slower than the 2.3% averaged over the previous 10 years.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Total CapEx on water, wastewater and desalination is forecast to grow by 6% from 2015 to 2019. As we know,  growth will be driven by global megatrends such as urbanization, the growing global population and emerging  market growth. These will drive the long-term demand for new infrastructure. However, aging infrastructure is  also likely to drive further investment.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As well as external drivers, we continue to review our own project tracking system. This should only be seen as an  approximate leading indicator, as it reflects projects that are visible to our sales organization, and does not try to  anticipate the date of order. As you can see, during the period, project activity was down in oil and gas and power,  up in water and steady in industrial. Activity levels remain steady in the Americas, but was down in other regions.

file: RORL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 27February2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Inventory reduction initiatives are ongoing and on an OCC basis, inventory is 15.8% lower than the start of the  year, and now represents 14.6% of sales compared with 16% last year-end. Trade receivables are 5.7% lower on  an OCC basis. And debtor days have reduced by 1 to 61 days. The EU referendum result and its impact on bond  yields has affected the pension scheme deficit, which has risen to £58.5 million, a funding level of 75%.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: At an adjusted operating profit level, lower volumes have a greater impact, and OCC margins are 60 basis points  lower despite a 2.5% reduction in the absolute value of overheads. Lower activity in midstream and downstream  saw total sales from oil and gas reduced from 48% to 45% of the division sales. Water and waste water sales  grew and increased as a share of the division sales to 18%, with the U.S. the largest contributor to this.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Sales in Power declined 8% in constant currency terms and reduced to 21% to the division sales. Whilst the  Americas saw a positive water market, this was more than offset by the decline in oil and gas. The Far East,  where power and oil and gas are the most significant end markets, also saw lower revenue compared with 2015.  The Middle East grew supported by a positive oil and gas market with Europe, Africa, and Southeast Asia also  making progress.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The breakdown of sales by end market is remarkably consistent between 2015 and 2016. Oil and gas has  increased by 1% to 69% with the delivery of the LNG projects in the year increasing midstream, slightly more than  the decline in upstream and downstream. Midstream was the only end market in Fluid Systems which saw growth  in constant currency terms.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: On an OCC basis, oil and gas would have reduced from 35% to 34% of the division sales. M&M has increased  the value of sales to the industrial markets and this remains 17% of sales. Each of the Instruments businesses  continues to expand their product ranges with new products and variants of existing products, and many have  been launched during the year across the wide range of end markets that Instruments sells into.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Right. As in previous years, I've tried to summarize the business on a couple of slides. All of these slides are on  an as-reported basis. All of the divisions except RFS grew with RFS impacted by the continued slow down in the  oil and gas market, which accounts for 52% of Group revenue.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Actually, this can be seen in the chart in the bottom right, all of the markets with the exception of other were up on  the prior year. Oil and gas was lower for Controls and RFS, but Gears saw an increase in its oil and gas business.  Instruments benefited from the acquisition of Bifold. And as most of you are aware, it's predominantly focused on  the oil and gas market, and especially the upstream sector. This helped to show growth overall in the oil and gas  market.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Water was actually up in every division, except RFS. And they saw results flat year on year in this particular end- market. Power was flat, too, down in each division, with only Instruments showing growth and supporting the  overall result. Controls performed well in the industrial sector and Instruments also grew.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: In terms of geography, we had positive performances in North America, Europe, and the Middle East. North  America saw positive activity in the midstream oil and gas area, water and power markets. Europe was up in the  oil and gas and industrial markets, but benefited from acquisitions. As part of our strategy, we have continued to  strengthen our presence in the Middle East, and this is having a positive impact with all end-markets up in the  region. Asia was down and is related to oil and gas activity with water, power, and industrial, all higher than the  prior year.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: If we look at our main markets to see the near-term drivers, upstream oil and gas, the recent OPEC agreement,  and positive sentiment in the U.S.A. has provided some support for new onshore drilling activity and this brings  with it an element of market stabilization. Our own product development and recent acquisition also provides  support to this market.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Midstream oil and gas is still expected to grow with new pipelines planned. However, the market still believes that  all pipelines will be slow with growth coming from gas pipelines. Downstream activity will be driven by emerging  market and low raw material cost, although this market is not anticipated to be growing strongly in 2017.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Automation and control in water is anticipated to grow at a rate of 7% compound annual growth rate until 2020. 1  in 10 people still lack access to clean water, and 1 in 3 lack access to improved sanitation. In power, there is a  change going on in power with renewables growing fast with investment in clean coal, gas, and nuclear. Despite  this, there is still over 1 billion people with no access to electricity. Industrial is becoming an important market for  us, and industrial automation is increasing as we see opportunities in commercial vehicles and life sciences and  process control.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: If we now look by division, we see the trend for controls is that we are seeing more project activity. However, the  size of orders are smaller, and this relates to some extent to the fact that we are seeing more water projects that  are often smaller in size than oil and gas opportunities, especially in downstream. China and the Middle East are  seeing positive activity.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The development of our CK brand for the power and water markets will support our focus in this growing area.  Broadening or extending our product ranges, such as the IQ3 and IQT3, remains a key part of our strategy, and  often provides us with an improved competitive offer for our customers. And developing our sales channels and  strengthening our local presence is another important part of developing these relationships, providing us with the  ability to increase our aftermarket service support.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: For Rotork Fluid Systems, the oil and gas market has seen some stabilization. But there remains uncertainty  around key projects. However, these is a market trend for increased reliability and plant efficiency driving our  customers purchasing decisions, with the Middle East and North America, an important market for us.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: A stable oil and gas sector will bring confidence back to the market and encourage further investment. We're  starting to see signs of this now, but it's still too early to say when or if the market will return to the previous levels.  But we are monitoring this closely. For this reason, we continue to broaden our market exposure for our range of  pneumatic and hydraulic actuators. Markets, such as marine and HVAC, provide those opportunities.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Gears continue to provide the valve industry with a competitive solution for their gearbox needs in a growing  regulatory market, meaning that a customer looking for a global brand with the support and necessary approvals  is becoming more important in this area. As in Controls, Gears are seen in active water and in industrial process  market, with the U.S.A., China, and Europe, important geographies for us.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Instruments now serves the widest variety of end markets out of all of the divisions. And so, the trends in each of  them vary a lot. But there is a general increase in automation, a drive for lower energy use and a general  reduction in the environmental impact of plants. The developing brand and broad product portfolio provides a  strong platform, but we need to continue to build out by expanding the product range further and developing the  sales channel for the division, including further integration and synergy with the Rotork organization. The  acquisition of Bifold provides a catalyst for a number of new product development, and the technology  collaboration across Rotork Instruments and the Rotork Group.

texts.speaker: Peter I. France
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: We anticipate that any near-term growth in energy markets will remain modest. Our focus will remain on providing  our customers with innovative, high-quality products and services, reducing their cost of ownership and improving  plant efficiency. Cost management will remain a priority in the current year as we look to mitigate any inflationary  pressure through our highly flexible operating base.

file: RORL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 6March2018 445 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Back in August, we announced a change in the leadership for the business and an ambition to return Rotork to  previous levels of growth and margins, irrespective of any cyclical recovery in oil and gas markets.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Now turning to the operational review. This slide summarizes the group's key markets and geographies. These  slides are on an as-reported basis. Revenue grew in each division and all end markets were up on the prior  period. Oil and gas was a lower percentage of group revenue, due to the faster growth in other end markets.  Upstream and downstream markets were positive but midstream was significantly lower than last year,  predominantly due to comparatively lower levels of LNG activity. Industrial was the fastest growing of the other  end markets with power the slowest, up 25% and 5% respectively.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: North America, Middle East and Africa, and Eastern Europe grew due to investment in upstream, whilst growth in  Europe was from industrial process. In Asia, the water market grew most, but other markets grew slower than  Controls as a whole.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The CK range developed to support the water market grew particularly in China. We continue to see growth in  HVAC and industrial markets across most geographies, but particularly in North America and Europe.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Fluid Systems is still the division with the highest proportion of oil and gas sales, but it's seeing the share of sales  from these markets reduce in the year. Order intake increased more in Fluid Systems than any other division, up  11.7% on an OCC basis. Revenue decreased 2.8%, as the improvement in order intake takes time to flow  through to revenue. Underlying gross margins improved 100 basis points, as a slight improvement in the pricing  environment compared with 2016, and material cost savings more than offset any inflationary cost pressures.  Adjusted operating profit increased £2.8 million to £9 million for the year, a 6% margin, 150 basis points  improvement in the year.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Within the overall oil and gas market, the Middle East and Eastern Europe saw positive activity from upstream,  whilst the U.S. and Asia were impacted by lower midstream activity. This was a combination of pipeline projects  being generally smaller than last year and several LNG projects completing in 2016. Downstream in China and  India was positive, and we're looking to indigenize some of our core RFS products in both countries. Korea also  saw growth in downstream, but the Middle East declined.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The water and industrial markets both grew, increasing their share of RFS sales. The growing presence of the  division in India and China is supporting a move to more low-cost sourcing, which together with value engineering  initiatives will help mitigate the continuing tough pricing environment and commodity cost pressures. During the  year, we continue to consolidate operations in Italy, relocating two businesses into the main RFS facility in Lucca  and ceased production in Germany.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Work continues to ensure the broader product range created with the Mastergear lines is fully adopted and being  sold wherever appropriate. New product ranges with greater connectivity and intelligence, such as the Fugitive  Emission Gearbox and Smart Position Indicator, are helping Gears to differentiate their products.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: We saw double-digit growth across the water, power and industrial markets. Asia and North America remain the  fastest-growing areas, and we are now more than 50% of Instruments sales. Each of the Instruments businesses  continued to expand their product ranges with new products and variants of existing products across a wide range  of end markets that Instruments sells into.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Jonathan. Activity levels within the oil and gas markets in smaller to midsized projects are picking up  following the sharp downturn over the last two to three years. This reflects a return to more normal investment  patterns around maintenance and upgrades, and is most visible in our Controls division.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Larger project investments in oil and gas is still materially lower than historic levels and remains patchy, albeit  there are signs of increased quotation activity, as project viability improves on lower engineering costs. This is  most visible within the RFS division.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The North American and Middle East regions are active, particularly in upstream oil and gas. We expect this to  continue throughout 2018. While we expect midstream oil and gas to remain flat in the short term, we see some  growth opportunities in the medium term, mostly arising from incremental investments in new gas pipelines in  territories such as Eastern Europe and Asia.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Downstream activity will be driven by emerging markets, low raw material costs and new environmental legislation  such as the demand for low sulfur content. We expect this sector to exhibit some growth in 2018.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Our analysis is focused on a number of significant market drivers impacting one or more of our end markets. In  broad terms, they relate to underlying changes in the drivers of market demand. The accelerating economic  pressures for cost reduction and the efficiency, the growing demand for real-time data and adoption of digital  automation, and the ever increasing impact of regulatory and environmental change.

file: RORL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 4March2019 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Kevin G. Hostetler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Let's take a look at our full year highlights. Once again, we've delivered a strong set of results driven by  management actions against the backdrop of macroeconomic conditions that became more uncertain as the year  progressed. Our business was supported by increasing activity within our oil and gas markets, notably evident in  smaller to midsized projects such as retrofits and upgrades.

texts.speaker: Kevin G. Hostetler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: In the first half of 2018, we also experienced several major project wins, principally in Asia, which we delivered  upon in the third and fourth quarters. We saw hesitation in the release of similar larger projects in the second half  of 2018, largely due to significant fluctuations in oil prices and increasing uncertainty on a variety of economic  fronts. Additionally, I'll highlight the significant progress made in our penetration of the Industrial process  segments driven by our increased focus on these markets coupled with a continuing increase in general  automation.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Redundancy costs in respect to a number of locations which have downsized as part of product rationalization  changes or through efficiency improvements or where roles have disappeared as we've reorganized the  management team. At the same time, disposal or closure of the three businesses resulted in a loss of £0.7  million. Other restructuring costs include R&D write-offs on discontinued product lines and asset write-offs in  respect of the footprint rationalization program. We are anticipating around a £5 million charge in respect of these  items in full-year 2019.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Now, turning to the operational review, this slide summarizes group's key markets and geographies. These slides  are on an as reported basis. Revenue increased in all divisions and in all regions except the Middle East and  Africa. Oil and gas increased from 50% to 54% of group sales. Its fastest-growing end markets were downstream  oil and gas, up 30%, and industrial which grew 14%. Midstream grew in line with group revenue, so remained 9%  of group sales whilst upstream and water markets grew but at a slower rate than the group.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Power sales fell by 11% as sales in the Far East declined and projects in the Middle East and Africa in 2017  weren't repeated in 2018. This was one of the contributors to the lower sales in the Middle East and Africa where  upstream also declined after an active 2017. All other regions reported higher revenue with a strong downstream  oil and gas growth being instrumental in the growth of the Far East, which was the fastest-growing region and  increased from 28% to 32% to group revenue.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Controls oil and gas exposure is greatest in downstream. The growth in that market up 35% in the year has  therefore benefited the division and boosted its sales particularly in the Far East and to a lesser extent North  America. Upstream and midstream were broadly flat overall, but within this, upstream was positive in Eastern  Europe but declined in the Middle East. And midstream was positive in the Far East as a result of improved  pipeline sales.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Power declined due to lower activity in the Middle East and Africa and Far East with the Far East also reporting  the largest reduction in water. Industrial process including HVAC and marine grew as a result of positive  performances in Europe and the Far East.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The downstream growth came in the Middle East and Far East, where some of the projects are the same as  those seen in Controls division. Upstream saw a positive North America and Far East region, offset by a decline  in the Middle East. Whilst water and industrial grew in line with the division as a whole, power declined. The  reduction in power was in the Middle East, following a large project there in 2017 and the sale of the Hiller nuclear  actuator business at the half year.

texts.speaker: Jonathan M. Davis
texts.profession: Finance Director & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Overheads reduced in the year and were also improved by the closure of the Valvekits facility, resulted in an  adjusted operating margin only 70 basis points lower than 2017. Midstream and downstream sales drove the  increase in overall oil and gas sales from 52% to 54% of divisional sales, with activity in the Middle East, Far East  and North America most positive.

texts.speaker: Kevin G. Hostetler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Jonathan. Now, let me begin this section by saying a few words about our outlook for 2019. So, firstly, we  do welcome the recent stabilization of the oil prices. And our view is the current CapEx forecasts for the oil and  gas sector are now coming in at between 4% and 6% year-on-year. Having said this, it's important to remember  this growth rate varies dramatically between sub-segments of the market, between geographic regions and  between the specific application sets.

texts.speaker: Kevin G. Hostetler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: The midstream segment for Rotork is largely about pipelines and LNG. We see pipeline expansion in the U.S.  shale market and pipeline expansion specifically related to LNG, as well as a general LNG-related expansion  beyond pipelines on a global basis.

texts.speaker: Kevin G. Hostetler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Lastly, the pillars we've discussed are supported by our strategy, portfolio and product line assessment activities.  In 2018, we previously announced the planned exits from three businesses: The nuclear island actuation  business, the valve adaptation business and a small regional engineering center. These exits are now complete.  Additionally, we initiated a detailed product line review identifying a number of product lines to be withdrawn from  production over the next 18 months.

texts.speaker: Kevin G. Hostetler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: I'll close out by making a few comments on the outlook for this year. 2018 began with very strong oil prices, which  supported expansion in larger programs and stimulated the return of small to midsized maintenance and upgrade  programs throughout the oil and gas spectrum.

texts.speaker: Kevin G. Hostetler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rotork Plc
texts.text: Towards the end of 2018, we saw a high degree of oil price instability causing some of the larger programs to  pause for what we believe is a short term. We've said it many times over a particular price in a barrel of oil, say  $55 to $60, the stability in the price of a barrel of oil is more important than the overall discrete price levels.  Despite a slowing global economic environment and these dramatic fluctuations in oil prices witnessed in our  fourth quarter, we continue to execute on our specific growth initiatives to drive our results.

file: RRL - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 29July2010 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-10.pdf
RRL - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 28July2011 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Secondly, our joint offer with Daimler for Tognum that is progressing well. This will add breadth and depth to our  Marine and Energy businesses. We will bring significant systems integration and aftermarket capabilities to an  already successful business. Tognum posses a particularly strong diesel portfolio that will complement our own  diesel and gas engine technologies allowing us to double the revenues of the business in much less than a decade.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Orders in Marine and Energy were similar to last year, but some sectors – notably oil and gas – will be second-half  biased. We remain encouraged by what is going on in both offshore exploration and production and land-based  pipeline and transportation activities. For example, investment announcements from Petrobras and BG Group,  making clear that there will be good opportunities to support a development and extraction of new reserves  around the world. The order book once again serves to highlight the global nature and the rapid growth in our  market position over the last few years. Today 47% relates to Asia and the Middle East, with that element alone  now larger than the entire order book just 5 years ago.

texts.speaker: Andrew B. Shilston
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Rolls-Royce Holdings Plc
texts.text: Profits to-date are more or less as we expected and compared to previous guidance we will see a small effect from  the nuclear disaster in Japan that has caused some disruption to our supply chains and delayed deliveries into the  factories and also delayed some overall activity and that's going to cost us about £10 million or thereabouts over  the full year. And there are some slightly higher R&D costs as well. And finally there is no change to our guidance  from the effects of the Trent 900 event last year. So that's in line with what we said before.

texts.speaker: Andrew B. Shilston
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Rolls-Royce Holdings Plc
texts.text: Turning to other areas of Marine, we've just been past the inflection point on orders in the Oil and Gas sector.  That's the – what we call the offshore market. Where it's taking a little bit longer than normal to get customers to  sign on the dotted line, but there's no point – sorry, there – its clearly, it's quite clear that it's – the inflection point  has been passed and so we will see some turnaround, some significant turnaround in original equipment  deliveries in Marine. They were down about 25% for the half-year, they were recovered quite strongly through the  second half of the year. So overall we will be down about 10% in Marine, which is plus or minus what we guided  back in February.

texts.speaker: Andrew B. Shilston
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Rolls-Royce Holdings Plc
texts.text: Turning to the last of the four divisions, Energy. We continue to invest to improve products in new businesses  such as nuclear, fuel cells, and tidal power. We still believe civil nuclear is worth pursuing despite the Fukushima  disaster in Japan. And the reason for that is our capability is unique and we are developing plans with key reactor  vendors and the all other participants in the market and I think that the quality of our brand together with our  capability is meaning that we have  access to all the key players in that marketplace.

texts.speaker: Andrew B. Shilston
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Rolls-Royce Holdings Plc
texts.text: Working capital is a big subject, as I've said before I think that gross working capital balances in aggregate add up  to something like ₤14 billion. So you can see that relatively small movements in these numbers can have an effect  on the business. What's been happening in the first half is that we've had some modest inventory build as we  anticipate the entry into service with the Gulfstream G650, Boeing 787 and then you add to that the disruptive  effect from the nuclear disaster in Japan and the knock-on effects in our supply chain, inventories in aggregate  have gone up something like ₤200 million at the half year.

file: RRL - Q2 2011 Earnings Call Fixed Income 28July2011 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Andrew B. Shilston
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Rolls-Royce Holdings Plc
texts.text: Taking marine and engine together, I think the leading indicator there are all turning up, largely because of the  pick-up in oil and gas activity and deepwater exploration and production, so order books starting to fill. We're  getting more inquiries and that's too soon – sorry, it's not soon enough probably to make much difference to OE in  energy this year, which will be fairly flat. But I think the OE recovery, we're already starting to see it and we'll see  some OE pick-up in marine in the second half-year as we deliver more of the specialized equipment and  specialized vessels to support the oil and gas industry.

texts.speaker: Andrew B. Shilston
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Rolls-Royce Holdings Plc
texts.text: Elsewhere in energy, I think power generation is still fairly quiet in the developed markets. It is quite active in  onshore power generation in some of the developed markets, which is really a diesel play rather than a gas turbine  play. As I say, oil and gas order interest has definitely picked up.
