Not only is Lumnia highly effective, but the LED  units also deliver a significant reduction in energy consumption around 50% to 60%. So customers like food  manufacturers and food retailers have a very, very strong interest in this product.

file: RTOL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 1March2018 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: John McAdam
texts.profession: Chairman, Rentokil Initial Plc
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I must admit I'm slightly surprised to be looking at so many people given  the weather conditions, but I'm delighted that you've made it. It's a pleasure to see you.

texts.speaker: Andrew M. Ransom
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rentokil Initial Plc
texts.text: Last year, we also launched a series of new customer innovations, for instance, Lumnia, which is the first insect- light trap to use LED lighting. Not only is it highly effective, but it also uses up to 60% less energy. We also  introduced RapidPro, which is a new fast-acting bait formulation. It's highly effective against mouse infestations  including those that are resistant to traditional baits. Both products have been tested against existing competitor  ranges to ensure that they set new benchmarks in the industry, and initial sales for both of these have been well  above our year one targets.

texts.speaker: Andrew M. Ransom
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rentokil Initial Plc
texts.text: In our UK Property Care business, we have unrivaled expertise in woodworm and damp proofing services, and  we've created a national business with scale. 2017 was, however, significantly impacted by the slowdown in the  UK property market. So, our focus here is on cost and on efficiency whilst also sharing our digital expertise from  Pest Control.

file: RTOL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 28February2019 415 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Andrew M. Ransom
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rentokil Initial Plc
texts.text: 40% of our new Lumnia insect light traps headed to the U.S. in 2018. Now, that's a product that hadn't previously  been thought possible, but we delivered it using LED lights to replace traditional fluorescent tubes. And by doing  so, we're reducing customer's energy consumption by around 60%.

texts.speaker: Andrew M. Ransom
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rentokil Initial Plc
texts.text: And finally, with air quality deteriorating in many urban areas, and in particular across Asia, we see a good  opportunity for air purification products not just in the washrooms but also outside of the washrooms using initial  hygiene services to deliver clean air in offices, kitchens, reception areas, and we will be launching new air care  products in 2019 to target this opportunity.

texts.speaker: Andrew M. Ransom
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rentokil Initial Plc
texts.text: Finally, then we've made some – we've got some high-quality independent accreditation already in the area of  sustainability. But today, I am delighted to announce the formation of Rentokil Initial Cares. This is a new  charitable fund. Innovatively, this is a new program where we will be using both unclaimed shares and unclaimed  shareholder dividends going back over the last 12 years and using that money to involve our 40,000 colleagues in  helping support good causes around the world, all in line with our mission to protect people and to enhance lives.

file: RUI - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 7September2017 1130 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Sep-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: We've acquired during this half year and integrated in over two months a company that's called Dinasa and its  subsidiary, Sodigaz. Dinasa is the number one distributor of fuel products in Haiti, and Sodigaz is the number one  distributor of LPG in that country. So, that's about 600,000 cubic meters for fuel products. That represents for us a  significant addition of about 20% to the volumes and distribution. 125 gas stations. We are above champions like  Total. There are two French companies in distribution in Haiti, Total, and Sol, that's from Barbados, that's our  main competitor in all of the Caribbean Islands in general.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Another striking point, it's that turn since – over three years until 2016, fuel product prices were dropping. That  period stopped in the second half year of last year. It went up again then. And well, the drop allowed us to lower  prices and to try and improve our margins. It's a different exercise now because we've got to increase our prices  and keep our margins. It is something we've been doing for 25 years and that continues to roll well and margins  are protected as you will see and that comforts our principle. That is to say that the market is the best coverage  we can have against variations in fuel product prices.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: Good evening. We'll continue. Now, talking about the storage of liquid products and moving on directly to this  map. So, indicating the storage capacities on a per type of product basis changes in terms of the – against last  December, EBITDA of more capacity in [ph] a while (08:48), 70,000, 75,000 cubic meters. Those have been built.  And so as to store, as of this Q2, as part of the [indiscernible] (09:07) contract, there are 150,000, which will be  part of our oil product. So, for fuel and consumption purposes, we've developed the existing facilities and we've  converted the fertilizers [ph] taxi (09:27) into cities that can accommodate oil so as to increase the new capacities.  So this is a redevelopment of existing facilities.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: So, this is account we gained. So, we won the corporate tenders in a very short span of time. So, we only have  one year for building works to take place, and so as to provide these new capacities for storage on Rotterdam.  We still have a capacity to take this up to 300,000 cubic meters. So, we're reaching the 200,000 at this point and  we want to accommodate existing capacities. And on both depots, the occupancy rate is highly satisfactory with  95%. So, very happy with the choice made.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: And then finally, Turkey, and then here, which sales we hold at 100%, so out of the current storage capacities, our  ambition is for us to build about 150,000 cubic meters between now and the end of next year. So, we're now in a  phase of obtaining, building permits so as to ensure to take care, to meet the strong demand from the part of the  – well, on the depot, so in total 3.5 million cubic meters.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: Let us now look at the revenues on a per product basis. So, our oil – fuel products account for two-thirds of the  revenues and three-quarters of the capacities. Then, good performance all around, plus 7%, so revenues up 7%,  increase in traffic as well.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: And in France, we're talking plus 5% against the consumption of fuel. Our products stable, about hardly 1%  growth over the period in France. I'm talking about France here on the relevant markets. And it's interesting to see  that with 4 million tonnes that have transited on the – in terms of the fuel products and the depots against 45  million tonnes distributed in France.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: So, to simplify this, one in every six liters of fuel products distributed in France has transited via our Rubis  facilities. A few contracts have come into play notably in our [indiscernible] (00:13:32) and so adding a strong  contribution contract with Shell on the former [indiscernible] (00:13:39) refinery transferred into a storage facility.  And so, with this large Shell contract in Rotterdam mainly for chemicals but we have, well, a contract with Shell  Group as well. So, up 3% in revenues, in terms of revenues. Turkey went through very strong, very intense  activity, up 19% as can be seen here.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: France, Spain – so ahead of schedule, 4%. Portugal, Switzerland down, so lagging behind, hence, because the  description of this stable situation, very good month of January, and this is where the [ph] various supply  (00:29:29), while the effect of the quite tough winter was [ph] foul to (00:29:34) good month of January and we  can see with – as a result of weather conditions. We were way below the average over the past 10 years. Hence,  that is why we lost the LGP (sic) [LPG] being used as – for heating purposes. So, hence, the results. So, Multigas,  out of our scope. So we're talking 2,000 cubic meters then.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: What you mean? It means that we do not take this contract into account. That's what we mean by reprocess is  recalculated in actual fact. So, we're talking volumes here. So, we really are talking about plus 2%, 3% growth  volume-wise, which is totally appropriate for this type of basic product. So, related to energy new scope. So, Haiti,  two months, pretty strong contribution; so 210,000 (sic) [110,000] cubic meters. About 600,000 cubic meters  expected over in a whole year.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: And finally, Africa, so including LGP (sic) [LPG] as well as the bitumen and 10% growth in total volume-wise, so  really ahead of the planning. This is kind of catching up against 2016, has been lagging behind. So, now, we're  talking plus 36% of the bitumen activities. So, we'll talk about this in a moment. Overall, we have actual scope,  plus 8%. So adjusted with the Guiana and Martinique as well as EDF effect, we're talking plus 4%; a fine  performance for all of the products related to energy.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: So we've – over February, April, May, we experienced a decline of margins for these reasons. What is bound to  happen did happen. That was not sustainable for the local operator [ph] and turning went on (00:38:18) flooding  the market, and these political decisions and strategy were dried up by the end of July. And now, we are ending  up with operative standards, business-as-usual situations, returning to normal margins, so three difficult months  impacted to the tune of €3 million the contribution of the Caribbean segment over the period.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: I can tell you that the amount of movement in trading and procurement, that represents about more than 1 million  tonnes annually. So, you've got 600,000 to 700,000 for the first half year, especially because of the increase in  the bitumen activity and bitumen sale that's trading and shipping, as I said, over the rest of the world – Africa,  India, North America, South America. The contribution, it is growing. It is ramping up. It is marginal today in  comparison with ambition of €2.5 million.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: If I look at the bitumen activity and if I can consolidate it with – well, distribution, Rubis Énergie, and the share of  bitumen in the Support and Services segment, there's a contribution bitumen in – to the net result. That's €21  million, whereas it was €13.5 million in the first half year of 2016.

file: RUI - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 12September2018 1130 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Sep-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jacques Riou
texts.profession: Managing Partner and Manager, Rubis SCA
texts.text: We're going to start, ladies and gentlemen. Good evening. Thank you for the time that you're devoting to us.  Bruno Krief and myself again pleased to present to you the Results of the First Half Year of 2018. Highlights, a lot  of satisfaction [ph] but to (00:00:27) constraints in the beginning of this year. We worked this year, as you know, in  a period of increased oil products – of the price of oil products, plus 25% over the period in dollars, a strong  increase and quick increase. And you will see that we were able to adopt because the unit margins were [ph] well  funded (00:00:55).

texts.speaker: Jacques Riou
texts.profession: Managing Partner and Manager, Rubis SCA
texts.text: It's part of the job. You know that it's all – our economic model in the distribution of oil products has always been  such that the variations in prices of oil products can be transferred to the market. Obviously, it is more difficult in a  time of increase than it is at a time of decrease. We'll see that there's been a very good operational development  in terms of gains of market shares and development of volumes in real scope or constant scope.

texts.speaker: Jacques Riou
texts.profession: Managing Partner and Manager, Rubis SCA
texts.text: But bearing in mind that we made two big acquisitions last year in April with part of the Haiti Island. And in  distribution of oil products, we're number one now. And secondly, the Gana (sic) [Galana] (00:01:54) Company is  Madagascar were number one in distribution of oil products there. So two big affiliated [indiscernible] (00:02:05)  have joined the Rubis Group.

texts.speaker: Jacques Riou
texts.profession: Managing Partner and Manager, Rubis SCA
texts.text: In Turkey, we have a big depot in the southeast near the Syrian border. It is a depot that we had for a number of  years. It's been in existence for 20 years. It is sensitive to the structure of the oil market because it's got a big  customership of traders and currently, the price of oil products is less to than the cash price.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: So, here, on this slide, you can see the map of our facilities. It hasn't changed much since last year just to 3.5  million of cubic meters. And since there hasn't been any change, I'm just going to go into detail on the few  challenges we have to face.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: In France, you all know the main challenges, the change between fuel and diesel. So the trend is less diesel  consumption, approximately 2% to 3%, and an increase in gas fuel, 2% to 3%. You all know the reasons why it is  happening. It's not only happening in France, but also at a global level.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: Regarding Rubis Terminal, it will have an impact. There will be trends emerging from these changes. In terms of  logistics, the need to store gas fuel, it will increase demand. It means more regulations, more requirements in  terms of capacity, in terms of flashpoints, products volatility, the product is more hazardous. In that regard, our  asset in our depot is to have multiproduct facilities. [ph] Out of (00:13:11) 2 million capacity for fuel products in  France, approximately 20% for gas, which is not much and is compensated by the average demand [ph] relative  (00:13:29) versus diesel.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: So we are in a good position in order to satisfy this new demand, this new request. Lorries, reservoirs, the  handling of the product is different and we can see this happening every day in all our depots in France. At  multiproduct facilities, we can now broaden our offer in terms of petrol. And regarding the ongoing regulations that  have been implemented for the past 10 years, we now have authorizations to swap from diesel to petrol. It hasn't  happened [ph] everywhere (00:14:30) yet, it's due to the geographical area to the facilities. But I think that our  position is quite advantageous regarding that trend.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: In the Rotterdam, Antwerp area, here we're talking about petrochemicals. We observe an easier access for  American operators in chemicals to fuel resources related to shale gas, which means that the American  petrochemicals operators are becoming more competitive in the U.S. compared to the rest of the world. And so,  expect exports of these products towards Europe.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: This year, the border was closed in Turkey. And beyond these events, as you know, there are lots of changes in  this sector, especially regarding the [ph] VMO (00:17:33) directives. The IMO directives, that is going to be  implemented, and new diesel standards. Petrol with sulfur content, that is going to change from 2% to 0.5%. So,  lots of changes on this market and it will be logistical challenges and especially in this Mediterranean area.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: You must know that the [indiscernible] (00:18:20) production this year represent approximately 4.5 million barrels  per day, which is approximately 5% of the global production of refined products. Out of this, 3.5 million barrel a  day are used for bunkering, that is to say to then both fuels.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: What do we expect? I'll be brief. There are 100 pages about this, but we are expecting out of this 3.5 million  barrels per day to swap to approximately 500,000 for electricity production. This heavy fuel would replace coal, so  we would swap from the coal area to the HFO era. 2 million barrels per day would be used for the maritime  shipping industry with scrubbers. So, a system that is used to treat smoke. Approximately 500,000 will be used  despite the current regulations and will keep being used by the ship owners. They'll have to face the risks that  they're taking. And to conclude, 500,000 barrels per day used as a storage for that use.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: Here, we can draw a relation between the electricity need and the needs in storage, especially in the  Mediterranean area. For instance, we're talking about Egypt, Greece, neighboring countries, where coal is going  to disappear and HFO is going to be used to replace it. So, this is going to create more storage needs, which is  quite good news for us, for instance, for some of the operators, maritime operators in Turkey. For us, it's more a  positive lever.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: Now, overview of our revenue if we include Antwerp at 100%. As a reminder, you can see all the fuel products for  Rubis, that represents 54%, so half of the revenue, minus 10% on that same period of time. And for other  products, we can see a strong increase and now represent 46% for chemicals, fertilizers, edible oils, and a 15%  increase, growth. So, here, there's a bit of a contrast. Fuels is decreasing, but all the other products are  increasing, a strong increase. For fuels, minus 23%, 8% are due to France depot, can be increased by the facts  that we manage our clients, their stocks, their positions, and that generates decreases in terms of flow, which  explains the reduction of this revenue.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: Another reason is a difference in terms of revenue when some contract ended in the North of France and the fact  that new contracts were signed. And this gap should decrease by the end of this year because different types of  taxation between France and Germany, especially near the border, there's a tax on polluting activities that is  higher in France than in Germany and we can see that consumers cross the borders to fill up their tank. So, there  is less clients in France and German products are benefiting from it.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: For the rest, plus 15%, good situation for chemicals both near the Rhine region and France. New contracts, new  investment to find new customers, so revenues in France, plus 13%. Fertilizers, we have always been thriving  with good position, good revenues, so plus 6% for this semester. Edible oils and molasses have also been going  through a good progression, plus 13%. So, this is an overview of our storage revenues.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: As for the rest, it's to be shared between Rotterdam, where we are refurbishing two old tanks that [indiscernible]  (00:29:02) then filled. Two tanks that are already rented over four, five years and that will be commissioned in the  beginning of next year for Turkey. We made a marginal increase in capacity, 150,000 cubic meters. We needed  that increase to have more flexibility for the customer. So, €3 million for Turkey.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: Now, let's get to fuel distribution and what follows Support and Services is very much related and that contributed  up to 90% to the profit. That list that you see here, motor gas stations, that most represent about a third of our  volume; commercial and industrial fuel contracts, the fuels that are not sold in gas stations, that's about 25%;  LPG, that's 25% of volume; and lubricants, aviation/marine products, that's 8%, as well as bitumen. That's the  allocation, if you will, of volume.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: On the side of the Caribbean's, despite the good performance in volume, there's a slight drop by 3% at constant  scope at €40 million. The explanations can be found mainly in the French part of the Caribbeans, Antigua and  Guyana. The tax environment has got a negative effect because the south gates of energy savings cost a bit  more than €1 million of – well, it's a period over three years and there's been a multiplication by 5 or 6 of the cost  of the collection and of the purchase of certificates.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: For Africa, in constant scope, plus 11%, good performance with a contribution of €53 million. Bitumen, we – so in  volume, it's increasing by 11%. It's also the engine of that continent, the performance of that continent. On the  other hand, the Réunion part, same thing as for the French part of the Caribbeans, is subject to the tax effect, the  environmental tax and that's also an impact by €1 million and that's also an obstacle to growth.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: We are at a time of an electoral campaign. The elections will take place in December. There were lots of  movements. A new price formula was put in place. That had a little effect on the expected contribution. But what  had a negative effect was its non-application because to please the [indiscernible] (00:43:24), the government  decided to maintain the price in gas station, whilst, on average, the prices increased by 25%. So, it's the  distributors that pay the cost.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: And the last one, Support and Services business. This is where we can talk about refining SARA. We can talk  about shipping, supply, trading. It's a beautiful ship here. It's part of CapEx. We've just ordered a new bitumen  ship that will replace the Maroni and it will be one of the largest in the world, with 46,000 tonnes of cargo. We  have bought it at the end of the first semester. It's currently in China so that it can be transformed into a bitumen  ship. It used to be a gasoline ship. Total amount of $25 million.

file: RUI - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 12March2019 1230 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Jacques Riou
texts.profession: Managing Partner and Manager, Rubis SCA
texts.text: In Kenya, there are three main operators, KenolKobil, Total, and Vivo, one of the big shareholders of which is the  Viettel Group that represents 1,350,000 cubic meters, it's not about the level we aren't up to today. So, bit more  than 350 gas stations. We've got 620 KenolKobil during the take of the bid brought another 50 gas stations. It's an  acquisition of about €310 million at 100%. For in a bit of €350 million as it is listed company you know the  regulations. There's no confidential information. So it is according to our estimates as from the documents that we  could consult.

texts.speaker: Jacques Riou
texts.profession: Managing Partner and Manager, Rubis SCA
texts.text: Another acquisition that took place during 2018 that overlaps at the beginning of this year considering the  necessary period of time to get some authorizations from the competitive authority – competition authority. It is  the purchase of LPG assets of Repsol in Portugal, Repsol's business in Madeira and Azores and network of  pipeline of LPG. This is an acquisition of €42 million with six times the EBITDA. It is quite important, Portugal is  our man European subsidiary and that acquisition represents about 15% for the contribution. The other element  that is not reported here that everybody's got in mind is that, we've worked, you know the evolution of  international prices of LPG, all of petroleum products and we've worked in conditions that's according to us one of  the most difficult that is conditions of strong increase of petroleum product prices – the prices of oil products  especially propane, that is our lighthouse product, have been multiplied by 2.5 in three years after 46% previous  year.

texts.speaker: Jacques Riou
texts.profession: Managing Partner and Manager, Rubis SCA
texts.text: So it gives you an idea of the difficulties that we have had as we all distributers of petroleum products are not  producers. We prefer to tell our customers that margins are going to increase and prices are dropping instead of  saying to them that international prices increase and margins stayed stable. So these are the figures for the fiscal  year. €4.7 billion of turnover of revenue, it is an indicator, but it includes the increase of nominal prices, 16% of  increase in constant scope, 21% in real terms. We've got an increase of the EBIT by 6%, there is a summary  indicator and the other indicators are about zero.

texts.speaker: Jacques Riou
texts.profession: Managing Partner and Manager, Rubis SCA
texts.text: Then there were external shocks or events due to the will of governments not to apply pricings structures that on  regulatory. You know that in many areas where we operate, very often islands, there were regulations of prices.  The islands of French culture or English culture, those prices are regulated. These got many advantages. There  are also some drawbacks. And in two countries mainly, France and Madagascar, the pricing structures that are  regulated were not applied by the government. In France, as the consequence of the certificate of energy savings  that were blocked in the French Caribbean and at the Réunion, it costs us €6 million. And in Madagascar, the  pricing structure was not applied either and it cost us €7 million net of taxes. So it's simple, in Madagascar, the  government told us we've got a presidential elections towards the end of the year. We want people to be happy.  So we will block the prices and we're going to sign. We've got an agreement between the petroleum professionals  and the Government of Madagascar that details the delays in the application of the pricing structure. So we are  negotiating to get back and recover that delay.

texts.speaker: Jacques Riou
texts.profession: Managing Partner and Manager, Rubis SCA
texts.text: The delay in November was much less than – thanks to the negotiations in December. In France, we are still  negotiating. For those who appreciate the system of energy saving certificates, it works by a three year period  since the beginning – well the January 1, 2018, objectives were tripled. And as it was put in place some time ago  you know that we have got the constraint as distributors of all products to encourage our customers to consume  less energy. So we got to encourage them to change boilers, change lamps et cetera to recover certificate of  energy savings, that system works when things aren't reasonable, but when objectives aren't tripled especially if  you bear in mind that the possibility of getting the certificates were also restricted. We get to a situation of  blocking and to encourage people to switch to condensation boiler in the Caribbean or in the Réunion Island is a  difficult exercise. And last external shock is, it's really the increase in oil prices led to riots, the country is  experiencing very violent social movements in Haiti. It was difficult to find dollars.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: So we're going to continue and talk about the Rubis Énergie. About motor gas stations, commercial contacts,  LPG. Regarding the commercial contracts, here we're talking about supply and products to shipping companies  and mining companies, utilities, carriers, so products that are delivered in bulk. And then we'll talk about  aviation/marine, lubricants and bitumen. So the whole range of petroleum products that we are offering.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: In Africa, we can see Cameroon that we already present in bitumen or we do present in the western part of the  continent in Nigeria, Togo, Senegal, Mali, Burkina Faso. So Cameroon has a border with Nigeria and we can see  that we have built some facilities so that we can transport bitumen containers and store them. The market is  developing and we need facilities in this country.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: In Africa, we can also look at the Is Réunion Island. We have built a company that is manufacturing approximately  8,000 tons of LPG, as well as 2,000 tons of bitumen. So we are also having more impact from the islands, in  island where we already had interesting position. Another investment in Madagascar in LPG this time, so that we  can have better diversification of our logistics from both sides of the island. We have massive LPG supply, but we  are supplying large client that is exporting a nickel deposit in terminal [indiscernible] (00:22:19) since – that's why  we need to diversify risks.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: The road infrastructures are sometimes not taken care of abandoned and it can be hard to transport from one  side of the island to the other, so to avoid taking risk for this client, we want to build approximately 2,500 cubic  meters of additional capacity that will be delivered directly by both. Withdrawal in Iran, we talked about it. We  have got [ph] bolder (00:22:58) project in India, but it's on hold for now and then the five countries around with  deposit of 200 million inhabitant and growth in yearly consumption of petroleum products.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: This is an overview of all our infrastructures. The volumes, we've already commented on these volumes for Rubis  Énergie in last January with a 12% growth, 1% in constant scope. We can study the segment by segment that  there were climate factors that were – they had a negative impact in Europe in the Caribbean, in Haiti the market  was impacted as well, but good economy situation in the rest of the island. Canada, the U.S. was working well,  there were a significant tourist flows. So product consumption that increased. And in Africa, I would say that we  have developed our bitumen well with a two digit figure – two digit growth and however, by the end of the year the  Réunion Island went through some trouble times due to the social movements and that had a strong impact on  the growth figures for the last quarter.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: I am briefly going to comment on what happened on volumes. It's the first line of our accounts the 12% allowed us  to 4 million cubic meters in Europe minus 1% due to climate conditions a new scope in Europe, that is to say  Corsica station commercial business with 30 million cubic meters. Caribbean, constant scope, plus 3% and for the  51 additional cubic meters. The new scope in the Caribbean which is the four additional months in Haiti because  in 2017, we had only [indiscernible] (00:27:07) eight months, so here we have a four additional months and we  can see that it represents a large contribution. The same in Africa, constant scope which means the existing  scope plus the additional month in Madagascar, plus 1% in this financial year and new scope in Canada with – in  Africa, 180 cubic meters. Homogeneous results once again. And a good level of bitumen with an increase of 10%.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: In the Caribbean, as we said, the context was positive except in Haiti. Good levels of activity and good profitability  in Jamaica and in the Bahamas, the areas that was [ph] built (00:31:11) last year. And the same in the Cayman  Islands and the West Indies, former British islands that had a very good performance. The only issue was the  French Antilles that didn't catch up for reasons that were already mentioned by Jac regarding because of energy  saving certificates and they had an impact on the French Guiana and French Antilles contribution.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: In Africa, the broadest curve includes six months in Madagascar, so plus 7% growth which is a good result.  Homogeneous growth from in Africa, in Morocco, Djibouti for bitumen. Of course here the net profits of these  bitumen operations are increasing. Once again the Réunion Island here hasn't caught up with the rest due to the  social movements at the end of the year and irrecoverable cost of the energy saving certificates.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: Let's move on to bulk liquid storage. It's in a third position, but we've got to admit that for the last five years, the  relative share of liquid product storage went from 40% to about 12% of our business this year. Nevertheless it  exists, it's got very good position which allows me to comment on this map that used to seeing also, that presents  our positions and our capacities. What happened or what is going to happen between 2018 and 2019? With  regard to capital expenditure because this is what matters. We are interested in a bitumen in Dunkirk. We are  entering this market, there is demand and we are building some 10,000 cubic meters more on the Dunkirk  platform that is already quite diversified in fuels and chemicals, it will be important bitumen with a return on the  investment that is quite satisfactory with the payback of five years, an investment of about €5 million.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: In Rotterdam, we've got already 216,000 cubic meters of capacity, two-thirds for chemicals, a third of fuels. We  added some 10,000 cubic meters of chemicals storage, rehabilitating existing tanks, that's [ph] black (00:44:57)  carbon and chemicals that are used and exported to mostly Germany, and that may travel all the way to the U.S.  sometimes, so 10,000 cubic meters and investment of €7 million, and annual cash flow of €1.3 million, so also  quick return on investment.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: Volumes return about 3.6 million cubic meters in total as far as the capacity goes in terms of transits, products  have moved. That's 12.6 million tons over the fiscal year. So decline in comparison with 2017 because of Turkey  of the flows that stopped in Turkey, 600,000 cubic meters. So in total, the revenue of Rubis Terminal, that's 55%  fuel, 37% chemicals. So we can see the increase of chemicals in last four years. It was less than 15% in 2016, we  had 37% in 2018, and we'll go over 40% in 2019.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: Fertilizers and edible oils are still marginal, but they still contribute. Something else that is important regarding oil  products, in France, we've got three types of customers. We've got operators and distributors. Oil companies, that  represent about 50% of customership for fuels in France. We've got traders, importers, wholesalers that represent  between 10% and 15%, that's a lower this year because of lesser use of capacity by traders. But the third pillar of  the customership has reached 25% from 15% between the end of 2016 and the beginning of 2019, with long-term  contracts so that increases visibility, it gives us more strength and stability as for the revenue in fuels of Rubis  Terminal. So that's what the general picture of our locations.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: There were also other negative effects in France. A succession of negative effects also in France because of the  drying of the rain – river that did not allow barges to go from Rotterdam to supply Strasbourg. We also had an  environmental taxation that was unfavorable between France and Germany. So flows of consumption migrated to  Germany region benefited from all of the flows in France and that was rather negative. And the phenomenon of  the foundation that we observed in Turkey disseminates over the place, over the world and part of our trading  customer ship was lower in Strasbourg, Dunkirk.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: And that affected Strasbourg and Dunkirk and also Rouen. So that's why there's that drop of the France – French  part as for fuels. You've got here the corresponding figures with oil products dropping by 25% on a non- chemicals, plus 15% fertilizers, plus 7% edible oils and molasses plus 20%. So we talked about the minus 9% in  fuels of France in Rotterdam. We're mainly in chemicals, but also we've got 75,000 cubic meters of heavy fuel.  And you see a decline by 3%, that's related to the extension of the duration of the contracts.

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: So obviously we had to make an effort, but it gives us more visibility that depot is interesting. And our customers  use it for blending of heavy products upstream of the new provisions of [ph] IMOS (00:52:14) from 2020 that will  change the specifications of heavy fuel in the world. So what is true for Rotterdam, we hope will be true also in  Turkey, and it's something we don't work on also capacity of blending in Turkey to make it hub for products to  work on specs in global way. So Turkey, we talked about it as collapsing for revenue by 71%. In chemicals, we've  got very good growth in Rotterdam and Antwerp, plus 15% and plus – around 95% of occupancy rate in France,  they're happy with investments and the new contracts we've had, saw strong increase by 21%. As for fertilizers,  we've had very good positions historically and [indiscernible] (00:53:20)

texts.speaker: Bruno Krief
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, Rubis SCA
texts.text: Rubis Terminal €31 million of CapEx in 2018, €23 million next year, so it's going to come down, there was an  acceleration in last two years, but it's going to come down. We anticipated on constraints. New projects I told you  about some €13 million last year, €14 million for 2019 and new tranche in Rotterdam, 30,000 cubic meters to  saturate in the next five years, the 300,000 cubic meters of global capacity that site will [ph] apprise on (00:57:16).  So for a global budget of 2019 of €244 million for Rubis Énergie for example, we've got CapEx of well – starting a  business in Suriname and we are building a depot of 20,000 cubic meters of fuel to start business of distribution  of oil products in that country. There is a [indiscernible] (00:57:51) few players and there is a lack of logistic  structures, so it's a good niche in country where everything is imported and that investment will allow us to  develop a distribution activity there. Thank you.

file: RWE - Q1 2010 Earnings Call 12May2010 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-May-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: What else for the highlights in the first quarter of 2010? On April 14, we commissioned the new  CCGT in Lingen. This is the first large generation project of our total program of approximately 12  gigawatt of gas and coal-fired power plant that we will bring online by 2013. Also in April, we took a  further step according to our motto, the energy to lead. RWE Innogy started a new cooperation with  26 municipal utilities and regional electricity companies. This joint venture is called Green GECCO.  It will invest approximately €1 billion in renewable projects by 2020. The first projects are already  underway.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Last weekend, we signed an agreement with E.ON to purchase 4.8 terawatt hours generation rights  from their decommissioned Stade nuclear power station for our Biblis A nuclear plant. With this, we  are making sure a point of no return is not reached before the energy plan and the reversal of the  nuclear phase-out scheme have been presented by the government. With the good start to the  year, we are confident that we will achieve our set of targets for 2010 despite some uncertainties,  especially in the gas market.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: On to our divisional performance, let me start with RWE Power. Its operating result improved by  11%. Slide 5 gives you the individual value drivers as usual. Since the beginning of the year, we  have included the regular adjustment of nuclear and mining provisions, the so-called [inaudible] in  the operating result, which is in line with the industry standard. In the past, it was part of the non- operating result. We have not adjusted the previous year’s figures. The effect in Q1 this year was  plus €51 million.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As the provisions were originally built within the operating result, there is no reason to exclude the  reg adjustments from this line. However, there is only one item with respect to nuclear and mining  provisions. In total, we had a negative impact of minus €103 million in Q1 compared to the previous  year. Extraordinary items in the future however would of course be reported as part of the non- operating result. We expect the positive trend at RWE Power to continue during the rest of 2010.  The high availability of our Biblis nuclear power plant and lower costs for fuel and CO2 emission  certificates will be the main reasons for this.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let’s have a quick look at the sketches of our German forward selling. We have sold for 2010 more  than 90%. We have sold for 2011 more than 80%, for 2012, more than 30% and we have started  selling volumes for 2013. Average realized prices are still above €6 per megawatt hour, which in  principle corresponds to a mix of approximately a 90% base and 10% peak. However, we already  see that this split might develop towards 80% to 20% or even above in the future, due to our  changing power plant portfolio and the increase in renewables in the overall system.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our sales and distribution network business area closed up 2%. The cold weather supported our  gas sales volumes. This was offset by low electricity margins. The German Distribution Grid  business was hit by the refunding of excess proceeds, the Mehrerlösabschöpfung. I explained the  background in February.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: On the other hand, the cold weather led to lower maintenance work and hence reduced  maintenance costs. This will lead to increased activities and costs in the rest of the year. For 2010,  we expect the operating result to be up. This will be mainly due to improved earnings in the  electricity and gas sales business, but/or because of the absence of one-off costs caused by  negative gas-to-oil spreads incurred in 2009. In the distribution grid business, we expect that a  negative impact of refunding excess proceeds will be partly compensated for by lower costs for grid  losses.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now onto our new Netherlands/Belgium division. The numbers for 2010 are substantially affected  by consolidation effects. Let me remind you of the most important ones. The €100 million operating  result in Q4 last year included €141 million from Essent and 39 million from RWE Energy  Nederland, REN. The Q4 2009 figure for REN was disproportionately high and may not be  extrapolated for full year. Essent itself in 2009 still included the wind and the trading activities.  Since January of this year, we have been reporting the wind activities within the renewables  division and the trading – as part of the trading in a midstream division. Since REN is now fully       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The performance of the Netherlands/Belgium division in Q1 was supported by higher gas sales due  to the cold weather. Please don’t extrapolate Q1 for the full year. Essent’s profit was  disproportionately high. In the first quarter, Essent typically counts for more than half of a full year’s  earnings. In addition, we expect lower generation spreads for the rest of the year, but due to the  consolidation effect, the division is expected to be significantly above last year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let me continue with RWE npower. Its operating result improved by 18%, adjusted for FX effect, it  was by 15%. Earnings in our retail business were the main driver for the improved performance.  Margins in our gas business improved on the back of lower purchase costs. As we lowered our gas  tariffs at the end of March this year, this trend will not be sustainable for the rest of the year. On the  other hand, we suffered from declining electricity margins after our price cut in March last year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The performance of our generation business was down, driven by reduced spreads and lower  income from the short-term markets, while its commercial availability remained high. In contrast,  costs for purchasing CO2 certificates declined by approximately €20 million due to fuel switch from  hard coal to gas. We expect that lower spreads will also influence the performance of our  generation business for 2010 as a whole. This will be partly offset by the commissioning of our new  power plant at Staythorpe in the second half of 2010. On the other hand, we will digest the first  upfront costs of our U.K. nuclear program.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We expect retail earnings to benefit from slightly lower purchasing costs, but in this fiercely  competitive market, this will be offset to a large extent by the electricity and gas price reductions  implemented in March last year and March this year, respectively. In addition, we expect burdens  from higher electricity network charges. Our focus will remain on efficiencies to ensure a  competitive cost base. The €100 million program initiated last year will be turned into a sustainable  improvement and we are working on additional measures. Overall, we should see a moderate  increase in RWE npower’s operating result.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Operating earnings at our Central & Eastern Europe division climbed by 39%. One major factor for  improved margins in our Czech gas sales business, mainly since Q4 last year. But this made up for  lower margins in earlier periods. On the other hand, trend of revenues and volumes were lower. In  addition, we had a positive contribution from improved electricity sales margins in Hungary and  Poland. This was supported by positive FX effects.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We anticipate that earnings generated by this division would decline this year. And the main reason  is that margins in our Czech gas sales business, as well as in the Hungarian electricity sales and  generation business, are expected to come down again. On the other hand, we will see higher  earnings contributions from our regional Czech gas grid business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our renewables division posted a steep increase in operating result of 50% of it coming from a very  low bases. The first-time consolidation of the Essent wind assets contributed €6 million to earnings.  This is less then originally expected, as Germany and the Netherlands had a quarter with  disappointing very low wind levels due to the cold winter. The first time consolidation of Danta de  Energias in Spain in May last year, as well as the commissioning of the 90 MW Rhyl Flats wind  farm late last year also had a positive effect on our earnings.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Upfront costs for our large investment programs still dampened the development of Energy’s  operating result. As regards 2010, we are quite positive for RWE Energy. We will see further results  of our growth investment program. But upfront costs for our projects are still offsetting most of this.  In addition, Energy will benefit from the first time consolidation of Essent’s wind activities. The  earnings improvement will accelerate in the coming years, as you know.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 4 Upstream Gas & Oil reported a 20% increase in operating earnings. This is mainly a result of higher  oil prices, as well as lower royalties and production costs in the drilling business. In addition,  exploration costs in North Africa were down. On the other hand, they have suffered from lower gas  prices and production volumes. Compared to the very weak 2009, we see significant upside  potential for 2010. RWE Dea expects to see improved oil prices, this will be partly offset by lower  gas prices and volumes.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Operating results in our Trading/Gas Midstream division fell by 76%. Please bear in mind that the  first quarter of last year was extraordinarily high. The mark-to-market performance of the trading  business was as good as last year. On top of this, we benefited from the first time consolidation of  the Essent trading activities. They contributed €86 million in Q1 this year. This is a  disproportionately high number and may not be extrapolated for the full year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The steep decline is mainly related to our supply activities. This is because of two major effects.  First, in 2009, the supply business realizes an extraordinarily high profit in the first quarter. Second,  the fall in gas market prices led to a write-down of our Czech gas storage inventories. In 2010, we  expect the division to close significantly below the previous year’s record level, despite the  integrations of Essent’s trading activities. Though our trading margins compared to the  extraordinarily high level in 2009, and the absence of the special items in 2009 are the major  reasons.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In Gas Midstream, we are exposed to risks from oil-indexed gas contracts. You know our gas  position from our February presentation. [inaudible], we see Trading/Gas Midstream to show a  positive gas margin for 2010, despite negative effects from the gas-to-oil spread. On the other  hand, we still see some various prospects regarding the gas market for the mid-to longer term. We  see that the Czech gas market becomes more competitive, which might lead to further burdens for  future years. However, as outlined in February, we actively used the given instruments in our  contract to mitigate this asset.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The split of non-operating results looks a bit different than in the past. To further increase  transparency, there’s a new line for the earnings impact of commodity derivatives. We reported this  number last year as part of restructuring, other, as you may remember. These are typically effects  stemming from derivative hedges for gas forward sales in our sales and distribution business area  and Trading/Gas Midstream division.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: While the derivative has to be valued mark-to-market, the underlying business transaction is still  accounted for our own use. Since the beginning of the year, there’s also been additional impact  from the German gas portfolio. The amount and liquidity in the gas market allows us to actively  manage our purchase contracts and thereby make use of opportunities and limit associated risks.  Accordingly, in 2010, we started accounting for these contracts at fair value instead of on use. All  the numbers we shown in this slide are purely timing differences.

file: RWE - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 12May2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-May-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Stephan Lowis, Vice President, Investor Relations  Thanks. Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our conference call. We are living  in turbulent times. After the domestic event in Japan, the public debate about nuclear energy in  Germany is dominated by motions rather than facts. Therefore let’s turn to facts with our Q1  conference call. And Rolf over to you.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Rolf Pohlig, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer  Thank you, Stephan. We are indeed living in turbulent times. Last February, I was discussing with  you the four major challenges for German utilities – that is, low commodity prices for Germany, the  fuel tax, negative gas storage spreads and tighter CO2 regime from 2013 onwards.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: These challenges are still relevant. However, on top of this, we have a new debate about the future  of Germany’s nuclear power plants. More about that in a minute.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let me first begin with the positive aspects of Q1 2011. Better [indiscernible] (0:01:15). As we  expected, EBITDA, operating result, and recurrent net income couldn’t match the record high  numbers of the previous year. The strong cash flow as well as the successful disposal of  Thyssengas and our stake in the Rostock hard coal power plant were the main reasons why we  could reduce our net debt to €27.5 billion.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Despite the negative impact from the three-month nuclear moratorium in Germany, we confirmed  the guidance we gave in February. But please let me emphasize, at the current point in time, we  can only comment including the effect of the three-month moratorium. We will have to reassess our  expectations especially in case of further burdens depending on the decisions of the German  government.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The earnings declines we recorded in Q1 this year is less than we expect for the rest of the year.  This is based on three main reasons. Firstly, performance in our German generation business will  not show the same strength as we have seen in Q1. Secondly, our UK business had a  disproportionately successful first quarter. And thirdly, we expect further burdens in our Trading  /Gas Midstream division mainly driven by the negative gas storage spread.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Before I guide you through the Q1 numbers, let me give you a brief overview of where we stand  with regards to the moratorium for the nuclear safety review in this country. This should help you to  get a better understanding of the current political situation in Germany. Altogether, five stages have  to be gone through before we see decisions on future energy policies in Germany.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide four gives you the details of this process and the major milestones. By mid-June, the  government wants to implement a new framework for nuclear energy in Germany. Within this  process, the government has set up an Ethics Commission to evaluate the role of nuclear energy in  our society as well as transition to new energy and how much risk the German public is willing to  accept.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 2 The parameters of this very narrow time [indiscernible] (0:03:43) is extremely ambitious so that  some delays might occur. As you know, we have filed a suit against the forced interim  decommissioning of our biggest power stations. Let me once again emphasize that we don’t want  to cause a confrontation with the German government. We’re open to any kind of discussion, but  we think it’s important to clarify whether the order of the Hessian authorities to shutdown was based  on valid legal grounds.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Before I provide you with more details on the performance of each of our divisions, let me give you  a brief overview of the group’s key performance indicators. External revenue was up 3% among  other things because of higher oil prices.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: EBITDA and operating result were down 4% and 5% respectively. This is mainly due to the  performance of our Trading/Gas Midstream division. The non-operating result improved as a result  of having higher capital gains from the sale of assets and the lower burden from the earnings  impact of commodity derivatives.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now, on to our divisional performance, starting with RWE Power. Its operating result improved by  2%. Slide six gives you the individual value drivers. Performance of plus 2% in Q1 was much better  than our expectation for full fiscal year 2011. This is mainly due to the fact that we have not yet  been burdened by the nuclear fuel tax, which we expect to reach €300 million to €400 million in  2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In addition, we expect higher fixed operating and maintenance costs, which were another major  issue in Q1 and higher depreciation charges associated with the commissioning of our new lignite  plant in Neurath later this year. Please bear in mind that there is still a lot of uncertainty against the  backdrop of the current nuclear moratorium.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Chart seven gives you our usual update of the hedge position of our German electricity generation.  At the end of March, we have sold more than 90% for 2011, more than 70% for 2012 and more  than 20% for 2013. In other words, the output position for the year 2012 was already sold before  the strong increase in electricity prices resulting from the moratorium on nuclear power plants in  Germany.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: A large portion of the output position for 2013 was also sold. Therefore, we received a full positive  impact from higher electricity prices in the year 2014 and thereafter if the current price level  prevails.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our Sales and Distribution Network business area closed 9% below the previous year. This is  mainly due to the development in our distribution network business. Normalized weather conditions  led to lower volumes, especially in the gas segment. Furthermore, higher burdens resulting from  the feed in of renewable energy could not yet be passed on completely to the transmission  operators.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: However, income from investments improved and cost for refunding excess proceeds were lower  than last year. Earnings in our sales business declined mainly due to lower gas volumes on the  back of normalized weather conditions. Also for full fiscal year 2011, we expect the operating result  to fall below the previous year. This is mainly a result of higher OpEx for improving the quality of  our distribution network business. The cost for refunding excess proceeds will be slightly lower than  in 2010. For the sales business, we expect lower gas volumes assuming normalized weather  conditions. Last year, we benefited from a colder-than-average winter.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now on to our Netherlands/Belgium division. The numbers for 2011 are substantially affected as we  now report part of the gas midstream business in Trading/Gas Midstream. In addition, the division  recorded lower gas margins as a result of normalized weather conditions. Furthermore, the  performance was negatively affected by decline in generation margins. However, the division  benefited from efficiency improvements and synergies from the integration of Essent into the RWE  Group. The effects we had Q1 will also drive down fiscal year 2011 significantly.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The performance of our generation business was supported by higher production volumes due to  our new CCGT at Staythorpe and a positive one-off impact following the settlement of claims  relating to major investment projects.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Operating earnings in our Central Eastern and South Eastern Europe division were nearly on par  with the last year’s record figure. Adjusted ForEx effect, the division was down 5%. Earnings  suffered from slightly lower income in our Hungarian business and weather induced lower gas sales  in the Czech Republic. This was partly compensated for by a high income in our Czech gas  transport business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: For 2011, we expect the operating results to be down significantly year-on-year compared to the  exceptionally high number in 2010. In the Czech Republic, we expect gas sales margins to come  down. The contribution from our Hungarian electricity activities is also expected to fall behind last  year’s level. However, we expect to see higher electricity network margins in Poland.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The operating result of our US division more than doubled to €68 million. Increased earnings were  partly driven by our growth CapEx program and improved electricity prices. In addition, we received  liquidated damages relating to the Greater Gabbard project. However, the liquidated damages  replaced lost revenues and profits due to delays in commissioning.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Upfront cost for large investment program, including higher staff costs are still dampening Innogy’s  operating result. For 2011, we expect RWE Innogy to post a strong earnings increase. We will see  further results of our expansion program. Higher electricity prices will have a positive impact as  well.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In addition, we assume improved wind levels compared to the very weak conditions in 2010,  although still not returning to normal levels. Upfront costs for projects including our staff costs are  still offsetting some of the positive effects.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Upstream Gas & Oil reported a 38% increase in operating earnings. The main positive factors were  rising oil and gas prices, higher oil production volumes and lower exploration expenditures.  However, gas production was down. In addition, production costs increased and royalties in the  German gas business were higher. We expect the earnings trend of Q1 to continue during the rest  of the year. Therefore, we see significant further upside potential for full fiscal 2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The operating result in our Trading/Gas Midstream division turned into a significantly negative  number in the first quarter of 2011. On the one hand, the developments in our trading business  suffered from the unforeseen effects on commodity prices caused by the events in Japan and  Northern Africa. In addition, our supply business is under pressure from the negative gas storage  spread. From our February conference that we are in negotiations with all our suppliers and don’t  expect major solutions in 2011. On the other hand, the division benefited from gas midstream  margins, which have previously been reported in the Netherlands/Belgium division.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, our guidance for 2011 remains unchanged. I already mentioned that this  statement can only take into consideration the current status of the German nuclear moratorium.  The final outcome is still unclear and it is not unlikely that further short-term burdens might result  from political decisions relating to the future of nuclear energy in this country.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Although from a macroeconomic point a view, the politically motivated phase-out of nuclear energy  is a disadvantage for German industry, it still has to be seen how utilities will be affected. On the  one hand, there will be lost margins, although these margins had already been squeezed by the  nuclear fuel tax and required investments for the lifetime extension. On the other hand, the  tightness of generation capacity has led and will lead to rising electricity prices, which increases the  value of the residual generation fleet, especially our lignite plants.

file: RWE - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 10May2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Please bear in mind that our results in 2011 were heavily affected by the events at Fukushima and the following U- turn in German energy policy. However, these burdens largely materialized only after the first quarter 2011.  Therefore, the development of the first quarter this year is within our expectations.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me quickly mention some important steps we have taken during the last few months. The renegotiation of our  oil-indexed long-term gas contracts, again, led to positive results. We were able to further structurally change  several smaller contracts to gas wholesale market indexation with major gas suppliers. We can now fully  concentrate on the remaining three big suppliers to also proceed with our structural solution.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me now come to the headline figures for the Group. External revenue was slightly down by 1% mainly as a  result of the deconsolidation of our TSO business, Amprion. I have already mentioned our decline in EBITDA and  operating result. Declining generation spreads and high burdens in the gas midstream business were determining  factors for the decrease in the operating result. I'll come to the details in a minute.  The non-operating result fell below last year's figures by about €200 million. One reason is the decrease in capital  gains compared to the first three months in 2011, which included the sale of Thyssengas and our minority stake in  the hard coal power plant in Rostock.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: As you know, working capital can be very volatile especially over the course of the year. One other fact is in  relation to the deconsolidation of Amprion. In 2011, we reported a temporary increase in liquidity at Amprion  resulting from the renewable energy allocation levy. The other fact is in relation to our trading business resulting  from the fact that payments in connection with purchases and sales fluctuate significantly over the course of the  year.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Before explaining the drivers for the operating results of our individual divisions, let me give you a quick update  on the gas-to-oil spread situation. You might recall that in March we reported that during 2011, we reduced the  volume of our oil-indexed gas contract by 4 bcm to 20 bcm. The net exposure, which includes our oil-indexed  sales to end customers, fell by 2 bcm to 18 bcm.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Over the last couple of weeks, we have been able to make further progress. We have successfully adjusted  additional contracts to gas wholesale price indexation. As a result, our gross exposure fell by another 1 bcm to 19  bcm and our net exposure to 70 bcm.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide six gives you an impression of how we have been able to reduce our future gas-to-oil spread exposure as a  result of our renegotiations compared to our original maturity profile. We are still renegotiating six out of our 17  contracts and are optimistic that we will reach a conclusion by 2013.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Our main focus now lies on the negotiations and arbitration proceedings for the remaining contracts with three  major oil and gas companies. Our main objective is to implement structural solutions for these contracts in order  to eliminate future earnings risks by either terminating them or referencing their prices to trade it against  wholesale market prices by recovering as much of our overpayments of the past few years as possible.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me now explain the development of the operating result in each of our divisions. The operating result in our  Power Generation division came down by 12%. The division suffered from lower realized spreads compared to the  first three months of 2011. The forced closure of our nuclear power plant at Biblis has an impact on the results. A  positive contribution resulted from the trial run of our new lignite plant BoA 2&3 at Neurath. We plan to have the  plant fully commercially operational in the next couple of weeks.  Before I move on to the other divisions, let me spend a minute on the development of the generation capacity in  Germany. As I understand, this is a burning question for you. From our side, you may recall our announcement in  February of 2011 that we would not extend some of the power contracts which we have with Steag. These contracts  have a total volume of 1.4 gigawatts in capacity and will expire at the end of this year. We've also decided not to  extend the additional Steag contracts with a combined volume of another 0.4 gigawatts. These contracts would  also expire at the end of this year.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: In March, I told you about the close of our remaining 12 coal and 150 megawatt lignite blocks by the end of this  year. Furthermore, we must close one gas-fired block at our gas-fired plant with a capacity of 355 megawatts in  spring.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Our Dutch business, Essent improved its results by 4%. Cost cutting and price increases improved margins. The  start of the commercial operation of our new gas-fired power plants Moerdijk 2 and Claus C also contributed  positively to the performance, despite overall lower margins in the generation business.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: RWE npower's operating performance fell by 29% to €291 million. The main reason is the deterioration of the  generation margins. In addition, the division suffered from the outage of our converted power plant at Tilbury due  to the fire in a biomass bunker. Last year, Tilbury still contributed to earnings as a hard coal plant. Furthermore,  last year's first quarter results benefited from one-offs relating to claim settlements.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Our Central Eastern and South Eastern division reports a reduction in operating results of 28%. Lower gas sales  margins in our Czech distribution business and decline in generation spreads and retail margins in our Hungarian  business are the attributing factors. In addition, we see some negative ForEx effects.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Our Renewables business benefited from increased generation volumes and more favorable wholesale prices. Our  wood pellet plant at Georgia in U.S. also contributed to the positive result.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Our upstream business strongly increased its operating result by 37% to €241 million. Higher gas and oil prices  and depreciation of U.S. dollar over the euro are main drivers.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: In our Trading/Gas Midstream division we see an improvement of 20% compared to the first three months of  2011, yet the division still reports a loss of €220 million. We had continuously faced the burdens from the negative  gas to oil spread. However, the performance of the trading business has considerably improved. Please bear in  mind that we will not know whether the gas losses are real losses but only temporarily effect until we have  completed the ongoing negotiations and arbitrations.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Finally, I would like to come to the Group's outlook for 2012. Today, I can confirm the outlook for 2012 that we  provided to you at the beginning of March. We expect EBITDA, operating results and recurrent net income to be  in the order of 2011 despite the lower than originally expected performance of our UK business. We will certainly  benefit from the commercial operation of our new plant. For instance, our lignite plant BoA 2&3 at Neurath. In  addition, it will not be affected by last year's negative effect resulting from the U-turn in German energy policy  except for the nuclear test.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: On the downside, we'll still be suffering from the negative gas storage spread despite our further successful steps  in reaching commercial agreements with suppliers.

file: RWE - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 15May2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The business development in the first quarter of 2013 was in line with our expectations. EBITDA and operating  results were slightly down on previous year while recurrent net income was on par with Q1 2012 mainly due to a  lower tax rate. One of the major strategic milestones in the first quarter was, of course, the decision to evaluate  potential exit routes for Upstream Gas & Oil Division, RWE Dea. Since the establishment of liquid gas markets in  Europe, the access to own physical gas sources no longer has strategic value for our core business. In addition, to  develop the attractive resources and reserves of RWE Dea in the coming years, significant investment is needed.  We are currently preparing the search process, please understand that we can't be more specific at this point in  time.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In the first quarter of 2013, we were also successful with further disposals. The biggest step was the agreement  with Allianz and the Canadian infrastructure group, Borealis, for the sale of our Czech gas transmission operator  NET4GAS for total value of €1.6 billion. On the basis of a normalized earnings contribution in the coming years,  this is equivalent to valuation multiple of 9.4 times enterprise value over EBITDA.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Furthermore, we made additional smaller disposals, which add up to a total of approximately €0.4 billion. This  was, among other things, the sale of minority shares in our UK offshore wind farm, Rhyl Flats, and onshore wind  farm, Little Cheyne Court.
