The main purpose of these disposals is to improve our leverage situation with the aim  of having access to long-term financing at attractive conditions at all times. In the current environment, that is  still the case. In the first quarter of 2013, we issued several bonds with a total volume of approximately €1 billion  at very favorable conditions. There was a huge demand by the market. Last but not least, we see that the  development in the first three months of the business year confirms our outlook for the year as a whole. I will  come to that point in a minute.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me give you a brief overview of the business performance in the first quarter on page four. Our operating  results declined by 4% as expected. This is mainly a result of lower earnings in our Conventional Power  Generation Division driven by the effect of full CO2 auctioning and the decline in generation margins.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: On our recent road shows, we have talked to many of you. One of the most intensive discussed questions has been,  what we are doing with our cash negative power plants? We plan to either bring the plants back into cash positive  territory or mothball or close the plants or to cancel contracted capacity. But please bear in mind that despite the  cancellation of contracted capacity, the legal owner of the power plant has to decide about the ultimate closure.  We will update you on our plans in August during our H1 results call.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: However, there were also positive offsetting trends. This was mainly the recovery of earnings in our Trading/Gas  Midstream Division. By the end of last year, we had settled all but one of our long term oil-indexed gas contracts.  In addition, our sales business units benefited from the cold weather.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: With slide six, I would like to shed a bit more light on the development of our cash flow in Q1 2013. Our cash flow  from operating activities was disproportionately low similar to the trend we saw last year. This is because of  negative developments in the working capital which will be offset in the course of the year. Among other things,  our German, UK and Dutch retail businesses showed an increase in accounts receivable of approximately €2.5  billion mainly as a result of larger sales volumes due to weather conditions.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me come to our outlook for fiscal 2013 on page seven. In general, we can confirm the outlook we provided on  5th of March at our full year analyst conference call. We still expect the settlement of our price review with  Gazprom during the course of the first half of 2013. Nothing has changed here. Also with regards to our divisional  outlook on page eight, we confirm our expectations from 5th of March, 2013 with the exception of our Renewables  and Upstream Gas & Oil Divisions.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: With regard to energy, due to the low wind levels in Northwest Europe and burdens from the new regulatory  framework in Spain, we now expect earnings to be in the order of last year. In March, we still expected earnings to  be above the previous year.

file: RWE - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 14May2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Our performance in the first quarter of 2014 is in line with our expectations. EBITDA and the opera ting results are  down by 16% and 18%, respectively. In addition to the weather effects, we suffered from the erosion of margins in  the Conventional Power Generation business.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Furthermore, the figures reflect the deconsolidation of natural gas as of August 2013. Our recurrent net income  was down by 36%, in addition to the trend of the operating result, our tax rate for recurrent net income increased  from 25% to 34%.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: A further milestone at the end of February was the commercial settlement with Gazprom on our long -term gas  supply contract. As a result, there will be no further exposure to the gas-to-oil spread until the next regular price  revision in summer 2016. Until then, we are confident we will find an amicable solution for the open issues so that  the gas-to-oil spread problem will be solved once and for all.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: We now expect EBITDA to be in the range of €6.4 billion to €6.8 billion, and the operating resul t between €3.9  billion and €4.3 billion. With this, we confirm our previous outlook adjusted for the numbers of RWE Dea. In  other words, the commercial settlement with Gazprom and lower operating depreciation on the positive side and  the weather effect and further margin pressure in the gas storage business on the negative side are more or less  offsetting each other. The outlook for recurrent net income now includes the interest on the purchase price of  RWE Dea instead of the businesses' income contribution. Assuming a deconsolidation by the end of this year, this  results in a range of €1.2 billion to €1.4 billion.

file: RWE - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 13May2015 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Let me start with a brief summary of the main political challenges we are currently facing and the latest update on  where we are. We can divide the whole political discussion to three main topics. First, the possible introduction of  carbon penalties for older coal plants. Second, the discussion about nuclear provisions and whether they should  be externalized. And of course, third, the discussion about the new market design for power generation in  Germany.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: So let's start with the proposal of an additional CO2 levy for old power plants. According to this proposal,  conventional power plants should only be allowed to emit a specific amount of carbon free of additional penalties  as soon as they are 20 years old. It starts with a limit of 7  million tons related to a plant size of 1,000 me gawatt at  an age of 20 years. It will go down to 3 million tons after 40 years.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: In case of emissions above those limits, an additional penalty of €18 to €20 for any additional ton would be  charged. The aim of the government is to further reduce carbon emissions by 22 million tons by 2020 to fulfill the  40% carbon reduction target the German government has set itself for 2020 versus 1990.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: The problem with this proposal is that it would not lead to a gradual reduction in carbon emissions but would  make the operation of all of our 11-megawatt, 300-megawatt and 600-megawatt blocks uneconomical in one go.  This is due to the fact that most of our fixed cash costs are related to the lignite mines and only by closing the  mines could we also reduce our fixed cash cost accordingly. This would take approximately 7-gigawatt out of our  total 10-gigawatt lignite-fired power generation out of the market.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Now, to the second topic, the discussion about the nuclear provisions. There's no official movement by the  German government on this issue, but every once in a while, there are e xperts quoted who argue that perhaps the  provisions are not high enough or that they should be externalized, as it might not be certain that the utilities  would be able to provide the cash flows once they are needed.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Let me emphasize. We have built the provisions in line with our general prudent financial approach. Secondly, the  decommissioning of the research reactor [indiscernible] (04:14) and the works on Mülheim -Kärlich support our  view that we are in line with our original expectations on decommissioning costs.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: With regards to the discount rate of 4.6%, it's important to see that the real discount rate, i.e., the difference  between the escalation in the discount rate is only in the order of 1%. This is fully in line with the current low  interest rate environment. But of course, we are not protected if politicians decide on new burns, for example, in  the context of looking for a new final storage facility.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Let me also remind you of our prudent approach to set aside financial assets for all our long-term provisions, the  non-funded pension obligations, the mining and nuclear provisions. We have more than 10% of those additionally  covered by financial assets on top of our physical assets.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: From what we can see at the moment, the introduction of a straightforward capacity market looks unlikely. It  seems more likely that the government will opt for a reform of the energy-only market in combination with the  tender of reserve capacity, which will then not be available for the energy-only market.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: The intended reserve capacity would be in the order of magnitude of 4 gigawatt at the beginning. We would expect  power plants in southern Germany, which are part of the current grid reserve, to be eligible to participate in the  auction.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Last but not least, let me update you on where we are with regards to the court cases on the nuclear fuel tax. We  were informed by the European Court of Justice that they will announce their verdict on 4th of June 2015. We still  don't have a fixed date from the German Federal Constitutional Court, but we still expect the decision in 2015 or  early 2016.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Now, back to the first quarter. The key performance indicators on slide 4 show a mixed picture. EBITDA and  operating result are down by 3% and 5%, respectively, mainly as a result of further deteriorating realized margins  in the Conventional Power Generation business. This was partly offset in our retail business units on the back of  normalized weather conditions.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Slide 6, gives you the development of the operating result by divisions and the main value drivers. The biggest  effect is the decline in Conventional Power Generation, mainly driven by a further deterioration of realized  generation spreads. But there's also some light at the end of the tunnel, as in the Renewables business. We are  starting to reap the benefits of our investments of the past years. Operating result of RWE Innogy is up by 56% to  €151 million.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: The decline of cash flows from operating activities on slide 7 does not come as a surprise. In March, we explained  to you the new procurement policy for CO2 emission certificates. While until 2013, we purchased most of the  certificates in the same year as the CO2 was emitted, we shifted the timing for the purchase of the certificates we  needed for 2014 to the beginning of 2015, the year we have to submit them. As a result, total cash flows from  operating activities in Q1 2015 is €0.5 billion lower than previous year's cash flow.

file: RWE - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 12May2016 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: One of the reasons for the difficult market environment I mentioned is the political uncertainty around financing  the nuclear exit. In this respect, the nuclear commission, which were instituted by the German government,  presented its recommendation at the end of April. We believe that the distribution of responsibility between the  company and the state proposed by the commission is logical in principle and that the concept is heading in the  right direction.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: RWE AG honors the obligation it has to fulfill in phasing out nuclear energy. We had a group provisions for this  which are very conservative even when compared at the international level and, therefore, constitute a strong  financial precaution against the risk of cost increases. However, the risk premium proposed by the commission on  top of this, is an irresponsible undue burden on RWE AG. It is unfortunate that the commission has failed to take  the company's economic situation into account. What is decisive now is the manner in which th e legislature  implements the proposals.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Now, on to the development of the key performance indicators in the first quarter. Let me start on slide 4 which  shows the development of the operating result by division. The earnings increase in the first three months is  mainly due to the positive development in energy trading which supported very high profits in the Q1 period,  which was partly offset by the negative earnings trend in Conventional Power Generation mainly due to the  decline in realized generation margins. Nevertheless, earnings contribution of this division is disproportionately  high in Q1 2016. Nuclear fuel tax and higher maintenance cost will come in the rest of the year. Furthermore, Q1  benefited from one-off gains from the sale of real estate.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: First on slide 8 for the key earnings figures of the group. We confirm the earnings guidance we gave in March. The  increase we have seen in Q1 2016 for EBITDA and operating results were not sustained for the rest of the year.  Positive one-off effects in the second half of last year as the VSE revaluation and the profit from the sale of a stake  in the Galloper project are two reasons. Moreover, Q1 2016 had positive one-offs which mainly impacted earnings  development in this quarter, rather than in the full year. This is the sale of real estate in Conventional Power  Generation, the sale of grid assets and the revaluation of our participation in Westenergie in the division Grids/  Participation/Others.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Furthermore, the strong earnings improvement in our Trading/Gas Midstream division in Q1 2016 may not be  extrapolated for the full year. In addition, we expect higher costs, for example, for maintaining our power plants  and for maintaining and operating our grid infrastructure, which will impact our earnings mainly in the rest of  fiscal 2016.

file: RWE - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 15May2017 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In Q1, the fourth UK capacity auction took place. After the situation for hard coal plants deteriorated and the  British government wanted to avoid shortfalls, they brought the start of the capacity market one-year forward to  2017 and 2018. We successfully secured contracts for all our sites with a total capacity of 7.9 gigawatts.  However, at £6.95 per kilowatt, we auctioned clearly at a much lower price, as seen in the previous auctions.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The European Power division had a good start to the year. Tight situations like [indiscernible] (05:26) so no wind  and no sun in Germany in Q1 led to a very good result from commercial asset optimization. It's overcompensated  for the decline in realized margins. Together with cost improvement has led to an increase in adjusted EBITDA to  €167 million. Nonrecurring items in this division were mainly relating to land sales in the UK.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: This brings me to the current hedge position on slide 7. Compared to our situation at the end of last year, [ph] the  average use (06:20) implicit fuel hedge for 2018 has increased to fully hedged position. The hedge spread  position in European power has also gone up to 60%. In 2019 and 2020, we have increased the implicit fuel  hedge positions.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Our hedge price for 2019 has improved by approximately €1 per megawatt hour till the end of last year in line with  the improvement of the fuel spreads in Q1. As a bulk of our 2019 outlined volumes is hedged via our implicit fuel  hedges, there's additional upside potential from further improvements of the spreads. On the European Power  side, we are still mostly unhedged from 2019 and 2020.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Now on to the performance of Supply & Trading on slide 8. Also the division has a good start to fiscal year 2017  at EBITDA of €146 million was slightly below the very strong Q1 2016. Furthermore, last year, we benefited from  the sale of Lynemouth power plant in Q1. The nonrecurring items in 2016 referred to the legacy gas book  including the long-term gas storage contract which we entrusted to market prices in Q2 2016.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Now, on to distributable cash flow on slide 10. The reconciliation from EBITDA to distributable cash flow is  dominated by the seasonal development of the operating working capital in Q1. This is mainly due to normal  timing effects since we purchase most of our required CO2 certificates in the first quarter of the year. This will  revert in Q1, once the certificates for emissions in 2016 are delivered to the national clearing authorities.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: As we mentioned at our Capital Market Day, we would assume changes in networking capital to be neutral over  time. Change in provision and other non-cash items show positive €128 million compared to our outlook of  approximately minus €650 million for the year as a whole. Again, recognition of CO2 emission is the reason. In  Q1 2017, we have approximately €0.2 billion of additions to CO2 provisions. Provisions will come down in Q2. It's  a delivery of emission certificates to the national clearing authorities. In addition, we have seen a very low  utilization of our nuclear provisions in Q1.

file: RWE - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 15May2018 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In March, we presented the agreement with E.ON to sell our stake in innogy in exchange for a wide range of  assets, which will transform us into a leading integrated renewables and conventional power generator. The  execution of the transaction is going ahead as planned.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, in December 2016, the Federal Constitutional Court declared that the operators of nuclear  power plants should be compensated for damages of the early exit of nuclear power in Germany. The Court gave  the federal government the task to come up with a compensation law by mid-2018.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Recently, a draft law by the Ministry of Environmental Affairs became public, which envisages compensation. We  welcome that the government is addressing the matter following the ruling of the [ph] Constitution Court  (00:05:40). We assume that we will be compensated for stranded investments as well asset generation volumes  of our Mülheim-Kärlich plant, which we will not be able to either use in our plants or sell to other operators.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: This brings me to our current hedge position on slide 7. The strong decline in fuel spreads since the beginning of  the year had only a limited impact on our hedge position for 2018 and 2019, as we are almost fully hedged. As a  result, the hedge price for those years stayed broadly flat compared to the improved level at the end of last year.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: For 2020, we have a much higher open implicit fuel hedge position. Hence, the current hedge price is  approximately €2 lower, compared to the end of last year as generation spreads have [ph] broadened (00:08:27).  We show for the first time, our hedge position for 2021. We are hedged more than 30%, mainly via an implicit fuel  hedge. And by that, we keep the upside of improving generation spreads.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: From now on, we will provide additional information on our hedged CO2 position. The average hedge power price  for our outright position can only be understood in the corresponding hedged carbon prices taken into account. In  an environment of stable CO2 [ph] prices' (00:09:02) information was not relevant to understand the economics of  the business.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: This has changed with the recent dynamics of the carbon and power prices. The current hedge price for 2018 to  2021 of €28 to €29 per megawatt hour correspond with average hedged CO2 prices of approximately €5 to €6 per  ton.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me also remind you of our long-term carbon position, which we have financially hedged through the end of  2022. In other words, change in carbon prices should not affect our generation margins for the next five years.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: On page 8, you can see the development of fuel spreads. Until the end of Q1 2018, which are relevant for our  hedge prices you saw on the previous slide. After the strong improvement of fuel spreads which peaked during  the Jamaica coalition negotiations due to anticipated coal capacity closures, they started to come down after the  talks failed. Since the beginning of the year, we have seen a further strong decline in clean dark spreads to levels  seen a year ago. We believe that spreads at current levels are fundamentally undervalued especially in outer  years and see some potential for recovery.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Now onto our distribution of the cash flow on slide 11. Reconciliation from adjusted EBITDA to distributable cash  flow is dominated by the seasonal development of the operating working capital in Q1. This is mainly driven by  timing effects since we purchased most of our required CO2 certificate in the first quarter of the year.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: This will revert in Q1, once the certificates for admissions in 2017 are delivered to the national clearing authorities.  Changes in provisions and other non-cash items are also impacted by the accounting of CO2 emissions. By the  recognition and provisions run throughout the year, the utilization takes place in Q2. Furthermore, Q1 showed a  very low utilization of our nuclear provisions. In the first quarter, we already accounted for the full-year effect of  the equity British pound hybrid payment which amounted to €60 million. Last year, this was reflected in Q2.

file: RWE - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 15May2019 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: When it comes to our energy transaction with E.ON, we continue to make good progress in the preparation for the  swift integration of both renewable businesses. We recently announced further appointments to the management  team of our future renewables business. We also signed a new €5 billion syndicated credit agreement. It replaced  the previous €3 billion credit agreement and will enable the smooth integration of the renewables operations of  innogy

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: While we have received clearance from the European as well as the German and UK competition authorities for  our part of the transaction, the European Commission stopped the clock twice and thereby extended the deadline  on its review of the planned takeover of innogy's network and retail assets by E.ON. This kind of procedure is  normal for such a complex transaction. Merger clearance is currently expected by the end of Q3, early Q4.  Operational control of the renewables business of E.ON and innogy is still expected by year end. In order to  conduct a thorough post-merger due diligence and allow the renewables management to settle into the new  company, we will hold our Capital Market Day in March next year.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Let's take a look at the development of our adjusted EBITDA. For RWE stand-alone, it amounted to €510 million.  The increase is mainly driven by an outstanding trading performance and the strong gas and LNG business.  Despite lower generation volumes, earnings at Lignite & Nuclear on previous year's level due to higher realized  generation margins. Earnings of the European Power division suffered from lower production volumes and a weak  commercial asset optimization, as well as a suspended UK capacity payments. The adjusted EBITDA does not  yet include the innogy dividend which will be accounted for in Q2.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 4 provides performance details of the Lignite & Nuclear division. Year-on-year, the production volumes  came down, among others, driven by the restrictions at the Hambach mine and outages. However, slightly higher  generation margins have been realized and led to a solid earnings contribution on the previous year's level. The  increase in depreciation is mainly influenced by changes from the IFRS 16 application and interest adjustments  for nuclear provisions which led to higher asset values for the operating plants.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: The European Power division realized an adjusted EBITDA of €63 million. Higher renewable feed-ins and a  warmer weather condition led to lower generation output at our power plants, as well as weaker earnings from  commercial asset optimization.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Now on to our current hedge position on slide 6. For 2019 and 2020, hedge prices stayed flat as we are almost  fully hedged. For 2021, we increased the hedge position to more than 90% and the hedge price moved from €37  to €39 per megawatt hour. The increase of approximately €2 was driven by higher carbon prices, which means  that hedge margins are unaffected. We have now also included our hedge position for 2022. More than 50% of  the outright generation is already hedged. With the hedged power price of €44 and the hedged carbon price of  €14, margins also remain stable in 2022 despite the rally in carbon prices. However, we still retain upside from  our implicit fuel hedge in case fuel spreads increase in the future.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me also remind you of our long-term carbon position which we have financially hedged through until the mid- 2020s. In other words, the change in carbon prices should not affect our generation margins for the coming years.  As mentioned, we have seen this affect our hedge prices for 2021 and 2022.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: On page 7, you can see the development of fuel spreads until the end of Q1 2019, which are relevant for our  hedge prices you saw in the previous slide. Since the beginning of the year, we have seen a minor increase in  fuel spreads. The fuel spread curve for calendar year 2022 is also included for the first time where we still see  some upside.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Now, on to our distributable cash flow on slide 10. The distributable cash flow in Q1 is also on a high level  amounting to €484 million. It is dominated by two drivers. Firstly, the high adjusted EBITDA, and secondly, the  positive effects from changes in working capital. The latter is a timing effect from last year which we already  indicated in our 2018 result presentation in March. At the end of last year, we saw unusually high levels of gas  inventories and higher than usual accounts receivable which have now come down. This over-compensated to  typical seasonal effect of an increase in working capital due to the purchase of CO2 certificates. We also expect  to end the year with a positive effect from change in working capital.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Changes in provisions and other non-cash items are also impacted by the accounting of CO2 emissions. While  the recognition and provisions run throughout the year, the utilization takes place in Q2. For the full year 2019, we  can confirm our expectation from March to reach a level of approximately minus €500 million in change in  provisions and other non-cash items.

file: RWE - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 12August2010 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Aug-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Political discussions around nuclear energy and the entire national energy concept in Germany,  create a lot of uncertainty. Before I will go into more detail concerning these issues, please let me  briefly take you through our achievements during the first six months of this year 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: All our key financials were up by more than 20% compared to the first half 2009. Even without  Essent, our operating result would have gone up by 11%. This is mainly due to the strong  performance of our German power generation activities, the division continued to benefit from  hedges concluded in the past at higher prices than current forwards and from the fact that B plus A  and B were on line again most of the time.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In addition, our Central Eastern and South Eastern Europe division performed well. One important  driver in the year has been our regional gas supply business in the Czech Republic. We increased  the sales margin thanks to lower gas procurement costs. Essent by the way is also doing very well.  All in all, this makes it very easy for us to comment on our outlook for 2010. We confirm our targets,  2010 will be another year with good results and hence an attractive dividend for our shareholders.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We also made progress executing our growth strategy. In June RWE Innogy entered into a joint  venture with the Munich Municipal Utility and Siemens to construct and operate 576 megawatt  Gwynt y Môr wind farm off the Coast of Northern Wales. RWE Innogy owns 60% of the joint  venture.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Also in June, RWE Innogy and the Dutch technology company Topell Energy laid the foundation for  one of the world’s first industry scale biocoal pellet production plant. The plant will have a       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 2 production capacity of 60,000 tons per year and start operations in 2011. We plan to use the  biocoal to coal fire Essent’s hard coal plant in Amer, which many of you already know from your  visits at our Capital Market Day. Such coal firing helps to meet stringency on two targets with the  existing thermal power stations i.e. no new build necessary.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Having signed the West Nile Delta concession agreement in July, we are on route to significantly  increase RWE Dea’s gas production capacity. With pro rata reserves on Dea of more than 50 bcm,  the fields are among the largest in our portfolio. They represent more than 20% of our existing  reserves. We will proceed with the field development at a rapid pace in order to commence  production in 2014.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: You can see that RWE is working hard to reach growth targets in the fields of renewable energies  and upstream gas and oil. However, there is one issue standing in the way of our ambitious growth  targets, which is the potential introduction of a nuclear fuel tax in Germany. As you can read on this  slide, the justifications for this tax are more than questionable both from a market perspective, as  well as from a legal point of view. A benefit sharing mechanism needs to be linked to a nuclear  lifetime extension. Our understanding is that, such a tax on any other profit-sharing mechanism the  so-called fund solution can only be referred to additional production volumes over and above those  set in the 2001 exit agreements.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: From our point of view, there are convincing arguments that the current draft law cannot be a  solution. This is obvious considering its potential impact on the profitability of nuclear power plants.  Based on our expert calculations, the specific additional costs would amount to at least €22 per  megawatt hour. This is a first rough indication, but it gives you the order of magnitude. We have to  add to these €22 per megawatt hour the total generation cost of a nuclear unit to decide, whether it  makes sense to keep a plant online at all. You may conclude that under these circumstances some  plants could reach the limits of their profitability.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The public debate and the media make us forget that the government is still considering nuclear  lifetime’s extensions. I would even say for the most Cabinet Members, they are committed as laid  down in the coalition agreement.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So we are using this as the base case assumption and are working on a solution representing a  legally binding agreement for all parties involved. The industry is in talks with all relevant political  players, the aim is to come up with an alternative solution, which helps the government,  respectively the budget with this austerity package, while at the same time securing additional  lifetime, as well as the profitability of nuclear plants.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In talks with investors, we frequently got the question who is working on this issue at RWE and at  what priority? I can assure you that I personally, my colleagues and our complete staff, plus all  other nuclear operators in Germany put the highest priority on this topic.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Just to give you some more flavor, while Pohlig is discussing solutions with the Ministry of Finance  and I have the privilege to be in talks with the Chancellor’s Office, Gerd Jäger, the nuclear, where  the Board Member of RWE Power responsible for nuclear operations is heading the council for       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: All in all, many points are still to be discussed and clarified with the government. But the current  draft of the legislation on nuclear fuel tax and the uncertainties surrounding this issue, have to be  taken seriously. It forces RWE to put the mid-term guidance, which we had given you this February  under review. It is not only the significant impact of our earnings, which calls for such a step. The  tax or any other alternative solution would also immediately be cash effective. This would reduce  our final headroom significantly and consequently our potential for growth both in CapEx and the  M&A budget.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Decisions and first results will be incorporated in our new mid-term planning, which is due by the  end of the year. Of course, we will give you a full update on all additional cost cuttings, efficiency  enhancements and changes in investment policies as well as on our guidance in February next  year 2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, now back to some more positive news on our CapEx project. In Germany,  all systems are go, at RWE Innogy, to build there first offshore wind farm called Nordsee Ost. We  have chosen Bremerhaven as the base port. The contract for the supply of the foundations was  signed in June. The construction of the offshore wind farm with a total install capacity of 295  megawatts is due to start in 2011. This means it is on schedule. We also constructed a little  special-purpose vehicle, not a financial one but a shift to be certain to erect the windmills on time  even in the adverse conditions of the North Sea.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the U.K, our offshore Greater Gabbard wind farm will commence production this month. The  work on building the first foundations for the Gwynt y Môr offshore wind farm will start towards the  end of 2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Construction work on our biomass pellet factory in the U.S. State of Georgia is also going well. I’ll  be personally inspecting it in October. The plant will have an annual production capacity of 750,000  tons. This will make it the biggest and most modern of its type in the world and will contribute to  securing the supply of our Dutch biomass coal firing plants, a good example of synergies across  our Group’s business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Turning to Germany. At RWE’s new lignite-based power plant BoA 2&3 at Neurath, the steam  boiler of unit G – the centerpiece of the plant – has withstood its first test. It proved its resistance to  pressure in a hydrostatic test required by law. The first of the twin unit plants is scheduled to go  online in the summer of 2011. The second will follow at the end of 2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Certain problems concerning the steel construction of the boiler in our 1,560 megawatt hard coal  plant project in Hamm has now been resolved. We don’t expect any further delays here. The two  units should go online in August 12 and October 12, respectively. Our CCGT fleet is also doing well  in the UK. The construction of npower 1,650 megawatt power station at Staythorpe is on schedule.  It is expected to be fully operational by the late 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 4 There is a 12 months time needed because Essent will test the turbines not all at once but one after  another. The original plan had envisaged only quarter two 2012, so we’re ahead of schedule.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Moving onto our gas upstream and midstream projects. In the third quarter of 2010, we expect to  receive approval for the Reggane gas field in Algeria. RWE holds an interest of 19.5% in that  license. Breagh, our largest development project in the UK is about to start. The field holds  reserves of up to 13 bcm of gas and that is just counting Dea’s share. RWE Dea is operator and  currently stepping up development to take up production in 2012. This project will significantly  increase RWE Dea’s UK production by that year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As planned, the Norwegian Gjøa gas field will commence production by the end of 2010. Gjøa will  make a substantial contribution to RWE Dea Norge gas production replenishment. At the same  time, it offers equity gas, which will be exported to the UK. RWE Dea Norge is currently  participating in two further development projects, Draupne and Luno. Field development approval  will be applied for with the Norwegian authorities at the end of this year and next year respectively.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Rumor has it that an invitation to the South Stream project has been extended to RWE. Therefore I  would also like to say a couple of words regarding Nabucco. We are holding on to this project, it is  a perfect fit for our strategy in the southeastern part of Europe. The construction of the new gas- fired power plant in Denizli in Turkey is proof of this. We are in intensive talks with potential supply  countries like Azerbaijan, Turkmenistan and Northern Iraq. In Azerbaijan, we have recently  received an invitation from the Shah Deniz phase 2 partners, which includes SOCAR, StatoilHydro,  BP, and Total amongst others to engage in the tender process for gas supply contracts.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Shah Deniz II is estimated to have between 10 to 13 bcm per year of gas available for export to  Europe by 2016. In Northern Iraq, the Kurdistan regional government has publicly committed to up  the 15 bcm per year for Nabucco and we are investigating these volumes. Finally with regards to  Turkmenistan, we are supporting the European Commission’s initiative to facilitate the finalizing of  transit arrangements for Turkmen Gas through the Caspian Sea, Azerbaijan and Georgia. We will  continue to look at all these options and evaluate as always their commercial viability.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the core message of today’s presentation is, RWE is performing well  despite uncertainties around the decisions about nuclear lifetime extension and the entire German  energy concept. But before I hand over to Rolf, who will explain to you the details of our H1 results,  let me conclude my part with the outlook for 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now on to our divisional performance, let me start with RWE Power. It’s operating result improved  by 25%. Slide 13 gives you the individual value drivers as usual. We expect the positive trend at  RWE Power to continue during the rest of the year. The higher availability of our Biblis nuclear  power plant and lower costs for fuel and CO2 emission certificates will be the main reasons for this.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let’s have a quick look at the status of our German forward selling. We have sold more than 90%  for 2010, more than 80% for 2011. We have hedged more than 35% for 2012 and we have started  selling volumes for 2013. Average realized prices are still above €60 per megawatt hour, which in  principle corresponds to a mix of approximately 80 to 90% base and 10 to 20% peak. We see an  increase in peak load exposure due to our change in power plant portfolio and the growth in  renewables in the overall system. And of course, not all of our generation volumes are exposed  purely to the out-priced electricity price. For the production based on hard coal and gas, the  development of spreads is more relevant. They have come down significantly for the last couple of  months. You can find more details on our backup slides 30 to 33.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our sales and distribution network business area closed slightly above the previous year. The cold  winter supported our gas sales volumes and favored gas margins. This was offset by low electricity  margins. The German distribution network business benefited from the economic recovery, which  led to increased volumes. Lower costs for grid losses had a positive impact as well. In addition, the  regulator allowed higher costs for growth CapEx to be included in network price.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: On the other hand, the business areas suffered from the refunding of excess proceeds I explained  this in detail already in February. We expect the operating results to be up for 2010 as a whole.  This will be mainly due to improved earnings in the gas sales business above all because of the  absence of one-off costs by the negative gas to oil spreads incurred in 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now on to our new Netherlands/Belgium division. Numbers for 2010 are substantially affected by  consolidation. I explained the major items in the Q1 presentation. The performance of the  Netherlands/Belgium division was supported by higher gas sales due to the cold winter weather  and favored customer account numbers. Please don’t extrapolate H1 for the full year. We’ve  already mentioned in Q1 that more than 50% of the annual result is typically earned in the first  quarter. In addition, in the second half of this year we would see costs related to the implementation  of a new retail customer gas system and one-off costs partially linked to the integration of Essent  into RWE.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 6 Let me continue with RWE npower. Its operating results improved by 14% adjusted for FX effects, it  grossed by 11%. Earnings from our retail business were the main driver of the improved  performance. Earnings in our gas business were covered on the back of improved residential  demand over the winter month and slightly lower commodity costs. This was partially offset when  we lowered our gas tariffs at the end of March this year. In addition, we have seen lower electricity  margins following our tariff cut in March last year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The performance of our generation business was down, driven by reduced spreads and lower  income from short-term position management, which was partly compensated for, by reduced  maintenance costs. We expect that lower spreads will also influence the performance of our  generation business for 2010 as a whole. This will be partially offset by the commissioning of our  new power plant at Staythorpe in the second half of this year and a reduction in station  maintenance costs.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As the build-up of arising nuclear power continues, we are seeing high upfront costs for our UK  nuclear development program. Although the aforementioned tariff reductions in our retail business  is putting pressure on margins, we expect negative impacts from high electricity network fees. We  expect retail margins to benefit from slightly lower commodity costs. However, the benchmark  continues to be extremely challenging due to the significant increases in commodity prices over the  last month.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our focus will remain on efficiencies to ensure competitive cost base. The €120 million program  initiated last year, they will be turned into a sustainable improvement and we are working on  additional efficiency measures, generation, retail and corporate functions or we anticipate a slight  increase out of the npower’s operating results.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We anticipate that earnings generated by this division will now be more in the order of last year  supported by positive Forex effects. The main reason for the slowdown of earnings growth in the  second half of this year is that margins in our Czech gas sales business as well as in the Hungarian  electricity sales and generation business are expected to come down again. On the other hand, we  will see higher earnings contributions from our Czech regional gas sales business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our renewables division posted an increase in its operating results of 13%. First time consolidation  of the Essent wind assets contributed €9 million to earnings. We explained already in Q1 that this is  less than originally expected due to the very weak wind production caused by the weather. As the  first quarter is the most important one for this business, we don’t expect to make up for low  earnings during the rest of the year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The first time consolidation of Danta de Energias in May last year, as well as the commissioning of  the 90 megawatt Rhyl Flats wind farm also had a positive effect on our earnings. In contrast upfront  costs for our large investment program still dampened the development of Innogy’s operating  result. In addition, earnings went down due to lower realized electricity prices in Germany and  Spain, and less wind volumes in UK. As regards to 2010, we expect RWE Innogy to record higher  operating revenues. We achieved further results of our growth investment program. But upfront  costs for our projects are still offsetting most of this.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 7 In addition, Innogy will benefit from the first time consolidation of Essent’s wind activities but due to  the low wind volumes in northwestern Europe, the advantage will be less than originally expected. I  would like to remind you that the earnings improvement will accelerate in the coming years.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Upstream gas and oil reported a 48% increase in operating earnings. This is mainly a result of  higher oil prices, as well as reduced exploration costs in North Africa. In addition, we benefited from  lower royalties in the German business. On the other hand, Dea suffered from lower gas prices and  production volumes. Compared to the very weak 2009, we see significant upside potential for 2010.  RWE Dea expects to see improved oil prices. This will be partly offset by lower gas prices and  volumes as well as increasing production costs.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The operating results in our Trading/Gas Midstream division fell by 62%. The mark-to-market  performance of the trading business fell behind the high level of the first half last year. On the other  hand, we benefited from the first time consolidation of the Essent trading activities. They  contributed €68 million in the first half of this year. The steep decline is mainly related to our gas  supply activities. This is because of two major items. First, in the first half of last year, we had  successfully concluded price revisions. Secondly, gas market prices dropped compared to oil  indexed purchase contracts. This especially affected our Czech gas portfolio due to growing  competition. As a result, we’ve built a provision.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In 2010, we expect the division to close significantly below last year’s record level despite the  integration of Essent’s trading activities. Lower trading margins compared to the extraordinarily high  level in 2009, the absence of aforementioned one-off items recognized in 2009, as well as the  provisions for Czech gas portfolio are the main reasons. The current situation in the Czech gas  market might even require further provisions in the second half of this year.

file: RWE - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 9August2011 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Turbulent weeks are lying behind us with all the uncertainties about the new German energy policy. Today, we  want to give you our strategic answers to how RWE will respond to the new situation. What are the major  differences compared to our situation in February? The German Government has withdrawn from the nuclear  lifetime extension but the nuclear fuel tanks stays in place. As a result, we are facing significant one-off burdens in  the current financial year.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide four gives you the operating performance of the group. EBITDA and operating results suffered by  approximately €700 million from the unexpected and hurried nuclear exit decision, plus approximately €200  million from the expected nuclear fuel tax. This is overshadowing the good performance in some of our divisions,  on which Rolf will enlarge later. But today, we don't look back and argue whether this decision makes sense or not.  We accept; we must accept the political will and [ph] to trust the (02:33) strategy accordingly. And you will see  that our general strategy we started in 2008 to make RWE more sustainable, more international and more robust,  is the right answer to this new environment, and therefore stays in place.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Due to the early nuclear closure, we are facing significant financial constraints. As a result, we will adapt our speed  to execute the strategy and have to ensure that our financial strength will not deteriorate in the long term. In this  context, you know about our planned divestment program after the successful sale of Thyssengas and our stake in  the Rostock hard-coal plant. The recent decision to bring long-term oriented financial investors onboard of our  TSO Amprion was a further important step in that direction. But against the unforeseen backlog of the current  environment, the financial pressure has intensified. Therefore, we will step up our disposal program and intend to  protect our solid A rating, which is important to finance long-term growth in our core markets. More details on  that later.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Before I start with the details of our planned measures, let me provide you with a summary of the key decisions of  the German Government on slide five. We were forced to shut down two of our five nuclear units, Biblis A and B,  with a total generation capacity of approximately 2.4 gigawatts or approximately 18 gigawatt hours per year. We  will make sure we protect the property rights of our shareholders and have already started legal action against the  moratorium decision and the nuclear fuel tax. The decision of the German Government was made at the peak of  our huge investment program to build highly-efficient conventional power plants and significant investment in  the renewables business as part of our CO2 mitigation strategy. This is an additional burden, which we couldn't  have expected at the beginning of the year. Although the nuclear phase-out will impact our CO2 mitigation  strategy, we uphold our general target. The measures we have initiated will reduce our CO2 exposure significantly.  Hence, from today's point of view, we are slightly along CO2 over the period from 2013 to 2020.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Please bear in mind, when we say evaluate our options it is still open whether we divest an asset fully, the majority  or a minority stake only. A good example is RWE Dea. The required contribution to support our balance sheet  might already be achieved by the sale of growth assets like, for example, our activities or part of our activities in  Egypt. Our planned joint venture with Gazprom is a further option within this program. We want to evaluate  potential partnerships in power generation. The benefit is to improve our CO2 position and to share the capital- intensive financing of such projects between two partners. This memorandum of understanding is not only an  attractive way to look for a project partner; it is an additional important chance to bring the current negotiations  on our gas contracts to a mutually satisfactory conclusion. We are still at an early stage and nothing concrete can  be added at this point in time, but it is a good starting point of further discussions in the next two months. And let  me add, both parties are willing to develop this MoU.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Our second building block is our CapEx program. As you know, 2011 will be the peak of our investment cycle in  mitigation strategy. This program will be more or less finalized by 2013. We expect CapEx in the next two years to  come down to less than €5 billion per annum. We see the long-term sustainable CapEx after our disposal program  at a level of about €4 billion. This includes approximately €2 billion of day-to-day CapEx, i.e., maintaining our  traditional businesses. The other €2 billion is earmarked for new projects, if they meet our strict financial criteria  for growth investments. Potential small bolt-on acquisitions are already included in this number. In 2012 and  2013, a significant amount of investments is already committed. From 2014 onwards, this will come down to a  level of 60% and lower including the day-to-day investments. This of course does not mean that we don't have  attractive investment opportunities; it is just an illustration of our flexibility to reduce CapEx, if needed, to further  support our solid A rating.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, RWE AG
texts.text: The aforementioned measures are accompanied by capital measures. These measures in particular will set the  stage for long-term growth and support our credit rating. Due to the loss of future cash flows from nuclear lifetime  extensions and the cash burden from the nuclear fuel tax, we can't avoid these measures anymore. We will pursue  two capital measures. First, we want to execute an equity capital measure of approximately €2.5 billion in total.  Depending on market conditions, we intend to execute this placement by the end of the year, but this is not a  must. We cannot be more specific about the details at the moment, but it will include the sale of our treasury  shares. Second, also depending on market conditions, we intend to issue further hybrid bonds by the end of 2012  to bridge the near-term financial needs.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Although we have a changed investment environment, we still have the financial flexibility to invest in the growth  areas, renewable energy at Eastern Europe including Turkey. We want to dedicate more than €1 billion per annum  for growth CapEx into renewables at more than €0.5 billion per annum for Eastern Europe including Turkey. We  can confirm our target for the renewables division to reach a capacity of 4.5 gigawatts by 2014 and to generate  operating earnings of €500 million in the same year. Central Eastern and South Eastern Europe promise a lot of  growth opportunities along all parts of the value chain. Of course, it will be of top priority to carefully evaluate  which are the most promising projects and what risk profile they have. Our focus therefore will be on organic  growth combined with selective small bolt-on acquisitions. There will be also a combination of renewable  investments in the region, Central and Southeastern Europe.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: On to our divisional performance, starting with RWE Power; its operating result decreased significantly by 43%.  The impact of the nuclear moratorium followed by the new energy policy played a decisive role in this  development. As a consequence, the operating result is negatively impacted by about €700 million in the first half  of 2011. This already includes the necessary adjustments on nuclear provisions. The nuclear fuel tax came into  effect and had a negative impact on our operating result of about €200 million. Overall, the total impact resulting  from the German energy policy is therefore about €900 million in the first half of this year. As we have mentioned  earlier, we have five lawsuits against the nuclear fuel tax.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: For the entire year, the expected impact of the political decisions on nuclear power is about €1 billion. On top of  that, we are burdened by €300 million of nuclear fuel tax. Compared to the result – impact of the nuclear lifetime  extension and nuclear fuel tax, which we had guided for in February this year, this is an additional unexpected  burden of about €600 million. Furthermore, we have also been negatively affected by the commodity price  development and lower realized electricity prices. For the full year, we expect higher fixed operating and  maintenance cost.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Our Sales and Distribution Network business area closed to 4% below the previous year. We benefited from the  full consolidation of the regional sales and distribution company, NVV, that has previously been accounted for at  equity. The main reason for the lower operating result is the development in our distribution networks business.  Higher temperature and milder weather conditions compared to the previous year led to lower volumes, especially  distribution grid infrastructure. The earnings in our Sales business declined, among other things, due to lower gas  volumes from the back of milder weather conditions. For fiscal year 2011, we expect the operating result to fall  below the previous year despite the first-time full consolidation of NVV. This is mainly as a result of higher OpEx  for improving the quality of our Distribution Network business. The costs for refunding excess proceeds will be  slightly lower than in 2010. For the Sales business, we expect lower gas volumes, assuming normalized weather  conditions. Last year benefited from the cooler-than-average winter.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Now, on to our Netherlands/Belgium division; as you already know, the 2011 results are substantially affected  because we now report part of the gas midstream business and Trading/Gas Midstream. The operational trends  are more or less unchanged compared to the first quarter of this year. We expect fiscal year 2011 to be significantly  below last year. The effects are listed in detail on slide 20.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me continue with RWE npower. The operating result has more than doubled. The increase is mainly attributed  to the improved operating performance of our Retail business, but also to some positive one-off effects. In the  Retail business, npower benefited from improved commodity cost management and growth in the segment of  larger business customers. In addition, our efficiency in cost reduction programs had a positive effect, in  particular on our bad debt position. The performance of our Generation business was supported by the  commencement of operation at our new CCGT plant at Staythorpe. Additional margins have been generated  despite some commissioning defects on two transformers that are currently reducing their production volume.  For full-year 2011, anticipate a significant increase in RWE npower's operating result, reflecting in particular RWE  npower's cost and efficiency programs. The second half of the year we expect to see a decline of the generation  spreads and increased commodity cost.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Operating earnings in our Central Eastern and South Eastern Europe Division reduced to €691 million, 4% below  the previous year's figure. Adjusted for ForEx effects, the division was down 8%. Pressure on earnings came from  weather-induced lower gas sales in the Czech Republic. Earnings are also impacted by lower margins in our  Hungarian business. One reason is that the Hungarian regulator reduced the allowed margins in the household  customer segment. The negative effects were partly compensated for by higher income in our Czech gas transport  business. For 2011, we expect the operating result to be below the exceptionally high number in 2010. In the Czech  Republic, we expect gas sales margins to further come down. The contribution from our Hungarian electricity  activities is also expected to stay slightly behind last year's level though less than anticipated. We expect to see  higher electricity network margins in Poland and a positive development in earnings from our Czech gas  transportation business.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: The operating result of our Renewables division more than tripled to €89 million. Improved wind conditions,  positive volume effects from our growth CapEx and high electricity prices were driving up Innogy's earnings to a  large extent. In addition, we received liquidated damages relating to the Greater Gabbard project as compensation  for lost profits due to construction delays. However, upfront costs for large investment program still weigh on the  division's operating results. We continue to expect RWE Innogy to post a strong earnings increase in 2011.  Generation volumes are set to increase due to the further execution of our expansion program and improved wind  conditions. Upfront costs for our projects will still be offsetting some of the positive effects.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Upstream Gas & Oil reported a 74% increase in operating earnings. Rising oil and gas prices, they're by far the  main factor. In addition, the division recorded high oil production volumes and lower exploration expenditures.  ForEx effects and the lower gas production, increased production costs and higher royalties in the German Gas  business had a counteracting effect. We expect the positive earnings trend to continue, resulting in a significant  operating result increase for full fiscal-year 2011.  The operating result in our Trading/Gas Midstream division turned into a significant negative number in the first  half of 2011. The performance of our Trading business has been exceptionally weak, mainly driven by the  turbulence on commodity markets caused, for instance, by the events in Northern Africa and the changes in  German energy policy. In addition, our Gas Supply business is still under pressure from the negative gas-to-oil  spread. As you all know, we are in negotiations and arbitrations with almost all of our suppliers. As a positive, the  division benefited from Gas Midstream margins which had previously been reported in the Netherlands/Belgium  division. All in all, we expect the operating result in 2011 to fall significantly below the level of 2010.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: The non-operating results increased by €799 million to minus €210 million. In the first half of 2011, capital gains  reached €315 million, mainly as a result of the disposal of Thyssengas and a 24.6% stake in the Rostock hard-coal  power plant. The impact of commodity derivatives on earnings was negligible in the first half-year but improved  significantly compared to last year's figures. Restructuring, other fell by €576 million to minus €522 million,  resulting from several items. In the first half of this year, we booked an impairment for the Essent gas and hard- coal power plant portfolio of approximately €270 million due to decreasing clean generation spreads in the  Deutsch power market. We built in provisions of about €220 million for restructuring programs for RWE Power  and RWE Deutschland to take personal reduction measures in a socially acceptable manner. This measure is a  reaction to the changing market conditions, particular to the early exit from nuclear generation in Germany. Our  financial result improved by €81 million to minus €706 million. This was mainly due to an improvement of our  net interest result. Here, we benefited from the release of provisions accrued in 2010.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Now on to our cash flow statement; funds from operations reduced by about €1 billion, mirroring our operating  performance. Our cash flow from operating activities increased by about 80% to €3.1 billion in the same period,  resulting from positive effects in our working capital. The majority of the CO2 certificates needed for the  redemption in April this year were already paid at the end of last year and therefore reduced our cash needs in  2011. Further relief comes from temporarily improved liquidity situation at Amprion. CapEx on fixed assets was  relatively stable and mainly related to the extension and modernization of our power generation fleet. Overall, free  cash flow increased considerably by €1.2 billion to €403 million. However, please bear in mind that as a result of  our large investment program this will change during the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, RWE AG
texts.text: First, the group's guidance for 2011; the expectation for the operational performance has improved compared to  February and May, but the unforeseeable German nuclear exit will lead to an even higher burden. As a result, we  now expect EBITDA and the operating result to come down by approximately 20% and approximately 25%  respectively. We see recurrent net income declining by approximately 35%. For 2013, we have now taken into  consideration the disposal of Amprion, Thyssengas and the stake in the Rostock hard-coal plant. They account for  €1.5 billion of our divestment program. The expected earnings figures before further divestments have improved  on the back of our increased efficiency program and better commodity prices and spreads.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, I started my presentation with reference to the turbulent weeks lying behind us. Dust has  settled now and we have a new and clear starting point for the development of RWE. With the package of  we'll be able to continue to finance growth CapEx, which will later on turn into profit growth. And thirdly, RWE  can weather future storms.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Looking forward, RWE will be – I should rather say, will continue to be an excellent operator who is active in  markets that we know and that you know. In addition, with our future investments we are focusing on markets  that we know very well. The energy market environment is changing dramatically, and RWE will be a reliable  partner playing an active role in shaping the new energy landscape. We believe that the combination of all four  actions represent a fair compromise in the interest of all stakeholders. In addition, I'm very happy that yesterday  the Supervisory Board decided early, and I should say timely on the successor to the CEO, and I'm sure that Peter  Terium – in Peter Terium we have an excellent personality whom you already know from investor and analyst  events. Hence, with our strategic measures and the management decision, we now have more or less all the  uncertainty out of the market, which dragged down our share price over the last couple of months.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chairman, Executive Board, RWE Aktiengesellschaft
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the energy industry is going through a far-reaching transformation, and RWE is operating  with a challenging, competitive environment. I am delighted to have the opportunity to play an integral part as  well as take a prominent position in shaping this transformation. This situation is not completely new to me. And  I have firsthand experience on, for instance, disposal programs. One of my most challenging jobs in the past for  RWE was the execution of the disposal of the Waste Management business. Furthermore, I was the CEO of  Essent, responsible for the Essent transaction and its smooth integration, as well as its performance improvement  and delivering even more than the originally promised synergies on this transaction. Last but not the least, I have  been in charge as CEO for over four years of supply and trading by which I'm very familiar with RWE's value chain  and the management of its commodity risks and optimizing those risks. The whole management team, including  myself, will work hard to deliver all what just has been presented.

file: RWE - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 14August2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Stephan Lowis
texts.profession: Vice President-Investor Relations, RWE AG
texts.text: Before we start with the presentation, I would like to remind you of our Offshore Wind Capital Market Day on the  12 of September. Some of you might have been on holiday when we sent out the invitation. So, please get in touch  with us if you have missed it.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: In renegotiation of our oil-indexed long-term gas contracts, we have made further progress. We're pleased that we  managed to find the structural solution with Statoil. This is a major milestone. There are now only two major  counter-parties left with whom we are still conducting price reviews. Rolf will provide some more details on the  current status of our gas-to-oil spread exposure.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: The completion of the renegotiation of our oil-indexed gas contracts is also an important factor in achieving our  financial targets. As we have said several times, we expect the conclusion of the price reviews with the remaining  two counter-parties by 2013 at the latest. The clear goal is to agree on the structural solution. And so, far our  perseverance has paid off.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Last, but not least, I would like to come to efficiencies. The focus in the next two years will be not only to deliver  on our efficiency enhancement targets, and I will comment on the progress we're making there in a moment, but  we also need to lay the foundations for continuous improvements beyond 2014. Operating efficiency is and will be  an ongoing commitment at RWE. We therefore, kicked off the RWE 2015 project, which will strengthen the core  of our business model and identify further efficiency potential. I'm going to introduce you to the RWE 2015  initiatives shortly.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me add that we will need to continue to do so since our market will keep on changing. Let me give you some  examples. Take our generation portfolio, for instance, while we have one of the most balanced generation  portfolios in the sector, we are not immune to the changes caused by the growing feed-in from renewables. We  have to analyze our fleet constantly for its competitiveness. Decisions have already been taken, but will continue to  be required in relation to capacity retirements. Further action is currently being analyzed and discussed.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Current economic conditions do not allow for any new-build decision in the foreseeable future. For our nuclear  portfolio and expertise, we have decided to phase them out, in line with the German decision. Regardless of the  current weak power prices, the cluster risk for such an investment will be simply too high. Also, it does not make  sense to bring a new nuclear power station on line, the year after our last German one would have to shut down.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Another example is renewables. Certain technologies have experienced a significant learning curve with  subsequent cost reductions in the equipment, which has led to their increased competitiveness. This includes  photovoltaic, which has already reached life-cycle competitiveness without subsidization in certain regions, where  competence in this field. This does not mean that we will suddenly invest several hundred millions or divert  investments from other parts of RWE Energy to this field. In a first step, we will be looking at a few carefully  selected demo projects. This includes, for instance, the pilot PV wind project in Morocco within the Desertec  Initiative.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: The energy market transformation requires a big effort by all market participants and cannot be delivered single- handedly. Offshore wind farms of several 100 megawatts require substantial upfront investments and carry  significant installation and operational risks. Networks need to be equipped to be able to manage the rising feed- in from decentralized sources. Partnerships will, therefore, become more important for future investments.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: I would like to talk now about our RWE 2015 programme, which we launched earlier this year.
