You are already  familiar with our new efficiency-enhancement programme, which will contribute €1 billion between 2013 and  2014. But this is only one part of it. The market environment around us is changing rapidly and we have to ensure  that we're well equipped to face those changes.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: This entails looking at our business model and structures rather than embarking on just another efficiency- enhancement programme. We want to lay the foundations for an organization which continuously drives for  operational excellence and efficiencies. We, therefore, have identified four fields of action, which have to be  addressed to make RWE fit for the future. And while some of them might lead to further efficiencies beyond 2014,  we will not provide any new targets beyond 2014. It is simply too early.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me go through them now. First, we are looking at some topics within our strategy. As mentioned before, we  are convinced that we are well positioned in terms of our general strategic direction. However, we are facing huge  challenges when it comes to the transformation of the energy system in Northwest Europe, with some challenging  our traditional business model. But rather than being part of the problem, we want to be part of the solution. We  are, therefore, working to identify the opportunities of the market transformation and how we can participate in it.  We are looking to be innovative and continue to grow. One example is the direct sale of large customers' electric  output from renewables on the wholesale market.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: With RWE Supply & Trading already following a pan-European approach, we are bringing the assets in line with  their commercialization. The new European GenCo will have one single point of accountability for RWE's  challenges and capture synergies between different fuel types. We are now starting with the implementation and  are expecting to have the new generation company in place by January 1, 2013.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide eight now gives you the details of our current efficiency programme that we will finalize this year. We are  well on track to achieve the outstanding €400 million in 2012, to reach the cumulative efficiency gains of €1.5  billion compared to 2006. In March 2012, we introduced a new efficiency target of €1 billion for 2014, compared  to 2012. Out of this €1 billion, approximately €500 million is follow-on efficiency improvements from the current  programme.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Staff reduction is not a prime target, but in the context of our €1 billion programme, we will see approximately  €300 million per annum from a reduction of our workforce between the end of 2012 and 2014. This will be done  in close contact with the works councils and employee representatives on the basis of socially-acceptable  measures.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: In addition, we expect to achieve another approximately €450 million on efficiency improvement from other cost  reductions and from margin improvements. Let me give you some concrete examples, so that you get an idea of  what we are working.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: In our generation business, we're focusing on the improvement of maintenance concepts and technical  optimizations. As you know, our Continental European generation business, in particular, has been put under  pressure by increasing production from renewables and from the shrinking market share of hard coal and gas- consequence of these initiatives was the mothballing of steam parts of the Gersteinwerk over the summer, even  permanently – or even permanently. This results in cost savings of double-digit million euro amount and, at the  same time, makes sure that the station remains cash-generating.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Additionally, we are working on the optimization of technical parameters of our units by increasing flexibility and  load gradients and reducing minimum load requirements. This helps us to earn additional margins, capturing  market opportunities driven by the increased demand for flexibility due to the volatile production from  renewables.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: In our Trading/Gas Midstream division, we are in the process of streamlining activities by moving all trading  activities out of the Geneva office, realizing considerable efficiency improvements between the Bosch, Essen and  Swindon by optimizing front as well as back-office processes. The whole programme takes 25% of the cost base  out in this business by 2014 and will contribute approximately €100 million to our €1 billion target.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: In our German Sales and Distribution business unit, we're also working on more than 100 individual measures to  increase efficiency by approximately €100 million. In our UK division, we are focusing on technical improvements  at our power plants to increase their efficiency. In addition, we are optimizing purchasing contracts for our UK  generation fleet and improving the information management between the stations and RWE Supply & Trading.  Furthermore, we are optimizing processes at our commodity and contract management activities, which will also  result in staff redundancies.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Thank you, Peter, and good afternoon to everyone. Let me start, as usual, with an overview of our performance  indicators in the first half of this year. External revenue was slightly down by 1%. The main reason of that was the  deconsolidation of Amprion. Our EBITDA and operating results bill increased by 9%. A major contributor was the  absence of one-off burdens experienced in the first half of 2011 due to Germany's accelerated nuclear phase-out  decision. In addition, we benefited from an improved performance by our energy trading business.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: The non-operating result improved almost €70 million on last year's figure. We realized lower capital gains from  disposals, but this was more than compensated for by higher value gains of commodity derivatives. While we had  much lower provisions for personal reduction measures, we accrued risk provisions for investments and made  some an impairment €134 million with regards to the power purchase agreement with the Dutch nuclear power  plant operator, EPZ. The financial result declined by about €150 million, driven by the higher financial liabilities  and an increase in the interest accretion to non-current provisions.  Furthermore, the 2011 result benefited from the release of a provision made in relation to the new refund which  ceased to exist with the nuclear phase-out decision. The effective tax rate was 33% or a 6 percentage point higher  compared to the first half of 2011. The increase was mainly driven by lower tax-free capital gains and  impairments, which are not tax deductible. For the full year, we now expect the tax rate to remain at this higher  level.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me now explain the development of the operating result in each of our divisions. The operating result of our  Power Generation division in Germany advanced by 33%. Major contributors were the already mentioned  extraordinary burdens in the first half of 2011. The accelerated nuclear phase-out decision led to an increase in  nuclear decommissioning provisions. In addition, we had to write down nuclear fuel rods at our Biblis plant. But  we also suffered from lower realized power prices and spreads. A positive contribution resulted from the trial run  of our new lignite plant BoA 2&3 at Neurath. The plant has now entered commercial operations.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Before moving on, let me say something about the operational performance of our power plants. Of course, we are  feeling the impact of the rising feed-in from renewables, especially our gas and hard coal portfolio are  experiencing lower utilization. However, this is not a recent development. Older plants have already been running  on lower loads for some time. We're, therefore, making adjustments to our portfolio reflecting these new market  realities. Peter already mentioned the mothballing of Gersteinwerk, but we're also looking at adjusting the  operating mode as well as flexing and reducing fixed costs of power stations. Ultimately, we will decide to shut  plants which we cannot maintain cash-generative.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Our lignite plants continue to display stable utilization. Despite the persistent expansion of renewables, we expect  our nuclear and lignite plants to run base load for the time being. The load adjustments will continue to come  from peak and mid-merit plants.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Let's return to our division performance, earnings at our German Sales and Distribution Networks business unit  dropped by 7%. Lower electricity sales margins and decline in the income from investments were only partly  compensated by efficiency-enhancement measures and capital gains from the sale of networks due to the loss of  concessions.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Hence, results deteriorated by 13% despite the commissioning of our new CGT's Claus C and Moerdijk 2. Clean  spark spreads are particularly weak at the moment, probably as a result of Germany's continued expansion of  photovoltaic capacity. In contrast, cost-cutting and gas-sourcing optimization had a positive effect on the Dutch  end customer business. In relation to acquisition synergies, I am also happy to report that we will achieve them  this year, two years earlier than promised.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: The operating performance of RWE npower decreased by 9% to €319 million. The main reason is the  fire in a bunker led to lower output compared to last year and the plant was still firing hard coal. The first unit is  back in operation again and we expect the two other ones to follow by the end of this month. The first half of 2011  also benefited from one-off items relating to claims settlements.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Efficiency-enhancement measures, higher sales volumes and improved commodity cost management had a  positive impact on the UK supply business. Our CE/SEE [Central Eastern/South Eastern Europe] division  recorded a decline in the operating result of 17%. The Czech gas supply business contributed to this development.  However, its earnings for the full year should return close to the level achieved last year. Lower generation spreads  and retail margins in Hungary as well negative ForEx effect were further contributing factors.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Increased generation volumes and higher realized prices benefited our renewables business; however,  compensation payments received in 2011 for delays in the construction of Greater Gabbard did not recur. Our  Upstream business increased its operating result by 27%. Higher gas and oil prices and the appreciation of the  U.S. dollar over the euro were the main drivers.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: The Trading/Gas Midstream division closed the first half with an operating loss of €340 million. This is a  significant improvement compared to last year. The performance of the Trading business has improved  considerably by the burdens from the negative gas-to-oil spread continued to increase. However, we managed to  renegotiate a number of contracts for which we also received compensation payments.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, you know this chart, number 14, from our previous presentations. The gray area gives you  the reduction already achieved in the oil-indexed share of RWE's gas purchase portfolio, which represents more  than 50% of the contract volumes. Peter already mentioned that we were successful with further renegotiations on  long-term oil-indexed gas contracts.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: In June, we reached a solution on the outstanding gas contract with Statoil. Statoil is one of the three biggest  suppliers of RWE. The agreement includes a structural solution by gradually adjusting the contract price towards  the prevailing market condition. The settlement further comprises compensation for the historic period, since the  start of the negotiations which is within the range of our expectations.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: This agreement reflects that the gas market pricing structure in Continental Europe is in a transitional phase. We  have been able to structure our relationship with Statoil to better fit the market conditions going forward. We are  still in renegotiations with two gas suppliers for volume of approximately 11 Bcf. We expect the renegotiations or  arbitrations to be finalized in 2013 and to soften gas-to-oil spread exposure by then.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 16 gives you the development of net debt in the first half of 2012. It increased by €4 billion to €34 billion.  This is more than we originally expected. The main reason is the adjustment of discount rates for pension  provisions as a result of the low interest rates. For the years as a whole, expect the current net debt figure to come  down again, but it will exceed last year's number.  This brings me to our divisional outlook. The good performance of our energy trading business and proven  progress in our gas supply contract renegotiations has led us to upgrade our guidance for the Trading/Gas  Midstream division. However, let me remind you that the performance can still fluctuate depending on the  development of the gas-to-oil spread for the remainder of the year.

file: RWE - Q2 2012 Earnings Call Fixed Income Call 14August2012 1115 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Aug-12.pdf
RWE - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 14August2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: However, we have also new capacity to our portfolio. At the beginning of August, we commissioned our 7 87   megawatt gas-fired power plant in Denizli, Turkey. Now that this plant is in commercial operation, there are only  two more stations to be completed as part of our conventional power plant new build program that began in 2006,  the two hard coal power stations in Hamm and Eemshaven.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In July, we completed the construction of the Belgian offshore wind park, Thornton Bank, with a total capacity of  325 megawatt and in which we hold around 27% stake. With the recent closing of the natural gas transaction, we  have successfully implemented the final step in the disposal of this asset. We have already received the payment.  Consequently, the proceeds from the transaction will impact our net debt figure in the third quarter. We still  expect this transaction to remain the largest one for 2013.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Since March, I'm now on page 4. Since March, when we presented our update on the profitability of our  generation fleet, the situation on the power market has not improved, in fact, quite the contrary. The forward - based price for 2014 has decreased by €4 per megawatt hour over the course of the last five months. Two major  drivers are low hard coal and CO2 prices. We have also seen a new record high for solar production in Germany  which reached almost 24 gigawatt capacity at noon on a Sunday in July.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The reasons why we didn't see a corresponding low in spot market prices were that solar power plants were being  inspected at the same time only very low wind levels were recorded. Nevertheless, on that Sunday, the peak prices  printed about €5 per megawatt hour below the base price, the typical solar effect on the shape of the power curve.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: As a result of the deteriorating profitability of generation capacity, particularly of gas and hard coal -fired power  stations, German generators have recently become more vocal on real or potential power plant closures or  mothballing.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Firstly, we decided to reduce capacity, which I will explain in a minute on the next chart. The total amount of  capacity affected is about 4.3-gigawatt.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Secondly, we will intensively review additional capacity of almost 900 -megawatt in Germany, with the option of  applying one of our capacity measures. This includes the hard coal unit Westfalen C and three of our older lignite  units.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Thirdly, we will make a decision on each of our remaining contracted hard coal plants individually according to  the contractual dates. By the end of 2013, we will make a decision on a further 1.4-gigawatt of contracts. This is in  addition to the termination of the 1.9-gigawatt contracted hard coal plant as communicated in our Annual Report  2012 and the 1.2-gigawatt, which I will explain in a second.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: And finally, we decided that for the time being we will continue the operation of certain plants, contracts, or  participations, despite them being cash flow negative at the moment. This also includes some U.K. power plants,  which have a better economic perspective in the medium term than, for instance, German or Dutch gas site  stations.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The reason is that some of the units carry unavoidable cash costs, which we cannot reduce at the moment. One  example for these unavoidable cash costs are long-running maintenance contracts. In these cases, we are in  negotiations with the suppliers to find solutions to reduce these costs. Another example of unavoidable cash costs  are onerous long-term power purchase contracts. Again, we have started to investigate solutions to  reduce these  burdens.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Our internal cash flow analysis, therefore, showed that continuing the operation for the time being is the least  cash burning option for these units. However, we will continue our thorough review of the remaining stations. We  will take a decision on each unit individually on whether to continue operations or to take the capacity offline,  either temporarily or permanently. A typical trigger point for such a decision would be the moment when a power  plant is due for a larger inspection, for example, if we will not commit to expenditure for repairs and maintenance  unless there's a commercially viable case for it.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Firstly, we will decommission the Dutch hard coal plant, Amer 8, with a capacity of 610 megawatt. The  decommissioning, however, is subject to the final decision on the Dutch energy agreement, the so -called  Energieakkoord by the Dutch government which is expected by the end of August this year. The Energieakkoord  contains conditions, among others, to close coal-fired power stations that were commissioned during the 1980s by  the beginning of 2016.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Secondly, we decided that certain gas units with a combined capacity of more than 1.7 gigawatt will be mothballed  long term between now and the second quarter of 2014. Please be reminded that we have already mothballed  several Dutch gas plants at a total capacity of around 800 megawatt in 2012.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Thirdly, we decided to seasonally mothball two steam turbines connected to gas plants in the north of Germany  totaling 720 megawatts. The result from our analysis showed that the optimal savings contribution at this specific  site will be achieved by a flexible approach to mothballing these two units.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: And finally, we decided on the termination of three of our hard coal contracts with a capacity of 1,17 0 megawatt.  The contracts will expire between end of 2013 and 2014. The total cash savings from all of our capacity measures  and further optimizations will be in the order of €7 0 million per annum.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: As you can see, gas-fired power plants are the first candidates to be taken out of operation due to their high  variable cost, which are not covered by current power prices. Nevertheless, let me emphasize again that we are  also thoroughly analyzing the profitability of our hard coal and lignite assets as you can see from our first  responses.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me now come to chart number 6 and to the second hot topic, which is the ruling from the arbitration with  Gazprom. At the end of June, we received the final award from the arbitral tribunal related to our request for a  revision of the purchase price payable for the natural gas supplied on our long-term gas supply contract.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In its ruling, the tribunal awarded RWE a reimbursement for payments made for the period May 2010 to May  2013. The tribunal also adjusted the purchase price formula for two components, which to a certain extent are  linked to each other. Firstly, adjusting the base price, a so -called P0-cut; and secondly, introducing gas market  indexation in the price formula. The new price formula has been applied retrospectively with effect from May  2010. The new conditions considerably reduced the price level on our contract with Gazprom. As a result, our  exposure to the gas-to-oil spread has been substantially reduced but has not been fully eliminated.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: So was it worthwhile to go the hard way? Y es, because the percentage of gas market indexation and the retroactive  payment are higher than what we think we would have been able to achieve in bilateral negotiations.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: At this point, let me quickly remind you that we reached mutually satisfactory solutions in relation to our o il index  gas supply contracts with all of our other gas suppliers by the end of last year. We have also initiated a new round  of price revision negotiations with Gazprom with effect from Q2 2013. The arbitration ruling in June relates to the  market situation in 2010 and, therefore, reflects only a transitory status of the market at this specific point in time.  Since then, the market has further developed which we take as a positive signal for our future negotiations with  Gazprom.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: I'm well aware that you are keen to learn more about the specific details of the award, for instance, the precise  share of the gas market indexation. Please understand, however, that both parties agreed on a high level of  confidentiality on all contractual terms. With regard to our future relationship, it is in the commercial interest of  both RWE and Gazprom to adhere to this agreement. Let me stress again that we are very satisfied with the result  from the award for the time being.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: From today's point of view, we expect the division to close the fiscal year 2 013 with an operating result in the  order of €1 billion. Please don't read this is as a zero contribution from our trading division. One has to keep in  mind that we will still incur some losses from the gas-to-oil spread exposure for the entire year.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: What does it all mean for the future earnings potential of RWE Supply & Trading? At current market prices, we  would assume this division to be able to achieve a normalized earnings contribution of between €300 million and  €400 million per annum, providing the gas issue is fully solved. As long as we are still facing some minor exposure  from the gas-to-oil spread, we would assume the division to earn about €200 million per annum. Please always  keep in mind that the trading arm of the division is typically more v olatile than the rest of our business.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me now give you a brief overview of the business performance in the first half of 2013 on page 7. Our operating  result increased by 12%, driven by the positive earnings contribution of our trading/gas midstream d ivision after  the arbitration court ruling on our long-term oil index gas contract with Gazprom.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In contrast, the decline we saw on Q1 for our conventional power generation division accelerated. Besides the  burdens of full auctioning of carbon certificates, declining generation margins and the loss of margins from  closing our old lignite plants, we suffered from a one-off burden to adjust provisions for loss-making contracts,  and burdens from the change in nuclear provisions.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The latter refers mainly to the new law concerning the selection of a final storage facility for highly radioactive  waste in Germany. This law became effective on 27 th of July. We are of the opinion that according to the  constitution, any additional cost beyond the necessary cost for one storage facility do not have to be carried by the  utilities as long as it is not decided that Gorleben, the existing facility, is not suitable for the final storage of highly  active nuclear waste.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: However, we have provisioned for the net present value of the additional costs for us already in H1 2013. The  provision amounts to approximately €400 million. But as we had other offsetting elements, the total effect on our  operating result was limited to approximately €70 million. Please keep in mind that the positive earnings trend in  H1 is mainly driven by the one-off effect in our trading gas midstream division and should not be extrapolated for  the full year.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 8 provides you with a reconciliation of our recurrent net income. The non-operating result declined to  approximately minus €1 billion, mainly related to a further impairment of our Dutch electricity generation  portfolio. Our financial result fell by approximately €7 0 million. The positive trend for net interest and interest  accretion to non-current provisions was more than offset by the negative development of the other financial  result. Here we had among other things less income from the sale of securities and significantly higher interest on  tax liabilities.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: With slide number 9, I would like to shed a bit more light on the development of our cash flow in H1 2013. Here  we have a special effect from the one-off payment after the Gazprom arbitration ruling on our long-term index gas  contract. We received the payment in July after the cut-off date for the H1 account. When we received the court  decision at the end of June, we booked accounts receivable against the pr ofit in the P&L.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me come finally to our outlook for fiscal 2013. We can confirm the outlook we provided on the 5th of March at  our full year analyst conference call and confirmed on our Q1 call in May. On 2nd August, 2013 we closed our  disposal of natural gas. As a result, it will only be included in our 2013 earnings numbers until that day. In the first  six months of 2013, natural gas contributed €150 million to our operating result.

file: RWE - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 14August2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me be a bit more explicit on what this means. It means, for me, that our operational performance and our  equipment actions are well in control. Remind you that this guidance that we are now confirming was first time  published in November of last year that confirmed in May of this year and reconfirmed right now. Despite that in  the meantime, we've had a very warm winter and various runoff effects, which we, accounting wise, to ok care of in  the first half of this year. Nevertheless, although this is actually a confident, I might even say, more confident,  without changing our guidance on the numbers as we are despite the factors I mentioned [ph] then (02:13).

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In Germany, the new Renewable Energy Act took effect on August 1. Intension to strengthen the market  integration of renewables is certainly a step in the right direction. The prolongation of the current subsidy scheme  for offshore wind is also positive.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: First, our efficiency program, which we announced in March last year is right on track and we are confident that  we will deliver on our accelerated target of improving our operating results by at least €1.5 billion by the end of  2016. We will update you on our current program in March next year when we will also present our new wave of  efficiency measures.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Second, we reduced our capital expenditure considerably. Our future CapEx levels will mainly be driven by  maintaining our power plant fleet and fulfilling regulatory requirements in our group businesses. In addition, we  will also allocate some funds to our renewables business. The ambition for the time being is, how ever, that new  growth projects will be financed debt neutral. For instance, by taking partners on board overselling stakes and  assets.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Mid-term, we expect our annual CapEx to be in the order of €2 billion. For 2014, it was still amount to about €3.5  billion. Little more, the €1 billion is dedicated to our Group Business. Another important portion is being spent on  a completion of our hardcore power plants in Germany and in Netherlands and our offshore wind farms, Nordsee  Ost and Gwynt y Môr.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Third, our disposal program. In 2013, we completed disposals with a total volume of €2.7 billion, of which the sale  of that for gas was the largest one. This year, the completion of our €5.1 billion sale of our RWE Dea will be the  most important transaction. In addition, we are still working on disposal of Urenco, which we do not expect to  materialize before next year.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: And reactive to the serious market deterioration, we took a number of measures in our generation portfolio. Slide  six provides an update of our capacity measures. As you can see, we took decisions on some more power plan ts.  The trigger points for deciding on capacity measures are events such as maintenance requirements, which go  hand-in-hand in investments, or expiry dates of long term contracts. We investigate thoroughly the economics of  potential, maintenance investments and the extension of contracts, and decide on a case-by-case basis where the  market conditions allow the operation to be continued profitably. The latest analysis showed that [ph] requiring  divestments (06:51) in three older coal plants would be uneconomical; hence, we decided the decommissioning of  these coal plants. They have a combined capacity of 1,000 MW by 2017, and in addition for the contracts with the  total capacity of some 470 MW, will expire by the end of this year. We will continue and we did it on an ongoing  basis to review our portfolio and we'll take further decisions if and when required and appropriate.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: We thought it might be helpful to look at the impact of the capacity measures on the development of our  conventional power plant portfolio. It's important to bear in mind that mothballed power plants do not influence  the actual size of our portfolio. The reason is that these plants are still connected to the grid. They can, therefore,  be ramped up again at a later point in time, if economics become more favorable. Taking into a consideration  further closures due to regulatory requirements as well as capacity additions, our [ph] stored (07:52) capacity will  decrease to about 40 GW by 2017. After a drop in 2014 due to the termination of almost  2.5 GW of contracts, we  will see an increase in capacity in 2015 due to the commissioning of our hard coal-fired power stations in Hamm  and Eemshaven. These are our last two thermal power plant projects in the pipeline. From 2016 onwards, we will  start to see net capacity reductions in our conventional generation portfolio.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me now spend some time on the trends in retail market, where we believe the energy market transition is  really happening. Our retail business is of growing importance with a combined annual contribution of almost €1  billion to the Group's operating results. In today's market, we sell our power and gas products to about 23 million  customers in Europe. It is a highly competitive business in most regions, especially the commodity part of the  business.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: However, we strongly believe energy retail markets will fundamentally change due to new customer requirements  and more efficient technology. Customers will play a considerably more active part in the energy business in the  future. They will be able to buy, to store, to save, and to produce electricity, and they will be able to manage it all  by themselves. The growing amount of household customers in Germany already produce electricity with solar  panels on their rooftops.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: However, while most of the electricity produced by household solar panels has started to the grid today, in the  future, customers will increasingly be able to decide whether to consume it themselves or to sell excess energy to  third-parties.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In addition, more efficient devices and energy saving measures such as home automation will help them to reduce  the energy consumption. Similar trends can be observed in the business sector, where an increasing number of  customers will produce and consume self-generated energy and will actively manage it.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: We consider the changing retail market as an opportunity for us rather than [ph] asset (11:43). The development  of innovative products and new business models to go with these trends will be key. Innovation is, therefore, the  key priority on my agenda. [ph] Whereby we scored (11:54) some success in this respect with our cooperation with  [ph] Next (11:56) in UK and the RWE [ph] home power solar and storage products (11:59) in Germany.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In the Netherlands, we offer the energy trading platform for horticultural customers enabling them to manage and  optimize the energy costs and revenues themselves, based on customer preferences and market opportunities.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 12 shows the earnings development in individual divisions. All in all, we see a decline of approximately €1.5  billion. By far, the biggest effect is the absence of the one-off payment from the gas from arbitration ruling last  year. This accounts for approximately €1 billion.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: In our Central South Eastern division, the operating result held by some €240 million. This is mainly due to the  deconsolidation of natural gas, which contributed to €151 million through earnings in H1 2013. Furthermore, the  significant earnings decline in our supply in Netherlands/Belgium division is especially driven by the weather  effect and a positive one-off in the previous year. Nevertheless, the general trend of declining earnings in our  conventional power generation division was mitigated in the second quarter of this year.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Last year, we had the addition to provision for impending losses from an electricity purchase contract. This was  not the case this year. For more details, on the individual value drivers, I would like to refer you to the backup  section and our interim report.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Let's have a closer look at our cash flow from operating activities on slide 13, which show a much different trend  than our earnings. While EBITDA is down by about €1.6 billion, cash flows have increased by over €9 billion. This  discrepancy is mainly due to three reasons. Firstly, our earnings and FFO in 2013 already reflected the  approximately €1 billion, one-off payment from the Gazprom arbitration ruling. This is not the case with our cash  flows from operating activities. While the FFO include this in Q2 2013, it is offset by the same amount in working  capital as the cash payment only came in Q3 2013. Secondly, the repayment of nuclear fuel tax of approximately  €0.5 billion. After the Hamburg Fiscal Court decided in April now favor, we will refund the tax that we had paid  for our Emsland nuclear power plant. This is only cash flow relevant as within our P&L. We have to build a  provision from the nuclear fuel tax until we have the final court decision on the legality of the tax. We received a  decision for our Gundremmingen power plant in our favor from the Fiscal Court in Munich at the end of July. So  this is not yet reflected in our cash flow statement. Thirdly, cash flows improved due to high advanced payments  in the retail business as a result of price adjustments.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Looking further at the difference between the development of FFO and change in working capital, besides the  effect from the Gazprom payment I just explained, we have a second significant effect from the switch to the new  CO2 compliance period in our accounts. Typically, the certificates for the previous year have to handed to the  relevant emission authority in April of the following year; i.e. in 2013, we submitted the certificates for 2012 and  in April of this year, the certificates for 2013. With a change to the new regulatory regime in 2013 and thereby the  full auctioning of certificates, the number of relevant certificates has increased substantially . In the cash flow  statement, it is reflected negatively in FFO due to the use of provisions. Nevertheless, working capital improved by  the same amount as CO2 inventories are also coming down.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Reasons for the lower expectation are the impairment of our Markinch project, and the low utilization of our  German run-of-river power stations in the first six months. With this, let me hand over to Stephan, to start the  Q&A part.

file: RWE - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 13August2015 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our net debt improved significantly to €25.6 billion, mainly due to the successful disposal of RWE Dea. In the  second quarter, we also finalized and inaugurated our two new offshore wind farms, Nordsee Ost and Gwynt y  Môr. Their contribution is one of the reasons why our renewables business almost likely doubled its operating  result this year.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We are continuing to expand our retail activities in Central and Eastern Europe. In June, we decided to enter the  Slovenian market. Initially, we were focused on electricity supply to households and target a market share of 10%  for 2020.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Poland and Hungary, where we have already established electricity supply businesses, we will start new retail  activities in the gas market. Here, the focus will initially be on industrial customers.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Over the past few weeks, policymakers in Germany and the UK have taken important decisions with regards to the  direction they want to take for energy policy. Let me elaborate in more detail on these decisions.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: At the beginning of July and after a series of intensive discussions, the German government abandoned the plans  of the Ministry of Economics to introduce a climate levy for all power plants. This levy would have had a massive  impact on our lignite operations, potentially leading to the shutdown of some 7-gigawatts out of our 10-gigawatts  and the associated open gas plants.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The new proposal is more in line with government's desire to avoid structural disruptions in the lignite industry. It  foresees the transfer of all the lignite plants with a combined capacity of 2.7 gigawatts into a strategic reserve and  the closure after four years in the reserve. It is envisaged that the operators receive payments to compensate for  the plant's availability. However, important details of the payment mechanism have still not been confirmed, so  that we cannot yet tell you which of our plants we will put into the reserve and what the net financial impact will  be. This will very much depend on the technical, economical and regulatory aspects, which will be determined  over the next few months. It is estimated that the strategic reserve will save some 12.5 million tons of CO2.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In addition to the shutdown of lignite plants, the government is targeting a faster expansion of CHP capacity, as  well as increased energy efficiency improvements to meet its 22 million tons of CO2 reduction target by 2020.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The second element of the proposed change in German energy policy regards to future energy market design. In  the white book the government confirmed early indications that it does not believe that a broad-based capacity  mechanism is the most effective way to maintain security of supply. Instead, it has opted for a revised competitive  energy market design. It proposes a number of adjustments to the energy-only market, which should improve the  price formation process on the wholesale market, and the ability to respond to energy supply intermitancy.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As with the strategic reserve, a lot of details are still missing so the assessment of the proposals is difficult.  However, we are skeptical whether this new energy-only market will be able to provide sufficient incentives to  retain our plant in the market or invest in new build capacity if it is required.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Finally, the government also outlined the further course of action with regards to nuclear liabilities. We welcome  the government's attempt to address the important questions regarding the management of nuclear liabilities. We  are aware of our responsibilities as operator and have made sufficient provisions to cover our future obligations in  respect to the nuclear decommissioning and final storage. RWE does not reject on principle the idea of a different  model to manage the nuclear liabilities, but it is imperative that the framework conditions of such resolution are  reached in agreement with the industry.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We are open to entering into a constructive dialogue with the government to find a safe and cost-efficient way to  carry out the nuclear exit. On 7 July, the UK Competition and Markets Authority published its provisional findings  report. We welcome the findings of the CMA, in particular that there is no evidence of excessive profits in the  generation business and uncompetitive behavior in the wholesale market. Vertical integration was not found to  have an adverse impact on competition.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Let me now come on to talk about something which is more within our control than political decisions on energy  policy. In the context of our ongoing efficiency-enhancement program, the supervisory board agreed on Monday  to change the legal and organizational structures of RWE and its subsidiaries. This is a consequence of organizing  our operations around the value chain over the last two years, and also follows our management approach. It  allows us to become leaner and more efficient in running our business.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In the course of this change, we also decided to streamline our steering model and aligned RWE AG executive  board more closely to the operating business. Chief operating officers for the future oversee conventional  generation, retail, grid and renewables. This will allow us to take decisions quicker, a prerequisite to be able to  face the challenges of the ever-changing market environment. The appointment of the new COOs will be  announced once it has been decided by the supervisory board.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: On the positive side, our retail business units benefited from normalized weather conditions. And in our  renewables business, we are now reaping the benefits of our investments of the past years. The operating result of  our energy nearly tripled to €233 million.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: On slide 13 we give you the development of our cash flow. It comes down by €1.3 billion to €0.7 billion. As  explained during our Q1 2015 conference call, this is mainly the result of a revised purchasing policy for required  CO2 emission certificates. This had a corresponding positive effect on our cash flow in 2014. Furthermore, we  have an increase in accounts receivable in our supply division, which is due to the weather affect. Again, this had a  positive counter effect in 2014.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: The UK retail market is one of the most competitive markets that RWE operates in across Europe, and this is seen  by the rapid growth of small suppliers and the increased switching between tariffs, all indicating that customers  are very engaged in selecting their energy needs. It should also be noted that in the current political framework,  we don't have a level playing field as small competitors don't have to bear the significant burdens from  government energy programs. Hence, most of the lost customers have signed contracts with the new players. This  is of course a very disappointing situation for RWE UK retail business, but we are confident that we have initiated  the right measures to turn the operation or our domestic business around, and that we will be able to return to  clearly improved returns in 2017. This assumes no further burdens from the CMA investigation.

file: RWE - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 11August2016 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: One of the reasons for the difficult environment I mentioned is the political uncertainty around financing the  nuclear exit. In this respect, the nuclear commission, which was formed by the German Government, presented  its recommendations at the end of April.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On a positive note, we were able to come to an agreement with Gazprom on our long-term gas procurement  contract. At the end of May, we agreed upon an amendment of the conditions for the contract. As a result, there's  no price risk from this contract in the coming years.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Conventional Power Generation, in particular, shows a different picture compared to our full-year outlook. We  have an increase of €100 million in H1 2016, which is partly driven by positive one-offs from the sale of real estate  in the UK. We still expect earnings to come down significantly for the full year. One reason is that higher  maintenance cost will especially hit the second half of the year. Another is that the positive effect from the lower  nuclear fuel tax has already had nearly its full impact in H1.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In contrast, Trading/Gas Midstream showed a very weak development in the second quarter. Once again, this  shows the natural volatility of the business. While Q4 2015 and Q1 2016 had in total significant positive earnings,  we have a similar negative amount in Q2 2016. On average, we still expect to be able to achieve an underlying  annual earnings contribution of approximately €200 million to €250 million. This year, we'll be, of course,  significantly below this level.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: These are the sale of real estate in Conventional Power Generation and the sale of grid assets in the division  Grids/Participations/Other. In addition, we expect higher costs, for example, due to more maintenance activities  for our power plants and for maintaining and operating our Group infrastructure, which will impact our earnings  mainly in the rest of fiscal 2016.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On slide nine, you will find our divisional outlook. Since our last outlook update in May, we are now adjusting the  outlook for two divisions. First, for Trading/Gas Midstream, down to significantly below 2015 from significantly  above. We don't expect to fully offset the weak trading performance of Q2 in the rest of the year.

file: RWE - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 14August2017 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Thank you, Gunhild, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. We had a good start to the fiscal year after the  reorganization of RWE. This not only relates to our operating business, but also in particular to the positive  developments that have occurred in the field of our nuclear power business.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Based on the H1 results and our account expectations for the rest of the year, we can improve the outlook for the  European Power division. For the group's KPIs, we can confirm the outlook for the year as a whole and expect to  achieve a result at the upper end of our guidance.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: On June 7, the German Constitutional Court published its decision that the nuclear fuel tax was not compliant with  the provisions of the German constitutional law and declared it null and void retroactively. We have already  received the refund for the [ph] paid (02:38) tax of approximately €1.7 billion and expect another approximately  €250 million of interest by year-end. With regards to our 2017 income tax, we expect an effect of around €200  million.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In the context of nuclear energy, we can also report the successful conclusion to the restructuring of  responsibilities for nuclear waste disposal. On June 16, the new law entered into force, according to which the  government is now in charge of the handling and financing of the interim and final storage of nuclear waste. On  July 3, we transferred the relevant funds to the government. For RWE, this was €7 billion including E.ON's  minority stake in our Emsland Nuclear Plant. The economic stake for us was €6.8 billion.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: What is important in this context is the fact that we concluded the public contract with the German government.  This contract provides us with a higher level of legal certainty related to the release from the liability and also  establishes the conditions for transferring the radioactive waste to the federal authorities. Furthermore, it forms  the basis for ending numerous legal disputes involving nuclear energy-related issues between the utilities and the  government.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The only major outstanding topic in the context of nuclear energy is the settlement around the constitutional claim  to shorten the operational life span of German nuclear power plants. In this context, the Federal Constitutional  Court decided in December last year that some aspects were unconstitutional and that the utilities were entitled to  compensation for damages. This refers to generation volumes, which cannot be used as well as the loss in value  of investments which the plant operator had made on the basis of the lifetime extension set out by law in 2010.  The legislator was given until mid-2018 to formulate suitable regulations for this compensation. We estimate that  our claim will amount to a low triple-digit million euro amount. That's it on the nuclear topics.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 5 provides the detail of the performance of the Lignite & Nuclear division in H1 and the outlook for this  division for the full year. Adjusted EBITDA has come down mainly due to declining realized generation margin.  This was partly offset by the phase out of the nuclear fuel tax in 2016. Last year, we had a burn of approximately  €100 million from the tax in the first half of the year.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: This brings me to our current hedge positions on slide 7. Compared to our situation at the end of March, we  almost closed implicit fuel hedged for 2018 and reduced it slightly for 2019 and 2020. Our hedge prices for 2019  and 2020 have improved by €1 per megawatt/hour compared to the end of March. As a result of our implicit fuel  hedge strategy, we could benefit from the improvement of the fuel spreads, which you can see on page 8.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The financial results we have adjusted for the effects from the changes in discount rates for nuclear and other  long-term provisions as well as the interest component on the nuclear fuel tax. In the non-controlling interest  position we adjusted for the effect of the write-on on our Mátra participation, taxes were adjusted accordingly.  Details of the reconciliation can be found in the appendix on slide 15.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: With regard to the change in provisions and other noncash items, I would like to point to the timing effects of CO2  provisions mentioned on the slide. With the transfer of the CO2 certificates to the national clearing authorities in  Q2, we have completed this year's utilization of provisions whereas the additions are only halfway through the  year. For the year as a whole, we can confirm our expectation for the change in provisions in the order of €650  million as we have guided previously.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The details of net debt are shown on slide on 12. At the end of June, it stood at €4.3 billion for RWE stand-alone,  approximately €2.6 billion below the end of fiscal year 2016. There are three main drivers. First, the positive  distributable cash flow. Second, the refund of the nuclear fuel tax of €1.7 billion. And thirdly, a positive effect from  a reduction in provisions mainly pension provisions, which accounted for an improvement of €450 million. One  reason is that the discount rate for our German pension provision increased from 1.7% to 1.9%. Furthermore,  pension assets performed well and thus contributed to a decline in pension provisions.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: On slide 13, you can see the details of our outlook for RWE standalone 2017. I have already explained the  reasons why we are much more optimistic for our European Power division and have upgraded the expectation to  significantly above previous year. However, our earnings expectations for the Lignite & Nuclear division have  slightly deteriorated compared to Q1 for the reason which I explained earlier.

file: RWE - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 14August2018 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Further, innogy will support the preparation of the transfer of innogy's renewables business to RWE. In this  context, it will also be reviewed how the transfer of renewables businesses can be implemented as soon as  possible after the transfer of RWE's stake in innogy to E.ON. All in all, the agreement is an important step, and it  should give additional impetus to the execution of the transaction.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: At the beginning of June, the German government nominated the members of the Commission Growth, Structural  Change and Employment. The Commission is tasked to identify measures which will close the gap to the 2020  climate goal as quickly as possible and ensure the achievement of the 2030 CO2 reduction targets. In addition to  the environmental targets, the Commission should also take into consideration security of supply, affordability, as  well as social aspects and the avoidance of structural disruptions.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In addition, the Commission shall develop a plan for the phase out of coal-based power generation, detailing the  necessary companion law, economic, social and structural measures. The Commission held its first meeting on  June 23 and is expected to present first proposals by the end of this year. We hope and expect that the  Commission will deal with the complex topics based on factual expertise and reach a consensus which will also  provide planning certainty for the companies involved. The timeline, however, where results are expected by the  end of the year looks very ambitious.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me also remind you of our long-term carbon position which we have financially hedged through to the end of  2022. In other words, the change in carbon prices should not affect our generation margins for the next five years.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In anticipation of your questions, I can confirm that we have also already taken measures on our open carbon  position for post 2022, but please understand that we will not provide any details on our position due to the  sensitive nature of this information.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: On page 8, you can see the development of fuel spreads until the end of June 2018 which are relevant for our  hedge prices you saw in the previous slide. The graph looks slightly different to the previous one as we instead of  average monthly figures we now show end of month data to bring the graph in line with our hedge prices on the  previous slide. Fuel spreads continued their Q1 decline in April and May before starting to recover strongly at the  end of June.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let's move to the Supply & Trading division on slide 9. We saw a good trading performance which was driven by  a very strong second quarter. While our gas and LNG business posted a good performance, it lagged behind the  very high result of last year. Besides that, we had a negative effect from a value adjustment within our principal  investment portfolio. For the full year, we confirm our earnings expectations for this division of between €100  million and €300 million.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: With regards to the change in provisions and other non-cash items, I would like to point to the timing effect of CO2  provisions mentioned on the slide. With the transfer of the CO2 certificate to the national clearing authorities in  Q2, we have completed this year's utilization of provisions whereas additions are only halfway through the year.  For the year as a whole, we expect to be in line with our initial guidance of roughly €650 million.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: innogy's continuing activities, which are the renewables business, gas storage activities, and Kelag are expected  to contribute an adjusted EBITDA of between €700 million and €800 million compared to €785 million in 2017.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: We see CapEx for the continuing operations of RWE to amount to €1.2 billion to €1.4 billion. We are stating gross  CapEx here, so before proceeds from disposals or farm-downs. Out of this, approximately €0.8 billion to €1 billion  is attributable to innogy's continuing activities and will be mainly spent on growth projects into renewables  business.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In conventional power generation, we still expect CapEx of approximately €400 million predominantly for  maintenance and modernization purposes. Furthermore, it includes more growth projects, for example the  conversion to biomass co-firing in the Netherlands. RWE Group net debt from continuing operations is expected  to be moderately below the level as at June 30, 2018, of €5.4 billion.

texts.speaker: Gunhild Grieve
texts.profession: Head of Investor Relations, RWE AG
texts.text: Thank you, Markus. Before we start the Q&A session, we just wanted to draw your attention to a slide deck we  have put together on the pro forma combined renewables business. You can find it on our IR website, and we  hope that this is going to answer the many questions we have received over the last few weeks.

file: RWE - Q3 2010 Earnings Call 11November2010 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Nov-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Dr. Rolf Pohlig, Chief Financial Officer  Thank you, Stephan, and good afternoon to everyone. The title of our presentation gives you the  topic for today. We are discussing with you the first nine months of 2010 and the update to the  outlook for the full fiscal year. We know that due to the introduction of the nuclear fuel tax, a lot of  questions are still outstanding with regard to our future strategy. But as every year, we are currently  working on our strategy update. This will last into December. And as always you will get the full  strategy update in February at our full year analyst conference.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: At the end of September, the German government decided on a comprehensive energy concept  providing the framework for the energy strategy until 2015. Nuclear energy is considered to be a  bridge technology until renewable energy is able to provide the bulk of the acquired electric power.  As part of this concept, nuclear power plants should be granted to an extension of the lifetime of 12  years on average. This was approved by the lower house of parliament on October 28th.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Also in October the lower house decided to introduce a nuclear fuel tax. As you are familiar with the  general framework around the tax, we expect RWE to face an average annual burden between  €600 million and €700 million with regard to its operating result and approximately 400 million to  500 million as regards recurrent net income.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In addition we founded RWE East located in Prague. It will be responsible for our Central Eastern  and South Eastern activities with the exception of the gas transmission business. These  organizational measures will become effective as of January 1st next year. In line with these new  organization measures we downsized the number of Board seats to five as Ulrich Jobs left the  company at the end of September.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now on to our division performance starting with RWE Power. Its operating result improved by  17%. Slide five gives you the individual value drivers. We expect the positive trend at RWE Power  to continue beyond the rest of 2010. A higher availability of our Biblis nuclear power plant and lower  fuel prices and costs for CO2 emission certificate will be the main reasons for this.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The sales business benefited from efficiency measures and slightly improved gas margins. We  expect the operating result to be up for 2010 as a whole. This will be mainly due to improved  earnings in the gas sales business above all because of the absence of one-off cost caused by the  negative gas to oil spreads incurred last year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now on to our new Netherlands/Belgium division. The numbers for 2010 are substantially effected  by consolidation effects. I commented on the major items in the first quarter presentation. The  performance of the Netherlands/Belgium division was supported by higher gas sales due to the  cold winter weather and stable customer account numbers. On a standalone basis, we had an  operating loss in the third quarter for two main reasons. Firstly, the seasonality that is typical  especially in the gas business, and secondly we transferred the Eemshaven power plant project  from RWE Power to Essent. The accumulated upfront cost of approximately €25 million are now  reflected in this division.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let me continue with RWE npower. It’s operating results fell by 24% adjusted for Forex effect it  came down by 26%. The decline is mainly linked our generation business, the adverse market       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 3 condition for hard coke plants led to reduced earnings. This could only partly be offset by higher  production volumes of our gas pipelines and by lower maintenance cost. Addition, the third quarter  on its own looks weak compared to 2009 has some other things, we had some positive one-off  items last year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In our retail business, we benefited from improved residential gas demand over the winter months  and slightly recovered gas margins on the back of lower commodity cost. This was partly offset and  reduced our gas tariffs at the end of March this year. In addition, we have seen lower electricity  margins following our tariff cuts in March last year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the generation business, we expect that lower spreads will also influence the performance for  2010 as a whole. But we are more optimistic for the fourth quarter based on the contracts we have  already locked in. The lower spreads will be partially offset by the progressive commissioning of the  four power plant units at Staythorpe during the second half of this year. In addition, we expect to  see a reduction in station maintenance costs.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Although the aforementioned tariff reductions our retail business are putting pressure on margins  we expect negative effects from high electricity network fees, retail margins are likely to benefit  from slightly lower commodity costs. However, the British market continues to be very challenging  due to the continued increases in commodity prices over last month, which have already led to  price increases in the market.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our focus will remain on efficiencies in order to ensure competitive cost base. The €120 million  efficiency program initiated last year will be turned into a sustainable improvement and we are  working on additional efficiency measures in generation, retail and corporate functions. For the  years ahead, we anticipate a slight increase in RWE npower’s operating result.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Operating earnings at our Central Eastern and South Eastern Europe Division climbed by 29%  supported by positive Forex effects. Adjusted for Forex effects, division posted an increase of 24%.  Major factor was improved margins in our Czech gas sales business especially since the last  quarter of last year. On the other hand, we suffered from declining volumes of distributors.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In addition, we had a positive contribution above all from improved electricity sales margins in  Hungary and Poland. We anticipate that earnings generated by this division will be in the order of  last year supported by a positive Forex effect. The main reason for the slowdown of earnings  growth in Q4 is that margins in our Czech gas sales business as well as in the Hungarian electricity  sales and generation business are expected to come down again. In addition, there will be burdens  from the new energy tax in Hungary. On the other hand, we will see higher earnings contributions  from our Czech regional gas grid business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The operating result of our renewables division fell short of last year by 33%. Upfront costs for our  large investment program are still dampening the development of Innogy’s operating result. In  addition, earnings went down due to lower realized electricity prices in Germany and less wind in  Germany, UK and the Netherlands.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In contrast, the first time consolidation of the Essent wind assets contributed €10 million to  earnings. We explained in our earlier calls that this is less than originally expected due to the very  weak wind production caused by the weather.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As regards to 2010, we expect RWE Innogy to record higher operating earnings. We would see  further results of our growth investment program. But upfront costs for our projects are still  offsetting most of this. In addition, Innogy will benefit from the first time consolidation of Essent’s  wind activities, but due to the low wind volumes in northwestern Europe, the earning increase will  be smaller than originally expected.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 4 Upstream gas and oil reported a 52% increase in operating earnings. This is mainly a result of  higher oil prices, the stronger U.S. dollar as well as reduced exploration costs in North Africa. In  addition, we benefited from lower royalties in the German business. On the other hand, they have  suffered from reduced gas prices and lower production volumes. Compared to the weak 2009 we  see significant upside potential for 2010. RWE expects to see improved oil prices from the back of  a stronger U.S. dollar. This will be partly offset by lower gas prices and volumes as well as  increasing production costs.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The operating result in our trading/gas midstream division fell by 91%. The mark-to-market  performance of the trading business fell below the very high level of the first three quarters last  year. On the other hand, we benefited from the first time consolidation of the Essent trading  activities. They contributed €61 million in the first nine month of 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The steep decline is mainly related to our gas supply activities, this is because of two major items.  First in 2009, we had successfully concluded price revisions and had to a release provisions  accordingly as a one-off item. Secondly, prices on the gas market dropped relative to oil-indexed  purchase contracts. This primarily effects our Czech gas portfolio due to growing competition. As a  result, we built a provision for onerous contract.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In 2010, we expect the division to close significantly below last year’s record level despite the  positive effect from the integration of the Essent’s trading activities. Lower trading margins  compared to the extraordinary high level in 2009, the absence of the aforementioned one-off items  recognized in 2009 as well as a provision for our Czech gas portfolio are the main reasons for this  decline.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Ladies and Gentlemen before I continue with the non-operating result, I would like to say few words  about the gas-to-oil spread exposure. We recognized on our recent trade shows that the market still  needs some more clarification. This chart, chart number 14 from our analyst conference in  February.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: There is additional slide on our backups on page 27, which provides some more information on the  recent gas-to-oil price development. The facts in brief are, we have a total annual gas purchase  portfolio of 50 bcm or about 500 terawatt hours. Approximately 27 bcm of this are covered by long- term oil-indexed purchase contracts, which however include different types of price revision  clauses. In 2010, we have approximately 11 bcm in oil-indexed sales contracts so that as a result, I  guess the oil spread exposure is approximately 16 bcm or 160 terawatt hours.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: This exposure is expected to grow to approximately 20 bcm due to the fact that more and more  sales contracts are renewed at market price levels. We are currently in negotiations with all our gas  suppliers. As a result, we expect this exposure to decline significantly again over the next two to  three years.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As a result, the operating income of RWE Supply & Trading over the next couple of years will be  heavily influenced by the timing and the final outcome of negotiations with our gas suppliers. Now  please understand that we cannot disclose details of the negotiations while talks are ongoing.

file: RWE - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 10November2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Nov-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
