texts.text: The renegotiation of our oil-indexed long-term gas contracts, as well as the arbitration processes have developed  slightly better than our conservative plan builds in terms of timing and structural solution. We've got the first  positive news here as we made progress over the last few months in our negotiations with three major oil and gas  suppliers. These contracts are now indexed to traded gas wholesale prices or terminated early their mutual  consent that has the same economic effect, which is the removal of the gas to oil spread risk. We also  retrospectively set up contracts on a commercial basis, which is in one case still subject to the approval of the  Board of our contractual partner. With all other gas suppliers, we are in different stages of negotiation, parallel to  the ongoing legal proceedings. And we can also confirm that these discussions are on course for long-term  structural solutions. This makes us confident that our strategy is right. We are sure you will understand that we  cannot be more specific at this point in time as we are in difficult legal renegotiation processes with high values at  stake.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Finally, you are all aware of the negative impact from the new German Energy Policy. One particular instrument is  the nuclear fuel tax introduced with effect from January 1 this year. We filed a lawsuit regarding the payment of  the nuclear tax for our Gundremmingen B power plant at the Tax Court in Munich. We have serious doubts  concerning legality of the law imposing the nuclear fuel tax.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: The Tax Court in Munich passed a temporary injunction in favor of RWE on this question. The Munich Tax Court  has been the second after the Hamburg Tax Court to rule in favor of a nuclear power plant operator in this matter.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: The Munich decision led to a refund of €74 million. For the nuclear power plant at Emsland a nuclear fuel tax of  154 million was paid. We expect that this amount will also be refunded. The Hamburg Tax Court, which will be  responsible for Emsland, has already decided in favor of the operator of the nuclear power plant at  Grafenrheinfeld. Despite the first positive signals, it is however only the first step in a potentially very long legal  process. We therefore have to book refunds as tax liabilities.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: However, these positive effects are contrasted by additional burdens from provisions for restructuring measures,  from asset impairment at Essent power plants in H1 and from asset impairments on gas storage activities. The  financial result improved by 5%, mainly driven by the release of provisions and lower interest accretion to  additions to non-current provisions.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: As a result of the reduction of our operating results, net income decreased by 46% to €1.4 billion. Our recurrent  net income, which is adjusted for the non-recurrent items, decreased by 44% to €1.8 billion. The operating result  of the Group amounted to €4.3 billion, which is €1.9 billion below the comparable figure last year. This chart  number five gives you an overview of the development of the operating result by division. The new German  Energy Policy leaves its mark on the German Power Generation division with a reduction of the nuclear lifetime,  the implementation of the nuclear fuel tax and earlier closure of our nuclear power plants at Biblis.  In the period under review, we had about €1 billion of burdens from the new German Energy Policy, out of which  €0.2 billion relates to the nuclear fuel tax. In addition, the Power Generation division suffered from lower realized  spreads. These factors taken together lead to a decrease in operating result of 38% in the division.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: The second negative factor is the development in our Trading/Gas Midstream division. The division is particularly  hit by the impact of the negative gas-to-oil-spread. In addition, the performance of the Trading business has been  much weaker than usual.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Earnings at our German Sales and Distribution Networks division fell by 7%. The main driver here are higher  costs for improving the quality of our grid business. Our Dutch business, Essent, cannot repeat the excellent  results from last year, mainly due to the transfer of gas midstream activities to our Trading/Gas Midstream  division. Weather conditions were also less favorable than last year.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Our Central Eastern and South Eastern European division reports a reduction in operating performance of 4%,  resulting from decreasing Czech grid margins, decreasing Czech gas sales and from burdens from Hungarian  regulation. Our renewables business benefited strongly from higher revenues, from newly commissioned assets, in  total approximately 90 megawatts since October last year, better wind conditions and liquidated damages from  our joint venture in the wind offshore project, Greater Gabbard.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Our Upstream business almost doubled its operating result to €450 million. Increased gas and oil prices and  higher oil production are the main drivers. As usual, we explain individual value drivers and the full-year outlook  for the separate business divisions in more detail in the charts in the back-up section. These should be self  explanatory.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: I will now move on to the outlook of the Group. In August we updated our guidance for 2011 following the decision  to exit from nuclear in Germany and increased our 2013 outlook slightly due to higher expected earnings on the  back of our increased efficiency program and improved commodity prices and spreads.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: In fourth quarter, we expect the performance of the operating result to be slightly better than the EBITDA. The  reason is that we had in Q4 last year an extraordinarily high depreciation that we don't expect to repeat in Q4 this  year. We particularly expect an improvement for recurrent net income. This is mainly a result for better financial  result, which was disproportionately negative in Q4 last year. In the fourth quarter last year, we booked a  provision to compensate for financing cost from the non-interest-bearing prepayments to the renewables fund  and a high negative other financial result.

texts.speaker: Stephan Lowis
texts.profession: Thank you, Rolf. Before we start with the Q&A session I would like to take the opportunity to welcome a new team
texts.text: member at our IR team, Vera Bücker. She will replace Lars Korinth who is moving on. Let me say thank you to  Lars for his excellent and hard work over the last five years. We wish him all the best for the future. Just for Vera  just to let you know she was working – she is working now 10 year with RWE in several functions among others  corporate responsibility and at RWE Power, climate protection roof and with this now its your turn but let me  remind you to our famous two questions only rule and operator please open up the Q&A session.

file: RWE - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 14November2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Nov-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: It's a pleasure for me to provide you with the highlights of the first nine months of 2012. We have some good news  to report on although the environment overall remains challenging. First, with regard to the financial  performance, the numbers speak for themselves. EBITDA and operating result improved by 8%, recurrent net  income increased only slightly less with plus 6%.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Now, back to the current highlights of 2012. One of our major issues for RWE is how we will solve the outstanding  price revisions of our long-term gas contracts. We are still in negotiation and arbitration with two suppliers with a  combined contract volume of approximately 11 BCM per annum.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Besides the major discussions we have about the oil indexation for our gas supply contracts, we had one additional  dispute about whether we were allowed to reduce the minimum off-take volumes within our Gazprom contract  under certain conditions. Gazprom challenged our reduction rights in front of an arbitration tribunal and  requested payment for the full contractual minimum off-take volumes for the years 2008 to 2010.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: All in all, the development of the first nine months makes us even more optimistic for our guidance for the full  year. We now expect EBITDA and the operating result at least to match last year's level, the main reason is an  improved outlook for our gas supply activities within the Trading/Gas Midstream division and the positive  earnings trend in our German Generation business unit.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Let's now have a look at our key numbers for the first nine months of 2012 on page number four. Our EBITDA and  operating result both increased by 8%. A major contributor was the absence of one-off burdens experienced in the  first nine months of 2011 due to Germany's accelerated nuclear phase-out decision. In addition, we benefited from  a strongly improved performance by our energy trading business.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Furthermore, the 2011 result benefited from the release of a provision made in relation to a German renewable  fund which ceased to exist following the nuclear phase-out decision.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Turning to page number five, let me now briefly explain the major developments within our operating result. The  operating result of our Power Generation division in Germany advanced by 14%. Major contributors were the  already mentioned extraordinary burdens in the first nine months of 2011 from the new German energy policy  with the nuclear phase-out.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: A positive contribution resulted from the successful trial run and the commercial operation of our new lignite  plant, BoA 2&3 at Neurath. However, we suffered from lower realized power prices and spreads.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Earnings at our German Sales and Distribution Networks business unit fell by 4% due to lower electricity sales  margins and a decline in the income from investments. Essent result fell by 26% despite the start of commercial  operation of our new CCGT's Claus C and Moerdijk 2. Clean spark spreads are particularly weak at the moment,  partly as a result of Germany's continued expansion of photovoltaic capacity.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: In addition, the outage of our converted biomass plant at Tilbury due to the fire in a bunker led to lower output  compared to last year when the plant was still firing hot coal. Meanwhile, the plant is back in operation. Efficiency  enhancement measures, higher gas sales volumes and improved commodity cost management had a positive  impact on the UK supply business.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Our renewables business showed a weak third quarter and closed the first nine months 12% below last year's  number. Compensation payments received in 2011 for delays in the construction of Greater Gabbard did not

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Our Upstream business increased its operating result by 25%. Higher gas and oil prices and the appreciation of  the U.S. dollar over the euro were the main drivers.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: The Trading/Gas Midstream division closed the first nine months with an operating loss of approximately €400  million. This is a significant improvement compared to last year. The performance of the proprietary trading  business has improved considerably while the burdens from the negative gas-to-oil spread continued.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: At the peak of our renewable program, we have invested about €600 billion per year, a level which has never been  envisaged as sustainable in the long run. We have therefore announced that we will reduce our CapEx to about €4

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide nine gives you our divisional outlook for the whole year. We have changed the outlook for the Trading/Gas  Midstream division to significantly above last year's level from – in the order of last year's lever. This is mainly a  result of an improved expectation for our Gas Midstream activities.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: A further adjustment has been made to the outlook of our Renewables division. We now expect RWE Energy to  achieve an operating result in the order of last year's level. The main reason for this reduced outlook are delays in  the disposal of projects.

file: RWE - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 14November2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Y es. Thank you, Stephan, and also good afternoon to everyone from my side. When I presented our strategy  update in March, the outlook for our generation business was not exactly encouraging on the back of depressed  commodity prices. Since then, power prices have moved even lower and put further pressure on the business. We  have made no secret about the precarious situation many of our power plants find themselves in. Therefore, we  provided you with an overview of the profitability of our fleet.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: But what does this actually mean for the overall earnings of our generation business? We want to refrain from  providing you with an outlook for any specific year as a lot can happen and we would not wa nt to constantly revise  it until then. However, on slide three, you can see how the generation business would have fared in 2013 under  current forward prices. It probably will not surprise you that the business would not show a positive operating  result without any efficiency improvements. For now, we are still benefiting from higher power price hedges.  However, they are rolling off over the next three years.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Generation business is therefore working very hard on measures to ensure it still can provide a po sitive earnings  contribution. Nevertheless, the GenCo will still be far off from earning its capital costs. And if power prices were to  stay at today's level, we will need to shut further power plants even if they were needed at certain times of the year.  We are running our assets purely on commercial grounds regardless of expectations on any kind of future political  support.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: First, we have identified further efficiency enhancement potential in the years to come. In addition to the €1  billion already underway until 2014, we are already working on another net €500 million of efficiency  improvements by 2017. The latter will provide financial headroom of some €1.5 billion. Second, we have decided  to drive our CapEx down, down to maintenance levels, for the time being. This will save another €2 billion in cash.  And third, the envisaged disposal of RWE Dea and Urenco will contribute to some extent to a reduction in debt.  However, the amount will depend on the achieved sales price.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Now let's focus on the combined €1.5 billion for now. A big part of the efficiency enhancements will come from  planned head count reductions. As part of the old program 2012 to 2014, we had announced staff reductions in  the magnitude of 3,700. Out of this, approximately 1,000 were already achieved early in 2012. So another 2,700 to  come between 2013 and 2014.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Finally, we are continuing to look for further small optimization potential in our portfolio. At REW Innogy, we see  opportunities to streamline activities even more towards the most cost effective renewable technologies. We are,  for example, targeting the sale of the offshore logistics activities bundled under the company of OLC.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Thank you, Peter, and good afternoon from me as well. Let me give you a brief overview of the business  performance in the first nine months of 2013 on page 11. Our operating result was on a par with previous year's  earnings. We have two main counteracting efforts. On the one hand, our trading/gas midstream division achieved  an extraordinary high result due to the arbitration court ruling on our long-term oil-indexed gas contract with  Gazprom.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: On the other hand, we are suffering a massive earnings decline in our conventional power generation division.  Besides the burdens of full auctioning of carbon certificates, declining generation margins and the loss of margin s  from closing our old lignite plants, we suffered among other things from a one -off burden to adjust a provision for  loss-making contract.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: In addition, earnings in our upstream gas and oil division are under pressure due to lower realized oil and gas  prices and burdens from dry wells as well as delays in ramping up our production. The earnings trend in the first  nine months does not reflect the earnings trend that we are expecting for the full year. While the positive earnings  effect from the Gazprom arbitration ruling is fully locked in, the negative earnings development is continuing  especially in the conventional power generation division.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: In addition, we had in Q3 mainly a write-down of our offshore wind farm project Nordsee Ost of some €0.3 billion  and a value adjustment on our German gas storage activities of some €0.2 billion.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me briefly touch upon our cash flow statement on slide 13. The cash flow from operating activities shows a  strong increase of €1.8 billion driven by the one-off from the Gazprom arbitration ruling. As opposed to the  development of our operating result, the earnings declined due to the full auctioning of carbon certificates is only  partly reflected in the cash flow.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Looking at our divisional outlook on slide 15, we confirm our expectations from August 2013 with the exception of  upstream gas and oil. Here we have adjusted our outlook down to significantly below last year's level from below  last year's level. The main reason is that due to delays and infrastructure -related production restrictions, we are  not able to produce as much gas from our UK gas fields Clipper South and Breagh as originally planned. In  addition higher than originally expected exploration costs impact on the result.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 16 gives an overview about the main value drivers and their impact for the earnings in fiscal 2014 compared  to 2013 from today's point of view. There are two main reasons for a further decline of the operating result. First,  the absence of the one-off payment from the Gazprom arbitration ruling. Second, the rolling off of our hedges in  the conventional power generation business compared to the current much lower market prices.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Our ambitious and increased efficiency program will only compensate part of this. We expect in general a stable  trend for our grid and sales margins. Furthermore earnings in 2013 still included €17 1 million from NET4GAS,  which was sold beginning of August as I mentioned earlier.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: For Innogy and Dea we had mid-term target for 2014 of more than €320 million and €800 million outstanding.  For Innogy we now expect an operating result of approximately €200 million. Innogy's operating result will be  negatively impacted by project delays in Nordsee Ost and Gwynt y Môr as well as adverse developments of  wholesale power prices and prices for green certificates, mainly in Poland.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: RWE Dea is still targeting to grow the production volumes of their hydrocarbons to approximately 40 million BOE  from a level of approximately 32 million BOE in 2012.

file: RWE - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 13November2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: This has no impact on our guidance for recurrent net income because we will include the pro rata interest on the  purchase price in the recurrent net income with the full year numbers. Please understand that we cannot be more  specific on the Dea transaction at this point in time. For the UK capacity market, National Grid announced in the  middle of October which power plants have qualified for the upcoming offering process. RWE has qualified with a  total capacity of 8-gigawatt. A list of the individual plans is provided in our backup section on page 13. The first  auction will take place in December this year and refers to the period from1st of October 2018 to September 30  [indiscernible] (2:11). You'll find more details on the process in our interim report. All in all, the UK's decision to  implement a capacity market is the right step in securing sufficient generation capacity at any given time and to  make conventional power generation economically viable again. But it is currently too early to make specific  forecast about earnings implications.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: So what is the current status of the discussion in Germany about the capacity mechanism? It is still open whether  the German government wants to go for a reformed energy-only market or a capacity market and what the  potential capacity market could or should look like.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: The timeline of the Economy Minister has the following milestone. At the end of October, his ministry published a  Green Book. It simply outlines the different alternatives and gives an indication of what the ministry is inclined  towards the present. The tendency is towards a reformed energy-only market in combination with a strategic  reserve. The Green Book will be the basis for the discussion in the cabinet at the beginning of December. It will be  followed by a White Book which is scheduled for spring time next year and which will give more clarity on the  detailed plans of the government. A further timeline is that a new law could be in place by spring or summer of  2016.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: After this brief excursion back to our milestones. At energy, we have taken a further step in line with our asset- light strategy to grow the business and exploit our project pipeline. At the beginning of September, we sold 85% in  the offshore wind projects Nordsee One, 2 and 3 to Northland Power. As part of this strategy, we are able to work  on large-scale projects without having to dedicate huge amounts of our funds to these projects. Furthermore, as  part of our renewable strategy to concentrate on coal activities, we have sold our 80% stake in the Enna biomass  project to FRI-EL Green Power. Energy will focus in future on an electricity generation from wind and hydro.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Slide 5 shows the earnings development in the individual divisions. All in all, we see an expected decline of  approximately €1.3 billion. By far, the biggest effect is the absence of the one-off payment from the Gazprom  arbitration ruling last year. This accounts for approximately €1 billion. In our CEE/SEE division, the operating  results fell by approximately €300 million. This is, to a large extent, due to the deconsolidation of natural gas,  which contributed €171 million through earnings in 2013. Furthermore, we are suffering from the deterioration of  realized market spreads in the conventional power generation business, and negative weather effects, mainly in  our supply businesses. This can only partly be offset by our efficiency improvements.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Firstly, we received a repayment of nuclear fuel tax of approximately €0.5 billion. After the Hamburg Fiscal Court  decided in April in our favor, we will refund the tax that we had paid for Emsland nuclear power plant. This is only  cash flow relevant as within our P&L, we have to build a provision for the nuclear fuel tax until we have the final  court decision on the legality of the tax.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: We received a decision for our Gundremmingen power plant in our favor from the Fiscal Court in Munich at the  end of July. But we have not yet received the payment as we are still in discussion with the authorities on how to  provide credentials or guarantees. As a result, there is not yet a positive impact on our cash flow.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Where do we stand regarding the main cases of the nuclear fuel tax? We still expect a decision either by the  European Court of Justice or by the Federal Constitutional Court some time in 2015. There was a hearing at the  European Court of Justice on the 4th of November, which still leaves the final decision absolutely open. The next  milestone will be the conclusion by the Advocate General which is scheduled for the 3rd of February 2015. But  please bear in mind, this will not be a decision and the conclusion from the Advocate General is not binding for  the European Court of Justice. So that's all on this topic, and back to our cash flow comments.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: The second reason for the different trend between cash flow and earnings is higher advance payments and the fact  that the mild weather led to a lower increase in our accounts receivable. In other words, while the mild weather is  already reflected in revenues, it's not yet to the same amount in the cash flow. As you can see from the slide, these  effects led to a significant positive free cash flow. Let me remind you that one of our prime targets is to become  free cash flow positive post CapEx and dividends from 2015 onwards.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Second, the trading/gas midstream division had quite a negative earnings development in Q4 2013, which we do  not expect this year. Third, although we have lowered the outlook for the supply UK division, we still expect the  fourth quarter of 2014 to improve compared to the fourth quarter of 2013. This is mainly driven by the phasing  effect on the ECO program and [ph] the crystallization (10:32) of our operational efficiency metrics.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Slide 9 gives the divisional outlook. The trend of the individual divisions we gave in August can be confirmed with  one exception. For oil supply UK division, we now expect earnings to be significantly below 2013. The weak  earnings development in the first nine months cannot be offset by the expected strong fourth quarter.

file: RWE - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 12November2015 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: First, let me give you an update on the most-important points regarding the discussion around nuclear abilities.  As you know, the whole debate on nuclear ability is split into a three phases. The first phase concluded with a  publication of the results of the so-called stress test on October 10. The most-important result is that the nuclear  provisions fully reflect future obligations and are more than sufficient compared to other European countries.  Although, this result has not been a surprise and has been communicated many times, it was seen as very positive  by the capital market.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Furthermore, it provides a solid foundation for the second phase of the process, which has recently started with  the establishment of a commission for the review of the financing of the nuclear phase-out. This commission will  provide proposals by the beginning of the next year. One of the options considered is the establishment of the  foundation financed by energy utilities. Just to be clear here, these proposals will have to be seen as non-binding  recommendations and decisions will be made in the political process that follows afterwards, which we have called  Phase 3.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As mentioned at our Credit Day in September, it is important to see that the German Government follows the aim  to maintain the economic performance of utilities in the context of the nuclear phase-out and its subsequent costs.  This was outlined by the German Cabinet in the principles for successful implementation of the energy transition,  which was published on 1st of July 2015 and has been reiterated several times by statements by the German  Minister for Economic Affairs and Energy.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Second, on October 23, the German Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy announced a framework for the so- called standby capacity that contributes to the German climate protection targets. Between 2017 and 2019, RWE  will gradually transfer five lignite power plant units with a total capacity of 1.5 gigawatt into standby for four years  each before being shutdown, the last one in 2023. The solution provides clarity with respect to the remuneration  for the companies and, therefore, reduces commodity exposure for the lignite plants affected.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On top of that, positive news came at the end of September from the North Rhine-Westphalian government with  publication of an official draft document detailing the future role of lignite in our home area. This would give us, if  finally approved, the possibility to optimize all of our lignite mines for a time horizon beyond 2030.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Third, we are successfully growing our renewables business further. As you know, we do this currently, primarily  in the form of strategic partnerships. In line with this strategy, at the end of October, RWE Energy formed a  consortium for the Galloper Offshore Wind Park with three partners, UK Green Investment Bank, Siemens  Financial Services and Macquarie Capital. Construction has recently been started and we expect the wind farm to  go online in 2018.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The earnings development in our Supply UK division has decreased by €156 million to minus €66 million. This is  mainly a result of process and system-related problems with private customer billing. Besides the operational  problems, lower energy consumption of customers, a shift from standard to non-standard rates tariffs and high  customer losses are also factors for the lower results.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On the positive side, the operating result of RWE Energy has increased significantly. In the first nine months, we  have recorded an operating result of €280 million, which is already €100 million higher than the 2014 full-year  results. By the end of this year, we expect Energy to double its operating result compared to 2014. Furthermore,  the revaluation of VSE, as a result of its full consolidation, leads to an improvement of the operating result in our  CEE/SEE downstream business.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Slide five shows the development of our cash flows from operating activities. It comes down by €2.6 billion to €2.2  billion, mainly due to changes in working capital. First, as explained in our last analyst calls, our most-significant  working capital effect is a result of a revised purchasing policy for the required CO2 emission certificates. This had  a corresponding positive effect on our cash flows in 2014.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Second in 2014, we had a positive weather effect in our working capital. This was mainly due to the mild weather  which led to relatively low energy consumption in 2014, to a large extent lower than the basis for the advanced  payments we received from our customer. As a result, in 2015, we see a counter effect as final billing for the year  2014 shows lower amounts than the cash flows we received in 2014.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Furthermore, it is also important to recognize that in Q3 2014, a temporary repayment of the nuclear fuel tax of  approximately €0.5 billion was considered which was based on the Hamburg Fiscal Court decision. However this  money had to be paid back in Q4 2014 until a final decision is made. Latest indications suggest that a final  decision concerning the nuclear fuel tax is scheduled for 2016.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: However, there were offsetting effects like regular service cost that increased our pension provisions by 0.6%. Due  to the regular interest accretion, nuclear provisions increased by approximately €0.2 billion so that the net effect  in our provisions is currently minus €0.1 billion.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On the asset side, as part of our mid-term planning which we typically conduct in the fourth quarter, we will  challenge our asset book values. Therefore, we cannot exclude impairments in the context of our full-year  accounting. However, we have had to make two adjustments, on slide eight, with respect to our divisional outlook.  First, we have to change the outlook for Trading/Gas Midstream to significantly below 2014, among others due to  a weaker Trading business performance than expected.

file: RWE - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 14November2016 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Gunhild Grieve
texts.profession: Manager-Investor Relations, RWE AG
texts.text: Thank you. Good morning to everyone on the phone and to those who are joining us via webcast. This is the first  time the new RWE, so RWE after the innogy IPO, is reporting its quarterly numbers. Although I'm sure that I've  met most of you several times during my eight years with the company, it's the first time in my new role as Head  of Investor Relations. I'm looking forward to working on the new equity story, and I'm convinced that this part of  the business has a great future although the environment is still very tough.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Finally, the government has published draft law on the transfer of financing and duties of disposal of nuclear  waste. They were largely in line with our expectations; however, we still need to clarify some key aspects of the  framework. At this point, we will also be able to finalize our funding consideration. More about our current thinking  in this topic in a moment.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, slide four shows the structure of the new RWE. Before I come to the numbers of the first  nine months, let me highlight the following. The new RWE will concentrate on the operational management on  Conventional Power Generation and Trading/Gas Midstream.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Here we see a mixed picture in the earnings trend. Operational result for Conventional Power Generation was  slightly better than in the same period 2015. We saw operational improvements from our efficiency program,  positive one-off effects from the sale of land in the UK, and compensation payment in the context of our Hamm  power plant. These effects overcompensated lower realized generation margins, mainly in our lignite and nuclear  generation feed.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Margins in our hard coal and gas power station were more stable and, in some cases, even improved.  Trading/Gas Midstream still shows a strong decline year-on-year. Also, we had a positive operation result in Q3.  This was not enough to offset the trading loss we made in Q2.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: As previously mentioned, we can confirm our guidance for the group as a whole. Due to the positive earnings  development we have seen so far in conventional power generation, we have upgraded our outlook for this  division too in the order of 2015 from significantly below 2015. This is also the reason why from today's  standpoint, we expect to end the year at the upper end of the guidance corridor.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let us now have a look at the most recent developments around the transfer of the nuclear waste disposal and  storage provisions. Slide 10 provides the key facts from the draft law established on October 19. I mentioned  before that while it provides some clarity on the framework, it still lacks clarity on some key issues.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 12 shows our net debt adjusted for innogy as of September 30. This number does not yet include the €2.6  billion proceeds from the innogy placement nor the risk premium on the nuclear provisions. It also still includes  some debt which will be transferred to innogy over the coming weeks and [ph] spec by (13:36) intercompany  loans, that's not affecting our net debt position on a net basis.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The €8.7 billion of net debt which remains at RWE is dominated by our long-term provisions for nuclear, mining  and pensions. Our financial liabilities are actually more than covered by our financial assets, even without any  consideration of our innogy shareholding.

file: RWE - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 14November2017 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: As you know, we will use €650 million of the nuclear fuel tax refund to pay a special dividend in May next year.  This leaves roughly another €500 million of the proceeds. We are currently working on further measures to use  these proceeds which will strengthen our cash flow profile further. We expect to announce more in due course.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 5 provides the details of the performance of the Lignite & Nuclear division in Q1 to Q3 and the outlook for  this division for the full year. Adjusted EBITDA has come down mainly due to the declining realized generation  margins. This was partly offset by the phase out of the nuclear fuel tax in 2016 as well as our operating cost  improvements. Last year, we had a burn of approximately €150 million from the nuclear fuel tax in the first nine  months. The decline in generation margins are also the main reason for the outlook for the full year of significantly  below previous year.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The European Power division showed an earnings decline as we had significant higher positive one-offs in 2016,  among others from the settlement of damages at our Hamm Unit D power plant. Excluding non-recurring items,  EBITDA was up year-on-year. This is mainly due to a strong earnings contribution from our commercial asset  optimization and improved gas generation margins.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: This brings me to our current hedge position on slide 7. The strong improvement in commodity prices and  spreads is reflected in our hedging. The hedge price for 2020 has improved by approximately €2 compared to our  last update as of June 2017. Still, most of the hedging in this year is via our implicit fuel hedge and therefore still  open to further changes in the spreads. Average hedge prices for 2018 and 2019 have moderately improved as  well, but not enough to move around the prices. Compared to our situation at the end of June, we've now closed  the implicit fuel hedge for 2018 and reduced it for 2019.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The details of net debt are shown on slide 12. At the end of September, it stood at €3.4 billion for RWE  standalone, approximately €3.5 billion below the end of fiscal year 2016. There are three main drivers: first, a  positive distributable cash flow; second, the refund of the nuclear fuel tax of €1.7 billion; and thirdly, a positive  effect from the reduction in provisions mainly pension provision, which accounted for an the improvement of €500  million. One reason is that the discount rate for our German pension provisions has increased from 1.7% to 1.9%.  Furthermore, pension assets performed well and that's contributed to a decline in pension provisions.

file: RWE - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 14November2018 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Moving on to our decision to de-mothball the Dutch CCGT Claus C which has a capacity of around 1.3 gigawatt.  Based on the increasing market prices and spark spreads, bringing the station back on line results in significant  value versus keeping it mothballed.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Coming to the situation around the Hambach mine, we were surprised by the resolution handed down by the  Münster Higher Administrative Court on the 5th of October imposing a temporary stop of the clearance of  Hambach Forest. The final decision and the principal proceedings should be reached at the later date, possibly by  the end of 2020. The litigious point of the proceedings deals with the question of whether the Hambach Forest is  subject to the protection regime for potential flora/fauna habitat areas.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: The Commission for Growth, Structural Change and Employment has continued its work over the last few  months. As reported in the press, the commission met regularly to gain insight into various special topics in  relation to the energy system and the lignite regions.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: At the end of October, they finalized their interim findings and recommendation for measures to support the social  and structural development in the affected regions. By the end of November or the beginning of December, we  expect to see their recommendations on climate goals. These proposals will be more relevant for us than the  chapter on structural development, as it will provide some details on the recommended magnitude and speed of  the coal phase-out.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: As a reminder, the commission was tasked to identify measures which support structural change and  development in the affected regions, ensure the achievement of the 2030 CO2 reduction targets, and close the  gap to the 2020 climate goal as quickly as possible. In addition, it should set a date for the final shutdown of coal- fired power generation.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: As a sign that the coal phase-out is already on its way is the fact that we transferred two additional Lignite units,  Niederaussem E and F, with the capacity of 300 megawatt each into the security reserve at the end of  September. They will remain there for the next four years before finally shutdown. This was agreed for climate  protection reasons in 2016, and RWE will contribute 1.5 gigawatt to the lignite reserve from 2.7 gigawatt in total.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: The European Power division realized an earnings decline of €90 million. Adjusted for non-recurring items, it  nearly reached the level in the corresponding period of the previous year. Our hard coal and gas plants realized  lower margins; however, a positive effect came from income from the UK capacity market.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: The presented figures are as at 30th of September. So, the impact of the temporary stop to the clearance of  Hambach Forest is not reflected here. As mentioned at the beginning of my presentation, we currently assume a  decrease of some 9 to 13 terawatt hours per annum in 2019 to 2021 for outright generation.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me also remind you of our long-term carbon position which we have financially hedged through until the mid- 2020s. In other words, a change in carbon prices should not affect our generation margins in this time period.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Let's move to Supply & Trading on slide 9. We again saw a good trading performance in the third quarter.  Furthermore, our gas and LNG business posted a good performance, even if it lagged behind the very high result  of last year. Besides that, we had a negative effect from a value adjustment within our Principal Investment  portfolio in Q2. For the full year, we confirm our earnings expectations for this division of between €100 million to  €300 million.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Change in operating working capital was also much better than in the comparable period last year, despite an  increase in inventories due to higher gas prices. The main reason is the phasing out of working capital  optimization measures last year. For the fourth quarter, we expect a positive change in working capital due to a  typical decrease of gas inventories. Hence we confirm our expectation to end this year with a positive balance.

file: RWE - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 25February2010 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Feb-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Let’s first have a brief look at the year just gone by. On performance, I am proud to say that we not  only achieved our financial targets but outperformed despite the difficult economic environment and  despite the prolonged outage of our Biblis power station. This allows us to pay another attractive  dividend in the year where not everybody is able to do so.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: 2 Our renewables business has also come a long way. It grew its operating asset base by almost one  gigawatt. Our new-build program is bearing fruit with the current commissioning of our CCGT in  Lingen. It will be commissioned in April. The 1.7 gigawatt station at Staythorpe will shortly follow.  This will contribute considerably to the reduction of RWE’s overall carbon exposure.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, we live in uncertain times. The economic downturn has brought an  unprecedented drop in power and gas demand. Recovery looks challenging. This situation is not  helped by the continuous lack of clarity on regulatory framework conditions, neither globally – i.e.,  the failure of the Copenhagen Summit, and I guess we will have to call it a failure. We have to call a  spade a spade. It’s no use in saying we achieved something. We achieved nothing – and so neither  globally, Copenhagen, nor nationally, be it in Germany where the national energy policy will only be  unveiled in October or in the United Kingdom where similar decisions depend on the upcoming  election results. It provides an insufficient basis for investment decisions.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: But increasing market volatility also represents further challenges for the industry. Negative power  prices and the decoupling of oil and gas markets are just the two most prominent examples.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: One of the burning questions I was asked in Investor meetings throughout last year was about the  outlook for energy demand. The main concern was a lasting drop. Some even call it demand  destruction. Overall, the situation will remain challenging. However, we believe that the downward  trend has bottomed out. Energy demand has stabilized in the fourth quarter of 2009 and the  beginning of this year already showed first signs of improving industrial activity. A return to pre- crisis levels will nevertheless take a few years.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: On the political and regulatory front, nothing much has changed. Political commitment to reduce  carbon emissions is not of equal strength around the world. We still lack clarity on regulatory  framework conditions.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Copenhagen as I already mentioned is the catchword for this. And the uncertain future of carbon  capture and storage as well as the Clean Development Mechanism and JI, Joint Implementation  are examples.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: With regard to German nuclear legislation, there has been little visible progress yet. It is good news  that the new government considers nuclear energy a bridge technology and a part of the energy  mix for the foreseeable future.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: However, we don’t expect details or clarity before October. This is when the government aims to  publish a National Energy Plan with nuclear strategy being part of it.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Please rest assured that we will not overpay for lifetime extension. A solution has to make sense for  all parties involved. While the demand side, there is an uncertain outlook, power supply is also  becoming more unpredictable.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: 3 On this slide you can see an estimate on the flexibility of Germany’s overall generation portfolio,  when in baseload operation an additional 57 gigawatts can be fit into the grid within 12 hours. This  still covers the maximum combined load swing stemming from changes in demands and renewable  generation but only by a small margin. Our experts call this the flexibility margin.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: With the rising share of renewables, load swings are forecast to become bigger and faster, thus  making the flexibility in the system increasingly tight. This situation is not helped by the ever  growing number of canceled new build projects.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: In the last 12 months, we’ve seen eight large power plant projects withdrawn with a total capacity of  8.6 gigawatts. Flexibility and responsiveness of power stations have therefore become a lot more  important. This makes our new build projects even more valuable.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: But the gas market is undergoing dramatic changes too. This is similar to the situation of the power  generation market a few years ago. What we see today is a mix between a more liquid wholesale  gas market and still existing long-term contracts. There are three major consequences.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Firstly, supply and demand are more and more independent from each other. Like in power  generation, the supplier doesn’t have to wait until the customer asks for a gas contract. There is  also a wholesale market where the gas can be sold too.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Secondly, customers become more and more market price oriented, short-term market price  oriented. And thirdly, long-term supply contracts have become supply options. They can be  optimized comparable to a power plant portfolio. So much on this challenging environment.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: The standardization of trading and risk management systems has commenced. The renewables  teams of both companies are now one. And we are cherry-picking the best wind projects on both  pipelines.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: The focus lies clearly on organic growth and efficiency enhancement projects and of course on  lower CO2 emissions. No major acquisitions are planned for the short-term. Even our planned  financial investments are of some organic nature like the future spend on Nabucco.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: The lion’s share of our CapEx is earmarked for a major new build program. By 2013, about 14  gigawatts of new capacity will be operational. They not only reduce our CO2 intensity but will also  enhance the flexibility of our portfolio, something which is very much in demand. I have already  shown you that all signs point in this direction.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: However, there are significant delays in two large projects. The lignite-fired BoA 2/3, that is,  Braunkohlenblöcke mit optimierter Anlagentechnik, BoA 2/3 blocks in Neurath will come online in  2011 instead of 2010 with full commercial availability later in 2012.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: The coal-fired twin block in Hamm will be operational in 2012 instead of 2011. This is due to the  fatal accident in Neurath and serious quality problems at our supplier sites at both sites.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Let us now look at other parts of the group’s business which also play a major role in our CO2  mitigating strategy. Our effort to grow renewables was given a big boost last year. As mentioned,  RWE Energy together with Essent has increased its operational generation base to 2.2 gigawatts.  Additionally, we have another 375 megawatts under construction.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Essent’s project pipeline is also of great value to us. With Nordsee Ost, we gained a fully consented  295 megawatt off-shore wind project. Here we can make use of our framework agreement with  REpower to fit six megawatt turbines. This way, we have significantly improved economics of the  project.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Our upstream gas and oil business is also moving on quickly, though not as quickly as expected.  As explained in conference calls, the economic crisis was slowing down projects in which RWE  Dea is not the operating partner.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: In North Africa, negotiations with governments and later realization of the gas pipeline led to delays.  Nevertheless, we confirm our target of €900 million operating result in 2013 in this division.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Before moving on to our outlook for this year, I would like to inform you about progress in our  efficiency-enhancement program. Over the last three years, we have implemented efficiency  measures which generated additional earnings of €450 million in 2009 versus 2006. For this year,  we aim to increase this figure to €700 million.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: As you know, NAP II will have experience by then and RWE will have to purchase more CO2  emission rights on the market by that time. Today, I would like to share our expectations with you.  Of course, there is still nearly three years to go until 2013 and a lot of things might happen in  between.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: We have provided you on this slide 19 with the major assumptions for our outlook. We know current  forwards are below these levels and the longer this situation lasts, the more stretched our targets  will look. But we remain optimistic on the mid to long-term power price trend.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Also the power price is not the only variable in our performance, margins, generation spreads, the  availability of plants, contributions from asset optimization are only a few more just within our  generation business.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: We must observe shifts of earnings into later years due to delays at some of our major new build  and upstream growth projects. This is what I referred to earlier on. In addition, we have put in more  conservative assumptions in terms of gas margins and tighter generation spreads.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Now on to 2013, as you have seen we have laid the foundation stone for future growth with our  large investment program. Essent is one part of it. The new power plants in Germany and the  United Kingdom as well as our planning for growth for RWE Dea and RWE Energy are other major  components.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: This will lead to a substantial earnings improvement offsetting to a large degree the pressure we  will face from the full accounting – from the full auctioning, I am sorry, from the full auctioning of  carbon certificates from 2013 onwards.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: The figures published for 2009 are already at a record high. Nevertheless, if we compare those  numbers with our expectations for 2013, we see EBITDA, operating result and recurrent net income  to grow further. And this is despite the burden from full auctioning of carbon certificates from the  National Allocation Plan III.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: This means we are confident that we can manage the carbon challenge while maintaining a high  level of profitability and a high dividend. Our policy of a dividend payout ratio between 50 and 60%  of recurrent net income remains unchanged. We aim to give you even more visibility. Our target for  dividend is to match at least the previous year’s level for each year from 2010 to 2013.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: So let me start with what we think the market misunderstands and this is our long and short  positions. For our power generation as well as our gas mid-stream and supply business, it’s  important to understand that we talk about options rather than outright positions.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Options, we will actually actively manage more later. First, however, how do we look at our CO2  position? And actually what really matters to us is to make sure that we are not short and by this I  mean financially short.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Our challenge here is just that the market in average is currently longer than us. Our target  therefore is to close the gap here. Just looking, however, CO2 only is too simple. To get a more  balanced view on this challenge, you have to remind yourself that CO2 is only one of the value  drivers in generation.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: You have to also see the other relevant commodities for the generation markets, which are  interrelated. If one goes up then – otherwise the others normally follow suit. And this chart shows  you highly simplified that if CO2 prices go up, gas should follow. This means that gas would  become the price setter and this increases the spread for our lignite and nuclear stations.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: However, if you do not believe this, just consider that our modern lignite stations actually have the  same CO2 intensity than the price setting hard coal stations. So at least we might not be long but  we will be neutral versus the market.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: So what out of all that? This shows that our lignite and nuclear stations actually make our  generation portfolio robust. CO2 reduction at any price does not help our portfolio position and this  is the underlying basis of our CO2 strategy.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Let’s just look at the next slide, how does this look like? We aim to reach the market average in  CO2 exposure in our core markets by 2020 at the latest. And how do we get there? That’s obvious.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: First, our focus on the physical reduction of our exposure mainly comes from modernization of  existing stations before actually building renewables. This slide shows the effect of our new build  projects plant-by-plant. For example, you can see that our new lignite-fired plant in Neurath  contributes in annual reduction of about six million tons.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: You can see that there is a significant CO2 reduction that can be realized in a relatively short span  of time.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: 7 Beyond the physical measures, we have non-physical ones, financial mitigation measures. The first  block JI/CDM, you’re familiar with. The second component is our portfolio optimization. What are  the key elements here?

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: First, asset swaps; second, long-term supply contracts, I will give you an example. Our lignite-fired  power plants have a big advantage which is the low cost fuel position, the disadvantage obviously  being the higher CO2 position – CO2 intensity, sorry.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: And to reduce our CO2 exposure, we have set up long-term supply contracts where we sell the  favorable economics of a lignite-fired power station and this gives us a classical win-win situation.  We reduce our CO2 risk. The customer gains a secure supply and a margin potential.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Third, we are building a position in CO2 certificates. You can basically see this as a hedge for our  lignite generation. We secure the profitability of this part of our portfolio even in case CO2 prices  should go up drastically.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: That leads me to one important point, being commercially skewed is actually the best for the  environment. Here you see what our long-term plan is. The message is clear. Until 2025, the share  of zero or low carbon generation capacity shall amount to 75% obviously with some political bond  reconditions like the nuclear lifetime extension. This is the long-term perspective.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: And now how do we manage our existing assets. So let me switch from CO2 to power. This slide  shows you how we market our generation portfolio on the wholesale markets. You are all familiar  with our forward selling strategy. It’s based on the available liquidity in the market.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: All realized prices are north of €60 per megawatt hours, which refers to a mix of 90% base and  10% peak. Forward selling for our UK and Dutch generation operations is done in a similar way.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: You might be also already familiar with this slide. It’s the best example to illustrate short-term and  long-term asset optimization. It shows you what we can earn on top of the forward selling because  we own, as I said in the beginning, a generation option and not just a power long position.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: The classic make or buy decision is what we do everyday, not just short-term, but also long-term.  This means we continuously calculate the optimal dispatch of our power plant portfolio for a period  of up to three years and adjust our forward position accordingly.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: So let’s now move from power to the interesting field of gas, which is in everybody’s mind  nowadays. And also judging from the number of questions we have received over the last few  weeks, first I would like to give you a sense of the volumes we are talking about here.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Overall, we currently have a gas portfolio of about 50 bcm. Besides purchases, the Dutch TTF and  the UK NBP, about 54% or 27 bcm of our procurement is based on long-term oil-indexed take or  pay contracts. A significant amount of these volumes is still sold at cost plus. This means it’s  naturally hedged against the so called gas-to-oil spread.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: The remainder of the oil-indexed contracts which you see here is already sold into liberalized  markets and therefore exposed to the gas-to-oil spread, currently approximately 16 bcm of our  portfolio. This portion is obviously expected to increase due to a further opening of gas markets.  However, we can manage these exposures with different tools, which I am going to show you now  on the following slides.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: First, to manage the volume that’s exposed to the gas-to-oil spread, we use a similar approach to  our power generation. The aim, the aim, I repeat that, here is to optimize our gas margins and  minimize the negative effects of the gas-to-oil spread. And this is the price difference between the  long-term contracts and the wholesale markets.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: After a price revision of the long-term take or pay contracts we usually know our exposure to the  gas-to-oil spread for the next few years. And for this time period, we can therefore determine our  hedging strategy. Depending on market liquidity, we execute this strategy by forward selling.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: However, as in power generation, all these contracts have a certain flexibility. They give you  options to a certain degree, when and where and how much gas to take. Together with storage  facilities, this forms a portfolio of optionalities again and they have to be continuously monitored  and actively managed.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: And this slide now shows you the regular price revisions in an illustrative way between buyers and  seller. The aim of the negotiations is to bring the procurement conditions of the long-term contract  back in line with the relevant market price for the buyer. After each price revision, we will start to  hedge our take-or-pay position by selling the gas against the forward price, for example against  TTF.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
