texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: At the same time, we buy oil swaps and this way we lock in the spreads and are not exposed to  further changes in the gas-to-oil spread any more until the next price revision comes up. By the  way, in case of exceptional price differentials, some contracts give us the opportunity to exercise  one-off price revisions, the so called joker revisions right away. We make active use of them.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Why forward selling is important can be seen on this slide. In 2009, the difference between the  actual spot price of wholesale and contract gas was almost €15 per megawatt hour. Going forward  for 2010, the spread is still 10 and for 2011, seven. At current forwards, we do not see a re-coupling  meaning TTF and LTCs are on par before 2013.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: We are actively selling forward our take-or-pay volumes. This minimizes the impact of the current  weak spot prices on our business. However, it’s obvious that continued negative gas-to-oil spread  will not pass us without hurting us after a certain time period.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: This is the downside we want to minimize. The upside is the contract flexibilities, which we can  optimize. Let me take make-up gas as an example. It’s comparable to the asset optimization we       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: 9 pursue with our generation business, only that here the gas contract is the asset that we are  optimizing.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Assumed we have sold gas for delivery in May-June 2009, at the time we’ve also locked in the cost  of our LTC sourcing by buying oil swaps. In Q1, 2009 we see that sourcing these sales via the  wholesale market would be more favorable.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: However, what do we do with the gas from the long-term contract? We defer this via make-up to  April-May 2010 and sell it at prevailing forward price. We might realize a loss on the make-up gas  but the additional spread achieved in 2009 by sourcing spot gas more than compensates for the  loss being this, the principle of the optimization.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Have to say that I am really proud of the numbers that we have published today. In a very tough  environment, our earnings have reached a new record high. And this is despite a burden of  approximately €1 billion from the outage of our Biblis nuclear power plant.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: On now to our divisional performance, let me start with RWE Power. Its operating result improved  by 12%. You are familiar with the major drivers for this increase. We expect the positive trend to  continue in 2010. High availability of our Biblis nuclear power plant and lower costs for fuel and  CO2 emission certificates will be the main reasons for this.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Our sales and distribution network business area closed down 9%. The main reasons were  negative gas-to-oil spread effects of existing purchase contracts. This was a one-off. Since RWE  Supply & Trading has taken over responsibility for the optimization of our gas portfolio, future gas- to-oil spreads don’t have an impact on the earnings of our sales and distribution business.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: On the other hand, we had positive effects from the optimization of our electricity procurement  portfolio. For 2010, we expect the operating result to be up. This will be mainly due to improved  earnings in electricity and gas sales business above all because of the absence of the one-off cost  from gas-to-oils spreads in 2009.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: On the other hand, we were faced burdens from German grid regulation. We have reached an  agreement with the regulator of note issue, the so called refunding of excess proceeds, in German  Mehrerlösabschöpfung. The excess proceeds from the end of 2005 to the beginning of 2007 will be  compensated for by lowering tariffs from 2010 onwards. Efficiency managements can only partly  offset these extra costs.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Now on to our new Netherlands/Belgium division, the numbers for 2009 as well as 2010 are  substantially affected by the first time consolidation. Essent contributed €141 million, which is  above our guidance from November last year. This is mainly due to higher earnings in the gas  business because of the cold weather. RWE Energy Nederland had an operating result of 39  million in Q4 last year. It is disproportionately high and may not serve as a proxy for full year  contribution.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: From Q1 this year onwards, Essent proprietary trading and its wind activities will be reported within  RWE Supply & Trading and RWE Energy respectively, but we’ll give you pro-forma Essent  numbers as well so that you can track our progress.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Let me continue with RWE npower, its operating result was down by 54%, adjusted for a mix effect  a decline by 49%. The performance of our generation business was down driven by reduced  spreads. Moreover increased capacity in UK market reduced opportunities for asset optimization  team. On the other hand costs for purchasing CO2 certificates declined by approximately €140  million.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: 11 Earnings in our retail business deteriorated compared to the previous year. This was mainly due to  higher energy procurement costs. Despite this fact, we had to reduce electricity prices by an  average of 8% due to competitive pressure. Additionally, high expenses for governmental  programs, including social obligation costs, reduced our earnings. RWE npower’s 120 million cost  and efficiency program delivered on target.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: In 2010, we expect that lower spreads will affect the performance of our generation business. We  expect retail earnings to recover slightly due to the recent fall in wholesale energy prices. Social  costs will, however, continue to affect us by approximately the same magnitude as in 2009.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Operating earnings in our Central and Eastern Europe division climbed by 16%. One major factor  was our price increases in our Czech gas sales business mainly in Q4 last year. This made up for  lower margins in early periods. In addition, the Czech regulator allowed for higher gas grid margins.  Our Hungarian electricity generator Mátra benefited from the increased margin for electricity  production based on biomass. Furthermore, earnings were supported by efficiency measures in  Hungary. This was partly offset by lower volumes, our Hungarian electricity sales and Czech gas  sales businesses.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: We anticipate that earnings generated by this division will decline this year. The main reason is that  margins in our Czech gas sales business as well as in the Hungarian electricity sales and  generation business are expected to come down again. On the other hand, we will see further  efficiency enhancements, entire earnings contributions from our Czech gas grid company.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Our Renewables division showed an operating result on par with 2008. We had mutually offsetting  effects. On the one hand, earnings were supported by consolidation effects and the commissioning  of new wind farms. On the other hand, the ambitious investment program leads to upfront costs and  requires additional staff. In addition, we suffered from low electricity prices, especially in Spain.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: As regards 2010, we are quite positive for RWE Innogy. And as see further results of our growth  investment program, but upfront costs for our projects are still offsetting most of this. In addition,  Innogy will benefit from the first-time conservation of Essent’s wind activities. The earnings  improvement will accelerate in the coming years as you know. With 2013, we expect an operating  result in the order of €500 million.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Upstream Gas and Oil reported a 59% decline in operating earnings. This is a result of the decline  in oil and gas prices as well as lower production volumes. Lower exploration costs due to lower  number of dry wells than in 2008 had a positive impact.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Compared to the very weak last year, we see significant upside potential for 2010. RWE Dea  expects to see improved oil prices and higher oil production volumes, but the latter will also  increase operating costs. Our target remains to double the production of hydrocarbons by 2015 at  the latest compared to 2008, and achieve an operating result of approximately €900 million in 2013.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: 12 we see strong earnings contributions from the continuous optimization of our international gas  procurement portfolio.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: In 2010, we expect the division to close significantly below the previous year’s record level despite  the integration of Essent’s proprietary trading activities. Lower trading margins and the absence of  the special items in 2009 I just explained are the major reasons. In gas midstream, we are exposed  to risks from oil-indexed gas contracts. Leo already explained how we aim to mitigate this effect.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Now on to our cash flow statement on slide 51, the funds from operations declined by 15%, there  was a 1.1 billion higher cash out for CO2 emission certificates for 2008, which were not paid until  Q1 last year.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: Cash flows from operating activities were down 40% as mainly a result of changes in working  capital, which have an effect of minus €2.5 billion. Net variation margins received for electricity  hedges via energy exchange were significantly lower than in the previous year.

texts.speaker: Ingo Alphéus, Vice President and Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to all of you who’ve joined us here in Essen
texts.text: CapEx on fixed asset was up by almost €1.5 billion as mainly due to the strong investment program  especially our power plant projects at RWE Power and npower. As a result, free cash flow declined  by €5 billion to minus €0.6 billion.

file: RWE - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 24February2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: All divisions with the exception of Trading and Gas Midstream showed at least a double-digit  earnings growth. With the conclusion of the integration of Essent, we are well on track to achieve  our synergy targets. We also progressed our plans for a more efficient organization by streamlining  the Group Center and by pooling our German sales and distribution businesses.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our Central Eastern and South Eastern Europe division is now steered by the newly established  RWE East domiciled in Prague. Our CapEx program is well advanced. We commissioned two  CCGT plant in Lingen, Northern Germany and Staythorpe, Great Britain and started the  construction of another one in Denizli, Turkey.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: RWE Innogy has taken major steps to prepare for the construction of its Nordsee Ost and Gwynt y  Môr offshore wind farms. By the end of 2010, the first turbine had already started generating  electricity at the Greater Gabbard offshore wind farm.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let me briefly explain our view on the current situation in Egypt and Libya. Egypt is an important  country for RWE Dea, even more so in the years to come after the significant gas findings in the       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 2 Western offshore Nile Delta. However, our exposure is limited as so far the country contributes less  than 10% to RWE Dea’s operating result. We also trust that the new government in Egypt will keep  the reliable investment in environment, not the least because our production is mainly intended for  the Egyptian market. Let me also update you the situation is stabilizing significantly and we have  begun to send back our experts to Egypt. So, no disruptive development there is to be expected.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Increasing energy demand on the back of a colder than average winter has not yet led to significant  improvement of electricity prices or spreads. The continued construction of generation capacity  above all the unexpected, perhaps even unforeseeable, expansion of solar PV, photovoltaic, is one  of the major reasons for this. In addition to this already challenging environment in the generation  market, political conditions have also become much less reliable. The German government’s  decision to introduce a tax on nuclear fuel is the most prominent example.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The decoupling of oil and gas prices resulting in a negative gas to oil spread is a result of the  demand supply imbalance mainly caused by the economic crisis in addition to U.S. shale gas  production and discoveries. While other countries are shying away from firm commitments in the  face of economic uncertainties, Europe is still committed to its ambitious CO2 targets. We therefore  have to brace ourselves for the tighter CO2 regime from 2013 onwards. But this is not new to us,  and comes as expected. However some smart, or should I say smarter, nations like the  Netherlands are introducing cost-efficiency considerations into their plan for a greener economy i.e.  how much greenhouse gas abatements can you get for each euro spent.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: First and foremost, we didn’t see any reasons why we should change our strategy. We stick to our  guns taking advantage of our regional expertise, process know-how and positioning in our existing  and growth markets. Our CO2 mitigation strategy is still key to making us more competitive.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our organic growth ambitions will focus on renewables and upstream. Both activities will show on  average double-digit earnings growth over the next years. However, the nuclear fuel tax affects our  overall earnings and therefore also our financial headroom and investment budget. We reduced our  existing CapEx program by approximately €3 billion and stepped up our existing €1.2 billion  efficiency enhancement program by another €200 million by 2012.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In addition, we have already taken steps to make our asset portfolio more suitable to the changed  environment. Such initiatives include the renegotiation of our gas procurement contracts and the  ability to increase the flexibility of our power plants.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our current markets offer attractive investment opportunities, Central Eastern and South Eastern  Europe present additional growth prospects which we intend to pursue in the medium-term. Most of  you are already familiar with our CO2 mitigation strategy, which remains key to the competitiveness  of RWE. We maintain our target of reducing our CO2 intensity to market average by 2020.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We are working on physical as well as financial mitigation measures to achieve this goal.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The most recent example for financial measures is a deal we signed at the end of last year with a  big industrial client. We sold 300 megawatts of lignite capacity for 15 years where the client takes  their cost for the required CO2 certificates. This deal alone hedges approximately 2.6 million tons  per annum of our CO2 procurement requirements and lowers our economic exposure significantly.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Last year, we provided you with the details of the CO2 mitigation measures.  These can be found in  the backup slides. However, the near-term challenge is full auctioning of CO2 certificates from 2013  onwards. We won’t be able to fully compensate for that financial burden stemming from the  purchase of some additional 100 million tons of CO2 certificates in 2013. However, we have laid  the foundation for growth projects, which will more than make up for the negative impact beyond  2013.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, from strategy, now let’s move on to execution. Let me start with our new  medium-term investment program, including the impact of planned portfolio divestments. We intend  to spend approximately €18 billion over the next three years mainly on our large power plants and  infrastructure projects. These projects are well advanced and we’re working hard to bring them on  stream as soon as possible. This is the reason, why we will see an increase in our capital spending  of up to €1 billion in the current year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 4 power generation in North-Western Europe, as we don’t want to miss out on opportunities in our  broad areas of renewables and upstream gas and oil.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Once operational, we expect these projects to contribute approximately €1.2 billion of EBITDA and  €0.9 billion of operating results. But please bear in mind, developing offshore wind farms or new  gas fields takes time. As a response to the tougher financial environment, we have increased the  hurdle rates for new investment projects despite lower average cost of capital. This ensures that  RWE will concentrate on the most attractive opportunities.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, now let’s focus on the specific growth areas of RWE; one of course is our  renewables business. RWE Innogy continues with an ambitious investment program, which also  plays a major role in our CO2 mitigation strategy. The acquisition of Essent did not only bring  excellent power stations, and a solid customer base in the Netherlands to RWE, we also inherited a  well advanced project pipeline in renewables. We refocus on our development plans on some  larger fully consented projects, and postponed some smaller ones. This has, of course together  with CapEx cuts, some impact on RWE Innogy’s growth targets.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: With the focus now on offshore wind projects, which are more time consuming, we have to  postpone our [inaudible] capacity target. We now expect to have 4.5 gigawatts in operation or  under construction in 2014, two years later than originally envisaged. This corresponds to an  operating result of approximately €500 million. Let me emphasize, this is only the first milestone.  We plan for a significant further growth in the years thereafter.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: It is also worthwhile mentioning that we expect RWE Innogy’s results to exceed its cost of capital by  2016. Excluding the significant startup costs for such a young and capital extensive business –  intensive business and assuming normalized weather conditions, we expect operational projects to  make a positive value contribution in 2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As a consequence, RWE Dea will achieve its production earnings targets slightly later than  envisaged. We now target oil and gas production of 70 million barrels of oil equivalent in 2016, with  an operating result of roughly €1 billion. We have good indications for further growth potential of up  to 90 million barrels of oil equivalent per year in a couple of years later.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, in 2010 the German market recorded a year of considerable growth in  renewable capacity. Photovoltaic, i.e., solar was an especially strong contributor to that. I don’t  want to bore you with the arguments about how uneconomical of this is. You’re all aware of the  facts. There will be even the – though there will be massive additional capacity coming on to the  system. Only very little between 10% and 20% of this capacity can be considered reliable to cover  demand at any given time. As a result, the need for conventional power plants to provide the so  called swing capacity will increase dramatically.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 5 The current system requires a good 30 gigawatts, which is covered by today’s generation fleet. But  one can expect this to grow up to 50 gigawatts in 2020, and even more thereafter. The positive  thing is, tight markets will provide good opportunities for operators who own flexible plants. This is  the reason why we have started a program to further upgrade the flexibility of our generation fleet.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We also believe that competitive markets are to be favored over regulated capacity markets.  Experience gained in other European countries is not convincing. In the existing market model,  price signals will indicate necessary investments in new generation capacity, even if renewables  continue to expand.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: These signals will trigger timely decisions by potential investors if policy makers create clear and  reliable framework conditions and do not interfere in the price formation process allowing price  spikes as necessary market signals. The strong increase in renewables will take our demand for  conventional power plants. But in times of low wind levels and no sun there has to be capacity to  back up the system.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let me mention on this occasion that we are now in the third consecutive year of low wind levels,  30% below the long-term average. On one hand, this conventional capacity will grow by some 40  gigawatts which is going on line by 2013, 2014. Thereafter, we don’t expect any further additional  conventional and renewable capacity to be realized for a considerable time.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The last project was announced in 2008. Since then, we’ve only seen cancellations. On the other  hand, some 4 gigawatts will go out of the system in the short-term or has already left the system as  a lot of a new build projects are replacement plants. You might remember that even in RWE, our  new lignite BoA plant is replacing 16 old lignite blocks of 150 megawatts each.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As a consequence, we have decided not to exercise the option to prolong 1.4 gigawatts of our  Steag contract. They will phase out in 2012. Of course, these plants will still be in the market until  their owner decides what to with do them.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: On the back of current market conditions, we see approximately 8 gigawatts of traditional inflexible  hard coal plants struggling hard to even cover their fuel cost. In case, the current market conditions  prevail, we would assume that the bulk of these plants will go out of the system if their operators  behave rationally. Recent debt finance acquisitions of generation portfolios should put additional  pressure on acquirers to behave with sense.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As a consequence of the tough industry environment, we have stepped up RWE’s efficiency  program, the original program of 1.2 billion per annum for 2012 compared to 2006 is well on track.  On top of this, we want to produce another 200 million of cost savings by 2012. Please be aware  that this was already net of any cost increases with the exception of higher fuel costs. These  additional measures are mainly referring to programs to cut overhead costs. In addition, we will  introduce a new IT system in our U.K. division. This will bring significant changes to our operations,  making processes more efficient and reducing the numbers of staff required.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Jürgen mentioned already that all divisions, except Trading/Gas Midstream as strongly contributing  to this. In addition, we experienced one-off effects in the other consolidation line mainly from the  release of provisions in the magnitude of €200 million.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now, onto our divisional performance, starting with RWE Power. Its operating result improved by  17% to a record level of €4 billion. Slide 18 gives you the individual value drivers. For 2011, we are  less optimistic for obvious reasons. Our German generation business will be hit for the first time by  the introduction of the nuclear fuel tax. We expect to burn up approximately €400 million.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Average realized electricity prices were far behind last year’s high level of €67 per megawatt hour.  In 2011, our Biblis A nuclear power plant will be off line for approximately six months and Biblis B  for approximately three months. As a result, the earnings contribution of Biblis will fall behind the  2010 level and we have to incur costs for retrofit measures. However, the impact from the change  in nuclear and mining provisions will have a positive effect. This is mainly due to the absence of  costs we had in 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Coming to our customary update in our forward selling position, at the end of fiscal year 2010,  we’ve sold more than 90% for 2011, more than 50% for 2012 and more than 10% for 2013.  Although we saw some recovery of electricity prices at the beginning of the year, current price  levels are far below the high prices we saw two to three years ago. The strong increase in  renewable volumes has particularly put pressure on peak low prices. As a result, the clean dark  and spark spreads are levels which are too low to justify operation of old inefficient power plants.  Jürgen mentioned already in his presentation that old and expensive plants might leave the system  if prices stay so low for longer.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the sales business, gas volumes increased mainly because of the cold weather, while electricity  margins declined. We expect the operating result for 2011 to fall below the previous year. This is  mainly a result of higher OpEx for improving the quality of our distribution network business. The  costs for refunding excess proceeds will be slightly lower than in 2010. For the sales business, we  expect lower gas volumes assuming normalized weather conditions.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now onto our Netherlands/Belgium division, the numbers for 2010 are substantially affected by  consolidation effect. The performance of the Netherlands/Belgium division was supported by higher  gas sales due to the cold winter and slightly higher customer count numbers. Earnings were  negatively affected by the transfer of the Eemshaven power plant project from RWE Power to  Essent. The accumulated upfront costs of approximately €25 million are now reflected in this  division.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 7 With regard to 2011, we expect the operating results to come down significantly. This is mainly a  result of the integration of the Gas Midstream business into RWE Supply and Trading.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In 2010, the Gas Midstream margin which was supported by the cold winter weather was still  reported in the Netherlands/Belgium division. Lower electricity generation spreads will have a  negative impact as well, however, the division will benefit from efficiency improvements and  additional synergies.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Then we continue with RWE npower, operating result was up by 10% adjusted for f/x effects, it  increased by 6%. The increase was mainly linked to our retail business where we’ve benefited from  our efficiency programs and from improved residential gas demand over the cold winter month.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: On the downside, we faced increased costs for bad debt this year. The performance of our  generation business was affected by the adverse market conditions for our hard coke plants. This  could only partially be offset by higher production volumes of our gas fired plants including our new  CCGT in Staythorpe and lower operating costs. RWE npower’s extensive cost and efficiency  programs also helped to stabilize earnings at difficult market environment. For the year 2011, we  anticipate an increase in RWE npower’s operating result due to an increased operational  performance program across all business segments.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The generation business will benefit from full contribution of our new gas plant at Staythorpe.  However, the deterioration of generation spreads will further suppress overall performance of this  business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Operating earnings at our Central Eastern and South Eastern Europe Division climbed by 11%  supported by a positive forex effects. Adjusted forex effects, division posted an increase of 7%.  One major factor were improvements in our Czech gas network and sales business. However, we  suffered from decline in volumes with distributors. In addition, we had a positive contribution from  our Polish activities among other things due to efficiency improvements.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In Hungary, improved electricity network margins were more than offset by lower electricity  generation margins and the introduction of a special tax. For 2011, we expect operating result to be  down significantly year-on-year compared to the exceptionally high number of 2010. In the Czech  Republic, we expect gas sales margins to come down as well as earnings from gas storage  activities. The contribution from our Hungarian electricity activities is also expected to fall behind  last year’s level. However, we expect to see a higher electricity network margins in Poland.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The operating result of our Renewables Division improved by 29%. The first-time consolidation of  the Essent wind assets contributed €23 million through earnings. We explained in our earlier calls  that this is less than originally expected because of the very weak production volumes due to low  wind levels in Northwestern Europe. The commissioning of our Rhyl Flats offshore wind farm and  the consolidation of Danta de Energías for full-year had a positive effect. Upfront costs for large  investment program including higher staff costs are still dampening Innogy’s operating result.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: For 2011, we expect RWE Innogy to post strong earnings increase. We’ll see further results of our  expansion program, but upfront costs for projects including higher staff costs are still offsetting  parts of this. In addition, we assume normalized wind levels compared to the very weak conditions  in 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Upstream Gas & Oil reported a 50% increase in operating earnings. This is mainly a result of higher  oil prices, a stronger U.S. dollar, as well as reduced exploration costs. In addition, we benefited       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 8 from lower royalties in the German business. However, Dea suffered from reduced gas prices and  lower production volumes.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We see significant further upside potential for 2011. RWE Dea expects improved oil and gas prices,  anticipate a higher oil production but gas volumes will decline due to the natural depletion of our  German and U.K. fields. In addition, we expect exploration costs to come down further.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The operating result in our Trading/Gas Midstream Division turned into a slight negative number in  the year under review. On the one hand, the mark-to-market performance of the trading business  was good, but fell below the very high level of fiscal 2009. On the other hand, we benefited from the  first-time consolidation of the Essent trading activities, which contributed €96 million in 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The steep decline is mainly related to our gas supply activities. This is because of two major items.  First, in 2009, we successfully concluded price revisions which led to a triple digit one-off release of  provisions. Second, prices on the gas market dropped relative to oil purchase contract as slide 49  in our back-ups indicate. This is also the reason why we see the operating result in 2011 falling  significantly below the level of 2010 despite an expected stable development for our trading  activities.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let me take the opportunity to update you on the situation for our gas supply business. This slide,  number 27, will be familiar to you but the numbers have changed slightly. Our original 27 bcm take- or-pay exposure has come down to 24 bcm as some smaller contracts phased out.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As indicated to you in our recent presentations, the net exposure temporarily grows to 20 bcm as  more and more sales contracts have turned from oil-indexation to market prices especially in the  Czech Republic. However, with the current prices and contract renegotiations underway, we would  expect the oil-indexed take-or-pay exposure to come down significantly in the coming years.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide 28 gives you now about the maturity profile of our gas supply contracts and the status of our  revision talks. As of January 2011, we are in negotiations for a good two-third, or 17 bcm of our  long term supply contracts.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Although we are ahead of other midstream companies, the bulk of refund will most likely only come  in 2012 and ‘13. However, as we started the process to fundamentally restructure these contracts a  much earlier than most and have not accepted any temporary quick fixes, we expect any good  news also to show retroactive effects for part of the volumes from the years 2009 and 2010.  However, you should always keep in mind that price renegotiations and arbitration process of  market developments of seismic shifts have never happened in Europe before. And therefore,  precise outcomes are hard to predict. Please understand that as long as we are in negotiations, it  cannot be more explicit.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The non-operating results fell below last year’s number by €1.3 billion. This was driven by the  earnings impact of commodity derivatives. Please remember, that all the numbers we show in this  line are purely timing differences. Restructuring, other fell by approximate €240 million, is mainly  driven by three effects. The deteriorated market conditions for U.K. hard coal and oil fired power  plants forced an impairment of €296 million. Secondly, last year, 2009, we recognized an  impairment loss on our at-equity participation in Excelerate. And thirdly, in 2009, we still had a  positive contribution from the change in nuclear and mining provisions since 2010; these changes  are accounted for in the operating result.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We have already seen smaller deals like the disposal of Thyssengas, which we envisage to close  by the end of this month or the disposal of our 24.6% stake in the [inaudible] hard coal plant. You  also know that we are evaluating options with regard to financial investors as potential partners for  our electricity transport business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Further assets will follow, but it’s too early to talk about details. The second measure to support our  rating was reduction of CapEx. Compared to our old program, we have reduced capital spending  for the next three years by approximately €3 billion. Nevertheless, due to the disposal proceeds, we  still have enough funds available to grow our renewables and upstream businesses.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: EBITDA and operating results are expected to come down by approximately 15% and 20%  respectively; the decline for a recurrent net income is expected to be approximately 30%. What are  our expectations midterm for 2013, earnings will be affected as a result of low commodity prices  and the full auctioning of carbon certificates. The portfolio divestments of – up to €8 billion are  expected to lower our EBITDA in 2012 and 2013 by approximately €1 billion, operating result by  approximately €0.7 billion and recurrent net income by approximately €0.3 billion.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The 2013 going forward price for base load went up by some €3 to nearly €55 per megawatt hour  over the last couple of days, which of course is helpful for our future profit. If you figure that in –  with 160 terawatt hours we are selling, 60 are dependent on the spreads, 100 terawatt hours are  just basically nuclear and lignite, and each Euro would transform into about 100 million in result,  disregarding our gas to oil spread.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We also expect that the influence on increased power generation from renewables will start  showing bigger effects. The lack of flexible capacity in conventional generation will be positive for  our business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Seconds, the European gas market is already in a transition phase. Current negative spreads can  also not persist forever. But don’t get me wrong, these developments might need some years to  resolve but definitely not decades.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 11 For the later years, we also expect commodity prices to pick up again. Further we are confident that  our gas to oil spread exposure will be largely gone beyond 2013 as price reviews will have to bring  these long-term contracts back in line with wholesale prices. This is the core principle of contracts;  they have to reflect market realities.

file: RWE - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 6March2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Mar-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me start with a brief review of 2011. Last year, it was marked by Germany's new energy policy, the  government's sudden decision to phase out nuclear power, resulted in significant one-off burdens, overshadowing  our financial performance. As anticipated, all major financial performance indicators were down on the previous  year, although we slightly outperformed our own expectations.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Our efficiency program is also on track. We are actually ahead in our plans and managed to achieve more than the  envisioned €900 million for 2011. The program will come to a close by the end of this year, with cumulative  savings of €1.5 billion compared to the base year 2006. But we are not resting on our laurels. You know you won't  wear them on the wrong spot on your body if you're resting on them. We have already kicked off a new program,  which together with the additional efficiencies of the current program, target to further efficiency enhancement of  all together €1 billion compared to 2012.  Finally, we have also made progress in the renegotiation of our long term oil-indexed gas contracts. With three gas  suppliers, by the larger number of contracts, we were able to remove the gas-to-oil spread risk by either moving to  gas wholesale price indexation or early termination of the contracts by mutual agreement.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, one of the cornerstones of our strategy to transform RWE into a more international, more  sustainable and more robust company is our new built program of thermal power plants. By 2014, we will have  renewed more than one quarter of our generation fleet. At that point, we have – we will have invested  approximately €12 billion to operate one of the most modern thermal generation portfolios in Europe.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: This program reduces specific CO2 emissions conservatively. The replacement of our old 150 megawatt lignite  blocks of which we still have 12 at the end of 2011, with the new BoA which is the new improved lignite fire  technique will also – will alone reduce our annual CO2 emissions by 6 million tons per year.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Where do we stand in this program? At the end of last year, we had 2.6 gigawatts of new capacity connected to the  grid. For the year 2012, we expect five power plants with a total of 6.8 gigawatts to enter into operation in rapid  succession.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In January and February, the two gas combined cycle gas turbines, Claus C and Moerdijk, were commissioned. At  the end of March, our lignite plant in Neurath will come into operation, followed by the CCGTs in Pembroke, U.K.  and Denizli, Turkey in the second half of the year. Next year, we will start operations at our hard coal power plant  in Hamm, Germany. The program will be finalized in 2014, with the commissioning of the Dutch hard coal plant  in Eemshaven.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: I'm happy to report that we are finally coming to an end of this huge program successfully, the biggest in the  history of RWE. I would also like to compliment the skills and experience of our engineers. You might have heard  about the problems that other players in the market have faced concerning the new T24 steel grades used in coal  plants, mainly the occurrence of hydrogen-induced stress corrosion cracking, Spannungsrisskorrosion in German,  which leads to significant delays and cost overruns. Thanks to the sophisticated ramp-up project developed by  RWE technology, we have been able to exclude any such problems on our project so far, knock on wood.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: On the other hand, we were able to profit from trial runs of our new Neurath lignite plant precisely at the height of  the cold temperatures, while we still have our traditional 150 megawatt blocks in operation, 12 of them. This  enabled us to have 11,500 megawatt, 11,503 to be correct, of lignite power connected to the grid in the middle of  February, which was a new record production.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: When I came onboard almost five years ago, I knew that I would have a big task at hand to change the course of a  supertanker such as RWE, to make it more sustainable, more international and more robust. In addition to the  financial crisis and the economic downturn, politicians did their bit to make the sea rougher. But as a hobby  sailor, I know that you sometimes have to adjust course due to stormy weather without losing sight of the final  destination.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: I believe that we have prepared the group for the radical changes in the energy sector by initiating and executing  the biggest investment program in RWE's history. We were not deterred by external or internal setbacks and are  just starting to reap the benefits.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Four out of nine new power plants are already operational. These replace older less-efficient plants, provide more  flexibility and lower CO2 emissions. With the foundation of RWE Innogy, renewable energy became an integral  part of the group strategy. By 2014, we will have 4.5 gigawatts in operation or under construction, contributing to  €500 million of operating results. By 2020, we are targeting 20% of renewable and generation capacity.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: RWE Dea has become and will remain a core growth area of the company. Despite the planned disposals, our  upstream business will increase production to more than 40 million barrels of oil equivalent per year and reach  €800 million in operating results by 2014.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: With our CCGT project in Turkey, we also stepped into new growth regions for our traditional electricity and gas  activities. There are further opportunities to grow in Central Eastern and South Eastern Europe, and RWE is well- positioned to make use of its expertise and skills.  Over the last four years, we also doubled our research and development expenditures. We put major emphasis on  finding solutions to prevent carbon dioxide from power plants entering into the atmosphere. With our innovative  pilot projects, I believe we are one of the pioneers in this field.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Großmann
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Finally, the bundling of our gas procurement contract allows us to proactively manage the gas portfolio with the  commercial expertise and knowledge of RWE Supply & Trading and seeks structural solutions to fundamental  market changes in the sector. So whilst the selling conditions have not always been as favorable as I would have  liked, I believe that as I prepare to hand over to the new captain, RWE is well-positioned for the voyage ahead.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, let me start with the headline numbers for the group. External revenue was slightly down  by 3%, mainly as a result of lower external sales from own electricity generation via RWE Supply & Trading.  Jürgen has already mentioned the performance for our key earnings numbers, EBITDA and operating result. I'll  come to the details in a minute.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: The non-operating result declined by approximately €400 million, mainly due to restructuring measures. We had  one-off burdens of approximately €500 million for staff reduction matters in our German Generation and Sales  and Distribution businesses. Peter will give you more information on our further efficiency targets in a minute. In  addition, we suffered from impairments on our Dutch Generation portfolio and on the former Essent gas storage  activities.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 10 gives you an overview of the development of the operating result by division. The new German energy  policy has left its mark on the German Power Generation business unit, with the reduction of the nuclear lifetime,  the introduction of the nuclear fuel tax and earlier closure of our nuclear power plant at Biblis.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: In the period under review, we had about €1.3 billion of burdens from the new German energy policy and the  nuclear fuel tax. In addition, the Power Generation division suffered from lower realized spreads. Take together,  these factors led to a decrease in operating result of 33%.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: The second negative factor is the development in our Trading/Gas Midstream division. The division has been  particularly hit by the impact of the negative gas-to-oil-spread. In addition, the performance of the Trading  business has been much weaker than usual.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: As expected, our Dutch business, Essent, couldn't repeat the results from last year, mainly due to the transfer of  gas midstream activities to our Trading/Gas Midstream division. Weather conditions were also less favorable than  last year.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Our CEE/SEE division reports a reduction in operating result of 5%. In the Czech market, we faced decreasing  grid margins and lower gas sales. In addition, in Hungary, we suffered from burdens from regulation and  declining electricity sales due to tough competition.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Our Renewables business benefited from increased generation volumes and more favorable quotes of prices.  Furthermore, liquidated damages from our share in the wind offshore project, Greater Gabbard, had a positive  impact.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Our Upstream business strongly increased its operating result to €558 million. Higher gas and oil prices and  improved oil production are the main drivers.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, let's have a look at what we are expecting for the individual divisions of this year before  Peter will give you an update on the overall group outlook for 2012 and 2013 later. The German Power Generation  business unit is expected to close above 2011. Major driver is the commissioning of the new lignite-fired power  plant in Neurath.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Furthermore, expect the positive contribution from the change of nuclear provisions and lower maintenance and  operating costs. This will more than offset declining generation margins and a higher nuclear fuel tax. Although  first court rulings on the nuclear tax were in our favor, we still have to book the costs in the P&L.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: We see our German Distribution and Sales business unit on par with the last year. On the one hand, we will  benefit from our efficiency improvements. On the other hand, we expect lower income from participations and the  absence of positive one-offs from the first-time consolidation of NEW in 2010.  The Netherlands/Belgium division had fallen significantly below the previous year. Declining gas midstream and  electricity generation margins cannot be fully offset by further efficiency gains.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Before the fire at our Tilbury site on February 27, we expected a further significant increase in RWE npower's  operating result year-on-year, particularly as a result of our ongoing efficiency improvement and the  commissioning of our Tilbury biomass plant. This will now be dependent on the extent of the damage from the  fire.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: In the Retail business, we are expecting progress on the squeezed domestic margins. Again, this Power Generation  business will suffer from declining from declining generation spreads.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: The CEE/SEE division is expected to show decline in operating result compared to 2011. This is mainly due to  expected lower gas sales and good margins in the Czech business. Continuous commissioning of new projects in  our Renewables division will lead to an increase in operating earnings in 2012.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: In the current year, we expect our Upstream Gas & Oil division to show a further strong earnings increase. The  start of production in new gas fields, higher gas prices and lower exploration costs will be the main drivers.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: The development in our Trading/Gas Midstream activities are still dominated by the negative gas-to-oil spread  and our ongoing price reviews. We do expect further improvements during the course of the year, but we only  anticipate significant relief to come from 2013 onwards. For that reason, the operating results might even fall  significantly below the negative number of 2011, as we are still paying the high contract prices to our suppliers but  achieved only traded wholesale prices with our customers.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, let me take the opportunity to give you a brief update on the situation with our long-term  oil-indexed gas contracts. Total procurement portfolio is approximately 45 bcm. This is approximately 2 bcm less  than last year. Long-term oil-indexed contracts account approximately 20 bcm compared to 24 bcm at the  beginning of 2011, after we settled first renegotiations at the end of last year of which some were transitioned to  fully-traded wholesale market indexation in the next years, some moved already to fully-traded wholesale market  prices.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: But the volume of our oil-indexed gas contracts to end clients fell from approximately 4 bcm to approximately 2  bcm. As a result, our net exposure declined to 18 bcm as of February this year. We are still in renegotiations for  nine out of our 17 contracts and are optimistic that we will solve this issue during the course of 2013.

texts.speaker: Rolf Pohlig
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, RWE AG
texts.text: Last but not least, we also did announce new efficiency targets. By 2014, we want to improve our underlying  earnings by €1 billion, of which approximately €750 million should already be realized next year.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: So let me quickly run through this. In terms of regional strategy, we continue to remain focused on our core  electricity and gas markets in Central Europe. However, our growth areas of Renewables, Upstream Gas & Oil as  well as Central Eastern and South Eastern Europe will be broadening our geographical exposure, and thereby  diversifying specific country risks, predominantly those of regulatory and political nature. To this end, more than  60% of our investments between 2012 and 2014 will be outside Germany.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: The same holds true for our Generation business. Our broad generation mix is less exposed to single isolated  commodity price movements. The best example is the combination of our lignite and gas generation fleet, but the  combined risk is much lower than the individual risk position.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: At present, we are benefiting from the fate of our clean brown spreads. The geographical-diversified Renewables  business is also better suited to balance better patterns in different regions. In addition, investments in the most  economic renewable technologies reduce these future regulatory risks.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Our Distribution and Renewables businesses provide a regulated and stable income stream. Disposals of regulated  network companies will be compensated for by the increase in contribution from regulated renewables. Our  Upstream business offers exposure to global unregulated commodity prices.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Becoming more sustainable remains at the top of our agenda. Here, we are working I three different areas. First,  we want to lower our specific CO2 emissions by more than 20% by 2020 compared to 2005. Although CO2 has  become less prominent in the realms of the financial market, but at least because of the steep decline in costs for  emission certificates, CO2 reduction remains a key priority for Germany and Europe. We don't see this changing  in the foreseeable future or in relation to any new carbon mitigation regulation post 2020.  Our target, therefore, is to reduce the specific CO2 emission factor physically to 0.62 tons per megawatt hour by  2020. Including financial measures, it will even come down to 0.5. More details on our current CO2 position and  reduction path can be found in the back-up section.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Second, with the nuclear phase out in Germany, renewable energy plays an even bigger role. It's important to see  that the trend for more renewables has decoupled from the goal to simply reduce CO2 emissions.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Firstly, renewable technologies such as wind and biomass are expected to become even more economical in the  long run. Secondly, they support the desire to be less dependent on the traditional primary energy sources. We  have, therefore, set ourselves a target of increasing our renewable capacity to at least 20% by 2020, from  approximately 8% at the end of 2011. We will focus on those technologies which are most economic and therefore  be – they have the lowest risks for political intervention.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Thirdly, last but not the least, we promote the efficient use of energy, not only through more efficient power plants  but also by developing and offering energy-saving products to our customers; products as micro cogenerated –  cogeneration units and heat plants.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: To our smartphone offering, we standardize and encourage the customers to use less energy. And with our  investments in the charging infrastructure, we facilitate the use of electric cars, not only in Germany but for  example also in the Netherlands. The city of Amsterdam ordered last year at least 125 charging stations to support  their project of 10,000 electric vehicles by 2015.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: With this in mind, let's have a look at our capital expenditure on slide 19. As you can see, we have passed the peak  of our investment program. For this year, we expect investments of some €6 billion. This includes the completion  of a number of conventional power plants projects which we haven't mentioned before.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: From 2013 onwards, our investments will come in line with more sustainable CapEx levels, which we see between  €4 billion and €5 billion. This includes day-to-day CapEx of approximately €2 billion to €2.5 billion. And for 2012  and 2013, the majority of investments are already committed. For 2014 onwards, there is more flexibility to adjust  CapEx levels which will be used for our financial discipline if required.  On slide 20, you can see how much we will be spending in our key growth areas. Some €6 billion is earmarked  from Renewables, Upstream Gas & Oil in Central Eastern and South Eastern Europe until 2014. This does not  include the day-to-day investments in these divisions.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: We will invest more than €1 billion per annum in our Renewables activities, focusing mainly on offshore and  onshore wins as well as biomass projects. We can't confirm our capacity target of 4.5 gigawatts in operation or  under construction by 2014 as well as operating earnings targets and €500 million for the same year.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: With a number of projects currently under development and said to start production over the next three years, we  have decided to provide you with a nearer-term target. It shows that successful growth path developed RWE Dea.  The target is to increase production to more than 40 million barrels of oil equivalents by 2014 with an operating  result of approximately €800 million.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: However, despite the planned asset disposals, we are still confident in the longer-term growth post-2014. RWE  Dea has continued its successful exploration track record, increasing its resources and options for further  developments, for example, in its Titan and Zidane projects in Norway. On this basis, we will still expect Dea to be  able to double its production to 70 million barrel oil equivalents in the course of this decade.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: In Central Eastern and South Eastern Europe, we see growth opportunities in Generation, especially in Turkey  and Poland. Please bear in mind, slide 20 gives you the divisional split of the planned CapEx. From a regional  point of view, there is, of course, an overlap. Investments from the Renewables and Upstream division can also  take place in Central Eastern and South Eastern European markets.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, we have already initiated the next efficiency program. For 2013 and 2014, we are targeting  further efficiency enhancements of approximately €1 billion per annum compared to 2012. On the one hand,  already existing measures will lead to additional efficiencies of €500 million from 2013 onwards compared to  2012. On the other hand, we are working on completely new measures of approximately €500 million.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Out of the new measures, a total of approximately €250 million is expected for 2013. All of this will help to offset  the pressure we are facing from the full auctioning of CO2 certificates which will hit us from 2013 onwards.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: We have identified the major synergies between generation portfolios of the group and have started to realize  them. Take for instance our fleets of state-of-the-art CCGTs in Germany, the U.K. and the Netherlands. In terms  of where we operate, 14 identical machines of Alstom, type GT 26 gas turbines in all of these plants. In the future,  we can benefit by sharing our experience and having a common maintenance strategy across the national  companies. This provides synergies over a double-digit million euro amount.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: This brings us to our outlook for 2012 and 2013. Corporate call press already provided you with the divisional  outlook for this year. For 2012, overall, we expect EBITDA operating results and recurrent net income to be in the  order of 2011. This means that we are able to mitigate the full-year dilution effects from our disposals of Amprion,  Thyssengas and the Rostock hard coal power plants.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: Moving out to 2013, we now anticipate to not only offset the dilution from further disposals, but also the impact of  full auctioning of carbon certificates, so we are confident that we will avoid the infamous carbon cliff. Our new  efficiency program is one major reason for the improved outlook. Last August, our outlook did not yet include the  centrally decided measures we are currently working on.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: For EBITDA, we even expect to be above last year's level. However, you have to bear in mind that our new power  plants will lead to an increase in depreciation charges.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, RWE AG
texts.text: With regard to the gas-to-oil spread situation, we updated our expectations in mid-February. We also anticipate  some successful results for our gas contract negotiations.

file: RWE - Q4 2011 Earnings Call Fixed Income 6March2012 1115 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Mar-12.pdf
RWE - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 5March2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: We have also successfully continued the renegotiation of our long-term oil-indexed gas contracts, more so than  envisaged in our initial guidance for 2012, which did not foresee a settlement with Statoil for last year. Our  solutions are fully structural and include compensation payments for past losses.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: After the conclusion of the price provision with GasTerra late last year, there is only one counterparty, namely  Gazprom remaining with whom we are still in the price review proceedings. As you are aware, these are in front of  an international arbitration tribunal and we expect a conclusion in the first half of this year. We have finalized our  2012 efficiency program which brought an accumulated €1.5 billion compared to 2006. Our new efficiency  enhancement program is also well on track with all operational measures identified and already bearing first fruits  last year; more on that in a moment.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Since most of you are following the power price development on an almost daily basis via your Bloomberg screens,  I won't bore you with the obvious, but I would like to highlight a couple of points. First, the drop in power prices  over recent weeks can mostly be attributed to the weakness in fuel prices, notably CO2 and coal.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Taking into consideration that these are the input costs of the price-setting plant in Germany, this is also the  reason why clean dark spreads stayed relatively stable. Second point, it is undeniable that the increase in  proportion of renewables in the system has led to over capacities in times of strong sunshine and high-wind levels.  This has an instant impact on spot market prices and it translates, to some extent, into forward prices. Achievable  spreads for peak capacities are particularly affected.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Third point, we can currently observe a relatively flat power curve and backwardation in clean dark spreads. This  implies that the market anticipates net conventional capacity additions in the next two years, since there are still  some power plants under construction and few firm capacity shutdowns announced so far.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Finally, renewables also have an ever increasing impact on load factors for conventional generation, especially big  power plants. Gas-fired plants have seen their running hours decline steeply over the last two years, due to the  expanding feed-in from photovoltaics during peak hours. And while many of them are no longer able to cover  their fixed or even cash costs at those reduced loads, they are still needed in times of system stress as seen earlier  this year during the cold spell in January.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: This is also not only true for old gas-fired power plants, but also for brand new ones. Take for example our Lingen  plant, which we commissioned in 2010. It only ran for some 2,000 hours in 2012, a decline of more than 50%.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Current forward prices and spreads lead to decrease in load hours and do not allow peak capacity to earn  sufficient margins. Therefore, mid- to long-term, we see the requirement for an upward correction of revenues for  peak capacities. However, while it has become clear that the current market design does not provide the required  remuneration to keep conventional capacity online to serve as backup for intermittent renewable generation, it is  far from certain how a new system might look. Regulatory uncertainty will therefore continue to make operational  as well as investment decisions difficult.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: We cannot escape the commodity price developments, but it would be wrong to just look at outright power prices.  Due to diversified fuel mix, our generation portfolio can mitigate some of the downward pressures. For example,  although lignite spreads came down from the highs at the end of 2011 and beginning of 2012, the decrease was  much more muted than the drop in outright power prices, and as already mentioned, clean spark spreads – sorry,  clean-dark spreads stayed relatively stable.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: On the other hand, our gas fleet is not only suffering from low clean spark spreads, but also decreasing load  factors due to the renewable expansion. This is particularly evidenced by our new build CCGTs, Moerdijk and  generation business will be significantly down from 2013 levels. Although our outright position is largely hedged  for 2014 and to some extent for 2015, we have been selling forward into a falling power curve and our average  achieved price will therefore come down.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The forward selling of – forward selling for our spread positions is still in early stages. While clean dark spreads  have shown some resilience, spreads for gas plants continue to be extremely low. This will impact above all on the  profitability of our Dutch and UK generation portfolio.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Overall, the outlook for our generation business is anything else but exciting. However, we should not forget that  more than half of RWE's earnings is generated by businesses other than generation. Our regulated grid business  will continue to contribute stable earning streams and even show some moderate growth potential. The European  energy transition provides some opportunities to expand our energy services business and in areas such as  renewables and upstream gas and oil, we are still developing some growth projects. Do we believe that these can  compensate for all of the earnings pressure in the generation business? No, but we're doing everything possible to  mitigate these negative earning trends further, and I will come back to some of the measures we're taking in our  new European generation company.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Well, let me move on to RWE's strategic response to these challenges and how we intend to drive the business  forward. While we still believe that the cornerstones of our strategy are valid, it has become clear that they have to  adapt some of the targets in light of the new market conditions. The new targets are based on a number of our  fundamental beliefs for RWE's role in the transformation of the European energy markets.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: First, the transformation of the European energy market is not temporary, but structural. Renewables are here to  stay and play an ever more important role. Increasing energy efficiency and distributed energy solutions will have  a further impact on the future energy landscape. Second, today's business model for conventional generation,  especially for gas and hard coal fired power plants will not persist in the future. While it is not yet clear how a new  market design might look, we have to ensure our business can cope with current market realties and be fit for  future changes.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Lastly, a significant increase in RWE's operational excellence is necessary and possible. Initiatives such as the  European generation company as well as the bundling of business support functions will identify further cost  saving potential.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: These beliefs translate into the individual targets within our three strategic cornerstones: Invest in sustainable  projects which improve our CO2 intensity and support the energy market transformation, become more robust by  focusing even more on the cost efficiency of the business and improving our financial flexibility. Maintain our  international footprint while keeping our regional focus.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The implementation of this strategy will be based on three steps. Strategically positioning, here we have to take a  look at our portfolio and ask the question about the strategic rationale of owning each individual assets. Second  step, selective CapEx; given our financial constraints, we have to ensure that scarce investment funds are allocated  more effectively and efficiently.
