After the conclusion of our power plant replacement projects, we're looking for  less capital intensive growth opportunities.  Third step, spread the assets. I might even add, spread the organization. Finally, we have to ensure that our assets  continue to earn a positive value contribution by cost cutting and other efficiency enhancements. This holds  particularly true for our conventional power generation. While growth will be limited, we believe that we can  create long-term value along this route.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me now go into more detail on these individual steps. On the back of the fundamental changes in the  European energy system as well as our current financial constraints, we've taken another look at our portfolio to  identify assets which we do not consider core and do not add much value to the portfolio or where the ownership  structure could be optimized. A similar exercise was done for the ongoing disposal program where we have  divested assets such as Berlin Waterworks or Horizon which no longer fitted with our core activities.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: As mentioned earlier, we have already sold assets for some €2.1 billion. However, we will not achieve our €7  billion targeted by the end of this year. Our current focus is on the sale of our Czech gas transmission company  NET4GAS. In addition, we are not excluding further disposals. However, this will be opportunistic with the focus  on portfolio optimization and value enhancement. This could include stake reductions in companies or assets  where we do not necessarily need to hold 100%.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Our growth ambitions and investments have also been scrutinized under these considerations. The last couple of  years have been marked by the largest investment program in RWE's history. While the renewal and  modernization of our power plant portfolio was required, it also diminished our ability to quickly respond to the  changing market conditions.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: While we're more than ever convinced that Dea is an excellent business and provides promising growth potential,  we have to ask ourselves, if we are the best owner for this business. There's only limited synergy potential with the  rest of the group, even after considering a further integration of the LNG activities. In addition, with our reduced  financial headroom, we cannot provide RWE Dea with the necessary capital to realize their growth ambitions.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Our current investment program for 2013 to 2015 adds up to a total CapEx of €13 billion. This is approximately  20% below the €16 billion we had planned last year for the period 2012 to 2014. The program is still frontend  loaded as we're finalizing our power plant replacement program in 2013 and 2014. The longer term CapEx level  will be in the range of €3 billion to €4 billion. Our day-to-day investments will be between €2 billion to €2.5  billion per annum, nearly half of this is dedicated to our electricity and gas grids. The focus of our discretionary  investment projects will remain on renewables, mainly on and offshore grids.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Outside of traditional utility business, our upstream gas and oil activities will continue to require significant  CapEx. As we have much less financial headroom, we will concentrate even more on so called asset-light growth  projects. Let me give you some examples from our German and Central Eastern, Southern Eastern European  downstream activities.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The focus in our German sales and distribution division outside traditional grid business will be on energy  services. The German Energiewende presents ample opportunities in this field. For example, there are estimates  that de-centralized CHP generation will grow by 5 gigawatts to 6 gigawatts to approximately 10 gigawatts over the  next 10 years. Projects in this area typically provide an IRR slightly below 8% with a limited risk profile. In  addition, we are developing new products and solutions partly in close cooperation with our local municipal  partners, for example for complete energy concepts.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: For the coming years, we have a CapEx budget of approximately €100 million per annum for such growth  projects. In combination with our investments at the grid business and our efficiency program, medium term, we  see for the division the chance for moderate earnings growth in a magnitude of approximately 3% per annum from  a stable vacillated earnings base.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In our CEE/SEE division, we concentrate on downstream activities in addition to our grid investments. Over the  last couple of years, we established significant market positions in either gas or electricity. The next step will be to  leverage on these positions by offering the respective other fuel and entering additional markets. The Czech  Republic for example, we're the market leader in the gas market. From this starting point, we have already gained  approximately 170,000 electricity customers to whom we provided 1.6 terawatt hours of electricity in 2012.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 13 gives you more insight into our strategic targets for the other CEE/SEE regions. Ladies and gentlemen,  the environment for conventional generators is tough and further deteriorating. But to start on slide 14, with the  positive aspects, the current situation proves that we have followed the right strategy in three aspects.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Nevertheless, the slide shows that we're facing an alarming situation. Only about 50% to 60% of our plants still  cover their costs of capital. While some 20% to 30% show a negative cash balance at current market conditions,  this clearly is not acceptable. Our prime target for our generation activities is to solve the issue of those cash  negative plants. Our current efficiency program is already a step in this direction. Out of a total €1 billion for RWE  Group by 2014, approximately €0.2 billion will be realized in a new generation company and further measures are  already in preparation. This includes plant by plant specific actions to turn them cash flow neutral or cash flow  positive [indiscernible] (23:58) two-fold, improve the cash inflow and reduce the cash outflow.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 15 gives you an overview of what we're currently working on. Let's take as an example Gersteinwerk, an old  gas-fired power plant, which we have in Germany. Last year, we temporarily multiplied the steam turbines of two  units with 355 megawatt each from April to September and we will do the same in this year. In addition, one block  is in constant cold reserve. With this and with a new operational regime, we were able to lower the cash cost by a  high single digit million euro amount.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Last December, when demand was high and renewables more or less not available, the plant was needed and  generated cash. Over the next couple of months, we will thoroughly investigate the cost structure and further  optimization potential of each individual unit. You will identify the avoidable cash costs and in cases where the  achievable margins will be sustainably below the avoidable cash costs, we will shutdown the plants. It is also  obvious that under prevailing market conditions, additional conventional new build projects will certainly not be  undertaken.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: While most of the measures in our new generation platform are still being identified, we are on track with the  implementation of our current efficiency program. In contrast to the factors driving the current difficult  environment for utilities, which are beyond our control, efficiency enhancements are one of the important  countermeasures which are within our control. We finalized the old €1.5 billion efficiency program last year. On  top of that, we already have early results from our new program. The €200 million we achieved in 2012 is partly  driven by quicker staff reductions mainly in our German businesses. Out of a total plant head count reduction of  approximately 3,700, roughly 1,000 were already realized in 2012. The achievements with our new program were  also one of the main reasons why earnings in 2012 came out better than originally expected.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 17 gives you some information about where the efficiency improvements are coming from. 30% of the new  program will be coming from the German supply and distribution business. It includes mainly non-regulated  business. In our sales business, we're working on improvements by bundling functions. In the grid business, we  will further optimize our operating costs. But efficiency measures are not only focusing on plain cost reductions,  we want to improve our earnings situation with new products as well. The German Energiewende provides  chances for this and we want to be the partner of choice in this respect.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: With regards to conventional power generation, I just explained what we are working on. In our UK as well as  Trading/Gas Midstream division, IT optimization and further automation play an important role. As a result,  especially in our UK business, significant head count reduction is envisaged.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 18 shows our outlook for 2013. The current expectation for the three main earnings figures confirm the  outlook that we gave one year ago. Thanks to our conservative hedging strategy, we feel quite comfortable with  this outlook as the margins in our generation business are already locked in. The biggest value bill is still the  settlement of the gas contract price review with Gazprom that we expect to conclude in the first half of this year.  Again, our guidance is after expected disposals, which is mainly the sale of our Czech gas transport business  NET4GAS.  As mentioned earlier, please understand that against the backdrop of an increasingly volatile business  environment, we refrain from giving an explicit long-term or longer term guidance. We will update you in  November with our concrete expectations for 2014. By then we'll have more clarity about our business activities.  But during my presentation I explained trends that we can see and Bernhard will mention further aspects in a  minute. So, it will be obvious that earnings will not match the 2013 level.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me start with the operational performance on slide 21, the operating result was up by €600 million, an  increase of 10%. This was mainly driven by improved earnings in our Germ Generation business unit after the-one  off burdens we faced in 2011 from the nuclear exit. Furthermore, we felt a positive effect from the start of our new  lignite-fire power plant in Neurath. The Trading/Gas Midstream division recovered by approximately €200  million. The energy trading activities showed a healthy and strong performance. Furthermore, we were able to  settle several oil indexed gas contract reviews.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Looking at the major value drivers, on the right hand side of the slide, our efficiency programs explain  approximately €600 million of the earnings improvement. Out of this, approximately €200 million were already  early achievements from the €1 billion program until 2014. Further positive earnings came from higher grid and  sales margins. RWE Dea did quite well due to higher oil prices and a stronger U.S. dollar.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: However, depreciation increased by €300 million as a result of our huge investment program over the last couple  of years. Electricity generation margins came down by some €100 million. We were able to offset the decline of  electricity prices and spreads to a large extent. This was especially due to the positive volume effects, mainly from  the start of the commercial operation for our new lignite plant, BoA 2&3. As a consequence of our disposal  program, we lost an operating result of approximately €100 million mainly from the deconsolidation of Amprion  in the third quarter of 2011.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let's have a look on our earning numbers down to net income on slide 22. The non-operating result is dominated  by the value adjustment of €1.7 billion for our Dutch generation portfolio. The strong growth of renewable  capacity in Germany depresses electricity prices and generation spreads in our neighboring countries. There was  no need for additional goodwill impairments. The outcome and the sensitivity of our impairment tests to the  market parameters are shown on pages 155 to 156 of the Annual Report.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Summing up all the value adjustments we have undertaken since 2010, we reached a total of approximately €2.5  billion for our Dutch portfolio. The deteriorated environment is therefore reflected in the current valuation.  Our financial result declined by about €460 million driven by an increase in the interest accretion to non-current  provisions and the higher average net financial liabilities. The first aspect relates mainly to the adjustment of the  net present value of other long-term provisions as a result of lower discount rates. Furthermore, net interest in  2011 benefited from the release of a provision made in relation to a renewables fund, which ceased to exist  following the nuclear phase-out decision.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Before I turn to the development of net debt with slide 24, I would like to briefly introduce to you the changes in  the reporting of our hedge position on slide 23. This is a result of the new Conventional Power Generation  division. You were used to the reporting of the volumes for the German portfolio across all technologies: nuclear,  lignite, hard coal, and gas.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: With the establishment of the division, we have increased the transparency by providing a split between the so- called outright and spread positions of our Conventional Power portfolio. Outright includes our nuclear and  lignite capacities. One has to admit that with regards to its carbon price dependency, lignite could also be  considered a spread position. However, due to its dispatch features, it fits more into the outright position.  Generally, we hedge the next regeneration volumes forward driven by market liquidity.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me now come to the divisional outlook on slide 25. Since the beginning of this year, the new Group structure  has been in place. Our conventional power generation activities are now within one division, and in the  Netherlands and in UK, we show the supply activities separately. Therefore, we have provided you with pro forma  2012 numbers to give you our outlook based on the new Group structure. Please note that we will provide you with  a quarterly pro forma 2012 numbers a few weeks in advance of the publication of the quarterly reports, which  should help you to work on your quarterly forecasts.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: While we see a stable or even a slightly positive development in our downstream activities, our Conventional  Power Generation business in particular, will fall significantly below the previous year for the reasons explained  earlier. However, we expect positive one-offs from the settlement of the last outstanding gas price review in the  first half of this year, which together with the achieved settlements of the last year should improve the earning  situation of our Trading/Gas Midstream division significantly.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Our Central Eastern Europe, Southern Eastern Europe division would be significantly down mainly due to the  expected disposal of our gas transport operator net for gas. But even excluding this effect as pressure on earnings,  especially because of additional burdens from the tough political environment in Hungary.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: For RWE Energy and RWE Dea, we have additional longer term targets for 2014. For RWE Dea, we can confirm  the target to increase production volumes of hydrocarbons to more than 40 million barrel oil equivalents  compared to approximately 31 million in 2012. This should be in line with an operating result in the order of €800  million.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Unfortunately, the 2014 target for RWE Energy cannot be maintained. There are three reasons for this. First, the  reduced CapEx program for the Group as a whole will also impact RWE Energy. Although we expect to spend  CapEx in the magnitude of approximately €2 billion in the next three years, this is much lower than originally  planned. As a result, RWE Energy will not be able to reach its old 2014 targets of approximately 4.5 gigawatt of  installed capacity in operation or under construction.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: We now expect RWE Energy to operate approximately 3.5 gigawatts of renewable capacity by the end of 2014.  Consequently, the target for operating result has to be adjusted down as well.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Second, the 2014 operating results target of €500 million included a significant contribution from our German  offshore wind farm, Nordsee Ost. Due to the considerable delay with grid connection, the first feed in of electricity  is not expected before mid 2014, which clearly leads to a negative impact on 2014 earnings. This is before any  compensation payments as it is not yet clear how much and when we will receive compensation for lost earnings  by the delays.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: And third, parts of our renewable generation capacity is not eligible to receive fixed feed in tariffs and hence are  affected by reduced market prices.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: To sum up, RWE Energy's operating result in 2014 is now expected to exceed €300 million, excluding any  compensation payments for the delayed grid connection for Nordsee Ost.  Slide 26, gives you the major value drivers for the development of our earnings in 2013. Our efficiency  improvements are substantial but will not be able to match the pressure on operating earnings especially from the  full auctioning of carbon certificates and the decline in generation margins. Nevertheless, and as previously  mentioned, we do expect a strong relief in our Trading/Gas Midstream division, once the last outstanding oil  indexed gas contract with price revision is settled.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The disposal program is expected to lead to an earnings dilution of approximately €200 million depending on the  disposal timing of natural gas.

file: RWE - Q4 2012 Earnings Call Fixed Income Call 8April2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Apr-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Our financial headroom in 2012 was quite positive and in line with our upgraded guidance from last November. In  2012, we also made progress with our disposal program and we have achieved €2.1 billion in asset disposals. This  was followed by the sale of our Czech gas transport company, NET4GAS, at the end of March for €1.6 billion.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Our current focus on our disposals program is on the sale of our Czech gas transmission company, NET4GAS.  Here we made good progress and announced on 28th of March the sale to a consortium of Allianz and the  Canadian infrastructure investor, Borealis. The deal is expected to close in the second half of this year. It does not  mean that we exclude further disposals however, these will be opportunistic with a focus on portfolio optimization  and value enhancement.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: I am now coming to the end of my presentation. We touched upon the major challenges we face in our generation  business in our full year call. However, we should not forget that more than half of our earnings is generated by  businesses other than generation. Our regulated grid business will continue to contribute stable earning streams  and RWE Energy is still developing growth projects.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: We are well aware of the tough environment and RWE will respond to the challenges it is facing. Taking into  account these market conditions, our prime target for the group is first to reach a balanced budget and second, to  return to a leverage of 3.0x midterm.

file: RWE - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 4March2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Otherwise, our performance was marked by two major opposing factors. On the one hand, the deteriorating  electricity generation margins, including the full auctioning of CO2 certificates burdened our Generation business.  On the other hand, the successful revision of our gas procurement contract with Gazprom resulted in a  compensation payment of approximately €1 billion.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In August, we finalized the sale of the Czech gas transmission company, NET4GAS, thereby deconsolidating the  business for the remainder of the year. This year's earnings [audio gap] (02:21) also be impacted by the disposal. I  am very pleased that our efficiency improvements are progressing well and ahead of schedule. The g roup has  achieved some €250 million more in efficiencies than envisaged for the year. This is partly due to the fact that cost  saving is becoming a matter of course to the business and I'm proud of that.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Conventional Generation can offer an attractive upside should markets improve again, but this is not a given,  since we cannot control commodity prices, nor do we see any clarity on the political front over new market design.  However, we see a kind of bottoming out in German wholesale power prices at the moment, but this is clearly  dependent on hard coal prices.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: And this brings me straight to the next slide illustrating RWE's mid-term business profile and its main earnings  drivers. A very important business as well as earnings contributor will be the regulated distribution business. In  Germany, we have regulatory certainty until 2017 for gas and until 2018 for electricity. We see some potential for  growth arising from the energy market transformation, as well as efficiency improvements and performance.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In Central and Eastern Europe, we operate distribution networks in four countries. Our main objective is to  stabilize earnings against regulatory downward pressure, which is particularly strong in Hungary. In the Czech gas  distribution business, we are in intense discussions with the energy regulator on the parameters of the fourth  regulatory period scheduled to start in 2015. Significant effort is also being invested into operational performance  and optimization.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: On the Generation side, we have RWE Innogy, working on meeting their cost of capital by 2016. This implies  finalizing the two large offshore wind farms currently under construction. Divesting non-core activities, such as  biomass and offshore construction vessels, as well as improving overhead costs. We will continue to pursue  selective growth opportunities, more on that in a moment.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The Trading activities will continue to be an integral part of RWE, [ph] as we interface trade (08:32) wholesale  market. RWE Supply & Trading is responsible for the commercial optimization of RWE's asset base. Further, the  Trading business develops growth opportunities in new Trading markets, both in terms of new regions and  energy-related product. It also targets additional profits from principal investment activities and energy -related  projects.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: After the arbitration court ruling last June, we have come to a commercial settlement with Gazprom last week. We  cannot comment on details, but under the agreement, we expect no further negative impact from this long -term  gas supply contract on our accounts until the next regular price revision in summer 2016 can be triggered. Until  then, we are confident to find an amicable solution for the open issues, so that the whole the whole gas to oil  spread problem is solved. However, RWE Supply & Trading is currently losing money, from historically  contracted long-term gas storage capacities, due to the low summer/winter spreads, which do not allow us to earn  the capacity payments. Therefore, we see the underlying earnings potential of the division more in the order of  €200 million for the time being.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: I would now like to come back to our two generation businesses and explain in a little bit more detail what we are  trying to do here. In November last year, we showed how the Conventional Power Generation would have fared in  2013 at current forward prices. Of course, the actuals came out better, since we still benefited from higher power  price hedges. Our average realized baseload price was €51 per megawatt hour. Going forward, this will obviously  come down towards the current forward price.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Clearly, the business must ultimately earn its cost of capital again and although we are restructuring the business  to move in that direction again, we eventually also need the market to reimburse backup capacity, either through  higher power prices or a change in market design. We encourage policymakers to initiate the first steps of  implementation to just design and legislation process as quickly as possible. However, this is about long-term  viability of the market framework, hence we do not expect any commercial effect to materialize in the short term.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In terms of portfolio measures, let me provide you with a short update on where we stand. Based on the regular  reviews of our power plant portfolio, we decided to mothball further capacity. The fewer operating hours  combined with the [ph] whole – a bit low (12:02) wholesale prices has made the operation of Claus C, one of our  most modern gas-fired stations unprofitable. Unit A had already been mothballed at the beginning of last year. In  addition, we have decided to reduce our contracted hard coal capacity by another 1,000 megawatt.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: As part of the overall efficiency program, these portfolio measures minimize the negative cash flow contribution of  the portfolio, while keeping some of its optionality. Further capacity remains under review and we will update you  once concrete decisions are taken.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Moving on to our renewable generation business, we see a muc h more positive trend. While we had to revise down  our 2014 outlook, we are confident that from next year onwards, RWE Innogy's operating result will start to  progressively grow on an annual basis and this is despite cutting back on CapEx.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: So where is the growth coming from? First, our two large offshore wind projects, Gwynt y Môr and Nordsee Ost  have crossed the halfway line and will come online with all turbines by year -end 2014 and mid-2015. Second, we  are still investing in growth projects, albeit on a very selective basis and through partnerships to reduce our capital  requirements and diversify risk. Third, the business is also working on restructuring and efficiency measures to  ensure it earns its capital cost by 2016.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Looking now at where the improvements to operating result are coming from, it is probably no surprise to you  that Conventional Power Generation accounts for approximately half of it, don't forget that the main reason for  bringing all of our generation assets under one roof was to enable us to raise efficiencies and reduce costs.  Measures include staff reductions in management and support functions to bring down overhead costs; lowering  of O&M costs and improvement of the availability and flexibility of our plant fleet.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Our German Downstream business contribute some 20%. In the regulated business, the focus remains on more  efficient operations and regulatory outperformance. As an example, this can be achieved by optimized  investments in the grid, which reduce future O&M costs, but simultaneously increasing the regulated asset base.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: On slide 11, we have outlined, how the efficiency enhancements impact our total controllable cost base. In 2012,  total controllable costs stood at €10.8 billion, of which €5.3 billion accounted for personnel costs. For 2016, we  see them go down to $9 billion. Adjusted for portfolio and other effects, such as the expected sale of RWE Dea, the  operational cost savings amount to €0.9 billion, representing 60% of our total efficiency program.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let me give you a concrete example. The Generation business was able to increase the output of our lignite fleet,  by approximately 3 terawatt hours, by improving its availability. This was partly achieved through better  management of different core qualities and the process optimization leading to shorter maintenance outages.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Y eah, thank you, Peter, and good afternoon from me as well. Let me give you a brief overview of the major aspect  of our business performance in fiscal 2013 on page 14. Our operating result was down as expected to €5.9 billion.  We have two main opposing effects. On the one hand, our Trading/ Gas Midstream division achieved an  extraordinary high result. This was due to the arbitration court ruling on our long-term oil-indexed gas contract  with Gazprom. On the other hand, we suffered a massive earnings decline in our Conventional Power Generation  division. Here, the new CO2 regime and declining Generation margins were the main drivers.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Despite the strong earnings decline in this division, there are positive signs. Peter mentioned already that we are  ahead of our plan with our efficiency enhancements. The box on the right-hand side of slide 14 shows a net benefit  of €800 million. This compares to our original expectation of just €550 million in 2013. We had early  achievements, mainly in our Conventional Power Generation division. One reason is the sustainably higher  availability of our lignite generation fleet that Peter explained earlier.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: In addition, we benefited from higher staff reductions. By the end of 2013, we stand at a groupwide operational  staff reduction of approximately 4,500 since the start of the program. For 2013, this means approximately 900  more than originally planned. In addition to the aforementioned trends, earnings in our Upstream Gas & Oil  division were under pressure. We suffered from the weaker U.S. currency as well as lower realized gas and oil  prices. In addition we had burdens from dry wells and delays in ramping up our production.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 20 gives the divisional outlook. I think the general trends are not surprising. Therefore, I want to keep my  presentation short and refer to the Annual Report, where you can find all the details. Slide 21 provides the majo r  value drivers for 2014 compared to 2013. I mentioned already the general trend of declining realized electricity  generation margins, the absence of the Gazprom payment in 2013 and the dilution effect from the disposal of  natural gas.

file: RWE - Q4 2013 Earnings Call FixedIncome Call 31March2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Mar-14.pdf
RWE - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 10March2015 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The transaction does not only eliminate our exposure to oil prices but also significantly strengthens our equity  capital. Our efficiency program is progressing faster than expected. We are now looking at achieving the targeted  €1.5 billion for the first two waves by the end of this year, two years earlier than originally promised.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our renewables business is on track to improve its performance by refocusing and streamlining its activities. They  have shown great financial discipline over the last two years, bringing down our capital expenditure close to  maintenance level and improving our net debt position and our cash balance.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Let's move to the first area of focus: growth. Since 2012, we have shown strong financial discipline. We have  exceeded our efficiency targets and significantly reduced our capital expenditure. We have shown financial  restraint when it comes to projects which do not offer sufficient returns to just the offshore wind project Galloper.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We've made a virtue out of necessity. We entered into partnerships for a development of renewable projects and  sold minority stakes and some regulated assets to just the gas distribution network in the Czech Republic.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The energy market is changing. Renewable energy will continue to grow in the quest of decarbonizing the energy  system. Smart infrastructures and balancing systems will become increasingly important to handle the  decentralization of electricity generation. And the drive towards energy efficiency and convenience products calls  for innovative customer solutions.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our initiatives to grow will focus on the three parts of the value chain which support and enable this  transformation of the energy market and of RWE. In renewables, we will continue to expand our asset base. Due  to the commissioning of recently constructed assets, the business will show high double-digit compound annual  growth in earnings over the next three years. The focus will be mostly on onshore and offshore wind. We will  continue to enter into partnerships to realize our attractive project pipeline while reducing our capital  requirements and diversifying development risk.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In our most recent deal in February, Statkraft agreed to buy a 50% stake in our Triton Knoll offshore wind farm  project in UK. The final investment decision will be taken in 2017.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our distribution grids play a key role in the transformation of the energy market. Investments will not only go into  maintenance, but also the expansion of the grid, enabling the integration of renewables and decentralized  generation units. The deployment of intelligent grid solutions and smart technologies will offer additional growth  potential. We are working to deliver long-term, a single-digit earnings growth rate here, although we'll have  fluctuation in individual years.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Moving on to our generation business. It will certainly come as no surprise to you that a situation in our  conventional power plant fleet has deteriorated since the last time we showed you this slide. Base load wholesale  prices have come down from €37 to €32 per megawatt hour since then. As you can see, under recent commodity  prices, only roughly 55% to 65% of our portfolio is free cash flow positive, roughly 15% points less than 12 months  ago. We've worked hard over the last months to optimize our portfolio. While we have decided to shut certain coal  plants and limited their costs, we have opted to mothball a large part of our gas-fired power fleet. This allows us to  minimize the cash burden while maintaining the option to bring them back when they will be needed and  profitable again.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Slide 7 shows how dramatic the situation for conventional power generation is. At current levels, price levels of  around €32 per megawatt hour, the division is just free cash flow neutral. In other words, it is only able to earn  the cash flows it needs to cover the current cash-outs for provisions and the required CapEx to keep our assets  running. This is not a sustainable situation long term and a clear political framework is needed in the short term.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The contribution along the value chain will roughly stay the same with RWE generation contributing about 50%,  and the supply and distribution business another 30%. A central point of attention when defining our additional  measures has again been the continuous improvement of our cost position. We are focusing on limiting cost  increases, for instance, the staff factor costs, as well as reducing our process costs.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Here are just two examples out of more than 100. In the generation business, we have optimized our requirements  for specific pipes in our plants across fuel types and increased the competition on the market. This leads to annual  cost savings of more than 20% for these pipes. And in the grid business, we were able to simplify technical  requirements together with our customers and suppliers which led to cost savings in the area of a high double- digit million euro amount.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Slide 11 outlines how the efficiency enhancements impact our total control of our cost base, as just mentioned, cost  reduction is of particular importance. About half of the contribution to our efficiency improvement will be  achieved by operational cost reductions.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Of the remainder, €1.5 billion to €2 billion will be mainly spent for renewable projects and to complete our power  plant completion program. Furthermore, we will spend a little bit in our retail business as I mentioned earlier in  my presentation.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: We continue to classify goodwill impairments as well as bookings and losses as the impact from the change in  certain derivatives in the non-operating result. Furthermore, we were suffering from the deterioration of realized  market spreads in the conventional power generation business and negative weather affects mainly now supply  businesses. This was only partly offset by our efficiency improvements, although we were able to realize them  faster than originally planned as Peter has already explained.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: First, we changed our procurement strategy for CO2 emission certificates in 2014. While until 2013, we purchased  most of the certifications in the same year as the CO2 was emitted, we shifted the timing for the purchase of the  certificates we needed for 2014 to the beginning of 2015, the year, we have to submit them. This general policy will  continue for the time being.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Second, in 2014, we had a positive weather effect in our working capital. Due to the mild weather and the effective  energy consumption in 2014, was to a large extent, lower than the advanced payments we received from our  customers. As a result, in 2015, we expect much lower cash flow from the final billing for the year 2014 compared  to the cash flow we received in 2014.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Let's now move on to slide 18. Due to the favorable cash flow trend including one-off, and the planned decline in  CapEx, we were able to reach our cash balance target one year early. We achieved a significant surplus of €1.1  billion. Mainly due to further margin erosion in the conventional power generation and the working capital effect  drawn by the weather, which I have just explained, we don't expect to achieve a positive cash balance again in  2015. Upside would come from potential cash contributions from a positive outcome of our court cases regarding  the nuclear fuel tax. Nevertheless, in general, we are sticking to our ambition of a positive cash balance on average  from 2014 onwards. Although due to the aforementioned volatility in working capital, this might be at risk in a  single given year.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Nevertheless, our achievements are better than the outlook we gave in March last year when we said we would  expect our net debt to be in this order of magnitude. This outlook was given under the assumption of a positive  contribution from the repayment of nuclear fuel tax of approximately €1.3 billion, as well as no impact from the  change in discount rates. Besides efficiency improvements, our efforts to optimize working capital were the main  reasons for the success.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Let me conclude my remarks with the outlook for 2015. First, on slide 21 for the key earning figures of the group.  Further efficiency improvements and growth in our renewables business will not be sufficient to stabilize earnings  in line with 2014. Hence, we expect EBITDA to decline to €6.1 billion to €6.4 billion. Our operating result will  most likely reach €3.6 billion to €3.9 billion and recurring net income is expected to be at level of €1.1 billion to  €1.3 billion.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: The main reason for the earnings decline is the further deterioration of generation margins in the conventional  power generation division. Let me also point out that our outlook for 2015 does not include contributions from a  positive outcome of our court cases regarding the nuclear field tests.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: On slide 23, you see the major value drivers for our outlook for 2015. I already mentioned the future decline in  generation margins, in addition, our supply and distribution networks Germany division had a very positive  earnings contribution from the sale of grid assets in 2014, which we won't see this year. Furthermore, we expect a  negative impact from the change in provisions.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: On the positive side, we expect further contributions from our efficiency program. For this year, we envisage  approximately €100 million.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: For our outlook, we have also assumed normalized weather conditions. As we don't expect similar value  adjustments that we saw in 2014, depreciation should be lower than in 2014. Last but not least, our renewables  business is expected to show strong growth due to the commissioning of new generation assets.

file: RWE - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 8March2016 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: First, we are establishing a new international company comprising our grid, retail and renewables business, which  will receive fresh capital, enabling it to fund growth investments. Second, we are implementing further significant  cost savings and efficiency measures to improve the cash flow situation of the company. And third, we won't pay a  dividend to holders of RWE common shares for fiscal 2015 in order to preserve cash and equity. However, let me  emphasize that this decision was not taken out of desperation, but rather as a result of prudent financial  management.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We want to maintain flexibility when facing our future challenges. With these measures, we aim to put RWE back  on solid ground. We will be better placed to face future developments on the commodities market. We will be able  to accelerate growth in renewables and downstream businesses with the new company. We are strengthening our  balance sheet. We will be better prepared for funding our nuclear liabilities.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In December, we informed you of our plants to bundle our grid, retail and renewables business in a separa te  company and to list a new company via capital increase. The recent slump in power prices has only underlined our  conviction that this move is necessary to secure the future of the Group.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our downstream and renewables businesses, which will form the new company, have progressed well over the last  year and have taken a number of further growth initiatives. Our grid business continue to work on new pioneer in  technologies and solutions, which will ensure the energy system's ability to integrate the ever growing renewable  capacity. We have taken further steps to develop energy storage facilities and intelligent grid devices.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The retail business also successfully expanded its activities. We entered the Slovenian electricity market and  started to sell gas in Poland and Hungary, where we already have electricity supply businesses. However, we also  took the decision to withdraw from the Turkish retail market where we do not see the opportunity to establish a  meaningful presence.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our network of charging points for electric vehicles has also grown. With some 4,900 charging stations across 20  countries, we are one of the biggest infrastructure operators in Europe in this area.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Last year, we have also agreed to equip various new customers, including Daimler and Volkswagen with charging  solutions. Our renewables business made major strides in the expansion of its installed capacity. Over the course  of 2015, we commissioned two large offshore wind farms bringing our total installed capacity to more than 3.5  gigawatts.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our operating result more than doubled in 2015 and also exceeded our internal expectations. We also laid the  foundation for further growth with the start of construction of another two offshore wind projects, Nordsee One in  the German Nordsee, and Galloper in the UK.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Let's move on to Conventional Power Generation. This business has been under persistent pressure over the last  few years and there are no signs that this is going to change any time soon, rather the contrary. The business has  worked relentlessly to take out costs and increased efficiencies. So far, we have bee n able to implement measures  with an accumulated net benefit of €1 billion to the operating results. We announced some 9 gigawatt of capacity  measures and reduced the head count by some 3,600 FTEs. However, in recent weeks, we have seen a further  dramatic drop in commodity prices, which puts many of our power plants in an unsustainable position.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On page 10, you can see the free cash flow situation of our generation fleet by technology. At current power prices,  it should not come as any surprise to you that our lignite operations, including the mines, are no longer able to  cover their full cash costs.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: With regards to the spread positions, situation is a little bit more distinct. The recent power price moves have  largely followed price developments of hard coal, gas and CO2. Our generation spreads for hard coal have  remained fairly constant in Germany, they have slightly declined in the Netherlands, and they have deteriorated  significantly in the UK.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: However, clean spark spreads have recently improved across all our large markets and they've moved quite  considerably, making parts of our gas fleet more profitable again. Nuclear operations are still cash flow positive at  current forward prices, although only marginally. Overall, at prices of €20 per megawatt hour, the fleet is not able  to cover its cash costs.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The generation business, therefore, continues its efforts to find additional measures to improve its cash flow  situation relentlessly, which is also one of the reasons we are stepping up our overall effic iency program. However,  the speed and extent of the recent power price decline will be extremely difficult to mitigate. The focus remains on  cash flow generation, but it will be challenging to be free cash flow positive at current power prices in the medium- term.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: This brings me to the overall efficiency-enhancement program. I'm very pleased to say that our efficiency program  continues to progress faster than expected. Despite the negative performance at RWE npower, we have delivered  €200 million instead of the planned €100 million in 2015. This brings the total efficiency improvement achieved  since 2012 to €1.6 billion. But we are not stopping here. In light of the deteriorating market conditions, we are  stepping up the program by another €500 million to be delivered by 2018.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As mentioned before, the focus will be on efficiency improvements in the generation business. This takes the total  program to €2.5 billion net benefit to the operating result, which I believe is a significant amount in such a short - time period.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, this brings me to our CapEx program on slide 12. For 2016, we intend to spend between €2  billion and €2.5 billion. This includes investments in growth projects. €1.8 billion is earmarked for day -to-day  spending and maintenance CapEx. This is in line with our previously communicated intentions to bring CapEx  down to €2 billion. More than half of this amount will be spent on the regulated grid business to support our  regulated asset base. In light of the planned IPO of NewCo, we intend to step up investments in growth  opportunities. The majority of growth projects are within the renewables business.

texts.speaker: Peter Terium
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: When we decided to propose a suspension of the dividend for common shares for fiscal 2015, as per our dividend  policy, we took into account not only the financial situation of the company, but also the expected mid -term  earnings development of the company. We reached this decision mainly in light of the recent dramatic  deterioration of the earnings prospects of Conventional Power Generation. The current discussions around  funding of nuclear liabilities was also taken into consideration. The decision did not come easy to us as we noted  below disappoint many of our shareholders. However, it is necessary in order to strengthen the compa ny.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The earnings development in our supply UK division has decreased by €364 million to minus €137 million. This is  mainly a result of process and system related problems with private customer billing, as Peter explained. Besides  the operational problems, lower energy consumption of customers, the shift from standard to non-standard rate  tariff and higher customer losses are also factors for the lower results. The restructuring plan for this division  means that we expect the situation to stabilize in 2016, but will only be fully solved by the end of 2018.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On the positive side, the operating result of RWE Energy has increased significantly. In fiscal 2015, we have  recorded an operating result of €493 million. Besides underlying earnings improvements from the commissioning  of our offshore wind farms Nordsee Ost and Gwynt y Môr, this is also driven by a positive one -off, above all, from  the sale of stakes in our offshore wind project, Galloper. This alone accounts for an earnings contribution of €93  million. Furthermore, the revaluation of VSE as a result of its full consolidation, it's an improvement of the  operating result in our Eastern European downstream business.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Slide 16 shows the earnings development from EBITDA down to adjusted net income. EBITDA is at €7  billion,  clearly above our guidance of €6.1 billion to €6.4 billion. This is due to the fact that we decided not to finish Bloc k  D of our hard coal power plant in Hamm. In this context, we received among other things insurance payments.  However, we had to write-off the asset fully which accounted for €654 million. But as EBITDA as before  depreciation only the positive effects are reflected in this number, while the operating result reflects the total one- off burden of approximately €130 million.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Slide 17 shows the development of our cash flows from operating activities. It comes down by €2.3 billion to €3.3  billion, mainly due to changes in working capital. First, as explained in our  most recent analyst calls, our most  significant working capital effect is a result of the revised purchasing policy for required CO2 emission certificates.  This had a corresponding positive effect on our cash flows in 2014. Second, due to volatile commodity price  developments, we had higher variation margin payments, both as part of FFO and in working capital.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Second, keep a positive cash balance long-term. Although, as previously mentioned, due to volatile working  capital, this might be at risk in a single given year. Third, dedicate financial assets to long-term provisions. In  doing so, we have now funded more than 20% of our total mining, nuclear and the non-funded pension  commitments.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Let me take the opportunity for a brief comment on the work of the Commission for financing in the nuclear exit.  At the end of February, the CEOs of the utilities met with the co-heads of the Commission. The meeting was  meant to evaluate possible solutions. The Commission is going to continue its work in order to clarify the  outstanding issues. We are in constructive talks, however, any agreement has to be acceptable for both sides.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: For 2016, in Conventional Power Generation, the major drivers expected to be lower realized generation spreads.  The strong earnings decline, we expect for our renewables business is due to the one -offs in 2015, above all from  the sale of our stakes in our Galloper wind project. The earnings improvement for our division, Trading/Gas  Midstream is mainly due to an expected normalized earnings situation from our trading activities after below  average earnings in 2015.

texts.speaker: Bernhard Günther
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In our German grid business, we see lower earnings from the sale of grid assets and higher OpEx to improve the  quality of our grid business. In Eastern Europe, we will be mainly affected by the positive one -off in 2015 from the  revaluation of the VSE participation in the context of the full consolidation of the Group. The la tter applies to our  supply business as well. Furthermore, we expect burdens from the restructuring of our UK retail business.

file: RWE - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 14March2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Operationally, we closed the year in line with our guidance. Adjusted net income was even slightly above the  range we gave in March, but we have significant one-off effect in our non-operating and financial result mainly  due to impairments of our conventional generation fleet and changes to nuclear provisions as a consequence of  the intended nuclear energy fund. We have the financing for the nuclear energy fund in place and will pay the full  amount of €6.8 billion on July 1. So, we no longer have to be a significant political risk linked to this part of the  liabilities.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: On this occasion, I'm happy to confirm that last week, an agreement has been reached with the government on a  supplementary public-law contract. It is to be signed once the law comes into force up on receiving EU subsidy  law clearance. In this context, we have agreed to withdraw from the [ph] CARD claims (02:40) related to waste  disposal and the moratorium claim. The agreement does not include the constitutional claim, nor the nuclear fuel  tax claim. For the latter, we expect a final decision this year.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: First, the decision not to complete the second block of our new hard coal-fired power plant in Hamm in 2015 led to  compensation payments of more than €500 million. While this is reflected in adjusted EBITDA and adjusted EBIT,  the corresponding write-down of the plant of approximately €650 million is included in adjusted EBIT.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: On the positive side, we will see no further burden from the nuclear fuel tax, which will by law phase out at the  end of 2016. In 2016, we paid approximately €0.15 billion. In addition, we are working on further efficiency  improvements.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Now, onto the performance of the Trading/Gas Midstream division. Adjusted EBIT fell by approximately €300  million to minus €145 million, as a result of the negative trading performance especially in the second quarter.  Although it is a high loss, it is still in the range of our expected business volatility. At the Capital Markets Day, we  will provide a comprehensive insight into the performance and management of this division.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 8 shows the details of non-operating result, which is dominated by the impairment charges mainly on the  German generation fleet and the risk premium on the nuclear provisions of approximately €1.8 billion with the  nuclear energy fund.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Financial result on slide 9 also contains significant special items. It is impacted by the adjustment of the net  present value of the nuclear and other long-term provisions. Furthermore in 2016, we incurred losses from the  sale of securities, while in the year before we realized profits. In 2017, we will see [indiscernible] (09:25), a decline  of the regular interest accretion to provision of approximately €0.4 billion to €0.5 billion as a result of the lower  discount rates and the externalization of nuclear provisions into the nuclear energy fund.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Now, onto adjusted net income on slide 11. Here you see the details of the adjustments which lead to an average  adjusted net income of €777 million in 2016. Let me give you some explanations to the individual adjustments. As  usual, the complete non-operating result is reversed. In the financial result, the adjustment of the net present  value of the nuclear provisions due to the change in real discount rate is eliminated.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: On slide 13, you can see the details of our net debt development. It came down by €2.8 billion since the end of  2015. The proceeds from the listing of innogy and further sales of innogy shares more than outweighs the  additional burden from the risk premium for the nuclear energy fund of €1.8 billion and the increase in provisions  due to lower discount rates.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Nuclear provisions increased by €2.2 billion to €12.7 billion at the end of 2016. This splits into €7 billion which will  be transferred into the nuclear energy fund and the residual nuclear provisions for the decommissioning of the  nuclear power plants and operational waste management. The €7 billion is a fully consolidated figure which  includes E.ON's minority stake in the Emsland nuclear power plant. The economic stake for RWE is €6.8 billion.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The residual provisions which will stay on the RWE's balance sheet amount to €5.7 billion. Here we have digested  an additional €0.9 billion from the change of the real discount rate from plus 0.9% down to minus 0.9%. This is  partly offset by the release of provisions due to lower expected decommissioning costs.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let's now look at the liquidity position of RWE stand-alone. We have said that we want to pay the €6.8 billion into  the nuclear energy fund on July 1. On slide 16, you can see that we have sufficient funds available. The  remaining available liquidity after transferring €6.8 billion to the fund amounts to some €3 billion at December 31.  In addition, we have our commercial paper program in place, of which €0.5 billion were used at the end of the last  year. Finally, we have a committed syndicated credit facility of €2.5 billion and uncommitted bank guarantees of  €2.3 billion as additional reserves.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: We expect adjusted EBITDA to reach between €5.4 billion to €5.7 billion and adjusted net income of €1 billion to  €1.3 billion. Adjusted EBITDA would be moderately above 2016 due to improved earnings in our Trading/Gas  Midstream Division and a better expected result at innogy. This over compensates an expected earnings decline  in the generation business. Adjusted net income shows disproportionally strong increase.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: 2016 was a year of significant restructuring and heavy burdens for RWE. We have a significant liquidity  requirement in 2017 to finance the nuclear energy fund. Against this backdrop, we don't see any room for paying  a dividend on common shares for fiscal year 2016.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Furthermore, we are looking at RWE stand-alone and not the consolidated IFRS figures. This means that the  operating cash flow from joint Conventional Power Generation and Trading/Gas Midstream and the dividend that  we receive from innogy are relevant. On that basis, we have set the 2017 dividend target at a level which we can  afford mid-term from an earnings and cash flow perspective. At the Capital Market Day, we will provide you with  more details on the different elements of our cash flow to give you a better feeling on how the dividend might  develop.

texts.speaker: Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Furthermore, we want to improve the general transparency of the operational part of our business. You will have a  chance to meet senior management of our operational business, Conventional Power Generation and  Trading/Gas Midstream and use this opportunity to drill deeper in these units. I'm looking forward to seeing many  of you in two weeks' time in London.

file: RWE - Q4 2017 Earnings Call Sale of Innogy Stake of RWE AG to EON SE 13March2018 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Welcome to the RWE Conference Call on the Sale of Energy Stake to E.ON and the Business  Performance for RWE's Fiscal Year Results 2017 with Rolf Martin Schmitz and Markus Krebber.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Thank you, Gunhild, and good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Today, we cannot only look back at a very  successful first year for the new RWE, but also look ahead to an exciting future. Before I go into the details on the  sea change deal, we have agreed with E.ON that we'll very quickly highlight what we accomplished last year.  RWE's core business performed strongly last year. Supply & Trading restored its profitability. Commercial asset  optimization achieved above-average earnings contribution, and our efficiency program is well on track.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Adjusted EBITDA therefore came in above our expectations, and adjusted net income is at the upper end of the  benefits. I'm also pleased that we have restated a dividend for fiscal 2017. Both, the executive and supervisory  boards [ph] have proposed in which (00:01:46) operational dividend of €0.50 as well as a special dividend of €1  per share as part of the refund of the nuclear fuel tax through the AGM next month.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In mid-2017, we saw the discussions on the responsibilities for nuclear waste disposal come to a successful  conclusion. We were able to transfer the full amount of €6.8 billion to the government at the first possible date  without any negative implications for our balance sheet, rating or liquidity situation. The conclusion of a property  contract with a German government also provides us with a high level of legal certainty.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: At our Capital Markets Day last year, we committed ourselves to the value maximizing management of our innogy  stake. We believe yesterday's announcement goes a step further. With the envisaged transaction we are  transforming RWE into a leading European generation company providing both clean renewable power as well as  security of supply. The combination of innogy and E.ON's renewables businesses will also create one of the  largest platforms in Europe in this field. In offshore wind, we will become the second largest operator. The scale of  the combined operations will provide scope for efficiencies and a platform for attractive growth opportunities.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Our leading trading platform will provide the commercial link between renewables and our flexible conventional  generation portfolio. As renewables become increasingly competitive and moving towards deregulation, we see  attractive opportunities to optimize the combined portfolio. The transaction will significantly enhance our earnings  and cash flow profile.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Page 6 shows the shape of RWE after the conclusion of the transaction. At that point, we will be a fully  operational company again. The combined renewables business will provide us with a strong new operating  segment, while we will also have access to an attractive portfolio of financial assets. The assumption of innogy's  gas storage supports Supply & Trading ambitions to grow its gas and LNG business. With gas gaining in  importance, the storage facilities will become more attractive again in future.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let's now have a look at the combined generation portfolio. Together, with the two renewables portfolios of innogy  and E.ON, we will have a highly diversified and well-balanced generation mix. Over 60% of the capacity will be  CO2-free or low emission. This includes our highly efficient gas fleet. The renewable capacity will clearly de-risk  our generation portfolio with regards to carbon.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: However, I would like to briefly comment on our efforts to reduce CO2 in our conventional generation fleet. Since  2012, we have continuously reduced carbon emissions. Last year alone, we brought down our emissions by more  than 10% compared to the previous year and this at a time when CO2 emissions are stagnating in Germany. We  will continue to strive to bring down emissions, but see our conventional generation fleet with its reliable and  flexible plants as an important part of the future energy system.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The new combination allows us to provide both clean as well as reliable energy, something which will become  increasingly important as the energy transition is to be successful. Over time, renewables will have to be operated  in the wholesale market either because their subsidy schemes expire or they need to prevail in highly competitive  auctions. Our commercial asset optimization is ideally positioned to integrate an increasingly merchant  renewables portfolio with our flexible generation portfolio to extract value by optimizing this combined portfolio.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: On page 8, you can see that this transaction is also transformational for the renewables business. Combining the  two platforms of innogy and E.ON will create the third largest renewables player in Europe. In offshore wind, we  will become the second largest player. The focus of the two renewables businesses is currently on onshore and  offshore wind. However, both players have ambitions to grow in solar as well as battery storage solutions and  have recently taken steps to develop their capabilities in this area.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Regionally, the combined portfolio is well balanced. In addition, E.ON's platform provides a strong operating  onshore wind platform in the U.S., a market where innogy intends to grow and has recently agreed to acquire a  development pipeline. We are convinced that the enlarged portfolio provides the scale to prevail in this  increasingly competitive market and scope for optimization. At the same time, there's a financial headroom to  develop this business further as we see attractive growth opportunities in onshore and offshore wind as well as  solar.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Slide 10 shows the key transaction parameters. Fundamentally, the transaction is an exchange of assets. E.ON  will acquire our 76.8% stake in innogy for an equity value of €17.1 billion, which equals €40 per share. The  minority shareholders of innogy will get a €40 cash offer from E.ON. This implies an equity valuation of innogy of  €22 billion and an enterprise value of €43 billion. This is equivalent to an implied EV to EBITDA multiple of 10.5  times, based on expected 2018 earnings. In exchange for the value of €17.1 billion, we will get the renewables  business of E.ON and innogy. This excludes minor renewable assets held by the different regional companies, as  well as a 20% stake in Rampion.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Furthermore, we received innogy's German and Czech gas storage business as well as its 37.9% stake in Kelag.  In addition, we will take over E.ON's minority stakes in our nuclear power plants Gundremmingen and Emsland.  We will also receive shares in E.ON amounting to a 16.7% stake post transaction. These shares are entitled to  dividend payments from fiscal 2019 onwards.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: For all the efforts we receive, especially the renewables businesses, we are entitled to the economic success  from January 2018 onwards. For technical reasons, we will also receive the innogy dividend for fiscal 2017 and  2018. Therefore, the transaction includes a balancing cash payment of €1.5 billion from us to E.ON.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Rolf already mentioned the strengthening of our financial profile. With regards to our earnings, we see a step  change as our EBITDA will double as a result of the transaction. Income from dividends will be of minor  importance in the future with over 90% of earnings coming from operational businesses. Renewables will account  for approximately 60% of pro forma EBITDA.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In addition, we will have a higher degree of feasibility for our medium-term earning development, as  approximately 50% of our expected operating EBITDA will come from contracted businesses such as capacity  payments for conventional power generation, ROCs, CfDs, PPAs or fixed feed-in tariffs for the renewables  business. The transaction will also improve our financial position. As a result of the transaction, we will only  assume approximately €2.8 billion of debt to our standalone balance sheet.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Since we are becoming a mostly operational company, we can also look at traditional leverage ratios again, which  do not make much sense for RWE standalone now. Post transaction, we expect our net debt to EBITDA to be  between 2.5 times and below 3 times. We expect this to be in line with our current investment-grade rating which  we are strongly committed to maintain. We have the financial headroom to support all existing growth ambitions in  both renewables businesses. In addition, the financial portfolio provides additional financial flexibility.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In the second step, E.ON will implement steps to further – to gain full control of innogy under corporate law. Once  this is finalized, the final transaction steps will take place. We will receive the innogy and E.ON renewables  businesses, the gas storage activities as well as the stake in Kelag. We currently expect the whole transaction to  be closed by year-end 2019. As you can see, the transaction is complex and will take almost two years to  complete.
