During this time, we will continue to steer the company with our economic view on RWE standalone,  and we will provide full disclosure and transparency on its main KPIs. This will be important, as the transaction will  have significant implications for our IFRS group results.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Before we come to your questions, let me reiterate the strong strategic rationale for this transaction and the  compelling outlook for RWE. For RWE, this is a unique combination of our existing business model of a provider  of security capacity with the growing market of renewables. Our leading commercial asset management and  trading capabilities will ensure that we can extract additional value from the combination of the combined  platforms. This will become even more important as more and more renewable assets will become merchant over  time.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: I will not go into the details of our 2017 results. Gunhild already mentioned that you can find all the details in the  usual format on our website. However, let me just address one question upfront, which we receive frequently the  moment and which relates to our carbon exposure. Our implicit fuel hedging approach allows a more flexible  hedging than the old linear hedge path. We have made use of that and have already today hedged our implicit  financial carbon short position until the end of 2022. That's for the next five years.

file: RWE - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 14March2019 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Gunhild Grieve
texts.profession: Head of Investor Relations, RWE AG
texts.text: Thank you very much. Good morning to everyone on the phone and to those of you who are joining us via  webcast. I'm joined here by Rolf Martin Schmitz and Markus Krebber for the presentation on fiscal year 2018 and  the outlook for 2019. Rolf will give you a strategy update, focusing on the progress of our transaction with E.ON,  as well as the status of the discussions around the German coal phase-out. Markus will provide details on our  2018 financial performance and the outlook for 2019. As always, in order to focus on your questions, we have  kept it short.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Thank you, Gunhild, and hello, ladies and gentlemen. 2018 has been pivotal for RWE's future. We have laid the  foundation for the transformation into a fully operational company, again, with a strong and sustainable platform  for future growth. With the envisaged asset swap with E.ON, we are creating the leading renewables player. The  combined platform will be the third largest in Europe and number two in offshore wind globally. More than 60% of  our generation portfolio will be CO2-free or low carbon emitting. And it is also this part of the portfolio in which we  will focus our future growth efforts. The execution of the transaction is well on track and fully within our timeline.  We are also making good progress with the integration planning to ensure a swift and smooth integration of the  new businesses.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: After intensive analysis and works, the Commission on Growth, Structural Change and Employment presented its  final report at the end of January. While the Commission's proposals will have wide range in implications for RWE,  we believe that they provide a good basis to achieve mutual consent on plant closures, providing planning  certainty for our lignite operations.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Irrespective of the discussions of the goals set out, we continue with our own efforts to reduce RWE's carbon  emissions with changes to our generation portfolio. And last but not least, we decided to propose to this year's  AGM, the conversion of our preferred shares into common shares. With this step, every share will bear a voting  right, which is customary on international capital markets and called for by many institutional investors. The  proposed conversion aims not only to strengthen our corporate governance, but also to improve our shares  trading liquidity. This is in the interest of all RWE shareholders.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let's now have a look at the progress of the transaction with E.ON. We are well on track with the execution of the  transaction and have taken important steps into integration planning. Since our last results call in November, we  have reached some major milestones. Most relevant filings with competition authorities have been submitted. We  have appointed the future renewables management team under the roof of the RWE and we have formulated a  high level strategy for the renewables business.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: On the 17th of January, we announced the future management team and presented the target operating model of  the combined renewables business. The team will be headed by Anja-Isabel Dotzenrath as Chief Executive  Officer who is currently CEO of E.ON's Renewables business. It will further consist of Holger Himmel as Chief  Financial Officer and Tom Glover as Chief Commercial Officer who will be in charge of the commercial  management of the renewable assets.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Holger is currently CFO at innogy Renewables and Tom brings his extensive expertise from RWE where he is  currently responsible for the commercial asset optimization of our conventional generation fleet. The team will be  completed by three Chief Operating Officers who will lead the operational units and be responsible for project  development, as well as construction operations. We are excited to have been able to nominate a highly qualified  and diverse management team with extensive expertise and international experience in the field of renewable  energy.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Before Christmas, we also concluded our high level strategic considerations. The transaction is going to create a  leading renewables player in Europe with a strong position in the U.S. However, our clear strategic ambition is to  take this newly created platform and build a truly global renewables player. The focus will be on the three leading  technologies, Wind Onshore, Wind Offshore, and Solar PV added by storage technologies where we continue to  cover the whole value chain from development through to commercialization.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: We see that these are ambitious aspirations, but we are excited by how the two renewables businesses have  progresses after the last 12 months, and we are confident that the new team will drive the business forward once  the transaction is closed. They will also develop and define the high level strategy further on which we will provide  more details after closing.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Let's now have a look at our current business portfolio. Slide 9 provides an overview of selected focus areas of  our three segments. Within the Lignite & Nuclear segment, we have turned our particular attention to the  decommissioning concept of our nuclear power plants. We have developed a new process focusing on end-to- end dismantling approach, Lean principles and a zero waste attitude in order to optimize the total  decommissioning costs. We've been starting this new approach this year at our Biblis nuclear power plant and  rolled it step by step out to the complete fleet.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Moving on to the European Power segment. In October, we have decided to de-mothball our Dutch CCGT Claus  C with the capacity of 1.3 gigawatt. Improved generation spreads and market perspectives led to this decision.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: We will also continue with the conversion of our Eemshaven and Amer 9 hard coal fired power stations to  increase the biomass coal firing capabilities. The current coal firing capacity at Amer 9 amongst the 50% and is  targeted to reach approximately 80% by early 2020. We are also working on diversifying our biomass sourcing  and focusing on identifying additional sources of biomass.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: The focus in the UK is clearly of the management of our generation fleet during the suspension of the capacity  payments. The UK government is sponsoring the reinstatement of capacity markets. That is continuing to operate  a scheme short of making payments to ensure that capacity providers maybe eligible with deferred payments. We  continue to maintain the availability of our power plants and are in constant dialogue with relevant authorities and  other stakeholders to manage the suspension and the impact on our portfolio.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: For Supply & Trading, the focus remains on growing its global LNG business and to expand the Asian business.  In late December 2018, we signed an agreement with the Australian oil and gas company Woodside for the mid- term supply of LNG. This transaction represents another key building block in the further development of RWE's  flexible LNG portfolio.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Supply & Trading also realized further milestones in its Asian expansion. The Singapore office converted into a  principal trading enterprise, which is now concluding both physical and financial transactions in most energy and  energy-related commodities. We also expanded our presence in China by successfully establishing a wholly- foreign-owned enterprise in Shanghai and a branch office in Beijing.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, Germany should end coal-fired power generation latest by 2038. This, together with  significant early plant closures, was a recommendation by the Commission for Growth, Structural Change and  Employment in the final report.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: As the report did not provide specific details on which plants to close, the majority of early lignite closures are  expected to take place in the Rhenish mining area. RWE is prepared to shoulder the lion's share of some  measures until 2022. However, the implementation of these recommendations will have wide ranging implications  for our lignite operations and employees. It is therefore only right and consistent that the Commission stipulates  adequate compensation for these plant closures, and it is also obvious that compensation must be significantly  higher than the one paid for earlier shutdowns.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: In contrast to the security reserve, the suggested additional plant closures will also have an impact on our mining  operations including substantial redundancies. The Commission also expressed its desire to preserve the  Hambach Forest. We are currently analyzing the technical feasibility of this request. What is already clear is that  maintaining the forest will cause additional burden.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Having said all that, we believe that the Commission's proposal is a good basis for discussions with the  government. We have a clear chance to reach an agreement on the phase-out of coal-fired power generation in  Germany, which will be supported by a broad public consensus. It would ensure that the energy sector will reach  its ambitious climate targets and provide planning certainty for operators.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, RWE is fully aware of its environmental and social responsibility, especially when it comes  to climate change. We therefore have set ourselves ambitious CO2 reduction targets and our efforts are paying  off. Since 2012, there's been on a continuous path to bring down our carbon emissions. In 2018, we saw another  reduction of 10% compared to 2017. This means that we have now lowered our emissions by more than 50  million tonnes or 30% compared to 2012, which puts us fully on track to achieve our 2030 target. This  implementation of the Commission's recommendation would accelerate our emissions reduction and end coal- fired power generation by 2038 at the latest.

texts.speaker: Rolf Martin Schmitz
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, RWE AG
texts.text: Coming back to the more immediate future, it is clear that 2019 will be a transformational year. We are working  full steam ahead on the execution of the transactional preparation for the integration of the renewables business.  We are excited and looking forward to become a leading renewables company as well as developing and  expanding business further.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Our hedge strategy has also shown to be beneficial in light of the recent development in spreads, as you will see  later on our hedge slide. And against the backdrop of a volatile and rising CO2 market, our strategy to hedge our  portfolio against higher CO2 prices proved to be the right decision. As part of the optimization of our capital  structure, we announced at the beginning of February that we would exercise the right to redeem the £750 million  hybrid at the first call date on March 20 this year.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Further cost improvement had a positive effect. By the end of 2018, we had reached our efficiency improvement  target of €200 million targeted for 2019 compared to 2016 for the most part. CapEx in 2018 remained on a  relatively high level. This is driven by accelerated resettlement activities in our lignite mining business. We  currently recognize an increased interest from affected residents in the mining area to move location in light of the  ongoing uncertainty. We expect a similar trend in 2019.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: The outlook does not yet include any potential impact from the proposal of the Growth, Structural Change and  Employment Commission. We have to await the outcome of the negotiations with the government, while it  remains unclear what impact the proposed coal phase-out will have on our earnings. We currently don't expect  major implication for our adjusted EBITDA in 2019.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: The European Power division shown on slide 17 realized an earnings decline of approximately €130 million. Out  of this, €80 million refer to non-recurring items in fiscal year 2017 mainly from the sale of real estate in the UK.  Our hard coal and gas plants realized lower margins. However, we saw higher revenues from the UK capacity  market, but this was less than we had originally expected. Under the UK capacity market regime, we had secured  payments of approximately €100 million for 2018. For Q1 to Q3 2018, we received payment of around €50 million.  The remaining €50 million for 2018 are outstanding as the UK capacity market was suspended in November last  year after the decision of the European Court of Justice

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: The UK government has indicated that it want to maintain the capacity market which prompted the EU to open an  in-depth investigation last month. We will have to await the EU Commission's decision to know if we will receive  the suspended payment at a later point in time. Operating cost improvements were another positive factor. Similar  to our Lignite & Nuclear division, we have already achieved our efficiency targets that we had set ourselves for  2019 for the most part. At European Power this is an annual efficiency improvement of €100 million compared to  2016.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: CapEx increased to €245 million. This is driven by higher maintenance CapEx for our generation fleet and growth  projects such as our biomass conversion in the Netherlands. We expect CapEx to stay on this level in 2019. We  will see a peak in inspection and overhauls of our gas and hydro assets in 2019. For our earnings outlook for  2019 of €250 million to €350 million, we don't assume any income from the UK capacity market as long as the  legal situation is unclear. Originally, we had secured revenues of approximately €180 million for the fiscal year  2019.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Now to our current hedge position on slide 18. Average hedge prices for our outright position in 2020 and 2021  increased by €1 and €4 respectively compared to the level we reported in Q3. The gain of €4 per megawatt hour  for 2021 is mainly due to the increase in hedge ratio from more than 60% to more than 80%. Additional hedges  were concluded at market prices which were significantly above the average hedge price. However, locked-in  carbon cost also increased to €7 per megawatt hour. This increase in carbon cost is rather moderate because the  financial carbon exposure above the market pass through factors was hedged in the past at favorable prices.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: The outright volumes showed on this slide reflect the expected production restrictions from the court decision on  the Hamback Forest. Due to optimization measures, we expect only a negative impact of approximately 5 terawatt  hours for 2019. And for 2020 and 2021, our expectation is more towards the upper end of the corridor of 9  terawatt hours to 13 terawatt hours. The slide does not yet include any impact from potential further plant closures  as a result of the proposal from the Growth, Structural Change and Employment Commission as it's still unclear  which plants will close by then. We hope to have more clarity by the end of this year.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Let's move on to Supply & Trading on slide 20. Adjusted EBITDA has held slightly short of our average earnings  level of approximately €200 million while trading closed for the year below last year's level and our principal  investment business suffered from a value adjustment. Our gas and LNG activities again showed a very strong  performance.

texts.speaker: Dr. Markus Krebber
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of Executive Board, RWE AG
texts.text: Furthermore, the distributable cash flow is lower than we expected in Q3 2018 when we guided for a positive  change in operating working capital. This is a timing effect due to higher gas inventories as well as unusual high  net accounts receivable. We expect this to reverse in 2019 which ceteris paribus will have a positive effect of  approximately €250 million on our change in working capital for this year.

We also  saw solid growth in Austria, up 9.7%, and in Switzerland, which grew by 4.7%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: With a focused organization and motivated team, we continue to seize opportunities as market  rebound, building on strong position in key growth segments such as lighting retrofit, renewable  energy, and major projects.

In North America, we continue to see a  strong rebound in sales, with double-digit growth in the quarter after 9.4% growth in Q4 2010. This  is mainly due to a very strong performance in Canada.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In France, which represents 35% of our sales in Europe, we continued to improve strongly over the  previous quarter, with sales up 7.7% versus a 2% growth in Q4 2010. Germany was almost stable  despite a challenging comparable basis, as Q1 2010 was boosted by strong photovoltaic sales.  Excluding photovoltaic, sales grew by some 10% year on year. Significantly, this quarter we saw a  return to growth in the UK and Spain. The UK grew by 1.5% and Spain grew by 2.9%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: On Slide 20, as usual, we provide you with a progress report on our four key growth drivers. As expected, photovoltaic sales fell at the  Group level by 16.4%, but this decline was due to Germany, where photovoltaic sales in Q1 2010  was unusually high in anticipation of the phasing out of tax incentive at June 30th last year.  Excluding Germany, we doubled our photovoltaic sales in other countries.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: IPG, our international structure dedicated to big global EPCs, posted a 22% increase in sales. A  very strategic move was done recently with the creation of a global division that will help to align  with our goal as the global supplier organization and validate our approach to the EPC market.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Wind sales, as expected dropped as the continued overstocking at the turbine manufacturers.  Overall, our structure organic growth drivers posted a double-digit growth if we exclude the  extraordinary impact of photovoltaic in Germany. We are strongly convinced that major countries  will review their energy strategy and accelerate the development of renewable energy and energy  efficiency program. This represents a fantastic growth driver for Rexel that will probably accelerate  from 2012 onwards.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: On the right-hand side, you can see that Rexel was awarded a major contract in Scotland to  provide €1.5 million of lighting supply to the New Forth Valley Hospital. This is the biggest  commercial project in Scotland. These two projects illustrate how Rexel has gained a major  foothold in big projects involving lighting and energy efficiency.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: In the UK, sales grew by 2.5%, particularly boosted by photovoltaic sales, but unfavorably impacted by branch  closures. And excluding these impacts, the underlying sales trend in the first quarter was plus 0.9%.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: In Germany, sales grew by 4.3% also boosted by strong photovoltaic sales, ahead of a reduction in subsidies. And  excluding this impact, the underlying sales trend in the first quarter was plus 0.9%

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: Thank you very much, Michel. So, let's move to slide 16. As usual, we provide you with a progress report on our  structural organic growth initiatives, four specific areas of the business we focus on. These areas together grew  66% in the quarter to €136 million. And they all recorded strong double-digit growth. Lighting retrofit was up  50% year-on-year. Photovoltaic sales boosted ahead of the planned reduction in incentive in certain countries  grew by 66%. The recovery in wind was substantial and continued this quarter with a very strong 176% growth  rate. And lastly, IPG, our International Projects Group, posted 24% growth in the quarter. So, the strong growth  registered through our structural organic growth initiatives makes us confident that we will achieve our target of  €650 million in sales in the full year.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: Now, on slides 17 and 18, I would like to share a couple of examples of how we run the business in those specific  areas. On slide 17, specifically, you'll see a case of a major lighting retrofit project that we have carried out in the  UK. We have signed a contract with the New Look fashion brand to upgrade its existing halogen lamps to LED  lamps in 650 stores nationwide. And Rexel's added-value offer consisted specifically in offering solutions and  services and to leverage – and we were leveraging our Rexel's branch network to support and accelerate the switch  to energy-saving lighting. So, over the lifetime of the project, Rexel expects sales of £650,000, generating a return  on investment of 15 months for the customer.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: Second example you'll find on slide 18, which provides you with an illustration of how we are leveraging our  expertise in the area of renewable energy with contractors. In partnership with Scott Electric, we installed solar  panels at a high school in California in order to reduce its energy consumption. It is a $1.5 million contract, which  demonstrates how Rexel, through its Gexpro operations, can provide value-added services to contractors in  addition to delivering equipment.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: On slide 23, we featured the acquisition of Erka, a major player in the distribution of electrical supplies in Spain's  Basque country. This company was founded in 1975. It's based in San Sebastian and this family-owned company is  specialized in electrical building and industrial equipment, lighting, engineering, domotics, energy efficiency and  renewable energies. This acquisition will contribute by helping us on the synergy side to optimize our back office  and logistics operations in Spain and to broaden our national coverage as Rexel was not previously present in the  Basque country. Operating through 10 branches and employing 95 people, Erka should generate €35 million of  sales on an annualized basis. And will be consolidated as from June 1 this year.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: Now, as you can see on the second table, sales in Europe continue to be impacted by a sharp drop in photovoltaic  sales. texts.text: So, let's go into some country detail now on slide five. We have the key countries features – featured. This performance was  broadly in line with the previous quarter, taking into account also the very poor weather conditions in March that  impacted logistics activities for a few days. But we continue to gain market share in the quarter and we did a  wonderful job in terms of profitability.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: In Germany, also here, factoring out the base effect of strong photovoltaic sales in Q1, 2012, sales were down 1.9%,  which is actually a limited drop and which reflects the resilience of the industrial end markets and the renovation  segment. texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: On slide seven, you have a bit more detail. Reported sales in North America were up 8.2%. In U.S. specifically, our sales benefited from the recovery in the  residential market as well as improved trends in industry. As indicated earlier, the wind industry was negatively  impacted by the change in tax incentives, which led to a 63% drop in the quarter of sales. So, excluding this  impact, the U.S. were up 4.5% year-on-year. We're very encouraged by this performance, which comes amid other  positive signs of an incipient recovery in the U.S., such as housing statistics and business indicators like the ABI,  for the commercial end market, continue to indicate.

file: RXL - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 30April2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Apr-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: Let's start on slide three that details our sales performance. And as you can see, the past quarter saw Rexel  returning to organic growth and sales for the first time since the first quarter of 2012. As the chart indicates, we  continued our trend of sequential improvement quarter-after-quarter and posted a Q1 2014 growth of 0.4% in  constant and same-day sales. This is, I think, a significant achievement given that this growth included two  negative impacts. First, 1 percentage point impact from lower copper prices, and secondly, 1.3 percentage points  impact from lower activity in North America due to the extreme weather conditions in the U.S. and Canada over a  good part of the quarter.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: With the exception of North America, the three other regions in which we operate posted organic growth. Asia  Pacific was up 3.8% driven by very strong performance in China. Latin America was up 3%, thanks to continued  recovery in Chile and solid performance in Peru. And more importantly, as it represents 57% of group sales,  Europe was up 1.6% driven by Northern and Central Europe while our operations in France continued to be very  resilient and outperformed the market. As regards to North America, restated for the weather conditions that  represented a 3.9 percentage point negative impact, our sales would have been up 1.1%.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: Moreover, our adjusted EBITA was also impacted by a €7 million effect from the weather conditions in North  America that I mentioned previously, which means that without that effect our adjusted EBITA would have  reached €144 million or 4.6% of sales stable year-on-year. So given our performance in the first quarter, we  confirm the 2014 targets that we indicated in February.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: In the UK, sales returned to grow this quarter with sales up 0.9%. And actually, if you take into account the  closure of branches as the result of our restructuring program of last year, on a like-for-like basis, we would be up  3.2%. Obviously, there's still – this reflects the macroeconomic conditions in the country which are gradually  improving, as well as higher sales in photovoltaic and the project business as I was talking about earlier.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: Let's move to slide seven with North America which accounted 32% of sales. As previously mentioned, sales and  profitability in the quarter were strongly impacted by the implications of extreme weather conditions in much of  the zone. The estimated impact of the weather conditions is actually indicated on the table on the bottom part of  the slide. Our sales were down in North America 2.7% on the same-day basis; while in normal weather  circumstances, they would have been up. Gross margin in the quarter rose by 20 basis points to 22.2%. Actually  reflecting improved margin performance in the United States were also the share of warehouse sales that carry  higher gross margin increased against the share of direct sales.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: Our adjusted EBITA was down 24% in the quarter, but it would have been down only 8% without the weather  effect, and adjusted EBITA margin would have decreased by only 40 basis points, which is actually a reflection of  the impact on the OpEx side of the U.S. network optimization program, which is currently underway and carries  slightly higher cost than expected.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: In Canada, representing slightly more than one quarter of the region's sales, the weather impact was even  stronger. Sales were down 5.1%. Factoring out the impact of weather, we would be almost stable. Important to  mention is solid photovoltaic equipment sales growth, but on the other side, a drop in cable sales.

texts.speaker: Catherine Guillouard
texts.profession: CFO, Group SVP & Member-Management Board, Rexel SA
texts.text: Let's look now at the 0.4% organic growth in greater detail. Same-day sales excluding copper were up 1.4% in the  quarter. This marked a return to growth and sequential improvement of 150 basis points over the 0.1% growth  recorded in Q4 2013. Copper had a negative effect of 1% as an average copper price in the quarter stood at $7,000  per ton compared to close to $8,000 per ton in Q1 2013. There was no calendar effect in the quarter. The new  sequential improvement in same-day sales would have been even stronger without the negative weather impact in  North America, which represents 1.3% at group level.

texts.speaker: Catherine Guillouard
texts.profession: CFO, Group SVP & Member-Management Board, Rexel SA
texts.text: Cost control will remain a key focus going forward in the context of positive sales momentum. We already  indicated at the start of this presentation that the bad weather condition in North America represented a net  impact of €7 million on adjusted EBITA as a result of lower activity and additional costs. We state for this impact,  our G&A expenses in Q1 would have represented 20.3% of sales, down 30 basis points year-on-year. And our  adjusted EBITA margin would have been flat year-on-year at 4.6%.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: Thank you very much, Catherine. So I'm going to conclude straightaway with the last slide, slide 21, which  reiterates our outlook for the year. Again, in the context of Q1, where the recovery clearly is underway in a number  of European countries with the exception of France, where we remain determined to continue to do better than  the market, and considering the North American situation with the bad weather conditions, we think we are in the  right place to confirm our outlook.

In Peru, sales increased by 32.4%,  thanks to increased customer penetration and acquisition.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Of course, since we announced these targets in February, we've seen the first quarter changes in the business  environment. On the negative side, for instance, the oil and gas activity started to drop earlier, and also faster than  expected throughout the first quarter impacting our North America platform, but also Southeast Asia.

So, excluding copper, that means 3.3%. In both the U.S. and Canada, sales continue to be  impacted by the oil and gas situation that began, as I said also earlier, beginning in Q2 last year.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In the U.S., sales were down 3.6% on a constant and same-day basis, but it's important to understand all the  elements. Actually, oil and gas impact on an overall basis is 4.1 percentage points of sales negative, as sales to the  oil and gas segment fell by 42% in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: There is also an impact of lower cable sales, representing 2.2 percentage points. And remember that last year, we  implemented a significant branch network footprint optimization program that was implemented in the second  quarter, which has some impact around the top line, actually, 1.6 percentage points in Q1.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Canada, sales were down 7 .4% on a constant and same-day basis. Also here, let's have a look to the main  elements. Photovoltaic sales  represented 1.1 percentage points. Sales dropped by more than 90% in the quarter. So, that is a business that is a  project business and quarterly sees variations. file: RXL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 27July2012 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: Now, this sequential growth is partly attributable to a significant slowdown in photovoltaic sales, and more  generally, the weaker demand from the industrial end-market. So overall, we saw a slowdown in sales in some of  our major markets. In France, actually, sales fell 2.8% due to a drop in demand from large industrial companies,  slower construction and cable sales.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: And in U.K., the drop in project activity linked to the completion of major Olympic projects contributed to a 3.3%  fall in sales in the quarter. And in Germany, sales fell by 5.4%, but actually were almost flat, if you exclude the  effects of photovoltaic sales. In Southern Europe, sales were down 7.2%. But I think it's important to highlight that  this is a sequential improvement over the 22.6% drop, which was recorded in the first quarter.  And in Netherlands, sales continued to be weak, reflecting both the difficult markets and the business  transformation that is underway. But we've got positive news from countries like Austria, which grew by 10.8% in  the quarter and to a lesser extent from Switzerland and Scandinavia, which grew respectively by 2.8% and 1.5%.  But despite the overall slowdown in sales, we managed to improve our adjusted EBITDA margin in Europe to 7.1%  of sales both in the quarter and in the half year.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: It's important to note that both countries continue to feel the impact of a difficult macroeconomic environment.  And New Zealand, in particular, is impacted by branch closures, and by persistent delays in the post-earthquake  reconstruction projects in the Christchurch area.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: One area has to do with high-potential business categories related to energy efficiency, renewable energies and  building automation. Second area focuses more on international customers and projects. And thirdly, we have  identified specific vertical markets, in particular, oil and gas and mining, as areas of priority.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: Now, for the sake of bringing it to life, I would like to share with you two case studies. The first one, on slide 18, is  Capitol Light which is related to our activities in the energy efficiency segment. Capitol Light is one of our U.S.  subsidiaries specialized in offering value-added lighting solutions for the retail sector. And Capitol Light's full- service offer aims at providing turnkey solutions from store concept and design to retrofits of existing installation  to a broad range of retail businesses. We have a very dedicated business model, a dedicated – specialized technical  commercial team, and a customized supply chain in order to quickly and efficiently address the needs of our  clients.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: And by helping them to boost sales, as well as reduce their energy bill, and improve their productivity, Capitol  Light offers its clients high return on investments. I think we can say that Capitol Light successfully became the  market leader in U.S. for specialty retail lighting. Between 2009 and 2011, its sales have grown by over one-third,  and its profitability both in terms of gross margin and EBITDA are above Rexel's average in the U.S., But even  more important is that, in the first half this year, year-to-date, organic growth exceeds 20% with continued  improvement of profitability.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: So, it is indeed a very good example of how a vertical market approach with a dedicated business model can drive  performance levels that are above average growth and profitability. It fits perfectly in our Energy in Motion  approach. And it is a repeatable model for the future.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: The second case study is focusing on how we make key countries work together with our international teams to  accelerate the development in vertical markets such as oil and gas. We actually won in the U.S., a $20 million  MRO contract with a major international player in the oil and gas segment. And that contract comes on top of the  $15 million contract that we had already won with the same customer in Canada.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: So, it's a good example of a multi-country approach, which establishes Rexel as a partner of choice in the oil and  gas segment. It is, again, confirming that the choices we've made in the context of our Energy in Motion plan  work, and that focusing on key vertical markets is an important source of growth going forward.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: If you compare that with the 4.7% decline in organic sales on an actual-day basis in H1 at group level, clearly, this  is a very solid performance and a validation of our strategy. texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: Our adjusted EBITA was down 14.4% in the half, but it would have down only half of it without €7 million impact  of weather in Q1. texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: Slide 26 provides you with a snapshot of the performance in the first half. texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: With regards to the international customers and projects which combines our International Key Accounts and  International Project Group divisions, we see mid single-digit growth. texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: We are also implementing a fully-fledged customer segmentation and management system in France, as we think  we have the momentum to even step up our competitive advantage in that sense. We are also deploying a new  business activity called Rexel multi-energy in France, with the aim of broadening our energy efficiency spectrum  with interlink solutions that are not just limited to the traditional electrical space, but mix various applications  and products and services ranging from gas boilers to hot air pumps, heating floors and photovoltaic energy.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: Lastly, we concluded a joint venture agreement in Saudi Arabia to increase Rexel's penetration in the oil and gas  segment, again, consistent with the strategy. We will own a 65% of that venture, with the remainder owned by Al- Hobayb, the leading Saudi group, with expertise in the electrical industry. Headquartered in Riyadh, Rexel Arabia  Electrical Supplies will address both large-scale projects and the traditional electrical distribution market, and we  target annual sales of at least €25 million by 2017.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Thank you, Catherine. So, we go straight to slide 23, in order to give you an update and a bit more color on how we  view the two key factors that impact our sales and profitability. On the one hand, sales to the Oil & Gas segment,  and on the other hand, copper prices.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Concerning Oil & Gas, we mentioned in this presentation that our sales to that segment declined strongly in Q2 as  a result of the suspension or downsizing of several projects in the wake of falling oil prices. And as mentioned, the  impact was particularly strong in our North American business. Given this performance, we now estimate that  sales to the Oil & Gas segment in the full year could fall by between 25% to 30%, which is actually equivalent  between 1% to 2% of our group sales.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: With respect to the copper prices, the evolution has been below our expectations. As you see, on the right-hand  side of the slide, prices in dollar terms were down by 17% in Q1 and over 10% in Q2. Copper prices are currently at  around $5,500 per ton. And assuming that this price remains constant in the second half, we estimate the  following impacts.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And actually, in view of the first half performance we detailed today, on the one hand; and the lower-than- expected copper prices and performance over the oil and gas sector, on the other hand, we expect to be at the low  end of the range represented in February. And the way we express this is that we expect an organic sales decline of  maximum minus 2% for the year and an adjusted EBITA margin of at least 4.8%. And regarding cash flow, we  stick with our at least 75% of EBITDA conversion rate before interest and tax, which corresponds to an around  40% of EBITDA conversion rate after interest and tax.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The adjusted EBITA margin target for the full year 2015 obviously represents a year-on-year improvement in  adjusted EBITA margin in the second half, building on the sequential improvement we recorded in Q2. I think  we've been very clear today about the cost-efficiency measures we're implementing, which should contribute to us  achieving that target. And on the gross margin side, we have very specific action plans in place to maintain the  momentum we've seen increasing in the first half. And our teams are mobilized and incentivized to that end.

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Rexel SA
texts.text: Well, thank you, Michel. As you know, we have identified four key growth drivers: energy efficiency, photovoltaic  equipment, renewable wind energy and major international projects. Let me provide you with a brief progress  report.

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Rexel SA
texts.text: Lighting retrofit continued to show a solid increase of 16% in the quarter. This is driven by initiative throughout  the group, like what we are doing now with our Newey & Eyre subsidiary in the UK. We have set up a national  team of eight energy advisors who can provide audits, lighting retrofit solution for the benefit of our clients. This  new team targets £1.5 million turnover as soon as 2012. As expected, photovoltaic sales fell at the group level by  14% in the quarter. But this decline was due to Germany where photovoltaic sales were down 53% year-on-year,  owing to the phasing out of tax incentive at June 30 last year.  Actually, excluding Germany, photovoltaic sales in other country grew by 10% in the quarter. We posted a very  strong growth in the quarter with a doubling sales in Q3. We won a major contract in the U.S. to supply the  world's largest land-based wind farm in Oregon. The farm generates capacity of more than 900 megawatts and  Rexel supplied components and services for $11 million in 2011. This positions Rexel as a major player in the  distribution and supply in the wind industry.

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Rexel SA
texts.text: IPG, our international structure, dedicated to major projects with global contractors was slightly down in the  quarter but 7% up over the nine months. Overall, our structural organic growth drivers, SOGs, posted organic  growth of 21% in the quarter and 29% over the nine-month period, excluding the extraordinary impact of  photovoltaic in Germany.

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Rexel SA
texts.text: We are strongly convinced that major country will review their energy strategy and accelerate the development of  renewable energy and energy efficiency programs. This represents a fantastic growth driver for Rexel that will  probably accelerate from 2012 onward. Actually, in conclusion, our performance since the beginning of the year  has been solid. Organic growth in October stood at about 4.4%. Taking into account the less favorable impact of  copper prices and copper comparables, these figures confirm solid volume growth in line with the third quarter.

texts.speaker: Patrick Berard
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: In Canada, sales were down 4%, a sequential improvement after drops of 7.4% and 7.1% in Q1 and Q2, of which  0.4 percentage points is attributable to the 6% drop in sales to the oil and gas industry, 1.4 percentage points  attributable to the 50% drop in sales to the wind industry.

texts.speaker: Patrick Berard
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: In Southeast Asia, sales dropped by 13.3%, most of which came from a 38% drop in sales to the oil and gas  industry. In the Rest of Asia, sales grew by almost 26% driven by double-digit growth in India and the Middle East.

texts.speaker: Catherine Guillouard
texts.profession: CFO, Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Group SVP, Rexel SA
texts.text: In Q3, copper continued to represent a negative effect of 0.9% versus a negative effect of 1.2% on average in the  six previous months. Overall, in the nine months, copper had a negative effect of 1.1%.

texts.speaker: Patrick Berard
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: Conversely, copper should impact our sales less negatively than in the previous quarters. The current price is  around $4,700 per ton versus an average of $4,882 per ton last year, same quarter.

file: RXL - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 27October2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Oct-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Berard
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: In the U.S., our sales were up strong 4.3% despite a 1.2% negative impact from Hurricanes Irma and Harvey. But  very fortunately, our teams in installation were largely preserved from the effects of the hurricanes.

texts.speaker: Patrick Berard
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: On the Project side, sales growth is back in positive territory, notably thanks to the Oil and Gas business which  grew by 30%. The business remains affected by the non-renewal of a wind contract with a large contractor and by  disruptions in the supply chain of one of our large supplier.

texts.speaker: Patrick Berard
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: Canada saw a slight drop in sales of 0.4% in Q3, mainly due to a more challenging base effect. Sales were  impacted by the absence of a large wind contract that boosted Q2 2017, but oil and gas sales were in positive  territory in the quarter, mainly due to a maintenance activity in the midstream market.

file: RXL - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 31October2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Berard
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rexel SA
texts.text: We confirm our expectation of a positive impact of 2% on the full year. And quite importantly also to all of us,  Canada sales were up 4.8%, driven both by mining and a large wind project, but also by very focused sales  organization by the two banners which contributed for 2% – I mean, the mining and large wind, 2% of the 4.8%  and the rest being the focus of our teams.

texts.speaker: Laurent Delabarre
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Rexel SA
texts.text: Concerning currency, we expect the foreign exchange effect to continue to ease over the year and our forecast,  assuming spot rates remain unchanged, is an impact of minus 2.6% on sales in full-year 2018. As shown on the  chart on the bottom right-hand side, we saw a lower contribution from copper price at plus 0.3% in Q3. Based on  current copper price, we expect now our copper contribution to go to minus 0.5% in Q4. On the bar chart above,  you clearly see that the comparable base will become more challenging in Q4.
