texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 5 Pascal Martin, Group Senior Vice President, Business Development and Corporate Operations  Thank you, Jean-Charles. Good morning. Now to illustrate these levers and more specifically those  are related to business opportunities which we’ve identified as being high priority. This was  described on 4 December Investor Day. Number one, we’re going to tackle the energy efficiency  market energetically. We’re doing – we’re calling this lighting retrofit. What this means is replacing  obsolete lighting equipment with high performance equipment when it comes to energy savings.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now, renewable energy, wind, solar, we’re going to tackle those segments as well. We have  international scale projects and our service provision is quite unusual and indeed unique and is a  way to address the needs of our large international contractors. These segments account in 2009  for sales of €250 million approximately and by 2012 the increment will be another €400 million.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now this set of value-added services will come along with a high degree of profitability. Now to be  more specific or to take a closer look at some of these, when it comes to lighting, for instance, what  do we mean? A few examples of what we’ve got in our portfolio for hotels or retirement homes.  These are French projects between five and €20,000 projects. We provide service when it comes to  the choice, the technical choice, technological solutions.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Another illustration for a larger size project, a hospital in Germany, we provided everything from  project management to technical solutions and implementation. Lastly, a somewhat different  example. Related equipment, a parking lot, we put in a low energy consumption equipment with  automatic triggering of alerts if there’s intrusion into the parking lot. And this equipment makes it  possible to decrease the use of energy of those buildings. Those are energy efficient solutions.  These illustrations which might seem to be anecdotal to you highlight significant aspects of our  business assets.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Number one, we can provide a service to the customer, which is a turnkey and seamless and the  value-added is significant. When we perform an energy audit, when we fill out all of the  administrative forms to make it possible to access funding from local authorities, well, from the  customers standpoint, this is a huge simplification, a tremendous service. And these services are  based on the sale not of products or technology but we sell a return on investment. From the  customer standpoint what we’re offering is a way to save money.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Second illustration in a related area, world of solar panels. Such an installation is complex. Even  though seen from the outside it looks pretty straightforward, just a bunch of panels placed in  parallel but that’s 140 components you’re looking at, connected altogether and then they represent  140 suppliers.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now we have to bring together all these components and get them to work together successfully  and we provide a full service coverage. In France to access state funding for solar panels, we have  to fill out five different documents, technical, administrative. You have to write to the different  agencies and you also have to work with the tax authorities. In Belgium, if you state funding, you  have got to comply with entirely different rules. So in spite of the small size of Belgium, the  complexity is genuine.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We also worked on setting out a school in France in Poitiers and we put in equipment in the amount  of about 700 solar panels. This type of school uses about €170,000 of energy. That’s the energy  bill. And the solar panels brought down energy bill to €700, almost erasing it from their budget. And  for the customer the acquisition cost is zero because of the availability of state funding. And a  school equipped with solar panels has got high symbolic value. So it’s a win-win situation.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: This example here is the extension of a gas terminal in Georgia, U.S. This is €200 million in cost  and the share of ours – our share was $50 million. And the illustration here revolves around three  basic points. Number one, the contractor was CBI, Chicago Bridge & Iron Company. They are very  familiar with this business and we’ve had business ties for many long years and they’re always –  they always turn to us for such projects.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And thirdly, we can organize a distribution of products to the different electricians working on their  premises and makes it much easier to conduct this type of project, €1.5 billion worth of bill. We  started in 2008 and it’s just about to be completed. We do a large number of such projects around  the world, we are working on a project called Gorgon, which is also the extension of our gas  terminal in Australia, hundreds of billions of dollars in that case. So, all of these examples will make  it clear to you that we know how to take up opportunities as they come along, given our assets, our  ability to replicate and given the fact that these are highly buoyant industries, major projects, new  energy sources, renewable energy sources. This is a new business ultimately, and we’re now able  to  provide our customers with a full service provision.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: I would also like to recall that we’re focusing more and more on certain countries, where beyond the  adjustments due to the business climate structural adjustments were required in our view, the U.K.  is one, U.S. is another, particularly Rexel network and Spain. In U.K. macroeconomic synergy with  Hagemeyer, in U.S. we’re going to pursue the work that we already undertook to consolidate Rexel.

file: RXL - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 9February2011 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze, Chairman – Management Board
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: Now let’s look at the major regions around the world. We’ve got slide six here, let’s start in Europe.  In the fourth quarter organic growth was high in Switzerland, Austria and Finland. Plus 9.7% in  Switzerland, plus 12.5% in Austria and plus 12.7% in Finland. There was substantial growth in  Germany too, plus 6.6%. And if you factor out photovoltaic sales, you’ve got that picture there. So,  as of late 2009 and for the first part of 2010, photovoltaic sales in Germany were boosted by tax  incentives and they went down as of 1st of July. France level, plus 2% growth. The UK was down  2.5%, there was an improvement in the previous quarter.

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze, Chairman – Management Board
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: Southern European countries saw an improvement in the last quarter, in particular, in Italy with  growth up 18.3%. This was boosted by photovoltaic business. And Spain has almost broken even.  In 2010, we saw there was another increase in our market share in three key countries, which are       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze, Chairman – Management Board
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: You can see that it’s quite diversified. There’s good growth in energy efficiency. In our terminology,  this means proposals to customers covering order to work, the service provision, project  management, lighting retrofit and so on. And this is working within and in stores. You may be  thinking of we’re selling green labeled products, but we’re not talking about that because 60% of  our lighting sales are for bulbs which are energy-saving bulbs. But we’re talking about different  things. We’re talking about the development of our business model where we provide a very high  service level for our customers, in particular it’s the customer relationship and the type of service  we provide for them. And this gives us very high profit level and it’s certainly two digits growth and  it’s well above the group average.

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze, Chairman – Management Board
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: Secondly, we also have photovoltaic business there. I’ve mentioned that it’s a fluctuating business  and of course it depends on different policies and the incentive schemes in the countries. But when  you can look at the figures comparing 2009 and 2012, there’s significant growth there and half of  the business there is in Germany. So 2011, there’ll be growth, but it will not be as high as this  because we won’t have the impact of the incentives that were available in Germany in 2010.

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze, Chairman – Management Board
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: For wind, we’re coming back to a good level there. There was inventory there at the time of the  financial crisis, and it was not possible to start producing again, but we’re using up the inventory  and some businesses [inaudible] up again there and it looks promising for years to come.

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze, Chairman – Management Board
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: On the next page, we have what we call vertical approach to energy efficiency. We’ve seen this –  we want to have something, which is reproducible and have a systematic approach in different  areas. Now, what are we talking about? Now, we’re talking about car dealers where they own sites  or branches where we’re working and they have huge car lighting systems, and we have to find the  lighting sources. These lights are on 24 hours a day, so it’s high-energy consumption even  [inaudible] many customers are around in the middle of the night. We’ve looked at technological  changes; we’ve got detective systems to detect movements, for example. And there’s great energy  saving up to 50% of energy consumption there. And these energy sources can often be replaced  and we can get lighting systems with lifetime of $100,000, it’s quite something.

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze, Chairman – Management Board
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: Industry, page 26, this is a similar approach. We have a dedicated team here for the industrial  customers, and this is a bit different because here we’ll take the lighting system of a major industrial  plant, now this is the leader in pulp and paper. And this customer wants to optimize lighting and  energy consumption. We looked at a whole lighting area and there was a saving of around 70% in  the energy consumption there. And this was a good prototype, but it was really very convincing,       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze, Chairman – Management Board
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: The next page shows you – this type of approach can be adapted to other customers. We have  dialog with customers; we show them simple operations, get their interest to change the lighting.  For example, these are things that are very easy to understand and you can show the return on  investment, which is good. And then, when you get a good customer relationship, you can get more  operations, which are more sophisticated, you can improve their air-conditioning system and you  can even put solar panels on their roofs.

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze, Chairman – Management Board
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: Here we have an industrial customer producing – started with dairy work, and then there’s also  poultry. We’ve started off looking at the parking facilities, and then we put solar facilities on the roof,  and this is 1.1-megawatt facility. The process is easy to understand at the beginning, but then it  goes and becomes more sophisticated, it’s a three-month process. This is not just selling products,  you have a real dialogue with your customer and you sell services and you work on all the different  elements. You provide documents, administrative work, so that the customer can get any financial  incentives or government aid which is available. But the lighting here was some €500,000 in sales  and we’re reproducing this on other sites. And now it’s often the financial managers at the site  confirm the deal with us.

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze, Chairman – Management Board
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: The last illustration is on page 29. I would like to point out that we’re dealing with the manufacturers  of the different components, all the different parts, which you can see there, the C-class  components. They’ve got the hardware, the towers, hoists and so on. It’s quite a range of products,  and it’s an industrial environment, which is highly structured and we provide these products as part  of the renovation programs for these wind towers.

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze, Chairman – Management Board
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: You can see the energy there, we’ve developed business in Brazil, we’ve got companies, we’re  talking about a Spanish company which is a leader in the business, leader in the automotive  business, as well as in renewable energy, and is moving into Brazil, and we hope to work on  operations there, so this is good for our capacity.

texts.speaker: Jean-Charles Pauze, Chairman – Management Board
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: Jean-Charles Pauze, Chairman   Thank you, Pascal. Let me conclude our presentation. I’d like to highlight our prospects or answer  to 2011. 2010 has been a year during which we have started to grow again. Michel was mentioning  a turnaround or turning the corner and 2011 will make it possible for us to continue this  improvement all through the year. The economic outlook on our various markets are quite favorable  and we continue with determination our strategy to seize all kinds of new opportunities and services  and solutions in dynamic areas, like energy efficiency. It’s a very interesting area for us and a very  interesting market and we have a strong position. Another interesting market for us is renewable  energy. We trust that volumes are going to go up in 2011 in order to support our organic growth  and we will continue, of course, to continue adopting an active external growth policy, particularly in  the high-growth markets.

file: RXL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 10February2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In Canada, organic same-day growth stood at 7.6%, mainly driven by industrial end-market, not only in the  mining and oil and gas sector, but also by telecom and renewable energies. In North America, overall adjusted  EBITDA margin rose 110 basis points to 5.6% in the quarter reflecting recovery in sales and improved cost  structure. In the full year, sales grew by 8.3% on a constant and same-day basis and adjusted EBITDA margin rose  100 basis points to 4.4%.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Member-Management Board, Rexel SA
texts.text: Now we believe that Rexel has a structural ability to generate organic growth that outpaces GDP growth. On one  hand, we are focusing our efforts and investments on developing more aggressively in fast-growing markets. And  on the other hand, we are further expanding our offer of value-added services notably related to energy efficiency  and projects with international customers.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Member-Management Board, Rexel SA
texts.text: On Slide 30, as usual, we provide you with a progress report on our four structural organic growth initiatives, and  some of you know the acronym, the acronym is called SOG. Now, these four drivers represent a real or key organic  growth accelerator for the group. In total, they grew by 23% last year to €526 million. And this strong  performance was achieved despite the unfavorable base effect of photovoltaic sales in Germany that were boosted  in 2010 by tax incentives. So, eliminating this base effect, the four structural organic growth initiatives together  show a growth of 39% in 2011, and on average over the last two years they grew by 37%.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Member-Management Board, Rexel SA
texts.text: Lighting retrofit projects posted the strongest increase with 57% growth in 2011 and 68% on average over the last  two years. The photovoltaic part of the portfolio recorded a 4% decline in 2011 due to the already mentioned  unfavorable base effect of sales in Germany, but it delivered still a solid 29% growth on average over the last two  years.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Member-Management Board, Rexel SA
texts.text: Wind has posted a very strong 56% growth in 2011, offsetting a poor 2010, and it grew by 12% on average over the  last few years. And then, last but not least, IPG, our international organization dedicated to major projects with  global engineering companies posted a 28% increase in 2011 and a 52% increase on average over the past two  years.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Member-Management Board, Rexel SA
texts.text: This product category of course benefited from the impact of energy efficient lighting, which represented about  one-fifth, about 20% of the total lighting sales, which is about €400 million consolidated sales. In there, as part of  the €400 million, the lighting retrofit projects which are indeed a priority area for us as you saw on the previous  slide grew by 57% in 2011.  And it's really a proof point of a vertical market approach, a very specific dedicated focus on a specific dedicated  market by implementing a sales model that is based on specific dedicated teams offering full service assistance to  customers including audits, administrative report, financing solutions and project management skills.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Member-Management Board, Rexel SA
texts.text: It's also important to mention that lighting and energy efficient lighting and in particular, the lighting retrofit  projects do not only have an above average growth performance, but are also above average profitability  contributors, which helps to drive better performance of the group overall. So, we believe this segment remains  and should remain a priority and it will give us further upside going forward.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Member-Management Board, Rexel SA
texts.text: Slide 32 illustrates how we are increasingly providing value-added services to our clients related to energy  efficiency and renewable energy. And as you can see on this slide, in the UK, we have identified the growth  opportunity working alongside local authorities, municipalities, counsels to provide energy-efficient services to  social housing development.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Member-Management Board, Rexel SA
texts.text: In these projects, Rexel is not only delivering products, it's not only providing supplies such as photovoltaic  equipment, but it also adds bespoke kits turnkey packages and assembly services and technical support. And these  examples you see in this slide, in Surrey in Scotland generated sales of more than £2 million in 2011 and can be  replicated on a much broader scale both in new building and in the renovation projects.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Member-Management Board, Rexel SA
texts.text: Similarly, IPG concluded a major contract with WorleyParsons to provide supplies and services for a major oil  refinery project in the Middle East, and here we expect to build more than €6 million in 2012 due to this contract.

file: RXL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 12February2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And then finally, the third highlight of the year was the launch in May last year of our new company plan, Energy  in Motion, which in fact is Rexel's medium-term roadmap, which focuses on four main pillars, four strategic  priorities, four drivers of value creation.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: First and foremost, it talks about profitably growing both organically and through acquisitions notably by focusing  on promising high potential segments linked to energy efficiency, renewable energies, building automation, as  well as expanding our business with leading global customers and through international projects and developing  specific vertical markets such as oil, gas and mining.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: By country, the picture is as follows: in France, sales was down 2.1%, which, however, marked an improvement  over the 4.9% drop posted in Q3. In the UK, sales were down only 3.5% excluding the base effect of strong  photovoltaic sales last year, which was a rather limited decline as Q4 2011 also benefited from major Olympic  projects.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In Germany, sales went down 2.4% excluding the base effect of strong photovoltaic sales in Q4 2011. And in  Germany, we've seen industrial end market and export activity slowing in that quarter. In the Benelux, we saw a  2.7% drop in sales in Belgium excluding the PV effects. And in the Netherlands, we posted a 16.1% drop, which  continues to reflect both and to a large extent the difficult markets, as well as the business transformation process  that is under way.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: On a constant and same-day basis, sales were down 8.7%. As in Australia, representing 60% of our sales in the  region, constant and same-day sales were down with 13.6%, which continues to reflect the tough macroeconomic  conditions in the country, nothing new, we've seen that for a few quarters, impacted also by low commodity prices,  as well as the impact the effect of mining and projects of the new carbon tax and regulations implemented as from  July 1.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And then in China, which represented about 30% of our sales in the region, sales were down 1.5% on a constant  and same-day basis, but that is very much impacted by a strong decline in the wind sales. Because if you exclude  wind sales, sales were actually up 7.5% in Q4 versus 1.1% in the previous quarter. So the core business performed  very well.  Because of the effect of Australia, as I mentioned before, adjusted EBITA margin in Asia-Pacific as a whole fell  230 basis points to 3.3% in the quarter. Gross margin in there fell by 190 basis points due to the conditions in the  Pacific countries. So there's also a mix effect. But the 6.7% reduction in operating expenses partially offset the  8.9% fall in actual daily sales.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: When we actually presented our Energy in Motion company plan last year in May, we shared with you what we  thought would be the critical success factors. Now, one of those critical success factors was to actually make  progress in key markets and particularly in UK and U.S. And at that time, we articulated bold ambitions, which I  would like to comment on page – on slide 28 starting with the UK.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: As far as UK is concerned, we posted sales of over €1 billion last year, up 9.3% year-on-year, which included a  positive effect of the consolidation of Wilts since March. On an organic basis and excluding both the negative  effects of photovoltaic sales and branch optimization, sales were down only 1.8%, which constitutes a very solid  performance taking into account the difficult market environment in the UK. You're all aware of the economic  situation and also taking into account the fact that 2011 figures were boosted by activity linked to the Olympic  games.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: So on slide 31, we give you an update on the organic growth sides. We, in fact, looked at three areas of growth:  high-potential business categories, international customers and projects, and specific vertical markets. So with  regards to the high-potential business categories comprising energy efficiency, the renewable energies and  building automation, we posted a growth of 9.5%, but if you exclude the renewable energies, which as you know,  behave very erratically and which were negatively impacted by changes in regulation in 2012 both in photovoltaic  and on the wind side, growth of this business category – of the high-potential business category was up 19.4%.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: So, in 2012, we acquired 12 companies that allowed us to make headway on all three of those fronts. We made two  strategic acquisitions in the U.S. with Platt and Munro, which significantly strengthens our position on the West  Coast as well as in the northeast of the U.S. and which perfectly fits our Energy in Motion strategy by accelerating  the development of energy-efficient solutions particularly through the acquisition of Munro.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: So let's move to the next chapter of the Energy in Motion story. We talked about accelerating in key markets. We  talked about focusing on the engines of growth. Let's now talk about a third critical success factor that was  highlighted last year, which is about enhancing our organizational effectiveness, which brings us to slide 36.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: So, in this position, Gonzalo is in-charge of accelerating the implementation of group and country initiatives  related to the earlier mentioned high-potential business categories such as energy efficiency, renewable energy,  building and home automation. And in that context, to make sure that category management has the – is tightly  connected with strategic supplier management. He's working on and responsible for strategic partnerships with  key suppliers to make sure that, from a marketing standpoint, we are completely aligned.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: So by aligning our accountability structure with our strategic priorities and also strengthening, reinforcing the  capabilities and the competencies with very dedicated and single accountable management, we think we're  creating the enabling conditions to successfully implement our Energy in Motion company plan.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: So she will succeed Michel who announced his decision to step down in October 2012 to pursue new career  opportunities. And Michel will remain in his position until Catherine's arrival beginning of May latest. And I'm  absolutely convinced that Catherine's management experience and financial acumen will be strong asset for Rexel  and of tremendous value in the implementation of the group's Energy in Motion company plan.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: Please remember that we created a new position of Group Senior Vice President Operations actually focusing on  one of the pillars of the Energy in Motion company plan, IT, supply chain management, CRM and e-commerce  and sales force automation. Peter Hakanson is in-charge of that position, and he joined us last July.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: And just to complete the story, as I mentioned before, we have Jean-Dominique Perret today as the Group Senior  Vice President Human Resources. He will retire latest by the end of the year, and we are currently searching for  his replacement. So we will make sure that in terms of transition, continuity and consistency in the way we run the  company, everything is in place to do a quality job.  So let's then move to the last critical success factor I would like to highlight with respect to our Energy in Motion  company plan, which is about the drivers of operational performance. And I would like to feature three key  elements. One, on slide 41, it's related to what we call multi-channel sales development, particularly related to  what e-commerce is bringing us and can do for us going forward. I will talk about pricing and financial discipline  in a minute.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: And, of course, from a CapEx standpoint, this business is a low capital intensity business. So this is also reflected  in our low percentage of sales dedicated to capital expenditure, which consistently remains around 0.8% of sales.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: So with that overview and then having highlighted the – I would call it the four key success factors, the critical  success factors of the Energy in Motion company plan we announced last year, I think we can say that in 2012 we  lived up to our commitments. We did what we promised to do. We have traction in every area. And I'm confident  that we will be able to keep that momentum, and if possible, we'll do everything to accelerate that momentum.

texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: So let me now conclude the presentation with slide 45, which summarizes or I would say articulate – it's probably  a better way of saying it our 2013 outlook. Now, clearly, the ongoing uncertain macroeconomic climate leads us to  exercise caution with regards to 2013. Nevertheless, we target slightly positive organic sales growth for the year as  a whole. The trend is likely to remain negative in the first half. We expect to return to positive in the second half  and that in particular due to improving indicators in North America and in fast-growing countries.  From a profitability point of view, we aim at maintaining profitability levels, we aim at delivering a stable, solid,  robust adjusted EBITA margin of 5.7%. We also aim at generating free cash flow before interest and tax again  above €600 million corresponding to around €300 million after interest and tax.

texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: Now, having discussed the geography, I still would like to make a point about how we did with our high-growth  initiatives. texts.speaker: Rudy Provoost
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Rexel SA
texts.text: And I think we've managed that part of the business extremely well. Everything included, we had a growth of  5.7%. texts.profession: CFO, Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Group SVP

And in addition, we confirm our dividend policy of paying out at last – at least  40% of recurring net income.

And we also  decided in the course of the year to launch refinancing operations to seize market opportunities to reduce the cost  of our debt, allowing us to maintain a sound financial structure.

texts.text: We're in a good business, because there are now new avenues by which growth will come on top and above of  the previous usage. And IoT is not something totally neutral. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Rexel SA
texts.text: But one more important thing, whether we took carbon-free, I know only one carbon-free real way of getting there,  electrical. And therefore, very often we forget to look into it, but  obviously, there are macroeconomic cycles, but there is also a resilient growing demand for electrical product at  the same time by structural support and evolution, and very often we forget about this. file: RYA - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 25July2011 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: The traffic growth in Q1 was flattered by the airspace, the volcanic ash airspace closures in April and May last  year, which caused the cancellation of 9,500 flights, and the loss of almost 1.5 million Ryanair passengers. So, our  18% traffic growth combined with an 11% rise in average fares led to a 29% increase in revenues. Significantly  higher revenues were largely offset by higher costs, principally fuel, which rose 49% to €427 million. Despite  substantially higher fuel costs, we still recorded profit after tax of €139 million, slightly up on Q1 of last year. Our  robust results are testimony to the strength of the Ryanair lowest fares/lowest cost model.

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: Fuel prices remain stubbornly high, as spot is trading at around $116 a barrel. We're 90% hedged for FY12 at  about $86 per barrel, an 18% price increase on the previous year, but significantly below current prices. We've  taken advantage of recent price dips to hedge about 20% of Q1 of FY13 at an average price of just over $100 per  barrel. Higher oil prices, though, are forcing competitors to further increase fuel surcharges and fares, which  makes Ryanair low fares even more attractive. It will also drive further consolidation, and more airlines will exit  the industry this winter. This will generate further growth opportunities for Ryanair because we operate the most  fuel-efficient aircraft and have the lowest operating costs.

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: The recent Brighter Planet survey ranked Ryanair as the greenest, cleanest airline in the world, and that survey is  available to you if you care on the ryanair.com website. In June, we signed an MOU with COMAC, the Chinese  aircraft manufacturer, to enter discussions on the development of a new 200-seater short-haul aircraft for Ryanair  that should be available from 2018 onwards. We believe this aircraft, which will be a larger version of the C919,  will be a real alternative to the existing short-haul duopoly of Boeing and Airbus. Real competition in the aircraft  manufacturing industry will deliver more choice and lower costs for airlines and passengers. We also believe it will  make economic sense for Ryanair to become in time a two-aircraft operator, if the present Boeing fleet economies  can be matched or improved by another aircraft manufacturer.

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: Our outlook for the remainder of the year remains unchanged. We anticipate traffic in FY12 will grow by 4%,  comprising 10% growth in H1, and will then fall by approximately 4% monthly in H2, which will be the first time  in our history that we've contracted during a winter period. We expect average fares in FY12 to rise by up to 12%  due to the better mix of new routes and bases, our winter capacity cuts, higher competitor fares, and fuel  surcharges. We also anticipate that Q2 yields will rise by between 12% to 15%. We expect operating costs per  passenger for FY12 to rise by 13%, primarily due to higher oil prices. Excluding fuel, sector length-adjusted costs  should rise by no more than 2% mainly due to Eurocontrol, Dublin Airport, and staff pay increases.

texts.speaker: Howard Millar
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive, Chief Financial Officer, Ryanair Holdings Plc

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We'd also like to update you on our fuel hedging problem. As investors will be aware, we're 90% hedged for the  current year, FY 2016, at an average cost of $91 per barrel. texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We believe that will result in stronger competition from other airlines, particularly as they begin to benefit from  lower spot oil prices and lower fuel hedges as we go through the winter. We're aware that many of our competitors are guiding for a benign fare  environment this winter. We think that's optimistic. We think we should be cautious.

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Just to touch on the load factors and forward bookings. You'll see in recent months we've delivered very strong  load factor growth, April, May and June. Now, we don't expect the load factor in those  months to grow by 3% or 4%, but it does indicate how strongly booked we are into Q2 and in the start of Q3.

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We have very limited visibility into the second half bookings at the moment. Q3 is about 10% booked but Q4 is less  than 2% booked. And as a result of that, we're increasing our winter traffic  forecast from 10% to 15%. As always, Ryanair's model is to remain load factor active, yield passive. So we'll take  whatever price we get, whether that's up or down, as long as we hit our load factor objectives.

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And here is just a brief detail on our fuel hedging program. As you know, we are 90% hedged in the current year at  about $91 per barrel. That means that for FY 2017, on the basis of those hedges, we will  reduce our fuel bill by about €250 million compared to the current year.

file: RYA - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 2November2015 1200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Today, we are pleased to report a strong set of half-one results. We've enjoyed a bumper summer, due to a very  rare confluence of favorable events, including stronger Sterling, adverse weather in Northern Europe, reasonably  flat industry capacity, and further savings on the 10% of our fuel that was unhedged, at a time when millions of  consumers are switching to Ryanair, for our Always Getting Better customer experience program, our low fares,  and our punctuality.

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The continuing success of our Always Getting Better program is driving stronger forward bookings, higher load  factors and is accelerating our traffic growth. Having recently raised our full year target from a 103 to 104 million  passengers, we're now raising it again today to 105 million passengers for the full year. Most of that growth will  come about as a result of higher load factors during the winter period.

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We've taken advantage this summer of lower oil prices and opportunistically extended our hedging program. We  are now hedged 95% of our fuel requirements for FY 2016, but we've also hedged 95% of our fuel requirements for  next year, ending March 2017, at a rate of about $62 barrel. As a result of those lower – these lower oil prices and  our attractive U.S. dollar hedging program, we expect to lower our oil bill next year in FY 2017 by approximately  €430 million. We do, however, expect to give away some or maybe all of those fuel savings in the form of lower  fares in the next 12 months, as we expand and grow across Europe and take market share from our competitors.

texts.speaker: Neil Sorahan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So last year our load factor in year one of Always Getting Better increased by five percentage points to 88%. In the  current year, we will see that figure increase to 92%. And despite very strong comparative numbers, you can see  we have very strong load factors throughout the summer period. And indeed, on a like-for-like basis, we're  between 2% and 3% better booked now than we were at the same time last year, for the remainder of the year.

texts.speaker: Neil Sorahan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Our oil is very well-hedged for the current year, and indeed into FY 2017. This year, our oil will be approximately  $898 per metric ton and our oil is hedged at $622 per metric ton next year for 95% of our exposures. In euro  terms, that will deliver €430 million of savings. However, we anticipate that this will help drive lower fares for our  customers in the next financial year. The outlook for the remainder of FY 2016 is that we will see our load factors  increase by four points to 92%. Traffic will grow by 16% to 105 million customers. We have 19% growth in traffic  this winter, 22% increase in Q4.

texts.speaker: Neil Sorahan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Average fares will be broadly flat in Q3. We have very limited visibility into Q4. However, we anticipate that  average fare will be down approximately 4%. Our lower oil prices will fund lower fares in the second half of this  year and into FY 2017, with our €430 million savings. So as a result of all of this, we are now happy to increase our  guidance to be up around the range – our previous range was €1.175 billion to €1.225 billion. We will now be at  the upper hand of that range. This, of course, is highly predicated on closing bookings in the remainder of Q3 and  into Q4, where we have no visibility. Ryanair will continue to be load active, yield passive, which means we will  absolutely hit the passenger numbers, and the fare will end up where the fare ends up.

texts.speaker: Michael O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: That is a much stronger position than most of our competitor airlines. For example, Norwegian is 85% unhedged  for the next 12 months and Wizz is about 60% unhedged. And I, therefore, much prefer our hedging position to  theirs given where oil is at the moment and where it's likely to go to.

texts.speaker: Michael O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: We have not ruled out – and I think we should make it clear to investors – we have not ruled out that there may be  further base closures or capacity reductions this winter if oil moves materially higher than $85 per barrel, or if  airfares fall further than the 2% we are guiding at the moment. But there is – we cannot rule out there might be  some upside as well if there was further failures – or competitor failures this winter, then the winter trading might  be positively impacted.

texts.speaker: Michael O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: But on balance, we remain comfortable with the new guidance of €1.1 billion to €1.2 billion. The fuel bill will be  significantly higher, ancillary sales will be significantly higher, but the guidance is driven by the expectation that  airfares will fall by 2%, and that oil – our unhedged oil won't rise more than $85 per barrel. Our guidance for the  full year of €1.1 billion to €1.2 billion excludes Laudamotion's results and we expect it to lose approximately €150  million in the first – out to March of 2019.

texts.speaker: Neil Sorahan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: I think, it's well covered, Michael, in the pre-record, as you mentioned. I suppose the key thing is that while we  have a little bit of a pain this year on the cost front, we're in pretty good shape as we look forward with MAXs  coming in next year. Equally, as you said, I'd highlight that fuel hedging, 90% hedged for the next 12 months, at  well below current spot prices. And total revenue performed well with the help of ancillaries, although we did take  the pain on the cost front from fuel, staff and EU261 this year. But other than that, nothing else to add, Michael.

file: RYA - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 31January2011 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jan-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Excluding fuel, which itself was up 37% in the quarter, unit costs rose by 8%. This was compounded by a spate of  ridiculous bad weather airport closures in December.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Although, oil prices have risen significantly in recent months, and again over the weekend, Ryanair  continues to benefit from a favorable fuel hedging strategy. texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The extraordinary scale of the ATC and weather cancellations during the third quarter brings  renewed focus on the unfair and discriminatory nature of the EU261 airline regulations. Urgent  reform of these regulations is vital since it’s inequitable to force airlines to pay for right to care or  compensation in circumstances where widespread flight cancellations are caused by ATC strikes,  airport’s failures to keep their runways open or the Icelandic volcanic ash air space closures.

file: RYA - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 30January2012 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jan-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: We're very pleased to report this Q3 profit of €15 million. It's slightly ahead of our expectations, but largely due to  the benign weather conditions experienced in December 2011 compared to the widespread snow closures, deicing  comps we suffered in December 2010. And also a better yield performance as we grounded up to 80 aircrafts and  cut our traffic in Q3 by 2%.

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: As you can see, the EU recession, higher oil prices, the unfolding failure of the package tour operator model,  significant competitor fare increases and capacity cuts, have created enormous growth opportunities for Ryanair,  as large and smaller airports across Europe compete aggressively to win our growth.

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: Our unit costs rose 11% mainly due to an 18% increase in fuel costs. Excluding fuel, sector length adjusted unit  cost fell 1%, as we continue to control costs despite a 2% basic pay increase, higher Eurocontrol fees, and  significantly higher Dublin Airport charges. In FY 2013, we are 90% hedged for half one at about $99 per barrel.  70% hedged for the second half at approximately $100 a barrel. We do expect to hedge out the balance of our H2  FY 2013 needs over the coming months. But at these prices, our fuel bill for FY 2013 will rise by approximately  €350 million which poses a significant cost challenge as we move into FY 2013.

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: Our Q3 net profit of €15 million was slightly ahead of guidance due to a combination of benign weather, which  caused fewer flight cancellations and significant deicing savings, and a better performance on yields, reflecting our  planned winter capacity cuts, longer sectors, and higher competitor fares and fuel surcharges. Should these  positive Q3 trends continue into Q4, we now expect our full year profit will exceed previous guidance of €440  million and rise to approximately €480 million after tax.

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Howard. Okay, ladies and gentlemen, I think we'll open it up for questions. Now, if I can though, just to  temper some of the irrational euphoria. I think the overriding view of these numbers, they're heavily distorted by  very benign weather conditions in Q3 last year compared to horrendous weather conditions in the prior year of  Q3, a significant decline in cancellations, flight disruptions, significant savings, therefore, a disruption in deicing  costs, et cetera.

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: And lest anybody run loose ahead of themselves, I'd like to highlight again that we do face very significant fuel cost  headwinds over the next 12 months. We expect our fuel bill to rise by up to €350 million given our continuing  expansion. But then it goes on the other hand, fuel will be rising very significantly for all of our competitor  airlines, many of whom won't be as well, aren't as well hedged as we are, and certainly don't have the margins to  pay for these entire comps.

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: So I think our profit growth will be strong with significant fuel cost headwinds and a fair challenge to try to ensure  that through cost management and selective price increases, we can cover that higher oil bill this year.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Airlines are unable to compete with us as we bring in our low costs and our Always Getting Better program. texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director

texts.text: With that said, we expect full year traffic to grow 8% to 130 million, up 1 million from the 129 million previously  guided. texts.speaker: [0DLGQP-E Michael O'Leary]

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: At last year, some 14,000 Ryanair flights were canceled arising primarily from three separate  incidents: the volcanic ash disruptions in April and May; the airport snow closures in the U.K. and  across much of Europe in December and January; and a total of 15 national air traffic control  strikes across Europe last summer.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: This brings into further focus the unfair and discriminatory airline EU 261 regulations which forced  airlines to pay for “right to care” expenses and compensation during these events even though  they’re beyond our control. It’s absurd, for example, that the insurance companies last year paid out  nothing during the volcanic ash crisis because it was an act of God, yet the airlines were passed on  all of those costs and the compensation.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In terms of oil, higher oil prices continue to force our higher-fare competitors to increase fares and  fuel surcharges which are making our lower fares even more attractive. In many cases,  competitors’ fuel surcharges are higher than Ryanair’s lead-in fares. Higher oil prices will, as  previously, lead to further consolidations, increased competitor losses and more airlines going  broke this autumn. This creates further growth opportunities for Ryanair because we operate the  most fuel-efficient fleet, have the lowest operating costs and also the strongest balance sheet.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We expect to increase our market share and expand further into new markets as high oil prices  force more competitors to cut capacity or go bust this autumn and winter. In Ryanair, we’re 90%  hedged for the remainder of the fiscal year at about $82 a barrel. This is still, however, a 12% price  increase on last year but significantly below current spot prices which are trending around above  $100.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Higher oil prices next winter and the refusal of some airports to offer lower charges make it more  profitable to tactically ground up to 80 aircraft this winter compared to the 40 aircraft we grounded  last winter rather than suffer losses operating them to high cost airports such, as example Dublin, at  low winter yields.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 3 time in our history that we will have cut capacity and cut traffic for a period of time. However,  despite these winter capacity cuts, we still expect the full year fuel bill will rise by approximately  €350 million and, to put that in some context as you’ll know, we’ve just announced full year profits  of €400 million and, yet, our fuel bill will go up by almost that amount next year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In terms of outlook, we expect to grow traffic by 10% in the first half and then cut traffic by 4% in the  second half. Accordingly, traffic overall for the year will grow 4% to 75 million passengers. Half-one  figures will be boosted by the late Easter and modest prior year comparables due to the volcanic  ash disruptions last April and May but will also be impacted by a 40% increase in Q1 fuel costs,  partly due to volume increases but also due to the fact that we had very favorable fuel hedges in  place in Q1 last year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Due to the higher oil prices, we expect operating cost per passenger to rise by 13% in FY ‘12; that  includes a 5% growth in sector length. Excluding fuel, sector length adjusted unit cost will rise by  just 2% mainly due to excessive euro control increases and some staff cost increases.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Howard Millar, Deputy Chief Executive, Chief Financial Officer  Thank you, Michael. The MD&A comes with the usual caveats. For the purpose of the  management’s discussion and analysis, all figures and comments are by reference to the adjusted  income statement excluding exceptional items. There was one exceptional item in the periods to  March 31, 2011 which amounted to €29.7 million pre-tax cost relating to the closure of air space in  April and May 2010 due to the volcanic ash disruptions.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Total operating expenses increased by 20% to €3,113 million primarily due to an increase in fuel  prices, the higher level of activity and higher operating costs associated with the growth of the  airline. Fuel, which represents 39% of total operating costs compared to 35% in the prior year,  increased by 37% to €1,226 million due to the higher price per gallon paid and a 17% increase in  the number of hours flown.

file: RYA - Q4 2012 Earnings Call Second Call 21May2012 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: Obviously, the key threat theme for us for the next 12 months is significantly higher oil prices despite the fact that  we are hedged 90% out to March FY 2012 at about $100 a barrel. This still means that our oil bill in the next 12  months will rise by some €320 million. We do expect with slower capacity growth that the yield performance will  continue to be up, but we're concerned and cautious at the moment it won't be up sufficiently to make up another  €320 million increase in our oil bill.

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: In terms of outlook, we expect in FY 2013 that traffic will grow 5% to just over 79 million passengers. The oil bill  will rise by €320 million. Most of this will be skewed into the first half of the year, and as a result, we expect to  report a decline in the Q1 profits because of these higher stepped up oil prices.

file: RYA - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 20May2013 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: As I've said, fuel costs rose by over €290 million and now represent 45% of our total costs. Excluding fuel, unit  costs were up 3% due to excessive and unjustified increases in particularly Italian air traffic control charges,  Eurocontrol and Spanish airport fees. Ancillary revenues outpaced traffic growth, rising 20% to just over €1  billion or 22% of the total revenue.

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: Under the EU Treaty, the UKCC has a duty of sincere corporation with the EU and cannot make alternative  findings for those recently made by the EU Commission. On that basis, we believe that the existing, the current CC  investigation, should be abandoned. However, we think it won't be. And we think the UKCC would look stupid if  they abandon it, and as happens with many of these regulatory issues, we think they'll continue with their  investigation and we expect them to come up with some kind of bizarre finding where in the future it may result in  reduced competition and, accordingly, they'll try to force us to sell down.  If they do, we intend to-well, firstly,  we've already appealed the EU decision that the UKCC must await the outcome of the EU appeal. But if the UK CC  comes up with a finding that's contrary to what the EU has found, we'll also be appealing that decision in the U.K.  because it will be in clear breach of the UKCC's duty of sincere cooperation.

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: Fuel hedging, again, we remain somewhat on the slightly optimistic. We have extended our fuel hedging into the  first half of FY 2015, slightly less than FY 2014. We're currently 90% hedged for FY 2014 at an equivalent of $98 a  barrel. We're hedging into FY 2015 currently at $93 a barrel. We have 25% of our H1 requirements hedged and  we've said the exchange rate is pretty similar. So we'll hope that we'll continue to see kind of a 5% cost decline in  our oil costs. But it could be at least FY 2015. FY 2014 will largely hedge at $98 a barrel, and because the currency  has slightly moved against us, our unit oil costs will be up slightly in FY 2014.

texts.speaker: Michael Anthony O'Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: In terms of outlook, again, I know it's difficult for the market and for ourselves at this time of year because we  have such little visibility over H2. We are confident the traffic will grow this year by some 3% to €81.5 million.  That growth will be markedly slower in the first half at around 2% month on month but rise to about 5% month on  month in the second half as we ground fewer aircraft. Unit costs will increase in FY 2014 primarily due to rising oil  prices at 3% growth in sector length and further unjustified higher Eurocontrol and Spanish airport charges.

file: RYA - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 19May2014 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: Fuel is 90% hedged at about $96 per barrel for the remainder of the year. That should kick in about a €70 million  cost saving over last year's number. It's the saving itself that's slightly higher but we expect to give back some on  the de-icing where we had a very mild winter last year.

file: RYA - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 26May2015 130 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Neil Sorahan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Costs, as you would expect with Ryanair, remained very much in check. We saw a 5% per passenger reduction in  unit cost this year, driven by our fuel bill, and ex -fuel, our costs were flat.

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Within that, we expect sector length to be stable. We expect unit cost excluding fuel to be flat. But we will be  cautious on fares and yields. In the first half of the year, we expect fares, average fares, to be flat to minus 2% – to  down 2%. But in the second half of the y ear, we expect to see some irrational price competition from competitors  around Europe, particularly those who are un-hedged on oil and, therefore, benefiting from lower oil prices. We  believe this will lead to some price competition next winter, particularly as Ryanair continues its successful  expansion across Europe, and accordingly, for the second half of the year, at the moment, with very little visibility,  we're guiding that average fares will fall by between 4% to 8% year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our forward bookings into the peak months of this summer – and this was taken in early May – show that, on  average, we're running 4 percentage points ahead of where we were this time last year. And remember, this time  last year, our load factors during that period grew by about 4% through the peak summer months. You won't see  that growth again this year because of the high prior year comparables. But it gives us a reasonable optimism that  our load factors will grow this year by between 1.5% and 2% over last year's numbers, so from 88% to about 90%.

texts.speaker: Neil Sorahan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Sure. We're well-hedged, Michael. We've got great certainty into next year on both our fuel and our operating  expenditure and indeed our capital expenditure. 90% of our fuel bill is hedged at $92 per barrel. And indeed, the  10% that isn't hedged will benefit from the low spot rate for approximately $65 a barrel in the market.

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We do, however, expect average fares to fall slightly in the first half of the year. We think they'll fall materially in  the second half of the year, particularly as some competitors engage in irrational price competition, because they  can't sustain price or cost competition with Ryanair; that price competition may be driven by lower oil. But  remember, Ryanair will also be benefiting from lower oil costs on our unhedged portion, and also as  we roll out  into FY  2017.

file: RYA - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 23May2016 1200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We're pleased this morning to announce a strong set of full-year results. Profits have risen by 43% to just over  €1.2 billion. As a combination of lower fares, our Always Getting Better program and cost control delivered strong  traffic and profit growth. Full year 2016 was a year in which we delivered significant traffic and profit growth in all  four quarters despite the fact that our average oil price which we had hedged in 2014 was just over €90 per barrel.  But our Always Getting Better program is attracting millions of new customers to our lowest fare, lowest cost  model.

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In the last 12 months, our fuel was hedged at just over $90 per barrel. And the coming 12 months to March 2017 is  95% hedged at a lower rate of about $62 a barrel. And we've begun hedging into FY 2018 where we're now 44%  hedged at $50 per barrel. As we've previously indicated, we plan to pass on most, if not all, of these fuel savings to  our customers in lower airfares, particularly as we grow capacity strongly over the next 12 months in key markets  around Europe.

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our cost discipline should see us deliver ex-fuel unit cost reductions of about 1% in FY  2017. Our fuel bill will also  fall by some €200 million, thanks to lower euro pricing being partially offset by volum e growth due to additional  flights we'll operate this year.

texts.speaker: Neil Sorahan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Just moving on to current developments. We've launched the third year of our Always Getting Better program.  Our forward bookings are rising. Our competition can no longer compete with Ryanair's low costs and the gap is  widening between ourselves and themselves. We have cheaper fuel hedged for next year and the year after, 95%  into FY  2017 and 44% into FY  2018. Labs are working hard to roll out new ancillary cross-selling opportunities for  us.

texts.speaker: Neil Sorahan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Last year, we were raising debt at just over 1.1%. This year we'll be financing ourselves at a cash leading to further  reductions. Our fuel is well hedged for the next couple of years with 95% of our fuel hedged at $62 a barrel next  year which will delivery approximately €200 million in savings of the fuel bill when adjusted for volumes. We had  44% of our fuel hedged into FY  2018, at just under $500 per metric ton, which will give a further saving of €160  million. And our new website and app have given us greater opportunities to reduce our sales and marketing costs  through greater personalization. But the real step change is going to come in 2019 when we take delivery of the  Boeing 7 37 Max Gamechanger aircraft. These aircraft have eight extra seats, will grow from 189 seats to 197 seats,  which gives us an opportunity to spread the costs over more customers, and to enhance our ancillary spend  opportunities. But they also come with the CFM LEAP engines, which are on average 16% more fuel efficient than  the engines in our current fleet.

texts.speaker: Neil Sorahan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On guidance, we're cautious as we move into the FY  2017 financial year. Our load factors will be flat at 93%.  Traffic will be up 9% to 116 million customers. We'll have a continued focus on cost which will see our unit cost ex - fuel drop by 1% or 6% when we factor in fuel. However, our average fare, we believe, will fall by approximately 7%  on a full-year basis giving a modest increase of 13% in our PAT to a range of €1.375 billion to €1.425 billion. We  have limited visibility at this period of time, and our guidance is very much predicated on our load factor yield  active (sic) [active/yield] passive strategy, and the absence of further shocks or ATC strikes in the system over the  next number of months.

file: RYA - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 30May2017 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael O’Leary
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: We expect for full year 2018, average fares will decline by between 5% to 7% due to combination of weaker  Sterling and continuing excess capacity in Europe and we'll be exceeding that capacity by – when we step up our  growth in both 2018 and 2019. We expect, however, our fuel bill – thanks to our hedging – will fall by €70 million  in the current year, but we'll pass those savings on to customers in the form of lower fares. We expect our ex-fuel  unit cost to fall by 1% to FY 2018.

texts.speaker: Neil Sorahan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Ryanair Holdings Plc
texts.text: Okay, Michael. Thanks very much. Just as was repeated, a couple of points there that Michael made, unit costs  very strong in the year. We saw unit costs down 5% on an ex-fuel basis, which was ahead of the minus 4% that  we previously guided and [indiscernible] (07:43) another 1% in the current financial year.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Okay, let’s start then. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our – presentation of our Half-Year Report.
texts.text: When it comes to the efficiency improvement programme, this is the last year of the plan-specific  programme. And I would say that we are well underway. We have had a strong focus on that. This doesn’t mean however that we stopped  focusing now on efficiency measures; but the way I see it is that this focus programme, will now be  handed over to the organization as a continuously ongoing process.

texts.speaker: Tomás Varela Muiña
texts.profession: General Manager and Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We keep going. In 2016, we are starting the year working on the sale of our portfolio of some 4,500 residential  units. Gross value above €550 million. We expect to finalize the sale by the end of the quarter. The investors'  appetite on Spain real estate has translated into lower discount levels. So in general, the environment for this  keeps going positive. And therefore, we see good prospects for a further reduction of our problematic assets at a  higher pace. And as I already mentioned, over-delivering in terms of the targets that we had for TRIple. So the  target for 2016 in terms of sales is to do more than €2 billion.

texts.speaker: Tomás Varela Muiña
texts.profession: General Manager and Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As you see, Spanish economy has performed since the beginning of last year 2014, away from the double-dip  recession that it experimented that you can see in the left graph. That process will continue. We'll continue  stabilizing the growth where we are now. And that is positive news. We do not think that the indirect effects of the  lower price of oil has any impact on balance sheets of the Spanish economy that have very little expose to the  related oil activities. So that is on the other side, the positive effect on the disposable income that is most  important, so that's why we sustained that.

texts.speaker: Tomás Varela Muiña
texts.profession: General Manager and Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: New financing operations will grow, and we think that that is what we expect to happen. As far as the UK, the  other main market in which Banco Sabadell's activity is evolving, economic growth at its potential level. We think  that we are at the potential level of 2.2% as well. And we have taken that as a basis for our forecasts. Y ou know the  corporate balance sheet's healthy. We are not in the Corporate Banking business in the UK, but as far as the  mortgages, so there will be positive evolution considering that the UK economy is also not a benefiter of the shift  in the worldwide oil prices. And therefore, we expect that to be continuing, and therefore, the b rands of TSB being  able to grow accordingly to what has been forecasted.

texts.speaker: Tomás Varela Muiña
texts.profession: General Manager and Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Efficiency will be our focus of attention during this year. A lot of the TRIple activities concerning the change and  the efficiency model of operating will be put in place during the third year, as long as in the second year, we have  put in place the internationalization, the efficiency will be main focus of the  Bank during the next year, and that  will have to drive our cost-to-income ratio to 48%. Of course, that is a higher cost-to-income than the one that we  were planning to achieve without the TSB, but the TSB has high cost-to-income ratio due to the effect of its  starting up activity. But that is also below 15%. So we're saying that that is achievable and in a positive side. And  finally, we'll keep our Core Tier 1 phase-in 12% while maintaining the same ratios of the fully loaded way above the  requirements of the SREP.

texts.text: The ramp-up of production is on. We are daily monitoring this ramp-up. If we look at now the LEAP-1B, the engine  has been certified in May by both EASA and FAA. texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director
texts.text: And, of course, when I talk about market share, I'm talking about the Airbus A320. As you know, on Boeing, we  are at 100%. texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director
texts.text: The business for our Landing Systems is doing very well, especially in the carbon brakes. We maintain our  worldwide position of more than 50% market share.
