texts.speaker: Bernard Delpit
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: I would say that the tailwinds are coming from aerospace services, contribution of CFM56 OE, organic growth in  Security and productivity gains and cost reductions across the board. When looking at headwinds, we have higher  expense R&D for €12 million, headwinds in our helicopter turbine business, and the negative margin on LEAP  deliveries and in production for something that represents roughly 1.3% of the group sales.

texts.speaker: Bernard Delpit
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: EBIT is stable. It means that headwinds from R&D, €34 million, and helicopter turbines margins, plus the st artup  costs of LEAP were offset by margin on OE and services.

file: SAF - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 28July2017 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: Going to page 6, if you look at an update or a more specific update on the LEAP program, the production ramp-up  is proceeding with 147 LEAPs sold in H1 2017. Our constant focus on supply chain and our extensive dual- sourcing policy provide us with comfort in our ability to meet customers' requirements. The production ramp has  started for the LEAP-1B. The first 737 MAX successfully entered into commercial service at Malindo on May 22.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: Regarding the LEAP-1A, the production ramp continues with now 15 airlines operating this engine, and over  190,000 flight hours as of today. Regarding the ETOPS 180, LEAP-1A also got granted this certification from both  FAA and EASA.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: In equipment, we have commercial momentum, which continues for carbon brakes, strengthening our leadership  in this fast-growing market; many new contracts with more than 10 major ones have been signed in H1 2017.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: The environment remained extremely favorable. I remind you that at the beginning of the year, IATA was talking  about the growth in the range of 5% of the traffic, of the worldwide traffic. At the end of May, we are at 7.9%, so  IATA has revised its forecast and now is scheduling a growth, which should be in the range of 7.4%, so very good  environment for our commercial business.

texts.speaker: Bernard Delpit
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Safran SA
texts.text: Cash R&D, most of the decrease came from LEAP. Decline in capitalized R&D also came from lower capitalized  R&D spending on LEAP. We have an increase in amortization due to LEAP. I remind you that the amortization of  LEAP-1A started in May 2016, and the amortization of LEAP-1B started this year in March. So, that drives the  impact on recurring operating income after tax credit to €6 million negative.

texts.speaker: Bernard Delpit
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Safran SA
texts.text: Growth in services for Propulsion is up 7.5% or 5.2% on organic basis, driven by civil aftermarket, up 8.4%.  Military services slightly increased, up 3%. But we had lower contribution of helicopter turbines support activities  due to softer demand from oil and gas customers and the grounding of part of the H225 fleet until last week.

texts.speaker: Bernard Delpit
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Safran SA
texts.text: On the negative side, with the negative impact of CFM56 transition, in line with annual assumption, lower  contribution of helicopter turbines and higher expensed R&D, which is a headwind of €19 million in this first half.  And as you will ask, I mentioned here the negative €165 million coming from the transition between CFM56 and  LEAP, balanced between decreasing OE margin of CFM56 due to volumes, and the contribution of LEAP with  negative margins, with more deliveries, less negative but still negative unit cost margins and lower depreciation.

texts.speaker: Bernard Delpit
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Safran SA
texts.text: On the other side, lower volumes for A380 that we have and we are anticipating this decline in the rate. Services  grew across the board, carbon brakes, landing gear MRO and nacelles spare parts. EBIT, it's up 20%, thanks to  increased volumes, productivity gains and hedge rate.

file: SAF - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 6September2018 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Sep-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: The CFM56-LEAP transition is on track. The ramp-up of LEAP production is proceeding, but remains a challenge  that we are addressing together with GE, our partner from the CFM and LEAP programs. The objective is to  deliver around 1,100 LEAP and 1,000 CFM56 in the year.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: So let's talk now about businesses. Update on the CFM56-LEAP transition. Executing on this transition remains a  top priority and a challenge. We are continuing to produce and deliver engines at a record phase, reflecting high  demand for our products. The combined delivery of CFM56 engine and LEAP engines increased by 20% in H1  2018 compare to H1 2017. We delivered 1,029 engines against 857 engines in H1 2017.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: The production ramp-up of the LEAP is proceeding. LEAP deliveries almost tripled in H1 2018 to 438 engines  compared to 147 engine in H1 2017. We have now 100% of double source for all our parts working to support the  rate increases. The unprecedented ramp-up puts us on a lot of pressure, notably on the supply chain, and we are  working with our partner, GE, to focus on all the challenges we have.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: So, recovery plan are in place to capture with our customers' request before year-end. We maintain, of course,  our 2018 targets to deliver around 1,100 LEAP in the year and 1,000 CFM56.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: A quick update on page 7 on the LEAP program. We have now on the LEAP-1A for Airbus 27 airlines operating  240 aircrafts. We have more than 1.2 million flight hours logged on this program. On the LEAP-1B, 41 airlines  operating 183 aircrafts, powering the LEAP-1B with more than 550,000 flight hours. And we are continuing the  development of the LEAP-1C for the COMAC C919.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: Business highlights, page 8. The CFM commercial success was sustained notably at the Farnborough Airshow  (sic) [Farnborough International Airshow] (00:07:45). We announced 858 LEAP and CFM56 engine order. And  when we look at all of this, the total order book of the LEAP at the end of July 2018 is 15,450 engines. We have  an order book for the LEAP at the end of July of 15,450 engines.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: The commercial success of our award-leading carbon brakes business continues. We have Turkish Airlines,  SunExpress, Indigo who have placed numerous orders with our division in charge of carbon brakes.

texts.speaker: Bernard Delpit
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Safran SA
texts.text: On profitability of this division, the one thing I wanted mentioned is the positive impact of the LEAP transition for  €35 million. As planned, H1 and H2 are in balance, but more than what we expected. LEAP cost reduction is what  we planned with a high-single-digit decrease of cost between January and June, but we shipped less negative  margin engines of LEAP. file: SAF - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 24February2017 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: So, after showing you this financial objective, let's look a couple of main highlights of the year for our businesses.  We can start with the LEAP programme. 2016 was a year of great operational achievements for the LEAP, with  the entry into service of the LEAP-1A for Airbus, certification of LEAP-1B for Boeing and for LEAP-1C for the  Chinese Comac. LEAP-1A production is ramping in 2016. We produced 108 engines. We delivered 77 engines,  supporting all the commercial commitments to our customers. The entry into service of the engine is going very  smoothly. Customers publicly expressed their satisfaction with the LEAP's performance in support of the  operation, and I am really, really proud of that.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: At the same time, the LEAP development for Boeing and Comac continues. So far, for Boeing, we have four  airplanes flying. We have accumulated more than 2,100 hours of flight tests, and we have logged more than  1,600 flights. So far, the engine is fully on track to meet the performance specification. For the Chinese LEAP -1C,  the certification was awarded at the end of December by FAA and European Certification Authority. The  propulsion system is ready for the first flight, which is scheduled this first semester of 2017.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: Finally, we logged 1,801 orders and commitments for new LEAP engines in 2016, bringing the total to 11,563  engines. And, by the way, at the end of January, we are over 12,000 engines. We had a very good month of  January in terms of booking for new LEAP order.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: If you look at these businesses, in Propulsion outside of the LEAP, we delivered a record number of CFM56.  1,693 engines were delivered. I remind you that last year we were at 1,612. So, it's still an increase of 5%  compared to last year, and it is a record ever in terms of production of the CFM56. So, demand remains robust,  and we logged an additional 876 engines in 2016 for the CFM56.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: Looking at Aircraft Equipment, we delivered on our commitments to support production rate increase on all our  customers programme. We executed flawlessly the on rising production rates on A350 and A320 programmes.  The main highlight is really the successful ramp-up of our nacelle business because we provide the full nacelle on  the A320neo for the LEAP-1A application. Carbon brakes were – did extremely well also. We have now an  installed base of more than 8,200 aircrafts using our carbon brakes. We have a market share which is higher than  50% worldwide for all these aircrafts which has more than 100 passengers.

texts.speaker: Bernard Delpit
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Safran SA
texts.text: And for recurring operating income, we have a positive impact of services, of course, higher contribution of  CFM56, negative margin and depreciation on LEAP deliveries, higher expensed R&D, that's a headwind of €65  million on Aerospace Propulsion recurring operating income and positive effect of hedged rate. This is just to say  that the negative contribution for LEAP is €215 million compared with 2015, and it includes depreciation of  inventories and WIP, and it only reflects LEAPs; nothing on CFM56. That's €215 million compared with 2015.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: Regarding the transition, which is a question you ask very often, what is the cost of the transition from CFM56 to  LEAP. First, we have lower volumes of CFM engines and we have a negative margin on the LEAP deliveries and  depreciation of inventory and WIP related to these future deliveries. So, the impact on our Propulsion adjusted  recurring operating income will be in the range of €300 million to €350 million for the year 2017.

file: SAF - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 27February2018 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: To wrap up. Safran team's execution was strong throughout 2017. We exceeded all our financial targets. More on  that a bit later. We executed well on the operational front. We delivered 459 LEAP engines in 2017, in line with  our target of more than the 450. LEAP production costs are coming down as we planned.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: CapEx is stable this year compared to 2016, as expected. We are investing to increase our production capacity to  address growing demand. For example, I was last week in Mexico where, with our partner, Albany International,  we inaugurated the third plant where we manufacture woven carbon fiber composite fan blades for the LEAP  engines.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: A word on the LEAP program, it's still a very big commercial success. We got 2,870 orders in 2017. We have a  backlog of 13,728 engine, almost 14,000 engines in backlog, and our forecast of production for 2018 is around  1,100 engines. Just quickly on LEAP-1A, it is in operation at 17 airlines with more than 530,000 flight hours  accounted. On the LEAP-1B, it's in operation at 16 airlines with more than 80,000 flight hours.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: Aircraft Equipment, in nacelle, we signed – it's a question which has been asked at the last discussion we had  with you. We signed the continuation of our contract to supply the nacelle of the A320neo LEAP engines. On  breaks, new contracts for carbon brakes for another 1,300 aircraft. This reinforce our market leader position with  more than 50% of market share for commercial airplanes of more than 100 seats. And finally, in electrical e- taxiing, we are moving in the right direction with our customer Airbus, and we expect very positive news in 2018.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: Some color again on the impact of the CFM transition, we track the incremental impact of LEAP ramp-up and  CFM rundown on EBIT. The €342 million of 2017 compared to €215 million in 2016 and to a range of €150 million  to €200 million in 2018. €342 million is lower than the revised guidance given in October for two reasons, less  LEAP deliveries and more spare engines sold to a lessor. It mitigated the cost of the campaigns we launched for  discs and shroud. Unit cost, by the way, is down 30% between January and December.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Director, Safran SA
texts.text: Page 24, Equipment, revenue €5.415 billion, 5.2% up or 6.5% organic. Recurring operating income, €682 million,  up 20.3%; that's a total margin of 12.6%. Reported revenue were up 6.6% for OE organically thanks to increased  volume for A350, nacelle for A320, landing gears and wiring for A330 and for A320 family. On the negative side,  lower volumes for A380 nacelle and small nacelle. Services were up 6.4% organically, driven by carbon brakes,  landing gear MRO, and nacelle support activities. EBIT is 20% up, thanks to increased volumes, productivity  gains, cost reductions, optimization of industrial footprint, and positive impact of FX, but higher expense R&D was  a headwind to profit for €25 million.

file: SAF - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 27February2019 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Safran SA
texts.text: With regard to the LEAP itself, we shipped 1,118 engines as announced. LEAP cost of sales is coming down as  planned. Overall, our profitability improvements were very strong in 2018 in [indiscernible] (02:50), Propulsion,  Aircraft Equipment, and Defense. Regarding Aircraft Interiors, we are executing on the operational and financial  recovery road map updated at the Capital Market Day. The teams and the management are focused on restoring  the trust of customers and meeting the planned synergies.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Safran SA
texts.text: Going to page 6, CFM56-LEAP transition update. The LEAP is the engine of choice for airlines. In 2018, CFM  International received 3,211 orders and commitments for this engine, bringing the total backlog to 15,620 units at  the end of December. With regard to operations, we are continuing to produce and deliver narrowbody engines at  a record pace. Combined of CFM engines and thinking about the LEAP and CFM56, the total increased by 14%  in 2018 to 2,162 units from 1,903 units in 2017. CFM56 continued its progressive ramp down with 1,044 units  shipped compared to 1,444 units in 2017.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Safran SA
texts.text: The production ramp-up of LEAP is making progress. LEAP deliveries reached 1,118 units compared to 459 in  2017. The planned reduction in the cost of sales of LEAP was achieved in 2018, paving the way to further  improvements in 2019. Looking ahead, CFM remains focused on addressing the challenges of the ramp-up and  the target for more than 1,800 LEAPs deliveries in 2019. We are in line to deliver more than 1,800 LEAP in 2019.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Safran SA
texts.text: Let's turn now, page 8, to Aircraft Equipment business highlights. In OE, Safran provides equipment to several  aircraft programs that are ramping up. Throughout the year, we supported our customers and executed on our  commitment, notably for the A320neo, the A330neo nacelle but also for wiring and landing gear in particular for  the 787, A350, 737, and A320 family. Momentum was sustained in services, which grew organically by 10%  driven by carbon brakes, nacelles, and landing gear support activities. Safran also strengthened its leadership in  the carbon brakes businesses and find new carbon brakes contract with the airlines for a total value of more than  1,000 aircrafts, bringing the total installed base close to 9,700 aircrafts at the end of 2018.

texts.speaker: Philippe Petitcolin
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Safran SA
texts.text: Going to Aerosystems business highlights, page 10. Safran supported its customers' rising assembly rates  throughout the year. Safran increased its deliveries of emergency slides for the A320neo, the 737 MAX, and the  787. Safran also shipped the first evacuation slide systems for the 777X. Safran supported the production ramp- up for the A220, the A350, and the 787 programs for Electrical & Cockpit systems and Water & Waste systems.  Safran also logged new contract including selection by Dassault for the electrical distribution and cockpit system  and the fuel control systems for the new Falcon 6X, and the selection of the RAVE inflight entertainment system  for new businesses and new airlines on the A320neo.

texts.speaker: Bernard-Pierre Jacques Delpit
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Safran SA
texts.text: In terms of profit, a tailwind of €15 million, 1-5, coming from the CFM56-LEAP transition. Transition impact in 2018  was more favorable than initially anticipated, reflecting stronger sales of CFM56 engines, notably of spare  engines. LEAP cost of sales reduction was in line with expectation, a cut of 25%. We had also a lower  contribution of R&D charged to P&L. This created a tailwind of €127 million. And the headwind also coming from  military sales.

texts.profession: Good morning. We’re going to start the 2010 results. I’m going to start with my script for this first
texts.text: Net interest income is more solid, backed by spreads management and deposit growth, because on  the other hand lending is slightly decelerating. Fee incomes were more affected in some of the lines  of business, sometimes due to the environment or sometimes due to the strategy followed by the  bank to captured funds, which mainly affected those related to securities and mutual funds. In the  fourth quarter, I suggested that the most likely outcome was that this trend eased off, i.e., lower  growth in net interest income and a better evolution of fee income. And we’re now starting to see  this in the first quarter, and we think that this will continue to be observed over the next quarters.  We think this trend will be repeated; i.e., at the beginning of 2009 the commissions went down 8%,  now it’s at zero growth rate; points to the recovery of pension funds, securities and insurance. Well,  that was regarded to the revenue.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Sáenz Abad, Second Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning. We’re going to start the 2010 results. I’m going to start with my script for this first
texts.text: Regarding Chile, first quarter was marked – was influenced by the earthquake, which apparently  will have some impact on the GDP, estimated at around 10 to 15%. However, in this country the  level of debt is very low and therefore the impact will be manageable. In this environment,  Santander Chile did not stop providing services in its branch network. The earthquake happened on  a Friday, and our branches opened the following Monday. It was the only bank that could do this,  thanks to its strong IT platform.

file: SAN - Q1 2010 Earnings Call 29April2010 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Apr-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So if I flip now just looking at some of these, research and development I think has gone through a  huge change in the past year. Marc Cluzel is here and be able to perhaps answer some questions  later. But you know this time last year, first quarter results of 2009 was the day we announced a  significant reduction in the portfolio of new products in our portfolio. We cut approximately 25% of  the portfolio on this day a year ago. And now a year later actually, I’m actually pretty encouraged by  what I see as green shoots of growth and development coming in research and development. We  have gone through a significant reorganization because we are a Europe company. We’ve of  course had to spend significant time on consultation with our social partners. That concluded  roughly towards the end of January and Marc has been rolling out a new organization, moving from  11 hierarchical levels to six. So, it pretty much has touched everybody in the R&D organization.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now, obviously, the other thing that we’ve been trying to do again is create those sustainable  growth platforms. Move away from the dependence on small molecule blockbusters. Two areas we  had identified for doing that were in Animal Health and Consumer Healthcare. We’ve been able to  strengthen our position in Animal Health, having acquired the other half of Merial last year from  Merck. We’ve now completed the second stage of that agreement in announcing that we intend to  combine Merial and Merck’s Animal Health business Intervet/Schering-Plough.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So we’ve been able to hire the former head of purchasing from the French car company PSA. My  belief is that the car companies do this better than anybody and we’ve decided to bring some of  that talent inside. We’ve created a global purchasing function and believe that will contribute further  to the cost savings program that we’ve already announced.

texts.speaker: Olof Faxander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sandvik AB
texts.text: Thank you very much, Magnus, and welcome here everybody to this presentation with our first quarter results.  Spring is coming around us and maybe we can talk a bit about spring for Sandvik as well. We have seen improved  demands in actually a number of areas around the Sandvik group. We have a strong positive book-to-bill for the  company in this quarter, and we've seen major orders from the energy sector  within Materials Technology, and  also quite significant major system orders to the Mining business area as well.

texts.speaker: Olof Faxander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sandvik AB
texts.text: Our cost reduction program that we announced in the second half of last year, within Sandvik Mining is running  according to schedule and we feel that we've reached that run rate by the end of this first quarter of this year. In  December, we also presented our plan to close down a number of production units within Sandvik and that first  wave is well underway. We have so far announced seven different closures or initiated those closures around the  company and most of these units are located in Europe as planned.

texts.speaker: Olof Faxander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sandvik AB
texts.text: Looking down a bit at the numbers here, as I mentioned, we had a strong book-to-bill in the first quarter of this  year, and we had increases both compared to the same period last year and sequentially co mpared to the fourth  quarter of last year. This was driven by general improvements in the markets that we're serving within Machining  Solutions, within Materials Technology. In fact, it's like automotive sector, the energy sector and the aerospace  sector. But we also received a number of major orders in Materials Technology relating to the oil and gas sector.  Those totaled SEK 1.3 billion, and we see very strong demand, actually, from oil and gas at the moment.

texts.speaker: Olof Faxander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sandvik AB
texts.text: Materials Technology has a clear strategy to continue to grow towards energy sector, and I think this is strong  evidence in this quarter of that we'v e been successful in continuing to grow our business there through the strong  order intake we've seen in the energy sector in this quarter.

texts.speaker: Mats Backman
texts.profession: Group CFO & Executive Vice President, Sandvik AB
texts.text: So what we do in order to address the gap going forward? This is just a selection of very high level activities for the  different business areas. But looking on Mining to start with, it is essential that we're suc cessful with the footprint  project going forward done in order to fix the structural issues related to supply chain. It's definitely about  inventory. But we also need to work with our internal processes when it comes to accounts receivables within  Mining so that's also a focus area. And we are reviewing the stock replenishment sector because we need to get  inventories down short term as well. And you can expect destocking going forward within Mining from where we  are today, though.

texts.speaker: Mats Backman
texts.profession: Group CFO & Executive Vice President, Sandvik AB
texts.text: Sandvik Construction, very similar to the situation we have within Mining. We definitely have structural issues  within Construction when it comes to the complex supply chain, so we will benefit from the ong oing supply chain  optimization program when it comes to Construction, as well.

texts.speaker: Mats Backman
texts.profession: Group CFO & Executive Vice President, Sandvik AB
texts.text: But in order to get the sustainable level around 25%, we need to address the supply chain as well. Our target to get  sustainable on the level of 25% requires that we'd finalize the first step in the supply chain optimization program,  and that will be done by 2016.

file: SAND - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 24October2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Oct-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Olle Wijk
texts.profession: Senior VP, Head-Group Research & Development, Sandvik AB
texts.text: Another example, as I mentioned, is the newly developed insert, 4325, which also has recently been introduced,  and this is about turning. You can see here on the left side, you can see a turning of a steel bar and you can see the  nice golden-colored insert, which has extreme demand, of course, with high forces and high temperatures. And  just to demonstrate – if you look on the temperature load on this piece, we make an animation here. Here, we can  see the dark-red color is corresponding to a temperature at the cutting edge of around 1,000 degree C. Meaning  that if the tool as such doesn't last, the customer loses productivity.

texts.speaker: Olle Wijk
texts.profession: Senior VP, Head-Group Research & Development, Sandvik AB
texts.text: So this means it starts – this is an animation showing some mill effect. In fact, you could see that, instantaneously,  you get this very, very high temperature combined with high forces. And we have been a pioneer in developing  surface-coated inserts.

texts.speaker: Olle Wijk
texts.profession: Senior VP, Head-Group Research & Development, Sandvik AB
texts.text: And the last generation is this 4325, and we can see here the surface coating is mainly alumina, which is  aluminum oxide. And here you can see that the grains of alumina is a kind of – we have succeeded in creating a  kind of unidirectional growth of these crystals. The total thickness of this layer is around 50 microns, 0.050  millimeters, given the properties of the product.

texts.speaker: Olle Wijk
texts.profession: Senior VP, Head-Group Research & Development, Sandvik AB
texts.text: So, if you compare with this competitor material, at the moment when our too l still looks new, our competitor  material has actually broken down. I think that is – and I talked about the way you're working. This is based on a  lot of thermodynamic modeling, a lot of modeling of the cutting process and a lot of experiments made by ou r  expert in the R&D organization.

texts.speaker: Olle Wijk
texts.profession: Senior VP, Head-Group Research & Development, Sandvik AB
texts.text: And we have a more down-to-earth attitude to this. We are using this technology already today in the prototyping  where we make prototypes in plastics. So we have a fundamental knowledge of the technology. But when you turn  into metals, the problem is much more complicated. So what we will do here is to also demonstrate a kind of  example of how we work within Sandvik R&D. We will start a broader program in this during thr ee to five years to  look on this fundamentally on metallic materials, meaning that 12 to 15 engineers including design engineers will  work with this full time and also utilize the network with experts that we have in the R&D organization.

texts.text: And at the same time, we have very low fixed costs associated with the mining systems business being a project  business where we really deliver mainly engineering services and project execution to our customers. But that is  the main driver behind our lower order intake in the group in the fourth quarter. We do see some, so far, smaller  effects due to the lower oil price in order intake affecting somewhat the order intake on Sandvik Materials  Technology.

texts.speaker: Olof Faxander
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The arrow on energy we've turned slight downwards, driven by the weaker oil price, which is likely to have, in the  near-term, some negative effects on demand. Aerospace continues to be now then the only arrow where we really  see strong positive development and continued strong demand.

texts.speaker: Mats Backman
texts.profession: Group CFO & Executive Vice President
texts.text: Constructions are now close to the long-term target. I mean, they are on close to 25%. So they have done a great  job. We have good development for Materials Technology and for Mining as well, but we are still far from the  long-term target looking on Mining and Materials Technology.

texts.speaker: Olof Faxander
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We're making good progress on our supply chain optimization program. As Mats said, we're actually slightly  ahead of where we're planning to be now by year end and we feel totally comfortable with the progress of this  program according to the plans that we have communicated and drawn out within the Sandvik Group.

texts.speaker: Olof Faxander
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And when it comes to the demand picture around us, we see mixed demand. But I think, in general, actually quite  a lot of positive things happening in the market right now. North America has very strong demand. Sandvik has  quite a large European business, and a lot of stimulus is going right now into the European economy with the  steps that Draghi has been taken with a fairly weak euro and also lower oil price, which somehow has to – we have  to expect will stimulate European economy to increase growth rates and that is a big positive for the Sandvik  Group.

file: SAND - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 3February2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Björn Klas Otto Rosengren
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Sandvik AB
texts.text: If we look at the Q4, we can see that the challenging market conditions continues. And if you look for the year- over-year, we can see that the demand, especially in China as well as somewhat in U.S., is declining. We also  see that the energy market continue to be challenging. And there are some spillover effects, especially in North  America when it comes to the general engineering part. The organic growth for the quarter was negative. And in  the back of the low volumes, our EBIT decreased with 11%.

texts.speaker: Björn Klas Otto Rosengren
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Sandvik AB
texts.text: On the other hand, we have three business areas, and that is Machining Solutions, Mining and Construction, that  had a stable or improved EBIT level. The Venture business area as well as Material Technology are being [ph]  inflated (02:01) by the low oil price.

texts.speaker: Björn Klas Otto Rosengren
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Sandvik AB
texts.text: This pie chart actually represent our invoicing, which is down 6% year-over-year. The small arrows, the yellow  one, they actually represent the sequential development. And we see it pretty much flat, somewhat down when it  comes to the energy segment as well as the mining side, while we see a strong development of the automotive as  well as the aerospace. When it comes to mining, it's pretty clear; it's an effect which is coming from the low  mineral prices.

texts.speaker: Björn Klas Otto Rosengren
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Sandvik AB
texts.text: On the energy side, that is very much, of course, driven by the low oil prices. And maybe just giving you an  example, in the U.S. market the sequential development of drill rigs actually went down with 20%. And if you look  year-over-year, it's actually 60% down. I think the number of rig counts in U.S. today is about 650, somewhere  around that. So, it's significant. And of course, these two are affecting two of our business areas.

texts.speaker: Björn Klas Otto Rosengren
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Sandvik AB
texts.text: As I mentioned, two of our business areas have been affected very much from the low oil price, and that is the  Material Technology as well as Venture. If we start up with the Material Technology, I would say some parts of the  tubular, which is called the core and standard, have had effects. We haven't seen too much effect yet on the  umbilicals business and we have a front view of about six months.

texts.speaker: Björn Klas Otto Rosengren
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Sandvik AB
texts.text: Venture, I think that is definitely the business area which has been affected mostly from the weak oil and gas  industry. And of course, you understand that the Varel business, or we call it Drilling & Completion today, it's of  course directly affected because they deliver the drill bits for the industry. And with such a weak market, of  course, they are being quite severe affected.

texts.speaker: Mats Backman
texts.profession: Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Sandvik AB
texts.text: On the positive side, we had a large tunneling order for Constructions in Australia, about SEK 270 million.

texts.speaker: Mats Backman
texts.profession: Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Sandvik AB
texts.text: And in the quarter, we had actually destocking for all our business areas. And we had some under-absorption  effect looking on the quarter, and I would say that Machining Solutions as well as Materials Technology had an  under-absorption effect on the margin. For Materials Technology, about 2% units and looking on Machining  Solutions about 50 basis points in under-absorption in the quarter.

file: SAND - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 1February2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Björn Klas Otto Rosengren
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sandvik AB
texts.text: On the Material Technology, you see here that it says minus 4% and, previously, I said that we were actually  positive there. But last year, we had an umbilical order, which was booked during the last quarter, and if you  exclude that, we actually come up to 3%. But if you take out the currency, as well as the metal pricing effects, we  end up at plus 1% on that side. And I think it's a good number provided the tough market condition; it is also in the  oil and gas industry.

texts.speaker: Björn Klas Otto Rosengren
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sandvik AB
texts.text: On that, EBIT level, underlying EBIT on 8.8%. And if you actually take out the metal prices there, I think we are an  8.1%.

And then on the right side here, you'll see besides two miners, I think.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sandvik AB
texts.text: Okay. There is Tomas and me and actually we visited one of the greenfield operation in Canada. It's called  Borden Lake from Goldcorp. It's actually the new gold mine. texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, SAP SE
texts.text: Finally, we are raising our outlook to reflect the closing of the Callidus acquisition, as well as the strong operating  profit performance in the first quarter and our confidence for the remainder of the year. texts.profession: Member-Executive Board & Chief Financial Officer, SAP SE
texts.text: So, in closing, let me state very clearly that SAP is a company not only with great financial ambitions, but also  aspires to be a leader in environmental, social and governance matters. texts.speaker: Luka Mucic

file: SAP - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 27January2010 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jan-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Stefan Gruber, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Hello, everyone, and welcome to SAP’s Fourth Quarter Results Conference here in Frankfurt. My
texts.text: In this new reality that we talked about in the beginning, we are convinced that IT, and in particular  software, our type of software, plays a key role in creating a sustainable future for the world. We  believe, therefore, that there are many opportunities for sustainable growth by providing companies  an increased competitive edge, by providing companies more efficiency and transparency. And we  actually want to go into new markets. There are new opportunities out there such as security,  efficient energy, sustainability, health management. And we are ready to seize these opportunities.  I feel ready to shape some of them, so that we can create the innovation that is required to drive  these industries forward.

texts.speaker: Stefan Gruber, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Hello, everyone, and welcome to SAP’s Fourth Quarter Results Conference here in Frankfurt. My
texts.text: Another important area of innovation is of course the clouds and we don’t think that clouds is just a  meteorological phenomena, it’s actually a real thing. But our answer towards, regarding the cloud is  little bit less hype, and we’d like to be a little bit more hybrid, because of the industry, they, our  customers want to do hybrid. So we believe in choice. We believe that customers should be able to  choose between on-demand and on-premise.

texts.speaker: Stefan Gruber, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Hello, everyone, and welcome to SAP’s Fourth Quarter Results Conference here in Frankfurt. My
texts.text: In this new reality, we also need to embrace sustainability, and you know that SAP has a two- pronged approach to sustainability. On the one hand, we want to provide our customers with  innovative solutions, and on the other hand, we want to be an exemplar of best practices in  sustainability.

texts.speaker: Stefan Gruber, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Hello, everyone, and welcome to SAP’s Fourth Quarter Results Conference here in Frankfurt. My
texts.text: As a provider, we have a great position. We were probably the first mover in this business. Our  customers, in general the market looks for reliable vendor for this. We have a very clear roadmap  for solutions in the sustainability arena and we are offering innovative solutions for our customers.  The first one is SAP BusinessObjects Sustainability Performance Management. A pretty long  name. Probably very sustainable in itself. It’s been co-innovated with Lexmark. Then we have SAP  Carbon Impact, that’s an on-demand solution, helps people to manage their carbon footprint, and  people like Autodesk, Hitachi, Freeport and Jabil Circuits are using that. And then there are a whole  battery of new sustainability analytics such as in the area of environment, health and safety to  reduce cost and risk.

texts.speaker: Stefan Gruber, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Hello, everyone, and welcome to SAP’s Fourth Quarter Results Conference here in Frankfurt. My
texts.text: But we also want to act as an exemplar. Our goal is to reduce our CO2 emissions by half in 2020  compared to 2007. We have reduced our carbon emissions in 2009 by 15%, well ahead of our  target. That generated a bottom line saving of about 90 million. So it’s obvious sustainability counts,  it computes, it generates margin and we have, of course, used our own technology to achieve this.  SAP runs SAP.

texts.speaker: Stefan Gruber, Head of Investor Relations

texts.text: We're one of the top places to work in the world and the first global IT company to receive EDGE Certification for  gender equality. texts.speaker: Luka Mucic

texts.text: Finally, as SAP's board sponsor for sustainability, I want to also emphasize our longstanding commitment to  address the biggest economic, environmental and societal issues around the world. texts.speaker: Luka Mucic
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SAP SE
texts.text: Turning to the environment, we were able to further decrease carbon emissions despite growing our cloud  business strongly in part because of our green cloud policy but also because of operational innovations such as  our ambitious goals around electric cars. And yes, I drive one, too.

texts.speaker: Luka Mucic
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, SAP SE
texts.text: Our employees are clearly excited to work for SAP. Our employee engagement score remained extremely high at  85%. texts.speaker: William R. McDermott
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SAP SE
texts.text: The true measure of a company goes beyond financial metrics alone. 93% of our employees are proud to work for  SAP. Our colleagues volunteered a quarter million hours and touched 4 million lives in 2018 alone. While growing  the entire size of the company by 10%, we beat our ambition to shrink our carbon footprint by nearly 5%. Among  many others, these make me proud to report that SAP is a strong, sustainable, profitable growth company.

texts.speaker: Luka Mucic
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SAP SE
texts.text: Before closing, I wanted to talk briefly about our sustainability story and a few of our key nonfinancial metrics. In  2009, SAP embedded sustainability in its long-term strategy. This is when we started our journey towards  becoming a role model of a sustainable company and we have made great progress. At the same time, there is  still a lot of potential for us to make a difference, especially by enabling our customers to run better with our  solutions.

texts.speaker: Luka Mucic
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SAP SE
texts.text: We remain committed to dedicate our extensive resources, our people and technology to help address the world's  biggest challenges and help achieve the UN Sustainable Development Goals. For example, we aspire for a world  of zero waste supported by our digital supply chain solutions.

texts.speaker: Luka Mucic
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SAP SE
texts.text: Looking to our nonfinancial metrics, women in management increased to 25.7%, a slight increase year-over-year.  Employee retention remained in our target range at 93.9%. And I'm happy to report that our greenhouse gas  emissions dropped to 310 kilotons below our target of 333 kilotons and here, being below a target is actually a  good thing. We are well on our way to becoming carbon neutral by 2025.

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: On the actual then operational highlights, we have secured a few contracts in the first half for the supply to OSX,  which is a new Brazilian client of an FPSO, and two large Turrets, one for Shell's Prelude FLNG and BP's Quad  204 Turrets. All of these are turnkey supply contracts.

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We then have in progress the contract for the Cidade de Paraty lease project for Petrobras, which has been in  progress since last year, but finalized the contract more recently. And with that, the new loan – financing loan for  this project, $1 billion loan facility, which is by far the largest we have had for the company.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And now, the project – the platform arrived in Norway and at the start of the year, more or less at the start of the  year this year, Talisman put in place a reimbursable agreement with Talisman directing the work to complete the  project all the way through to first oil.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Then in July, Talisman effectively revised its contractual position and essentially canceled the reimbursable  agreements. And during July, we also carried out a re-evaluation of the scope to complete all the way through to  first oil, including then lower efficiency figures on – or low efficiency factors on the work to be completed offshore.  The platform was installed offshore in July, end of June.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Then the platform was in Abu Dhabi in a different yard in Abu Dhabi than the Talisman platform and, in fact, in  the yard where we have worked many times before. The platform was transported to Canada. We had quite a  limited weather window to meet offshore Canada. We did want to install the platform, which has been successfully  completed in July. If we hadn't been able to install it in this relatively short window, we would have been faced  with really standing by, or standing by somewhere, until next year, probably May. So, it really was essential to get  offshore, and install the platform. We still have – there is still work to be done to hook up and complete and that  was the plan. We had a bit more work than planned to complete. But when we arrived in Canada, we spent a few  weeks in-shore to complete some work in preparation for the offshore phase and then we installed and now we  have to complete the work offshore.

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: I'd like to just run through a bit on each of the projects, which we have in the portfolio. texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV

texts.text: Last but not least is the level of commercial activity we have seen during the first half of the year.
