texts.text: Cidade de Paraty. Cidade de Paraty was actually delivered and got first oil in early June. It's the first lease and  operate project that's under Generation 3 concept. It was done on time, on budget with more than 55% of local  content. All of this was built in this 34-month period. But I think what is more remarkable on this project is the  fact that we have evolved in our ways of working and making sure that we are getting more productivity in  between the execution center doing the construction and the execution center doing the production. And really,  we have done this project in such a manner that the integration between the team of working as one throughout  SBM is such that we have been able to reduce the time of flaring the gas and actually getting into a better  production position on this project.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now the Stones project. One of the question you could ask is, this is a small FPSO, it's producing 50,000 barrel  per day, so why are you after this project? And I think the best way to describe this is really where this project is.  It's a deep project, it's deeper and it's Stones. In other words, it's a project whereby we're bringing new technology  to the industry. We're bringing a mooring system which is disconnectable, which is in the deepest water where any  FPSO has been awarded with an [indiscernible] (11:29) being connected to the mooring systems. We're really at  the forefront of the industry there, working with Shell in order to develop this new technology. The award was in  the second half of 2013, so it's not part of our order book.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now one of our non-core projects still in portfolio is the Deep Panuke project. What I can tell you today and what  we said in the press release is that the first gas was on the platform. We got authorization by the local authorities  to put the platform under production. We're in the final stage of commissioning and startup, and we expect the  platform to be on hire during the month of August.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now one question which comes naturally when you look at the market is, what is the evolution of the market, and  how do we see the production demand coming for – of services. The first point which is always important to  remember in the oil production market is that the depletion rate of existing fields is in the range of 7% to 10% per  year. So those field need to be replaced by new fields. Today, 30% of oil is being produced offshore. For the new  fields coming onstream, anywhere between 45% to 50% of the new field is coming from offshore. And most of this  offshore production is coming in deepwater.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now when we look at the opportunities of developing fields, we can see that deep water or ultra-deep water field  development can be developed between $30 to $80 per barrel. And it's quite competitive, even with conversion  only in some cases, but with all the other potential alternatives like oil shale gas in the U.S. or heavy oil also.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: In addition to that, if we look at the marginal cost of the costs associated with an FPSO, in particular, the  Generation 3 type of project, which is the large type of FPSO on which we are focusing, you can see that the  marginal cost of using an FPSO is only around $5 per barrel. So all of this give us confidence to state that the basis  of the economics of services to develop new FPSO – to develop new field with FPSO, is extremely good.

texts.speaker: Peter M. van Rossum
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: The other asset that we kept on the balance sheet is COOL hose technology, which we have sold in the meantime  as explained in the press release. We put a picture of the very proud SBM Installer on this page. The SBM Installer  is going through its sea trials at the moment. It's a brand new vessel which was commissioned by SBM some time  ago, before, let's say, the strategy definition that says we're going to focus ourselves entirely on FPSOs.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: And over the past two years, year-on-year, we have been investing more than $40 million into technology which  give us a lead into the Generation 3 project by optimizing the way the process is organized, by optimizing –  reducing the size of the equipment and so on, but also in advanced mooring systems. And you can see this in our  success rate on the turret mooring systems, including on the FPSO Stones Project for which the mooring system is  actually critical there.

file: SBMO - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 6August2014 130 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: From an environment point of view, also, we are producing – or we are better than the industry average by a fairly  big margin. And we are reporting no spill over the period in the first half of 2014.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, let's discuss, and I'm on slide nine for the one on the phone, let's discuss about the fundamental of our  market. Where is the supply of oil coming from, the additional supply of oil coming from? And really, we can see  three new buckets who are there really to replace the depletion of oil of existing reservoir in production today. The  first one is the shale oil in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: The impact has probably been larger than what was expected maybe even two years ago. Having said all of this,  because of shale oil is not new, it's pretty expensive, actually, and we expect that it's going to plateau by 2020  because the depletion of those field is even higher than the normal field. And therefore, it's – yes, it's an additional  [ph] cost (9:14) supply of oil, but it's not something which is going to be there on a meaningful way for a long  period of time, or at least that's our belief.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: A lot of projects went well, some projects didn't go that well, but the industry was learning at large. Today, what  we're seeing is that the projects are becoming more complex. The oil is more complex, it's often in deeper water,  it's often farther away from the shore base, so it's becoming more complex.

texts.speaker: Peter M. van Rossum
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: That's the kind of thing we're doing as well, looking at internal procedures, looking at the way we can manage our  projects better, looking how we manage our supply chain, and we have a clear expectation that the bottom line  benefit of these efforts should be at least a 5% cost reduction on the projects that we're managing. That 5% may  not all accrue to us, maybe part of that goes to the client. But reality is that it will makes us more competitive and  it will certainly, to a large part, improve our bottom line.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: We also announced probably a year ago that we're going to build on those competency in order to develop other  projects and other capacity for the market. And this is really for the FLNG product. Again, we're not going to be in  competition with the Shell of this world doing a large FLNG product like Prelude.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: What we're looking at is really positioning our product offering in the same manner than what we have done for  the FPSO conversion, so really medium-sized FLNG product, which will be there in order to help the development  of a field in remote area. And also, we're looking at other [ph] floating means (42:07) to develop field in deepwater  such as semi-submersible or TLP product, out of which we already have delivered five products and five TLPs over  the past few years.

file: SBMO - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 5August2015 130 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director
texts.text: Now, let me discuss about the market, and the market at large. What are we seeing in the market at this stage? We  will be seeing an industry which is in foundation. The oil price dropped significantly from $110 per barrel year ago  to in the range of $50 to $60 per barrel now. And really we believe that this is the market, the price of oil, which is  going to there to stay, and where we need to adapt the product and the services we're going to sell to the market to  this new reality.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director
texts.text: Why is this? What's happening really in the market? And what are we seeing is we are seeing that while the price  oil does decrease, there is still lot of investment in the Middle East, in particular, in Kuwait and Saudi to supply  the market with new capacity. We are also seeing that the shale oil part of the market is still there. That people  have made lots of progress in terms of their productivity and that the shale oil market has not decreased, the  supplies coming from shale oil has not decreased and in fact still present.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director
texts.text: So all of this is really creating a level of uncertainty in the market, in the pricing level for the oil price and is  putting pressure in us as an industry to adjust to that. Now, I would say that this is almost something which is  good, when the price of oil was around $100 per barrel, a lot of our clients were saying that, they still were not  profitable at $100 per barrel and we had to do something in order to reduce the cost of our product. With the  decrease in the price of oil, it's really putting the catalyst in the mind of everybody to fundamentally change the  ways of doing business. And that is good because that is really something which is going to play to the strength of  SBM Offshore and it is going to help us to generate a new way to do business in this environment.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director
texts.text: Now, our clients are already saying a number of things at this stage, in particular that they are cutting their CapEx.  That's clear. You can see this in all the numbers that you are seeing but it's really a sign that we see every day.  They are also telling us that they have plenty of opportunities to develop field in the quarter, plenty. But today,  those fields are not profitable at a price – oil price in the range of $60. So we need to find solution with them in  order to develop product and services, which is going to help them to develop those fields. And there are some  ways to do that. There are some ways that we can develop with them in order to get there. In order to get to this,  we are engaging with them. We are reengaging with them at lot of levels, at the project levels to start with, where  there is high number of tenders at this stage. It seems to be a bit counterintuitive, but really there is lot of activity  with people trying to seek ways to develop a field.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director
texts.text: So we're engaging at this level, we're engaging also at high level in oil companies in saying there is different ways  to develop fields. And if you can rely on a company like SBM Offshore, which has a lot of reliability in doing the  development of their project, you can be able to develop your field at a much lower cost than what you have done  in the past. And the third point that we are doing with our clients is really telling that for the restructuring we have  done over the past four years, we're today in a good place as a company, we're financially robust and we can look  to the future with them.

file: SBMO - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 11August2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board
texts.text: So, now, let me go more into what we expect on the macro-environment and our perspective in the markets. So,  the first point to note is that after a low 2015 order intake in the market with only four FPSOs were – being  awarded, 2016 is very slow so far; no award has been awarded. And we have revised our bull case from 10, only  a few months ago, to a maximum of three at this stage. And that, I just emphasize, is really our bull case.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board
texts.text: For 2017, the jury is still out. It really depends on the attitude of key clients to really make investment decision in  the countercyclical phase. Nothing is guaranteed there and there is a lot of uncertainty in 2017. But let's face it, if  this uncertainty were to materialize, meaning if no awards were to happen in 2017, the delay that the industry is   facing and the lack of supply that the oil industry is going to face, is going to grow exponentially.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board
texts.text: So what does it mean for the FPSO world? So, we're going to, first of all, look at our industry and have a look at  the industry at large, the oil and gas industry at large. All of this is leading us to make some choices, and the  objective of those choices, as a company, is really to come out of this downturn as the clear winner.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board
texts.text: Now, let's start, first of all, to discuss about the oil dynamic and two aspects explain the downturn in the industry.  The first one is the high cost level that the industry has been facing in developing deepwater field, and the other  aspect is the oversupply which are causing a low oil price.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board
texts.text: Let's start with the oversupply. Only since 2014, the world is producing more than consuming. It means the  implication of this is obviously price weakness of the oil price and the underinvestment which will lead to a lack in  production in the future.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board
texts.text: Now, the second point is really the high cost level that the industry has faced. And in 2013, a lot of the investment,  or most of the investments were made with the expectation of an oil price around $100 per barrel. Today, it's  obviously not the case, which means that the investments which have been done at the time are not making  money and later on paying dividend.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board
texts.text: At the end of this period, we're not going to have any order books, and this [ph] empty of the – (7:50) order book  is going to translate itself into a dip, which is we are not the only one obviously in the industry, but it's going to  translate itself into a dip into the supply of oil going forward.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board
texts.text: [ph] In this slide, we can see this on the commitment of big oil to the (8:24) CapEx. The oil companies today need  to juggle between their dividend payment, their debt payment and the reinvestment to preserve production. So  until they come back with CapEx in our market, our market is going to remain depressed. And our view is that our  market is unlikely to come back to a pre-level crisis in the medium term.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board
texts.text: Now oil companies cannot resolve the dilemma that they're facing of dividend, debt level and reinvestment into  new production without relying on competent contractor with qualified team and where experience matters.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board
texts.text: Now, if we look at the independent and the shale oil player, we can see that this crisis is starting to separate  winners and losers. But more importantly, in the oil services companies, the crisis has really taken a big beating  on this segment of the industry. And we believe that the shakeout which has started is not finished and is going to  be prolonged in next year.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board
texts.text: Now, the industry has really made a lot of progress over the past few months and has reduced the breakeven  point. And we can see that this breakeven point for the deepwater field has decreased and can be today probably  in the range of $50.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board
texts.text: If we specifically look at the deepwater challenges, there are plenty of those. There are plenty due to the water  depth, obviously; the complexity of the subsea field; the complexity of the oil which we are facing; the local  content; the life extension of those field and the regulation level which is increasing by the day.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board
texts.text: All this complexity means that [indiscernible] (14:35) are getting heavier, and all of this means that the costs have  been driving up. So, in 2014, looking at all of this, we started into a challenge in looking at what can we do in  order to reduce our costs and to reduce the time to market of our FPSOs, and we came with the Fast4ward  solution.

texts.speaker: Peter M. van Rossum
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Next please. Cost savings; as Bruno said, we've been at cost savings target since 2014. Initially, if I look at the  plans that we've announced, they add up to some $87 million. In reality, we have spent a bit more, around $100  million. But then the cost savings are also significantly ahead of what we had initially planned.

file: SBMO - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 9August2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: So, both the Yme and the Turritella commercial impact would be detailed by Douglas later on. From an industry  standpoint, what we can see is an improving economics of the deep water development. So based on this, we  have been working, as you know, over the past few years, to capitalize on our experience to find ways to make  FPSO more reliable, and we have committed to the development of the Fast4Ward hull. Again, more detail later  on the presentation.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: From an environmental standpoint despite the fact that we have increased significantly our fleet and operation,  our energy consumption has really not increased and has been stable through the quarter. So, that's really one of  the focus that we have also to limit the impact that we can have on the environment.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, let's discuss about the macro view and what we're seeing in the market at this stage. First of all, we're  seeing a new reality in the deep water development. We're seeing an improving deep water deep water academic  reality throughout the world. It could be in the North Sea, it could be in the Gulf of Mexico, in South America, in  Western Africa. So throughout the world, we're really seeing an improvement on the economics of deep water. It  means that further opportunity are going to be coming to the market and that today deep water is in part from an  economic standpoint with shale oil.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: In fact, if you look at the Liza development and those number have been provided by [ph] Heads (7:54), you can  compare the Liza cost of development compared to a good shale oil development. And the cost of supply with the  10% rate of return is 35% for – $35 per barrel for Liza against $40, $45 for the shale oil, typical shale oil.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: So, it demonstrate that deep water is becoming attractive again. And eventually, in the coming few months or  year, the deep water word is not going to become a dirty word anymore. It's really where activity is going to restart  and where opportunity are going to be there. Now, having said all of this, if we compare the potential market going  forward compared to the 2010 and 2014 phase, we're seeing a decrease. And basically, a market being reduced  by two compared to the peak of the market.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, one of the reasons why we are seeing such a bad word in the deep water market is really the delivery or  lack thereof in terms of the reliability in delivering FPSOs. Since 2009, we have seen 50 FPSOs being delivered.  Out of the 50 FPSO, basically, 70% has been delivered late. Now, the late delivery of an FPSO means that the  clients were getting their field in production later and their cash flow later. And the net impact on this of the  average delay is somewhere in the range of $500 million of loss of NPV for a client.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, the experience of SBM Offshore is really unique as you can see on this graph. It's unique in sense of the  number of FPSO we have delivered to the world, but also in the number of years of experience that we have in  running FPSO and, basically, with an average of time of 99%. This experience and this unique experience, and  learning suite is really what is going to help to provide new solution to the clients, which are going to be able to  come faster to the market, being more reliable and basically make deep water field development economic again  going forward.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: So, what is our position in all this? We're really on the floating solution market to the energy business and we  have three-legged growth strategy. The first one is really optimize or really to bring a premium performance in  everything that we do. It is from the operating side, delivering cash flow through the fleet that we're operating, the  Lease and Operate fleet that we have throughout the world, but it's also delivering our project on time to the  specification that the clients ask.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: The second leg is to transform the industry. If we were to stay in the same position as an industry, with so much  delay in the delivery of field, basically, the deep water industry is an industry which is not going to happen in the  coming few year. Now, we believe that through the experience that we have, we can standardize much more the  equipment that we're doing and deliver solution to our clients faster. That's the nature behind Fast4Ward project.  It's also what we're doing under the Digital FPSO project, whereby we're using the information that we have as a  company not only to improve our [ph] operation (12:28), but also to improve the delivery of what we're going to be  delivering going forward.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: The last pillar of our strategy is innovate, and there, it's really being to position ourself through floating production  in the gas and in the renewable market.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, in terms of premium performance, what we can see is that the production that we are doing has had an  average of, over the past half year, of 98%. We're producing basically 10% of the total deep water production oil  offshore and we have had an average of almost 1 million barrel of production per day in the past quarter. We also  can see the number of FPSO we have delivered throughout the world. And this experience, this unique  experience is really what is leading us to be able to standardize some of the things that we are doing.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, on the gas market. Gas is a commodity where the increase in demand is going to be significant going  forward and there are plenty of opportunity offshore. Now, we have had a number of experience in running plant  offshore – gas plant offshore like the Sanha or the Encana Deep Panuke plant. We have also tendered a number  of projects throughout the years and developed a number of concepts. And those concepts are not only for the  delivery of the full FLNG, but is also for the delivery of component pieces, like the turret on Prelude  and Ichtys. In  2017, we have signed a FEED, a FEED on which we're going to be working in order to find solution to develop  one of several FPSO going forward – FLNG plant going forward.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Okay. Thank you, Douglas. So, in summary, a performance in line with our expectation, a good performance for  the first half of the year. We're seeing improving deep water economics and opportunity arising from that. Those  opportunities are going to happen if we're able to standardize and we're able to bring reliable solution. And that is  what we are doing through the Fast4Ward program and the commitment that we have made in order to develop  this going forward.

file: SBMO - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 9August2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: From health, safety and environment, we're also showing some strong results. Our safety performance remain  good, where we're building on last year excellent performance and keeping the focus. We're also on track to meet  our environmental targets for greenhouses gas emission, flaring, energy consumption, and oil released in  produced water.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, with the aim of being relevant for year to come, we would develop then monitor and communicate on key  sustainable development goals in the same manner that we have done for the environmental indicator. As such,  as you can see, we have selected seven sustainable development goals for which we are in the process of  defining the goal, the action plan, and products that we're going to develop, a communication plan and a  monitoring plan of those.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, let's go through some of the key macro element that we're seeing in the industry, and why you can notice  that the tone of our communication is getting more positive. The first aspect is really a macro element, and the  supply gap that we're seeing happening in the industry. We have seen a lack of investments in 2014. Supply gap  in the production of oil is projected. The question is not if, but when, and investments are being required. As a  consequence, we're going to see, and we're seeing more projects in the industry, and probably more projects that  the industry can handle.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Given the capacity constraints, the meaningful upturn in the oil and gas services can be expected. And we believe  also that we're well-positioned to deliver sustainable competitive results by engaging early, by being close to our  clients, and by remaining disciplined on the type of projects we want to go after.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Deepwater also continued to gain competitiveness. More than 50% of projects in deepwater are more competitive  than shale oil. Now, the main issue in deepwater is the cycle time. It takes today eight years to start to get a  payback on deepwater development on average. This, we need to change. And this, we have the means to  change by developing – by reducing the time cycle. We believe that SBM should experience Fast4Ward again  investment that we have made of [ph] track record (08:05) will also help us to de-risk the project in the quarter and  to accelerate their development.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, the question then is how do we position ourselves in order to capitalize on the different trends that we're  seeing in the market? And so, our vision statement, we aim at better defining why we are here as a company. So,  starting with the big picture, energy is a basic need. The challenge is to supply a growing population with safe,  reliable, and affordable power. [indiscernible] (09:26) offer a competitive and sustainable energy now and in the  future under different form; oil, gas, and renewables. More than 60% of the population is close to shore and  offshore energy brings independency and local prosperity.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: [indiscernible] (09:47) to take to benefit from those big trends is that we are offshore people. We're deepwater  experts. And this is illustrated by the fact today we're delivering almost 1% of the global oil supply of oil from  deepwater. We have a unique set of values in entrepreneurship, ownership, care and integrity. Our value  proposition is centered around four key things, technology, project execution, operation and financing. In other  word, we commit to operate and make happen the things that we invent, develop and build. Our track record is  unrivaled and our experience matter going forward.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: So, in our strategy to grow, expand and create value is centered around three pillars, ranging from implementing  to inspiration, by creating a new future for the industry. So, under optimize, SBM builds on this experience to grow  our business, generate cash flow, create value from our solutions – from a proven solution. Under transform,  we're investing in the Fast4Ward and digitalization to transform the experience and leverage on our experience.  And innovate, we're focusing on the gas and renewable market and finding new solution for the industry going  forward.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: So let me try to illustrate, to give few examples for each pillar in the next part of the presentation. Under optimize,  you can see our track record in operating our fleet, which stand at 99% over time. And this is pretty remarkable  given the fact that we're producing 10% of the global oil in deepwater.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: The answer also in this cycle is threefold. It's first of all to be extremely selective in the project we're going to be  targeting. Second of all, to apply the Fast4Ward approach to our business, which will bring major benefit in cycle  time, de-risking project in the complex industry, and also keep the breakeven prices of deepwater low. And again,  Fast4Ward is one way of working by which we aim to create significant value to our stakeholders, our clients, our  shareholder, and the industry.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, why is cycle time important? And through this slide, we can show several points. The top slide show that the  time to first oil show an impact on oil company returns under different scenario. So, on-time delivery versus delay  or accelerated delivery. So, every one year of acceleration improves the breakeven price by up to $10 per barrel  with an IRR of 15%.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, the world is changing. And our aim is to provide safe, sustainable and affordable energy from the ocean for  generations to come. We're looking at the energy mix evolution and positioning ourselves in the growing market.  From the chart, it's clear that we can see a change on the evolution in the energy mix. Oil will remain dominant,  but its relative share will decrease. Gas will become as big as oil and form the transition fuel. Renewable is  ramping up also from a small base.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: How do we want to position SBM's growing market, and in particular, let me give you some example in the gas  market. We have been awarded a FEED on the new-build FLNG for New Age for associated gas project offshore  Cameroon, and we're working with a reputable world-class partner, which is responsible for the liquefaction on  this project. The FEED for the FLNG will apply the Fast4Ward principle as discussed previously. This new deal  creates another competitive project and product in this growing market. On the renewable side, we remain  committed to further develop a floating solution win solution.

texts.speaker: Bruno Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: So going to a Talisman Yme update. We have encountered a range of difficulties making the necessary progress to  meet our original target date of first oil in the first half of 2012. Poor productivity, caused by among other factors,  bad weather and an increase in work scope offshore are the main elements in slowing down the commissioning  and start up. We shall not be getting this type of facility again. But irrespective of this, I and the Board see this as  an imperative for SBM from a reputation standpoint as well as a commercial perspective to growing the project to  a successful completion with the client. As we have explained before, disputes, mainly related to cost, continue to  be the subject of arbitration proceedings with our client. But it can be categorized in saying that we are aligned  with Talisman in our determination to complete the platform for a mutual beneficial outcome.

texts.speaker: Bruno Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: On the project itself, progress is more satisfactory and remedial action has corrected the problems. However,  delays due to low productivity into the autumn and additional work on some system have required us to provide  for further cost. With productivity now understood and at the level satisfactory, delivery of first gas is expected to  be done during the summer.

texts.speaker: Bruno Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: So, when it comes to strategy, I think this slide has certain clarity. We have one focus, one purpose, one market  segment, and in concept one core product, the FPSO. SBM Offshore exists to develop complete offshore floating  production and storage solutions for the global energy industry.

texts.speaker: Bruno Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now a few words on our FLNG position; we would dedicate our offshore experiences just to large and medium size  units. We will selectively target edge technology products for large sized units and the complete vessel and  equipment in the medium sized categories.

texts.speaker: Bruno Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: We are also working on three turrets of which one is related to FLNG.

texts.speaker: Bruno Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: The operation contract only for FPSO Serpentina was extended until August 2013, including options for three  further one-year extensions. FSO Unity operation under contract with Total in Nigeria ended in September 2011.  And lastly, the FPSO Aseng started first oil production for Noble Energy in Equatorial Guinea early November and  is under contract for 15-year lease and operate contract with further extension of up to five years.

texts.speaker: Mark A. S. Miles
texts.profession: Thank you, Bruno. Afternoon, everybody. I'm going to go through first of all the income statements focusing on
texts.text: The third bullet point on the slide, $38 million associated with revised strategic focus on core FPSO products, so  indeed that's relating mainly to LNG investments in the past and pre-investments in LNG business and  development costs, and to a much smaller extent on renewables.

texts.speaker: Mark A. S. Miles
texts.profession: Thank you, Bruno. Afternoon, everybody. I'm going to go through first of all the income statements focusing on
texts.text: The fourth item, the ThunderHawk platform, you probably remember that this is the only platform in our units in  our leased fleet on which the revenues are partly depending upon production throughput, so the actual volume of  oil and gas produced through the platform, otherwise all of the leases are fixed day rates. This platform does have  a variable revenues element and with the delay in production in the Gulf of Mexico due to Macondo incident and  subsequent drilling moratorium.

file: SBMO - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 14February2013 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now the turrets is equipment business. As the FPSO units are becoming larger or, in some cases, one of the turrets  we're working on, the FLNG units are becoming much, much bigger, having a system to be able to move the  floating system and to be able to load oil on every day of the year, in some cases, if there is a hurricane or typhoon,  to be able to disconnect and go away is the critical component and a critical competitive advantage that SBM  Offshore has. Today, we're clearly the leader in this market segment. It's a market segment on which we have 30  years of experience, for which we are investing money in R&D and for which we're transferring the knowledge of  30 years of experience to our clients for value.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Why are our clients coming to us? They're coming to us because we're able to do systems which are reliable, able  to work with the higher tide and generate their cash flow. And that's what we have seen in 2012 in our fleet. We  have about 99% uptime in our fleet and able to do 440 offloading, meaning exporting the oil to our client – for our  clients [indiscernible] (0:13:54) good performance.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: That's the market. And the reason the market is so good in our view is that oil companies need to find new field in  order to compensate for the depletion of their resources. And the best way to find the resources is actually  offshore. And the solution we're providing at SBM Offshore is absolutely critical to their ways of developing field.

file: SBMO - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 6February2014 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: So what is the net effect of this? The net effect, if we look on the strategy, and here our – the strategy and if we  look at the strategy there, the orange boxes, we can see a few things. First of all that the  strategy of FPSO-led is  starting to bear fruit. We have been able to secure three contracts, which really are at the forefront of what the  industry is going to require. Two for Petrobras; one for Shell. We're going to expand on this later on.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, the only disappointing figure, I would say, is the LTI frequency. What is an LTI? LTI is when someone gets  injured at work and cannot work for a period of 24 months. This frequency actually increase year -on-year, despite  the fact that the number of incidents overall and the number of man hours were the same. And so it's really  something that we need to work on and to improve next year, 2014. In prior to that, we are not only looking at the  impact of our health and safety on people, but also in the environment and for the past two years, we have started  to take some measures about our performance there. We're measuring our performance compared to the industry,  which is pretty good. And we're going to be able to communicate further on this in the coming few months and few  years.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, let's discuss about the market. Two elements which are of interest in the market. Starting from – through  2012, what we see is that the production of oil from our clients has increased by 1.8%, fairly low inc rease.  However, what we're seeing is that the cost to do this development has increased in itself by 6.8% and if we don't  adjust to inflation, it has increased by more than 14%. All those figures are on a year -on-year basis.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: This is not a business proposition which is going to last, and it's going to have an impact on the industry [ph] and  all things that are going to be structured (9:14). We're also seeing that the national oil companies are facing more  importance in the market. They have access to the resources, and some of them used to develop those resources.  Petrobras is a case in point; they are the leader in deepwater development.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: But some other national oil companies used to be much more passive. They're getting more active. They are taking  more activity in developing projects and in the operation of project. What's happening now, is it okay? So there is   a shift in the industry. There is some change and it has an impact on how we're – what we're going to see, I  believe, in 2014, 2015, and maybe 2016.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: The other element on the market is the fact that projects or new potential projects are being discovered,  by and  large, in deepwater. In fact, over the last six years more than 50% of the elephant or the big reserves being  discovered has been done in deepwater by more than 2,000 meter water depths for oil, and more than 1,500  meter water depths for gas.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: This is a good news for SBM Offshore. Deepwater is really what's driving the utilization of FPSO, and the demand  for FPSO. And we're seeing that with more discoveries in deepwater there's going to be more opportunity to  develop those fields there.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: What is the knock-on effect of that? The knock-on effect of that is that the fields to be developed are more  complex. They are more complex because they are in deeper water; they are more complex because the oil is more  complex; and because the political environment is also more complex.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: On the technical side, we have been investing for a long period of time. But in particular for the past two years, in  developing technology, which is going to help to develop fields in deepwater. Fields which need disconnectable  power for example; fields which requires a lot of pressure going through the turret; field which required topside in  the FPSO which is heavier than we have ever seen for a converted tanker. So we provide the tech nical solution.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now looking at the E&P spending, and the E&P spending is segmented through the onshore market and the  offshore and deepwater market. I would say up to 2013, the E&P spending offshore including shallow water and  deepwater was in the range of 25% of the overall expenditure.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Over the period of 2013 to 2020 we're going to see yet an increase in the spending to be done, with the highest  increase coming from deepwater development, which is really the core market. But the net effect is – is it going in  and out? I'm sorry, is it okay now. Can you tell me if you can hear or – is it okay?

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: So with the net effect that the offshore E&P expenditure by 2020 is going to represent anywhere between 40% to  45% of all the expenditure of oil and gas company. So, we're in a market segment where the trend over the long  run is extremely good. It's extremely positive and we're well positioned in this market.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, our FPSO-led strategy also brought to us two new awards; one for two FPSOs for Petrobras of Generation 3.  What is Generation 3? Generation 3 is basically FPSO able to produce almost 150,000 barrels a day with a topside  in the range of 22,000 tonnes with a complex processing system, with a lot of interface with the client. All of this  needs to be done with local content, and all of this needs to be done in record time. And the client came to us  really to negotiate this, not through a call for tender, but through a negotiation for the award of this project.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: The second project is really the Stones project for Shell. In almost 3,000-meter water depth with a disconnectable  turret, it's the deepest, deepest of its kind worldwide and also, is at the forefront of where the industry is going to  go.

texts.speaker: Peter M. van Rossum
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: [ph] Here, it's (36:52) on the divestments; divestment program is continuing. We sold in 2013 two out of the three  office buildings in Monaco. The third one is being negotiated, as we speak. We sold the COOL hose technology;  that's a fairly minor overall divestment.

texts.speaker: Peter M. van Rossum
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Ratios, just want to highlight a particular ratio, which is pretty keen to us, which is the solvency ratio, where we  saw an improvement by just over 300 basis points, 27% at the end of 2012 to 30%, which is – clearly bringing us  much closer to, let's say, the green zone. But we're still quite a way away from the point where we want to be in  terms of balance sheet strength, which could also then bring us to, let's say, looking at an investment -grade credit  rating, which is still very much the [ph] costs (41:38) of the company.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: The second pillar of our strategy is the mooring technology. How do we fix FPSO, a floating object, to the sea  bottom; how do we fix system, which are going to access a lot of risers with high pressure, high temperature,  corrosive elements, going through an FPSO or through an FLNG?

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: And third pillar is really the development of new products. We cannot ignore the gas market. There are plenty of  opportunity in the gas market coming up, but we need to position ourselves in the gas market into such a way that  we can be credible and we can add value.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Our positioning in the FLNG market is basically the same than on the [ph] converted FPSO (46:18) market. If you  remember, the segmentation of our market is you have the small FPSO producing less than 60,000 barrels per  day; then you have the medium-sized or the large [ph] converted FPSO (46:31), which is our target segment,  producing between 80,000 to 150,000 barrels a day. Then you have the new build, which produce whatever  they're producing.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: The FLNG market is the same. Y ou have the new build; the new build is done by the Shell of this world; new stuff,  the Prelude project is a case in point. We are not competitive on that. We can provide components; we can provide  turret technology, but we're not going to do such a size of FLNG.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: What we can do is, we can provide a converted LNG tanker in order to produce small- to medium-sized fields, and  that's what we're developing. We're developing a concept which is called the twin hull concept o f FLNG. It's, at  this stage, we have done some design engineering; we're looking to go more into detail and developing this  technology over the coming few years.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: We are also developing technology to take into consideration the fact that oil is becoming mo re nasty. It's  becoming heavier. It's becoming more corrosive, that we need to transform gas to liquid. So, we're developing  technology on that.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: And, in some condition, you need to have a floating production system whereby the wellhead will be on the  topside rather than at the sea bottom. And the semi is really one way of doing this in deepwater. So, as you see,  we're developing a range of products also still linked to the floating production capacity.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: We want to keep investing into the large turret mooring technology. Again, there is plenty of opportunity there.  We have a lead on the market, and we want to further this lead. And we want to develop into new products. FLNG,  I expanded on this earlier on; semis, TLPs, and riser technology, in order to know how we interface the sea bottom  to our structure.

file: SBMO - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 4February2015 130 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director
texts.text: We can see the same evolution in terms of our environmental impact, whereby we've made further im provement  year-on-year on this side also. Having said all of these, this is a type of subject whereby we cannot be complacent.  We need to focus on them all the time. We need to make progress all the time; and is really a key indicator of our  overall performance as an organization.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director
texts.text: So what are we seeing in the market at this stage? And I mean all of us have seen that, but significant decrease in  price of oil. Y es, significant for sure, but the issue that the industry was facing were predating this decline in price  of oil. Our clients were not making enough money on the projects that they were doing. The type of projects that  we were doing and the structure of those projects had to be changed; and I would say that the decrease in price of  oil is in fact going to be a catalyst to change the structure of the industry and the ways of working.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director
texts.text: In fact, the last time we have seen such a change in the industry was probably in the mid -1980s, whereby the price  of oil decreased quite significantly and the industry changed. We went from an industry where most of the  offshore developments were done through platforms to an industry whereby the developments started to be done  subsea with FPSOs. We really believe that even though the market is extremely difficult, 2015 is not going to be a  good year in terms of order intake; it's going to give opportunity to restructure the industry, and really to help the  industry to grow over the medium and long-term.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director
texts.text: Now we also believe that the deepwater development is the place to win. 50% of the resources worldwide are in  deepwater and they all are going to have to be developed. They're going to have to be developed over the medium  and long-term, and we're well-positioned as a company in order to do that. In the medium term, we need to find  different ways of working with our clients.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director
texts.text: Now what are our clients telling us? They basically want to save cash at this stage. There is a high level of  uncertainty linked to the price of oil. What is the price of oil going to be tomorrow morning nobody has a clue. You  get forecasts ranging from $40 to $100 in the same day. Nobody has a clue. The volatility here is not good for  people to make plan. So there is – the only thing that people can do at this stage is really to preserve cash.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director
texts.text: Looking at the leverage ratio, as Bruno said, the expectation is given the current macro -environment is that the  order intake is going to be slow. That will have an impacts on EBITDA in 2015, it will have an impact from  EBITDA in 2016. 2015, we see an increase – 2014, we've seen an increase in net debt on the basis of high CapEx.  Part of that CapEx is paying off in 2015, but the full force of the cash flow contributions of the Generation 3 vessels  will only come in 2016, which means that we have seen an increase to a high level of debt. We're seeing EBITDA.  We will see EBITDA come down in 2015.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director
texts.text: What you do not see here is really all the Brownfield activity, the smaller type of project , which really is not  something that is visible in terms of large project, which really provides a lot of opportunity for us to generate  additional revenues to provide additional resources coming to our facilities. Also some FEED study, which really  are the bedrock of the future project to come. What you're not seeing also more importantly is really the Lead &  Operate portfolio of activity, which has an average life of 14 years and seven months.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Managing Director
texts.text: Now, we also have done a number of other strategic initiatives in order to position ourselves for the future. The  first part is really linked to our reaction to the market, with a drop of price of oil and the market volume, we have  had to reduce the workforce and we made an announcement on these in December, basically reducing our  workforce by roughly 12%.

file: SBMO - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 11February2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now, let's speak about the market and the macro environment. This shot is certainly not a surprise to any of you.  We have seen the price of oil dropping significantly over the past year-and-a-half, and to a level which has not  been seen for the last decade. Now, we can focus on the short-term price of oil and get worried about this, and  there is good reason to get worried about this, but also what we need to realize is that the industry and ourselves  need to adjust to a lower commodity price going forward.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now, if we look more at the medium and long-term fundamental, we need to keep hope on the market and on the  potential evolution of what's going to happen. From now until 2050, we're going to see a drop in population of  more than 2 billion people. We're going to see an increase in urbanization and we're going to see an increase in the  living standard. All of this means that in the coming 1 0 years, we're expecting to see a growth in gas demand by  42% and in oil or liquid demand by almost 20%.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Supply is going to have to be on the market for those demand increase. Even though, we don't want to speculate  on the price of oil, what we expect and what we have put into our plan is that we're going to see a tightening up of  the supply and demand in the period of 2018 and 2019 with a possibility of an increase in market demands for our  services.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now, we're taking the assumption that the offshore oil and gas industry is going to be able to adapt to the new  pricing environments, and that we're going to be able to develop projects in deepwater, projects which are going to  be economically viable at oil price between $45 to $55. Taking this assumption, we 're seeing an increase – an  expected increase in demand for oil or for services in deepwater and ultra deepwater which is quite significant.  Obviously, there is other markets which are going to increase lightly and conventional, but the demand for the  deepwater services and our product is going to increase. And this demand would increase in market such as Brazil,  Gulf of Mexico, and Western Africa. But we're also seeing new emerging market.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now if we look at the history of the number of awards for FPSO, we can see that this is tightly correlated to the  price of oil and it will not be a surprise to see with the low price of oil the historically low award market in the  FPSO market. In fact in 2015, we have seen only four FPSO being awarded, while on an average the average  demand for FPSO, new FPSO being on the market between 10 to 12 projects. So if we look at what is the market  telling us in the short-term, it's not a nice picture. The expectation two years ago was that in 2015, we would have  seen 13 FPSO being awarded. The reality has been that four FPSO have been awarded, one of which have been in  the target market of SBM Offshore.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So it's really a relationship which goes from a vendor relationship to more a tenant type of relationship. So the way  forward for us is first of all to protect the future. We believe that there is a future for the oil and gas industry  offshore, that there is plenty of opportunity to come for the FPSO market, and when the market is going to  rebound we need to have the capacity to be able to deliver our project and we need t o have the capacity to be able  to build two FPSO per year going forward.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: This is a reduction in our capacity of more than 30% compared to two years ago and is a reduction in fact much  greater in the sense that we are simplifying our ways of working and we 're also subcontracting much more, so our  fixed cost structure has been reduced significantly more than the 30% reduction, but it's a capacity we're going to  maintain and it's an investment we're going to have in the coming two years in the Company.

texts.speaker: Peter M. van Rossum
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The fact now that the full capacity is only reached later is actually also reflected in the average cost that we have  for declines at $7.20 which is even in today's oil price environment very attractive rates to continue to produce oil.  We had two new FPSOs. We also lost three FPSOs after end of contract and demobilization. Those were the Kuito,  the Marlim Sul, and the Brasil FPSOs that are no longer part of our operating portfolio.

file: SBMO - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 9February2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: The second point I would like to mention on this slide is our environmental performance. Despite the fact that we  increased our capacity and our FEED by three new vessels, our emission decreased year-on-year and our gas  flared decreased year-on-year. This is due to a number of factor, but some of them is also linked to the fact that  we launched Internet program in order to improve and lower our emission for [indiscernible] (05:12).

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, let's turn to the macro view in our market and what's happening in our environment. The first one, which is  not going to be a surprise for any of you, is really that the oil industry has been low in the investment and low in  the investment even further in 2016 compared to 2015 and 2014.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, the impact of this has been across the oil industry, but in particular offshore, whereby the number of new  tree order has been to all-time low for the past 17 years with 17 new trees being ordered, compared to an  average over the past 10 years of around [ph] 350 (06:39). It shows you the magnitude of the downturn in the  industry and the fact that there is a long way before we rebuild confidence in the deepwater industry and we'll  rebuild to a level of activity, which is going to be acceptable.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, what does it mean? It means that people need to adapt to the new reality and our clients need to adapt to  these. And a lot of work has been done in the industry in order to improve the economics of deepwater field by  reducing the specification and making them more fit for purpose by taking impact of the deflation in the industry.  And the net effect on these projects, which are being sanctioned or near being sanctioned, have decreased their  breakeven point per barrel significantly anywhere between 30% to 60%, depending on the case. It translates for  the FPSO industry into a demand we should increase. Now, it's not difficult to increase when you start from zero.  In 2016, basically, no project was awarded or no significant projects were awarded.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, how do we position at the end of showing all of this? Basically, we have looked at the reality of our market,  the opportunities that there is no market, and the broader market, and how to transform the company and to use  the experience that we have in the floating production systems. For this we developed a program, an  improvement program based on three pillars. Optimize, to optimize the current business that we have in portfolio.  Transform, and really transform how we develop the better project to transform the economics, the quality of what  we're doing. And this, we're working on two main projects, Fast4ward and digital FPSO. And third pillar is, to  innovate. Basically, to transfer the floating solutions that we have into other markets, being gas, being renewable  and other.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, Transform. On Transform, over the past two, three years, we really have been working significantly to  improve our ways of doing a project, to reduce the number of things that is being done on in terms of the over  specification and we need to come to solutions, which are more fit to our purpose. This is based on SBM Offshore  experience. This is based on what we have delivered over the year. And it's really a reduction which is  sustainable over the time even if we will see another increase in inflation going forward, the saving will remain.  And what we have done is basically being able to reduce our saving across our product portfolio in the range of  20% to 35%.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: While, going forward, we cannot be blind to the change in energy mix, which seems to happen in the industry.  What we can see in this slide is, going forward in the period 2015 to 2040, the expectation is that the demand for  renewable energy and gas is going to increase significantly. Even though that the demand of oil is still going to  remain at this [ph] steady or (17:54) good level. And let's not forget that for oil, there is a lot of depletion of the  existing fuel. Having said that, new areas or new markets for demand is going to appear in our markets. And it's  going to be on the gas side and on the renewable side.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: So, what is SBM doing about this? The first one is on the gas. And on the gas let's not forget that we have been  involved in this activity since 2005. We have been operating here Sanha LPG assets from [ph] this period (18:33).  We have been involved in the Deep Panuke assets also which is a gas plant for a number of years. We have  been involved in a number of turrets that we have – which have been involved on projects like Prelude and  Ichthys.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: So, all of this shows our track record and our experience. We are building on this. We're building on that capacity  in order to see what can be done to safely develop gas fields, which are smaller and to develop them in an  economic manner. And we're involved in a number of projects on this.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: CEO & Member of the Management Board, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: The second aspect is the floating wind. As you have seen, we're involved in the FEED project for EDF in France  on the floating wind farm. Now, this is important. If we believe the forecast, we can see that there is a huge  amount of opportunity for floating wind farm. And SBM is uniquely placed with the floating solution that we have  had over the past six years to provide a solution, which is fit for purpose. So, we have been investing in those  technology for the past few years. We're planning to finalize the FEED that we have. We're looking at all the  alternative projects for this technology and we want to grow this activity going forward because it's something  which is there on the core competence of SBM Offshore and while we believe that there is a good opportunity of  growing.

file: SBMO - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 8February2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: So, in summary, where do we stand for 2017? We have had a strong operating and financial performance in the  recovering market. All of these have been underpinned by the strong Lease and Operate activity that we have  had, which is really highlighted by the 1-million barrel production of oil per day, which is quite remarkable. Also,  another point which is remarkable given the fact that we were quite in downturn market is the fact that our backlog  is stable year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: From an operating standpoint, and you can see this through our safety performance, we have had the best year  ever on the Total Recordable Injury Frequency Rate. From an environmental standpoint, we have decreased our  flaring by 50%, and we have reduced our [ph] Greenhouse – green (00:04:59) gas emission by 30% (sic) [29%]  (00:05:00) year-on-year. We also have invested a fair bit of time and money into Process Safety Management,  improving what we're doing, putting much more focus – putting in place a number of campaigns, and we're going  to put further plans to develop the process safety in 2018 and 2019.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: So, from a macro standpoint, where do we stand? The first [ph] statement (00:06:13) is really linked to the oil  price. It's not news to any of you, but obviously the increase in oil price means that our client's cash flow has  improved, that their balance sheet is stronger, and that there is basically more opportunity for them to invest if the  right opportunity [ph] arises then (00:06:32).

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: There was also another point which is important is, when you look at the forecast on the oil price, it also means  that there is a perception in the market, which I believe is there to stay that the oil price is lower for longer. And  basically, [ph] new (00:06:50) investment decision are going to be made with the expectation that the oil price is  going to increase in the future. They're going to be made [ph] in which the mind (00:06:58) that the oil price is  going to be between $50 to $70 or let's call it around $50 per barrel. If it goes above that, there is [ph] bullish and  bonanza (00:07:08) coming up, but the investment decision would be made on that.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, a lot of talk has been happening in the industry about the significant cost reduction we have seen year-on- year since 2015, and when we look at the cost reduction of the [indiscernible] (00:07:48) inflation we have seen in  the industry is probably can be quantified around 30% overall.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, all of this will not make any sense if there was no project to develop. Now, what we have seen is, over the  past few years, a number of clients throughout the world have been able to decrease the break-even points by  more than 60% at times, and a number of high-quality reservoir being sanctioned for the development of [ph] fuel  (00:09:24). So, this gives us a visibility and opportunities to demonstrate that offshore is a viable investment  opportunity for the oil companies going forward.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now what is the strategy in order to capitalize on the market upturn? Our strategy which have been developed  only two years ago has not fully changed. The first aspect is really to optimize what we're doing. Let's not forget  that today we're processing more than 10% of the oil in deep water. We have a backlog of around $17 billion that  we deliver to the full satisfaction to our client. So, with a reliable production, with high [indiscernible] 00:13:35)  performance, and all of these were in budget generating the cash flow that we expect.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: We also see that there is an opportunity for the deep water field to be developed. And for this, we need to  transform the industry. For this, we have invested in Fast4Ward. We'll keep investing in Fast4Ward. For this,  we're investing also in digitalization and I'm going to go more in detail later on in the presentation.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, our world is evolving. Energy demand is growing. The shift in demand is changing with more demand for the  gas, more demand for the renewable. There, we have all possibility for future growth in the company. We are  positioned on the energy market both from moving system but also for full system development and we are also  positioned on the floating renewable market.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, the Lease and Operate activity, again we're delivering 10% or we're producing 10% of the [indiscernible]  (00:16:16) deep water which is quite remarkable. We have had an extremely strong [indiscernible] (00:16:21) year  and this year we've basically several time produce more than 1 million barrel per day. It's really a sign that we are  leading operator in this activity. And our expectation in these markets are fairly high, something which is going to take a bit of time, that's  [indiscernible] (00:19:29), but we want to be positioned and we want to be a leading competitor there.

And this was slightly offset by an  increase in R&D expenditure, reflecting the fact that we're continuing to invest in R&D projects such as  renewables and digital FPSO, as Bruno just mentioned.
