texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: The two business segments are sustained by game-changing attributes: continuous learning, which really helps  us to improve our product and services year-after-year; the investment into the Fast4Ward program, which is a  groundbreaking program in the industry; and the investment that we're doing in digitalization in all aspects of our  business from Lease and Operate where we started, but also on the Turnkey side. On top of this, SBM Offshore  wants to remain relevant for years to come and we're investing in transition fuel such as gas, renewable; and  investing in technology to develop a portfolio of product to get energy from the ocean for years to come.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: In environment, we're seeing also significant progress in the company. We have seen a significant decrease in  greenhouse's gas emission from a fleet of more than – almost 40% over three years, and this is despite the fact  that our fleet capacity has increased significantly for the period. All those points again demonstrate SBM  commitment to continuously improving our business execution and becoming better year-after-year.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, we want to remain relevant for years to come [indiscernible] (00:05:23) sustainability program is critical to  this endeavor. We're integrating sustainability in the ways of working, as has been done with safety and integrity  in the past. We have created a roadmap on how to integrate [indiscernible] (00:05:41) sustainability development  goals in the coming decade.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: As you can see, we have prioritized three of those goals with specific target and objective and scorecard that  we're going to follow quarter-after-quarter year-on-year. Four more sustainability development goals would be  added in 2019 and 2020. I would say that our teams embrace this effort. A nice example of their engagement  [indiscernible] (00:06:12) imagination has been in reducing the flaring with remarkable results as you have seen in  the previous page.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: So, the question now is what is our strategy to address this market and what is the strategy ready to grow SBM  Offshore in the future. So our strategy has been constant over the past few years. It's based on three pillars;  Optimize, and the end product of this is probably the cash flow generation to give us the ability to reward our  shareholders and to grow the business; Transform, and it's really to transform the oil development business in the  quarter, making Fast4Ward the industry [indiscernible] (00:10:47); and Innovate, while bringing investment into  our R&D project to create new products and services for the gas and the renewable market.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Let's put things in perspective. Today, SBM Offshore is producing roughly around 1 million barrel of oil per day  which is roughly 10% of – 1% of the overall production of oil worldwide. It's quite a remarkable statistic.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Some of the projects we're looking at and on which we're involved earlier on are going to be in production in less  than six years, so it's saving two years. I'm not saying that saving two years is coming only from the Fast4Ward  program but is also coming from the fact that we're involved with our clients as well.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Now, Innovate is really based on investing into new technologies for the renewable and the gas market. This is  exactly what we have done in the past in the oil market and that we'll continue doing. Our R&D budget has  probably been the biggest in the industry and we're using today this technology budget to address the renewable  market, the gas market, and other opportunity that we can see from developing or getting energy from the ocean.  That's what we call energy committed.

texts.speaker: Bruno Yves Raymond Chabas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SBM Offshore NV
texts.text: Tenure of the RCF is five years to 2024, with two extensions possible of one year. We secured this facility with  our key relationship banks who committed to continue to support SBM Offshore in this new growth phase. And we  were able to retain competitive rates plus as a first for the oil and gas services sector, we have a new innovative  feature where the margin can vary based on our sustainability performance. So with respect to liquidity, we've got  more flexibility in relation to the RCF. And addition to this, we have a $720 million loan with the Liza Destiny in  place, which we are intending to fully draw later this year.

file: SBRYL - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 10November2010 445 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Nov-10.pdf

texts.speaker: David Tyler, Chairman
texts.profession: Well welcome, ladies and gentlemen. I said a nice little bit of piece as I came up to the platform.
texts.text: Moving on to tight control of our costs, we’ve seen cost increases come through at circa 2% of the  lower end of our medium range – medium term guidance of 2% to 3%. We’ve seen a big uptick in  rates as a result of the revaluation exercise of last year, but that’s been broadly offset by savings in  energy; so the two have played a draw, so overall, costs up by 2%.

texts.speaker: David Tyler, Chairman
texts.profession: Well welcome, ladies and gentlemen. I said a nice little bit of piece as I came up to the platform.
texts.text: We’re very pleased to say that we’ve been able to fully offset all of those inflation increases through  costs savings in the business, principally driven by, for example, simpler in-store processes, the  rollout of our self-scan checkout, which is now in over 600 stores. And for those stores where we  have self-scan, over 40% of transactions go through that route. We’ve made savings in our logistics  area, and also reductions in energy, packaging, and waste. And indeed for our Energy Reset  Program for those stores that participated, we’ve seen on average 17% reduction in energy costs of  those stores.

texts.speaker: David Tyler, Chairman
texts.profession: Well welcome, ladies and gentlemen. I said a nice little bit of piece as I came up to the platform.
texts.text: And whether it be the fantastic announcement we were able to make of 100,000 – 100 million on  Active Kids, the announcement we’ve made in the half of Paralympics sponsorship, which we know  already is motivating customers and colleagues if they feel the same relationship with the  Paralympic Games is absolutely what they would expect of our business; all things, like  Compassion in World Farming recognizing our industry-leading position on animal husbandry. And  if you’ve seen the controversy in the press in the last month or so about issues of Halal butchery,  you’ll know that animal husbandry is very high still on customer’s agenda.

file: SBRYL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 9November2011 445 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Nov-11.pdf

texts.speaker: John Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: Moving from sales to profit, underlying EBITDAR up to £896 million, up 5%, delivering an EBITDAR margin of  7.66%, which at the headline level is 8 bps down, but taking account of the increase in fuel prices, adjusting for  that shows an underlying improvement of 8 bps. Operating profit up 7% to £396 million, delivering an operating  margin of 3.39%. Again, at a headline level 3 bps but adjusting to fuel prices, up 10 bps at the underlying level.

texts.speaker: John Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: Moving now into our operating costs, we've delivered good operating cost savings in the first half year of £50  million, they're bang in line with the guidance that we gave at the prelims. From a number of areas from self  checkouts, improving our store processes, central cost reductions here in Holborn, logistics efficiencies, and, of  course, our various energy saving initiatives in our stores that helped deliver that £50 million in the first half.

texts.speaker: John Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: And as we've said before, in the first year of opening a new store it tends to be earnings dilutive and you're seeing  that in these numbers here. And then, of course, our continued investment in growing the business diluted by a  further 2 bps to give the operating margin improvement on a fuel-adjusted basis of 10 bps. Obviously, fuel price  inflation, as I mentioned earlier, dilutes that by 7 to give a headline level of 3 bps.

texts.speaker: John Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: In terms of the full-year guidance, we expect the margin progression on a fuel-adjusted basis to be circa 10 bps,  within our guidance range of 10 bps to 20 bps that we gave at the prelims.

texts.speaker: John Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: Looking at our overall returns, you'll see here the EBITDAR margin, and so this is on a non-fuel adjusted basis, so  ticking back slightly, a slight improvement in our underlying operating margin. But I wanted to focus on the  ROCE number because ROCE, return on capital employed, is a key metric for us as a business. Indeed, it's been  part of our long-term intensive plans for management over the last five years. We've seen that tick back slightly  half-on-half as a result of the impacts of adding more new space. As that space starts to mature, we expect to see  that ROCE performance improve over time, as David mentioned. And in fact, he'll come on to talk a little bit in  more detail about how we see the ROCE performance of our stores, new stores, change over time.

texts.speaker: Justin M. King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: In my 30 years in this industry, we've not seen the graph at this level, but I think you can see the clear impact of  fuel, which will, all other things being equal, of course, unwind when we annualize. But I wouldn't expect to see  that lead to a step up in volume, unless of course, we saw a step back in fuel prices, and I don't think many of us  are expecting that to be the case.

texts.speaker: Justin M. King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: And I want to spend a few minutes reinforcing how we stand up that idea of Live Well For Less. It starts with our  values because, as I said earlier, our customers are saying, "Do not compromise on your values because they are  our values too." And there are many examples here. Our recently launched 2020 sustainability plan, a  confirmation that we're going to keep ourselves at the forefront of sustainability, significantly ahead of our grocery  competitors, something that our customers value.

texts.speaker: Justin M. King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: And you see this evidence in the performance of all of our sub-brands for Sainsbury's. You see both Taste the  Difference and Basics there growing at around 10% in the last quarter also. And again, this is showing savvy  shopping going on. About half of our shopping baskets with Taste the Difference in also have Basics in at the same  time. This is customers Living Well For Less: buying something, if you like cheap and cheerful, often to cook with,  when that's all they need, but making sure they keep enough money in their household budget to buy the very  best.

texts.speaker: Justin M. King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: Why is that? Well, again, it comes back to Live Well For Less. Our Basics have vested in it all of Sainsbury's brand  values. We don't compromise. We don't move to mechanically recovered meat or artificial additives in Basics. We  don't say to our customers: to buy the cheap stuff, you've got to give up on your values. Why? Well, because it's the  same customer. It isn't a customer uniquely buying it. It's the same customer savvy shopping across the mix.  And earlier, an encouraging sign is that our launch from Buy Sainsbury's is delivering growth. In fact, in the  categories that we've re-launched, average year-on-year growth at around 10%. So we're kicking on again in the  core of our own label offer in terms of delivering Live Well, as well as For Less.

texts.speaker: Justin M. King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: We have a market leading position on British apples. We sell more British apples than any other retailer, and that  includes Tesco, by the way. And that – again, it's back to this Live Well For Less. Our customers tell us that they  expect us to lead on things like British sourcing. Indeed, British sourcing is one of our key commitments in our  2020 sustainability plan. We've committed to doubling British sourcing in cash terms by 2020.

texts.speaker: Justin M. King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: As a simple example here, on the slide of car insurance, where we deliver our brand values, our complaint levels  are completely industry-leading on the insurance products that we sell. Our customers vest in us an expectation  that we won't be like other insurance companies. We use our Nectar data to identify customers who are likely to  own cars. Of course, one can even see that through their petrol purchases in our store. And of course, the key  insight -- it is not huge insight in this particular instance, is what's the number one thing on people's minds at the  moment if they have a car is how much it costs them to fill them up, so we delivered a promotion that's all about  petrol for taking you car insurance, and not surprisingly, by cross-selling in stores, so we know they are our  customers because there are shopping with us, we delivered 140% increase.

file: SBRYL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 14November2012 445 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Nov-12.pdf

texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: In terms of looking forward into the second half, we expect the environment to remain challenging, and of course,  we have some tougher comps year-on-year and also a smaller contribution coming through from extensions,  reflecting the step down in our property program. But we're guiding to, and I think this is [ph] stretch (4:28)  guidance to the business, a like-for-like similar in second half to that will go in the first.

texts.speaker: Justin Matthew King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: I said back six months ago when asked, what do we think the Olympics, the Jubilee, Paralympics would be in  terms of sales, and we felt then and it turned out to be the case, they we're not sales events in the round. The  events themselves were, the Jubilee, the two or three days before it rained was a fantastic sales event. But the  buildup, as we've seen for all major sales events in recent years was characterized by people cutting back, saving  money so they could splash out when the special event came. And then we also saw in the weeks immediately  following, not least of which because the weather was truly awful in June and early July, people cutting back to  sort of re-establish their balance sheet.

texts.speaker: Justin Matthew King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: Our pricing – our milk pricing model came into its own in the last six months. A lot of conversation about fair  prices in UK dairy farmers. The ability to say how our farmers are paid by a unique model, a model that they voted  on, which protects them from the pricing increases they're seeing, but also ensures that they continue to invest in  animal and environmental stewardship has really paid strongly these customers.

texts.speaker: Justin Matthew King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: A lot of our environment investments, perhaps less powerful with customers if you're in a shop with a photo  voltaic on the roof, you'll probably have noticed it. We are the biggest multi-site operator of photo voltaic in  Europe. Fairly marginal claim I expect but we are.

texts.speaker: Justin Matthew King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: And – but importantly, John talked about cost savings. They contribute towards cost savings too. There's a  straightforward capital case, as well as an environmental case in investments that we're making here. And I hope  most of you got the opportunity to see the fair share event we did in store about a month ago. Our customers  donated a million meals. We matched it with a million meals. Seeing their charitable community efforts pop up in  their community is incredibly important to consumers today.

texts.speaker: Justin Matthew King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: Now I think it is small and so we shouldn't overplay it. But remember the point I'd made earlier, if you're starting  to move away from customers choosing stores on price because they are reassured on price, they are able to make  the choice on one thing that's important to them. And I think that stunning growth in free form is not a reflection  of a sudden step on in people being aware they're dairy or gluten intolerant. It is people being able to choose  where they shop for the particular issues that are important to them, and 30% growth is the result.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: So how have we delivered that operating margin? Well, of course, it's often about cost management. texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc

If you remember, we guided at the prelims to  transitional payments in this year of £50 million. So we're coming in a little bit lower than that that we guided to.

texts.speaker: Justin Matthew King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc

texts.speaker: Justin Matthew King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc

texts.speaker: Justin Matthew King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc

texts.text: So, almost an inevitable consequence of that is that the supply and demand equation has changed. That's the  structural effect. So, from a customer point of view,  that's great news. If you look at fuel prices, petrol, customers are paying about 20p a liter less than they were this  time last year. So, that's about 4 pounds or 5 pounds a week in their pocket week-in and week-out.

texts.text: It wasn't that long ago that actually the UK strawberry season was only 10 weeks long. texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And indeed, there are other investments to be made like Mobile by Sainsbury's, and indeed the Sainsbury's Energy  business. So these are opportunities for us to develop our business and indeed, utilize our space potentially,  differently in the future.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Of course, when you add all of that number together, you get to a number of about £500 million of overall price  investment over the next three years but we think it's more intellectually honest to talk about it as an annualized  investment of £150 million. texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director

texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We've got fantastic opportunities, investment opportunities to continue to grow our business, whether it's online,  convenience, the bank, great growth opportunities for us. texts.speaker: David Alan Tyler
texts.profession: Chairman
texts.text: We're therefore, perhaps, a little bit ahead of where we expect it to be one year into the strategy. And of course,  there remains a great deal to do. texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Coming on now to the Bank transition, we now have a core banking platform that's being built. It's currently in its  testing phase. And hence, to get that right, we are delaying that  migration by six months to nine months. And we think that's a right thing to do from a customer perspective. The  consequences of that, though, in terms of our transition costs, if you remember last time at the prelims, we've  guided to a range of transition costs of £340 million to £380 million. texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Electricity usage. So whether it's inventory management or short life code checking, all of which has delivered significant cost  savings in the year, which is why we're able to up our target for the full year. What we've really been pleased about  is that – it says here no impact on sales or availability. If anything, the changes that we've made have improved  our availability, they've improved our service levels within our stores.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And actually, that simplifying pricing has had a significant impact on our supply chains, a positive impact. We've  actually seen a significant lowering of our waste bill over the last year. That's, I guess, in some respects not  unexpected, but, actually, we've been really pleased with the progress we've made on lowering our waste costs, but  actually, also improving our in-store availability. And I'll come back to this later on.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Firstly, the weather was particularly unseasonal or unseasonable over the summer. So the seasonal categories  were not particularly buoyant in the year or in the first half. And secondly, particularly, big ticket electricals have  been under pressure. So actually, it's a pretty good performance in the context of what has been a difficult market.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And the final part to talk about is our values making us different. And at the end of the day, Sainsbury's is a  business with a heart. This is a program that is aimed at  attacking the waste challenge that we have as an industry, but on a holistic basis so there are many, many  individual initiatives.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We're offering £10 million over the next five years, starting with £1 million working with a single town. We've  actually had close to 200 applications. And we'll be choosing a town to work with over the next period of time,  looking at how we can use all of our expertise and experience to work with that town to lower food waste both for  customers within our shops and, of course, increase and improve recycling content.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We've removed a lot of sugar from products. So we've talked about orange juice where we've reduced the sugar  content by about 10%. Similarly, on yogurts, we reduced the sugar content by 37 tonnes. Dairy is a big issue. We've  had a big challenge over the summer on the prices that's paid for milk. We pay on the basis of the cost of  production, which means that our dairy farmers, the 300 people that supply us, are, to some extent, insulated  from what happens within the marketplace. And we think that's right in terms of building long-term relationships  with those farmers. And that's just one example at how we work with our farmers to make sure that we do the  right things, not just for them but also for our customers.

file: SBRYL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 9November2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: We recognize the sustainable sourcing, so we have the highest possible score for the World Wildlife Fund's Palm  Oil Buyers' Scorecard, it's one of the key ingredients in the loss of the food and the loss of the products that we  sell. We made a big commitment to cutting food waste. This is the single biggest issue on the minds of our  customers when it comes to corporate social responsibility. So, we've committed to investing £10 million in  helping our customers reduce food waste, starting with the program in our Swadlincote store and then the  Swadlincote district of £1 million where we're learning what kind of interventions work, and therefore what kind of  things can we roll out across the country more widely.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: One other thing that we've also encouraged is food donation. So, we now have 1,100 charitable partners. We  have the highest proportion of food donations in the UK, and we're seeing a reduction in our food waste of almost  10%. So, we've started with reporting on our food waste in our business, and that's come down 10% year-on- year.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: If we look specifically in Sainsbury's business, the general merchandise business grew by 5%. So, pretty  creditable performance in a challenging market. Actually our clothing business grew by 1% in the half as would  have been reflected in other's results. It has been a challenging market, it's fair to say. The weather was less than  helpful during the early parts of the summer, which is one of the main selling seasons. But nevertheless, we saw  our market share grow, and we are the sixth largest clothing retailer by volume, which again, if you consider that  business through all intents and purposes didn't exist 10 years ago. That's a fantastic performance over that  period of time.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: So John Rogers was the one in the green suit for those of you who are watching carefully. So, we said we'd  deliver £160 million of synergies. We have more confidence than ever that we will deliver those £160 million of  synergies. We will put 250 Argos digital stores in Sainsbury's stores, so not quite about half of the estate.  Sainsbury's has about 656 markets but nevertheless as against going physical presence over the next three  years. And there were significant cross-selling opportunities, as I've already said, across the portfolio. For  instance, two clothing within the Argos business platform, and we'll have an Argos point of presence in every  single, more or less every single Sainsbury's store. So, while don't have an Argos digital store, we will have Click  & Collect points across our estate.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: Again, there are many things that we don't sell that we buy. And, across the group, things like electricity,  fixturization of things that we can seek to reduce our cost. And, again, we've got good line of sight on delivering  those synergies. And as I said already, other revenue synergies, for instance putting [indiscernible] (55:19)  clothing through the Argos network.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: We've reworked the non-food space, the physical presence of our non-food, our clothing and general  merchandise. And again, although, we're not pretending to be a department store, it certainly looks and feels  more like the High Street than ever. And we put our Habitat concession in, again, that's an interesting opportunity.  It's something that again we've not built into our synergy case. But as I've already said, we'll have seven habitat  stores running in Sainsbury's stores by the end our financial year.

file: SBRYL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 9November2017 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: Another example is respect for the environment. This is a good example of where our values not only have a  positive impact on society more generally on the impact on the environment, they also have a cost benefit. So as  an example, investing in LED lighting. It's a big program for us. It has reduced our overall cost and reduced our  energy consumption. I know it clearly has an environmental impact as well.

file: SBRYL - Q2 2019 Earnings Call 8November2018 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: Again we're looking to differentiate our product ranges through what we call distinctive products, some of which  are owned brands – some of which are owned brands and some of which are working with other branded third- parties to introduce new and unique products. So, example of that and a big trend in the UK is towards flexitarian  eating. I'm sure there's plenty of flexitarians in this room, eating more vegetables, less meat. I'm looking at how  we can combine those products together to help us introduce a range called, Love Meat & Veg! And there are  some examples of the products there. Again, vegetarianism is rising in the UK. Product you see on that side is a  Shroom Dog, a mushroom-based hot dog. And again, big trend, and opportunity for us to differentiate relative to  our competition. And then, naturally, what you get is a vegan-based spread, plant-based burger patty, which  again, adds differentiation and difference in our ranges.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: [indiscernible] (00:21:44) in this industry, we used to obsess about trading intensity. It kind of drops off the  agenda. But one of the things we'd like to highlight is how we are repurposing our space and making our space  productivity higher. And that's perhaps one of the untold stories in our overall strategy. So, we talked four years  ago about the need to repurpose about 1.5 million square feet of our space. And we repurposed around 700,000  square feet of that space. And typically, that means putting new offices in, like Sushi Gourmet, as an example.  Overall, and perhaps has more significantly, transferring Argos stores into Sainsbury's stores.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: We saw the strong performance in Argos driven by electricals, at least, in part, because of the timing of the World  Cup this year. And that has had an effect on the margin mix, which we believe, will carry through into the second  half. And of course, we hope summer weather has a benefit in the sense you sell all of your fans and barbecues,  but you don't sell many lawn mowers. So, there's a tradeoff one way or another in terms of the mix effect as a  result of sunny weather.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: And we don't mention Habitat much, but again, there's been a lot reshaping of the Habitat business; again,  closures in the home-based real estate; and we've opened a number of new stores, some in Sainsbury's stores,  but actually, also, during the last period of time, a couple of standalone stores, one of which is in the Westfield  Center in Shepherds Bush; one of which is in the center of Brighton. So, we just put our toe in the water as to how  we might develop that business into the future.

file: SBRYL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 9May2012 445 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In the last year, we've improved the future prospects of the business by continuing our major investment program,  offline and online, in our products, in our services and in our infrastructure. And we have at the same time set out  a comprehensive sustainability program 20 by 20 that underlines our environmental and social commitments

texts.speaker: John Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: Guidance for 2012-/2013, we expect cost inflation to be at the upper end of our range, so around the 3%. It might  even nudge a smidge over. So tough cost inflation coming through in this next year's numbers, but again we expect  to offset that through £100 million of efficiency savings, so broadly 75% of that inflation being offset by savings.

texts.speaker: John Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: And these savings have come from a number of different areas across the business, whether it's logistics,  optimizing our routine for drivers, whether it's procurement in the way that we buy. In this example here, our  supermarket trolleys, whether it's in our store costs, in our processes in store or indeed our energy. So, for  example, a good example on savings is electricity. Over the last five years, we have reduced our absolute  consumption of electricity by 9%. At the same time, we've increased our space in our portfolio by 25%. I think  that's a great example of driving cost savings through the business.

texts.speaker: Justin M. King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: In an average shopping grocery-shopping basket of 20 or so items, a 5% reduction is a one-item reduction. And I  would suggest that that took place over a five-year period, we would consider it a dramatic trend. For it to have  taken place virtually overnight, I think tells you quite how significant that change was and how consumers had to  react to the pressure they were under.

texts.speaker: Justin M. King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: In particular, we commented before, the tipping point was a step up in fuel prices. And we do see that connection  whenever fuel prices start to tick up, immediately consumers looking to find that saving in their weekly budget.  But of course, if you have a multi-channel business, and we do, with convenience and online, you can reflect that  trend, and it's why indeed – one of the reasons, at least, that both of those businesses are growing strongly.

texts.speaker: Justin M. King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: And the final comment on the slide reinforces a point that I made at the interims. We have seen a once-in-a- generation reduction in volumes in the grocery market through 2011. That's the first time since the oil price shock  in the 1970s. And I think it's reasonable to assume that this has legs to run yet, so underlying volume decline,  perhaps not as dramatic as it was last year, but further underlying volume decline in 2012 is certainly our  planning assumption.

file: SBRYL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 8May2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: Guidance for your models for next year; we expect cost inflation to be in the middle of the range, so similar this  year, in 2013-2014, to last year. And then we expect again to offset that with efficiency savings of around £100  million.

texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: The nature of the transaction is that in the early years we have to invest cash to build the new state-of-the-art  banking platforms, but once we've invested that cash and once we've overcome the double running cost of the  bank in the early years, the transaction very quickly becomes highly cash generative. And also, of course, as David  said, we're expecting to complete on this transaction at the end of January 2014. So we've got a bit of a lead into  completion, but that allows us to do plenty of preparation in terms of designing and putting more detail on the  transition plan going forwards.

texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: And of course the bank, in and of itself, has to invest in the new banking platform, so £170 million of transition  costs and £90 million of capital investment by the bank to build its new systems and transition off the old ones  from LBG.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: Under each of our five areas of focus for corporate responsibility, big achievements in the last year, and we've been  at the forefront of the debate around healthy eating with fun-to-pack labeling and we're starting to use our  pharmacies now to drive that healthy living message with our customers.

texts.speaker: Justin Matthew King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: Leadership positions in all of the major trends in ethical sourcing of food; it's both Fairtrade, MSC Freedom Foods  to name but three. The environment is interesting, because it's absolutely part of the corporate responsibility  program. 82,000 solar panels, it's the biggest solar array in Europe, but it's also part – as John touched on the  amount of money we're investing in programs, which drive cost savings, well, that's a capital investment in  addition to being environmentally sound, is also a cost saving capital investment.

file: SBRYL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call Preliminary 6May2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Coming on now to margins. Clearly, the margins have been impacted by the price investments that we've made  this year, not only in the first half but perhaps more importantly, stepping on in the second half. So, we've seen  underlying EBITDA margins taking account of changes to fuel prices of minus 39 bps. We've also seen at the  operating margin level a reduction of 62 bps, again, reflecting the price investments that we've made particularly  in the second half.

texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: From a transitional perspective, we do expect the costs of transition to increase from what we've previously  guided. Nonetheless, the business case for the Bank remains, in our views, very attractive. In fact, I think our view  on the Bank today versus 12 months ago would be the opportunity is even greater than we first thought in terms of  our ability to grow that business in terms of the loan book and the credit cards and savings, et cetera. So we  remain very upbeat about the Bank, but the reality is that the costs – the transition costs, we feel will be £80  million to £120 million higher than we previously guided, albeit all of that increase is in capital.

texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The guidance for 2015/2016, we expect the transition costs to be circa £50 million, and £75 million of transition  capital, that's in line with what I've just told you on the previous slide. And also something here, which we've  talked about in the past, is our property profits. And this is not property profits in relation to sale and leasebacks,  but this is property profits in relation to mixed use development schemes, specifically the opportunities that we've  talked in the past about at our Fulham store and our Nine Elms store, all of which flows through, over the next two  years, to circa £200 million of property profits, so that's again a very positive message in relation to how we're  using our property portfolio to unlock value.

texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So just breaking that out in a little bit more detail. So cost savings £140 million, in line with what we guided at the  interims, no change there. For 2015/2016, we expect cost inflation at the lower end of the range, 2%-3%, so call it  2%, and efficiency savings of £200 million in 2015/2016. That's in line with the £500 million that we talked about  when we announced our strategy at the interims, so a slight acceleration of that run rate. So, £200 million in  2015/2016 and obviously £150 million, £150 million in the following two years to deliver in total the £500 million  of savings. And we've got very, very good line of sight, project-by-project, as to how we're going to deliver those  savings, which give us great confidence in our ability to do so.

texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And again, all the usual areas where they come from, it's not one big area, there's a multitude of different sources  of those cost savings. Energy has always been a big opportunity for us. I think we have the largest – as we said in  the past, the largest multi-site solar array in Europe. We've obviously announced various changes to our  management structures, we've announced changes to the roles, indeed, in our store support centers, the  outsourcing of parts of our IT.

texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We continue to see good savings through our investment in our real time supply chain system, so reducing our  waste in our stores, and obviously procurement delivering savings as well. So savings from across the board to  deliver those savings, both the £140 million in 2014/2015 and the £200 million going forwards in 2015/2016.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive
texts.text: Our dishwasher tablets are rated by which as the best in the industry and that's as a result of again continuously  looking at how we can improve the quality and the delivery of that product. And our beef burgers, our Taste the  Difference beef burgers as well as having a better texture as a result of a product improvement. One of the things  that our customers increasingly demand is that we make our products allergen free. So we've taken the gluten out  of our Taste the Difference beef burgers, which makes them more available to the broader market.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive
texts.text: And we've seen our promotional participation reduce. So we've gone from around 37% promotional participation  to around 32% over the last period of time. So we've seen a fundamental switch in the way that we're presenting  value to our customers. And one of the byproducts of that, which we believe will come through and now we can  actually see demonstrably in our businesses, is that we've improved our store availability and we've actually  significantly reduced our waste because we've got a much flatter supply chain, a much flatter demand curve in our  week-to-week, day-to-day business which is very important.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive
texts.text: And we continue to work with our suppliers on lowering our cost of goods. So we talked again in November, we  would expect to recover the £150 million price investment through working through our supply chains with our  suppliers, looking at the value chains, looking at where the value leakage actually happens, and to make sure that  we do our – we work with our suppliers to reduce that value leakage and therefore reduce our cost of goods.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive
texts.text: A couple of examples are, detergent business. We've concentrated the powder. That means we've got less product  going through our supply chain delivering the same functionality. That means less pallets in our supply chain. It  means less lorries on the road, and ultimately, a cost saving to our business. We've concentrated our fabric  conditioner. Similarly, less water in the supply chain, less pallets and again less lorries, an that's a classic example  of how we're looking at our value chains, we're reaching through with our suppliers, cooperating and looking at  how we can reduce our cost of goods, and we're pretty confident that we'll recover the £150 million of price  investment over the next couple of years.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive
texts.text: We see the penetration of delivery pass increasing, which has the benefit of driving the number of orders, but  clearly the value per order is dropping in the industry more generally, and that's as a result of delivery charges,  broadly speaking, gradually being competed down and delivery pass is a very obvious example of that. We now  offer customers a green van option. So where we are coming to your street, you can nominate to have a green van  option, that gives you a much more environmentally-friendly and cheaper delivery, and we are anticipating that,  in London particularly, we'll get to the top end of our capacity over the next 12 months or so. So during the course  of 2016, we do anticipate that we'll open a dark store in London particularly. Now, we believe that the business  model picking some store is the right model and we still believe that, outside London, we have the capacity to do  that out of our large out-of-town superstores.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive
texts.text: Big issue at the moment are sugar in carbonated drinks. We've reduced the amount of sugar in our carbonated  drinks by 2,250 tons, as one example. We've increased the level of sustainable palm oil in our products, so now  95% of the palm oil in our products is all from sustainable sources. We actually have a store which is completely  off the National Grid and entirely powered by food waste, which has both an environmental and an economic  benefit to the business.

file: SBRYL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 4May2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Nonetheless, total transition cost, we're not changing the guidance here. We expect that to be at the top end of  £340 million to £380 million range. And indeed if you look at the components this year, you'll see transition cost  to this year of £59 million and capital cost of £19 million. That's quite a lot lower that we've guided to, and that's  principally driven because we've been able to share some of that capital investment with our third -party provider.

texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We've talked in the past of our Value Simplicity program and Mike will talk about it later on from a trading  perspective, but we also see the benefit of that Value Simplicity program in our underlying operating costs. So,  lower levels of waste given that we are reducing promotional profits patience in our sales. We've seen less volatility  come through our supply chain that allows us to control wastes more effectively allows us to spend less time  managing our inventory, and of course, fewer price changes, all of which results in operational cost savings within  our business.

texts.speaker: John Terence Rogers
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We've also [indiscernible] (18:41) to improve our whole logistics operations and looking at improving still in our  ability. And again, this program will extend into the new financial year and will deliver further savings going  forward. And again energy saving is one that we've called out in the past, but we continue year -on-year to deliver  fantastic energy savings to our various initiatives that we're making. In fact that's, as I've said in the past, that  capital investment that we make in those areas is one of the fastest paying back areas of all the capital we've spent  in the business.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And we're making progress on our cost of goods reduction program. We set ourselves a target of reducing our cost  of goods by £150 million over a three-year period and we will do that in a way which plays the same good strength,  which is understanding our end-to-end supply chains, working with our supply base to make sure we understand  how their business works, how we can remove errors of value leakage and that we can use in the case of the  [indiscernible] (33:30) example we did, the secondary products in a different way and in a way that allows us to  correct value throughout the supply chain. So, it's a big area of work for us. We continue to do it in the right way  and we continue to do in a way where we think we can get strategic advantage by working with the right suppliers  in the medium to long term.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And again, another example is our cereals range where we've done an ingredient/recipe review. We've reduced the  cost of packaging, again, working with our suppliers, working at where value leakage occurs in the supply chain  and we've broadened our supply base. So we have a more pan-European supply base, which again gives us the  advantage of scale, cost of goods reductions in that particular category.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We must never forget that our values make us different. Our customers would say to us, number one on our list is  household waste. And we're doing a lot of work to help them reduce their household waste and think about how  we can – and move that forward over the next period of time.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We've made a commitment to invest £10 million in an initiative to waste less, save more, starting with and in  around trial in Swadlincote in Derbyshire, where we're working with the local community, testing ideas, helping  them work out how to waste less and save money therefore. And as we learn, we intend to roll out those initiatives  across the country more widely. Our company also talks about health. I've already referred to some of the healthy  ranges and the My Goodness! range is a good example of a product range where it helps our customers get one of  their five-a-day if they consume one of those products.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And we've won the Climate Disclosure Leadership Index Award. We are the only UK retailer to get a Band A rating  and that's all about the disclosure that we give on the work that we're doing to r educe the environmental impact  that we make within our business. And John has already referred to the fact that we have invested a lot of money  in reducing particularly our energy consumption over the last period of time and that's reflected at least in pa rt in  that award.

file: SBRYL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 3May2017 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: We continue to invest in our supermarket chains. So, we've changed around 20% of our space. So, we have  space initiatives around 20% of our supermarket chain. If you went back to 2014, we acknowledge that around  1.5 million square feet of our space would be surplus to our requirements over a five-year period. Actually, we're  repurposing that pretty aggressively. So, we would have repurposed around 250,000 square foot of space during  the course of last year.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: I've already talked about pre-prepared vegetables. It helps us reduce our operating cost. So, we have Food  Donation Partnerships in about 80% of our stores for [indiscernible] (33:56) stores, which enables us to do better  job of dealing with our wastes. We have more healthy baskets, so we've reduced the sugar content in our cereals  by 13% in the year. And we mustn't forget our relationship with Comic Relief. I think we handed over the largest  charitable check in corporate history again this time around with an £11.6 million contribution to Comic Relief.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: Also, our values program helps us to mitigate risks. So, looking at water and energy security, we've reduced the  energy cost in our business by over 10% despite the fact that our space has grown by over 50% over the last five  or six years. So, we continue to have a significant energy reduction program to make sure that we can mitigate  the risks in our energy and water supply chains. We work with our farmers to help them reduce their cost for the  farming development groups, and we've reformulated a lot of products by taking sugar salt and fat out.

texts.speaker: Michael Andrew Coupe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, J Sainsbury Plc
texts.text: So, the bullets, I think in the past we've talked about around [ph] 80 things (45:41) that we've been doing whether  it's investing in online picking systems or energy reduction or looking at the logistics flow within our supply chains,  all of these things that require small incremental changes, which add up to a very large number over a period of  time. And we're also confident that we can deliver a further £500 million from the beginning of next financial year,  and for the subsequent three years roughly a rate of £165 million. And we stand by our track record of being able  to deliver that. I think we got a pretty consistent track record of delivering the cost savings that we've set out. And  that means that we've maintained and indeed improved our balance sheet strength.

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Going into Q4 to Q1 and as I said we have the normal seasonality actually from a profitability point of view, it was  much larger last year than it is this year. When it comes to EBIT we also have some impact of higher energy cost  compared to Q4.

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Personal Care, Tissue, seasonality marketing activities, but we have seen some lower raw material cost in part at  least in Personal Care, but during the quarter we see some of the important raw material costs coming up a little  bit. Pulp, waste paper, oil-based product, only excluding oil-based product, only driven by China, because there is  no development in the western world that is actually supporting any increase in raw material cost whatsoever.  And we know that China goes into the market, goes out of the markets, it will have an impact up and down even  through this year.  Coming back to Personal Care, as you can see we have good sales growth in all our categories and as high as 23%  growth in our emerging markets. texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We continue with efficiency improvement in Forest and as you know, we have a history of productivity  improvement of maybe 2% to 6% every year and that's something we will continue to drive through this year and  going forward.
