texts.speaker: Joséphine Edwall-Björklund
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, Group Function Communications, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Hello, and welcome to SCA's Press Conference for the First Quarter 2017. As you probably have noticed today,  we have released several reports due to the fact on the decision on the AGM in April this year to split the  company into two separate listed companies; one hygiene and health company, Essity; and one forest products  company, SCA.

texts.speaker: Joséphine Edwall-Björklund
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, Group Function Communications, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: So, today, we have of course, our CEO, Magnus Groth, who, together with our CFO, Fredrik Rystedt, will go  through the reports. And in addition, we have our Executive Vice President and President for Forest Products, Ulf  Larsson, who will also present, followed by a Q&A session.

texts.speaker: Magnus Groth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Most importantly, after the end of – on the 5th of April after the first quarter, the annual general meeting of the  shareholders and I'm now going to use this word, decided unanimously, so everyone agreed to split the group into  two separate companies. SCA, a well-invested and efficient forest products company; and Essity, a global leading  health and hygiene company.

texts.speaker: Magnus Groth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Most of the raw material that we use in Away from Home or Professional Hygiene is recycled fiber as opposed to  Consumer Tissue where we are mostly depending on fresh fiber. And recycled fiber has had a huge increase over  the quarter and for us somewhat unexpected, over 30% in North America, over 15% in Europe. So, a big negative  impact there on our margins and our EBITA. And we were not able to compensate through better price/mix,  higher volumes and cost savings, but of course, we're continuing to work very hard in all these areas to  compensate for this higher raw material costs.

texts.speaker: Magnus Groth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: And looking forward then into the second quarter, we expect to see still higher prices compared to the first quarter  when it comes to recycled fiber and significantly higher prices for recycled fiber compared to first quarter last year.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & President-Forest Products, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Thank you, Magnus. Ulf Larsson, responsible for the Forest Products part of SCA and happy to be here and give  you some more details about our operations. We also had a strong growth in the first quarter, partly due to  increased volume mainly in kraftliner and partly due to increased price and mix in mainly wood business.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & President-Forest Products, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Our adjusted EBITDA margin was down 1% or SEK 6 million. And one thing is that we had, let's say, one-time  effect on electricity certificates and that had a negative impact of SEK 40 million during the quarter, reevaluation.  And the second thing is that we have some higher costs related to the Östrand project. One thing is training,  education of the people that are going to run the new mill from next summer. Second thing is some write-offs due  to old spare parts and also due to the fact that we will start up the new wood handling department in the middle of  this summer. So we need to increase the speed of write-offs.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & President-Forest Products, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: And then, we have the third thing which is also that, now, when we are starting up the new wood handling  department this summer, we have some extra costs when it comes to distribution of raw material. We need to  distribute in a slightly different way. Otherwise, the project is on plan, both in terms of time and cost. We have so  far been investing SEK 3.1 billion, which is approximately 40% of the total investment that shall be done here. We  can also say that we now have committed credit facilities in place of totaling SEK 9.5 billion.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & President-Forest Products, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Many of these numbers are maybe already commented. But if we look back to EBITDA margin, we can also add  that – and I mentioned the revaluation of certificates, some extra costs connected to Östrand. But we also had  some extra costs in terms of raw material, mainly in recycled fiber also for our case. We use some recycled fiber  in Munksund and Obbola. On the other hand, we had a strong positive contribution from price and mix and  volume during the quarter.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & President-Forest Products, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: If we then walk over to our four segments starting with forest. One can say that we have a balanced market in our  region for the moment being. Good availability of logs, both saw logs and pulp logs. During the quarter, we have  increased the sales and that is mainly due to high volumes. And price is quite flat for the moment being.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & President-Forest Products, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Adjusted EBITDA margin has increased by 11% and we have harvested a little bit more on our own land this  quarter in comparison with the first quarter 2016, but also we have had a good winter. We have had good  conditions, it has been mild, not too much snow. And that has a positive impact, of course, on the cost side. And  the adjusted EBITDA margin is quite stable on slightly below 25%.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & President-Forest Products, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: EBITDA also has increased substantially with close to 70% due to high prices. We have seen some high raw  material costs not for the saw logs but reduced prices for by-products like sawdust and chips and things like that.  So that is one reason.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & President-Forest Products, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: In terms of adjusted EBITDA, it was heavily down during the quarter, as already mentioned. We will start up the  new wood handling department during this summer and that is the first part of the – big part at least of the big  investment in Östrand.

texts.speaker: Fredrik Rystedt
texts.profession: Executive Vice President,  Head of Group Function Finance & Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: I think both Magnus and Ulf, you talked about the raw material impact, so I'll speak a little bit about those trends  on the next slide when we look at the raw material trends. But you can see that we had a slight negative impact of  approximately SEK 40 million in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Fredrik Rystedt
texts.profession: Executive Vice President,  Head of Group Function Finance & Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Once again, raw material and Magnus mentioned it before. You can see on the left-hand side, this is sorted off as  paper in United States and also Europe and these are the grades we typically use for our Away from Home or  Professional Hygiene business. And you see the lower line there that's the same line for Europe.

texts.speaker: Fredrik Rystedt
texts.profession: Executive Vice President,  Head of Group Function Finance & Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: So, very clearly from this slide, what Magnus talked about before, you can very easily see that Q2, we will have  significantly higher raw material cost in comparison to last year for both Consumer Tissue and from Professional  Hygiene. We will have also higher cost for Personal Care. And that's also clear from this slide that fluff pulp is  increasing, oil-based material is increasing. So, partly, we're back to the scenario that we were in 2015.

texts.speaker: Fredrik Rystedt
texts.profession: Executive Vice President,  Head of Group Function Finance & Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: So, a few words on forest. You can see here that the growth was – and you have already talked about that, Ulf,  [ph] but it grow (31:11) with 5%. So, good contributions actually from all areas. Higher volume, pulp and paper  price/mix contribution was really, really, as Ulf talked about, strong from the wood part.

texts.speaker: Fredrik Rystedt
texts.profession: Executive Vice President,  Head of Group Function Finance & Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Forest cash flow, you talked about that and it's actually interesting, of course, when you look at this – if you look at  the capital expenditure there of SEK 640 million approximately, in the quarter, about SEK 500 million of that  relates to Östrand. So, of course, as Ulf said, 40% of Östrand investment has now been taken.

texts.speaker: Magnus Groth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: So, to sum up, positive development in both our SCA Hygiene business, our future Essity and in SCA Forest  Products, the future SCA. And also very, very exciting time ahead of us in both of these companies that are both  financially strong, exciting prospects, very good underlying market conditions. And, of course, important  opportunities also now in the near term with BSN transforming Essity from a hygiene company into a health and  hygiene company with fantastic opportunities going forward. And with SCA, the forest company moving closer  and closer to finalizing this huge investment in Östrand and all the positive results that that will bring to the Forest  Products business.

file: SCA.B - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 26April2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: EBITDA was up 47% from SEK 797 million up to SEK 1,175 million and again the reason – the main reason is  prices of course we have had also this year harsh winter conditions and we've seen some negative effect on the  cost side for our Forest operations and also when we look into our saw mills you can see some negative effect  from this strong winter. Östrand project is progressing according to plan and we have now stopped for the final  step where we will extend the recovery boiler. And, so far up to today we have invested 80% of the total amount  of SEK 7.8 billion.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We've seen a stable wood supply during the first quarter and also before Christmas despite harsh winter  conditions. And as you know we are less dependent on external wood supply than maybe some of our  colleagues, which has been a good thing this winter. Of course, we can see some effect in the saw mill production  and also in the Forest operations as I said.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: I did show this slide at our AGM recently just in order to show that we do continued investments in the profitable  growth in order to maximize the value from the Forest. We are happy to say that the production in Tunadal, the  new saw line in Tunadal is now up and running maybe better than we even thought. It is the world's fastest  sawmill, saw line, today, and it's working 200% just now.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We will start up the new mill in Östrand, the rebuilt mill from mid-June, as we've said according to plan. We have  now also started up the pilot facility that we have started up in Obbola in order to see if we can extract black liquor  from the process and from that produced biodiesel and some other green chemicals and things like that. Now, the  equipment is working, and it's – but it's still too early to judge what we can do about it. But it's working now as we  also planned that it should do at this time.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: As you know, we have an installed capacity of wind power on SCA land of 2.6 terawatt hours and now we have  closed further agreements. So, we today know that 2020 we will reach our goal which is 5 terawatt hours installed  capacity in 2020.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We have also, during the period, announced that we will invest another SEK 200 million in kraftliner mill in Piteå in  order to increase the production of white-top kraftliner again to move forward in the value chain. And we have also  started up environmental permit applications for a possible production increase in Obbola and also at the same  time for a biorefinery at Östrand mill. So, a lot of things is going on in this area.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We've also announced some management changes during the period. And if we start to the left – to the right,  Jonas Mårtensson, he has become the new President of Forest since 1st of April. Jonas has a long experience in  the wood industry. He is replaced by Jerry to the left. Jerry has been in charge of Obbola kraftliner mill for the  latest three years. And before that, he has spent many years in the Wood business as technical director. He's  been heading Tunadal sawmill and also Bollsta sawmill. He's also a very experienced guy here.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: If we then walk into our segments, start with the Forest. As already mentioned, we have had a stable wood  supply. We have been able to run our industry to 100% even if we have had tough winter conditions in the  northern part of Sweden. In some areas we have had up till two meters snow, which is quite hard to deal with.  And also it's been quite cold, which is not the least for the sawmills problem really in the production. We have now  started to see some slight price increases in the region and especially higher prices for imported goods. We do  not import too much as we have our high degree of self-sufficiency, but still we can feel that it is price pressure  upwards here.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: As you know that this project has been run as a sequential start up and that is a very good thing to have because  that will mitigate risk of course. And I can just show you some slides here. This is from the wood handling unit and  that one was up and running Q3 2017. And that is today the only wood handling unit that we have.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We've been running for 50% capacity up till now. But now from June, we will run it to 100%. But this is – I mean,  this is already finalized more or less. The evaporation plant, we started up Q4 2017 and as you can see we  struggled a little bit in December. But from January and up till March we have more or less 100% capacity in this  plant.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: And, finally, now we have started to extend the recovery boiler. And just today as we speak, we are moving the  big, big wall and that will take between two and three days. But so far, it is really good. The white liquor filter is  also up and running now. We have now also been able to look into the old recovery boiler. I mean, we have run  that for 10 years now, and you don't really know what you will find there when you open up and go in. But so far,  no bad surprises. So, we are happy to say that we think that is working well, and it is according to plan and we will  start up mid-June.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: When we come on the contribution by segment, here first on the left, you can see the Forest. And the top line  here is very stable. We have a seasonality in the Forest business, which is largely driven by how much we  harvest of our own forest every quarter. And the first quarter is always a bit lower quarter seasonally, but we also  had some effects from the winter here in the first quarter. So, I think without the additional effects from the winter,  we would had a slightly better first quarter in the Forest division.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: When it comes to EBITDA, again, the biggest effect of course is the same its price/mix where we have high prices  for all major segments. And an improved product and market mix, volume slightly down, a small negative. On raw  materials, we do see some cost pressure on raw materials in particular wood cost slightly higher for the wood cost  we buy in and chemicals where we see some cost increases.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Energy largely flat, we had probably more Energy costs, which I'll come back in the direct costs in Pulp slightly in  the first quarter offset by some other positive impacts in Energy, but overall largely flat. Currency, positive. Again,  euro positive, U.S. dollar negative. And then, we have some small negative in other as well which has really  driven. Here, we have the Östrand project costs and also some other costs related to the winter which effect the  other column. So, overall a 47% increase in our EBITDA margin in the first quarter at 26.7%.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We expect the fixed cost reduction, which will be the largest impact of some SEK 350 per tonne. We expect an  improved Energy balance where we will go from being a net consumer of around 0.1 terawatt hours before the  project to a net producer after the project of 0.5 terawatt hours. And on the other side, we expect potentially there  could be some higher wood costs as a result of having to source a higher volume of wood primarily from further  away. So, it's a higher cost to bring it to the mill. So, that's again nothing new with the investment cost SEK 7.8  billion.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: And then finally, we have the direct cost impact during the ramp up, which we expect to be around between SEK  100 million and SEK 250 million during the whole year due to the effect of higher costs for Energy, higher costs  for chemicals, some extra wood consumption, and a higher share of B-grade pulp during the ramp up.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We've added stable wood supply even if we had a strong and hard winter this year, of course, due to the fact that  we are – have a high degree of self-sufficiency, which is a good thing to have in a winter like this. And we have  also been working quite hard with – yeah, to improve our product and market mix. So...

file: SCA.B - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 26April2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: I will come back to the ramp up of Östrand, but I can already now say that it is progressing according to plan,  which is positive. We had two events during the quarter. One was the merger between Groupe ISB and SCA  Wood France, and we will retain with 38.5% of the shares so that we will be the main owner in the new company.  And we have also during the quarter finalized the acquisition of 10,000 hectares of forest land in Latvia and that is  according to our strategy to increase our ownership in Forest.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: If we then walk into our segments starting with the Forest. As you can see on the left-hand side, we have seen  higher prices in the market and also in the first quarter 2019. I think we now have reached some kind of peak level  in this perspective also when it comes to prices for imported wood. We have in SCA increased our wood sourcing  in order to meet the increasing demand from Östrand, of course, and the sales was up 27% due to that fact, also  due to high prices, but not the least due to an increased volume.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: EBITDA was up 9%. One thing is higher prices. But on the negative side, we have the mix as we now have some  yearly basis to supply 2.5 million cubic meters more than we did in the past. That have, of course, an impact on  the mix. So, less from our own forest and somewhat more from import and what we buy from private forest only in  the region.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: And, here, we have a lagging effect. So, that will be, of course, be charged to Östrand, but we have a lagging  effect between Forest and the industry.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: I have one slide regarding renewable energy, and you know that we have a lot of exciting growth projects in this  field. Maybe wind is not the most exciting area, but we've been very successful in this area in the past. We had a  long-term target to reach 5 terawatt hours and now we know that we will exceed that target. So, 2021, we will  reach 6.7 terawatt hours installed capacity on SCA land, which is equal to around SEK 100 million on EBIT level if  we had the same conditions as we have today in terms of energy prices and so on. And we also have a big  interest and lots of new projects in line, so we have also put a new target on 11 terawatt hours – long-term target  on 11 terawatt hours installed capacity.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Before I hand over to Toby, I'd like to finish up with this slide showing SCA's contribution to a fossil-free society.  And we did some work last year in order to present this slide at our AGM in March. And we did identify, we did  quantify, and also validate the contribution we could do for a fossil-free world. And if we start with the left-hand  side, you can see that there are well-managed forests growing fast, has a net binding capacity of 4 million tonne  carbon dioxide per year. And that is due to the fact that before each tree that we harvest, plant – replant to new  ones. We have – we are really intensive in our silviculture operations. On 50% of SCA land, we use Pinus  contorta, which has 40% higher growth than the normal conventional scots spine. We do some fertilization and so  on. But all in all, a net binding capacity of 4 million tonnes per year.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: If we then turn to the right side of this slide, you can see that we also, with the renewable fiber, can replace more  fossil-based materials, then we talk about paper instead of plastics. We talk about bioenergy instead of fossil fuels  and solid wood products instead of steel, concrete and so on. And that also give a contribution of 5 million tonne  per year. Then, of course, we have some emissions from our industry that we have reduced by 50% since 2010  up till now. But still, we are on the level of 0.9 million tonnes per year. But the net contribution is 8 million tonne  and that is as much as the total truck traffic in Sweden and also the domestic flights. So, it's quite a lot and it has  been very positively received at the AGM, but also afterwards in different occasions.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: When it comes to the bottom line, we have a seasonality in our business. So, we always – the bottom line is  driven more by the amount of harvesting of our own forest, which tends to be less in the first quarter. So, that  seasonality is there. But we also – the profit in the bottom line is driven by the result from our harvesting our own  forest. So, it's not – we're not growing the harvesting from our own forest at the same rate that we're growing the  top line because the increased sourcing for Östrand's needs comes mainly

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: When it comes to Pulp, we have increasing volumes, of course, from the ramp-up of Östrand pulp mill. Prices are  a bit lower than they were in the fourth quarter, and we all saw slightly worse mix because we're now selling a bit  further away and the increased volumes are a bit further away. So, the mix is a bit worse than it was in the fourth  quarter. When it comes to the bottom line, we have basically those effects from the price. We also have an  increased wood cost feeding through into the Östrand result, which is offset by a better energy balance. So, we  are improving the energy balance in Östrand.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: On the other hand, we're working very hard to improve the energy balance in the company which is driven a lot by  the better energy balance in Östrand and that improves our energy cost by SEK 51 million in the first quarter and  we have then a positive currency effect, again, euro and U.S. dollar primarily and then a positive effect on Other  of SEK 46 million which is largely again this effect from the restructuring in France which drives that. So overall,  the EBITDA grew by 33% and the margin then increased from 26.7% last year to now 30.7% in the first quarter.

file: SCA.B - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 21July2011 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We have had – if we look at the raw materials now, we have had a little bit more than 2 billion negative impact of  raw material on the first half year. We have been able, on group level, to offset that by price increases and cost  reduction.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Looking at the raw material, it seems like the price increase is not continuing. We see a stable or even maybe a  little bit down on pulp. We also see in China been reducing their import of pulp. We also see in wastepaper stable  price. In our oil base, which is impacting the Personal Care, we see prices actually coming down. And if we look at  Q2 to Q1, the two did more than 2 billion; on half year is on 100 million Q1 to Q2.  We have, as you may know, a contractual situation where the increases of raw material is hitting the P&L faster  than the contracts allow us to pass it on to customers. So as long as we still see growing cost in raw material, there  will be a delay before we can offset by price increases or cost reduction.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Q2 to Q1, all the business areas have been able to offset their higher raw material by price, volume, and cost. We  also see a substantially stronger Swedish krona. It's impacting the result with SEK600 million for the first half  year, of which SEK255 million is translation and the rest is transaction, mainly coming from the Forest products.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Going into the different business areas; if we look at Personal Care, which in local currency, we have an  improvement of sale by 4%. The raw material impact is as much as 3.1 percentage points, Q2 to Q2. And year to  date, it's 3.5%, if you just take the raw material. And as you know, in Personal Care, we have a delay on the impact  of the raw material increases between three to six months, which means that even though we see now oil-based  raw materials coming down, it will still continue into Q3 and the impact of that will come in Q4.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In Forest Products – one more thing on packaging, which I think is also important, is if we look at the testliner  situation in Europe today, the inventories are still in a low level. We have a very good balance on the market,  which means that there are possibilities to continue to increase prices in particular since we have seen raw  material continue up even during Q2.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In the Forest Products, we see some higher prices for publication paper, not at the level we expected when we  presented Q1. It has been more difficult to get that through in the market. We see very good development of our  solid-wood business and of course impacted by the acquisition. We don't believe that there will be any further  price increases in solid-wood in the second half but we believe it will be stable.  So, going forward, as I started, we still see a good demand for all our business. Very good growth in emerging  markets for our Hygiene business. We are having continuing high raw material costs even though it's sort of  phasing out and may be coming down in some of the raw materials.

file: SCA.B - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 19July2012 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Jan C. Johansson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Looking at the development Q1 to Q2, we also have sales increase of 4% and we're improving the EBIT by 15%.  Personal Care also substantial improvement by 17% and that's both higher volumes and more – maybe more  importantly, improved product mix. Tissue is also higher volumes and/or energy costs, but we also see higher raw  material cost in Tissue, and that is mainly currency impact. We actually have had a increase of pulp with 8%  compared to Q1, and that is mainly the weaker euro, since we are buying most of our raw material in dollars. But  Forest is also improving EBIT compared to Q1. You remember that we had some problems with the storm that  increased the cost of harvesting and that has now been mostly taken care of, and we're more in a normal  operational situation in the Forest operation.

file: SCA.B - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 18July2013 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Jan C. Johansson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We have seen some change in the Forest operation. The solid wood is much more positive than we saw from the  first quarter. We also have some stronger kraftliner operation. But publication paper is still quite weak. And of  course, I will get back to this when I get into the different business areas.

texts.speaker: Jan C. Johansson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: If we look at Forest, the result is improving by 9%. And having said that, we also have to remember that we had a  capital gain of SEK 121 million Q1. So, in spite of that, it's an improvement of 9% in profit. And we also had SEK  80 million in costs for maintenance in Forest during the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Jan C. Johansson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Forest operations, as I said, very positive development in solid wood, with price increases of 7 %. We estimate to  continue some price increases during the second half of the year, not in the level of 7 %, but at least it will be more  price increases. We have managed to get €15 out of the €20 in kraftliner and it seems to be very difficult today at  least to get the remaining €20 in kraftliner. And the reason is that the difference between test and kraftliner is a  little bit too big at the moment. So, if it's getting too big, then it's difficult to get – even though the balance is very  strong in kraft, demand is very strong. But if the difference is too big, it tends to be more difficult to get further  price increases into the market.

file: SCA.B - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 18July2014 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Jan Christer Johansson
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: And we still have a good momentum in emerging markets, overall in the Hygiene business. If we look at the Forest  business, we still as also expected that publication paper demand is coming down, I will get back to that a little bit  later, but also an improved market for solid wood.

texts.speaker: Jan Christer Johansson
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: In away-from-home, we have an innovation that we call Bloe. And this is really changing the sort of management  of bathrooms in terms of toilets. It's a system that helps to clean the toilet. It's a system that kills odors from the  toilet, but also maybe most important it can actually reduce water consumption with more than 30% and in some  countries, of course, water is a scarce resource. And it's already implemented in Holland and I was thought to  launch in other parts of the world.

texts.speaker: Jan Christer Johansson
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: But normally we should have seen a stronger cash flow. And the good thing is that we don't see any increase in  inventory except some in forest because of the storm. Then we have to take care of the tree that has been falling of  course, and that has a slight impact on the forest inventories.

texts.speaker: Jan Christer Johansson
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Forest operations, we did have another forest swap this quarter, SEK 17 5 million and we had one in Q1 also, I  think it was SEK 152 million if I remember rightly. But Q2 last year, we didn't have the swaps. So, that's of course  the comparison you can see here. But even if you remove the impact of the Forest swap, we have increased the  margin to 10.6%. So, it is really a good improvement in the forest operation.

file: SCA.B - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 16July2015 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Magnus Groth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: During the quarter, we also decided to invest in a production facility in Brazil. And our inclusion in the  FTSE4Good index has been reconfirmed. And this means that we get very, very high rankings when it comes to  environmental, social and governance factors. So this is something we're very happy about. And I will let Fredrik  dig into the numbers, but overall a positive development, as he already mentioned in sales, profit, and margin as  well as cash flow. And this reconfirms our focus on three strategic priorities: Profitable growth, innovation, and  efficiency.

texts.speaker: Fredrik Rystedt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: If we take a look at the operating profit, it has grown by, as you can see, 10%. So a good growth. And that includes  two items here, of course, currency translation, once again, Swedish krona and British pound primarily. But we  also have an adverse impact from forest swaps. You may recall that as of January 1, 2015, we no longer take profit  or gains from profit swaps into our income statement. So of course for Q2 of 2015 there is no profit contribution  from forest swaps, whilst in Q2 of 2014, we had a SEK 175 million and that's part of the other bar that you see on  this line. So, if you take away the currency and the forest gain from foreign swaps, those two the organic or  underlying comparable growth was 9% in the quarter. And of course, most notably here, SEK 435 million negative  impact from raw material, most of this coming from  the tissue operations.

texts.speaker: Fredrik Rystedt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: Just a few comments on the other, I already mentioned that part of this SEK 17 5 million or this SEK 240 million  that you see, relates to the gain from forest swaps, but there is also another part which comes from a wide number  of different things. Actually, we have a positive part, which is savings efficiency gains, and we have, in the quarter,  had levels of savings approximately equal to that of last year. So we continue to actually become more and more  efficient. But we also have higher A&P. We also have higher SG&A cost as – for the group as a whole. And, of  course, normal parts such as inflation, et cetera. Worth noting, however, is that A &P and SG&A, as a percentage of  sales, are not increasing. So it's just a normal continuation of the business, so to speak.

texts.speaker: Fredrik Rystedt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: So the big swing between last year and this year is largely due to the operating cash surplus. And if you look at the  number, it's actually a much bigger swing than what you would see for EBIT. And the re ason is very simply that,  once again, the forest – or gains from forest swap is not a cash flow item. So the underlying cash flow impact is  much bigger. And the other part is pretty much about the same size is increased depreciation this year. So that's  why the cash – operating cash surplus improvement is much bigger than what you would see for EBIT.

texts.speaker: Magnus Groth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Thank you, Fredrik. Then we'll dig into the key business areas in some more detail. And I'm very happy to, once  again, be able to state that better price mix, better volumes, and cost savings actually apply to all our three  business areas, so it's a recurring scene. When it comes to personal care, actually those three im provements have  made it possible for us to keep the operating margin at 11.3% in spite of the significant raw material headwinds  that we have also in this quarter. In personal care, we have a negative effect on the fluff pulp, from currency  mostly and the positive effect from the oil-based materials. But the positive effect doesn't outweigh the negative  effect in fluff pulp. And that negative impact on the margin was approximately 80 basis points, which is a  significant negative impact, and that we covered them through price mix volumes and cost savings.

texts.speaker: Magnus Groth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The innovations is a mix of things. And I actually have some of them here behind me. And looking specifically at  the Tork cleaning cloths, you could argue that what can you do with a piece of cloth. But I think, what  differentiates us from our competitors here is that we have the size to scale to really come with innovation that has  a noticeable and tangible payoff and benefit for the user. So as you can see here, we can prove that this new  product – it's this one over here, our new industrial cleaning cloth – requires 32% less time for cleaning a certain  surface than other products. It uses 40% less solvent which also has a positive environmental impact. And it uses  20% less effort, which is very important for the people who are using this product in an industrial situation, for  instance.

texts.speaker: Magnus Groth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Finally, forest products continues to have a very strong performance both in terms of sales and operating profits.  The operating profit is very much driven by the strong dollar which is benefiting our forest products division since  we are producing these products in Sweden, especially kraftliner and pulp, the increasing demand and a good  price picture. While sawn timber, during the quarter, we experienced slightly declining prices and, overall, again,  a good performance in forest products.

texts.speaker: Magnus Groth
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: I just want to briefly say something about our three-year marketing platform, the participation of our female team  in the Volvo Ocean Race, which finished in Gothenburg a few weeks ago, reaches for global marketing platform  with the focus on women and with a strong connection to sustainability and CSR issues.

file: SCA.B - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 19July2016 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Fredrik Rystedt
texts.profession: CFO and Executive Vice President. Head of Group Function Finance
texts.text: If we look at the growth rate here for Forest, I already mentioned the volume side, but price levels on pulp, on  kraftliner, and to some degree also on solid wood products continue to be lower this year than the average of last  year, although we can now see that the price levels are generally stabilizing.

texts.speaker: Fredrik Rystedt
texts.profession: CFO and Executive Vice President. Head of Group Function Finance
texts.text: For the first time, and you can see that here, for the first time I think it is in five quarters, we've actually seen a  positive impact from raw material. And most of this benefit that you can see on this slide, this SEK 70 million here,  relates to our Tissue business. And we expect this to continue also for Q3. So if you compare Q3 of 2016, we  expect that to be positive in comparison to Q3 of 2015. For Personal Care and Forest, raw material prices are  expected to be slightly lower. Not a lot, but slightly lower; and for Tissue, clearly lower. And some of you I know  are also interested in the sequential development on the raw material, and there we look at actually a s light  increase for Personal Care and for Forest, and also up for Tissue – slightly up for Tissue.

texts.speaker: Fredrik Rystedt
texts.profession: CFO and Executive Vice President. Head of Group Function Finance
texts.text: So not a great deal sequentially, but slightly up for Tissue; and this has to do with increases in recovered paper.  As you can see, and to the same as in Q1, energy prices are still very low and contributing to the profit. Now you  see the other bar there of minus SEK 368 million, and the other bar generally it actually includes all items that are  not included in either price mix volume, raw material or the other items listed on this slide.

texts.speaker: Fredrik Rystedt
texts.profession: CFO and Executive Vice President. Head of Group Function Finance
texts.text: And then finally, we also have a positive number here of SEK 218 million, which is relating to a capital gain when  we sold our recycling -or our shares in the recycling company IL Returpapper.

texts.speaker: Magnus Groth
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Also, operating profit was lower, 16% due to lower prices, lower volumes, helped by lower energy and material  costs. So altogether, operating margin of 12.4% for the Forest Products. Looking forward, we expect the  stabilization of prices in various areas, so no big change is expected going forward for the next couple of quarters.

file: SCA.B - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 21July2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Björn Lyngfelt
texts.profession: Senior Vice President-Group Communications, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Hello. My name is Björn Lyngfelt. I'm Vice President of Communications for SCA. Please be welcomed to this  presentation of SCA's Financial Results for the Second Quarter of 2017. This is our first report as an independent  listed forest products company.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We also have seen some higher raw material costs and that is in latex for example and in recycled fiber. And also  we have been forced to do some reevaluation of electricity certificates.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: As also announced in quarter one, we have some planned extra cost connected to the big project in Östrand and  that is related to training of staff in order to prepare them for the start-up mid 2018. And we also have had some  extra costs during the quarter connected to the fact that we now have started up the first big part in the new  project, the wood handling department. And we had to reorganize the wood – distribution of the wood transport  and that has also cost us some extra cost during the quarter.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Otherwise, I'm happy to say that the Östrand project is progressing according to plan. And we will start up the new  mill June 2018. We have now invested a little bit more than 50% of the project budget that is totaling to SEK 7.8  billion. And as already mentioned, we did start up to first big part of the new mill, the wood handling department  on plan 14th of July, this month.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: So, if we then turn over to our four segments and start with Forest. We have a balanced situation in the Forest  today. We have started to prepare for the start-up in Östrand next year, and that is also according to plan. We  have good availability in all assortments. We have seen some small price increases in the southern part of  Sweden and also in the very northern part of Sweden. But in our main market, one can say that price level is  rather stable.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Sales also due to that is stable quarter-on-quarter. And we have seen an increasing EBITDA margin and –  EBITDA level, and that is mainly due to an increased share of deliveries from our own forests. We can also see  some small positive effect from decreasing harvesting cost.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: So then, we turn over to Pulp, and also the pulp market is in general terms good and stable. We can now see  fixed prices on $890 per tonne. We've had some additional capacity coming on stream the first month this year. It  hasn't so far had any impact on prices. Now, we know that we will have another new capacity on stream from  quarter three, Äänekoski, that will add 700,000 tons on yearly basis. And in quarter four, we will also see UPM- Kymmene's mill coming up with another 170,000 tons on a yearly basis. And it remains to see what kind of impact  that might have on the price level. We are for the moment being a little bit hit by weaker U.S. dollars, as all prices  are set in dollars in this business.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: If I flick on here, you can see then our contribution per segment. And you can see first on the left hand side, we  have the Forest business. And here, the net sales was down slightly in the first – in the second quarter. Despite  the fact that our industry showed good growth and this is primarily due to a lower level of internal deliveries,  because all the deliveries from Forest are internal deliveries. So that was driven by managing working capital  tightly.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: When we come to EBITDA and EBITDA margin on the bottom half of the slide, you can see here on the Forest  segment we have a strong EBITDA level and EBITDA margin driven by a higher share of deliveries of wood  harvested from our own forests, which drives a higher profit margin.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: The Pulp segment is again being heavily affected by the plant maintenance stop in the second quarter, which has  a bigger impact from profitability and also by the costs related to the ongoing investment project in Östrand. And  on top of that, the energy cost is impacted by the revaluation of electricity certificates, which we revalued  downwards in the second quarter. Paper has a very stable margin. Again, small increase in EBITDA margin to  14%, and again, driven primarily by the strong price development in kraftliner.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: When it comes to energy, we have an increase in electricity cost, a small increase, but driven again by the  revaluation of the electricity certificates. We have again, when it comes to currency, a small gain due to a weaker  Swedish krona compared to last year against most currencies. And then, we have another variance on the right- hand side of SEK 124 million, and the biggest items here; once again, we're repeating this a lot, but it's the  maintenance stops and the Östrand project cost.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: So if I just move your attention, we have put a box in the bottom right-hand corner just to help show the  development of underlying margin. And here, we've normalized our EBITDA margin. So if you take the effect of  normalizing the maintenance stops, so replace the large maintenance stop impact we had in the second quarter –  and there are details presented on this in the report, so you can see more numbers. But if you replace the large  maintenance stop cost in the second quarter with a normalized maintenance stop cost in average quarter through  the year, then you add back 2.1% in EBITDA margin. And then similarly, if you add back the effects of the costs  related to the project in Östrand and the electricity certificates, then we would come to an underlying margin of  22.7%, which is a healthy underlying margin position.

file: SCA.B - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 25July2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: As we did announce during our Capital Markets Day in May, we have formed a partnership with St1 and SCA in  order to see in what way we can produce renewable biofuel based on crude tall oil. We've started up a pre- project. We believe that in the beginning of next year, we are ready to take a decision over SEK 500 million  investment in order to produce 100,000 tonnes of biojet.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: I'm also happy to say again that we are on time and on budget in Östrand. We have also started to deliver the  pulp, and the quality is surprisingly good when it comes to brightness, but also to cleanliness. It's perfect, more or  less. When it comes to strength, it's a little bit more volatile, but we have already now seen that we are able to  produce the highest strength in the new mill than we could do in the old mill, and the old mill was really good. But  we see great potential in this area.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: If we then walk into each segment starting with the Forest side, I can just mention that, as you've seen probably,  we've been hit by a lot of wildfires in this region and in the whole of Sweden during a couple of weeks now.  Between 20,000 and 25,000 hectares has burnt down all over the country. We have seen that many small private  forest owners has been hardly hit and which is, of course, a catastrophe for many of them.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We had, at the end of last week, 200 people from SCA out trying to help wherever we could. So far, luckily, we  are not hit in the company – too much. 600 hectares of SCA land has been burnt down and that is equal to what  we normally burn every year in order to keep our FSC certification. But we still have a dry and warm weather. So  still it is a danger out there, of course.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We've had a stable wood supply during the quarter and we also had a stable wood supply during the winter. We  had a harsh winter condition. We have had now dry and warm summer. But as we have a high degree of the  wood that we need from our own forest, we can handle that in a good way.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We've seen some price increases in the market, especially for imported wood. But again, as we have around 50%  from our own forest and as we also buy a lot of wood from the domestic market, we are not especially impacted  by import prices as [indiscernible] (00:06:54) now.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: So we have also during the quarter launched a new paper category which we called Fine Wood-containing Paper.  It is a paper based on chemical pulp, and that paper will compete with wood-free paper. We have a super good  brightness, good bulk in the paper, and also good opacity. And why we'd based this quality on mechanical pulp, it  would be really cost efficient both for us as a producer but also for our customers. We have done between 5,000  tonnes and 10,000 tonnes in the market. And it has been really well-received in the market.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: The EBITDA in Forest was stronger in the second quarter than the first quarter. And this is largely the seasonality  with a larger delivery of wood sourced from our own forest in the second quarter versus the first quarter but also  some effect from higher prices.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: When it comes to the EBITDA waterfall, again price mix is the biggest effect on here. We've seen a positive effect  in all segments from higher prices. We had an effect again from the volumes with minus SKE 39 million. Raw  material costs with negative effect from some higher cost for raw materials for wood and for chemicals and here  also some effect from the Östrand start-up, the higher direct costs, so the usage of raw materials in Östrand and  the chemicals.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: On energy, we have a small positive, the electricity price is actually higher, now, in the second quarter, but we've  had some effects from higher price for electricity certificates, and we also had a negative effect from electricity  certificates last year, in the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Just come on to a couple of more details on the Östrand project and this you've seen largely before, but just to  help you understand the affects. Production began in June according to plan. The ramp-up period is expected to  be 12 to 18 months. And that means we expect 2018 volumes to be in line with 2017, and that means also that  2020 is the first year we expect to be at full capacity. The new mill will be world class in its cost position. It will  double the soft wood capacity. We'll have a fixed cost reduction of SEK 350 per tonne, and we'll have an  improved energy balance with where we will go from being a small net consumer of electricity to a net producer of  some 0.5 terawatt hours.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: And we see potentially some higher wood costs from what needed to be sourced from further away. And then  particularly on the cost impact and here you've seen this table before as well, but we've updated for the second  quarter. And on the right-hand side, I just focus on the table on the right-hand side you can see the main effects  from the project here and you'd have the project-related cost where we had SEK 15 million in the second quarter.  We had the actual maintenance stop or expansion stop effect in the second quarter which was SEK 236 million.  And here, we expect SEK 256 million for the full year, so maybe we plan for some small effect in the second half.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: EBITDA up 43%, and as we also stated that we are negatively impacted by the plant start-up cost in Östrand  which has cost us SEK 250 million, approximately. We have, during the quarter, announced the partnership  together with St1 in order to produce biojet. And last but not the least, we are now up and running with Östrand.  We are well ahead of the start-up curve and the quality is really good as it is just now.

texts.text: Coming into the different business areas, we do suffer in Personal Care because of higher raw  material in particularly in relation to the oil-based materials, the superabsorbent. We have also  accelerated our market efforts.

file: SCA.B - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 25October2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Oct-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The interesting situation on pulp is that the spot prices today are about $100 below what you can see on the  contractual prices. So it seems like there is still downward pressure on the pulp side. And the important part in  our Personal Care business, the oil-based raw materials is also coming down. But as you know, we have a time lag  of between three to six months before we get the lower prices into our P&L in the Personal Care business.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So coming into Q3 compared to Q2, overall, still a growth in the company. We have a substantial EBIT increase of  13% and that's higher prices, but we still see also raw material continuing up in Q3 and that's mainly because of  the lag in the oil base, but also there is a lag in the pulp contract. And as I said, in euro terms, pulp is still on the  same level or even slightly higher compared to the previous period.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Forest, we say flat; it's actually SEK1 million better. So it's also slightly better, but, of course, it's flattish. And  increased prices, but also increased raw material costs.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now, of course, we will see what happen with raw material prices. We don't have any plans of further price  increases during Q4. Now, we have to focus to get all of these through into the system, so we can actually see in the  P&L in the coming quarters.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Forest operations, in general, we see a pressure on prices in our saw mills and that is mainly driven by increased  production in the system, mainly from Finland. The underlying consumption is still on a good level and I would  say that probably the saw mills are the earliest in any change in the consumption there even before Packaging, you  could see, and the change in behavior from the market. But the pressure on price now is overproduction and we  will reduce our production during Q2. And I believe that what I've seen from some of our competitors, they are  doing the same to keep the inventory levels on a decent level.

file: SCA.B - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 18October2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Oct-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Jan C. Johansson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Having said that, we still see a very good growth in emerging markets both in tissue and personal care, and we  also see some growth in Europe in some of our categories, and I'll get back to that. The sales and result is, of  course, impacted by GP, and I will comment on that when it's relevant. The business area [ph] within this age  today (3:51) that are impacted by the situation is, of course, our forest operation, and I will get a little bit deeper  into that when we come into forest, what is happening and what we assume will continue.

texts.speaker: Jan C. Johansson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Forest, from a market perspective, volume is down. We have not lost volumes, but we have seen price decreases in  our portfolio. We also have a nice improvement of our results, and of that 20% increase GP is about 9%.

texts.speaker: Jan C. Johansson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Looking at the EBIT increase, of course, acquisition, higher prices, we have improved mix in this system, but we  also have lower raw material costs. Cost saving here of the figure I mentioned is about 30% is coming into Tissue,  and the remaining 15% is coming into our forest operation.  Then looking at forest, we are kind of a perfect storm in our forest operations, where you have a structural change  at the same time as we have the economic development in Europe. News volume is down 10% year-to-date. The  magazine paper is down 6% year-to-date. And on top of that, we also have the stronger Swedish currency, of  course, hitting the forest operation.

texts.speaker: Jan C. Johansson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: So I don't expect any major changes in the pulp prices, but there will be some price increases. And as we always  say in SCA, the best situation for us is actually high pulp prices, but stable, then we manage very good. It's more  difficult to take the swings in short term in pulp prices. So positive on krafts, but no major positive impact in the  rest of the operation in forest.

texts.speaker: Jan C. Johansson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We have also, as you may have seen, been included in Dow Jones Sustainability Index. And maybe the most  positive thing, at least from my point of view, is that we do see a lot of new innovations coming out on the market  in all our categories. And that is, of course, the future and the future margin drivers for us, to really get out new  things on the market. Whether it's a big innovation or small innovation, they are as important.  And the improvement we have seen in margins in hygiene now is, of course, very positive, but it's not the level we  are satisfied with. And, of course, we want to – we would like to improve that going forward, but we need to do  that mainly short term, I think, by reducing our own costs and working with the productivity and efficiency within  the hygiene business.

texts.text: Coming back to the efficiency program, because we do get questions on that what we are doing, one major  measurement or action that we have is that we have a blueprint implementation in all our plants. And we are obviously have, there is by the weaker  Swedish krona.

texts.text: Sincerely welcome to this is presentation on SCA's Report for the Third Quarter. My name is Björn Lyngfelt. I'm  Senior Vice President-Communications of SCA. texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: By that, I turn over to our four segments and start with the Forest. And we have a really stable situation in the  Forest. We have a good supply and availability of wood. texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We have also now started to prepare for the startup of the new project in Östrand next year. So, by that, I mean,  we do what we can to prepare logistical systems. texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: In that business we supply 50% from our own sawmills and we buy 50% externally. But, on the other  hand, it will have a lower margin than our, let's say, traditional business.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB

And, here, it's slightly better than last year, slightly lower than  the second quarter this year, and that's always driven mainly by the share of harvesting of our own forest. And we  had a slightly higher share than we did in the third quarter last year, but a slightly lower share than we did in the  second quarter.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Then when it comes to the cost side, raw material costs and energy are very stable, a small improvement, but  that's driven mainly – that the pricing is actually slightly higher for raw materials and energy, but the efficiency and  the yield have offset the higher pricing environment. texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Then once, during the startup period, we also do expect there will be some increase in direct costs particularly  with some increased maintenance costs, increased costs for chemicals and energy in connection with the startup. file: SCA.B - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 30October2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: EBITDA was up 48% in comparison with Q3 but also in comparison with the second quarter this year. Again,  prices and the currency, we can see that we have a good stable cost control in all areas, except from wood where  also we are little bit hit by increasing wood prices.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We had a very dry summer as you remember which was good for people, but maybe bad for harvesting  operations. And due to our large forest holdings, we have the ability to move from really dry areas over to places  where we have more wet climate, and by that we could also continue to harvest. We had some extra costs, of  course, related to that but not more than maybe SEK 10 million during the quarter. But the most important thing,  we had a very stable and controlled wood supply during this period due to our big and large forest holding. And  last but not least the Östrand is progressing according to plan, and we will come back also to that with some more  details later on during the presentation.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: If we then walk into our different segments starting with the Forest, as mentioned, we had a stable wood supply  due to our large forest holding and we have seen in the market a continued price increase. And as you can see  also to the left-hand side, already mentioned that we now have to build up the inventory in order to provide our  customers with good service, but that is also the case for the Forest. We need to build up the inventory in order to  supply the Östrand mill with wood as we need a lot of wood, of course, in order to keep the production up and  running.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Sales was up 15%. Increased volumes, but also higher prices. EBITDA was down 8% for the Forest. And one  thing is that we had lower volumes from our own forest which has an substantial impact on the EBITDA level. We  had some minor costs related to the dry conditions during the summer, around SEK 10 million. And also, we can  see now that cost for externally sourced wood is getting up, and Forest is not 100% compensated for this wood  increase. That will come with some kind of lagging between three and six months. So as it is today, the industry  favors a little bit from that, but that is just internal.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: In Wood, we also have had increased prices during the quarter. We are on really low inventory levels. Sales was  up 9%. Prices and currency, we have somewhat lower volumes due to our inventory levels as mentioned before if  we compared with Q3 2017, but we are more or less sold out in our sawmills as it is today. EBITDA was up 48%  due to higher prices. On the negative side, we can see that wood prices is now starting to come up.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: In Pulp, I'm happy to say that the ramp-up is progressing according to plan. And we have said that we will reach  900,000 tonnes per year, which is corresponding to 2,500 cubic meter per day more or less. We have reached  around 60% to 70%, out of that now the first quarter, we have produced 150,000 cubic tonnes which is far better  than we expected. And what is also very positive to say is that the quality is really good. We have a better quality  today than we had in the old mill, of course, somewhat higher volatility, but still really strong and good quality. So,  that must go hand by hand with the increasing volumes, of course.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: EBITDA was up 73% due to high prices. And on the negative side, we can see that we still consume little bit more  chemicals in the new mill. We also consume somewhat more wood which is also absolutely normal because now  we have to adjust the process in a good way. And that is progressing also really well. We also are hit by  somewhat higher raw material costs. But still, for the first quarter in production, we are close to 37% EBITDA  margin, which is of course a really positive level.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: If we look per segment, and first, here you see the Forest segment and you can see the net sales in the Forest  segment were higher this quarter and that's really driven by supplying wood now to Östrand and now that Östrand  is up and running.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: On the bottom line, you can see the margin has dipped in Forest which is really three effects as Ulf mentioned.  Firstly, it's a seasonal effect that we harvest less of our own forests normally in the third quarter, which is what  you can see. We had some slightly higher costs due to the dry summer during the third quarter. And the third  effect is also that we have had higher prices for wood in the third quarter which Forest paid for and they've not  been fully compensated yet by income from the industries because of this that we use an average pricing model  when we price between forest and the industries, which means that just three to six months' time lag that Ulf  mentioned.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Looking at the same bridge for EBITDA, you can see we have a good impact from price mix, some SEK 652  million from higher prices and better mix. We then have a negative effect from volume which I mentioned on the  previous slides. And we do see an impact of higher wood costs which impact us with SEK 241 million, most of  which is wood costs. And within there, we do also have an impact from higher direct costs in Östrand during the  start-up, which is mentioned later, which is some SEK 50 million impact on direct costs in Östrand, but otherwise  we have an increasing wood costs, but limited on other items. So, it's nearly all driven by wood costs.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Energy, we have fairly flat. We do have higher electricity prices now in the third quarter, but that's been offset in  third quarter by also some increased income from selling electricity certificates, green certificates. Then currency,  we have a positive impact, again, due to the weaker SEK.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: And then in other, we have a positive variance. We sold a wind power project, which had an EBIT impact of  around SEK 50 million, which was shared between the second and the third quarter, which is the biggest impact,  then some impacts also from timing of maintenance stops versus the third quarter last year. So that led to a 48%  increase in EBITDA to SEK 1,549 million this year.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We had production in the third quarter as Ulf presented of 147,000 tonnes as well. We expect to double the NBSK  capacity in the mill up to 900,000 tonnes. And the biggest impact is on the fixed cost reduction, and there we  expect a SEK 350 per tonne reduction in fixed cost per tonne after the project, and that's the biggest impact.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: But we also expect a better energy balance and from previously being a net consumer of electricity of 0.1 terawatt  hours, we expect to be a net producer of 0.5 terawatt hours when we're up and stable at full capacity. And then  finally, we do expect a potentially higher wood cost due to wood being sourced further away.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: If we look at the project costs, the one-off costs, here is a slight update. The project related costs are slightly  updated from what you've seen before but very small. So, we have about SEK 75 million this year, of which SEK  20 million is depreciation. So, SEK 55 million impact on EBITDA due to purely project-related costs. Then we had  the big costs due to the expansion stop which was in the second quarter, and we've had now in the fourth quarter  a small stop which we also – according to plan, which you can see the guidance is around SEK 20 million for the  impact from that small stop in the fourth quarter. And then the ramp-up effects are the direct costs that are related  to the start-up, which are really related to energy, chemicals and also wood, wood uses during the ramp-up, a  significant part.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We've had a stable wood supply to our industries very much due to the fact that we have large forest holdings that  we can rely on and the Östrand start-up is progressing according to plan, both volume-wise but also quality-wise,  which is equally important.

texts.text: Jan C. Johansson  President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB  Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the SCA Year End Report 2011. Let me just start with some  key events during the year. And of course, then the binding offer to acquire Georgia-Pacific Tissue business in  Europe is one. The divestment of Packaging excluding kraftliner business in Sweden is one. We also have  acquisitions – strategic acquisitions in emerging markets such as Brazil and two acquisitions in Turkey, one 50%  and one 95%. We also have established the joint venture in Australia as communicated. We have introduced an  efficiency program in – particularly in our Hygiene business. And this is probably the first time in SCA's history  where we launched a major efficiency program, and that will bring us some cost saving but mainly foster to the  market more efficient sales force et cetera. We also have established new wind power venture that will give us fully  utilize two turbines per year in production.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Coming into the full year, we do have, if we compare like-to-like, a sales increase of 4%. We have a good growth in  emerging markets, and this is all in local currency. Packaging volume for the year is flat. We have substantial  increase in corrugated prices of some 9%. Forest – in the Forest area, publication paper volume is flat, and solid- wood is up by 5%.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Forest Products, we have in local currency increased prices by 20% in news during last year and 7% in magazine  paper, but that has all been consumed by currency or increased raw material costs. So it's – even though we have  been achieving what we – I think we communicated we would like to achieve is sort of being disappearing by the  currency and raw material. And here is mainly waste paper that we have seen increased prices, but also, clay, et

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Organization, I talked about the wind power capacity and upgrades. So we do accelerate the growth in the  company, but we want to accelerate it in a way so we feel safe that it's the right thing to do and, of course, that we  pay the right price for anything we are acquiring.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Independent Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
