texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Independent Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: If we start with efficiency programs, so shortly, it's running according to plan. We have some achieved cost saving  of SEK 390 million in the Hygiene business. And annualized, we are at – in average for Q4, we are up to €175  million in the €300 million program.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Independent Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Independent Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB

texts.speaker: Jan C. Johansson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Independent Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: The EBIT increase, 19%. Of course, we get the cost savings. We have higher volumes. We have the acquisitions. texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Independent Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Independent Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Independent Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: An EBIT increase of 188%. Then, of course, we have the forest swap of SEK 455 million. And for me, that's  obviously a task for the forest operation to manage the forest in the best way. And if we can trade land with less  growth to land with more growth, that's exactly what we expect for them. So it's a natural part of their business.  And that's exactly what we've been doing during this year and mainly during Q4. And we also get forest that is  closer to our industrial part of the business, which means less cost in the system when we operate the forest.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Independent Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Sustainability indexes, very important when we talk to customers, but becoming more and more important also  when we talk to consumers. And of course then the dividend increase, as I just explained.

file: SCA.B - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 30January2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jan-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jan Christer Johansson
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director
texts.text: I've talked a lot about innovations earlier and I will come back to that ones. We're having a very successful year  when it comes to introducing new innovations to the market. We have also successfully transferred our business  in China into Vinda and that creates a very interesting potential for further growth. We continue to be including in  key sustainability index, which is also very important for us, and we proposed an increase of dividend by 10.5% to  SEK 5.25 per share.

texts.speaker: Jan Christer Johansson
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director
texts.text: Operating profits increased by 14%. If we take away the big profit we had in forest swaps last year, it's actually an  increase of 18%. Also, operating margin is going up, earnings per share up by 19%, and we also had a  very strong  cash flow.

texts.speaker: Jan Christer Johansson
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director
texts.text: Efficiency program, we have been talking about that since we started it. If we look at the hygiene business in total  now, we have implemented the blueprint in all our sites. That doesn't mean that the impact of the blueprint is yet   seen in all operations. But now, we have a very clear way of how we should work, how we should improve, how we  should reduce cost in our operations.

texts.speaker: Jan Christer Johansson
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director
texts.text: We also more and more are using our scale when it comes to buying raw materials, et cetera, and we also, in some  areas, cooperate with other buyers like in pulps. So today, we are the biggest pulp buyer in the world and that, of  course, helps to get good terms in the market.

texts.speaker: Jan Christer Johansson
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director
texts.text: We also have combined the maintenance organizations up in the north of Sweden, and that's also a very good  efficiency impact on maintenance. And we work continuously, of course, too, on the harvesting and how we  harvest and improve the productivity on that. Then, of course, we had a storm that had a negative impact on that,  because it's so much more expensive to work into forest that is lying down than actually do it in a planned way.

texts.speaker: Jan Christer Johansson
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director
texts.text: Sourcing costs, down by 5%; logistics costs, 5%; energy consumption, 6%. So we can truly see that what we are  doing has an impact in all areas where we actually are working. And this work is, of course, not going to stop once  we have reached the target of the different programs we have announced. We will continue with this and we still  see some interest and potential going forward. We are not going to set up a new program, but now we will do it in  the day-to-day business.

texts.speaker: Jan Christer Johansson
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director
texts.text: If we look at operating profits, all in all, it's 3%. But then, as you remember, we had about SEK 455 million gains  in forest swaps last year. We have SEK 3 million this year. So if we compare apple-to-apple, it's actually an  improvement of 20% of operating profit. We have better price/mix, as I said. We also have higher volumes, cost  saving. Quarter-over-quarter, it's about SEK 385 million in cost savings.

texts.speaker: Jan Christer Johansson
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director
texts.text: Then we have the consolidation of Vinda, but quite a lot of headwind in raw materials, about SEK 600 million, Q4  to Q4, of which 55% is currency. If we remove the forest swaps in the standard margin in 2013 would have been  11.6%. So like-for-like, it's an improvement in margin also. Earnings per share is, of course, impacted by swaps,  but also of items affecting comparability. And as I said also, a very strong improvement of cash flow.

texts.speaker: Jan Christer Johansson
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director
texts.text: Then going into Forest operations. They have quite a substantial improvement. Y ou can't really believe that when  you look at this picture. But once again, SEK 455 million in forest swaps last year and SEK 3 million this year. So if  we compare apple-to-apple, the margin would have been 12.6% instead of 25.1%. So in that perspective, quite a  substantial improvement in operations, and we have improved all the different parts in Forest.

texts.speaker: Jan Christer Johansson
texts.profession: President, CEO & Independent Director
texts.text: Personal Care is completely different game. As you know, it's innovation, innovation, innovation. So it's not really  just a price increase. But we do have a benefit in Personal Care and that is that oil price is going down and we have  a lot of raw materials that is oil priced connected. But we have a lag of four months to six months before we have it  in our P&L. Pulp, we have a lag about 45 days. So it's a longer lag to oil-based materials than we have on the pulp.

file: SCA.B - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 26January2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jan-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Magnus Groth
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We also announced in August the potential split of the group in two listed companies, hygiene and forest  products. And as a consequence, we presented a new vision and enhanced strategic framework specifically then  for the hygiene part of the business.

texts.speaker: Magnus Groth
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Forest products had a pickup in sales in the fourth quarter. Organic sales increased by 4% behind these volumes  in pulp and in solid wood products primarily. Adjusted operating profit is down 10%, down from 14.8% to 12.9%  and this is due to higher energy and raw material costs and in spite of higher volumes and lower distribution  costs.

texts.speaker: Magnus Groth
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: And we also have us a bullet here of biological assets adjustment and Fredrik will talk more about this in a short  while. And as usual, I'd like to say something about the outlook for the first quarter when it comes to prices for the  most important products in forest products since these are global market prices. For publication paper, we foresee  stable outlook for the first quarter. Of course in the longer term, we have a bleak outlook for publication paper.

texts.speaker: Magnus Groth
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Kraftliner, a stable outlook for the first quarter even though we are starting to see some price increase  announcements coming now in the market. So, looking beyond the first quarter, maybe slightly higher prices. And  the same for pulp, slightly higher prices in the first quarter. And in solid wood products, also higher prices.

texts.speaker: Fredrik Rystedt
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & CFO, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Magnus talked about the biological assets. And I will just start by saying what this actually is. And what we do  every year is an adjustment or evaluation in accordance with IFRS in biological assets. And the way that works is  that based on the harvesting plan that we do every eight years, we haven't done that this year, but we base the  valuation on that harvesting model, what we do is we assess a starting value. And then we assess what the  inflation is both for the cost and for the wood price.

texts.speaker: Fredrik Rystedt
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & CFO, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Now, this therefore is not a market valuation, because it's completely linear and static model in the sense that we  don't estimate any potential future price increases that may come out from higher demand or perhaps more use of  biological assets for biofuel, et cetera, or other kind of things. So, we just have a static starting point for our  valuation.

texts.speaker: Fredrik Rystedt
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & CFO, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We have historically used a 10-year model. And if you look at the graph there, below, you can clearly see that  over the last several years, because of many things, including storms and other things, prices of wood have  actually come down. So, the 10-year average, which is kind of clear from this graph, is much higher than the  corresponding spot price at this point of time. And that means that we have adjusted now, and we've gone to,  instead, a five-year model, which is kind of very close to where the actual spot prices is. The result of this is that  the average price has come down from SEK 467 million to SEK 432 million as a starting point of the valuation.

file: SCA.B - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 30January2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jan-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: And we also, this quarter, had some extra costs related to that big investment project in Östrand, but they are,  again, according to plan for SEK 28 million for the quarter. Otherwise, the project in Östrand is running according  to plan. We have now done 70% of the investment or SEK 5.5 billion. We have just recently started up the  evaporation plant and, as you know, which is also big positive thing for this project.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We have a sequential start-up, so we took – the wood-handling department were up and running already in the  autumn. Now, we have taken the evaporation plant up and running from January. Now, we will have the  packaging line and also the drying machine up and running in February. And then we will have the big, big thing in  April, May where we will extend the recovery boiler, but everything, so far, is running according to plan.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Then I walk over to our four segments and I'd like to start with the Forest part, and we have a balanced timber  supply situation. We have also had a stable price development with minor increases in our area. We can see that  in other area, prices going up just now, but we feel that we have a good control over the price development here.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Last year, we did harvest 4.4 million cubic meters, which is according to the long-term harvesting plan. The year  before that, we were hit by the storm, so then we had to harvest a little bit more on external land, but this year, we  are back on track, so to say. We have also started to prepare in terms of wood supply for the big start-up. We'll  need between 2 million and 2.5 million cubic meters more annually due to the Östrand project, and we are  prepared for that.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: And one thing that is worth mentioning is the timber yield. We have a situation where 67% to 70% of the cost for a  sawmill is related to the log. And just now, we have a little bit more than 50% yield in our sawmills, and we have  rather narrow stocks, so we are very happy about that and that also give a good contribution to our profitability.  That is related, of course, to some investments but also to a lot of hard work in this area.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: I did mention the all-time high production in Obbola, which is really a positive thing. We also took just recently an  investment decision in order to increase capacity of white top kraftliner in Munksund. As I've said earlier, that will  not have an impact on the total production capacity, but it will increase the share of white with 50,000 tonnes  annually.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Looking here, this shows you the several year perspective per segment, and you can see if I take first the Forest  segment, the net sales are pretty stable in this segment as we've discussed before. The EBITDA margin and  EBITDA is also stable. We had a slightly higher level this year than we've had in the previous years, and some of  that is due to less effects from the storms that happened some three, four years ago, and therefore, a higher level  of harvesting from our own forest as well this year at 4.4 million cubic meters.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: If I go to the same picture for EBITDA and, here, you see the main factors, again, price/mix on EBITDA with a  SEK 390 million impact in the fourth quarter again for prices for Wood, Pulp and kraftliner, slightly negative  volume again. We had very small positive trend for raw material; and for energy, energy driven mainly by the one- off items taken last year. It's not driven by the general trend in energy costs, which is more flat. Currency again  was negative primarily due to U.S. dollar. And then we had a few items in the other column here. We had a larger  maintenance stop effect this year in the fourth quarter. We had more costs related to the project in Östrand this  year than we had last year.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We also – apart from the project-related costs, we've talked before about there is an increase in direct costs in  relation to the start-up, which we expect, which comes primarily from increased energy usage, increased chemical  usage, higher wood consumption and also a higher share of lower quality B-grade pulp during the ramp-up phase.  We've given a range for this cost impact, some SEK 100 million to SEK 250 million. We expect it to be  somewhere in between but depending how well and how fast the start-up goes, it can be within that range. And  we expect that impact to come mainly in the second quarter and the third quarter of the year.

file: SCA.B - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 30January2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jan-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Strong sales growth, up 16% due to price and currency mainly. And also EBITDA was in comparison with Q4  2017 up 38% due to price and currency. On the other side, we've seen higher costs for wood raw material. And  we also have had some negative impact of maintenance stops, not the least in Q4 if we compare with Q3, but I  will come back to that later.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: If we then walk into each segment, starting with Forest. We have seen higher prices during Q4. And if you  remember from Q3, we said that the price is lagging a little bit, and this quarter the Forest has been able to  passing on the price increases for wood to the industry. We have now seen that the wood prices have leveled out  on a rather high level and we've also seen that the import prices has come down SEK 50 to SEK 100 per cubic  meter.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We have increased our wood sourcing in order to meet the higher demand from Östrand. And last year, we did  buy more than 4 million cubic meters from private forest owners in the region, which is also that on a record level,  but which is exactly what we need in order to supply Östrand, of course. Sales was up 20% due to increased  volumes, but also to higher prices. And the EBITDA, up 19% from SEK 358 million up to SEK 427 million for the  fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Ulf Örjan Larsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We have had an extended maintenance stop in Obbola and it was a little bit of a bad surprise for us because  when we stopped the turbine, which we do every 10th year, we had more damages in the turbine than we  thought. So, that means that we haven't been able to produce any energy from Obbola during the fourth quarter.  And at the same time, we had an extended stop in order to provide the service that was needed. Now, it's up and  running again but the extended maintenance stop [ph] costed (00:11:50) us around SEK 80 million which is all  related to the Paper business, of course. Anyway, sales was up 9% due to prices and currency, and EBITDA was  up 11% when we compared Q4 2018 with Q4 2017.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Here, if I'll take a bit more time and go through the performance per segment, and starting on the left-hand side  with the Forest division. Here, we have net sales have increased this quarter and increased last quarter. And the  biggest effect here is the growing level of supply to Östrand, so we are sourcing more wood and growing the  supply to Östrand. So, that leads to a growth in the sales of the Forest division.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: The EBITDA has also increased this quarter in the Forest division. That's not due to the same effect because we  are harvesting around the same amount from our own forests. We are not increasing the level of harvesting from  our own forest due to this, but the price – the wood prices have gone up and Forest division is now passing those  prices through to the industries. So, we had some time lag. We didn't have that effect last quarter, but that effect  is now coming this quarter and, of course, that has an impact then on the industrial side, where they're taking a  higher wood cost also.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: Bottom line has grown also due to the higher volumes of course. The margin is slightly down on Q3, but it's  basically the increased efficiency from the high volumes going through the mill. We had a maintenance stop in the  fourth quarter, as Ulf mentioned, which had an impact on cost and we also have higher wood costs coming  through, of course, which Östrand has to take.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: And then, in the Paper division, top line was more or less flat. Bottom line, we were down on the third quarter. And  the impact here has been – the biggest impact is due to the maintenance stop, as Ulf mentioned, in the Obbola  mill where we had both a longer and more expensive stop than we expected, and it was this turbine that affected  the stop and we had, yeah, no energy production. So, worst energy performance on electricity for the quarter, and  we also took more time to get back up to full volumes after the stop as well. So, we had a weaker performance  there than expected.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We also have a small – there has been some smaller, slightly lower prices, but that's a small effect on bottom line  this quarter. But then, the wood costs as well impacts the Paper division where they're taking taking a higher  wood cost as well in the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: If I then do the same for our EBITDA, you can see the impact of price mix that you saw in the sales. Variation is  the main impact driving the growth in EBITDA. Volume, slightly negative – a negative effect which you also saw in  the sales variation. Raw materials, we have some SEK 600 million impact, which is mainly driven by the higher  cost for wood raw material or wood prices. So, that's the main impact. We also do have higher direct costs during  the start-up of the Östrand mill as well. So, it's those two factors that lie behind the raw material cost that we're  now absorbing as well. Electricity balance, we do have higher electricity prices so that has a negative impact. But  that's been offset in the year by an income from selling green electricity certificates, which balances it out.

texts.speaker: Toby James Lawton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Svenska Cellulosa AB
texts.text: We had production volumes this year. We're in line with the volumes last year. So, pretty much the same volume  in production this year as we had last year, which is what we talked about. Deliveries did lag behind, particularly,  in the third quarter and fourth quarter, because we built up this finished goods stock. But production wise, we  were very much in line with the volume last year. And then, you can see some of the assumptions further down,  including non-fixed costs and energy balance and so on. Östrand will also be absorbing the higher wood cost,  which is mainly due to price, but coming through now with prices being higher.

The reason for this change is  to simplify the external reporting and to eliminate potential confusion between EBIT Group and EBIT Elevators  and Escalators. However, we will continue to show the E&E EBIT in our mid-year and year-end segment reporting  and this is unchanged from the past.

texts.speaker: Alfred N. Schindler
texts.profession: Chairman, Schindler Holding AG
texts.text: Now you would think, okay, this is it, and by the way, the chart stopped here not too long ago. But now the world  is changing again and we are at what we call in the second planet phase where we now have to change our  footprint, and here is why. You might remember, at least those who follow us for a long time, I used to say my  ultimate dream is to have one-third, one-third, one-third of operating income around the globe – one-third in the  Americas, North and South, one-third maybe in Europe, including Africa, and then one-third in Asia. Well, this is  a pipe dream because we are, in terms of bookings, we are already far ahead of that. And probably, in the future, it  will be 50% and 25% and 25%, 50% being in Asia.

texts.speaker: Alfred N. Schindler
texts.profession: Chairman, Schindler Holding AG
texts.text: So what are the main reasons for this enormous change of the footprint is that there is a second planet. People call  four are the most important. It's urbanization – 70% of the world population will live in cities in the very near  future. Seven or eight elevators out of 10 at the world market level are sold between Bombay, Seoul and Hong  Kong already today. Our population is aging worldwide, so they don't like to walk.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Tinggren
texts.profession: CEO & President-Elevator & Escalator Division, Schindler Holding AG
texts.text: Other megatrends which impact us is energy efficiency, and here I have to say also we are very fortunate. We have  products that meet the highest standards and highest application in energy efficiency so we can take advantage of  this global megatrend. And then we also have the demographic change where in the advanced economies now,  more than 20% of the population is older than 60 years, and they – here, the aging population is looking for  comfort, safety and convenience, and, therefore, demand for elevators are quite high.

file: SCHP - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 14February2014 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Jürgen Tinggren
texts.profession: President-Elevator & Escalator Division, Schindler Holding AG
texts.text: Now, in a nutshell then, I'd like to summarize that our LEAP strategy is being executed, and it accelerates growth,  and even slightly faster than what we had anticipated in so many areas. Our emerging strategy is working and our  new products have been very well received.

texts.speaker: Silvio Napoli
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Schindler Holding AG
texts.text: OECD has published figures last year which were quite publicly disclosed that it is now the first time in history  that urban population is bigger than the rural population. This trend will continue. When one says urbanization,  one also means automatically vertical transportation is an enabler to create higher buildings allows for higher  density in the city.

texts.speaker: Silvio Napoli
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Schindler Holding AG
texts.text: The third trend is energy efficiency. That is an important one because it means that not only people are looking for  simple solutions, but they also try to find solutions that combine not only vertical transportation but also energy  efficiency. And vertical transportation is, in truth, a technology which enables energy efficiency solution.

texts.speaker: Silvio Napoli
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Schindler Holding AG
texts.text: And finally, one should not forget, the maintenance market in China will become more and more important. I'll  come to that in a second. Perhaps to give a face to all this growth, I put here on the right -hand side, you see a little  example of a specifically government-led program whereby the idea is to move from what they called new villages,  i.e., the former way to expand urban areas into small neighborhood. The idea is to create more livable space. The  idea is to allow people to have more areas, for example, for greenery. And that only can be achieved through  vertical construction. And that's why you see here, those evolutions, the growth from small houses into small  towers. And to give you an idea, those small towers are about 20 floors plus high. Very good. So Chin a will  continue to grow, and how does Schindler plan to go about it?

texts.speaker: Silvio Napoli
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Schindler Holding AG
texts.text: And what did we do? Did we come with just a cheap product? No, that's not what Schindler is about. We tackled  this market with a product that is not only cost competitive, but a product that is higher quality, superior ride,  which got less components, therefore, it's easier to manufacturer, easier to install, which  is very important in  China. It has energy rating A class, and it is an evolutionary product, i.e., it was built based on the 3300 platform,  and at the record time to market of less than two years. This product, ladies and gentlemen, I think is the example   of the many more that we plan to introduce in the future: market-relevant, cost-competitive.

texts.speaker: Thomas Oetterli
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Schindler Holding AG
texts.text: As a group with social responsibility, all buildings are certified either as a LEED Silver or LEED Gold building.  With these tremendous investments, we are confident that we also have the right focus now for the biggest  market in the world.

texts.speaker: Thomas Oetterli
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Schindler Holding AG
texts.text: When we look into the urban environment, more than 1 billion people will move into the cities until the year 2030.  This will create further demand for buildings and mobility equipments. The global middle-class will almost double  in the same period. They can afford their own apartments into urbanized areas or even a second one. The  number of persons aged above 60 years will increase by 0.5 billion people. Vertical mobility will become more and  more important for those residential buildings where those people are living in. And the number of one-person  households will increase by 50% until 2030. This will increase the demand for apartments and, therefore, for new  buildings with elevators.

texts.speaker: Thomas Oetterli
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Schindler Holding AG
texts.text: Also, technology will further create demand in the elevator and escalator business, as you can see on slide  number 20. The aged installed base in mature markets creates modernization opportunities in order to increase  safety and comfort of the installations. Digitization is part of our everyday's life. New business models are possible  there in the connected building world. Connectivity of our equipment will become a driver for better service and  additional revenue streams. Ecology has become a common value in the world, with more energy-efficient  solutions; we want to contribute to a better world. So, there are so many positive megatrends which have to be  taken into account for our further growth.

texts.speaker: Thomas Oetterli

texts.text: Digitization is part of our everyday life with the Internet of Things. New business models are possible in the  connected building world. Ecology has become a common value in the world, with  more energy-efficient solutions, we want and we will contribute to elevate our world to a better place. So, there  are many positive megatrends which can be taken into account for our further growth agenda.

texts.text: Before we can roll out service and sell higher bandwidth, it is clear that we need to roll out. So far, we have a fiber- to-the-home footprint of 576,000 homes or buildings where fiber passes the building and can easily be brought  into it once an order is done by a customer.

texts.speaker: Carsten Schloter
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG
texts.text: This represents a penetration on all buildings of 12%. As you may remember, we aim to reach a 30% penetration  on households by 2015. We will add another 50 percentage points to reach 80% of households with high  bandwidth by 2020 by applying more cost-efficient technologies.

texts.speaker: Carsten Schloter
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG

file: SCMN - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 15February2012 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Carsten Schloter
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG
texts.text: We're moving to next slide. We have here done a picture map of what we plan to do in terms of network priorities.  We have already started rolling out fiber-to-the-homes and building in multiple cities. Up today, 10% of Swiss  households are connected 400,000 units. The idea is to have around 1 million buildings households connected by  2015. We can however, not stop there and will push fiber further into the network outside the 30% territory but  not necessary as fiber-to-the-home.

texts.speaker: Carsten Schloter
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG
texts.text: And here, we see a number of interesting technology developments that are popping up not only vectoring there  have been much talk about this, but especially fiber-to-the-distribution-point. Fiber-to-distribution-point is due to  technological development, a new way, I would say, to implement basically fiber-to-the-curb. Fiber-to-the-curb up  to now needed huge technology, you needed big shrink, big covenants industry and basically today similar  technology is available with the size of a shoe box.

texts.speaker: Carsten Schloter
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG
texts.text: And the size of a shoe box has the advantage that you can drop it in a manhole, that you can drop it in a manhole  which is 100 meter, 150 meters away from the customer. You don't need no authorization because those manholes  are already ours, you don't need a construction, you don't need to build a cabinet it's just linking copper and fiber  together with copper.

texts.speaker: Carsten Schloter
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG
texts.text: The reason why we have increased our CapEx this – last year, sorry in 2011, compared to our original guidance  and the main reason that we have increased this year our CapEx guidance to historic levels is that we have decided  beyond this 30% fiber-to-the-home footprint to go with such a technology mix in order to drive bandwidth further  but avoiding to build over the medium term fiber-to-the-home. And this will allow us on the whole footprint that  we have to increase bandwidth much quicker than if we build only fiber-to-the-home.

texts.speaker: Alberto Calcagno
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & General Manager, FASTWEB SpA
texts.text: The impact of the cost reduction initiative, the saving initiative as I said before, they've been launched, all  launched in the second half of 2011, that means that the full benefit will come – will start to come in 2012 and also  to exploit the favorable regulatory evolution. As I said, MTR is the first step. Now, it's important to also to have  strong grip on the ULL, let's say, prices evolution. So as a consequence, 2012 will be the first year of free cash flow  generation and that we want just to be the first of many years along a trajectory of a sustainable financial growth  that will become as I said structure in the following years.

texts.speaker: Carsten Schloter
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG
texts.text: So for us it's a way to save 40% of the CapEx, because 40% of the fiber CapEx in those cities is done by the  electricians and to dedicate those CapEx through deployment of mixed technologies in outside the 30% footprint.  So for us it's good, for us it's good. Of course, it leads to an opening of the network, but we must be naïve. If we  would have built a fiber network all alone, we would have been forced to open it. So it's a good thing because we  only pay 60% of CapEx.

texts.speaker: Carsten Schloter
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG
texts.text: On the next slide, you will see the progress in the main cities where we have these type of corporations and you see  that there are now some cities, for example, Geneva, where the number of homes passed is close to 90%, Basel it's  50%, Zurich it's 25%, it's pretty much advancing, so within the urban areas, we're really making good progress and  we will have in 2013, early 2013, the first cities that will be 100% available in terms of fiber-to-the-home.

texts.speaker: Carsten Schloter
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG
texts.text: Last a split on investment and this is valid for Swisscom Switzerland. You see 2010, we had roughly CHF210  million that were dedicated to next generation networks either on the fixed line side or on the wireless side. You  see that we have roughly CHF437 million that were dedicated to capacity extensions meaning backhauling, beta  centers, energy efficiency improvements extremely important also from cost rationalization long term, and then  CHF537 million on customer development projects. On this category, we're almost [ph] able today (02:12:51). And  as I mentioned, we will have finished the big migrations on the IT systems by 2013 and 2014. And what is  increasing basically is of course the share of CapEx dedicated to next generation networks, and this is logical due  to what I've said before, but the increase is really coming only and solely from there.

texts.text: This will – and I would say it's not finished here because with the initiatives that we actually have ongoing in  terms of infrastructure condition and construction, the performance on Swiss networks will further improve  massively.

texts.speaker: Carsten Schloter
texts.profession: Thank you very much, Bart and a warm welcome from our side, ladies and gentlemen. I will follow the structures
texts.text: Let's talk a little bit about the first experience on fiber-to-the-home. And what you see here is, first, the number of  households that are connected. Today, it's 550,000 households that have passed with fiber-to-the-home. And of  those 550,000 households, they are a little bit less than 300,000 that are open for commercialization.

texts.speaker: Carsten Schloter
texts.profession: Thank you very much, Bart and a warm welcome from our side, ladies and gentlemen. I will follow the structures
texts.text: And as a result, as I mentioned, what you see here is the traffic growth. And you see it in comparison between our  different infrastructures, you'll see that especially where we have our own fiber infrastructure, the traffic growth  over the past year is absolutely impressive. So, the message is own infrastructure matters. If you are in this fixed  line business, you need to own your own infrastructure. By the way, the whole position that we have in the  business market wouldn't be possible without own infrastructure.

texts.speaker: Carsten Schloter
texts.profession: Thank you very much, Bart and a warm welcome from our side, ladies and gentlemen. I will follow the structures
texts.text: Then, as you're aware also, we continue to invest, and in fact, we are leveraging the same technology approach  between Switzerland and Italy on fiber-to-the-street, fiber-to-the-street which is a technology where you bring  fiber up to the last manhole in the street and then for the last 150, 200 meters of copper, you are using a  transmission technology that is very close to VDSL, allowing for bandwidth of up to 400 megabits. We are  building this from overall investment of CHF400 million in 2016, reaching 3.5 million households. And you would  see here that the investment per household is astonishing low. It's very low. It's roughly €100 per household. Why  is that? Why is that? Because we are leveraging the fact that Fastweb has already extensive metropolitan fiber  infrastructure in the ground. We are leveraging the fact that Fastweb already had fiber-to-the-manhole today. It  has been built over the past 10 years.

texts.speaker: Carsten Schloter
texts.profession: Thank you very much, Bart and a warm welcome from our side, ladies and gentlemen. I will follow the structures
texts.text: And so, today, with the electronics being available to put on the ground, it's only a matter of putting the  electronics. And this is something that Vodafone and Wind simply cannot replicate because if you look at the fixed  infrastructure of Vodafone and Wind, they have fiber that is going to local exchange of Telecom Italia full stop.  That's where it stops. So, if they want to replicate the same approach, they have to build all the metropolitan  been made by the past and improving our footprint to a total of 2 million, plus 3.5 million, meaning 5.5 million  households with their own infrastructure, are a relatively modest investment.

texts.text: Now, I would like to hand over to Heinz, which explain you the infrastructure strategy.

texts.profession: Head of IT, Network & Innovation, Swisscom AG

I would say the last one -and-a-half years we  were exercising here, you're going to see Swisscom really ramping up now, the marketing machine to  making sure  that the infrastructure is going to be sold up quickly.

texts.speaker: Urs Schaeppi
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And now I would like to hand over to Heinz who will brief you a deeper insight on our plans on the Swiss  infrastructure side. Heinz?

texts.speaker: Heinz Herren
texts.profession: Head-Information Technology, Network & Innovation
texts.text: This year with our own innovation product, we have developed a manhole antenna, which you can put into a –  under the street into a manhole, which will help us serve coverage and performance into the cities. We will start  launching that in the bigger cities this year. But also we might have a little highlight coming ahead of us which is  the regulation of the radiation law. For the first time ever we think we could be able to change that law in  Switzerland as you might know, the law in Switzerland is 10 times tougher than in European Union, when it  comes to how much volt per meter are we able to send out of an antenna. So, the Swiss Parliament has now took  an initiative to trying to increase these levels. We are not clear, when this will happe n, this might be something  happening this year or next year, but not yet clear on what levels they will increase it. But we have now a big  positive move on that and we hope this will happen, because it will help us to not having to add too much  antennas perhaps or to use the existing network with higher radiation a bit longer than we were thinking.

texts.speaker: Heinz Herren
texts.profession: Head-Information Technology, Network & Innovation
texts.text: I mentioned secondly the conviction that we will go cloud. There is a lot that will happen in the next few years. The  stacks are ready, the clouds are now ready. We will now this year launch the internal transformation towards the  Swisscom Cloud for our own services and I mentioned some of the SDN, NFV activities. Again, here our goal is  this will take us some years, all our network function should at the end be in the cloud. We will not start with the  most delicate ones. So we will start with the easier ones and learning – by learning also being able to put the heavy  stuff, the core stuff, for example, mobile core into the cloud.

texts.speaker: Christian Petit
texts.profession: Head-Enterprise Customers
texts.text: Then in terms of leadership, the reputation of the company is very important. The capacity to deliver new  proposition is well regarded because our customer are confronted to a lot of challenges and they expect an  innovative partner. So we launched an IoT platform. As Heinz mentioned, we will launch the first nationa l-wide  low power networks which leads to a lot of new use cases. We piloted these networks last year in Geneva and  Zurich, and we have recorded more than 30 different new use cases for parkings, for logistics, for field things, for  energy management, and by doing that we can really offer to our customer new improvement in terms of  customer experiences.

texts.speaker: Alberto Calcagno
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & General Manager, FASTWEB SpA
texts.text: First off all, I think that Fastweb had ambitious target, if we are back 12 months ago, we had our plan to cover the  30% of Italian population in terms of – with our fiber technologies. I would say that not only we did what we  planned, because we have cover in 2015 over 6 million of households with our fiber technologies, but also we will  be well on track to reach and to fulfill our goal to reach 30% of the Italian population, which is I think a unique  case, if you consider that we are an attacker.

texts.speaker: Mario Rossi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: For the next year, in the guidance, you will see slightly lower CapEx in Switzerland without stopping the rollout,  Urs told about the CapEx efficiency in times, told about the CapEx efficiency and then we will have some  optimization in the project CapEx.

texts.speaker: Mario Rossi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We, as a management team, we are committed to these savings. We want to reduce our cost level by at least CHF  300 million by the year 2020. Next year, the main impact will come from the EBITDA – from the FTE reduction  of CHF 50 million and in 2016, we will see the full impact on the full year basis. Then on 2018, we see the impact  kick in of the All IP savings and that brings us to an overall saving of more than CHF 300 m illion per year.

file: SCMN - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 8February2017 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Urs Schaeppi
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG
texts.text: So, we don't have to deploy the whole country with Fibre-to-the-Home. We have a hybrid strategy. We have in the  cities Fibre-to-the-Home, 30% footprint approximately. And then to have a fast rollout in more rural areas, we are  doing this with Fibre-to-the-Street and this will also keep our CapEx or will, let's say, have the ability to save a bit  CapEx.

texts.speaker: Urs Schaeppi
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG
texts.text: But coming now to the costs. Last year we announced our ambition to develop our cost structure. And then on the  left side of the chat, you see that roadmap of different actions will lead to this decrease of our costs or these cost  savings of CHF 300 million. We are on track. We delivered our savings of CHF 50 million in 2016, and we will  deliver savings of CHF 75 million in this year. And then you can see, it goes – with approximately CHF 60 million  additional savings year-on-year. So that at 2020 we will have CHF 300 million less costs. That's our plan, that's  our ambition and we are here on track.

texts.speaker: Urs Schaeppi
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG
texts.text: Some information on 2016. This CHF 50 million savings which I highlighted out before, so how did we achieve  them? One part is on reduction of the head count. We have a head count reduction of approximately 700  employees in 2016, and that's the result of a call center location harmonization, so we reduced the call center  locations. But we also, put together, we made a merge of the different field forces as another example, so that we  were able to increase the efficiency in our company. We also reduced the overhead in Swisscom and we have  done this – all the reduction, we have done it without a negative impact at the customer front and I think that's a  good achievement. Efficiency increasement without impact on the customer side.

texts.speaker: Urs Schaeppi
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG
texts.text: On our ambition for 2017, cost ambition. We want to decrease our cost by CHF 75 million and you see that there  are four main actions to do it. So we will have a spillover from the decreasement or from the efficiency measure of  2016, that's the benefit of organization efficiency improvement. Second, we will boost simplicity. Third, we are on  the track to do the All IP transformation and then the fourth level is CapEx efficiency.

texts.speaker: Urs Schaeppi
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG
texts.text: This will give us the opportunity to gradually decommission our TDM infrastructure and then we will get savings  what you see on the right side of the chart over the next year. So we will have some change and some savings of  All IP, coming from 2018 to 2020, and the full impact we plan to have in 2020 in the dimension of CHF 100 million  as we already communicated.

texts.speaker: Urs Schaeppi
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG
texts.text: Efficiency. An important dimension to increase the efficiency is also the technology mix. If we would only make a  rollout of fibre-to-the-home, expensive technology, we would have much higher CapEx and much higher costs.

texts.speaker: Urs Schaeppi
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Swisscom AG
texts.text: So with the hybrid technology of fibre-to-the-home, fibre-to-the-street in combination with G.fast, and with G.fast,  we will have 500 megabit per second. We are able to be fast in the rollout and actually save costs, that's why we  picked this strategy. And Heinz will explain a bit more about it.

texts.speaker: Heinz Herren
texts.profession: Head-IT, Network & Infrastructure, Swisscom AG
texts.text: There is not really those killer applications around. And hence since we also can build FTTS. So, our hybrid  approach much, much at lower CapEx. We have focused now to build the rest of Switzerland, when it comes to  ultra broadband with a massive rollout of G.fast-based FTTS or FTTB technologies.

texts.speaker: Heinz Herren
texts.profession: Head-IT, Network & Infrastructure, Swisscom AG
texts.text: So, we have about 85,000 of those manholes in Switzerland. This is [indiscernible] (46:53) our grandfathers who  did a good investment here. We are one of the, not only, but some countries in Europe at least, which have such  good infrastructures. So, we want to use them and we go into those manholes, we put that G.fast box in which is  the second little picture you will see, there is a 16 and 48 port box, which then takes the signal from fibre convert it  to the existing copper network using the latest 200 meters of copper to ensure that we can bring the signal from  400 to 500 megabits to the household.

texts.speaker: Heinz Herren
texts.profession: Head-IT, Network & Infrastructure, Swisscom AG
texts.text: But they already show how to go above gigabit speeds using a last tail of copper networks. We could also do if we  would need to have to do that, we could also go on with FTTH because that first part we build on the feeder  network is a point to multi-point fibre structure, so we could easily add more fibres on that drop part of the network  towards the household. We don't think we need that, but let's see what happens in 15 years, 20 years.

texts.speaker: Heinz Herren
texts.profession: Head-IT, Network & Infrastructure, Swisscom AG
texts.text: The big majority on FTTS with G.fast, the rest is done on FTTS using vectoring technologies, which allow you  also to go up to 100 megabits speed, and the remaining roughly 10% very rural areas, we will do a combination of  vectorizing those, but also using as we showed the DSL-LTE bonding technology. So, that's roughly the plan we  have on our fixed line side.

texts.speaker: Heinz Herren
texts.profession: Head-IT, Network & Infrastructure, Swisscom AG
texts.text: We had a discussion on the Council of States on the radio emission limits. Unfortunately this was lost by one  vote, one politician unfortunately went to holiday. He was pro, and he missed really on that vote. We will work on  it. That would have helped us to have a higher emission power to be sent out to the network. And so, we have to  find ways around how to do that. It will be an important topic. And I think politics have to engage on it, because if  you don't remove those burden for a 5G world, 5G will not really be able to happen in all its flexibility, which we'll  be able to offer.

texts.speaker: Dirk Wierzbitzki
texts.profession: Head-Products & Marketing, Swisscom AG
texts.text: We could have been able to manage indirect costs down by roughly CHF 23 million. However, we could not  entirely maintain EBITDA margin. The additional effects next to the reduction of service revenue were slightly  higher SOCs, but I explain later on what that means, mostly actually good effects on SOCs as it also is related to  the higher volume in retention, which we believe is good for the business.

texts.speaker: Alberto Calcagno
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, FASTWEB SpA
texts.text: This is one of the most important slide, because as I told you, we want to increase our ambitions in the mobile,  and actually here our aim is to become the first convergent player, but real one. And I think that 5G gives us very  strong opportunities, because 5G is a technology that is between fixed and mobile. And 5G needs at the end  three ingredients, and one is fibre. And on fibre, I think, as we were discussing before, we have old fibre that is  necessary. Then you need some places where you can store the equipment to manage the small cell, places that  needs to be secure, that needs to be electricity powered, and we have it because we have already 20,000  cabinets available, and in a couple of years, we will have 50,000 cabinets available, and each of them can  manage from 5 to 10 small cell. So, we are talking about potentially 500,000 small cell available for 5G.

texts.speaker: Denis Kessler
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SCOR SE
texts.text: Thank you, Ian, and good morning, everyone. In the third quarter, which, as you know, marked by a high  frequency of large natural catastrophes, SCOR clearly demonstrates its resilience and shock-absorbing capacity.  Indeed, it is a policy of the group to anticipate these risks and to absorb them within the framework of the group's  risk appetite.

texts.speaker: Denis Kessler
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SCOR SE
texts.text: Major catastrophes have punctuated history. We still have in mind the destructive hurricanes in North and Central  America in 2005, we have in mind the major earthquake which hit Chile in 2010, and of course, the Japan Tōhoku  earthquake and tsunami, as well as the flood in Thailand, which occurred in 2011.

texts.speaker: Denis Kessler
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SCOR SE
texts.text: Here, on this graph, we have the history of these shocks into our balance sheet in the last 11 years, including  financial and sovereign debt crisis, political uncertainties, and of course, natural catastrophes. As human beings,  we can only deplore these shocks, of course. But as reinsurers, our duty is to anticipate and to absorb these  events. As this graph demonstrates, the group has not only successfully anticipated and absorbed these shocks,  but it has also grown through them by more than tripling its shareholders' equity and successfully taking its credit  rating to best-in-class across this period.

texts.speaker: Denis Kessler
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SCOR SE
texts.text: Let's move to slide 5. In anticipation of large events such as the natural catastrophes which we faced recently, we  have done our job by maintaining a strictly controlled risk appetite on the one hand, and a robust and effective  capital shield on the other hand. As you know, SCOR maintains an upper mid-level risk appetite, our U.S. P&C  book is growing but it's still underweight, and we are less exposed and [ph] are pleased (04:06) to extreme U.S.  cats.

texts.speaker: Denis Kessler
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SCOR SE
texts.text: Let's move to slide 6. We see on this slide that we did a job correctly. What does it mean? First, you know that to  anticipate shocks, we have a system of limits in place against which we continuously check risk exposures to  ensure we remain consistent with the risk appetite. As you can see from the numbers, the actual losses of the  2017 hurricane events are still considerably below those associated with a 1-in-200-year scenario for a North  Atlantic hurricane. But had they been of such an extreme magnitude, our solvency ratio would still have been  within the optimal solvency range.

texts.speaker: Mark Kociancic
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SCOR SE
texts.text: As previously communicated during the quarter, our set of results has been impacted by an exceptional series of  large losses from natural catastrophes. SCOR's net income for Q3 2017 year-to-date stands at €25 million. And I  will come back later on to the net income and return on equity to give you some color.

texts.speaker: Victor Peignet
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-SCOR Global P&C, SCOR SE
texts.text: We've already communicated on the impact of these nat cats on the quarter on a year-to-date basis for the  insurance and reinsurance markets and for us. Whilst these series of losses, which occurred in Q3 and to which  the wildfires in California must be added as a Q4 event, remains within the shock-absorbing capabilities of the  reinsurance market, our view is that its impact on the annual earnings of insurers, U.S. principally, and reinsurers  can't be without consequences.

texts.speaker: Victor Peignet
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-SCOR Global P&C, SCOR SE
texts.text: For the rest of the year, our underwriting capabilities are unaffected and we continue to be adequately protected  by our retrocession program without having had to go to the market to buy replacement or additional covers. For  next year and the remaining period of Vision in Action, there is no change in our plan. We are progressing  normally in the renewal of our retrocession program, and have it started the process very early as we usually do,  we are already well advanced. We are confident in our ability to satisfactorily complete the renewal of the  renewable parts of the program.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-SCOR Global Investments, SCOR SE
texts.text: SCOR Global Investments delivered a 2.6% return on invested assets in the first nine months of 2017. Restated  from natural catastrophes impacting our ILS portfolio in the third quarter, the normalized return on invested assets  in the first nine months of 2017 would reach 2.7%.

texts.text: Just as 2010 started with a series of non-clustered Nat Cat events that heavily affected the first  quarter accounts, 2011 follows the same very unusual pattern. Because of the  nature and the extent of the losses, the qualitative and quantitative analysis in terms of the loans  recoverable from insurers and reinsurers will be a very complex operation that will take time.  Based on the limited information available to date and on the combination of vendor model  simulations and probability checks by the underwriting and modeling teams, the very first estimates  of the cost of the bulk 2011 Australian occurrences on the one end and of the second New Zealand  earthquake on the other end, net of [inaudible] and before tax are each close to €100 million. For  Nat Cat losses originating from Australia or New Zealand, the group is protected by an external  reposition program that responds in excess of $185 million per occurrence.

texts.speaker: Denis Kessler
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SCOR SE
texts.text: Thank you, Ian, and good morning, everyone. Our mission as a reinsurer is, of course, to help fellow citizens to  alleviate the negative impact of risks once they occur and to safeguard the resilience of societies around the world  facing risks of all kinds. We are proud at SCOR to have accomplished our mission in 2017, which was marked by  an exceptional series of major natural catastrophes, notably with Hurricanes Harvey, Irma and Maria, but also  with the forest fires in California.

texts.speaker: Denis Kessler
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SCOR SE
texts.text: The total insured costs of natural catastrophes in 2017, is along the lines of $130 billion. This record level loss  experience was exceptional. So, it falls within the range of possibilities of the probabilistic universe in which we  operate. And the strengths of our reinsurer is measured by its ability to deliver during such atmospheres.

texts.speaker: Denis Kessler
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SCOR SE
texts.text: SCOR successfully passed its full-scale stress test, once again demonstrating the strong resilience of its business  model and its shock-absorbing capacity. We did it before in 2011 when Japan was hit by a terrible tsunami.  SCOR was able to run all of its commitments to its clients, and contributed to the protection of hundreds of  thousands of people who were severely affected by these natural catastrophes, while managing to deliver a good  set of results. In addition, the relevance of the business model was recognized once again by the rating agencies  with an upgrade by A.M. Best on September 1, cementing the position as a Tier 1 global reinsurer.

texts.speaker: Denis Kessler
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SCOR SE
texts.text: Let's move to the next slide. Major catastrophes have punctuated history. Here on this graph, we see the history  of shocks to our balance sheet over the last 12 years, including financial and sovereign debt crisis, political  uncertainties, and of course natural catastrophes.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SCOR SE
texts.text: Going to page 10. I'd like to walk you through the normalization of our net income and return on equity. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-SCOR Global P&C, SCOR SE
texts.text: Thank you, Frieder, and good morning. These Q4 net combined ratios include a net technical ratio of  75.8% that is the sum of an attritional loss ratio of 49.5% and a commission ratio of 26.3%.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-SCOR Global P&C, SCOR SE

texts.speaker: [05HFRJ-E Denis Kessler]
texts.text: As far as acts of God are concerned, Mother Nature has also been quite agitated in 2018 with two destructive  hurricanes in the U.S., Michael and Florence; two powerful typhoons in Japan, Jebi and Trami; two wildfires in  California; and other smaller events across various areas and regions. Managing such risks and covering these  kinds of events is [ph] les soldats (00:04:02) as we say in French, the mission. We are there to help citizens and  societies face this risk. We are here to alleviate the negative impact of this risk once it occur. And at SCOR, we  are proud that during this second consecutive year of elevated natural catastrophe activity, we have once again  accomplished the mission.

texts.speaker: [05HFRJ-E Denis Kessler]
texts.text: On the P&C side, the 2018 P&C combined ratio remains below 100% despite the numerous natural catastrophes  that took place last year. SCOR Global Life [ph] because a  (00:07:56) robust life technical margin of 7% in 2018.

texts.speaker: [05HFRJ-E Denis Kessler]
texts.text: Finally, SCOR Global Investments delivered an elevated return on invested assets of 2.8% in 2018, largely driven  by a continuing increase in the income yield. Basically, all three of our group's engines are delivering. Even [ph]  though (00:08:22) we have not managed to achieve the group's global profitability target of 800 bps above the  risk-free rate due to the exceptional weight of natural catastrophes and the cost of the U.S. tax reform, the group  is certainly profitable and its underlying technical fundamentals are very strong.

texts.speaker: Victor Peignet
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-SCOR Global P&C, SCOR SE
texts.text: Thank you, Frieder. Good morning. 2018 was another year marked by natural catastrophe, although not as badly  as 2017. 2018 and 2012 are the second costliest nat cat years on record, with insured losses of around $80  billion. Costliest years are 2017, 2011 and 2005, with inflation-adjusted insured losses ranging from $130 billion to  $140 billion. Therefore, 2018 appears to have continued a six- to seven-year nat cat cycle that started back in  2004.

texts.speaker: Victor Peignet
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-SCOR Global P&C, SCOR SE
texts.text: 2018, beyond the six losses that received wide media coverage – two hurricanes in the U.S., two typhoons in  Japan, and two wildfires in California – the market has been impacted by a large number of smaller, but still  significant events all over the world. This unusual loss profile, with a high frequency of medium- to high-severity  losses, has always been monitored by SCOR's Enterprise Risk Management system and stands well within our  risk appetite as an earnings event.
