texts.text: But let’s take a closer look now to the market environment in the first quarter. This is slide number  one which I’m referring to. First, the Fertilizer business sector; the first quarter of 2010 was  characterized by a significant revival in demand for fertilizer. In preparing for the spring season  trade sector demand in the Northern Hemisphere, particularly in the case of potash fertilizers and  complex fertilizers grows considerably, whereas last year for strong purchasing restraints.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The contracts concluded by some potash suppliers with Chinese and Indian customers at the end  of last year, and at the beginning of this year supported confidence in the stability of potash prices,  and therefore supported demand. The majority of potash producers were back at almost full       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 2 utilization of their production capacity. However, primarily in the northern hemisphere, logistical  problems partly due to winter weather conditions restricted the flow of goods to some extent.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The Salt business; in the Western European de-icing salt market, the exceptionally long winter in  the first quarter resulted in very high demand. While the winter in the United States passed  relatively normally during the first quarter, Canada experienced a very mild winter overall. The  North American price level for de-icing salt was lower than during the same period of the previous  year, when it had benefited from supply bottlenecks. Both food grade and industrial salt saw high  demand as they were used as de-icing salt agents as well. Demand for salt for chemical use  slightly improved.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide five; with Salt now having gained a greater proportion of our revenues and income, we’d like  to provide you with more details on volumes and pricing, like in potash. Year-on-year, volumes  increased strongly mainly due to the consolidation of Morton Salt, and the already discussed good  winter weather overall. Without Morton Salt, volumes in de-icing salt would have increased by 5%,  whereas other crystallized salts would have increased by 4%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Going forward, and based on a 10-year average, we expect volumes of around 21 million tonnes,  divided into approximately 12 million tonnes of de-icing salt and approximately 9 million tonnes in  the remaining salt product groups, all figures excluding drying. In 2010, however, due to the better  than normal de-icing salt business so far, we project a volume of around 22 million tones, driven by  a slightly higher de-icing salt business of a good 13 million tonnes.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let’s now turn to the business segment development in the first quarter, slide number six. Potash  and Magnesium products revenues rose by 36% to about €500 million due to increased volume  demand. Due to a fixed cost degression, the EBIT I was up by as much as 55%, and amounted to  €150 million. Nitrogen Fertilizer revenues and EBIT rose by 13% as well as 79%, as the utilization  of production capacity was significantly higher year-on-year, and positive volume effects managed  to compensate for negative price effects. Moreover, earnings were no longer adversely affected by  restructuring measures.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Although not decisive on the group level, but to compliment the picture, complementary business  revenues increased by 14% to €33 million, driven by volume and price effects in the waste  management and recycling area and volume factors in animal hygiene products. Logistic sales  benefited from a higher transportation volume with rising demand for fertilizers. Logistics and waste  management were equally accountable for the significant rise in earnings, as mentioned, a little bit  more specifically to the Salt business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide number eight; we still expect 2010 to be a transitional year in the potash market. As a result of  lower trade sectors inventories, lower soil potash content following two very good harvests, and the  lower application of fertilizers since autumn 2008. For 2010, we assume an overall sales volume of  45 to 50 million tonnes, compared to our previous assumptions of around 45 million tonnes and  reported worldwide sales of 32 million tonnes in the year 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We now expect a tangible increase in revenues by significantly lower average potash price in 2010  compared to last year. Operating earnings will significantly increase on the back of total costs,  which we revised to less than full extent to the fixed cost degression. In the Nitrogen Fertilizers  business segment, we’ll see a significant increase in revenues based on higher sales volumes,  forecasting lower average mineral fertilizer prices than in the previous year, we expect a  moderately positive result.

file: SDF - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 12May2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-May-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide number four, all business segments performed better compared to Q1 ‘10. Potash and  Magnesium Products revenue rose by 15% to €572 million, due to strong demand for potash and  magnesium fertilizers. Higher average prices enabled us to more than make up for cost increases,  and led to an EBIT I increase of 34%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Nitrogen Fertilizer revenues rose by 26% to €484 million, primarily due to price factors. Operating  earnings in this segment reached €50 million, after €15 million in the same quarter last year. The  business segment profited from a very strong margin expansion.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Part B, the Fertilizer business sector in more detail. Slide number six, the fertilizer business sector  saw strong demand in the first quarter of 2011, which has been supported by the unchanged high  level of agriculture prices that provided a significant incentive for the farmers to raise yields by  hectare through an increased use of effective fertilizers.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: For both potash and magnesium product and nitrogen fertilizers, the utilization of production  capacities throughout the world has been very high. This environment favored the development of  prices for potassium chloride. In mid-January, the export organization BPC and Canpotex agreed  with Chinese importers to the supply of potassium chloride standard at US$400 per tonne, including  freight.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Starting with the Chinese settlement of US$400 per tonne, Canpotex announced in February prices  of US$460 per tonne for standard and US$475 per tonne for granulated potassium chloride for Asia  and Latin America.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In Europe, we, K+S, implemented the price increase announced in mid-December 2010 to €335 per  tonne of granulated potassium chloride, and announced a further price adjustment of €353 per  tonne in mid-March. Due to existing supply commitments, price increases currently become  effective with a delay of six to eight weeks, but it will.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Against this background, we forecast a global potash sales volume between 58 million to 60 million  tonnes. Please note that our outlook figures are usually approximately 2 million higher, 2 million  tonnes higher than those given by competitors as we include SOP and other low-grade potash  specialties.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Starting from the potash sales volume level in 2011, long-term growth rates are expected at 3% to  5% per annum again. For the next couple of years, this would result in utilization levels of about  85% annually. This is, again, a good level, especially if you consider the risk that announced new  capacities could be postponed or even canceled due to technological, geological challenges and/or  due to an inadequate price level.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now, I would like to provide you with some more details about business seasonality of the Potash  and Magnesium Products business turning to the next slide, number nine. As can be seen from the  graphs above, seasonality had a tangible effect on revenues, sales volumes, operating earnings  and total unit cots.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Please follow me now on the next slide to discuss a breakdown of selective cost items, slide  number 10. As can be seen, we expect energy costs to rise significantly and depreciation to rise  tangibly while personnel, material and freight costs are estimated to grow moderately in 2011. The  sales volumes are forecasted on a stable level. We assume total unit costs being slightly above  €200 million for the overall year 2011, compared to €196 million in 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The wintery weather at the East Coast of United States triggered above average demand for de- icing salt, too. In Canada, demand proved to be in line with the long-term average. The price level  was somewhat below that of the comparable period due to the mild weather of the previous year  and the resulting relatively high stocks. While the European market for industrial salt was       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Year-on-year, de-icing salt volumes increased mainly due to higher volumes sold at the U.S. East  Coast and in Canada. Average prices for de-icing salt rose slightly as a result of higher European  and Canadian prices but lower U.S. prices.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As we observed, an even greater seasonality in the Salt business than in the Potash and  Magnesium business segment, I would now like to take a closer look on this at the next slide,  number 14.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the Potash and Magnesium Product business segment, we assumed to achieve a significant  drives and revenues going ahead with a strong growth in operating earnings. This outlook is based  on the sales volume of 7.0 million tonnes and a significant rise and average prices.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The Nitrogen Fertilizer business segment is expected to significantly increase revenues and  operating earnings should rise tangibly. Revenues in the Salt business segment are forecasted to  remain stable on a very high level, but operating earnings should decrease moderately due to  higher freight costs and sales from stocks. As usual, we assume an average de-icing salt business  in the fourth quarter 2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: For the overall year, 2011, we have upgraded our outlook against the background of the recent  price increase in the Potash and Magnesium Products business segment to €533 per tonne, which  is now with €553 per tonne, which is now implemented and a good start into the de-icing salt       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Second, as you know, BASF has announced on 1st of March the intention to sell major parts of  their fertilizer production facilities. We, K+S, have clearly ruled out to buy the assets because of our  two-pillar strategy that provides for growth in the Potash and Magnesium Products and in the Salt  business segments. The existing capacities are not affected and everything else remains to be  seen.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Third, our most important project, the Legacy Project in Saskatchewan. We have started  infrastructure work and preparations for first drillings. Currently, we are reviewing the optimization  approaches in the existing feasibility study. The result of the review will most likely be  communicated in autumn.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Fourth, we currently run the feasibility study to examine the reactivation of our mine Siegfried- Giesen. The technical results should be available in summer, will be evaluated afterwards and  communicated most likely in autumn, too.

file: SDF - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 10May2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Christian Herrmann
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, K+S AG
texts.text: The first quarter 2012 has passed with a strong performance in the potash and magnesium products business  segment, and more or less stable performance in our nitrogen fertilizer business segment, and as expected and  flagged a rather weak development in the salt business segment. We, therefore, would like to provide you with our  interpretation of the latest numbers and the fundamental view on how we see our business going forward.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Let's now proceed with the key figures of the Group, slide number two. Driven by lower salt sales volumes,  revenues declined by 12% and reached the good €1.4 billion in the first quarter. Coming from a high level, EBITDA  and EBIT decreased by 21% and 24% respectively, as planned, capital expenditure increased compared to the  previous year. The increase was, amongst others, attributable to investments in the legacy project in the package  of measures on water protection in the Hesse-Thuringia potash district as well as in the renovation of the  evaporation facility at Morton salt in the United States.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Compared to the first three months of 2011, operating cash flow decreased and reached €85 million excluding the  out financing of pension obligations. This decrease was mainly caused by an increased tie-up in working capital  due to higher inventory risk in the salt business segment as well as higher payments to BASF to nitrogen fertilizer  business segment for the very successful previous financial year. Earnings per share followed the overall earnings  development and stood at €1.01 for the first quarter, a decline of 26%.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: On slide number three, we provide you with a closer look at the changes in K+S Group's revenues during Q1.  Revenues overall decreased by around €189 million. Of this decrease, €287 million were contributed by negative  volume and structure effects particularly in the salt business segment due to the unusually mild winter in Q1 2012.  Sales volumes of the potash and magnesium product business segment declined moderately while nitrogen  fertilizers business segment slightly increased its volumes.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Slide number four. Performance of the fertilizer division and in particular the potash and magnesium products  business segment was clearly standing out while the salt business segment suffered from the mild winter and dry  weather conditions during the first quarter of 2012.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Potash and magnesium products revenues rose slightly to €580 million due to higher average prices and the  positive currency effect compensating for somewhat lower sales volumes. On the cost side, positive earnings  effects of changes in inventories compensated for in particular higher energy cost and the negative currency result,  which led to an EBIT contribution of about €209 million for the first quarter, the strongest operating earnings  ever achieved in the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Nitrogen fertilizer revenues rose by 10% to €360 million due to positive price factors. Operating earnings in the  second reached a very good €32 million after €34 million in the same quarter last year. Higher input costs caused  a slight reduction.  Revenues in the salt business segment fell in the first quarter due to reasons already mentioned. This resulted  especially in comparison to the very high sales volume of the previous year's period and a strong decrease in  revenues of €495 million. First quarter's EBIT fell by €94 million to €46 million. The strong decline in earnings  was mitigated by savings in the areas of maintenance and personnel costs.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Let's now move on to the fertilizer business sector in more detail. Slide number six provides, as always, a general  view on the environment of the markets we are active on. In the wake of the European sovereign debt crisis, the  trade sector was more cautious in its early stocking-up of fertilizers at the end of 2011 and the beginning of 2012.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Moreover, winter kill resulting from rather dry and cold weather led to a postponement in the European spring  season. However, throughout the first quarter, the price levels for agricultural raw materials continued to offer  attractive income prospects for farmers and therefore incentives to increase yields per hectare also through the  optimal use of fertilizers.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Against this backlog, at the end of the first quarter, there was an upturn in demand for potash fertilizers,  especially after the contractual negotiations with China for the first half of 2012 were concluded with unchanged  terms in mid-March.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: The global market's price level for potassium chloride was tangibly higher in the first quarter of 2012 than one  year ago. In comparison to the average of the fourth quarter 2011, prices moderately decreased in some regions.  However due to conclusion of the contract in China, international potash prices tend to get stronger by now.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: As most – as you most likely have already noticed, on slide number nine, on the 8, May 2012, we announced an  agreement with EuroChem regarding the sale of K+S Nitrogen. We're also pleased to have found a well-suited new  owner of K+S Nitrogen and think that the sales to EuroChem is the best option for K+S but also of the employees  of K+S Nitrogen. Closing of the transaction will likely happen at the end of the second quarter, the enterprise  value amounts to €140 million. The sales will generate a book profit of around €70 million to €80 million mainly  depending on the net earnings of K+S Nitrogen generated by the time the transaction is closed.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Following the divestment of COMPO last year, the sale of K+S Nitrogen consequently fits into our strategy, which  pursues the goal of focusing management and financial resources particularly on the potash and magnesium  products and the salt business segments.  While we are evidently very content with the transaction overall, and we achieved enterprise value, I was very  negatively surprised when I saw from analysts' comments on the transaction, for example, stating the negotiated  EBITDA multiple was slow sorry – that K+S was eager to get the business off its books. Even worst, someone  stated they saw the price as disappointing and estimate that it should have been a €2 per share negative effect on  the target price.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: I know that analysts are often under time pressure to analyze results and so the events. On the other hand, our  presentations have been showing the details of the K+S Nitrogen contractual business this year, we are  transparent. But I think I don't go too far when I expect the same level of professionalism that we showed. I  definitely do not accept that an absolute and relative terms – a very good set of Q1 result is spoiled by unfounded  and negligent comments on the K+S Nitrogen sales.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: As a result of the very mild and partly dry weather conditions, the demand for de-icing salt in Europe and on the  East Coast of the United States was unusually weak, particularly compared to the above-average first quarter 2011.  Prices in Europe were slightly higher than one year ago and relatively stable compared to the fourth quarter of  2011.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: As you observed, a greater seasonality in the salt business segment than in the potash and magnesium products  business segment, I would now like to take a closer look at the next slide, number 13. Compared to one year ago  revenues decreased significantly due to factors already explained before. The strong decline in earnings was  mitigated by savings in maintenance and personnel costs. [indiscernible] (14:58) sales volumes declined by 39%  leading to a lower fixed cost coverage and thus to a lower profitability, but still generating an EBIT margin of 10%.  Slide number 14, it's significant to point out the extraordinary situation in our de-icing salt business during the  first quarter. Usually, the access to multiple de-icing salt markets in different climate regions mitigates the overall  degree of fluctuation in our de-icing salt business. As you can see, the results of the last year's proved that this  overall concept works quite nicely.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Finally, I would like to provide you with an update on how we see the year 2012 as a whole. First, slide number 16,  potash; we can see a certain improvement. Against the background of potash supply contracts concluded with  China in the middle of March 2012 at unchanged conditions and continued attractive agricultural prices, demand  for potash fertilizers improved towards the end of the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: This development should continue in the following month, so that we assume a global potash sales volumes of up  to 58 million tons for 2012 as a whole. Please note that this forecast in contrast to our peers includes potassium  sulphate and other potash specialties of around 3 million tons.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Salt, due to the unusually mild weather conditions at the beginning of the year, the demand for de-icing salt in  2012 in Europe as well as in North America will be reduced accordingly. In the food grade and chemical salt areas,  we expect demand to remain largely stable in the sales markets relevant for K+S. And in industrial salt area, we  expect it to decline somewhat, especially in North America.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: This brings me to our outlook that is unchanged to the one we have presented mid March, slide number 17. It still  includes the nitrogen division since the sale of K+S Nitrogen was announced after we have set up the outlook on  the 2, May.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the year 2012 should again be a very good one for the K+S Group. The prospects for the  development of demand for potash and magnesium fertilizers are still good, in particular in the regions that are  relevant to us. Therefore, from today's point of view, we continue to regard the sales level close to last year's 6.9  million tons as positive.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: In line with our customary purely technical forecast policy, which maintains the currently achieved potash price  level unchanged for the rest of 2012 and average price level that is moderately higher than that of the previous  year is to be assumed. Therefore, revenues in the potash and magnesium products business segment should  increase moderately. Due to higher energy costs, however, unit costs are expected to rise tangibly. Against this  background, we assume that operating earnings could approach with earnings of 2011.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: In the case of nitrogen fertilizers, our outlook expects a slight increase in development in revenues but also higher  input costs and therefore stable operating earnings.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: In the salt business, due to the significant decline in salt sales volumes, we expect a tangible decline in revenues  and a strong decline in earnings compared to the above average year 2011. Overall, this should result in stable  revenues for the K+S Group in 2012, as well as moderately decreasing operating earnings once again, still  including our nitrogen activities.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Just in case, you would like to know how the sale of K+S Nitrogen effects our outlook statements, well, slide  number 18, rest assured. The sale of K+S Nitrogen has no impact on the outlook I just presented. If we do a pro  forma adjustment, we still expect stable revenues and moderately decreasing operating earnings for the year 2012

file: SDF - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 15May2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Before we go into the details, let me briefly summarize the first quarter and I think this is slide number one or two,  I do not know. The EBIT I increased by 12% in the year-on-year comparison. Our Potash and Magnesium  Products business units delivered the best first quarter we've ever had, while Salt saw a significant rebound in  volumes.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Now, please turn to slide number three. Both business units contributed to the 19% increase in group revenues.  Main driver behind this increase were higher sales volumes. Negative price effect in the Potash and Magnesium  Product business could be more than offset by double-digit year-on-year increases in European and overseas sales  volume and more than 60% higher de-icing salt volumes.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Slide five showed a significant increase in the operating cash flow. This is mainly due to a lower tying up of  working capital due to lower inventories than in the first quarter of 2012. Salt inventories were used to a greater  extent than in the same quarter a year ago.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: The cash flow for investing activities in the period under review includes higher CapEx for the measures on the  water protection in Germany and the ramp-up of capital expenditures for the legacy project as expected. In total,  free cash flow was about 60% above the first quarter of 2012.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Thank you very much, Mr. Lohr – Dr. Lohr. I will now elaborate in more details on the market development and  drivers for the results of our two business units. We are starting with our Potash and Magnesium Products  business unit on slide number seven.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Dr. Lohr already mentioned the improved cost per tonne in the Potash and Magnesium Products business unit. As  you can see on slide number nine, unit costs were down compared to the first and fourth quarter of 2012. Higher  sales volumes, reduced energy costs and positive currency effects offset the effect of the change in inventories and  higher depreciation and amortization. All in all, we are on track to keep our costs under control and to maintain  stable cost overall for the full-year 2013 compared to the full-year 2012 as guided in March.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Let us now turn to our Salt operations. Looking at the market environment on slide number 11, I especially want  to focus on de-icing business. The long-lasting wintry weather conditions in Europe led to demand which was  above average and significantly above the level of the last year in that region. Also, North America experienced a  normalization after the mild conditions of previous year's first quarter. Everywhere, prices remained under  pressure due to the mild winter in 2012 and subsequently, higher inventories.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Having reached a sufficient certainty on the most likely CapEx and OpEx from the results of the basic engineering,  it is our duty and ambition to inform the market about the knowledge we have as immediately as possible. We can  divide the reasons for the increase in the CapEx in two groups. One, as we should have made that clear before,  consists of investments into our own infrastructure instead of leasing it. A good example here is the port facility at  the West Coast. These measures will reduce our operating cash costs. We also found that due to modifications and  optimizations of plant components, sustainable savings, for example, in energy consumption are achievable. But  we are also facing higher cost for material and labor during construction time, which are, for example, due to  higher wages for the construction workforce and a lower productivity of those people than we had previously  assumed.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Please turn to page 16. I talked about the changes in our plants – in our plants earlier and also indicated that some  of these measures will lead to lower operating costs compared to what we expected before once the site is up and  running. We expect a decline of sustainable operating cost by CAD 10 per tonne, and you can imagine that this has  an impact on the NPV calculation given the life time of that site.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Therefore, please turn to slide number 19. We expect a tangible increase of global potash sales volumes to about  59 million tonnes for 2013 due to the policy start into the new year after the contract conclusion with Chinese and  Indian customers in January, and due to the continued attractive income levels for farmers which give them an  incentive to maximize their yield by using fertilizers.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: We still expect a slight increase in revenues and EBIT as our sale volumes for Potash and Magnesium Products are  expected to be at about 7 million tonnes, but average portfolio prices was declined, we expect a decrease in EBIT  for this business unit. However, the normalization of sales volumes in our Salt business and here especially de- icing salt should be able to more than offset this. We now expect Salt volumes to be closer to 13 million tonnes for  the full-year 2013. The other number we changed is the CapEx estimate for the group as already indicated. After  some CapEx for the Legacy Project will be postponed to the year 2014, we now expect group CapEx to be around  €820 million compared to €1.1 billion before.

file: SDF - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 15May2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Our Salt business performance confirmed that our presence on three continents pays off. The strong North  American winter has offset an extraordinarily mild [ph] white (2:24) winter in the Europe. Last but not least, Fit  for the Future is delivering first successes and not only with regards to the identification and implementation of  cost-saving measures. Q1 already contained small but solid savings compared to Q1 2013.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Here again, the 7% decline in group revenue is due to lower potash prices that could only partially be offset by  higher salt sales. This is also true for the EBIT I. The financial results declined from minus €18 million to minus  €27 million, as this quarter includes for the first time the interest expenses of the two bonds issued in December  last year. Subsequently, the net income decreased by 25% to €142 million.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Four weeks ago, the IFA expected global sales volumes of about 56 million tonnes in 2013. But recent knowledge  based on IFA data suggests that global demand was even stronger, at about 59 million tonnes. You're aware that  we include in these numbers what makes K+S unique roughly 3 million tonnes of potassium sulfate products and  potash grades with lower K2O content.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Looking at costs per tonne, we see an improvement of 6% versus last year, despite lower year-on-year volumes.  The main reason for that was besides lower energy costs the fact that we sold more products in Europe instead of  overseas, which led to lower freight costs in this quarter.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: In addition, we have also achieved cost savings as an effect of our Fit for the Future program. We are very happy  about this development. But to be very clear, that was one quarter only. Our best guess is that costs per tonne on a  full year view will remain flat about 2013. This expectation, of course, includes higher depreciation and increased  year-on-year OpEx for Legacy.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Let's move to our Salt business on slide seven. You may recall that we already showed you these pictures eight  weeks ago, but we did not find any others that describe the situation in Q1 better; strong winter in North America  and nothing worth mentioning in terms of winter across Europe. Inventories in North America are now at a very  low level. The opposite is the case in Europe. And here you see that the K+S strategy works. No winter on one side  of the Atlantic is offset by stronger winter weather on the other side. So K+S did and will continue to make use of  its production on three continents. Our European side helped out our North American customers this year and  will certainly do so when we need to renew inventories to prepare for the next season.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Even in light of the comments I just made, and of course assuming no major hiccups from now, this number is a  bit too conservative from our point of view, and it seems the difference comes especially out of the business unit  Potash and Magnesium products.

file: SDF - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 13May2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Y ou can see the current stages in the pictures at the bottom of the page and the next slide which is slide number  nine. Not only is the snow gone, but the detailed engineering is also now fully completed, and the permit for the  port facility has been granted. Many components for the ECC were further assembled, and the steel bodies for the  factory are growing. Despite the fact that there is plenty of work ahead, we are still confident in beginning the  commissioning of the site and start-up sequences in the summer next year. All of this is in line with the allocated  budget of CAD 4.1 billion.

file: SDF - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 10May2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Let's have a look at the highlight of the quarter on slide two. Our two -pillar strategy has shown again that it  worked. Despite a mild winter, our Salt business contributed strongly to the Q1 results. In the Potash business,  our colleagues were busy managing the production by only having a limited deep -well injection permit for the  Werra site. So far the impact of temporary production outages was limited. We continue to expect that we will  receive the long-term permit by summer this year.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: I mentioned earlier that the cost discipline remains high. A very good example is our Potash business, which  decreased its cost per ton from €212 to €201. The progress we made is due to our Fit for the  Future measures.  Also, lower energy costs and freight rates contributed to this effect.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Let's have a look at the progress of our Legacy Project on slide four. Legacy continues to make good progress. We  have now invested around 90% of the C$4.1 billion budget. During the quarter, we focused on the production  facilities. Also, [ph] first, rail tracks were built to connect the tide (04:01) with Canadian Pacific's network to  transport our potash to Vancouver. The construction of the port facility there is also well underway. The project  remained on track for commissioning this summer and to produce the first ton of potash by the end of this year.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Now please turn to the outlook on slide seven. We have kept our assumptions unchanged compared to a few weeks  ago. Although, we have seen a stabilization of overseas potash prices, we stick to our outlook for 2016. Soft  commodity prices remain low and will, together with continued strong competition, lead to significantly lower  average selling prices compared to last year. The fact that we are still working on the limited permits for deep-well  injection makes us especially cautious. We continue to expect a long-term permit for summer this year.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: The Q1 impact was very small. However, we are now approaching spring, which is usually dryer than winter time  and thus, further outages at the Werra plant cannot be excluded. Our Salt business is faced with higher inventory  left in the system after the mild winter season and production is being adjusted accor dingly. We are doing our  utmost to further improve profitability of the business. However, lower de-icing sales volumes for the upcoming  season cannot be ruled out. All in all, we stick to our qualitative guidance of significantly lower operating results  for the full year 2016.

file: SDF - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 9May2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: We expect to have the first tonne of MOP available by the end of June. By the end of this year, the site will reach  its 2 million tonnes capacity and then ramp up further to about 2 million, 2.9 million tonnes by 2023. We assume it  will contribute positively to the EBITDA in 2018 already.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, when I look back to the multi-year construction period of Legacy, I must say the road was  from time-to-time bumpy. However, [indiscernible] (02:34) is certainly not unusual in case of such a big  undertaking by building up a potash mine. Eventually, we can say we made it. And we are looking into the future  of Bethune with great optimism, and it will begin to serve our customers very soon. Globally, we will do this with  our own network capability. In U.S., our marketing agreement with Koch Fertilizer [indiscernible] (02:56)  customers and the storage space we need to serve them. We do not see any shortage of storage capacity for us  [indiscernible] (03:11) recently.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: Please turn to slide number 3. As we have already guided, production in 2017 cannot run at full capacity yet as  the permits we have been granted in December last year includes a couple of restrictions, including a maximum  limits from daily injection volume. It will continue to impact in particular production at our Hattorf plant when the  Werra river water levels are low. We experienced this already happened during the first week of the year,  unfortunately.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: On the other hand, we made good progress to evaluate and implement alternatives for the disposal of  wastewater. Besides existing measures for temporary or permanent storage of [indiscernible] (03:58) production  plants, we have also again increased basin capacities on site. This increases our flexibility, but it's still not  sufficient to full production in prior periods. However, it ensures that the runtime should be above last year. Now,  for example, the Werra levels are not sufficient, but we expect production until the end of May at least.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: There is also good progress on the new KCF facility, which is an important element to reduce dependency on the  weather and the water level. The KFC (sic) [KCF] (04:36) will reduce saltwater residues by around 20% from 2018  onwards. It will help us execute production to a larger extent and will make us more – much more independent  from the water levels. And the KCF extracts further marketable and profitable product of around 250,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: With regard to the business in salt. It is non de-icing business at higher volumes in de-icing to offset the lower  prices [ph] for raw salt (08:58) in North America after a mild winter in the season 2015-2016.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: Slight tailwind from potash prices and from higher volumes in both business units is projected. We will continue  with our initiatives to reduce cost across the group, and execute our Salt 2020 strategy. On the other hand, mainly  the production start in Canada would burden our EBIT significantly more than the €90 million in 2016. This is  because D&A kicks in at amount exceeding the gross profits from potash sales.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: We anticipate a negative EBIT contribution from Bethune of about €150 million as for now. On top of that, [ph]  visibility (10:06) in the German potash environment remains low. The permit we have been granted along with our  additional measures will give us some relief, but it would not be sufficient for all production year round during this  dry period. This means, depending on the water levels of the Werra river, our Hattorf plant will continue to operate  on an on and off basis. Extraordinary dry periods would still have a significant negative impact once again on our  German production, which could impact profitability heavily, and the summer is still ahead of us.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: From 2018 onwards, the new KCF facility will help us to reduce the volume of saline wastewater by 20%. This  means that we will reduce the risk of production expenses significantly. And our Bethune mine is expected to  deliver positive EBITDA by then and our progress will continue on its path of consistently improved earnings.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: We are aware that today's potash prices make the target very ambitious. However, we still believe that prevailing  low price environment is not sustainable as the mid to long-term trends remain intact. Additionally, everybody  [indiscernible] (12:10) this group, deeply committed for delivering the €1.6 million by 2020 and we will keep this  momentum.

file: SDF - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 14May2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: And let me start with the highlights of the first quarter on slide 3. And most important message on that slide is that  sales and EBITDA are up over last year's first quarter. Our revenues rose by 4% on the back of high production  availability, mainly from Bethune, higher de-icing volumes, the absence of weather-related standstills at the Werra  plant, and, of course, further increasing MOP market prices.

file: SDF - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 14May2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Our Industry customer segment is comprised of our former potash and salt product. In combination, this is a 10- million tonne division, which is generating sound and relatively stable margins. Sales and EBITDA are clearly  equally spread over the quarters. In Q1 2019, we reached last year's revenues, although availability of product  was lower due to the closure of our Sigmundshall mine. In earnings, [indiscernible] (00:04:02) electrolysis,  customers improved whereas freights costs are still weighing on profitability.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Last but not the least, the Communities de-icing business benefited from the severe and long-lasting winter  conditions in the U.S. and Canada. Volumes were even better than last year. And as a result, prices rose. Now  we are looking positive into the next tender season starting in summer. First price indications are promising.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: And now please turn to the next slide to talk about full year guidance. First of all, we confirm our 2019 EBITDA  guidance of €700 million to €850 million. We also confirm production levels, expected cost per tonne of our potash  production and target sales volumes. After positive FX development and good winter businesses in Q1, we feel  confident with our EBITDA range. Please remember this assumes that we will not face drought-related outage  days in the months to come. For the moment, production is running smoothly. The background ponds are roughly  18% filled and we've already started with transportation of saline wastewater to offset this disposal. In summer,  we additionally expect the permit for a temporary underground storage of 400,000 cubic meters. The good news,  by obtaining this permit, we would be able to handle summer like last year without outages.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Let's sum up what we've achieved so far on slide 7. We are happy with our Q1 achievements. Our operating  performance improved both in Bethune as well as at the Werra mine. Our wastewater management improved and  makes us more robust. The first quarter also showed that we are on track to reach our main target becoming free  cash flow positive in 2019. All in all, we can confirm our 2019 guidance given in March and the targets we have  set so far for year-end 2020.

file: SDF - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 12August2010 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Aug-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let’s start with a closer look at the Q2 market strengths and figures now and this is slide number  three we’re always affirmative. Our fertilizer business sector. The second quarter of 2010 was  characterized by a normalization of demand for fertilizers. Farmers in the northern hemisphere  used potash fertilizers at almost of the normal level during the spring application. The positive  demand trend for nitrogen fertilizer continued during the second quarter and the business with  complex fertilizers also showed positive development.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Global potash prices stabilized between 350 and US$400 per ton. For most potash producers the  degree of capacity utilization did not achieve the very high level of the first quarter, but was  nevertheless at a reasonable high level. Prices for nitrogen fertilizers rose significantly against the  backdrop of increasing input cost and the European production facilities for nitrogen fertilizers  operated at high utilization rates.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 2 Some remarks on our salt business sector. In the Western European de-icing salt market there  were delays in the early stocking up despite the low inventories of many customers. After the  persistent wintry weather conditions and temporary supply bottlenecks many customers initially  looked to revise their stocking up policy. For Western European price level for de-icing salt tended  to firm up somewhat in the biddings and contracts for the winter season 2010-2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In North America high inventories due to a rather mild winter in many regions make the position of  suppliers more difficult in the local tenders. Until now this resulted in slight price declines in some  cases. The market for industrial salt in North America developed positively, while sales volumes in  South America declined slightly mainly due to weather related supply problems in Brazil. The  demand for salt for chemical use improved significantly and in line with the economic recovery,  most of all in Europe.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Nitrogen Fertilizer revenue rose by 12% as utilization of production capacity was significantly higher  year-on-year. Operating earnings in this segment reached €26 million after amounting to a negative  €27 million in the same quarter last year. In addition to higher sales volumes and lower raw material  costs, the EBIT of this segment benefited from the release of provisions after the final settlement of  input costs for 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide number nine. With today’s publication of our Q2 results we have upgraded our 2010 global  potash sales volume forecast to 50 million tons from the previous range of 45 to 50 million. This  improvement is mainly based on a strong and higher than expected volume recovery in Western  Europe and North America. While these markets had to suffer most last year, they now show the  strongest recovery.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: For 2011, we expect worldwide potash sales volumes to range between 53 and 57 million tons.  This goes along with demand increases in all regions and is put in relation to capacity data on the  next slide.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 4 major cultivated crops in Europe. A similar price trend can be observed in other crops such as corn,  soybeans, palm oil [inaudible].

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: You may well remember that the year 2008 offers farmers a record profit potential. Although costs  came down considerably farmers’ income in 2009 dropped on the back of significantly lower prices  for agriculture products. As a consequence farmers began to focus on cost savings instead of  optimization of crop yields. This is somewhat specific in drive weather conditions, put the  extrapolation of the last two years record harvest into question and cost us strong increase in prices  for agriculture products.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: But it has to be seen of the very recent development in prices for agriculture products [inaudible]  stocking in the Northern Hemisphere. Should the prospect of a better income situation prove to be  sustainable farmers have clear incentive to move away from the so-called savings mode into a yield  maximizing mode. This will then go along with an increased fertilizer consumption in the next spring  season.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now we would like to give you an overview on the performance of our second pillar, the Salt  business segment. And I continue with slide number 13. The left graph of this chart – on this chart  highlights that due to external growth mainly the acquisition of achieving SPL in 2006 and Morton  Salt in 2009, salt sales volumes have increased over the past years while keeping the de-icing salt  share rather stable at 50 to 60%. In addition this shows that the price level for de-icing salt has  been tending upwards over the past years, a trend that might come to a pause at least in 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The right graph shows that also on a quarterly basis the acquisition of Morton Salt is reflected in a  strong volume increase. But also with the strong result in Europe that de-icing salt volumes  increased in Q1 compared to the previous year. Further more, quarterly volumes and prices are  certainly affected by the seasonality of the de-icing salt business. Prices generally tend to be  somewhat lower in the off seasons quarters, two and three. Combined Q2 and Q3, de-icing salt  volumes as you can see sometimes even account for only 10% of salt volumes sold over the whole  year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide number 14. In Q2, salt volumes increased strongly due to the consolidation of Morton Salt  year-on-year. Without Morton Salt volumes in de-icing salt would have decreased by 14%, whereas  other crystallized salt volumes would have increased by 17%. Prices for de-icing salt were higher  than in Q2 last year, mainly due to positive product mix effects within North America.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: This chart number 15 now shows that Morton Salt with a very mild winter and a good part of de- icing salt regions could achieve the same attractive EBITDA margin of 22% in H1 of 2010 than the  former salt business of the K+S Group in H1 of last year which benefited from an above average  de-icing salt business.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: With regards to prices and compared with the first half of the year, we should see moderately  declining average prices of our potash and magnesium product portfolio in the second half of the  year. This should be caused by the usual seasonal product mix and [inaudible] price effects.
