texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Let's now move on to the Potash and Magnesium Products business segment in more detail. Slide number four  provides, as always, a general view on the environment of the markets we are active on. After the fertilizer trade  sector had still ordered cautiously at the start of the year, the demand for potash and magnesium products saw a  significant revival during the second quarter of 2012. The relatively high price level for agricultural raw materials  offered attractive income prospects for farmers and therefore an incentive to increase yields through the optimal  use of fertilizers.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: As already mentioned and as can be seen from the graphs on slide number six, we are very pleased with the  second quarter result in the Potash and Magnesium Products business segment. Revenues reached €670 million  in the second quarter of 2012 and were thus significantly above the figure of the previous year. EBIT I increased  by 31% to €241 million. As expected, unit costs increased tangibly to €219 compared to €192 one year ago. This  was mainly due to higher material and energy costs. The energy costs have still been impacted by last year's oil  price increases, which have influenced our cost accounting with a time lag of six to nine months.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Now let's move on to our Salt business, slide number eight. As a result of the very mild and partly dry weather  conditions at the start of the year, stocks of producers and customers in Europe are very well filled. Therefore,  prices declined in the early preseason business of the second quarter. While prices in the tenders for the winter  season 2012/2013 in Europe also decreased, overall volumes in the contracts concluded to date stand at a

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Quarter-on-quarter, following the normal quarterly seasonal patterns, de-icing salt volumes were significantly  lower. De-icing salt price declined, as usual, during early procurements. Volumes of the other product groups  mainly increased in overseas markets, but prices decreased slightly due to the regional product mix effects.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: As you observed the greater seasonality in the Salt business segment than in the Potash and Magnesium Products  business segment, I would now like to take a closer look at the next slide, slide number 10.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: I also would like to highlight the effect of earnings after taxes from discontinued operations, which are only  included on a after-tax level. In the second quarter of 2012, almost €10 million came from the discontinued  operations of K+S Nitrogen. The second quarter 2011 was affected by more than €90 million book loss related to  the divestment of the COMPO business.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: In the Potash and Magnesium business segment, trade receivables increased due to price effects. In the Salt  business segment, stock levels remained high after the unusually mild winter. In addition, trade payables were  reduced slightly.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: On slide number 15, I would like to give you some details about changes in our energy purchase agreement for our  German potash and salt sites, which we conducted during the second quarter. As you probably know, the energy  costs of K+S Group are particularly impacted by the purchase of natural gas. Until now, the energy supply clauses  were predominantly tied to the oil price, and a change in the oil price has normally been reflected with a delay of  six to nine months in our cost accounting.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: We have restructured these agreements during the second quarter in order to significantly reduce the dependency  on the oil price going forward. Therefore, the purchase of natural gas will be split in a relatively equal relation  which are reflected in our cost accounting with a delay of now only three to four months, and purchases on the  spot market for natural gas. The purchase of energy will thus be more strongly diversified in the future, and we  can seize opportunities arising on the energy market.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: Furthermore, the portion of agreements with fixed natural gas prices is providing better predictability. For 2012,  these changes will not have a remarkable impact anymore, but in 2013, all else equal, the positive effects from the  restructuring of the purchase agreements should be visible in our energy bill. But please keep in mind that this  would partly be mitigated if the currently strong U.S. dollar persists.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: For 2012 as a whole, we expect global potash sales volumes of about 56 million tonnes. Please note that this  forecast in contrast to our peers includes potassium sulphate and other potash specialities of around 3 million  tonnes.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Salt. Due to the unusually mild weather conditions at the beginning of the year, the demand for de-icing salt in  Europe as well as in North America will be reduced accordingly in 2012 in comparison to the above average year  2011. In the food grade salt area, we expect demand to remain largely stable in the sales markets relevant for K+S.  And in the industrial salt area, we expect it to decline somewhat, especially in North America. The demand for salt  for chemical use in Europe should fall moderately due to the economic cooling. In North America, it is likely to  increase slightly. And in South America, it should remain stable.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Taking this into account, revenues in the Potash and Magnesium Products business segment should increase  moderately. Due to higher energy costs, the negative currency result as well as costs for the Legacy Project, we  expect unit cost to rise tangibly. All in all, we meanwhile even assume a slight growth in operating earnings in the  Potash and Magnesium's division.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: The tangibly weaker financial results and an overall adjusted group tax rate of between 27% and 28% should lead  to adjusted group earnings from continued operations of €540 million to €600 million, or €2.85 to €3.15 per  share. Taking into account the earnings from discontinued operations, we expect adjusted earnings per share  between €3.30 and €3.60, up €3.04 in 2011 since the expected book profits from the divestment of K+S Nitrogen  in the third quarter of this year 2012 and the cessation of the adverse effects from the divestment of COMPO  business will have a positive effect.

file: SDF - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 13August2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: A lot was also discussed regarding K+S future in the Potash business. So let's take a closer look at our setup on  slide number four. One can look at our unique portfolio from different angles. The K+S follows the two -pillar  strategy with having a Salt business that has been expanded and diversified over the last couple of years. But also,  our Potash and Magnesium products business has elements that make us more robust and differ materially from a  pure potash producer.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Our portfolio includes 1.2 million tons of products that do not at all contain potash and go into investor  applications like oil drilling for the basic chemicals industry, as well as for feeding or as fertilizer specialities  fortification. The 5.28 million tons of potash and of potash-containing product, not only pure MOP. There are 2.5  million tons of products [ph] with low (4:45) K2O grade, including nutrients like magnesium or sodium or sulfur  that do not appear in deposits of other producers.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Digging deeper into our product portfolio on slide number five. K+S holds the leading market positions in certain  product segment. We generate about 50% of our revenues in markets where we act as the  market leader. From left  to right, intensity of competition fades out and you will not find many large producers of those kinds of products  as the nutrients cannot be found in all deposits. Of course, there is a correlation to the MOP price, but this as w ell  declines to lower – the lower the K2O content is.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Summing up what I explained, K+S is and will be a potash produce, no doubt; but we are more. We have fertilizer  specialities and salt; only a little or not at all affected by any disruptions in the fie ld of MOP. If necessary, the K+S  Group will stand together in order to maintain its integrity.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: In the Potash and Magnesium products business, receivables fell as a result of price and volume factors. And in  the Salt business, inventories were significantly reduced primarily due to the better weather conditions in the first  quarter of 2013 compared to Q1 2012.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Cash flow for investing activities in the first half year amounted €27 4 million and, therefore, significantly  exceeded the level for the same period a year ago. As expected, capital expenditure increased especially in  connection with the package of measures for water protection as well as the Legacy project. The free cash flow  reached €281 million and was about 36% above the same period a year ago.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Slide 13 provides an overview of the quarterly cost position in the Potash and Magnesium products business uni t.  In the second quarter, unit costs decreased to €207 per ton and were about 6% lower compared to the previous  year's figure. In addition to lower energy and freight costs, lower sales volumes resulted in an increase in  inventory levels year-over-year. I can assure you that in the context of our strategy, we're continuously focused on  improving cost efficiency in all areas of the company.

file: SDF - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 14August2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Our average selling price is lower year-on-year but has improved quarter-on-quarter mainly due to specialties.  Cost per tonne showed a very satisfying development. As in the first quarter, it remained at very low level. In  addition to lower energy costs, we also sold more product in Europe than overseas, which gave us a freight cost  advantage. In addition to that, our colleagues in potash and magnesium have also successfully worked on Fit for  the Future. Most of the effects can be seen in material and third-party costs which declined significantly.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: What forms our base case? We expect salt volumes to be slightly above 2013 levels with de -icing coming in above  14 million tonnes. With regard to potash and magnesium product, we are sticking to our volume assumptions. The  average selling price will of course be tangibly lower than last year. However, the €265 in the first half marks the  bottom. We anticipate further year-on-year progress in reducing costs. On the other hand, we are facing increases  in depreciation and higher OpEx for Legacy. €193 per tonne is not sustainable for the total year because the main  portions of the maintenance cost occur in the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: What would make the EBIT I move to one end or the other? The upside, for example, could be a better than  currently expected salt results if the winter is above average. With regard to potash, our specialties have already  made good progress, and potassium chloride is facing many variables, for example, the price development of such  commodities or adverse weather effect. This could move the trend. We are cautiously optimistic but also want to  be realistic.

file: SDF - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 13August2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: The underlying performance of our potash and magnesium business unit was very strong. Lower sales volume also  impacted the cost per tonne. However, costs have now stabilized, which is a great success of our Fit for the Future  program.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Please turn to the Legacy project update on slide eight. The development of this flagship project is on-time and  on-budget. We have spent about 65% of the CapEx allocated in the project and more than 90% of the contracts  with suppliers have been signed. This means we have not only made significant progress, but have also materially  de-risked this investment. 2015 will be the main year of construction, reflecting a peak in capital expenditure. The  CapEx used for further expansion will be significantly lower in 2016 and will turn to a sustainable level of  management CapEx from 2017.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: And now please turn to slide nine. The main achievement this quarter was the setup of major utilities like water,  gas and power, which is now available on-site. We have also started the earthworks for our rail connection from  sites to the intersection of Belle Plaine. There are still plenty of work ahead, but we are very confident that we will  commission the site next summer. This is all in line with the allocated budget of CAD4.1 billion.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Please turn to slide 10. We were asked to provide more details on our assumptions relating to the Legacy project  and our previously disclosed valuation of between €11 per share to €21 per share. If you could start with the  pricing, we have taken a conservative approach with regards to pricing assumptions, both in the medium and the  long-term. In fact, our long-term price assumption is below US$400 per tonne. This does not mean we are bearish  on the long-term prospect of the potash business.

file: SDF - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 11August2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Let's take a look at the highlights of a really challenging quarter on slide two, please. We pre-released our Q2  result estimate on June 27 as the quarterly EBIT was significantly below the previous year and certainly below  what was expected. We regret that this caused trouble in many ways, but it was unavoidable; and why? Alongside  developments like the significantly lower average selling price in potash and the low activity in salt because of the  mild winter, there was an unforeseeable factor. In the second half of June, it became clearer that we face more  production [ph] still stands (01:31) because of the dry weather in the Werra Valley than anticipated.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: This alone cost us around €60 million in the second quarter. Three weeks ago there was an incident at our  Legacy site. During hydro testing, a crystallizer dropped. Of course, this is not insignificant; but from today's point  of view, it will not have a material impact. I will come back to that later. Finally, we expect an EBIT I range  between €200 million and €300 million for 2016.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Please turn to slide four. As I said earlier, during hydro testing for pre-commissioning on July 17, one of five [ph]  ECC (03:08) crystallizers fell. Of course, the most important point is that nobody was injured. Together with our  partners, we are currently undertaking extensive efforts to fix and evaluate the damage. What does that mean; we  can continue the gradual commissioning of the other parts of the plant. From today's point of view, production of  the first ton will be postponed into Q2, 2017. The expected 2017 production volume of up to 1 million tons will not  be achieved. No doubt this incident is serious. But the most important milestone seems not to be at risk from  today's point of view. We expect to reach a production capacity of 2 million tons per year by the end of 2017.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Now, please move to slide five. Saline waste water disposal remains a challenge. There is an ongoing review of  the application submitted by us in April 2015 regarding the continuation of deep-well injection until the end of  2021. Since the beginning of the year, production has been largely based on water flow in the Werra River. In  other words, our ability to fully produce remains highly dependent on the amount of rainfall unless the new permit  will be granted. To be very frank, the third quarter is usually drier than the second quarter and the effect from an  absent permit may hurt us even more in the current quarter.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Now, please move to slide six. The current situation is difficult but not without hope. We are working on measures  that will help us to mitigate the effect from the missing deep-well injection. The possible measures range from  additional storage in owned and third-party premises to various smaller measures. We are currently working on  implementing those requiring minimal efforts and are in talks with relevant authorities to get the necessary permits  for the others.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Beyond 2017, the situation will ease significantly, as you will then have the so-called KCF plant up and running.  This new facility will recycle [indiscernible] (05:42) from the production. This will help reduce saline waste water  and even deliver additional marketable products. Nevertheless, obtaining a new deep-well injection permit  remains crucial for dealing with salt water, especially in very dry period.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Looking at magnesium sulphate product, they are unaffected from the potash price decline at all. And this brings  us to slide eight. In Q2, we were also active in M&A. By acquiring the fertilizer assets of a Chinese producer of  synthetic magnesium sulphate, Magpower, we made an important step in expanding into Asia and strengthening  our position in specialties.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Synthetic magnesium sulphate is used as a fertilizer for oil palms, soybeans and sugarcane as well as for  industrial applications. Magpower will complement the existing K+S kieserite production by adding highly active  effective water soluble magnesium sulphate through scalable low cost production and further expand our global  coverage.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Now, please move to slide nine. Let's switch to our salt operation. After a mild winter leading to high inventories in  North America and Europe, de-icing volumes and prices are down year-on-year. A significant portion of North  American bidding is now behind us, and what we have seen in Q2 can also be applied to the remainder of 2016.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Slide 10, please. In line with our company's strategy of growth in the Salt business, we have added another  component to our Salt 2020 strategy. With the purchase of mining licenses in Western Australia, we are looking to  expand our Salt business into Asia. The project is still at a very early stage and we are currently preparing the  required documents to apply it for the necessary permit. We expect that production capacity will be 3.5 million  tons with a possible production start in 2022. CapEx is estimated at around €225 million. The salt produced in  Australia will be mainly supplied to the chemical industry in Asia, particularly to China.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Now let's come to our outlook for 2016 on slide 11. The business unit Salt may face tangible decline in earnings  due to the mild winter. The decline in potash prices remains the biggest factor. We believe in higher prices in the  long-term, but tend to remain cautious for this year. The second big factor is the situation at the Werra. Amongst  other things, we resume a normal year in terms of price fall for the rest of the year and that our counter measures  will help us to reduce the impact from the missing deep-well injection permits. If and when we receive a new  permit will impact our cost and expected sales volumes. Currently, we calculate with 6.2 million tons to 6.4 million  tons.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Of course, when we created the €1.6 billion goal, we were in a better potash environment. For example, the MOP  price we used for the granulated product in Brazil was slightly above $300 per ton. But we always we maintained  to believe that the current potash market situation is not sustainable. We expect to see the bottom this year and  believe that we will experience positive impact from the announced production cuts in the industry.

file: SDF - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 15August2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: And now, let's get started, on page 3. I'm very proud to announce that we have the first potash volume from our  new Bethune mine in our hands and even two weeks earlier than we expected. Many of our colleagues have  been working very hard on this. Now, the first trains have started to Vancouver.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: We do expect about 600,000 tonnes production in 2017, which is mainly back-end loaders. We have reached our  capacity of 2 million tonnes annual run rate by the end of this year.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: Here we want to repeat, due to our low fixed cost basis at Bethune, we have the flexibility to adjust production for  the very first time. That means we are not flooding the market with additional potash, if it cannot be used. Please  also keep in mind that Bethune is partly replacing our depleting capacities, for instance, our Sigmundshall mine,  which is to be closed by 2020 at the very latest.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: Now please turn to slide 4 and let us have a look at the situation at our Werra plant. Last year, we were hit hard  by low water levels and missing permits, this has turned positive in 2017. After 25 days of production outages, we  did not have to put production on hold, with regards to waste water disposal in the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: As we made good progress with our countermeasures and also the expansion of basin capacities helped a lot.  However, further production limitation in long period of low water levels in the river, Werra, as we have seen in the  first quarter, cannot be ruled out for the rest of the year. That means production cannot yet run at full capacity in  2017.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: This will change 2018. We are making good progress with our new KCF facility. The start is scheduled for early  2018 and we continue to expect a reduction of saline wastewater by 1.5 million cubic meters on a full year basis.  This will help us to secure production to a larger extent and will make us much more independent of water level.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: Meanwhile, the expansion of tailings pile capacity at Hattorf remains challenging. We are working on a solution  along with the regulator. At the same time, we are optimizing the capacity of the existing tailings pile. The  important message is we believe to solve the issue without further standstills in Hattorf.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: For the remainder of the year, we expect our average selling price in potash and magnesium products to move up  slightly on last year's achievement.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: In Q2, we built up some inventory on a generally low level. Unfortunately, we had to cover some small hiccups.  Production fell a bit short on our potential due to some logistic problems at our rail partner in Germany on the  back of stormy weather. In addition, we had hot weather and high temperatures in Germany in June resulting in a  short suspension of production at our Werra plant.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: Our guidance is based on the assumption that the overall product availability in the Potash and Magnesium  Products business unit will be significantly up from last year. We expect normal weather and water conditions for  the rest of the year and, again, a successful execution of our countermeasure to reduce the disposal of saline  wastewater into the river Werra.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: In total, we expect Potash sales in the range of 6.8 million tonnes to 7.2 million tonnes. On top of the volume  increase, we would not be surprised to see a slightly higher average selling price for Potash and Magnesium  Products compared to last year's level.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: On the other hand, the start of our production in Canada will burden our EBIT by about an additional €60 million  compared to 2016. We thought we expect a moderate increase in volume by selling prices, but selling prices are  soft as a result of the mild winter season at the beginning of this year. The upper and lower end of our guided  EBIT I range are determined on the still ongoing ramp-up of Bethune, uncertainties about the weather conditions  and the water levels at our Werra site. Furthermore, our guidance is based on normalized winter conditions and  the 10-year average.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: Finally, in 2018, our new KCF facility will help us to reduce the volume of saline wastewater by 1.5 million cubic  meters per year. This means that we will diminish the risk of production standstills, significantly another huge  tailwind and the KCF delivers additional specialty volume. At the same time, our investments will come down  significantly in 2018 and we expect our adjusted free cash flow to turn positive. 2018 will therefore be the year  when we will start reducing our financial debt and strengthen our balance sheet again.

file: SDF - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 14August2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Now, let's start with a highlight on the second quarter on slide 3. When we are talking about the second quarter  2018, the emphasis is that the market conditions remain supportive and that is very important. On the back of  higher volumes from Bethune, increasing potash prices and potash salt demand, our revenues and EBITDA rose  compared to last year.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: However, Bethune is still in a ramp up mode and what does that mean? Please turn to slide 6. While K2O content  is excellent and that is very important, and our Canadian team is doing a great job. We still have to be aware that  we are ramping up the first greenfield mine in Saskatchewan in 40 years. This also includes a learning process on  production, processing, and shipping.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: The Werra site in Unterbreizbach is currently suffering from extraordinary low nutrient content as a result of  crossing a field with lower quality. This will be resolved by the end of 2019. And finally, our site in Neuhof has lost  about 50,000 tonnes of production in the second quarter on the back of lower roof stability. We have implemented  additional safety measures and expect production to start to improve in the third quarter of 2018. However, lower  nutrient content in Germany is not improving.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Please turn to slide 8. In Germany, we are operating mature potash mines and the overall K2O content is  diminishing. Compared to 2017, the annualized impact in 2018 will be about 100,000 tonnes. However, this trend  is not coming as a complete surprise and we have talked about it several times. And together with our consultant  McKinsey which is very experienced in this field, we are currently evaluating countermeasures. This program  called operational excellence has started with a site-by-site investigation and today, we have already identified  many opportunities to increase the efficiency across all sites.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Next year, after the closure of Sigmundshall, with an annual production of about 600,000 tonnes, we scheduled a  German production of about 6.1 million tonnes to 6.2 million tonnes. This number includes an improvement on the  back of the above discussed measures of about 300,000 tonnes to the German production. Bethune should add  1.7 to 1.9 million tonnes including about 100,000 to 200,000 tonnes of low-cost secondary mining and supporting  our target to reach breakeven on an EBIT level. All in all, our Operational Excellence program is in favor of  compensating the declining nutrient content in Germany after 2020.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Some of you seem to wonder about the expectations of our average selling price in the Potash and Magnesium  division for 2018. Please turn to slide 11. For our Potash and Magnesium division, we expect this year's average  selling price to be up slightly over 2017. While we agree on market expectations on the overall potash price  development, we also have to take into consideration that our product and regional mix is reflecting the production  starts of the two. Compared to our specialty, MOP is lower priced and an increasing part of business with  customers in China and Southeast Asia is also having an impact on our reported ASP. Finally, the weather is also  having an impact on our current earnings.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Please turn to slide 12. This year's record summer in Germany is stretching our logistics mainly at the Werra site.  The good news is that so far we have not been faced with any standstills related to the water level of the Werra.  The KCF is full up and running and reducing the salty wastewater by 20%. Furthermore, our additional measures  we implemented last year are also quite supportive. The entire team is doing a great job.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: On the other hand, inland shipping capacities are short and freight rates are increasing. All in all, the extreme  weather situation is causing additional logistics costs, which we expect to impact this year's profitability by about  €20 million. Finally, it is still too early to get a feeling for the impact on farmers' yield and the implications for our  business.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: What is our appraisal of the current situation? Please turn to slide 13. First of all, we are pretty sure that the  problems now have been discovered and addressed. However, we have to admit that our challenges are holding  us back somewhat longer than previously expected. Nevertheless, the entire management team has started  working on the list and the bottom-up findings of our Shaping 2030 program on efficiency and cost effects will be  supportive in reaching our target.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: One of the moving parts of our EBITDA guidance for 2018, please turn to slide 14. This year's EBITDA will be  burdened by the topics we have just discussed. However, it will also be supported by higher potash volumes and  prices. Profits from Bethune are increasing and EBITDA is scheduled to be positive in 2018. However, currency,  higher logistics cost and the discussed production issues remain challenging. As said earlier, in 2018, we do  expect some costs related to our new Shaping 2030 strategy, which should turn into net savings already next  year.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, there are many goals in the year. Bethune is the first greenfield potash mine for 40 years,  and the Sigmundshall closure, a mine that ran more than 100 years, is also weighing on the organization.  Furthermore, the Shaping 2030 related reorganization is demanding and requesting the utmost of all our  colleagues. Please note that this is the first time ever that K+S is facing with such an intense cost-cutting and  efficiency program.

file: SDF - Q3 2010 Earnings Call 11November2010 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Nov-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: There are three main reasons for – from our point of view for this. First, the takeover bit of the  mining group BHP Billiton and for PotashCorp, which reminded market participants of the long-term  attractiveness of the potash market. Secondly, the surge in weed and other agricultural commodity  prices which led to a recent tightness in potash markets and the thus announced price increases.  And last but not least, the continuous and attractive earnings contributions right from the start of  Morton Salt underscored by the well balanced strategy of potash and salt.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So, let’s now take a closer look at the Q3 market trends now and I will flip to slide 2 directly. The  Fertilizers business sector, the third quarter of 2010 was characterized by higher normalizing  demand for fertilizers. As said, Potash Fertilizers ordered in the summer month by the trade sector  in the northern hemisphere were used by farmers for autumn fertilizing at the almost normal level  again. A relatively high level of capacity utilization at most potash producers and significantly  declining stocks led to price announcements from competitors for the Asian markets of U.S. $420  per ton for granulated potash. Brazilian market prices were announced between 410 and 420 per  ton of granulated potash. And in mid-September, we announced a price increase by €12 to €317  per ton, once again for granular potash in Europe, which is therefore very similar to overseas’ level.  The positive strength and demand for straight nitrogen and complex fertilizers also persisted, and  prices rose significantly against the backdrop of higher input costs.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Salt. European tenders for de-icing salt were predominantly concluded by tangibly higher prices,  after the persistent wintry weather conditions at the start of the year. European production facilities  operated at full capacity in the third quarter.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the United States, we saw moderate price declines at lower contract volumes due to still  relatively high stocks, as a result of the previous mild winter in some regions, and increased  competitive pressure on the East Coast. The consumption of water softening salts in the area of  industrial salt was still lower, because of a difficult economic environment in North America.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Nitrogen Fertilizers revenues rose by 50% to €306 million. Operating earnings in the segment  reached €2.6 million in Q3, after a negative €47 million in the same quarter last year. The business  segment profited from higher sales volumes as well as from a tangible increase in fertilizer prices in  all product groups.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 3 Now I would like to turn to the Q3 developments and future trends in the Potash and Magnesium  business segment, slide number seven.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In 2010, global potash sales volume forecast ranges between 52 and 53 million tons, compared to  our previous estimate of 50 million tons. For 2011, we expect worldwide potash sales volume to  range between 55 and 60 million tons, previously we had 53 to 57 million tons. Please note that our  autumn is usually approximately 2 million tons higher than those given by competitors, as we  include SOP and other low-grade potash specialties.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Starting from a described sales volume level in 2011, long-term growth rates are expected at 3 to  5% per annum again. This would result in utilization levels of about 85% annually until 2014. This is  again a good level, especially if you consider the risk that announced new capacities could be  postponed or even cancelled due to technological, geological challenges or due to an adequate  price level. The industry’s production forecast is now fully dependent on the timely fulfillment of  brown field projects.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now I would like to take a closer look at the historic and recent volume and price development of  the salt business. And therefore, please turn to slide number 12.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The 22 million tons we have lifted our outlook for the salt business segment in our expectation for  the end of 2010 to the upper end of our original sales volume forecast of 21 to 22 million tons. 30  million tons out of this will be de-icing salt. In our outlook for 2011, we assume sales volumes of 21  million again, based on the long-term average of historical icing salt volumes. 12 million out of this  might be de-icing salt.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Nevertheless, the EBITDA margin of our salt business segment is developing very effectually, as  can be seen on the following slide. That shows that even in the mild winter Morton Salt is capable  of achieving an attractive EBITDA margin of 23%. This is remarkable as the former salt business  application of the K+S Group achieved indeed the same EBITDA margins as on the back and  above average de-icing salt business. With Morton Salt K+S’ Salt business is therefore much better  positioned to mitigate the former risk of volatile de-icing results.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Business space. On a specific sales volumes, guidance between 6.7 and 6.9 million tons in the  Potash and Magnesium Products segment and the assumption of a stable average price in the  fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the Salt business, there should be a consolidation effect of a good €600 million of revenues due  to the first time inclusion of Morton Salt for the whole year. The total we asserted of about 22 million  tons of salt products should be sold. 13 million tons out of this can be allotted to de-icing salt,  assuming the well-known average de-icing salt business in Q4 2010. This altogether should result  in significantly higher group operating earnings of between €630 and €670 million compared to the  €550 to €600 million previously forecasted and €238 million last year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Finally, some initial indications for 2011. In the Potash and Magnesium Products business  segments, we expect to achieve the tangible life in revenues, going ahead with significant growth in  operating earnings. This was based on a moderate increase in sales volumes to just over 7 million  tons and on the basis international potash prices attained at the present time, the moderate rise  and average prices.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: With regard to our volume guidance, we would like to highlight the following. Since our portfolio  comprises of broad variety of specialties with different nutrient compositions, the maximum  production capability depends on the envisaged product mix and formulas. As you want to further  optimize our product portfolio going forward by ceasing production to lower margin products – by  ceasing production of lower-margin products, our mid-term capacity figure will reduce. This and for  the mining companies – this for mining companies is usual and gradual decline in all grades will  lead to the decrease of our maximum production capacity from approximately 7.8 to approximately  7.5 million tons.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: For the year 2011, our forecast of slightly above 7 million tons is furthermore affected by the  following two reasons: first, the recovery of the global potash markets came on the back of  significantly higher grain prices earlier and to a higher decrease than expected. Therefore, we are  actively seeking to employ new miners in order to reach our maximum production capacity. This  process will take time for hiring and training. Second, to start off the environmental program at the  Werra sites will force us to adjust our existing production processes, and will tie up our manpower  to some degree. Due to that, we foresee in addition to our usual two weeks maintenance shutdown  period, one further week being necessary at the Werra plants. This brings me now to next year’s  outlook for the fertilizer, Nitrogen Fertilizers business segment which is expected to slightly  increase revenues but tangibly grow operating earnings due to a moderate relief on the cost side.

file: SDF - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 10November2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Nov-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: As planned, capital expenditure increased compared to the previous year. The increase was, amongst others,  attributable to the replacement of the ship in Chile, investment in the Legacy project and the package of measures  on water protection in the Hesse-Thuringia potash district.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Slide number four, the performance of the Fertilizer conditions and in particular, the Potash and Magnesium  products business segment was clearly standing out while the Salt business segment suffered amongst others from  one-off issues during third quarter.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Potash and Magnesium product revenues rose by 20% to €5.9 million due to significantly higher average prices  for Potash and Magnesium products, as costs were even slightly lower. EBIT I has more than doubled.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Nitrogen Fertilizer revenues rose by 34% to €321 million due to positive price factors. Operating earnings in this  segment reached €17 million after €12 million the same year and the same quarter last year. Here, it was possible  to more than make up for higher input costs.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: The Salt business delivered stable revenues during the low season for de-icing salt. That increases compensated  negative currencies. Third quarter operating earnings amounted to €13 million, after there were, among others,  burdened by weather-related production loss in the Bahamas and higher costs for demurrage charges due to the  maintenance of one of our two port facilities in Chile.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Let's now move on to the Fertilizer business sector in more detail, slide number six. The Fertilizer business sector  saw a strong demand in the third quarter, which has been supported by an attractive level of agricultural prices  that provided a significant incentive for farmers worldwide to raise yields per hectare through a need-base use of  fertilizer. Of those, Potash and Magnesium Products, as well as Nitrogen Fertilizers due to utilization of  production capacities throughout the day, has been very high.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: This environment lets Potash producers to ask for higher prices. At the beginning of August, suppliers agreed  contracts with Indian importers at significantly higher prices until the end of the first quarter 2012. Furthermore,  BPC announced price increases in Asia to $535 MOP and up to $580 per tonne for granular MOP in Latin  America. Last but not least, an increase of €12 to €375 per tonne in Europe was announced by K+S.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: On slide number seven, we come to the global potash demand and supply outlook. As usual, in November we have  specified our outlook also for the year 2012. For this year 2011, we confirm our forecast of the global potash sales  volume between 58 million and 60 million tonnes. For 2012, we are assuming a number of at least 60 million  tonnes, providing for a rather high utilization of installed capacity. Please note that our numbers usually differ by  2 million to 3 million tonnes to those used by our peer group since we include potash facilities as well.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: The current grain price levels long-term growth rates are still expected to range between 3% and 5% per year.  Based on IFA data and announced capacity expansions, utilization rates are estimated to slightly decrease over the  next couple of years. But the track record for former forecasts shows that the longer a forecast survives it comes  along with a reduced forecast quality, especially with the future world potash supply increasingly depending on  the realization of capital-intensive greenfield projects.  As always, the following table on slide number eight should only be understood as provided with what indication  of how prices have developed. Factors like freight cost, exchange rates and product mix usually distorts this  picture.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Slide number 10, the breakdown of selected cost types shows that we expect energy costs to rise significantly in  2011. Material costs should increase tangibly, while personnel, freight cost and depreciation are estimated to grow  only moderately.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: As sales volumes are forecasted on a stable level, we assume total unit costs in the range between €200 and €205  for the year 2011. For 2012, energy costs are most likely to continue to rise significantly. Please keep in mind that  as a result of energy supply sources, changes in energy prices are often only reflected in our cost accounting with a  delay of six to nine months.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Furthermore, personnel costs should rise tangibly due to an increase in personnel for the activities in the area of  environmental protection as well as additional costs arising from pay settlements.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Now, let's please move over to our Salt business. Slide number 12. In the Western European pre-stocking business  of de-icing salt, the above-average wintry weather conditions in the last two seasons led to continued high pre- stocking demand for de-icing salt in third quarter, too. The price level has risen tangibly for the winter season, '11  to '12.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: In local tenders at the U.S. East Coast, moderate price declines occurred as a result of lower freight rates for salt  imports. In the other, for K+S, relevant de-icing salt regions of the United States and in Canada too, the pre- stocking demand for de-icing salt improved in the third quarter in comparison to the previous year.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Earnings were significantly lower due to weather-related production losses on the Bahamas, higher costs for  demurrage charges due to the maintenance of our terminal in Chile, negative currency effects as well as higher  maintenance and packaging costs in North America.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Finally, I would like to give a short update on our Legacy project and provide you with our current outlook for the  year 2011 and 2012. First of all, this is shown on slide number 16, a short update on our Legacy project in Canada.  The review and customization of the feasibility study of Potash One is progressing according to plan. At the same  time, construction work for water connection, site preparation, roads, and drilling preparations are being done.  CapEx of almost €40 million can therefore be expected for these measures in 2011.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: This is based on a stable sales volume of about seven million tonnes in the Potash and Magnesium Products  business segment and a significant rise in average prices, based, and this is important, on the currently set and  achieved products for potash price level, the similarly positive development we see in the Nitrogen business.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: And the Salt business, the total of the good 23 million tonnes of salt products should be sold. Assuming an average  de-icing salt business in the fourth quarter in 2011, about 14 million tonnes out of this can be allotted to the de- icing salt, which is largely dependent on economic cycles.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: In the Potash and Magnesium products business segments, we expect to achieve a tangible rise in revenues with a  slight growth in operating earnings. This is based on sales volumes of about 7 million tonnes and once again, on  the basis of the international potash prices set and maintained at the present time, the tangible rise in average  prices.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: In the Nitrogen Fertilizer business segment, we expect revenues and earnings to remain largely stable in the  upcoming year. While in Salt, a somewhat lower average sales volume of crystallized salt of about 22 million  tonnes should lead to a moderate decrease in revenues. Along with the lower capacity utilization, operating  earnings will decline significantly to a normal level of between €175 million and €190 million EBIT 1.

file: SDF - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 13November2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Nov-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Let's now move on to the Potash and Magnesium Products business segment in more detail, and slide number  four provides, as always, a general view on the environment of the markets we are active on. After there was  cautious early stocking-up of fertilizers at the start of the year, the demand for potash and magnesium products  developed positively during the second quarter of 2012.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: As can be seen from the graphs on slide number six, revenues reached €561 million in the third quarter of 2012  and was up above the figure of the previous year. Operating earnings EBIT I decreased by 7% to €159 million.  Currency and volume-related revenue increases could not completely make up for increased energy costs, higher  freight costs, costs related to the Legacy Project, as well as the negative currency result and the effect of a  reduction in inventories.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: As expected, unit costs increased tangibly to €238 in the quarter compared to €210 one year ago; especially  energy costs had an effect, as they still were impacted by the old energy supply contracts. Therefore, with the time  – with that time lag of six to nine months, last year's oil price increases still influence our cost accounting.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Now, let's move on to our Salt business and on slide – and we continue to slide number eight. In the third quarter,  it was not possible to achieve the very high level of the early stocking-up business of the previous year in Europe,  as a result of the mild and dry weather conditions at the beginning of this year. However, the creation of  additional storage capacities of on customer side ensured average earlier stocking-up volume. Due to the high  stock levels, prices fell slightly during the early stocking-up season and in the tenders for the winter season  2012/2013. By contrast, the contract volumes for the upcoming season stood at a good level.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Year-on-year, de-icing salt volumes were 240,000 tons lower due to the weaker early pre-season in all our de- icing salt regions. As a consequence, the average price level declined. In the non de-icing salt product groups,  volumes slightly decreased; an improved product mix and a positive exchange rate effect as well as some price  increases led to a higher average price.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Quarter-on-quarter, following the normal seasonal patterns, de-icing salt volumes increased due to early season  procurement. De-icing salt average prices improved due to a change in the product mix. Here, the bigger portion  of higher priced packaged de-icing salt relative to by-products had a positive impact on the average price. Volumes  on the other product groups decreased mainly in overseas markets, but prices increased due to regional product  mix effects.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, K+S AG
texts.text: I also would like to highlight the effect of earnings after taxes from discontinued operations, which are only  included on an after-tax level. After the closing of the sale of K+S Nitrogen on the 2 of July, €66 million of  earnings from the divestment were booked in the third quarter. This figure was almost €10 million higher than  expected.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: While demand continued to be at a good level on the markets relevant for K+S, price negotiations in these regions  became increasingly difficult due to the missing contracts in China and India. For 2012 as a whole, we now expect  global potash sales volumes of about 54 million tons. Please note that this forecast in contrast to our peers  includes potassium sulfate and other potash specialties of around 3 million tons.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Salt; as a result of the exceptionally mild weather conditions at the start of the year, the demand for de-icing salt  in Europe as well as in North America should decline accordingly in 2012 compared to the above-average year  2011. For 2013, we are assuming sales volumes to be on its multi-year average level both in the North American  and in the European markets.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: After demand was below average due to the mild weather conditions at the start of the year 2012, the sales  volumes of de-icing salt in 2013 should increase again accordingly. However, prices for tenders for the winter  season 2012/2013 are overall slightly below the level of the last season with regional differences.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: This means revenues of a good €3.9 billion and operating earnings EBIT I of about €820 million. The outlook is  based on sales volumes of 6.9 million tons in the Potash and Magnesium Products business segment and a  moderate rise in average prices. As always, we apply our customary and technical forecast policy, which maintains  the currently achieved potash price level unchanged for the rest of the year 2012.  On this assumption, revenues in the Potash and Magnesium Products business segment should increase  moderately. Due to a strong rise in energy costs, costs connected with the Legacy Project and the negative effect  from the foreign currency result compared to the previous year, we expect stable operating earnings in the Potash  and Magnesium Products business segment.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Taking into consideration the discontinued operations with the higher than initially expected income from the  divestment of K+S Nitrogen, we assume adjusted Group earnings after taxes of about €630 million; a value at the  lower end of the range of €630 million to €690 million given in August. This would correspond to adjusted  earnings per share of about €3.30.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: In the Potash and Magnesium Products business segment, we assume slightly weaker operating earnings. In the  Salt business segment on the basis of again normal winter business that follows the long-term average of de-icing  salt volumes, we are anticipating strongly increasing earnings in comparison to the probably below-average figure  in 2012. Following the already mentioned dividend policy, the dividend for the business year 2013 will decline as  Group earnings will no longer benefit from the effects of the divestment of K+S Nitrogen.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: In the Salt business unit, there was also a significant decrease in receivables and a significantly higher reduction in  inventories due to the above-average wind-free weather conditions in the first quarter, particularly in Europe.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Cash flow from investing activities increased as planned due to higher capital expenditures, especially in  connection with a package of measures for water protection and the legacy projects.
