texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Looking at our volumes and average prices on slide seven. We saw sales volumes in the Potash and Magnesium  Product business unit in Q3 of 1.63 million tonnes, which were somewhat down year -on-year. This could lead to  the impression that Europe underperformed in this quarter, which was definitely not the case. The decline can be  well explained by the strong first half in that region.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Slide eight provides an overview of the quarterly cost position in the Potash and Magnesium Products business  unit. In the third quarter, unit costs decreased to €215 per tonne and we're about 10% lower in a year-on-year  comparison. Lower energy cost, decreased volume-related freight costs and favorable currency effects resulted in  an improvement. The quarter-on-quarter increase is totally due to the lower volumes in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Average price for non-de-icing salt came down mainly to the regional mix in food grade salt. Since we had lower  sales in higher-margin regions, in addition to higher sales volumes of lower-priced by-product in industrial salt  applications contributed to the decline.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Efficiency improvement programs, selected projects seen on slide 13 are part of our DNA and have already been  started. We have now bundled all initiatives in the Fit for the Future program.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: In order to harvest the fruits from that program as quickly as possible, we will initiate cost savings resulting to a  good €150 million already in 2014. This will be reached by a combination of short-term measures and first  structural changes. From 2016, we want to be able to implement the planned cost savings in full by sustainable  measures. All parts of the group will contribute to the success of the program.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: In order to give you a rough indication, we expect that Potash and Magnesium Products business unit to deliver  more than half of the expected total savings, both in the mid-term and next year. Salt should contribute one third  and the remainder should come from the complementary activities, our holding and from IT.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: To be very clear on this point, Fit for the Future is a challenging program. The percentages mentioned shall give  you a rough indication about what we are aiming at. Internally, we need to go very much more int o detail, but we  will always exchange a measure against another one should we find the latter one better suited. Having said this,  as an example, we ask for your understanding that we will not disclose any further monetary details and that we  reserve all rights to shift saving measures between the respective units.

texts.speaker: Norbert Steiner
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: An important step to make K+S an even stronger player in this field, very attractive potash market, which is  also  our legacy project, which is from an operational point of view well underway.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: In total, we are now expecting world potash sales of 56 million tonnes compared to 59 million tonnes before in  2013. As you know, our forecast always include about 3 million tonnes of fertilizer specialties. Regarding the de - icing salt business, we assume, as usual, multi-year average sales volumes for de-icing salt over the remaining  months of the year.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Taking into account the de-icing salt business for the first quarter of the year, as well as the good early stocking-up  business in the second and third quarter, this results in the expectation of significantly higher sales volumes,  especially after demand in 2012 was below average due to the mild weather conditions at the start of the year.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: In the food grade salt segment, the demand in both Europe and North America should largely remain stable in  2013, while salt consumption in Asia for the chemical industry continues to grow considerably.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: What does that mean for K+S? Our assessment for 2013 as a whole is largely based on the following assumptions,  as you can see on slide 19. Sales volumes for Potash and Magnesium Products of about 6.8 million tonnes and, of  course, tangibly reduced average prices. In the salt business unit, we expect volumes of a good 22 million tonnes  in total, of which de-icing salt should contribute a good 13 million tonnes.

file: SDF - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 13November2014 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Now please turn to slide six. Alongside the market development, the good performance of the business unit Potash  and Magnesium Product was driven by high cost discipline. As expected, costs per tonne were above the average  of the first six months. However, we made further progress in comparison to Q3 last year.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: In addition to lower material and energy costs, we have also achieved structural savings on the logistics side. For  example, we are now bundling more shipments for overseas deliveries of industrial potash at our terminal in  Hamburg. This reduces lease costs for storage facilities at other ports and complexity in the network. And as you  can see, excluding the increase in OpEx for the Legacy Project, the progress is becoming even more visible.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, let's conclude with our guidance for the full year 2014 on slide nine. We have upgraded our  expectations for the full year EBIT I to a range of €580 million to €640 million. While K+S sales volumes in  Potash and Magnesium Product should come in at the levels of the previous year, recent demand patterns should  have a positive effect on global sales volumes. We are now also more positive regarding our average selling prices  for the business units. In addition, our colleagues are doing their utmost to keep costs under control.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: The biggest swing factor to reach either end of the range is our Salt business. We have always factored in long - term average volumes to forecast the remainder of the year. But it clearly depends on actual demand in the  various regions, whether or not we will see an average winter or one of the other extremes.

file: SDF - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 11November2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Slide seven please. The main reasons for the decline in EBIT were higher depreciation and increase in Legacy  OpEx as planned and the missing contribution from the insurance payment. In addition, we had lower sales  volumes during the quarter. Hot weather and high temperatures in Germany in August and September resulted in  the suspension of production at our Werra plant. Adjusted for all these effects, Q3 EBIT development was very  robust.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Especially the lower volumes and the higher depreciation impacted costs per ton. In addition, Q3 is typically a  quarter where we do a lot of maintenance work. This inflates costs especially compared to the first half of the year.  Ladies and gentlemen, what does that all mean for our 2015 volume and cost guidance? Due to the current weak  demand in potash market, we no longer expect to make up for the lost volumes in the remainder of the year. This  also means that due to lower volumes, we will not be able to reach our targeted costs per ton at the 2013 level.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Now, please turn to the Legacy Project update on slide eight. The development of our flagship project is still on  time and on budget. We have spent about 70% of the CapEx allocated to the project. All main contracts with  suppliers have now been signed, which means we have further reduced project risk. We are still very confident  that the site will be commissioned in summer 2016, while still remaining in line with the allocated budget of  CAD4.1 billion. More details on our Legacy Project will be presented tomorrow during our Capital Markets Day at  Merkers, which will also be webcast.

file: SDF - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 10November2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: This also had an adverse effect on our product mix as our specialties are mainly produced at the Werra site.  Subsequently, the ever selling price of our business unit, Potash and Magnesium Products declines year-on-year  and quarter-over-quarter.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Slide 6 please, Legacy remains our flagship project. Despite the incident in July, we are continuing to commission  pads that were not affected. We have one of the biggest available cranes in Canada onsite and have started with  the removal of damaged equipment. We expect production to start in the second quarter of next year. This should  give us the ability to produce up to 700,000 tonnes of MOP next year and we will reach the 2 million tonnes  capacity by the end of 2017 as planned.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Now, please move to the slide 7, we have already highlighted the limited deep well injection permit as it has left a  severe mark on our numbers. What we can say from today's point of view is that the revenue process is ongoing.  Production remains challenging as we are dependent on the weather to a large extent. We are still confident that  we will still find the solution in the near future, but from today's point of view, we can neither predict the outcome  nor the timing.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Our roadmap shows what is on the horizon in the coming years. For example, the application to expand the tailing  pile captivity in Hattorf, also part of the Werra plant is already underway. Also the construction of the K+S facility  is making progress. This will help us to reduce salt water [ph] revenues (06:57) by around 20% from 2018 on.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: The main reason for the cut is our Potash business. The previous upper end of €300 million for the group assume  a new deep well injection permit in Q4, which we don't have yet. Counter measures are making good progress,  however, the missing permit is expected to cost at around €200 million this year.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, K+S AG
texts.text: Now please move to slide 9 and let me conclude my presentation with our 2020 goal. Our Salt 2020 strategy is  well on track to delivering an EBITDA of more than €400 million by then. Also, Legacy will contribute positively.  Today, potash prices makes the target very ambitious, however, we still believe this low pricing environment is not  sustainable. On top of that, our business units are working on strategic initiatives that will support our goal of €1.6  billion EBITDA by 2020. Everybody within the K+S group is very committed to delivering, irrespective of the  challenges we are facing right now.

file: SDF - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 15November2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: On slide 5, we will give you an update on regulatory and environmental affair. We have already spent a lot of time  and effort to improve our environmental standard and we have achieved a lot. After we had received our permit  for deep-well injections at the end of 2016, we immediately started to implement additional measures to limit our  outage days. Instead of the 55 days expected at the beginning of 2017, we are now optimistic to have no  additional outage days in addition to the 25 reported in Q1.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: With the ramp-up of our KCF in 2018, we will further reduce the saline wastewater by 1.5 million cubic meters or  20%. We have commissioned an external advisor to carry out a concept for extracting additional products from  saline wastewater. And last but not least, we have just recently, more precisely, last Thursday, been granted the  approval for early commencement for the needed expansion of our tailings pile in Hattorf. This project remains on  schedule. This is an important milestone for us.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: Finally – and I had the chance to discuss that already with many of you on our last roadshow – I have amended  the way to handle our pending approval procedures and ongoing disputes. It's my aim to settle the most important  topics on that list sooner than later. And as you might have already seen in the last news flow, we are on the right  track to get it done. It is very important to secure our license to operate and to avoid further shortfalls as in 2016  and Q1 of this year. Moreover, we are on track to set our long lasting discussion with the German environmental  organization BUND and Gerstungen, the township in Thuringia about our deep-well injection practice.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: Our guidance is based on a normal winter and no additional outage day for the remainder of the year. The  potentially positive impact from having only 25 outage days versus our previous guidance of up to 55 days will be  compensated by lower volume mainly from Bethune. 500,000 tonnes will be the production at the end of this year  instead of the earlier guided annual production of 600,000 to 700,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors, K+S AG
texts.text: Having said this, let's move on to slide 8 and an update on Shaping 2030. At the beginning of October, we  published our new Shaping 2030 strategy. Let's recap the most important point. We remained convinced  especially after intense discussions with our shareholders and [ph] sales sites (10:54) and others, that our one- company approach is the best way to generate long-term value for all stakeholders. We see significant upside  potential in our earnings and profitability when thinking and acting as one company. Currently, the focus of our  daily work is dedicated to Phase 1 of realizing synergies of at least €150 million by 2020, and reducing our  indebtedness by 2023, we aim to achieve an investment grade rating again. It is of utmost importance to regain  financial strength in Phase 1 before we are able to start Phase 2.

file: SDF - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 15November2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: In salt, the North American de-icing business benefited from a strong pre-stocking. Compared to last year, we  increased the volume of de-icing salt by more than 500,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: However, this overall positive development was overshadowed by the severe and ongoing drought in Germany.  We stopped production of two of our three Werra sites, which resulted in more than 50 outage days. Moreover,  we were forced to use additional shipment of saline wastewaters for offsite disposal. And the unusual low water  level increased freight rates substantially. All in All, the potash division had to absorb a weather-related burden of  about €80 million.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Let us have a closer look at the market conditions in our potash and salt businesses on slide 4. Overall, the  potash market remained supportive. Demand is solid and many producers are already fully committed into 2019,  which is also reflected in current pricing.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Bottom line, after the first nine months, potash prices have moved into the right direction. But, overall, rising cost  inflation [ph] need our attention. (00:04:32) For example, freight costs increased price-related by more than 5% in  the first nine months compared to last year. And even on a group level, we expect an increasing trend for the  quarters to come.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Looking at Bethune, we are able to increase production quarter-over-quarter. And this positive trend continued in  the fourth quarter as we reached in October a new production record. On top of that, the seasonally lower  temperatures helped to cool down our product easier. In addition, in Q4, we are going to install a temporary  grinder pump. Both effects should further increase our output. All in all, we took very high efforts to tackle our  production issues.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: On slide 6, we would like to talk about the very unusual weather situation here in Germany. Due to the severe  drought in Germany, we had to stop our Werra production at Wintershall and Hattorf in September. To improve  the situation, we have further expanded our basin capacities by more than 10% to about 600,000 cubic meters  and also stretched our logistics for off-site disposal to a new limit. Therefore, we are able to restart the production  by the end of September.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Just as a reminder, without the additional measures we have implemented already last year, we would have to  have stopped production back in June. And very important is the look into 2019. In 2019, we will further  significantly expand our capacity to store saline wastewater on-site, and that will make us even more robust next  half.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Nevertheless, water levels in Germany remain extraordinarily low. The rainfall has been seen so far in the final  quarters is clearly below the five-year average. Due to all our countermeasures, we have to now secure protection  to the beginning of December. Nevertheless, we cannot exclude additional outage days until the end of 2018.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: In any case, we do expect further extensive shipments of saline wastewater for off-site disposal in Q4. On top of  that, inland shipping is increasingly impacted by low water levels and causing overall higher logistic costs across  the group.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: And what does it all mean to our full-year 2018 guidance? And therefore, please turn to slide 7. Overall, demand  in potash remains robust, and we expect the positive impact on pricing on our full-year EBITDA, increasing  profitability of our Bethune mine and tangibly higher salt volumes will also help the situation. However, the  production issues at our German mines, FX development and shaping 2030-related costs will negatively affect  our full-year result. The outage days in Q3, extensive oxide disposal on the back of the ongoing drought, and  inflated logistics costs will reduce this year's EBITDA. We expect additional wastewater volume and related freight  rates having an impact of up to €20 million in Q4.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Bottom line, we are reducing our EBITDA guidance to €570 million to €630 million. This year's cash unit cost in  potash is now expected to be around €215 per tonne. Excluding the weather-related outages in Q3, we would  have been well in line with our previously guided range of €205 to €210 per tonne. Potential additional outage  days in December are not part of our full-year EBITDA guidance. The upper and lower end of our guided EBITDA  range is mainly determined by the weather situation in Q4 both for the de-icing business as well as for river water  levels and the implied logistics costs. The adjusted free cash flow should improve significantly compared to 2017  mainly on the back of lower CapEx.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Finally, let me give you a first rough idea about 2019, and therefore, if you move to slide 8. We have done our  homework with respect to our several production issues. From next year on, our operations excellence program  will further increase our productivity to stop the impact of declining K2O content in Germany beyond 2019.

texts.speaker: Burkhard Lohr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, K+S AG
texts.text: Bethune, we are making good progress to meet our 2019 guidance of 1.7 million to 1.9 million tonnes, an  increase of 300,000 to 500,000 tonnes. Altogether, 2019 should show a much better operational performance.  Nevertheless, this year's outage days have a negative impact on our Werra volume of about 200,000 tonnes.

texts.text: However, at the beginning of this February, the majority of the Round Table voted that K+S should  completely – stop the discharge of saline waste water into the Werra and its injection underground  from 2020 at the latest. And connected with this is the demand to build up a pipeline to the North  Sea.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen we’re very happy to see so many of our analysts today here in Frankfurt,
texts.text: Together with the states of Hesse and Thuringia and at the Round Table, criteria were developed  which have to be fulfilled in order to implement any project including the pipeline. The project must  be ecologically feasible, reasonable and economically justifiable. A joint political will on the part of  all parties concerned must be present. And the construction and operation of a pipeline and the  discharge of salt solutions must be secured by long-term approvals.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen we’re very happy to see so many of our analysts today here in Frankfurt,
texts.text: Nevertheless, we affirm our commitment to balance ecological, economic and social concerns to an  equal extent, and will therefore continue to work in order to achieve further significant  improvements for the Werra/Weser river system in the medium and long-term.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen we’re very happy to see so many of our analysts today here in Frankfurt,
texts.text: Above all, however, Morton Salt has strengthened our salt business as a part of our two pillar  strategy. As you know, our business basically rests on the two pillars, fertilizers and salt. And in       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen we’re very happy to see so many of our analysts today here in Frankfurt,
texts.text: In addition, we were also able to record volume and structure related improvements. This is true for  the salt business segment, but there are also visible signs of a beginning volume recovery in the  potash business.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen we’re very happy to see so many of our analysts today here in Frankfurt,
texts.text: However, as opposed to that, there were still significant price related revenue decreases in the  fertilizers business segment. The significant decline in potash prices compared with the high level  of the same period a year ago weighted heavily on earnings in the fourth quarter of 2009. This is  also true for the Nitrogen Fertilizer business which was in addition depressed by high input costs.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen we’re very happy to see so many of our analysts today here in Frankfurt,
texts.text: We also saw significant revenue decreases for potash and nitrogen fertilizers of about 477 million  attributable to price factors. Currency-related improvements and the first time inclusion of Morton  Salt from the fourth quarter onwards fell far short of offsetting these two factors.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen we’re very happy to see so many of our analysts today here in Frankfurt,
texts.text: We saw the steepest decrease in both absolute and percentage terms of about 507 million or 30%  in material costs, including goods for trading and external services. This can mainly be explained by  lower trading volumes from nitrogen fertilizers. However the substantial scaling back of output and  our potash plants in response to the exceptional decline in sales volumes last year also resulted in  significant savings on material costs and external services.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen we’re very happy to see so many of our analysts today here in Frankfurt,
texts.text: The adjustments of output to lower sales volumes is also the main reason behind the decline in our  energy costs. Although they also include the costs for Morton Salt for the first time, energy costs  decreased by 42 million or 17%. The freight cost picture is similar. The consolidation related  increase attributable to Morton Salt was more than offset by decreases arising from lower sales  volumes in the fertilizer business, with the result that freight costs were down about 52 million or  12% in total on the previous year.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen we’re very happy to see so many of our analysts today here in Frankfurt,
texts.text: Despite all the savings efforts we do not of course lose sight of the fact that production needs to be  economically efficient and have to take account of work safety and environmental protection  requirements. Given the prudent policy implemented about two thirds of capital expenditures are  used for replacement and continuity of production.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen we’re very happy to see so many of our analysts today here in Frankfurt,
texts.text: This is illustrated by, for example, the ROCE, which, at 9.3% is standalone, not a critical number. It  should be underscored in this regard that the operating returns achieved in 2009 in the Potash and  Magnesium Products as well as in the Salt business segments exceed the cost of capital and only  failed to do so in this level in respect to the Nitrogen Fertilizer business segment.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen we’re very happy to see so many of our analysts today here in Frankfurt,
texts.text: Norbert Steiner, Chairman of the Executive Board  Thank you from my side as well. As announced, a look at 2010, our last slide. The fertilizer  business is tangibly picking up again in terms of volume, even though on a significant lower price  level than just one year ago. And our salt business is once again profiting from a good overall de- icing salt demand in the current year.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen we’re very happy to see so many of our analysts today here in Frankfurt,
texts.text: We also see ourselves as being properly positioned in the medium and the long term. Important  global megatrends continue to remain intact: Global population growth, changes in dietary patterns  in the emerging markets and the greater importance of renewable raw materials should ensure an  increasing demand for fertilizers in the future as well.
